ACCT 217.title: Introductory Financial Accounting
ACCT 217.description: Introduction to accounting for business organizations. Reporting of financial results of operations and financial position to investors, managers, and others. Emphasis on the use of accounting information for decision making.
ACCT 217.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 12 units.

ACCT 301.title: Accounting Principles
ACCT 301.description: Introduction to basic accounting principles and practices. Emphasis is placed on the accounting cycle and the key financial statements necessary for business decisions. Introduces basic financial and managerial accounting concepts.
ACCT 301.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 24 units including Entrepreneurship and Innovation 201.

ACCT 323.title: Introductory Managerial Accounting
ACCT 323.description: An introduction to the use of accounting within an organizational context. Emphasis is placed on the development and dissemination of accounting information necessary for effective management including: planning, directing, motivating, and controlling activities and behaviours.
ACCT 323.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, and Accounting 217.

ACCT 341.title: Intermediate Financial Accounting I
ACCT 341.description: Financial accounting from a producer point of view. Topics include cash, receivables, inventories, short and long-term investments, intangible assets and capital assets including the appropriate financial statement considerations.
ACCT 341.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Accounting 217 and 323.

ACCT 343.title: Intermediate Financial Accounting II
ACCT 343.description: Financial accounting from a producer point of view. Topics include accounting for liabilities, shareholders equity, leases, future income taxes, pensions, accounting changes and earnings per share including the relevant financial statement considerations.
ACCT 343.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Accounting 341.

ACCT 355.title: ESG and Sustainability Reporting
ACCT 355.description: Environmental, social, and governance (ESG) performance is the key to unlocking the power of business today - to build a better tomorrow. Expand your professional opportunities by learning how to measure, analyze, and report on ESG.

ACCT 357.title: Accounting for SMEs
ACCT 357.description: Covers accounting from the perspective of small or medium-sized enterprise (SME) or a new business venture - and investigates the interplay between accounting and informed, strategic decision-making.

ACCT 359.title: Contemporary Topics in Accounting
ACCT 359.description: Examination of selected contemporary topics in accounting.
ACCT 359.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 24 units including Accounting 217 or 301. For certain topics consent of the Haskayne School of Business will also be required.

ACCT 361.title: Cost Accounting
ACCT 361.description: The production of accounting data for the purpose of decision-making, control and evaluation. Topics covered are in the cost classifications and methods of cost establishment, cost data appropriate for decision models, standards and controls.
ACCT 361.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Accounting 323.

ACCT 421.title: Taxation
ACCT 421.description: Taxation levied on profits, sales, property and estates and its impact upon management decisions. Consideration will be given to the biases and shifts implicit in any system of taxation.
ACCT 421.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, and 54 units including Accounting 217.

ACCT 423.title: Advanced Taxation
ACCT 423.description: Focuses on tax planning. Extends the material covered in the introductory tax course with an examination of specialized topics in personal and corporate income tax. Topics include detailed review of taxation of corporations, income trusts, partnerships, business reorganization, amalgamations, winding-up of businesses, sale of an incorporated business, tax consequences of leaving Canada and death of a taxpayer.
ACCT 423.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Accounting 421.

ACCT 425.title: Auditing
ACCT 425.description: A conceptual study of audit evidence, basic audit techniques, professional ethics, audit reports.
ACCT 425.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 54 units including Accounting 341.

ACCT 443.title: Advanced Financial Accounting
ACCT 443.description: Topics include accounting for business combinations and intercorporate investments, foreign currency transactions and translation, bankruptcy, partnerships, and not-for-profit organizations.
ACCT 443.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 54 units including Accounting 343.

ACCT 445.title: Accounting Theory
ACCT 445.description: Examines the origins of financial accounting and current theories on the use of financial accounting information by investors, regulators, standard setters, and other corporate stakeholders.
ACCT 445.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 54 units including Accounting 343.

ACCT 465.title: Managerial Control Systems
ACCT 465.description: Case approach to Management Control Systems explaining the use of accounting data from a managerial perspective. Emphasis is placed on how managers use planning and control to accomplish a firm's strategies.
ACCT 465.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 54 units including Accounting 361.

ACCT 559.title: Selected Topics in Accounting
ACCT 559.description: Investigation of selected topics in Accounting.
ACCT 559.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 54 units including Accounting 343. For certain topics, consent of the Haskayne School of Business will also be required.

ACCT 601.title: Introductory Financial Accounting
ACCT 601.description: Introduction to accounting for business organizations. Reporting of financial results of operations and financial position to investors, managers, and others. Emphasis on the use of accounting information for decision-making.

ACCT 603.title: Management Accounting
ACCT 603.description: Break even analysis, activity-based costing and management, budgeting, productivity measures, and other tools and techniques that are part of a planning and control system that will help the manager make better economic decisions.

ACCT 621.title: Taxation
ACCT 621.description: Discusses the core concepts, regulations, and interpretations underlying the Canadian individual and corporate income taxation. Emphasis is on who is taxable, on what income, when and how tax is calculated. Tax planning opportunities will be identified by using long-term and clientele-based techniques.
ACCT 621.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Accounting 601.

Also known as: (formerly Accounting 721)

ACCT 623.title: Advanced Taxation I
ACCT 623.description: Focuses on tax planning. It extends the material covered in the introductory tax course with an examination of specialized topics in personal and corporate income tax.
ACCT 623.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Accounting 621 or 721.

Also known as: (formerly Accounting 723)

ACCT 641.title: Intermediate Financial Accounting I
ACCT 641.description: Provides detailed coverage of the Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP) primarily related to assets. Emphasizes the theory behind the methods, the strengths and weaknesses of such methods and the need for sound professional judgement.
ACCT 641.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Accounting 601 and 603; or consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

ACCT 642.title: Financial Statement Analysis
ACCT 642.description: Covers the theories, concepts and practices of financial statement analysis with an emphasis placed on applications.
ACCT 642.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Accounting 601.

Also known as: (formerly Accounting 741)

ACCT 643.title: Intermediate Financial Accounting II
ACCT 643.description: Builds on Intermediate Financial Accounting I with coverage of the Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP) primarily related to liabilities and owners' equity. Emphasizes the theory behind the methods, the strengths and weaknesses of methods and the need for sound professional judgment.

ACCT 644.title: Advanced Financial Accounting
ACCT 644.description: Focuses on advanced accounting methods related to inter-corporate investments and financial reporting. Topics include accounting for business combinations and inter-corporate investments, foreign currency transactions and translation, bankruptcy, partnerships, and not-for-profit organizations.
ACCT 644.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Accounting 643.

Also known as: (formerly Accounting 743)

ACCT 645.title: Accounting Theory
ACCT 645.description: Examines the conceptual framework underlying the preparation of financial accounting information, and the theories and propositions on the use of such information by investors, regulators, standard setters, and other corporate stakeholders.
ACCT 645.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Accounting 643.

Also known as: (formerly Accounting 745)

ACCT 646.title: Integrative Accounting I
ACCT 646.description: Integrated application of the technical CPA competencies relating to financial reporting, audit, finance, taxation, and performance management within case scenarios that provide a rich professional context.
ACCT 646.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Master of Business Administration and Accounting 443 or 644.

ACCT 647.title: Advanced Taxation II
ACCT 647.description: Further development of taxation competency by focusing on tax compliance and planning issues for individuals, corporations, trusts and partnerships within case scenarios, which focus on tax implications of business decisions.
ACCT 647.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Master of Business Administration and Accounting 423 or 623.

ACCT 661.title: Cost Accounting
ACCT 661.description: Provides intermediate level discussions to the production and analysis of costs used for pricing, production and investment decisions, revenue analysis, performance evaluation, management incentive systems and strategy analysis.

ACCT 665.title: Managerial Control Systems
ACCT 665.description: Emphasis is placed on how managers use planning and control to accomplish a firm's strategies. Uses a case approach to management control systems explaining the usefulness of accounting data from a managerial perspective.
ACCT 665.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Accounting 661.

Also known as: (formerly Accounting 765)

ACCT 666.title: Auditing
ACCT 666.description: Discusses the techniques and theory behind the external auditor's provision of assurance services on financial information. Topics include: the demand for assurance, the role of auditors in providing assurance, auditor independence, audit reports, and audit liability.
ACCT 666.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Accounting 641.

Also known as: (formerly Accounting 725)

ACCT 667.title: Advanced Auditing
ACCT 667.description: Further development of assurance competencies necessary to perform internal audit projects and external assurance engagements, including assessing needs, developing and performing procedures, and documenting and reporting results for realistic case scenarios.
ACCT 667.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Master of Business Administration and Accounting 425 or 666.

ACCT 668.title: Integrative Accounting II
ACCT 668.description: Integrated application of the CPA competencies of strategy, governance in management accounting within case scenarios that demonstrate how to build control systems and perform financial analysis for different entities.
ACCT 668.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Master of Business Administration and Accounting 465 or 665.

ACCT 669.title: Seminar in Accounting
ACCT 669.description: Development of and solutions to current issues and problems in accounting.
ACCT 669.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Accounting 603 or consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

Also known as: (formerly Accounting 789)

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ACCT 672.title: Financial Accounting Concepts
ACCT 672.description: Introduction to accounting for business organizations emphasizing the use and analysis of financial statements for decision-making purposes.
ACCT 672.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Management (MMgmt) Program.

ACCT 674.title: Managerial Accounting Concepts
ACCT 674.description: Introduction to the use of accounting within an organizational context.  Emphasis is placed on the development and dissemination of accounting information necessary for effective management.
ACCT 674.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Management (MMgmt) Program.

ACCT 797.title: Advanced Seminar in Accounting
ACCT 797.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ACSC 325.title: Theory of Interest/Mathematics of Finance
ACSC 325.description: Measurement of interest, elementary annuities, general annuities, amortization schedules and sinking funds, bonds and other securities.

ACSC 327.title: Life Contingencies I
ACSC 327.description: The survival function, force of mortality, life tables, analytical laws of mortality, life insurance, continuous and discrete life annuities, recursion equations. Introduction to benefit premiums and/or insurance and annuity models with interest as a random variable as time permits.

ACSC 425.title: Intermediate Finance and Investment
ACSC 425.description: Mean-variance portfolio theory, asset pricing models, market efficiency and behavioral finance, investment risk and project analysis, capital structure.

ACSC 427.title: Life Contingencies II
ACSC 427.description: Benefit premiums, premium principles, fully continuous and fully discrete premiums. Benefit reserves and their analysis. Insurance models including expenses. Multiple-state models.
ACSC 427.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Actuarial Science 327; Statistics 323; and 3 units from Mathematics 311, 367 or 375.

ACSC 437.title: Actuarial Models
ACSC 437.description: Basic distributional quantities; characteristics of actuarial models; continuous models; Basic and advanced discrete distributions; frequency and severity with coverage modifications (deductibles, policy limits, coinsurance); aggregate loss models.
ACSC 437.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Statistics 323.

Also known as: (formerly Statistics 437)

ACSC 511.title: (ACSC 611) Generalized Linear Models for Actuaries
ACSC 511.description: Description of insurance data, response distributions, exponential family responses and estimation, GLMs, models for count data, categorical and continuous responses. Applications include: personal injury insurance, vehicle insurance, diabetes deaths, third party claims, and degree of vehicle crash. Software for fitting GLMs will be discussed.

ACSC 513.title: Fundamentals of Actuarial Practice
ACSC 513.description: An introduction to the foundations of actuarial science including the history and development of insurance, the actuarial profession, and the professional societies. Standards of practice and codes of ethics and conduct. An examination of the contexts and environments (including the legal, political, and societal) in which actuarial work takes place. Foundational skills required by actuaries, with an emphasis on communication.

ACSC 515.title: Models for Financial Economics
ACSC 515.description: Survey of financial derivatives, valuation of derivatives using binomial trees, Black-Scholes-Merton equation, dynamic hedging, Brownian motion and Ito's Lemma.

ACSC 517.title: Estimating Unpaid Claims in General Insurance
ACSC 517.description: Data collection, adjusting premiums, trending losses, development triangles, expected method, frequency-severity method, Bornhuetter Ferguson method, Benktander method, Cape Cod method, impact of changing conditions on projection method.

ACSC 519.title: Quantitative Financial Risk Management
ACSC 519.description: Risk measures, correlations and copulas, various approaches to modeling market and credit risk, liquidity risk, enterprise risk management.

ACSC 527.title: Life Contingencies III
ACSC 527.description: Multiple life functions, dependent and independent models, related annuities and insurances. Multiple decrement models: time until and causes of death. Associated single decrement tables. Applications of multiple decrement theory. Asset shares. Business and regulatory considerations.
ACSC 527.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Actuarial Science 327; Statistics 323; 3 units from Mathematics 311, 367 or 375; and 3 units from Computer Science 217, 231, 235 or Data Science 211.

ACSC 531.title: Loss Distributions and Their Estimations
ACSC 531.description: Review of mathematical statistics; estimation based on complete and modified data; frequentist estimation; Bayesian estimation; simulation in actuarial modelling; model selection.
ACSC 531.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Actuarial Science 327; Statistics 323; and 3 units from Mathematics 311, 367 or 375.

ACSC 535.title: Mathematics of Demography
ACSC 535.description: Conventional and adjusted measures of mortality; measures of fertility; measures of morbidity; North American demographic characteristics and trends; evaluation of demographic data; projections for stable and stationary populations; actuarial applications of demographic characteristics and trends.

ACSC 537.title: Credibility Theory
ACSC 537.description: Limited fluctuation credibility; full and partial credibility; greatest accuracy credibility; Bayesian methodology; credibility premium; Buhlmann model; Buhlmann-Straub model; empirical Bayes method; bonus-malus system.
ACSC 537.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Actuarial Science 327; Statistics 323; and 3 units from Mathematics 311, 367 or 375.

ACSC 539.title: Topics in Actuarial Science
ACSC 539.description: Study in advanced topics that may include reading projects, seminars, lectures, term papers and other aspects of training in theory or research methodology.
ACSC 539.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Actuarial Science 327; Statistics 323; and 3 units from Mathematics 311, 367 or 375.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ACSC 602.title: Research Seminar I
ACSC 602.description:
A professional skills course, focusing on the development of technical proficiencies that are essential for students to succeed in their future careers. The emphasis is on delivering professional presentations and using modern actuarial techniques and statistical research tools. Ethics and professionalism are also covered.

Also known as: (formerly Actuarial Science 600) 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

ACSC 604.title: Research Seminar II
ACSC 604.description:
A professional skills course, focusing on the development of technical proficiencies that are essential for students to succeed in their future careers. The emphasis is on delivering professional presentations and using modern actuarial techniques and statistical research tools. Ethics and professionalism are also covered.

Also known as: (formerly Actuarial Science 600) 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

ACSC 611.title: (ACSC 511) Generalized Linear Models for Actuaries
ACSC 611.description: Description of insurance data, response distributions, exponential family responses and estimation, GLMs, models for count data, categorical and continuous responses. Applications include: personal injury insurance, vehicle insurance, diabetes deaths, third party claims, and degree of vehicle crash. Software for fitting GLMs will be discussed.
ACSC 611.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics.

Antirequisite: Credit for Actuarial Science 611 and 511  will not be allowed.

ACSC 617.title: Estimating Unpaid Claims in General Insurance
ACSC 617.description: Data collection, adjusting premiums, trending losses, development triangles, expected method, frequency -severity method, Bornhuetter Ferguson method, Benktander method, Cape Cod method, impact of changing conditions on projection method.
ACSC 617.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics.

ACSC 619.title: Quantitative Financial Risk Management
ACSC 619.description: Risk measures, correlations and copulas, various approaches to modelling market and credit risk, liquidity risk, enterprise risk management.
ACSC 619.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics.

ACSC 627.title: Advanced Life Contingencies
ACSC 627.description: Multiple life functions, dependent and independent models, related annuities and insurances. Multiple decrement models: time until and causes of death. Associated single decrement tables. Applications of multiple decrement theory. Asset shares. Business and regulatory considerations.
ACSC 627.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics.

ACSC 637.title: Credibility Theory
ACSC 637.description: Limited fluctuation credibility; full and partial credibility; greatest accuracy credibility; Bayesian methodology; credibility premium; Buhlmann model; Buhlmann-Straub model; empirical Bayes method; bonus-malus system.
ACSC 637.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics .

ACSC 639.title: Conference Course in Actuarial Modelling
ACSC 639.description:
Topics in advanced actuarial theory and practice, such as: insurance risk models; practical analysis of extreme values; advanced property and casualty rate making; actuarial aspects of financial theory.

Also known as: (formerly Statistics 639)

Note: Credit for Actuarial Science 639 and 539 will not be allowed when they share the same topic and/or with the same decimal course number.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ACWR 201.title: Introduction to Academic Writing
ACWR 201.description: An introduction to academic writing and to the genres of narrative, critical, and essay writing. Emphasis on developing an effective writing process, reading critically, developing arguments, and using and citing sources. Some emphasis on oral presentations may be included.

ACWR 203.title: Introduction to Research Writing
ACWR 203.description: An introduction to inquiry-based research writing, from formulating good research questions to conducting an information search, developing an argument, using sources effectively, and revising and editing. A focus on oral presentations may also be included.

ACWR 303.title: Discipline-based Academic Writing
ACWR 303.description: An intermediate level course in the writing styles, genres and modes of evidence and reasoning appropriate to academic writing in a specific discipline or disciplines. Emphasis on connections between reading, writing, critical reasoning and, where appropriate, other discourse forms such as oral and electronic presentation.

AFST 201.title: Introduction to African Studies
AFST 201.description:
An inter/multidisciplinary study of the African continent, its people, culture and ecology with emphasis on the historic, socio-cultural, economic and political diversity within the continent.

Also known as: (formerly African Studies 301)

AFST 302.title: Anti- Black Racism in North America
AFST 302.description: Critical examination of the concepts and theories of anti-Black racism in North America and the intersections of gender, race, ethnicity, class, culture, politics and power, and privilege and inequality in the context of transnational migration.

AFST 303.title: Critical Contemporary Issues in Africa
AFST 303.description: Analysis of critical issues and themes of contemporary importance, which may include governance and democratization, human rights, resource extraction (e.g., energy, mining) and the environment, democratization, poverty and inequality, health, social movements, conflict, migration and refugees, and the continent's dynamic and changing relations with the world.

AFST 305.title: Introduction to African/Black Diaspora
AFST 305.description: An inter/multidisciplinary examination of the evolution, and the diverse histories, cultures, identities, experiences and contribution of African/Black Transnational/Diaspora communities worldwide (e.g., African transnational, Black/African Diaspora in the Americas, Caribbean, Europe, Middle East and Asia.

AFST 399.title: Topics with Regional Focus
AFST 399.description:
Topics focused on contemporary African culture with a regional focus, which could include the Horn of Africa, the Great Lakes Region of Africa, North Africa, Central and Southern Africa, and West Africa.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT.

AFST 400.title: Field Study in Africa
AFST 400.description: A field course for interdisciplinary study of a country or region of Africa, emphasizing the geographical, archaeological, historical, cultural, political, economic and artistic aspects.
AFST 400.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Program Co-ordinator.

AFST 401.title: Topics in African Studies
AFST 401.description: Interdisciplinary course on topics within the field of African Studies.
AFST 401.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units from the Field of African Studies.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

AFST 407.title: Topics in African and African Transnational Studies
AFST 407.description: An in-depth investigation of topics in African Diaspora and Transnationalism. Topics and content in any given year varies and depends on the instructor.
AFST 407.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units from the Field of African Studies. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

AFST 501.title: Capstone Seminar in African Studies
AFST 501.description: Study of a particular topic(s) or region(s) from an interdisciplinary and comparative perspective. Students will be required to examine how political, social, economic and cultural factors intersect to shape various issues in the African setting.
AFST 501.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 60 units including African Studies 201; and 3 units from courses labelled African Studies (AFST), Anthropology 320, Political Science 371, 471, History 397.01, 402, 573.

ALMC 202.title: Beginners' Arabic I
ALMC 202.description: A comprehensive course for students with no prior knowledge of the language. Includes training in listening, speaking, reading and writing of Modern Standard Arabic in its cultural context.
ALMC 202.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

ALMC 204.title: Beginners' Arabic II
ALMC 204.description: Continuation of Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures 202.
ALMC 204.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures 202.

ALMC 301.title: Continuing Arabic I
ALMC 301.description: A comprehensive course that includes further training in listening, speaking, reading and writing Modern Standard Arabic in its cultural context. Development of increased sophistication in language production and cultural understanding.
ALMC 301.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures 204.

ALMC 303.title: Continuing Arabic II
ALMC 303.description: A continuation of Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures 301.
ALMC 303.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures 301.

ALMC 309.title: Arabic Culture in an Immersion Setting
ALMC 309.description: Introduction to contemporary Arabic culture through research projects and life experience in an Arabic-speaking country.
ALMC 309.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures 204.

ALMC 311.title: Modern Standard Arabic Language
ALMC 311.description: Stresses oral skills and cultural understanding in an immersion setting in an Arabic-speaking country. While the focus will be on speaking and aural comprehension, reading and writing will also be covered.
ALMC 311.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures 204.

ALMC 317.title: Muslim Civilization I
ALMC 317.description: Comparative study of Muslim civilization from Africa, the Arab and Persianate world, Asia and the West up to the end of the 18th century.

ALMC 319.title: Topics in Muslim Civilization II
ALMC 319.description:
Comparative study of Muslim civilization from Africa, the Arab and Persianate world, Asia, and the West focusing on the developments of the nineteenth, twentieth and twenty-first centuries.

Notes: Taught in English. May be repeated for a maximum credit of 9 units. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ALMC 331.title: Intermediate Arabic I
ALMC 331.description: A comprehensive course that increases the command of the structure of modern standard Arabic through reading materials; develops reading and writing skills and comprehension. Development of increased sophistication in language production and cultural understanding.
ALMC 331.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures 303.

ALMC 334.title: Topics in Intermediate Arabic II
ALMC 334.description: Increases reading, writing, listening, and speaking skills in Modern Standard Arabic through the study of a given topic. Topics may include Arabic news media, literature, and historical texts. A continuation of Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures 331.
ALMC 334.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures 331.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ALMC 343.title: Topics in Colloquial Spoken Arabic I
ALMC 343.description: Introduction to the everyday spoken language used in a particular Arabic-speaking country or region. Spoken varieties of Arabic taught may include Egyptian, Levantine, Gulf Varieties, and North African.
ALMC 343.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures 204.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ALMC 345.title: Topics in Colloquial Spoken Arabic II
ALMC 345.description: A continuation of the everyday spoken language used in a particular Arabic-speaking country or region. Spoken varieties of Arabic taught may include Egyptian, Levantine, Gulf Varieties, and North African.
ALMC 345.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): The corresponding language in Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures 343.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ALMC 354.title: Topics in Arabic Language and Linguistics
ALMC 354.description: Exploration of aspects of the Arabic language through classical and modern sources. Topics may include the history of the Arabic language, Arabic in Muslim contexts, the varieties of Arabic, Arabic linguistics, and the grammatical tradition.
ALMC 354.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures 204.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ALMC 358.title: Topics in Cinema of Muslim Societies
ALMC 358.description:
Exploration of the diversity of national and regional cinemas in predominantly Muslim societies of the world.

Notes: Taught in English.

Also known as: (formerly Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures 357)

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ALMC 360.title: Topics in Muslim Literatures
ALMC 360.description:
Study of literary texts within the context of the rich, diverse traditions and cultures of predominantly Muslim societies of the world.

Notes: Taught in English.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ALMC 413.title: Reading Classical Arabic
ALMC 413.description: An introduction to Arabic texts, grammar and syntax through readings of classical sources.
ALMC 413.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures 301. 

Also known as: (formerly Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures 313)

ALMC 430.title: Directed Studies in Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures
ALMC 430.description: Topics may include textual traditions, cultural patterns, historical periods, or social movements in the field of Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures.
ALMC 430.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ALMC 499.title: Topics in the Study of Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures
ALMC 499.description: Study of topics in the fields of Arabic language, literature, or culture, or Muslim cultures.
ALMC 499.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s):  3 units in a course labelled Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures at the 300 level or above.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ANME 301.title: Ancient Near East I: Sumerians to Hittites
ANME 301.description:
An introduction to the history and culture of the Near East, from the origins of civilization in Mesopotamia to the Bronze Age collapse.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Ancient and Medieval History 301 and Greek and Roman Studies 335 will not be allowed.

ANME 302.title: Ancient Near East II:  Assyrians to Alexander the Great
ANME 302.description:
An introduction to the history and culture of the Near East, from the Bronze Age collapse to the conquest of Alexander the Great.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Ancient and Medieval History 302 and Greek and Roman Studies 335 will not be allowed.

ANME 303.title: Byzantine History
ANME 303.description:
The history of Byzantine society from its beginnings in the 3rd century to the fall of Constantinople in 1453.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Ancient and Medieval History 303 and Greek and Roman Studies 347 will not be allowed.

ANME 304.title: Cervantes and the Early Modern World
ANME 304.description: Addresses Miguel de Cervantes's interactions with the historical issues of the early modern world through his literary texts.

ANME 305.title: Premodern Christianity
ANME 305.description: Examines key figures, practices, and events between 800-1600 CE. Topics include popes, interfaith relations, Protestant and Catholic Reforms, Christianity in Asia and the New World.

ANME 401.title: The Camino de Santiago
ANME 401.description:
Examines the Christian pilgrimage to Santiago de Compostela, Spain, popularly known as the Camino de Santiago, in history and as currently practised.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Ancient and Medieval History 401 and Religious Studies 484.10 will not be allowed.

ANTH 201.title: Introduction to Biological Anthropology
ANTH 201.description:
Introduction to the major fields of biological anthropology including evolutionary theory and processes, human paleontology, primatology, genetics, osteology, human adaptation, development, and variation, with special emphasis on the path of human evolution.

Antirequisite(s):  Credit for Anthropology 201 and Archaeology 203 will not be allowed.

ANTH 203.title: Introduction to Social and Cultural Anthropology
ANTH 203.description: Introduction to the study of human society and culture with the focus on major institutions (such as politics, economics, religion, kinship, and gender), operating on both local and global scales.

ANTH 303.title: Business in Cultural Context
ANTH 303.description: Ways in which differences in cultural values and practices affect the form and nature of interaction between business parties, especially those of differing national/cultural/ethnic backgrounds.

ANTH 305.title: Human Variation and Adaptation
ANTH 305.description: Some of the major problems involved in interpreting modern and recent human diversity. Emphasis on the interaction between human cultural and biological systems and on cultural influences upon human biological diversity.
ANTH 305.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Anthropology 201, Archaeology 203, Biology 211, 213, 241, 205.

ANTH 308.title: Roots of the Anthropocene
ANTH 308.description:
Examines relationships between humans and earth systems from the combined perspectives of anthropology, archaeology, and paleoecology. Focuses on the long term, and specifically on contexts where the actions of past communities structure environmental processes that we take for granted in the present as "natural".

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Anthropology 308 and 399.08 (Roots of the Anthropocene) will not be allowed.

ANTH 309.title: Human Evolution
ANTH 309.description: Investigation of the major phases of human evolution, with an emphasis on understanding how, when and why specific adaptations evolved. In laboratories, students learn to reconstruct behaviour from anatomical and palaeontological evidence.

ANTH 311.title: Primate Behaviour
ANTH 311.description: Primate behaviour and related topics, including social dynamics, sociobiology, socio-ecology, dominance, aggression, kinship, sexual behaviour, socialization, learning, cognition, communication, ape language, and conservation.

ANTH 313.title: Anthropology of the Environment
ANTH 313.description: Cross-cultural perspectives on human-environment relationships and application to contemporary problems concerning conservation, resource management and environmentalism.
ANTH 313.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Anthropology 203.

Also known as: (formerly Anthropology 399.03 Environment and Culture)

ANTH 320.title: Ethnographic Overview of Africa
ANTH 320.description: Ethnographic survey of the peoples of Africa and historical analysis of their incorporation within the contemporary nation states of the continent.
ANTH 320.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Anthropology 203. 

Antirequisites: Credit for Anthropology 320 and 317 or 319 will not be allowed.

ANTH 321.title: Ethnographic Overview of Latin America
ANTH 321.description: A survey of cultural traditions of Mexico, the Caribbean, and Central and South America as they have evolved since the 16th century.

ANTH 329.title: Topics in Ethnographic Overview of Selected World Areas
ANTH 329.description: Selected topics in the anthropology of world areas.
ANTH 329.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Anthropology 203.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ANTH 331.title: Sex and Gender
ANTH 331.description: Cross-species and cross-cultural perspective on sex and gender.

ANTH 341.title: Medical Anthropology
ANTH 341.description: A survey of anthropological approaches to disease, illness and the maintenance of health.

ANTH 346.title: Development of Indigenous-Settler Relations in Canada
ANTH 346.description:
An exploration of Indigenous-Settler relations in Canada from first contact to present, including the development of Indian policy, the Indian Act, treaties, residential schools, and Sixties Scoop.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Anthropology 213 and 346 will not be allowed.

Also known as: (formerly Anthropology 210)

ANTH 350.title: Laboratory Practice in Biological Anthropology
ANTH 350.description: Examines the basic concepts and methods of biological anthropology using an experiential learning model. Coverage includes genetics, osteology, primatology, paleoanthropology, and human biology with a strong emphasis on the role of evolutionary theory throughout.
ANTH 350.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Anthropology 201 and admission to the BSc Anthropology or BSc Archaeology major or Honours programs.

ANTH 355.title: Indigenous Peoples of Canada
ANTH 355.description: A critical overview of the historical, social, political, economic, environmental, and cultural contexts related to health, justice, education, gender, traditional practices, and identity of Indigenous Peoples, Nations, cultures, and organizations across Canada.

ANTH 357.title: Anthropology of Development
ANTH 357.description: Cultural dimensions of local and international development policy, programming, and evaluation.
ANTH 357.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Anthropology 203, Development Studies 201, Indigenous Studies 201.

ANTH 361.title: History of Anthropology
ANTH 361.description: Historical survey of anthropological thought from the enlightenment to the present.

ANTH 363.title: Magic, Witchcraft, and Gods: Anthropology of Religion
ANTH 363.description: Contemporary anthropological theoretical perspectives on topics such as divination, ritual, witchcraft, magic and symbolism in both Indigenous and world religions. The relationship of religion to healing, gender and power is also examined.

ANTH 371.title: Political Anthropology
ANTH 371.description: Critical analysis of political structures and processes that illuminate connections between culture, politics, and economics.

ANTH 393.title: Anthropology of Global Systems
ANTH 393.description: Investigates the complex relationship between the global and the local by examining the social, cultural, economic, and political changes in specific localities as a result of the global rise of capitalism. Special attention is paid to how local-global connections are made, and the movement of people, goods, and ideas.

ANTH 395.title: Anthropology of Science
ANTH 395.description: An introduction to the culture and the politics of science. Examines conceptual and daily practices in the laboratory, the scientific method, the training of scientists, the work of scientific collaboration and the intersection between scientists and wider political, racial, gendered and religious issues. Special consideration will be given to the anthropology of scientific controversy.
ANTH 395.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Anthropology 203.

Also known as: (formerly Anthropology 399.06 Anthropology of Science)

ANTH 399.title: Topics in Anthropology
ANTH 399.description:
Examination of select problems in Anthropology. Topics may be drawn from all subfields in the discipline.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ANTH 400.title: Individual Supervised Study
ANTH 400.description: An independent study course for Anthropology majors under the supervision of a faculty member.
ANTH 400.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BA or BSc Anthropology and consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ANTH 408.title: Topics in Social and Cultural Anthropology
ANTH 408.description: Examination of select topics in social and cultural anthropology.
ANTH 408.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Anthropology 203 and 3 units of courses labeled Anthropology at the 300-level or above.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ANTH 409.title: Topics in Biological Anthropology
ANTH 409.description: Examination of select topics in biological anthropology.
ANTH 409.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Anthropology 201 and 3 units of courses labeled Anthropology at the 300-level or above.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ANTH 410.title: Contemporary Indigenous Affairs in Canada
ANTH 410.description: Investigation of current affairs related to First Nations, Mtis and Inuit peoples, communities and Nations, including an examination of the historical, social, political, cultural and economic contexts of racism, colonialism and Indigenous strengths, resistance and resurgence.
ANTH 410.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Anthropology 210, 213, 346, 355 or courses labelled Indigenous Studies.

Also known as: (formerly Anthropology 310)

ANTH 411.title: Methods and Analysis for Socio-Cultural Anthropology
ANTH 411.description:
An introduction to research design, data collection, and analysis as used in anthropology. Cross-cultural research design and methods, use of participant observation and personal documents will be emphasized.

Prerequisite or Corequisite(s): Anthropology 490.

ANTH 412.title: The Primate Fossil Record
ANTH 412.description: A review of the evolution of the primates, covering the morphological and taxonomic diversity of fossil primates, environmental and chronological context for primate evolution, and current debates and problems in the field of primate evolution. In class laboratories focus on the diversity of primate dietary, locomotor, and social adaptations, and how these are inferred from the fossil record.

ANTH 413.title: Methods in Primatology
ANTH 413.description: Focus on observational methods and analysis, with practical application in laboratory study at the Calgary Zoo.

ANTH 421.title: Contemporary Latin American Society
ANTH 421.description: An examination of selected issues in the anthropological study of contemporary Latin America.

ANTH 425.title: Primate Cognition
ANTH 425.description: Causes and consequences of primate sociality, such as brain structure and evolution, kin recognition, Theory of Mind, social perception and awareness, and similarities and differences in communication and cognition between human and non-human primates.

ANTH 435.title: Perspectives on Evolution and Human Behaviour
ANTH 435.description: Investigation of various perspectives on humans' place in nature and evolutionary approaches to understanding human behaviour.

ANTH 441.title: Problems in the Anthropology of Health
ANTH 441.description: An examination of selected problems in the anthropology of health. Topics may include models of health in Canada, etiological claims in health research, and anthropology of pharmaceuticals.

ANTH 445.title: Ecology and Behaviour of Small-Scale Human Societies
ANTH 445.description: Survey of the ethnographic record of small-scale societies from a biocultural and evolutionary perspective. Topics include energy systems, subsistence, social organization, learning, psychology, institutions, kinship structures, aggression and warfare, exchange, and interactions between state and non-state societies.
ANTH 445.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Anthropology 201 and 305.

Also known as: (formerly Anthropology 505.07 Small-Scale Societies)

ANTH 449.title: Anthropology of HIV/AIDS
ANTH 449.description: Examines the individual, clinical, epidemiological, cultural, social, psychological, political, economic, and public policy dimensions of HIV/AIDS along with its meaning and importance on a global level from an anthropological perspective.
ANTH 449.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Anthropology 341.

Also known as: (formerly Anthropology 349)

ANTH 451.title: Primate Ecology and Conservation
ANTH 451.description: An exploration of conservation challenges for nonhuman primates including how primates interact with their environments, the causes for population declines, and the strategies to reduce the threats to their survival.

ANTH 466.title: Disaster Studies
ANTH 466.description: Examines disasters in the Anthropocene with the goal of assessing human and environmental vulnerability, risk perception, and risk mitigation across cultures and political realms.
ANTH 466.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Anthropology 203 and 3 units in courses labelled Anthropology at the 300-level or above.

Also known as: (formerly Anthropology 399.15 Disaster Studies)

ANTH 490.title: Anthropological Theory
ANTH 490.description: Examination of the fundamentals of anthropological theory through key concepts in anthropology since the nineteenth century, such as race, history, society, function, structure, gender and representation.

ANTH 501.title: Advanced Topics in Social and Cultural Anthropology
ANTH 501.description: A seminar on a selected topic of social and cultural anthropology.
ANTH 501.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Anthropology 203, an additional 3 units of a course labelled Anthropology at the 300 level or above and consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ANTH 505.title: Advanced Topics in Biological Anthropology
ANTH 505.description: A seminar on a selected topic of biological anthropology.
ANTH 505.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Anthropology 201 and consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ANTH 506.title: Anthropological Genetics
ANTH 506.description: Examines the principles of evolutionary genetics with a focus on applications to current topics in Anthropology such as behaviour, life history, adaptation, migration and disease. Explores the contents of the primate genome as well as human and non-human primate genetic variation in an evolutionary framework.
ANTH 506.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 60 units including Anthropology 350.

Also known as: (formerly Anthropology 505.13 Anthropological Genetics)

ANTH 523.title: Human Ecology
ANTH 523.description: Current directions in various subfields of human ecology as they apply to Anthropology, Archaeology, and Geography.

ANTH 534.title: Biological Anthropology Perspectives on Health
ANTH 534.description: The biocultural study of human health among contemporary and past populations via cross-cultural studies of health and healing, child growth and development, reproductive health, aging, infectious disease, immune function, and the impact of stress on physical and mental health.
ANTH 534.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Anthropology 201 and 305.

Also known as: (formerly Anthropology 533.92 Bioanthropology and Health)

ANTH 541.title: Field Study in Social and Cultural Anthropology
ANTH 541.description: Research projects under the supervision of a member of academic staff.

ANTH 552.title: Field Studies: Topics in Primatology
ANTH 552.description: Intensive training and practice in field methods of observational primate behaviour or behavioural ecology.
ANTH 552.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Anthropology 413 and consent of the Department.

ANTH 553.title: Field Study: Primate Behavioural Research Design
ANTH 553.description: Design of a research project, including the identification and operationalization of a research question and the collection and analysis of data.

ANTH 573.title: Honours Seminar in Social and Cultural Anthropology
ANTH 573.description: Current theoretical and methodological issues will be explored in a discussion-based seminar format, with the possibility of development of a research project.
ANTH 573.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Anthropology 411 and admission to the Anthropology Honours Program.

ANTH 589.title: Nutritional Anthropology
ANTH 589.description: The study of human dietary practices from biological and cultural perspectives. Subjects covered include the development of nutritional anthropology, principles of nutrition, principles of ecology, diet from an evolutionary, comparative and historic perspective, the impact of undernutrition on human physiology, and behaviour and methods in nutritional anthropology.

ANTH 590.title: Honours Thesis in Anthropology
ANTH 590.description: Research project under the direction of a member of the Department.
ANTH 590.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Anthropology Honours program.

ANTH 601.title: Conference Course in Anthropology
ANTH 601.description:
A specialized area of Anthropology selected on the basis of particular interest and need.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ANTH 603.title: Thesis Development
ANTH 603.description:
A reading and conference course in the student's substantive area conducted jointly by at least two faculty members.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ANTH 605.title: Prof Skills For Anthropologists
ANTH 605.description:
Training and practice in research/teaching skills: grantsmanship, conference and classroom presentations, academic publishing, job interviews.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Anthropology 605 and 601.90 will not be allowed.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

ANTH 611.title: Ethnographic Research
ANTH 611.description: Seminar focused on ethnographic methodology as the foundation of anthropological research.

ANTH 613.title: Current Issues in Methodology in Biological Anthropology
ANTH 613.description:
A variety of topics relating to aspects of data collection and data analysis in biological anthropology, with a focus on research design for hypothesis-testing in current research. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ANTH 631.title: Theory in Anthropological Research
ANTH 631.description: An in-depth examination of the main theoretical currents relevant for research in social and cultural anthropology.

ANTH 635.title: Primatological Theory
ANTH 635.description: Seminar dealing with the theoretical material of primatological and biobehavioural perspectives in Anthropology.

ANTH 641.title: Seminar in Civil-Military Relations
ANTH 641.description: Comparative analysis of relations between civil society and military institutions. A critical approach to analyzing how civil and military institutions mutually constitute each other, rather than taking the military and civilian sectors as a given. Special attention will be paid to twentieth century militarization as a social process that has dramatically changed the shape of both civilian and military spheres.

ANTH 701.title: Independent Studies
ANTH 701.description:
Designed to allow PhD students to explore specific topics in anthropology beyond the standard curriculum.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

APLA 580.title: Special Topics in Architecture, Planning and Landscape Architecture
APLA 580.description:
Thematic inquiry and design related to special topics in architecture, planning and landscape architecture. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

APLA 582.title: Special Topics in Architecture, Planning and Landscape Architecture
APLA 582.description:
Thematic inquiry and design related to special topics in architecture, planning and landscape architecture. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

APLA 584.title: Special Topics in Architecture, Planning and Landscape Architecture
APLA 584.description:
Thematic inquiry and design related to special topics in architecture, planning and landscape architecture. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

APLA 586.title: Special Topics in Architecture, Planning and Landscape Architecture
APLA 586.description:
Thematic inquiry and design related to special topics in architecture, planning and landscape architecture. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

APLA 670.title: Design Research Methods
APLA 670.description: An introductory overview to the variety of research strategies, methods and project-based inquiries pursued in the professional design disciplines of architecture, planning and landscape architecture. Design research requires creative and critical thinking in the pursuit of inquires as to how we shape our world, recognizing the intense complexities and emerging challenges to be addressed in the creation of buildings, cities, and landscapes.

APLA 672.title: Design Research Writing
APLA 672.description: Knowledge translation, written communication and dissemination are key skills for design researchers. Addresses effective writing approaches in the development of research proposals, research abstracts, conference presentations, research paper submissions for peer review, and thesis documentation.

APLA 674.title: Design Innovation
APLA 674.description: Examines theories, precedents and strategies at the heart of novel and innovative design research, design responses, and approaches to design practice. Introduces design entrepreneurship and innovation skills crucial to advancing the impact of design research and its far-reaching implications within the built environment.

APLA 680.title: Design Practice Research Project Definition
APLA 680.description:
Introduction to practice-based research in the design fields. Explores the differences between first professional degree training, traditional PhD research, and design-based creative practice research.  Students will define their doctoral research question through a critical interrogation of their existing professional expertise and experience through self-reflexive study and design thinking diagramming. Students will explore their research intent, the problem space for that intent, and diverse design practice contexts, including precedents, social, political, economic and cultural contexts, and communities of practice in defining their main research question.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

APLA 681.title: Design Practice Research Symposium
APLA 681.description:
Recurring symposium course where students have a forum to present and discuss progress in their DDes practice based research. 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

APLA 682.title: Strategies for Design Practice Research I
APLA 682.description:
Explores strategies for conducting practice-based research in the design disciplines. Design Science Research methods are used to refine the research question and develop practice-based research strategies and benchmarks within the context of an active professional practice. Research ethics are introduced, and students will develop their ethics application for certification. Emphasis is on the relationship between doctoral research activities and the student's professional practice, explored within the student's research project. Students will develop their doctoral research proposal and work plan.

Prerequisite: Architecture, Planning and Landscape 680.


NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

APLA 685.title: Strategies for Design Practice Research II
APLA 685.description: Expands on the Design Science Research methodology as applied in practice-based research. Students will complete their doctoral research proposal, work plan, and ethics application in advance of preparation for candidacy field of study examinations.
APLA 685.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Architecture, Planning and Landscape 682.

Also known as: (formerly Architecture, Planning and Landscape 684)

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

APLA 690.title: Topics Course in Architecture, Planning and Landscape Architecture
APLA 690.description:
Thematic inquiry and design related to special topics in architecture, planning and landscape architecture.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

APLA 692.title: Topics Course in Architecture, Planning and Landscape Architecture
APLA 692.description:
Thematic inquiry and design related to special topics in architecture, planning and landscape architecture.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

APLA 694.title: Topics Course in Architecture, Planning and Landscape Architecture
APLA 694.description:
Thematic inquiry and design related to special topics in architecture, planning and landscape architecture.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

APLA 696.title: Topics Course in Architecture, Planning and Landscape Architecture
APLA 696.description:
Thematic inquiry and design related to special topics in architecture, planning and landscape architecture.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

APLA 790.title: Directed Study in Architecture, Planning and Landscape I
APLA 790.description: Thematic inquiry, research, readings and design related to Architecture, Planning and Landscape design topics.
APLA 790.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School of Architecture, Planning and Landscape.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

APLA 792.title: Directed Study in Architecture, Planning and Landscape II
APLA 792.description: Thematic inquiry, research, readings and design related to Architecture, Planning and Landscape design topics.
APLA 792.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School of Architecture, Planning and Landscape.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ARCH 201.title: Architecture and the Future of Cities
ARCH 201.description:
An introduction to architecture as a creative and technical endeavor that shapes the spaces and places in which we live. An examination of the purposes, intentions, processes, and products of architecture and how they can positively impact climate change, social equity, and quality of life. Students will develop an understanding of the social, cultural, historical, technological, economic, and natural contexts influencing the design of buildings and cities. 

Also known as: (formerly Architectural Studies 201)

ARCH 400.title: Introduction to Architecture, Planning and Landscape Architecture
ARCH 400.description:
An examination of the central concepts of architecture, planning and landscape architecture delivered in an online format. 

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design 401)

ARCH 402.title: Design, Digital Technology and the Built Environment
ARCH 402.description:
An introduction to the fundamental principles underlying modern digital technology-based systems, from a design of the built environment perspective. Topics include The Attention Economy, Big Data, Surveillance Capitalism, Ambient Intelligence, the Internet of Things, Opaque and Transparent Algorithms, Biocreepiness, and Systems Thinking. No specific technical background is required. Participants will complete a design project on a topic of personal interest.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design 402)

ARCH 404.title: Architecture and Life Cycle Thinking: Climate Change and Beyond
ARCH 404.description: An introduction to strategies for comparing building and product performance in relation to environmental impacts and contributions to climate change. Concepts of circular economy, life cycle analysis, embedded energy, recycling/reuse of building materials are explored through the lenses of resource depletion, carbon and water footprints and waste generation.
ARCH 404.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Architecture 201 or Architectural Studies 201.

Also known as: (formerly Architectural Studies 421)

ARCH 406.title: Design Thinking in the Built Environment Studio I
ARCH 406.description: A foundational introduction to design thinking as applied to the built environment of buildings, cities, and landscapes. Students will complete a series of experiential learning exercises that emphasize three-dimensional thinking and problem-solving skills. The course is offered in a studio environment, which along with the course-work, will provide valuable experience to develop a portfolio.

ARCH 408.title: Design Thinking in the Built Environment Studio II
ARCH 408.description: A capstone project-based course that builds on the skills acquired in Architectural Studies 431. Students will work in small groups to develop, research, execute, and present a small design thinking project based in Calgary. The course is offered in a studio environment.
ARCH 408.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Architecture 406 or Architectural Studies 431.

Also known as: (formerly Architectural Studies 441)

ARCH 500.title: Sustainability in the Built Environment
ARCH 500.description: The principle of sustainability recognizes people as temporary stewards of their environments, working toward a respect for natural systems and a higher quality of life. Examination of the built environment and the tools to achieve a stable and balanced and a regenerative ecosystem in a process of responsible consumption, wherein waste is minimized and the built environment interacts with natural environments and cycles. Healthful interior environments, resource efficiency, ecologically benign materials, renewable energies and social justice issues are examined.
ARCH 500.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Minor in Architectural Studies or the Master of Architecture Programs.

Also known as: (formerly Architectural Studies 423 and Environmental Design 523)

ARCH 502.title: History of Architecture and Human Settlements I - Premodern Traditions of the World
ARCH 502.description: A survey history of architecture and human settlement addressing the premodern traditions of the major world cultures. The course will examine the changes in world view that have altered the course of architecture through the study of selected works of architecture and urbanism.
ARCH 502.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Minor in Architectural Studies or the Master of Architecture Programs.

Also known as: (formerly Architectural Studies 457.01 and Environmental Design Architecture 523.01)

ARCH 504.title: Graphics Workshop I
ARCH 504.description: A skill building course with instruction and supervised experience in basic drafting, sketching and rendering; principles of perspective, drawing and presentation conventions. A variety of instruction may be offered to accommodate the varied level of student development.
ARCH 504.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Minor in Architectural Studies or the Master of Architecture Programs.

ARCH 506.title: Studio I in Architecture
ARCH 506.description: A studio that explores the foundation concepts in architectural design and form making involving a sequence of progress skill building, visual and spatial thinking and problem-solving exercises.
ARCH 506.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Minor in Architectural Studies or the Master of Architecture Programs.

ARCH 508.title: Building Science and Technology I
ARCH 508.description: Functioning of the building enclosure: demonstration of the behaviour of building elements and their sub-assemblies under differential temperature and pressure stresses; fundamentals of acoustics; nature and use of building materials; response of building materials to climatic cycles radiation, precipitation, heating and cooling.
ARCH 508.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Minor in Architectural Studies or the Master of Architecture Programs.

ARCH 510.title: History of Architecture and Human Settlements II - The Rise of Modernity, 1750 to Present
ARCH 510.description: A survey history of architecture and human settlement exploring the traditions of the Western world from the beginning of the Italian Renaissance until the present. The courses will examine the changes in world view that have altered the course of architecture through the study of selected works of architecture and urbanism.
ARCH 510.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Minor in Architectural Studies or the Master of Architecture Programs.

Also known as: (formerly Architectural Studies 457.02 and Environmental Design Architecture 523.02)

ARCH 512.title: Graphics Workshop II
ARCH 512.description: Instruction and supervised experience in drafting, sketching and rendering; drawing and presentation conventions. Builds on Architecture 504. A variety of instruction may be offered to accommodate the varied level of student development.
ARCH 512.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Architecture 504, 506 and admission to the Minor in Architectural Studies or the Master of Architecture Programs.

ARCH 514.title: Studio II in Architecture
ARCH 514.description: A studio exploring the application of ordering principles of architecture and to the numerous layers that contributes to the quality of inhabitation of place and space through design. Issues explored include the formal, the experiential and the theoretical concerns of architectural design in today's cultural context.
ARCH 514.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Architecture 504, 506 and admission to the Minor in Architectural Studies or the Master of Architecture Programs.

ARCH 600.title: Structures for Architects I
ARCH 600.description:
Fundamentals of Structural Analysis including the characteristics and performance of the various components of structures; the terminology and notation necessary for effective teamwork with structural engineering consultants; and basic design calculations for simple structures.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design Architecture 613)

ARCH 602.title: Introduction to Design Theories
ARCH 602.description:
The contemporary cultural, social, and philosophical arenas in which architecture exists are examined through lectures, readings and seminars.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design Architecture 621)

ARCH 604.title: Leadership in Architecture
ARCH 604.description:
The practice of architecture deals with complex design requirements, diverse groups of people, changing processes, evolving contexts, and a range of modes of production. This course introduces students to a broad set of contemporary themes around the concept of leadership and architecture.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design Architecture 665)

ARCH 606.title: Intermediate Architectural Design Studio
ARCH 606.description: An intermediate design studio in which students work on projects defined by the instructor. Topics may vary from year to year. They are determined by the creative interests of the faculty assigned to the course.
ARCH 606.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Architecture 514.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design Architecture 682.02)

ARCH 608.title: Architectural Lighting Design
ARCH 608.description:
Fundamentals of light and visual perception. Approaches to the design of non-uniform and uniform lighting systems for buildings. Issues in system design such as human satisfaction, performance, and energy efficiency. Development of skills in the selection and design of lighting systems.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design Architecture 617)

ARCH 610.title: Structures for Architects II
ARCH 610.description: Advanced structural systems for buildings including: structural connections and composite structures; system characteristics and architectural intent; and case studies in contemporary building structures.
ARCH 610.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Architecture 600

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design Architecture 619)

ARCH 612.title: Building Science and Technology II
ARCH 612.description:
Theory and principles of structural, foundation and building service systems. Application of building science principles to building structure and enclosure, examination of the types and manufacture of building elements and the application of building components to specific problems in architecture.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design Architecture 611)

ARCH 614.title: Environmental Control Systems
ARCH 614.description:
Approaches to the design of heating, cooling, and ventilation systems for buildings. Issues in system design such as energy efficiency and indoor air quality.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design Architecture 615)

ARCH 616.title: Comprehensive Architectural Design Studio
ARCH 616.description: A comprehensive design studio in which students work on projects defined by the creative interests of the instructor.
ARCH 616.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Architecture 606 or Environmental Design Architecture 682.02.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design Architecture 682.04)

ARCH 618.title: Architectural Professional Practice
ARCH 618.description:
The nature of the building industry, stakeholders and many of the participants and their responsibilities. Brings together the theoretical framework of the architect's role in society with the practicality of managing a practice. Project management and office administration, trends, liabilities and systems for project control such as building economics; cost analysis and estimating techniques; and cost controls during design and construction.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design Architecture 661)

ARCH 670.title: Experiential Learning in Architecture
ARCH 670.description:
Thematic inquiry and design contextualized by experiential learning in landscape architecture.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ARCH 672.title: Experiential Learning in Architecture
ARCH 672.description:
Thematic inquiry and design contextualized by experiential learning in architecture.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ARCH 674.title: Experiential Learning in Architecture
ARCH 674.description:
Thematic inquiry and design contextualized by experiential learning in architecture.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

ARCH 675.title: Urban Systems
ARCH 675.description: Provides a general overview of urban history, development and planning traditions. Lectures and field studies give a chronological overview of urban, architectural and design history and the inter-relation to political programs, economic and strategic planning as well as cultural nationalism. Extracts a number of more general issues about contemporary cities for debate.
ARCH 675.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Architecture, Master of Planning or Master of Landscape Architecture program.

ARCH 676.title: Experiential Learning in Architecture
ARCH 676.description:
Thematic inquiry and design contextualized by experiential learning in architecture.

ARCH 680.description:

ARCH 688.description:
Thematic inquiry and design related to urban environments and issues.

Corequisite(s): Architecture 675.

ARCH 690.title: Studio Research Selective
ARCH 690.description:
Provides additional expertise in an area of focus to support the work students complete in research studios. Topics and themes vary but include; Design Responses to Climate Change, Energy Performance, Historical Precedents and Theories, Designing for Social Equity and Inclusion, Life Cycle Analysis, Digital Fabrication, Simulation and Communication Techniques.

ARCH 692.title: Gillmor Theory Seminar
ARCH 692.description:
Explores architectural history and theory as the context for the production of architecture and its artifacts. Students work with a visiting lecturer to develop design responses within a provided theoretical framework. Outputs may include manifestos, speculative projects, drawings, prototypes and exhibits.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design 697.64)

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ARCH 694.title: Studio Research Selective
ARCH 694.description:
Provides additional expertise in an area of focus to support the work students complete in research studios. Topics and themes vary but include; Design Responses to Climate Change, Energy Performance, Historical Precedents and Theories, Designing for Social Equity and Inclusion, Life Cycle Analysis, Digital Fabrication, Simulation and Communication Techniques.

ARCH 696.title: Somerville Design Charrette
ARCH 696.description:
Explores an architectural problem proposed by a visiting practicing architect. Exposes students to the work of an architectural practice and provides an opportunity for students to collaborate with the visiting lecturer on a speculative architectural project. Outputs include drawings, models and exhibits of the work completed during the course.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design 697.65)

ARCH 698.title: Taylor Workshop
ARCH 698.description:
Examines the role of computation and making in architecture. Explores these topics through a guided process of fabrication using contemporary design techniques. Outputs may include prototypes of various scales, drawings, digital workflows, installations and exhibits.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design 697.66)

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

ARCH 700.title: Senior Research Studio in Architecture I
ARCH 700.description:
A research design studio in which students collaborate with design faculty in exploring projects that engage contemporary issues defining the built and natural environments.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design Architecture 782)

ARCH 702.title: Senior Research Studio in Architecture II
ARCH 702.description:
A research design studio in which students collaborate with design faculty in exploring projects that engage contemporary issues defining the built and natural environments.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design Architecture 782)

ARCH 790.title: Directed Study in Architecture
ARCH 790.description: Thematic research, readings, or studio projects related to architecture design topics.

ARCH 792.description: Thematic research, readings, or studio projects related to architecture design topics.
ARCH 792.prerequisitesText:

ARCH 799.title: Preceptorship in Architecture
ARCH 799.description: A preceptorship is a study and training arrangement made between a student and an employer or an equivalent supervisor which has specific educational objectives, a method of evaluation, and is an integral part of a student's Program of Studies. Preceptorships offer a number of benefits: acquiring skills and knowledge which may be better obtained outside the University; developing first-hand experience of professional design practice; preparing for more focused studies in the School; and conducting research.
ARCH 799.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

ARHI 201.title: Introduction to Art History I
ARHI 201.description: An examination of art and architecture before 1400 in relation to significant historical and cultural events.

ARHI 203.title: Introduction toArtHistory II
ARHI 203.description: An examination of art and architecture after 1400 in relation to significant historical and cultural events.

ARHI 211.title: Writing and Art History
ARHI 211.description: An introduction to the techniques and strategies of writing about art and cultural objects within the discipline of art history. Students develop and strengthen their writing skills in relation to addressing, evaluating, and assessing art.

ARHI 305.title: Canadian Art History
ARHI 305.description:
A critical analysis of the forms, objects, and practices that compose the art canon of northern North America. Organized thematically, this course covers the period of history ranging from European contact to the present day.

Antirequisite(s):  Credit for Art History 305 and either 301 or 303 will not be allowed.

ARHI 311.title: Topics in Art History and Visual Studies
ARHI 311.description:
Key concepts and theories within the discipline of Art History. Topics may include: Feminist Art Histories;andArt and Social Critique.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ARHI 319.title: History of Photography
ARHI 319.description:
An examination of the development of photography as a technology, an art medium, and a way of envisioning the world. Historical antecedents of contemporary practices will be emphasized.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Art History 319 and either 419 and 423 will not be allowed.

ARHI 321.title: Medieval Art and Architecture
ARHI 321.description: An examination of art and architecture c. 400- 1400.

ARHI 323.title: Survey of Far Eastern Art: India and Related Civilizations
ARHI 323.description: Anexamination of the art and architecture of ancient India and related civilizations, with special emphasis on Buddhist, Hindu and Islamic art.

ARHI 325.title: China & Related Civilizations
ARHI 325.description: Anexamination of the art and architecture of ancient China and related civilizations, with special emphasis on Confucian, Taoist and Buddhist art.

ARHI 327.title: Renaissance Art
ARHI 327.description:
Anexamination of the arts and architectureofEuropefrom c. 1300-1600.

Antirequisite(s):  CreditforArt History 327and329will not be allowed.

ARHI 331.title: Modern Art and Architecture
ARHI 331.description:
A critical exploration of the development of and discussions about different art movements in relation to Modern Art and the avant-garde, addressing the historical circumstances that enabled the creation of selected art movements, which may include Impressionism, the Arts and Crafts Movement, Cubism, Surrealism, Pop Art, Fluxus, and Situationist.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Art History 331 and any of 405, 407 or 415 will not be allowed.

ARHI 333.title: Contemporary Art and Architecture
ARHI 333.description:
An introduction to the socio-political approaches and critical theories that have informed art-making in the contemporary period. Examines artworks and their production, circulation, and reception through a variety of positions including gender, race, sexuality, and post-coloniality.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Art History 333 and 209 will not be allowed.

ARHI 340.title: Topics in Art and Technology
ARHI 340.description:
Examination of the development of art techniques and forms in relation to a variety of technologies. Topics may include the printing press, the history of video games, telematics, interactive art, and structures of surveillance.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Art History 340 and either Art History 341 or Art 311.01 will not be allowed.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT
