ARHI 343.title: A History of Design
ARHI 343.description: An introduction to the history of design including international movements, materials and technologies, production and consumption, and contemporary issues of critical design practice.

ARHI 357.title: Baroque Art
ARHI 357.description: An examination of the art and architecture of Europe during the seventeenth century.

ARHI 359.title: EighteenthandNineteenthCenturyArt
ARHI 359.description: Anexamination of the art and architecture inEuropeand its colonies during theeighteenth and nineteenth centuries.

ARHI 365.title: Survey of Far Eastern Art: Japan
ARHI 365.description: Anexamination of the art and architecture of dynastic Japan, with special emphasis on Shinto and Buddhist traditions.

ARHI 367.title: IndigenousArtof the Americas
ARHI 367.description: Historicaland contemporary studiesofindigenous cultural production withinthegeographic contextoftheAmericas.

ARHI 371.title: Art and Site
ARHI 371.description: An exploration of the ways in space, place, and context influence the meanings and values of art objects. Topics may include the history of displays, street art, art and the environment, and art in public spaces and sacred sites, and monuments.

ARHI 389.title: Artist Case Study
ARHI 389.description: Introduction to case study methodology in Art History by way of an in-depth study of the work and life of a particular artist.

ARHI 411.title: Topics in the History of Art
ARHI 411.description: An in-depth examination of a particular topic related to the study of Art History.
ARHI 411.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 6 units of courses labelled Art History.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ARHI 425.title: Architecture in the Western World Since 1900
ARHI 425.description: A survey of significant examples of modern architecture, defining their stylistic character in light of developments in technology, the history of ideas, and social and historical factors.

ARHI 431.title: Art and the Body
ARHI 431.description: A critical analysis of the power dynamics inherent to forms of looking and representations of the body in a variety of historical periods and geographical locations. May include gendered representations, the medicalized body, the body in classical art, and displays of marginalized bodies.
ARHI 431.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Art History 331, 333, 357 and 3 additional units of courses labelled Art History at the 300 level or above.

ARHI 471.title: Topics in Global Art
ARHI 471.description: An advanced exploration of topics and issues relevant to art-making and exhibitions within global contexts. Topics may include World's Fairs, art biennales, outsider art, and souvenirs.
ARHI 471.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 6 units in courses labeled Art History at the 300 level or above. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ARHI 501.title: Independent Research in Art History
ARHI 501.description: Independent research projects for advanced students in art history.
ARHI 501.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 18 units of courses labelled Art History at the 300 level or above and consent of the Department.

ARHI 511.title: Capstone in the History of Art
ARHI 511.description: A critical investigation of a particular subject related to the advanced study of Art History and Visual Culture.
ARHI 511.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 18 units of courses labelled Art History at the 300 level or above and consent of the Department.

ARHI 513.title: Directed Studies in Art History
ARHI 513.description: An independent research project conducted under the supervision of a faculty member.
ARHI 513.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 18 units of courses labelled Art History at the 300 level or above and consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ARHI 613.title: Independent Study in Art History
ARHI 613.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ARHI 615.title: Conference Course in Art History
ARHI 615.description: Focusesonclose examinationsand discussionsofstudents' researchandwriting,with an emphasis on communicating informed research creation practices. The course will culminate in a conference presentation.

ARKY 201.title: Introduction To Archaeology
ARKY 201.description:
Basic principles of archaeology. How archaeological remains are located, recovered and interpreted.

Notes:  A supplementary fee will be assessed to cover additional costs associated with this course.

ARKY 205.title: World Archaeology
ARKY 205.description: An overview of Old and New World archaeology; the emergence of humans; development of humans and culture from hunting/gathering to agricultural and ancient urban societies.

ARKY 303.title: Archaeology of North America
ARKY 303.description: Prehistoric cultural developments in North America.

ARKY 306.title: Field Course in Archaeological Techniques
ARKY 306.description: Practical application of modern field techniques in archaeology, including excavation, recording and analysis of sites, artifacts and related materials.

ARKY 321.title: Archaeology of the Plains
ARKY 321.description: Introduction to Canadian Plains archaeology. Processes of cultural and social change on the northern plains over the last 12,000 years from early hunters of Ice--Age megafauna to tribal level farming societies are explored from a Canadian Plains perspective.

ARKY 325.title: Ancient Civilizations
ARKY 325.description: The rise and achievements of the earliest civilizations in both the Old and New Worlds. Emphasis will be placed on the civilizations of Mesopotamia, Egypt, India, China, Mesoamerica and the Andes.

ARKY 328.title: Topics in Archaeology
ARKY 328.description:
Examination of contemporary developments in the field of Archaeology. Topics may be drawn from theoretical, methodological, ethical, or regional research frontiers and may critically address the role of archaeology in contemporary society.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ARKY 329.title: Fringe Archaeology
ARKY 329.description:
Explores popular, fantastic and alternate interpretations of archaeological remains presented in the press and popular media and analyzes the logical flaws in pseudoscientific explanations. Students hone their critical thinking skills and discover the \"real story\" about our past revealed by the science of archaeology.

Antirequisite(s):  Credit for both Archaeology 329 and 327.01 (Frauds, Myths & Mysteries) will not be allowed.

ARKY 331.title: Archaeology and the Media
ARKY 331.description:
Explores how the ancient world, human evolution, archaeologists, and archaeology are represented in a range of media (e.g. films, books, video games, websites, newspapers). Examines how archaeologists use digital media and social media sites to conduct research, as well as disseminate information to Indigenous communities and the general public.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Archaeology 331 and 327.02 (Archeology and the Media) will not be allowed.

ARKY 335.title: African Stone Age
ARKY 335.description: Introduction to the African Stone Age, with emphasis on sub-Saharan Africa. Major cultural developments are explored through archaeological data, as well as other disciplines, including biogeography and geoarchaeology. Topics include early human origins and the behaviour of early humans during the middle Pleistocene, as well as the Later Stone Age. Focus on major chronological events and the cultural processes that characterize the Paleolithic era on the continent.

ARKY 341.title: Ancient Mexico
ARKY 341.description: Ancient cultures of Mexico, excluding the Maya, from their beginnings to the historic period. Emphasis on the civilizations of the Olmecs, Zapotecs, Teotihuacanos, Toltecs and Aztecs.

ARKY 343.title: The Ancient Maya
ARKY 343.description: Ancient Maya, from their beginnings to the historic period.Emphasis on the Classic Maya civilization, from AD 200-900.

ARKY 345.title: The Legacy of Mesoamerica
ARKY 345.description: Traditional native cultures of Middle America. Emphasis is on technology, social organization, economic systems, religions, arts and languages, particularly in the culture centres of Mexico.

ARKY 347.title: Field Studies in Latin American Archaeology
ARKY 347.description: A general survey of the archaeology of the region and an intensive look at the archaeology of the immediate vicinity, including visits to sites and museums. Content varies according to region in Latin America where course is taught. Individual and group study are interspersed with formal instruction.

ARKY 415.title: Lithic Technology
ARKY 415.description: Study and analysis of tools and other artifacts, including their forms, methods of manufacture and use.

ARKY 417.title: Zooarchaeology
ARKY 417.description: The study and analysis of osteological remains used in reconstructing the subsistence strategies of past peoples.

ARKY 419.title: Indigenous Peoples of the Plains
ARKY 419.description:
Explores traditional Plains cultures as recorded in ethnographic accounts and First Nations oral traditions.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Archaeology 419 and Anthropology 419 will not be allowed.

ARKY 423.title: Archaeology of the Arctic
ARKY 423.description: Prehistory/history of N. E. Asia, Alaska, Canada and Greenland. Emphasis will be placed on ecological and ethnographical data.

ARKY 437.title: Paleolithic Archaeology in the Old World
ARKY 437.description: A global survey of Old World prehistoric hunter-gatherers with an emphasis on factual data, analytical techniques, and interpretive trends in the study of the Paleolithic era.

ARKY 440.title: Ancient Cities in Archaeological Perspective
ARKY 440.description: Exploration of archaeological approaches to ancient cities and urbanism. Uses a cross-cultural perspective to examine features and functions of ancient cities, as well as historical and current theoretical and methodological used to interpret them, and their relevance to studies of modern cities and urbanism.
ARKY 440.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): History 354 or 3 units labelled Archaeology or Urban Studies.

ARKY 443.title: Hunter-Gatherer Archaeology
ARKY 443.description: An overview of the history of hunter-gatherer studies in anthropology and archaeology. Introduces current theoretical issues in hunter-gatherer research.

ARKY 451.title: Method And Theory in Archaeolog
ARKY 451.description: A survey of approaches to the study of the relationship between theory, method, and data in archaeological practice.
ARKY 451.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Archaeology 201 and completion of at least 60 units.

ARKY 453.title: Fundamentals of Geoarchaeology
ARKY 453.description: Methods used in geoarchaeology to interpret site and regional context, provenance, stratigraphy, environmental and climatic changes, and principles applied in dating, chemical and isotopic analysis, and remote sensing. Basic principles of sedimentation and soil development explored in experiential learning modules.
ARKY 453.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Archaeology 201, Geography 211, 310, Geology 201, 209.

ARKY 471.title: Ceramic Analysis
ARKY 471.description: The production of pottery: raw materials and techniques. Form, function and decoration. Ceramic ecology. Field processing and sampling. Classification: a survey of approaches. Ceramics and archaeological inference. Practical exercises.

ARKY 490.title: Current Topics in Archaeology
ARKY 490.description: Examination of current theoretical, methodological, or topical issues in archaeology.
ARKY 490.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ARKY 504.title: Archaeology and Heritage
ARKY 504.description: Advanced seminar that scrutinizes archaeology's complex relationship with the concept of heritage. Focuses on diverse conceptions of heritage and trace their reflexive relationships with archaeology from the inception of the field in the 18th century into the present.
ARKY 504.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Archaeology 201 or 205 and completion of 60 units.

ARKY 506.title: Advanced Archaeological Field Techniques
ARKY 506.description: Training in the more advanced aspects of field work.

ARKY 515.title: Paleoethnobotany
ARKY 515.description: The study of ancient plants for food and other purposes through microbotanical remains and ethnobotanical research. Explores uses of microscopic markers such as phytogenic silica and starch granules to reconstruct human ecology, while using ethnobotanical information from traditional knowledge. The emphasis is on the Old World.
ARKY 515.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Archaeology 201 and 3 units of courses labelled Archaeology at the 400 level or above.

ARKY 531.title: Advanced Topics in Archaeology
ARKY 531.description: Investigation of various theoretical, methodological, analytical, and/or topical issues in archaeology.
ARKY 531.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ARKY 555.title: Human Osteology
ARKY 555.description: Identification and interpretation of human skeletal and dental remains. Emphasis is on functional anatomy and reconstruction of prehistoric lifeways.

ARKY 590.title: Honours Thesis
ARKY 590.description: Research project under the direction of a member of the Department.
ARKY 590.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to BA or BSc Archaeology Honours program and consent of the Department.

ARKY 591.title: Landscape Archaeology
ARKY 591.description: Human perceptions and uses of thebiophysicaland cultural environment.The emphasis is onthe act of humanizing theenvironment by naming places, identifying resources, establishing paths,andmodifyingthe natural landscape thereby creating a tradition of land use that can be accessed archaeologically.

ARKY 593.title: Household Archaeology
ARKY 593.description:
Human perceptions and uses of the built environment, particularly residential architecture. The emphasis is on
the structure and symbolism associated with the spatial arrangements of objects, activities, and social
interactions.

ARKY 597.title: Independent Study
ARKY 597.description: An independent study course for Archaeology majors under the supervision of a faculty member.
ARKY 597.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BA or BSc Archaeology and consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ARKY 601.title: Theoretical Foundations
ARKY 601.description: The philosophy of science, the history of anthropological theory, and a survey of contemporary theoretical approaches in anthropology. Throughout, the relevance to and connections with the subdisciplines of archaeology and biological anthropology will be emphasized.

ARKY 603.title: Seminar on Special Topics
ARKY 603.description: Intensive study of special problems of particular interest to Archaeology Department graduate students. Subject matter for any particular year to be left to the discretion of the Department.
ARKY 603.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ARKY 613.title: Analysis Of Human Skeletal Remain
ARKY 613.description: Methods of analyzing human remains from archaeological contexts with emphasis on identification and description. Lecture, lab and weekly seminar directed to Archaeology graduate students who have not had a previous course in human osteology.

ARKY 615.title: Topics in Archaeological Theory & Method
ARKY 615.description: The history of archaeological theory and contemporary theoretical and methodological approaches used in archaeological research.

ARKY 617.title: Theory and its Application in Biological Anthropology
ARKY 617.description: Basic issues in the study of human adaptation with a focus on principles of evolutionary biology as they apply to modern studies. Throughout, a bio-cultural approach will be emphasized.

ARKY 619.title: Adv Topics In Human Osteology
ARKY 619.description:
Advanced Topics in Human Osteology
Current developments in interpretation of human skeletal and dental remains. Topics include forensic anthropology, bone biology, and population reconstruction.
ARKY 619.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Archaeology 555 or consent of the Department.

ARKY 621.title: Problems In Ethnoarchaeology
ARKY 621.description: Seminar on selected topics relating to ethnoarchaeology.

ARKY 625.title: Hunter-Gatherer Adaptations
ARKY 625.description: Intensive study of contemporary and prehistoric hunter-gatherer social and economic adaptations.

ARKY 627.title: Origins Of Agriculture
ARKY 627.description: Intensive study of the origins of agriculture throughout the world.

ARKY 631.title: The Development of Complex Societies
ARKY 631.description: The rise, development, and collapse of complex societies throughout the world.

ARKY 633.title: Specialized Analyses of Archaeological Materials
ARKY 633.description: Theory and practice for specialized analyses of the physical and chemical composition of archaeological materials, including microscopic traces of use. Topics will cover procedures used to prepare materials for such specialized analyses and to identify the relevant properties, as well as issues of quantification and interpretation.

ARKY 635.title: Social Identity
ARKY 635.description: Social identity is a fundamental theoretical and practical concern for archaeologists, physical anthropologists, and paleoanthropologists. Explores how humans use material culture and material practices to interact in a world ordered by social identities. Students will explore how research in their area of interest has addressed social identities.

ARKY 637.title: Mesoamerican Archaeology & Hist
ARKY 637.description: Ancient history of Mesoamerica, emphasizing a conjunctive approach based on hieroglyphic, historical and ethnohistorical sources as well as on archaeological evidence.

ARKY 639.title: Stable Isotope Methods in Archaeology
ARKY 639.description: Methods and applications of stable isotope analysis to archaeological research.  Topics to be covered include the use of light stable isotopes to determine past and present diet, the use of stable isotopes to document residence and migration, analysis of stable carbon isotopes in soils, stable isotope ecology for environmental reconstruction and paleoclimate studies.

ARKY 701.title: Special Topics in World Archaeology
ARKY 701.description:
Archaeology of particular geographical areas such as Circumpolar, North America, Mesoamerica, South America, Africa, Oceania, and Europe and Near East.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ARKY 703.title: Advanced Seminar in Selected Topics
ARKY 703.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ART 231.title: 2D Fundamentals
ART 231.description: Foundation course in two-dimensional art making. Creative exploration of pictorial space, colour, and composition. Working with wet and dry media, students will develop imagery and concepts, promoting technical competence and artistic vision.

ART 233.title: 3D Fundamentals
ART 233.description: Foundation course in three-dimensional art making. Students will be introduced to the elements and principles of art through three-dimensional creative exploration. Students will be introduced to the technical shops and will have the possibility of working in wood, metal, and other materials. Research,  problem solving, visual fluency and conceptual development.

ART 235.title: Introduction to Photography
ART 235.description:
An introductory course in current photographic methods and practices, highlighting digital photography, digital image processing and the presentation of photographs.

Notes: Students must provide their own advanced digital camera. Consult with the department for more information.

ART 241.title: Introduction to Drawing
ART 241.description: Introductory course in observational and representational drawing. Creative exploration includes mark-making, hand-eye co-ordination, proportions, perspective, line, texture, figure-ground relationships and pictorial composition. Approaches may include pencil, cont, charcoal, pastel, pen and ink. These will be addressed in the context of research, problem-solving, visual fluency and conceptual development.

ART 251.title: Introduction to Digital Arts
ART 251.description: Technical instruction and creative opportunities in the media arts, in addition to examination of historical, theoretical and critical context.

ART 271.title: Introduction To Printmaking
ART 271.description: An introduction to fine art printmaking. Technical approaches may include monotype, intaglio and relief.

ART 309.title: Foundations of Art Education
ART 309.description:
An introduction to the history, theory and philosophy of art education through participatory learning events.

Also known as: (formerly Art 205)

ART 311.title: Topics in Art
ART 311.description:
Lecture-based class focused on different topics and approaches to studio art practice.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ART 312.title: Net Video Art
ART 312.description: Introduction to contemporary approaches to video art production and web dissemination. Students will gain experience and a working knowledge of concept development, video shooting and editing in the context of digital art and social media.|

ART 313.title: Video Art
ART 313.description: Focuses on concepts, issues, and techniques of video as an art medium.  Gain experience and a working knowledge of concept development, video shooting and digital editing, in the context of contemporary art theory and practice.

ART 314.title: Introduction to Indigenous Art
ART 314.description:
Introduction to Indigenous art and Indigenous ways of knowing through making. Students will engage with Indigenous perspective(s) and worldview(s) around visiting and community.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Art 314 and 365.03 (Introduction to Indigenous Art) will not be allowed.

Also known as: (Indigenous Studies 350)

ART 315.title: Programming for Artists
ART 315.description: An introduction to computer programming techniques used to create interactive art projects.

ART 317.title: Electronics for Artists
ART 317.description: Theoretical and practical applications of basic electronic principles and techniques involving the use of electronics in contemporary art practices. Will include applied experiences with hardware and visual programming environments.

ART 319.title: Digital Illustration
ART 319.description: Introduces students to vector-based illustration techniques, their historical context, and terminology. The course provides a focus on the fundamentals of layout and image construction, the various methods of output possible with vector-based designs, and the relationship between verbal and visual communication.

ART 320.title: Digital Painting
ART 320.description: Introduces students to raster-based image creation techniques, their historical context, and terminology. The course may cover the creation of representational imagery, photo manipulation and retouching, or other bitmap-based practices.

ART 323.title: Digital Sculpture
ART 323.description: Introduces students to 3D modeling by means of digital sculpting techniques, their historical context and terminology. Provides a focus on the fundamentals of working and designing in three-dimensional space.

ART 332.title: Topics in Photography
ART 332.description: Studio inquiry in photography developing students' foundational, technical and conceptual skills. Exploration of topics in photography such as large format, projection, narrative and fine art printing processes will enable research creation directed toward self-generated practice. Activities will include workshops, studio practice and critique.

ART 334.title: Animation
ART 334.description: Practices and concepts of animation as an art form, which may include stop motion, cameraless animation, cutout animation, installation, and video projection.

ART 336.title: Key Concepts in Contemporary Photography
ART 336.description: Fundamental, aesthetic and conceptual considerations in contemporary photography. Digital camera use and the use of editing software in support of fine art photography. Introduction to digital printing for photographic artists. A portion of assigned course work will be output as inkjet prints.

ART 338.title: Film Photography
ART 338.description: Analogue film-based photography. Darkroom skills and practices, including film developing and analogue printing.

ART 340.title: Panorama and 360 Virtual Reality Photography
ART 340.description: Students learn how to use software and hardware needed to create panoramas and virtual tours.

ART 341.title: Drawing the Figure
ART 341.description: Theory and practice of drawing the human figure at a developing level involving an extended range of drawing media.

ART 342.title: Art Education Across the Lifespan I
ART 342.description:
An exploration of the cognitive, emotional, and social development of infants, children and adolescents learning art. Students will engage in experiential learning in formal and informal settings.

Antirequisite(s):  Credit for Art 342 and any of 305, 307 or 393 will not be allowed.

ART 343.title: Drawing: Construction of Pictoral Space
ART 343.description: Extendsthe range of concepts andpracticesin drawing to include pictorial space.

ART 344.title: Art Education Across the Lifespan II
ART 344.description:
An exploration of the cognitive, emotional, and social development of adults learning art. Students will engage in experiential learning in formal and informal settings.

Antirequisite(s):  Credit for Art 344 and any of 305, 307 and 393 will not be allowed.

ART 346.title: Drawing: Media and Process
ART 346.description: Developing observational and representational skills through figure drawing and exploration of the contemporary field. Approaches will include a more developed understanding of colour, research, problem solving, visual fluency and conceptual development.
ART 346.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Art 241.

Also known as: (formerly Art 243)

ART 350.title: Painting: Materials and Processes
ART 350.description: Technical and conceptual exploration of painting, with experimentation in at least two media, including acrylic and/or oil. May include colour theory, painting style, application of materials and different painting supports.

ART 351.title: Painting: Figuration
ART 351.description: Exploration of painting proceeding from observation and traditions of figuration. Media will include acrylic and/or oil.

ART 353.title: Painting: Abstraction
ART 353.description: Exploration of painting proceeding from traditions of abstraction. Media will include acrylic and/or oil.

ART 362.title: Photographic Storytelling
ART 362.description: Photographic storytelling approached from a variety of perspectives and using multiple narrative strategies. The course examines photo editing, sequencing, printing, and ways of presenting narrative work to an envisioned audience.

ART 364.title: Contemporary Portraiture
ART 364.description: Approaches to portraiture within the context of contemporary fine art photography. Review of significant work within the field as a means of considering and expanding the practice of photographic portraiture.

ART 365.title: Topics in Studio Research and Critique
ART 365.description:
Studio-based introduction to contemporary and emerging creative practices. Topics may include: installation art, performance art, slip casting, or hybrid art forms.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ART 366.title: Photography as Activism
ART 366.description: Photography is role in promoting and instigating cultural, social, economic, and political change. Historical and contemporary examples will be reviewed, along with varied approaches to socially-engaged photographic practice.

ART 368.title: The Photographic Book
ART 368.description: Contemporary approaches to the photographic book. Editing, sequencing, and design consideration, along with approaches to the use of written texts in conjunction with images. Artist books, self-publishing, and contemporary fine art publishers will be reviewed and discussed.

ART 370.title: Large-Format Photography
ART 370.description: Exploration of large-format photography. Approaches to using field and/or studio cameras, processing and printing large-format work. Technical and conceptual considerations associated with large-format photography and its presentation.

ART 373.title: Printmaking: Lithography
ART 373.description: Exploring the creative potential of lithography. Working with lithographic techniques, materials and processes, students will develop imagery and concepts, promoting technical competence and artistic vision.

ART 374.title: Printmaking: Relief
ART 374.description: Exploring the creative potential of relief printmaking. Working with relief techniques, materials, and processes, students will develop imagery and concepts, promoting technical competence and artistic vision.

ART 376.title: Sculpture: Mold Making and Casting
ART 376.description: An exploration of mold making and casting techniques in the realization of sculptural forms.
ART 376.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Art 233.

Antirequisite: Credit for Art 376 and 481 will not be allowed.

ART 377.title: Printmaking: Screenprint
ART 377.description: Exploring the creative potential of screenprint. Working with screenprint techniques, materials, and processes, students will develop imagery and concepts, promoting technical competence and artistic vision.

ART 379.title: Printmaking: Intaglio
ART 379.description: Exploring the creative potential of intaglio printmaking. Working with intaglio techniques, materials, and processes, students will develop imagery and concepts, promoting technical competence and artistic vision.

ART 381.title: Sculpture: Materials and Processes
ART 381.description: Students will build on foundational technical knowledge in wood, metal, and other materials to explore concepts of materiality and process in sculpture.

ART 383.title: Sculpture: Concepts and Strategies
ART 383.description: Conceptual exploration of sculpture introducing students to strategies and concepts to assist in research, problem-solving, and developing conceptual-driven projects.

ART 400.title: Professional Development I
ART 400.description: Extending studio art practice to professional contexts. Students will develop the ability to communicate ideas that inform creative practice. Content may include developing an artist statement and CV.
ART 400.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 9 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level.

Antirequisite: Credit for Art 400 and any of 327, 329, 397 or 599 will not be allowed.

ART 402.title: Professional Development II
ART 402.description: Continued professional development associated with working as an artist. Course content is supported by lectures from arts and culture professionals. Content may include art documentation, applications, finances, and art communities.
ART 402.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Art 400 and 9 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level.

Antirequisite: Credit for Art 402 and any of 327, 329, 397, 599 will not be allowed.

ART 411.title: Topics in Art Education
ART 411.description:
Exploration of topics in art education such as multiculturalism, creativity, developmental issues, or special needs learners.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ART 414.title: Advanced Topics in Indigenous Art
ART 414.description: Advanced studio inquiry into Indigenous art developing students' technical and conceptual skills. Explores advanced practices through topics that may include beading, quilling, and hide.
ART 414.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Art 314

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ART 420.title: Advanced Topics in Art
ART 420.description: Advanced studio inquiry in creative practices and art making.
ART 420.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 9 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level.

ART 421.title: Advanced Topics in Digital Arts
ART 421.description: Advanced studio inquiry into digital art forms developing students' technical and conceptual skills. Advanced exploration of digital media topics such as 2D graphics, 3D graphics, animation, motion capture, and modelling will enable research creation directed toward self-generated practice.
ART 421.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Art History 340 and 6 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ART 436.title: Projects in Photography
ART 436.description: Individually conceptualized and designed creative research projects in photography. Approaches to proposal-writing, researching, editing, printing, and presenting projects. Writing artists' bios and artist statements in support of exhibition of photographic series.
ART 436.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 9 units of courses labelled Art at the 300-level, including 6 units from Art 332, 336, 338, 340, 362, 366, 368, 370.

ART 438.title: Advanced Topics in Photography
ART 438.description: Advanced studio inquiry in photography, further developing students' technical and conceptual skills. Deeper exploration of topics in photography such as projection, printing and alternative processes, enabling research creation directed toward self-generated practice. Activities include workshops, studio practice and critique.
ART 438.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 9 units of courses labelled Art at the 300-level, including 6 units from Art 332, 336, 338, 340, 362, 366, 368, 370.

ART 445.title: Advanced Topics in Drawing
ART 445.description: Advanced studio inquiry into drawing that deepens technical and conceptual skills aimed at developing a self-directed practice and research.
ART 445.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Art 243 and 9 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level, including 3 units from Art 341, 343, 346.

ART 455.title: Advanced Topics in Painting
ART 455.description: Advanced studio inquiry into painting that deepens technical and conceptual skills aimed at developing a self-directed practice and research.
ART 455.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 9 units of courses labelled Art at the 300-level including 6 units from Art 350, 351 or 353.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ART 475.title: Advanced Topics in Printmaking
ART 475.description: This advanced studio course builds upon students' previous experiences in areas such as lithography, screenprinting, intaglio, relief, and photomechanical print processes.
ART 475.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 9 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level, including 3 units from Art 374, 373, 377, 379.

ART 485.title: Advanced Topics in Sculpture
ART 485.description: Advanced studio inquiry into sculpture that develops technical and conceptual skills. Activities will include studio practice aimed at developing the student's self-directed practice and research. Topics may include sculptural exploration of installation, performance, and site-specific art.
ART 485.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 9 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level including 3 units from Art 376, 381 or 383.

ART 491.title: Community-Based Art Experiences
ART 491.description: A seminar and field experience course introducing prospective educators to all facets of planning and implementing positive art experiences in a non-school setting.

ART 509.title: Curriculum Building for Art
ART 509.description: Developing curriculum and program structures for formal and community art education. Program design includes current theory and practice and a field research component.
ART 509.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 12 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level or above.

ART 513.title: Directed Study
ART 513.description: Independent studio research. Class structured to enable students to undertake advanced level research of their own choosing. Must be developed under the supervision of a faculty member.

ART 560.title: Honours Thesis
ART 560.description: Honours-level course focused on writing thesis exhibition support paper.
ART 560.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BFA Honours Visual Studies Program.

ART 561.title: Honours Studio Research I
ART 561.description: Directed studio research and production for honours students.
ART 561.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Honours in Visual Studies and consent of the Department.

ART 563.title: Honours Studio Research II
ART 563.description: Further directed studio research and production for honours students. The course culminates in a thesis exhibition.
ART 563.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Honours in Visual Studies and Art 561.

ART 564.title: Studio Research
ART 564.description: Advanced studio course that introduces students to self-generated approaches to creative research. Situated in an interdisciplinary setting, students can work across a variety of media as best supports their creative and conceptual interests.
ART 564.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 9 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level and 3 units of courses labelled Art at the 400 level.

ART 565.title: Advanced Studio Research
ART 565.description: Studio course that advances understanding of self-generated approaches to creative research. Situated in an interdisciplinary setting, students can work across a variety of media as best supports their creative and conceptual interests. Students will demonstrate competency in a final presentation, such as an exhibition, performance, or installation.

ART 601.title: History of Art I
ART 601.description: Individual study: In consultation with the instructor, the student will select a research topic in art history or art criticism.
ART 601.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in the Department of Art.

ART 603.title: History Of Art II
ART 603.description: Individual study: In consultation with the instructor, the student  will select a research topic in art history or art criticism.
ART 603.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Art 601 or consent of the Department.

ART 605.title: Critical Study and Research
ART 605.description: Individual study and research in the area of studio specialization, critical theory, methodological issues and/or historical topics.
ART 605.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Restricted to MFA or PhD students enrolled in the Art Department, or consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ART 609.title: Art Theory and Criticism
ART 609.description: Investigation of contemporary global art theory and criticism.

ART 611.title: Research Methods in Art
ART 611.description: Introduces students to art making as a process of knowledge production and research creation.
ART 611.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in the Department of Art.

ART 691.title: Pedagogy & Professional Practice
ART 691.description: Issues in professional practice and post-secondary teaching in visual art. Optional course.
ART 691.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Restricted to MFA of PhD students enrolled in the Art Department or consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ART 761.title: Advanced Independent Studio Research
ART 761.description: Theoretical and applied concepts in studio.
ART 761.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Restricted to MFA or PhD students enrolled in the Art Department, or consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ART 661.01.title: Advanced Studio Practice I
ART 661.01.description: Individual study in studio, with seminar-based discussions in research area.
ART 661.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department; courses must be taken sequentially.

ART 661.02.title: Advanced Studio Practice II
ART 661.02.description: Individual study in studio, with seminar-based discussions in research area.
ART 661.02.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department; courses must be taken sequentially.

ART 661.03.title: Advanced Studio Practice III
ART 661.03.description: Individual study in studio, with seminar-based discussions in research area.
ART 661.03.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department; courses must be taken sequentially.

ART 661.04.title: Advanced Studio Practice IV
ART 661.04.description: Individual study in studio, with seminar-based discussions in research area.
ART 661.04.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department; courses must be taken sequentially.

ARTS 501.title: International Study Topics
ARTS 501.description: Group or individual study topics which involve international experience. Group study topics will vary from year to year.
ARTS 501.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Third year standing and consent of the faculty.

ARTS 502.title: Academic Field Placement
ARTS 502.description: Authorized academic field placements will vary from year to year.
ARTS 502.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Acceptance to a recognized academic internship or field placement program and approval of the Faculty of Arts.

ARTS 503.title: Multidisciplinary Capstone
ARTS 503.description: Participation in a seminar focused on completing and presenting individual research projects that integrate the primary and secondary focus within a student's multidisciplinary degree program.
ARTS 503.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BA Multidisciplinary and completion of 75 units.

ARTS 507.title: Collaborative Learning and Peer Mentoring
ARTS 507.description: Study of learning theories and learning processes with practical experience through mentoring learners in an undergraduate course in the Faculty of Arts under the supervision of that course's instructor. Service-learning activities may include facilitating discussion in classrooms or online, discussing topics for term papers, organizing and assisting study groups, and/or coaching peers in their oral presentation or writing skills. Course requirements include a 39-hour practicum .
ARTS 507.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 48 units and consent of the Instructor. 

Also known as: (formerly Communication and Culture 507)

ARTS 509.title: Research in Peer Mentoring and Higher Learning
ARTS 509.description: Students continue to support peers in their learning processes using a facilitative, collaborative approach. As part of their service-learning mentoring hours, students will assist new peer mentors to grow into their roles. Students will conduct either a textual or field research project related to their peer mentoring roles. Course requirements include a service-learning component of approximately 39 hours .
ARTS 509.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Arts 507 or Communication and Culture 507 or Science 511 and consent of the instructor.

Also known as: (formerly Communication and Culture 509)

ARTS 601.title: Theory and Practice of Teaching and Learning
ARTS 601.description: An introduction, exploration, and application of the theories and practices of teaching undergraduate students in the arts, humanities, and social sciences.
ARTS 601.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to MA, MSc or PhD program in the Faculty of Arts.

ASHA 222.title: Ways of Making and Knowing
ASHA 222.description: Exploration of how human beings from diverse communities and cultures have sought to understand themselves and their environments through practices of invention, discovery, preservation, and craft.
ASHA 222.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Arts and Science Honours Academy Program.

ASHA 322.title: Questions for our Time
ASHA 322.description: Exploration through interdisciplinary frameworks of urgent questions associated with such topics as technology, gender, digital cultures, creativity, politics, race, and the environment.
ASHA 322.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Arts and Science Honours Academy 222 or 220 and admission to the Arts and Science Honours Academy.

ASHA 422.title: The Nature of Research
ASHA 422.description: Exploration of interdisciplinary modes of inquiry through case studies, with a consideration of how research and cultural frameworks create objects of knowledge and standards of evidence.
ASHA 422.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Arts and Science Honours Academy 322 and admission to the Arts and Science Honours Academy.

ASHA 503.title: Capstone Seminar
ASHA 503.description: A capstone seminar in which students reflect on their intellectual and experiential journeys from both disciplinary and interdisciplinary perspectives, and develop public-facing forms of mobilizing their research.
ASHA 503.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Arts and Science Honours Academy 422 or 421 and admission to the Arts and Science Honours Academy.

ASL 201.title: Beginners' American Sign Language I
ASL 201.description:
Introduction to American Sign Language (ASL) and the culture of deaf people. Covers material in matriculation-level ASL. It teaches basic communication and conversational skills in ASL and is for students with no background in ASL.

Notes: Preference in enrolment is given to students in Medicine, Nursing, and Social Work.

ASL 203.title: Beginners' American Sign Language II
ASL 203.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): American Sign Language 201 or consent of the Department.

ASPH 305.title: Introduction to Astrophysics
ASPH 305.description: Fundamentals of modern astrophysics including observations and physical interpretation physical phenomena in the Universe. Topics include the nature of the Sun and stars, galaxies, and the interstellar medium; distances and motions in the universe; radiation and telescopes; celestial mechanics; stellar evolution. Minor laboratory exercises including one at the Rothney Astrophysical Observatory as circumstances permit.
ASPH 305.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Physics 211, 221, 227 or Engineering 202; and 3 units from Mathematics 267 or 277.

Also known as: (formerly Astrophysics 213)

ASPH 307.title: Introduction to Observational Astrophysics
ASPH 307.description: Lectures and practical laboratory sessions in observational astronomy. Students will collect, reduce, and interpret astronomical data, develop an understanding of telescopes, instruments, and detectors; reduction and analysis methods; simulations and model fitting; data and error analysis. Observations will be carried out at the Rothney Astrophysical Observatory and/or the main campus.

ASPH 401.title: Galactic Astrophysics
ASPH 401.description: The galaxy: space distribution of stars and interstellar material; kinematics and dynamics of stellar systems; rotation and spiral structure; classification and global properties of galaxies; active galaxies.
ASPH 401.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Physics 229 or 325; Physics 259 or 355; Mathematics 376 or 375; and Astrophysics 213 or 305.

ASPH 403.title: Stellar Structure and Evolution
ASPH 403.description: Observational properties of stars; equations of stellar structure; physics of stellar interiors; structure and evolution of stars; white dwarfs, neutron stars, black holes; observational aspects of stellar atmospheres; radiative transfer in stellar atmospheres; opacity; spectral line formation.
ASPH 403.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Astrophysics 213 or 305; Physics 229 or 325; Physics 341 or Engineering 349; and Mathematics 375 or 376.

ASPH 409.title: Planetary Astrophysics
ASPH 409.description: Orbital mechanics. Planetary interiors, surfaces, atmosphere, ionospheres and magnetospheres. Solar magnetism and activity cycles. Comets, asteroids, meteorites. Origin of the solar system. Exoplanets.
ASPH 409.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Astrophysics 213 or 305; Physics 229 or 325; Physics 341; and Mathematics 376 or 375.

ASPH 503.title: The Interstellar Medium
ASPH 503.description: Multiwavelength observations of gas and dust in our Galaxy; distribution and physics of neutral atomic hydrogen and molecules; interstellar chemistry; physics of dust grains; HII regions; interstellar shocks; gas dynamics; star formation.

ASPH 509.title: High Energy Astrophysics and Cosmology
ASPH 509.description: High-energy continuum radiation processes, shocks, supernovae and supernova remnants, white dwarfs, neutron stars, black holes, multi-messenger astrophysics, transient sources, active galactic nuclei, clusters of galaxies and cosmology.

ASPH 607.title: Advanced Observational Astrophys
ASPH 607.description: Principles and tools of modern ground-based and space astronomy emphasising ultraviolet, optical, infrared, and radio radiation. Data acquisition and reduction techniques for astrometry, photometry, spectroscopy, imaging, and interferometry. Use of astronomical data analysis software.

ASPH 611.title: Radio Astronomy
ASPH 611.description: Wave propagation, antennas, interferometry,  aperture synthesis, radio receivers, and spectrometers. Applications to continuum and line radiation in stars, interstellar medium, and extragalactic objects.

ASPH 621.title: High Energy Astrophysics
ASPH 621.description: Interaction of high energy particles with matter, propagation and origin of cosmic rays; structure of white dwarfs and neutron stars; the physics of jets and the accretion process onto compact objects; supernovae and supernova remnants; active galactic nuclei.

ASTR 207.title: Introduction to Astronomy I - The Solar System
ASTR 207.description:
A comprehensive, descriptive overview of the solar system covering how ideas have changed from ancient times to today. The latest discoveries. The electromagnetic spectrum; telescopes and detectors; laws of planetary motion; planets, asteroids, comets, and the Sun. Formation of the solar system. Extra-solar planets and the possibility of extraterrestrial life. Possible field trip to the Rothney Astrophysical Observatory.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Astronomy 207 and any of Astronomy 205, Astrophysics 213 or 305 will not be allowed. Physics Majors, Astrophysics Majors, Natural Sciences Physics Concentrators and Environmental Science Physics Concentrators are not permitted to register in this course.

ASTR 209.title: Introduction to Astronomy II - The Cosmos
ASTR 209.description:
A comprehensive, descriptive overview of the universe outside the solar system. The electromagnetic spectrum; stellar spectra; distance determinations. Origin and evolution of stars; white dwarfs, neutron stars and black holes. The interstellar medium. Dark matter. Galaxies and quasars. The Big Bang. The fate of the universe. Possible field trip to the Rothney Astrophysical Observatory.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Astronomy 209 and either of Astronomy 205 or Astrophysics 213 will not be allowed. Physics Majors, Astrophysics Majors, Natural Sciences Physics Concentrators and Environmental Science Physics Concentrators are not permitted to register in this course.

BCEM 341.title: Biochemistry of Life Processes
BCEM 341.description: Emphasis is placed on describing the chemistry of biochemical molecules including proteins, carbohydrates, lipids, and nucleic acids. Cell structure and life processes are introduced by examining the chemistry of the biomolecules involved. Basic concepts of metabolism are introduced, focusing on the breakdown of carbohydrates for energy. The laboratory component reinforces learning of the lecture material, while teaching technical skills and the analysis and interpretation of experiments involving biochemical molecules.

BCEM 393.title: Introduction to Biochemistry
BCEM 393.description: Emphasis is placed on analyzing the chemistry of biochemical molecules including proteins, carbohydrates, lipids, and nucleic acids. The chemistry of biomolecules is applied to prerequisite knowledge of cell structures and life processes. Basic concepts of metabolism are introduced, focusing on the breakdown of carbohydrates for energy. The laboratory component reinforces learning of the lecture material, while teaching technical skills and the analysis and interpretation of experiments involving biochemical molecules.
BCEM 393.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemistry 351, Biology 311 and admission to a Major offered by the Department of Biological Sciences or the Neuroscience Major or a primary concentration in Biological Sciences in either the Natural Sciences or Environmental Science Major. Or, Chemistry 351, and Medical Science 341, and admission to either the Biomedical Science or Bioinformatics Major.

BCEM 411.title: Laboratory Techniques I
BCEM 411.description: Practical experience in the laboratory with protein purification and protein characterization techniques. Topics may include bioinformatics, sample sources, classic and affinity tag chromatography, electrophoresis, enzyme assays, antibodies and methods to study protein: protein interactions.

BCEM 413.title: Laboratory Techniques II
BCEM 413.description: Practical experience in the laboratory with recombinant DNA techniques, protein production, mutagenesis and characterization. Topics may include bioinformatics, DNA amplification and gene cloning and expression strategies, biophysical characterization, stressing the properties of nucleic acids and proteins relevant to these techniques.

BCEM 431.title: Proteins and Proteomics
BCEM 431.description: Protein structure and chemistry: structural motifs, ligand-binding, conformational changes, chemical modification; protein folding; structure prediction by molecular modelling. Identification of proteins in the proteome: 2D gel electrophoresis and chromatography, mass spectrometry; metalloproteins; post-translational modifications; protein-protein interactions.
BCEM 431.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biology 331; Biochemistry 341 or 393; and Chemistry 353 or 355.

BCEM 443.title: Metabolism
BCEM 443.description: Intermediary carbohydrate, lipid, amino acid and nucleotide metabolism, and the regulation of these metabolic pathways.
BCEM 443.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemistry 353 or 355; and Biochemistry 341 or 393.

BCEM 471.title: Physical Biochemistry
BCEM 471.description: The laws of thermodynamics as they apply to biological systems: the hydrophobic effect, properties of water, electrolyte solutions and ligand binding. Optical spectroscopic methods including UV/visible absorption, fluorescence, and infrared as applied to biological molecules.
BCEM 471.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Biochemistry 341 or 393; and 3 units from Chemistry 353 or 355; and 3 units from Mathematics 249 or 265 or 275; and 3 units from Physics 211 or 221; and Physics 223.

BCEM 528.title: Research Project in Biochemistry
BCEM 528.description: Research project under the co/supervision of faculty members in the Department of Biological Sciences. Original and independent thought, practical research, and written and oral reports presented on completion of this course.
BCEM 528.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 72 units and consent of the Department.

BCEM 530.title: Honours Research Project in Biochemistry
BCEM 530.description: Research project under the co/supervision of faculty members in the Department of Biological Sciences. Original and independent thought, practical research, and written and oral reports presented on completion of this course. Open only to Honours Biochemistry students or Honours Biological Sciences students.
BCEM 530.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 72 units and consent of the Department.

BCEM 541.title: (CHEM 541) Concepts in Biochemical Toxicology
BCEM 541.description: An interdisciplinary course focused on the diverse biomolecular mechanisms by which organic (e.g. PCB's) and inorganic pollutants (e.g. Cd, Hg, As) adversely affect cell function examined at multiple levels of organization, from molecules to whole animals organisms. Topics include how natural toxins exert toxicity, how toxins/light generate free radicals within cells, how the speciation of metals in the environment affects their bioavailability/toxicity, and the toxicity mechanisms that lead to homeostatic dysfunction.
BCEM 541.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Biochemistry 341 or 393; Chemistry 311, 321 and 351.

Also known as: (Chemistry 541)

BCEM 547.title: Signal Transduction and Regulation of Metabolism
BCEM 547.description: Principles of signal transduction with examples from prokaryotes and eukaryotes. Discussion of protein covalent modifications, inositol lipid signaling, structure and function of protein kinases and protein phosphatases and their role in regulating various aspects of cell function. Emphasis on metabolic pathways, cell cycle control, checkpoints, DNA damage response and epigenetics.

BCEM 551.title: Structural Biology
BCEM 551.description: Experimental and theoretical foundations of X-ray crystallography and cryogenic electron microscopy as applied to structural studies of proteins, nucleic acids, and cellular structures (including organelles, vesicles, and cytoskeleton). Comparison of the structural information derived from the two methods.
BCEM 551.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biochemistry 341 or 393; and Biochemistry 471 or Chemistry 371.

BCEM 553.title: Molecular Biophysics
BCEM 553.description: A comprehensive survey of modern biophysics covering the flow and processing of matter, energy and information in living systems. Equilibrium and non-equilibrium thermodynamics in biology. Molecular motors and facilitated proton transport. An integrative approach connecting atomistic theories to cellular processes.
BCEM 553.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biochemistry 341 or 393; and Biochemistry 471 or Chemistry 371.

BCEM 555.title: Biomembranes
BCEM 555.description: The material examines the structure and function of biological membranes with a strong emphasis on the role of membrane proteins. Topics may include: the physical properties of lipid bilayers, isolation and purification of membrane proteins, preparation of membrane mimetic systems, ion and solute movement across membranes (transport and ion channels), membrane protein folding, assembly and structure, and protein secretion and translocation systems.

BCEM 561.title: Applied Biochemistry and Biotechnology
BCEM 561.description: An introduction to the language, materials, methods, concepts and commercial applications of biotechnology with emphasis on methodology, proteins as products, and the impact of genome sequencing on biotechnology. Topics will also include microbial, animal, and bioremediation biotechnology, expanding the genetic code, synthetic biology, antibiotic resistance, cancer immunotherapy, stem cells, and gene therapy.

BCEM 575.title: Lipids
BCEM 575.description: Structure and function of lipids including phospholipids, sphingolipids, and steroids. Topics include properties of lipids and bilayers, lipid-lipid and lipid-protein interactions, technological applications, biosynthesis and regulation, lipids as second messengers, intracellular trafficking, and lipids in physiology and disease. Literature review and student seminars are significant components of this course.
BCEM 575.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units of courses labelled Biochemistry.

BCEM 577.title: Biomolecular Simulation
BCEM 577.description: Introduction to simulation and computer modelling methods commonly used in biochemistry and biophysics, with a focus on physical models to understand the behaviour of biomolecules. Topics include simulation methods, dynamics of proteins, DNA, and lipids, calculation of binding constants, protein-drug interactions, properties of ion channels as well as a number of recent literature topics.
BCEM 577.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biochemistry 341 or 393; and Biochemistry 471 or Chemistry 371.

BCEM 599.title: Topics in Biochemistry
BCEM 599.description: Exploration of various areas in Biochemistry. Topics may vary from year-to-year. It will be offered as required to provide the opportunity for students to engage in additional areas in Biochemistry.
BCEM 599.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Faculty.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT.

BCEM 641.title: Independent Study
BCEM 641.description: Independent research or reading project that may include seminars, term papers and training in theoretical and/or laboratory methods.
BCEM 641.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

BCEM 731.title: Current Topics in Biochemistry
BCEM 731.description: A discussion of contemporary experimental and theoretical biochemical methods used for the study of drugs and diagnostics at a biomolecular level. Structural analysis, drug design and computational methods will be introduced, as well as modern 'omics' research approaches and current protein drug targets of the pharmaceutical industry.

BCEM 507.01.title: Directed Research in Biochemistry I
BCEM 507.01.description: Directed training in field/laboratory methods and research.
BCEM 507.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 54 units and consent of the Department.

BCEM 507.02.title: Directed Research in Biochemistry II
BCEM 507.02.description: Directed training in field/laboratory methods and research.
BCEM 507.02.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 54 units and consent of the Department.

BIMA 610.title: Data Management and Business Analytics
BIMA 610.description: Covers organizing, storing, and managing available data using relational database technologies and generating insights through business analytics techniques.
BIMA 610.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Business Intelligence and Data Analytics.

Also known as: (Business Technology Management 631)

BIMA 611.title: Enterprise Analysis
BIMA 611.description: Course focus is on enterprise analysis and management of IT-enabled solutions to business problems. Emphasis is placed on problem identification, requirements determination, process analysis, enterprise architecture design and IT auditing using the COBIT framework.
BIMA 611.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Business Intelligence and Data Analytics.

Also known as: (Business Technology Management 635)

BIMA 612.title: Data Analytics I
BIMA 612.description: Covers tools and methods used in data analytics to discover, collect, organize, and clean data to make it ready for analysis. Software packages used to clean and organize the data for analysis will be introduced, as well as software to enable users' understanding of the data that is collected.
BIMA 612.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Business Intelligence and Data Analytics or the Graduate Certificate in Management Analytics.

Also known as: (Business Technology Management 636)

BIMA 613.title: Data Analytics II
BIMA 613.description: Covers tools and methods used in data analysis. Focus is on analytic and mapping methods, such as data mining, text mining, machine learning, social network analytics and preference mapping, and their application to business data analytics.
BIMA 613.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Business Intelligence and Data Analytics.

Also known as: (Business Technology Management 637)

BIMA 620.title: Predictive Analytics in Business
BIMA 620.description: Application of data-driven predictive models to solve real-life business problems in operations, marketing, finance and other business functions. Techniques covered include decision trees, classification and association rules, and cluster analysis.
BIMA 620.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Management Analytics.

Also known as: (Operations Management 631)

BIMA 621.title: Marketing Analytics
BIMA 621.description: Developing and implementing marketing strategies driven by data analytic techniques. The course will integrate key marketing concepts with segmentation analytics and social media analytics.
BIMA 621.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Management Analytics.

Also known as: (Marketing 631)

BIMA 622.title: Prescriptive Analytics in Business
BIMA 622.description: Advanced quantitative decision-making and problem-solving skills in business environments with data and fact-based analysis. Techniques such as data-driven optimization, deterministic and probabilistic modeling, and simulation are covered through case studies.
BIMA 622.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Management Analytics.

Also known as: (Management Studies 631)

BIMA 623.title: Supply Chain Analytics
BIMA 623.description: Optimal design and management of supply chains with analytical tools. Topics include network design, inventory management, transportation, contracting, coordination and collaboration, capacity management, and customer-supplier relations.
BIMA 623.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Management Analytics.

Also known as: (Supply Chain Management 631)

BIMA 624.title: Analytics of International Business Environment
BIMA 624.description: A data-driven approach to the analysis of international business environment. Use of data analytics to appraise emerging trends in a country/region/world business environment and derive strategic implications for business enterprises.
BIMA 624.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Management Analytics.

Also known as: (Strategy and Global Management 631)

BIMA 625.title: FinTech
BIMA 625.description: An understanding of fast-moving recent technological improvements in various industries and how they change the conventional thinking and trading in the banking and finance industry.
BIMA 625.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission the Graduate Certificate in Management Analytics.

Also known as: (Finance 631)

BIOL 202.title: The Science of Food, Cooking and Eating
BIOL 202.description:
Introduction to a scientific understanding of food and cooking using principles from a range of biological sciences, including biochemistry, molecular biology, microbiology, immunology, physiology and ecology. Topics include: building blocks of food, molecular-level understanding of recipes, biochemical reactions of cooking, microbiology of food production, physiology of sensory apparatus, food-related diseases, and industrialized food production.

Antirequisite(s): Not open for registration to Honours, Majors or Minors in the Department of Biological Sciences or to Natural Sciences program students with a Concentration in Biological Sciences, or to Environmental Science program students with a Concentration in Biological Sciences, or to Neuroscience program students.

BIOL 205.title: The Organization and Diversity of Life
BIOL 205.description:
A study of biological concepts and mechanisms illustrated by current examples of medical and environmental problems.

Antirequisite(s): Not open for registration to Honours, Majors or Minors in the Department of Biological Sciences or to Natural Sciences program students with a Concentration in Biological Sciences, or to Environmental Science program students, or to Neuroscience program students. Credit for Biology 205 and any of 211, 213, 241 or 243 will not be allowed.

BIOL 211.title: Biomolecules and Cellular Systems
BIOL 211.description: An introduction to cellular biology and genetics. Major topics include biological macromolecules and structures of prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells, cellular energetics, DNA structure and the flow of information through DNA replication, transcription, translation, and cell division. Laboratories will explore methods for analyzing biomolecules and the study of cells, with an introduction to data collection and presentation, and scientific writing.
BIOL 211.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biology 30 or 212; and Chemistry 30 or 212.

BIOL 212.title: Biological Ways of Thinking
BIOL 212.description: An exploration course that is designed to build up knowledge and bridge gaps in biology to prepare students for further study in biology and to meet the biology requirements for their program of study. This course parallels elements from high school biology and introductory university biology with Indigenous Ways of Knowing.
BIOL 212.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biology 20 and admission to an Indigenous Pathway program.

BIOL 213.title: Ecology, Evolution, and the Biosphere
BIOL 213.description: An introduction to evolution, ecological systems, and biodiversity. Major topics include an overview of evolutionary and ecological theory, information flow through inheritance and population biology, phylogenetics, life history strategies, Indigenous perspectives, and the impacts of human activity on biodiversity. Laboratories will explore elements of scientific inquiry through a collaborative research experience that includes quantitative skill development and results dissemination.
BIOL 213.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biology 30 or 212; and Chemistry 30 or 212.

BIOL 297.title: Topics in Biology
BIOL 297.description:
Lectures and study in biological sciences.

Antirequisite(s): Not open for credit to Honours, Majors or Minors in the Department of Biological Sciences or to Natural Sciences program students with a Concentration in Biological Sciences.

Notes: This course is not part of the Field of Biological Sciences.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

BIOL 305.title: The Human Organism
BIOL 305.description: An introduction to human biology that analyzes the structure and function of systems in our bodies. Leads to an appreciation of how the human body maintains itself and carries out the functions necessary to sustain any organism. A course for non-majors that will develop their understanding of the anatomy and physiology of their own species in a zoological and evolutionary context.

BIOL 307.title: Ecology and Human Affairs
BIOL 307.description: The major principles of ecology. How the physical environment affects organisms; behavioural ecology and life histories; species interactions; the biology of populations, communities, and ecosystems; biodiversity and conservation. The non-biologists will gain an understanding of ecological and evolutionary principles that will allow them to better appreciate the natural world, and the increasing environmental impacts of humans.

BIOL 309.title: Plants and People
BIOL 309.description: A review of the structure and function of plants. A survey of the nature of people's basic food plants and an overview of agricultural and forestry practices. Plant improvement by traditional and modern methods, and plant propagation.

BIOL 311.title: Principles of Genetics
BIOL 311.description: Topics will include Mendelian inheritance, allelic relationships, genetic linkage, sex linkage, changes in chromosome structure, segregation and recombination, epistasis, molecular genetics, genetics of bacteria and viruses, gene fine structure, gene function, complementation, bioinformatics and regulation of gene expression. Several selected organisms will be used in the laboratories to illustrate pertinent genetic principles.

BIOL 313.title: Principles of Ecology
BIOL 313.description: The ecological principles, theories and interactions of organisms at individual, population, community and ecosystem levels will be explored. Ecological principles will be applied to examine current issues involving conservation of species, habitats, biodiversity and ecosystem function.

BIOL 315.title: Quantitative Biology I
BIOL 315.description: Data collection, presentation and analysis in the biological sciences. Basic design of biological experiments including concepts of control, replication, and interspersion. Analysis of biological data will include tests of statistical hypotheses and estimation techniques.
BIOL 315.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 6 units from Biology 211, 213, 241 or 243; and 3 units from Mathematics 249 or 265.

BIOL 331.title: Introduction to Cellular and Molecular Biology
BIOL 331.description: The principles of cellular structure and function. Molecular organization of membranes, organelles, nucleus and cytoplasmic structures; the integration of cellular functions; assembly of organelles; the regulation of cell proliferation; and the interaction of cells with their neighbours and their environment.

BIOL 371.title: Comparative Biology of Plants and Animals
BIOL 371.description: An exploration of how multicellular organisms meet the challenges of living, both as individuals, and in an evolutionary context. Parallels and divergence between plants and animals are illustrated in their responses to the challenges they face, with the water-to-land transition forming a central theme in shaping the form and function of plant and animal life.

BIOL 375.title: Insects, Science and Society
BIOL 375.description: Examination of insects as the most diverse and abundant form of animal life on the planet, why they are so successful and how they influence our lives. Topics include how insects are built, what they do, and how they interact with people and have come to be so important economically and culturally, as pests, pollinators, experimental animals, maintaining our environment and forming complex societies. Other topics include evolution of insects, insects in history and culture and how insects can help us address issues such as biological conservation, climate change and animal rights.

BIOL 399.title: Topics in Biology
BIOL 399.description: Exploration of various areas in Biology. Topics will vary from year-to-year. It will be offered as required to provide the opportunity for students to engage in additional areas in Biology.
BIOL 399.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Faculty. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

BIOL 401.title: Evolutionary Biology
BIOL 401.description: An introduction to the micro- and macro-evolutionary processes responsible for the diversity of organisms. Topics include heredity, genetic variation, population structure, genetic drift, natural selection and adaptation, sexual selection, evolution of interactions between species, speciation, phylogeny and biogeography.

BIOL 435.title: Biology of Fungi
BIOL 435.description: Morphology, life history patterns and systematics of fungi. Fungal ecology including fungi as parasites, symbionts and decomposers. Basic molecular biology, genetics and physiology.

BIOL 451.title: Conservation Biology
BIOL 451.description: The application of ecological theory and principles to the conservation and management of natural and modified ecosystems, with emphasis on preservation of biodiversity and sustainable development. Topics include disturbance as an ecological process, ecological and evolutionary responsiveness of natural systems, ecology of resource harvesting, management of endangered habitats and populations, implications of human population growth and global change.

BIOL 453.title: Plants in their Environment
BIOL 453.description: An integration of physiological and ecological aspects of plant adaptation to different environments. Topics include interactions between plants and other organisms (e.g., bacterial and fungal symbionts, animal pollinators, herbivores) as well as the influence of abiotic stressors on plant growth and distribution. The ecological consequences and possible applications of such interactions are discussed.
BIOL 453.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biology 313; and 3 units from Biology 371 or Plant Biology 403.

BIOL 499.title: Topics in Biology
BIOL 499.description: Exploration of various areas in Biology. Topics will vary from year-to-year. It will be offered as required to provide the opportunity for students to engage in additional areas in Biology.
BIOL 499.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Faculty. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

BIOL 501.title: (MDSC 501) Principles and Mechanism of Pharmacology
BIOL 501.description: Basic principles of pharmacology and mechanisms with a focus on pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics, pharmacogenomics, and mechanisms of action and signal transduction pathways for major drug classes. Clinical applications of these pharmacological principles will be explored and may include consideration of sex, genetics, age, adverse drug reactions and disease states.
BIOL 501.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Biochemistry 341 or 393; and Zoology 463 or Medical Science 404.

Also known as: (Medical Science 501)

BIOL 503.title: (MDSC 503) Pharmacology of Organ Systems
BIOL 503.description: Through analysis and discussion of research literature, this course explores topics in pharmacology including the nervous, cardiovascular, renal, respiratory and immune systems, as well as anti-cancer therapies.
BIOL 503.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Biology 501 (Medical Science 501).

Also known as: (Medical Science 503)

BIOL 505.title: Medicinal Plant Biochemistry
BIOL 505.description: Deals with biochemical, molecular, and cellular aspects of plant metabolism, natural product diversity in the plant kingdom, and modern molecular and biochemical methods to understand plant metabolism. The focus is on the metabolic pathways that are either unique to plants, or that exhibit unique features in, plants. Several key plant pathways that produce plant-derived medicines will be discussed.

BIOL 509.title: Advanced Topics in Biological Sciences
BIOL 509.description: Study in advanced topics that may include reading projects, seminars, lectures, term papers and other aspects of training in theory or research methodology.
BIOL 509.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 54 units and consent of the Department. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

BIOL 515.title: (MDSC 515) Cellular Mechanisms of Disease
BIOL 515.description: The cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying basic human disease processes and how these can be influenced by lifestyle and environmental factors. The ways in which this knowledge can be used in the laboratory diagnosis of disease.
BIOL 515.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Biochemistry 341 or 393; and Biology 331 or Medical Science 351.

Also known as: (Medical Science 515)

BIOL 520.title: Field Course in Tropical Biology
BIOL 520.description: An examination of biodiversity in a selected region of the tropics, including aspects of ecology of animals and plants, animal behaviour and an introduction to field techniques for observing and censusing selected taxa. Field studies will take place at diverse habitats with consideration of community-based conservation efforts.

BIOL 528.title: Research Project in Biological Sciences
BIOL 528.description: Research project under the co/supervision of faculty members in the Department of Biological Sciences. Original and independent thought, practical research, and written and oral reports presented on completion of this course.
BIOL 528.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 72 units and consent of the Department.

BIOL 530.title: Honours Research Project in Biological Sciences
BIOL 530.description: Research project under the co/supervision of faculty members in the Department of Biological Sciences. Original and independent thought, practical research, and written and oral reports presented on completion of this course. Open only to Honours Biological Sciences students.
BIOL 530.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 72 units and consent of the Department.

BIOL 591.title: Invertebrate Biodiversity
BIOL 591.description: Field course in the natural history and classification of invertebrates as they are encountered in their natural habitat. Course material will include: techniques for collection and identification of major groups of invertebrates; aspects of behaviour and ecology of local species; use of invertebrates as indicators of environmental change; censusing/monitoring invertebrates populations.

BIOL 599.title: Topics in Biology
