BIOL 599.description: Exploration of various areas in Biology. Topics will vary from year-to-year. It will be offered as required to provide the opportunity for students to engage in additional areas in Biology.
BIOL 599.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Faculty.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT.

BIOL 607.title: Independent Study
BIOL 607.description: Independent research or reading project that may include seminars, term papers and training in theoretical and/or laboratory methods.
BIOL 607.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

BIOL 609.title: Advanced Statistical Applications in Biology
BIOL 609.description: Explains and demonstrates the analysis of biological data with general linear models, generalized linear models, maximum-likelihood fitting of non-linear models, and resampling techniques. Content is presented in a workshop format, so that students learn the application of computer analysis coincidentally with statistical concepts.
BIOL 609.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Ecology 425 or consent of the Department.

BIOL 617.title: Darwin's Origin of Species
BIOL 617.description: An examination of the first edition of Charles Darwin's "On the Origin of Species" and related writings. Students will lead discussions of scientific, philosophical, and other issues raised by the book.

BIOL 619.title: Advanced Evolutionary Biology
BIOL 619.description: The theory of organic evolution. Historical development of evolutionary ideas. Darwin's contribution. The mechanism of natural selection; sexual, kin and group selection. The application of the theory in biogeography, ecology, ethology and other areas of biology.

BIOL 633.title: Special Topics
BIOL 633.description: Topics may include genomics, biotechnology, biochemistry, cell biology, development and evolutionary biology. Emphasis is on technical advances and their application to research.
BIOL 633.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

BIOL 703.title: Recent Advances in Biology
BIOL 703.description:
Lectures, seminars and/or laboratories on special advanced topics in biological sciences. Each student should seek consent of a departmental faculty member who will supervise the chosen study.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

BIOL 507.01.title: Directed Research in Biological Sciences I
BIOL 507.01.description: Directed training in field/laboratory methods and research.
BIOL 507.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 54 units and consent of the Department.

BIOL 507.02.title: Directed Research in Biological Sciences II
BIOL 507.02.description: Directed training in field/laboratory methods and research.
BIOL 507.02.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 54 units and consent of the Department.

BIOL 601.01.title: Biochemistry I
BIOL 601.01.description:
Reports on studies of the literature or of current research. Graduate students normally register in their supervisor's research cluster.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

BIOL 601.02.description:
Reports on studies of the literature or of current research. Graduate students normally register in their supervisor's research cluster.

BIOL 601.03.description:
Reports on studies of the literature or of current research. Graduate students normally register in their supervisor's research cluster.

BIOL 601.04.description:
Reports on studies of the literature or of current research. Graduate students normally register in their supervisor's research cluster.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

BIOL 601.05.title: Ecology & Evolutionary BIOL I
BIOL 601.05.description:
Reports on studies of the literature or of current research. Graduate students normally register in their supervisor's research cluster.

BIOL 601.06.description:
Reports on studies of the literature or of current research. Graduate students normally register in their supervisor's research cluster.

BIOL 601.11.title: Microbiology I
BIOL 601.11.description:
Reports on studies of the literature or of current research. Graduate students normally register in their supervisor's research cluster.

BIOL 601.12.title: Microbiology II
BIOL 601.12.description:
Reports on studies of the literature or of current research. Graduate students normally register in their supervisor's research cluster.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

BIST 600.title: Research Seminar
BIST 600.description:
A professional skills course, focusing on the development of technical proficiencies that are essential for students to succeed in their future careers as practicing statistician in academia, government, or industry. The emphasis is on delivering professional presentations and using modern statistical research tools. A high level of active student participation is required.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

BIST 601.title: Biostatistical Consulting
BIST 601.description: Content covers the  responsibilities, skills, knowledge, and habits of working as a biostatistical consultant  or collaborator. Topics will cover common biostatistical consulting problems as well as  statistical methods, use of various statistical packages and programs  and ethical aspects of consulting. Communication and problem-solving skills will be emphasized, so that students can work cooperatively with and support researchers by conveying concepts and findings in the language of the research problem.
BIST 601.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics.

BIST 610.title: Fundamentals of Biostatistics and Epidemiology
BIST 610.description: Measures of disease occurrence; study design; control of extraneous factors; interaction; exposures at several discrete levels; regression models (linear, log-linear, logistic); logistic regression mode; causal inference and extraneous factors.
BIST 610.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics.

BIST 611.title: Infectious Disease Modelling
BIST 611.description: Population-level ordinary differential equation models; different compartmental frameworks (SEIR, SIRS, stratified models); stochastic population-level models; Bayesian inference and computation; individual level models; spatial models; network-based models; approximate methods of inference; model-based mitigation methods; disease surveillance methods (time series; spatial models)
BIST 611.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics.

BIST 620.01.title: Research Project in Biostatistics I
BIST 620.01.description: Research project in biostatistics carried out by the student under the supervision of a faculty member.
BIST 620.01.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MSc (course-based) in Mathematics and Statistics with a Specialization in Biostatistics, and agreement from a faculty member to supervise the project. 

Note: Students may complete the research project over one term or two terms. Students register in 620.01 in first term and 620.02 in second term.

BIST 620.02.title: Research Project in Biostatistics II
BIST 620.02.description: Research project in biostatistics carried out by the student under the supervision of a faculty member.
BIST 620.02.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MSc (course-based) in Mathematics and Statistics with a Specialization in Biostatistics, and agreement from a faculty member to supervise the project. 

Note: Students may complete the research project over one term or two terms. Students register in 620.01 in first term and 620.02 in second term.

BMEN 300.title: Biology for Engineers
BMEN 300.description:
An introduction to basic biological concepts for engineers. Topics include eukaryotes and prokaryotes, biochemistry, molecular biology, cell biology, cell function, metabolism.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Biomedical Engineering 300 and Biology 331 will not be allowed.

BMEN 301.title: Introduction to Biomedical Engineering
BMEN 301.description: Fundamentals of biological systems and the application of engineering principles to address challenges in human and animal health. The role of the biomedical engineer in society and in the current industrial landscape. Topics include pharmaceuticals and drug delivery, instrumentation and devices, physiological and biological measurements, biomechanics, imaging and diagnostics, the Canadian health-care system. Applications may include the cardiovascular, neural and musculo-skeletal systems.
BMEN 301.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Minor or Major in Biomedical Engineering.

BMEN 309.title: Anatomy and Physiology for Engineers
BMEN 309.description: Physiological terminology and anatomical planes of reference; cell biology and physiology; includes structure and function of musculoskeletal, cardiovascular, nervous, gastrointestinal and respiratory tissues and systems; diseases and disorders of those systems; design constraints for bioengineering products.
BMEN 309.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Minor or Major in Biomedical Engineering.

BMEN 322.title: Biomedical Engineering Processes
BMEN 322.description: Analysis of biomedical engineering processes using material and energy balances and associated physical and biological concepts. Introduction and application of thermodynamics, reaction kinetics and modelling. Introduction to biomanufacturing and biodesign concepts including production of cell-based products.
BMEN 322.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 277; and either Engineering 201 and Chemistry 209; or Engineering 204 and 212

BMEN 381.title: Continuum Mechanics I
BMEN 381.description: Review of linear algebra and introduction to vector calculus. Physical space, bodies, configurations and displacement fields. Velocity and the substantial derivative, acceleration. Deformation and strain, deformation and strain rates. Master balance equation, balance of mass, linear momentum and angular momentum, and control volume analysis. Introduction of stress as the flux of linear momentum, stress transformations, and Mohr's circle. Equations of equivalence in the Saint Venant beam. Constitutive equations: isotropic linear elastic solid, perfect fluid, viscous fluid, Navier-Cauchy equation for isotropic linear elastic solids, Navier-Stokes equation for viscous fluids.

BMEN 383.title: Continuum Mechanics II
BMEN 383.description: Elements of Solid Mechanics: review of axial-force, shear-force, bending moment and torque diagrams, equations of equivalence in the de Saint Venant beam, solution of axial force, torsion, bending, shear force, stress transformation and Mohr's circle, yield criteria, beam deflection and statically indeterminate structures, Euler buckling. Elements of Fluid Mechanics: static forces on surfaces, buoyancy, stability, dimensional analysis and physical similarity, Bernoulli's equation, introduction to external flows and flow through pipes.

BMEN 388.title: Biomedical Signals, Systems and Instrumentation I
BMEN 388.description: Principles of signals and systems in the context of operating principles of biological systems at multiple physiological scales. Impulse response and convolution. Concept of frequency and time domains, Fourier and Laplace transforms for signal and system analysis. System analysis in the frequency domain. Difference equation representation of systems. Stability analysis. Sensors and actuators. Review of circuits and introduction to basic analog signal conditioning amplification and filtering. Noise and mitigation. Programming for signals and systems.

BMEN 401.title: Fundamentals of Biomedical Devices and Technologies
BMEN 401.description: An introduction to the development of biomedical devices and technologies. Topics may include identifying biomedical needs, concept generation and prototyping, biologically inspired design, human factors related to design, regulatory issues, intellectual property protection, clinical trials, and commercialization considerations. Case studies may be drawn from cardiovascular, neural and musculoskeletal applications.
BMEN 401.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biomedical Engineering 301 and admission to the Minor or Major in Biomedical Engineering.

BMEN 415.title: Sensor Systems and Data Analytics
BMEN 415.description: Introduction to matrix and tensor manipulation with focus on computer programming aspects. Sensor systems and design of data collection strategies, with examples in relevant areas of biomedical engineering. Data curation and conditioning including outlier and anomaly pattern detection, noise removal and data reduction. Unsupervised clustering and association mining using machine learning techniques. Supervised classification using advanced machine learning techniques. Completion of a sensor- and data-oriented project in an area of biomedical engineering.
BMEN 415.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 375 and admission to the Minor or Major in Biomedical Engineering.

BMEN 455.title: Transport Phenomena in Biomolecular Systems
BMEN 455.description: Basic concepts in transport phenomena, including fluid dynamics (momentum transport), mass (molecular transport) and heat transfer (energy transport), with applications to biological systems, both medical and non-medical. Topics in fluid dynamics include: properties of Newtonian and non-Newtonian fluids; dimensional analysis; drag; differential/microscopic balances (continuity and Navier-Stokes equations); boundary layer approximations. Topics in mass transfer include transport of chemicals in channels, diffusive and convective molecular transport. Topics in heat transfer include elements of conduction and convection.

BMEN 468.title: Problem-based Biomedical Engineering Design I
BMEN 468.description: Introduction to open-ended biomedical engineering problems: defining the problem, identifying solutions, feasibility analysis, generating concept, modelling, prototyping and testing. Students will work in teams on a series of design projects. Problems to come from BME partners (faculty, local industry). The teams will seek input and feedback from the partner, learn to communicate effectively within and outside the team.

BMEN 478.title: Problem-based Biomedical Engineering Design II
BMEN 478.description: Expanded work on open-ended biomedical engineering problems. Students will identify problems from draft concepts that address new biomedical needs, or around redefinition of current medical devices and technologies. Students will work in teams and apply problem-based learning to address these problems. Problems to come from BME partners and solutions will be presented to these partners.

BMEN 488.title: Biomedical Signals, Systems and Instrumentation II
BMEN 488.description: Discrete-time and discrete-value signals and systems. Introduction to digital signal processing. Digital and mixed-signal circuits. Embedded system programming. Introduction to cellular and molecular instrumentation.

BMEN 500.title: Biomedical Engineering Research Thesis
BMEN 500.description: A research project in an area of interest, directed by a project advisor/faculty member. Includes a lecture component covering the scientific process, ethics, review of literature, and writing scientific proposals and manuscripts. The course culminates with a written thesis and presentation. Projects may involve experimental, analytic or computer modelling studies.
BMEN 500.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Fourth- or fifth-year standing in Schulich School of Engineering and admission to the Biomedical Engineering minor.

BMEN 501.title: Biomedical Engineering Project
BMEN 501.description: A one-term research project in an area of interest, supervised by a project advisor/faculty member. Includes a lecture component covering topics including the scientific process, ethics, review of literature, patent searches, market analysis, and technology evaluation. The project involves working with a supervisor on a particular product, process or theory relevant to biomedical engineering, or refining a methodology or short research project. A final report and presentation are required.
BMEN 501.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Third- or higher-year standing in Schulich School of Engineering.  

Note: To participate in this course, students must secure a supervisor. Students may approach the Department Head or Instructor for assistance if they do not have a supervisor by the start of classes. Students without a supervisor will be removed from the course.

BMEN 503.title: Research Thesis in Biomedical Engineering
BMEN 503.description: A two-term research project in an area of interest, directed by a supervisor (project advisor/faculty member). Includes a lecture component covering the scientific process, ethics, review of literature, and writing scientific proposals and manuscripts. The course culminates with a written thesis and presentation. Projects may involve experimental, analytic or computer modelling studies.
BMEN 503.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Third-year or higher standing in Schulich School of Engineering.

BMEN 509.title: Introduction to Biomedical Imaging and Applications
BMEN 509.description: Principles of various imaging modalities used in Biomedical engineering applications, including CT, MRI, ultrasound, PET, SPECT. Image processing operations: filtering, enhancement, feature extraction, pattern recognition and image reconstruction. Image registration and integration of different imaging modalities.
BMEN 509.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Fourth- or fifth-year standing in Schulich School of Engineering.

BMEN 511.title: Biomaterials and Biocompatibility
BMEN 511.description: Basic chemical and mechanical properties of biological and synthetic materials and their role in biological system health, dysfunction, and repair. Role of microstructure, material properties, and biocompatibility aspects in selection of biomaterials for medical or industrial applications. Incorporation of biomimetic concepts in material design. Topics may include artificial and tissue engineered products, implants, prostheses, biofilms, biosensors, and foreign body response.
BMEN 511.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Fourth- or fifth-year standing in Schulich School of Engineering.

BMEN 515.title: Bioengineering Methods in Systems Biology and Physiology
BMEN 515.description: Concepts from systems theory, differential equations, and stochastic processes applied to physiological and biological systems. Experimental and computational approaches to the study of gene expression and gene networks. Use of quantitative model-based approaches for integrative analysis of physiological and biological functions. Case studies of applications to disease mechanisms and the drug discovery process.
BMEN 515.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 375, Fourth- or fifth-year standing in Schulich School of Engineering.

BMEN 519.title: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering
BMEN 519.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the BMES Director or designate.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

BMEN 523.title: Biomechanics of Movement
BMEN 523.description: Introduction to musculoskeletal biomechanics, including experimental and analytical approaches to the analysis of movement, experimental instrumentation and devices, and joint dynamics. Review of linear algebra. Description of physical space, coordinate systems, optical measurement of marker position. Three-dimensional rigid body kinematics, extraction of the kinematical quantities from the experimental data. Three-dimensional rigid body dynamics, determination of segmental inertial properties, determination of the joint forces and moments, measurement of ground reaction forces, theorem of the impulse. Force sharing problem, method of the Lagrange multipliers, optimisation. Elements of muscle and cartilage mechanics, introduction to the analysis of healthy and pathologic gait. Laboratory experiences complement and reinforce the theory.

BMEN 525.title: Biomechanics of Tissues
BMEN 525.description: The structure and functional behaviour of complex tissues which make up the human musculoskeletal system (bone, cartilage, muscles, tendons, ligaments) and cardiovascular systems (heart, blood vessels) will be explained by applying basic principles of continuum mechanics. Introductory topics include: review of linear and tensor algebra, kinematics of continua, deformation gradient, deformation and strain tensors, balance equations and Cauchy stress tensor, stress power and measures of stress. Constitutive equations introduced as they apply to the study of biological tissues; anisotropy and inhomogeneity, fibre-reinforced behaviour. Laboratory experiences complement and reinforce the theory.

BMEN 585.title: Molecular, Cellular and Tissue Engineering
BMEN 585.description: Concepts and methodologies in molecular and cellular bioengineering. Applications in areas such as tissue engineering, point-of-care diagnostics, organs-on-chips and nanomedicine. Topics include micro-nanoengineering, surface engineering, biomaterials, stem cells, bioreactors, bioengineering scaffolds, and drug delivery.
BMEN 585.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Fourth- or fifth-year standing in Schulich School of Engineering.

BMEN 600.title: Biomedical Engineering Foundations
BMEN 600.description: An introduction to core concepts of Biomedical Engineering including both fundamental biological and engineering knowledge. Course also provides students with both theoretical and practical knowledge related to developing and testing solutions to questions/problems relevant to the biomedical engineering field that is applied in a group project that runs the duration of the course.

BMEN 602.title: Biomedical Engineering Core I
BMEN 602.description:
Focus is on the development of a biomedical engineering career. Topics may include an introduction to a) biomedical engineering research, research integrity and ethics, b) career paths and progression in biomedical engineering and c) oral research communication skills.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

BMEN 604.title: Biomedical Engineering Core II
BMEN 604.description:
Focus is on the academic aspects of graduate school and the preparation of a research proposal. Topics may include an introduction to a) research methodology, including experimental design and b) written research communication skills in biomedical engineering, and c) preparation and review of research proposals.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

BMEN 609.title: Anatomy and Physiology for Biomedical Engineers
BMEN 609.description: Advanced instruction on human skeletal structure, types of connective tissues, structure of joints, muscle and organ structure and function, cardiac physiology, blood properties and flow, introduction to autonomous nervous system, and disorders of the musculoskeletal system. Other topics will be covered dependent on the interests of the instructor and students.

BMEN 619.title: Advanced Topics in Biomedical Engineering
BMEN 619.description:
Designed to provide graduate students, especially at the PhD level, with the opportunity of pursuing advanced studies in particular areas under the direction of a faculty member.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

BMEN 623.title: Medical Imaging
BMEN 623.description:
Introduction to the theory and practical applications of medical imaging with an overview of modern diagnostic imaging techniques. 

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Biomedical Engineering 623 and 509 will not be allowed.

BMEN 624.title: Multiscale Biomechanics
BMEN 624.description: An exploration of how mobility and biomechanics influence the design of health and biomedical technologies. Studies from the molecular, cellular, tissue, organ and organism level with a focus on human health.

BMEN 631.title: Human Factors Engineering and User Centered Design
BMEN 631.description: Students will learn about human cognition and applying those theories to understanding how humans interact with their environment, equipment, and each other to make decisions and complete tasks. With this understanding of human skills and limitations, students will be prepared to design better systems in which healthcare providers work to reduce the likelihood of errors and poor outcomes for patients. The process of design and development will be illustrated and opportunities for end-user participation within the design processes will be highlighted.

BMEN 633.title: Medical Technology Design and Innovation
BMEN 633.description: An introduction to the development of biomedical devices and technologies. Topics may include identifying biomedical needs, concept generation and prototyping, biologically inspired design, regulatory issues, intellectual property protection, clinical trials, commercialization considerations and bringing a technology to market. Experimental design, testing, validation. Case studies may be drawn from cardiovascular, neural and musculoskeletal applications.

BMEN 642.title: Introduction to Scientific Computing
BMEN 642.description:
Fundamental components of a digital engineering system. Basic programming constructs for implementing digital engineering systems. Programming techniques to facilitate data analysis. Obtaining and cleaning data. Data validation. Data visualization. Introduction to basic machine learning techniques and data-driven modeling. Applications chosen from all engineering disciplines.

Also known as: (formerly Biomedical Engineering 619.42 (Intro Scientific Programming))

BMEN 663.title: Biosignals and Bioinstrumentation
BMEN 663.description:
Introduction to the electrocardiogram, electroencephalogram, electromyogram, and other diagnostic signals. Overview of computer techniques for processing and analysis of biomedical signals. Case studies from current applications and research. 

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Biomedical Engineering 663 and 488 will not be allowed.

BMEN 668.title: Integrated Biomedical Engineering Topics I
BMEN 668.description: Determine a real health-care challenge and propose a technology solution from concept to implementation.  Problems will be drawn from industry and animal and human health care providers. Team-based project designed to apply and synthesize previous courses.   Teams will be given the opportunity to prototype their device or a mock-up and present to potential end users.

BMEN 689.title: Advanced Medical Image Processing
BMEN 689.description:
Development of computer-based methods to generate quantitative data from common medical imaging technologies. Traditional and machine learning-based methods of medical image processing and visualization. Techniques and applications covered include image segmentation, image registration, finite element modeling, geometry processing, and deep learning-based image classification and image generation. 

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Biomedical Engineering 689 and Medical Science 689.03 will not be allowed. 

Also known as: (formerly Biomedical Engineering 619.14 (Adv Medical Image Processing))

BTMA 317.title: Introduction to Business Technology Management
BTMA 317.description: Focus is on digital business technology management and enterprise applications. Foundation areas include: digital business strategy, strategy alignment, enterprise analysis, IT platforms, data management, business analytics, IT governance, IT innovation, organizational impacts, and economic considerations. Technical skills are developed with an examination of managerial and leadership issues.
BTMA 317.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Management Studies 217 and Strategy and Global Management 217.

BTMA 321.title: Information Technology in Business
BTMA 321.description: Introduction to the fundamentals of business technology management and how such systems facilitate business transactions and decision-making at all levels of management. Topics examine the development, organization, management, control, and evaluation of information systems. Societal implications of the use of computer and networking technologies in business are also examined.

BTMA 331.title: Data Management and Business Analytics
BTMA 331.description: In today's world, businesses, consumers, and societies create massive amounts of data, by design and as a by-product of their activities. Businesses in every industry are harnessing the power of data to support operations, decision-making, planning, and risk management. Students will focus on organizing, storing, and managing the available data using relational database technologies and generating insights through business analytics techniques.
BTMA 331.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Business Technology Management 317.

Also known as: (formerly Management Information Systems 331)

BTMA 333.title: Enterprise Analysis
BTMA 333.description: Focus is on enterprise analysis and high level design of IT-enabled solutions to business problems. Emphasis is placed on problem identification, requirements determination, system development methodologies, modelling the enterprise architecture (business, information, application, and technology), building the IT business case, IT project management, and change management.
BTMA 333.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Business Technology Management 317.

Also known as: (formerly Management Information Systems 333)

BTMA 431.title: Gathering, Wrangling, and Analyzing Data in R
BTMA 431.description: Introduction to software tools, including R, to clean/organize/analyze data, for graphical analyses, reports, and presentations. Topics include working with API's, advanced data scraping tools, dynamic and interactive visualizations, and implementations of statistical methods in data analytics. Skills are applied to typical business data sources and case studies with presentations.
BTMA 431.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Business Technology Management 317.

BTMA 455.title: Business Technology Management Field Project
BTMA 455.description: Student teams are assigned to organizations in Calgary and the surrounding area to solve specific information and technology issues. Teams investigate the issues and present proposed solutions to the organization contact. Teams will execute the approved project plan and present a final report both orally and in writing to the organization contact. The project may involve interviewing, library and Internet research, and data collection.
BTMA 455.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Business Technology Management 317 and one senior Business Technology Management course.

BTMA 459.title: Decision Support Application Development using VBA Programming
BTMA 459.description: Students will work with Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) to create decision support systems and other applications across Microsoft Office Suite applications. Students will also learn how to use VBA skills to produce business applications. The focus of the course will be the creation of applications that will allow managers to make meaningful decisions using available data like financial and other industry data from both internal and external sources.
BTMA 459.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Business Technology Management 317.

Also known as: (formerly Management Information Systems 459)

BTMA 461.title: IT Platform Management
BTMA 461.description: Technology background related to telecommunications, data communications and IT platforms. Technologies and management issues associated with network models, networking, security and compliance, platform design and competition. Network planning design, integration, implementation, and operation including inter-organizational issues. Current and future issues in organizational implications of telecommunications and IT platform business technologies.
BTMA 461.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Business Technology Management 317.

Also known as: (formerly Management Information Systems 461)

BTMA 463.title: Issues in Business Technology Management
BTMA 463.description: Using an integrated learning approach, students are exposed to issues and emerging issues confronting both information systems managers and functional area managers, incorporating the customer point of view. Emphasis is on the managerial, organizational, and technological issues associated with effective and efficient use of information, technology resources, and IT platforms.
BTMA 463.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Business Technology Management 317.

Also known as: (formerly Management Information Systems 463)

BTMA 465.title: Enterprise Systems
BTMA 465.description: Students will explore the technologies and issues underlying enterprise systems, enterprise application integration, workflow systems, and information analytics. The focus is on strategic, managerial, and technical implications of the use of such systems in organizations. Students will examine the current managerial practices for enterprise system design, implementation, and usage.
BTMA 465.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Business Technology Management 317.

Also known as: (formerly Management Information Systems 465)

BTMA 467.title: e-Business
BTMA 467.description: Role, management and use of information technologies to enable a range of organizational and business relationships, models and strategies. Topics include developing an IT strategy; digital marketing; customer relationship management (CRM); supply chain management (SCM); planning, developing, and maintaining websites cloud computing; IT platforms; legal, privacy, and security issues; and information technologies for facilitating the use of data, knowledge, and multimedia.
BTMA 467.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Business Technology Management 317.

Also known as: (formerly Management Information Systems 467)

BTMA 531.title: Data Analytics Tools for Business
BTMA 531.description: An examination of tools and methods used in data analysis upon which sound business decisions are made. One or more data analysis packages/programs will be used to analyze different types of business data. Statistical and other analytic methods; data mining, machine learning and various techniques, and their application to business data analytics will be explored.
BTMA 531.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Business Technology Management 317.

BTMA 559.title: Selected Topics in Business Technology Management
BTMA 559.description: Discussion of current or special interest topics in Business Technology Management from a managerial orientation.
BTMA 559.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Business Technology Management 317. For certain topics, consent of the Haskayne School of Business will also be required.

BTMA 601.title: Business Technology Management
BTMA 601.description:
The fundamentals of how to use information technology (IT) innovatively to create competitive firms, to manage global interdependencies, and to provide and support quality products and services efficiently and effectively. Topics covered include trends in IT and how they may affect organizations, how organizations and the value chain can be redesigned using IT to encourage and facilitate better performance, how the Internet and electronic commerce impact organizations and markets, how IT-based platforms drive the network economy.

Also known as: (formerly Management Information Systems 601)

BTMA 631.title: Data Management & Business Analytics
BTMA 631.description: Covers organizing, storing, and managing available data using relational database technologies and generating insights through business analytics techniques.
BTMA 631.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Business Technology Management 601.

Also known as: (formerly Business Technology Management 731)

BTMA 635.title: Enterprise Analysis
BTMA 635.description: Course focus is on enterprise analysis and management of IT-enabled solutions to business problems. Emphasis is placed on problem identification, requirements determination, process analysis, enterprise architecture design and IT auditing using the COBIT framework.
BTMA 635.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Business Technology Management 601.

Also known as: (formerly Business Technology Management 735)

BTMA 636.title: Data Analytics I
BTMA 636.description: Covers tools and methods used in data analytics to discover, collect, organize, and clean data to make it ready for analysis. Software packages used to clean and organize the data for analysis will be introduced, as well as software to enable users' understanding of the data that is collected.
BTMA 636.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Business Technology Management 601.

Also known as: (formerly Business Technology Management 736)

BTMA 637.title: Data Analytics II
BTMA 637.description: Covers tools and methods used in data analysis. Focus is on analytic and mapping methods, such as data mining, text mining, machine learning, social network analytics and preference mapping, and their application to business data analytics.
BTMA 637.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Business Technology Management 601.

Also known as: (formerly Business Technology Management 737)

BTMA 661.title: IT Platform Strategy
BTMA 661.description: Basic characteristics of industries based on network and information goods. Topics include platform-mediated networks, network effects, versioning, pricing, and compatibility, discussed through analytical models and business cases.
BTMA 661.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Business Technology Management 601.

Also known as: (formerly Business Technology Management 743)

BTMA 667.title: e-Business
BTMA 667.description: The fundamental theories and practices in e-Business. Topics include economic motivations for e-Business, the underlying information technologies and applications that enable e-Business, and e-Business strategies.
BTMA 667.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Business Technology Management 601.

Also known as: (formerly Business Technology Management 725)

BTMA 668.title: Selected Topics in Business Technology Management
BTMA 668.description: Investigation of selected topics in Business Technology Management.
BTMA 668.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Business Technology Management 601 or consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

BTMA 672.title: IT Management
BTMA 672.description: Builds a basic understanding of IT infrastructure and how infrastructure influences business processes. The managerial issues associated with IT implementation will be discussed.
BTMA 672.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Management program.

BTMA 674.title: IT for Value Innovation
BTMA 674.description: Examines organizational IT strategy and business opportunities created by rapidly evolving information technologies.
BTMA 674.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Management program.

BTMA 797.title: Advanced Seminar in Business Technology Management
BTMA 797.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

Also known as: (formerly Management Information Systems 797)

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

BTMA 799.01.title: PhD Seminar I in Business Technology Management
BTMA 799.01.description: Also known as: (formerly Management Information Systems 799.01)

BTMA 799.02.title: PhD Seminar II in Business Technology Management
BTMA 799.02.description: Also known as: (formerly Management Information Systems 799.02)

BTMA 799.03.title: PhD Seminar III in Business Technology Management
BTMA 799.03.description: Also known as: (formerly Management Information Systems 799.03)

BTMA 799.04.title: PhD Seminar IV in Business Technology Management
BTMA 799.04.description: Also known as: (formerly Management Information Systems 799.04)

CEST 313.title: An Introduction to Cultural Traditions
CEST 313.description:
A survey of Russian and Eastern European cultural history from the settlement of the Slavic peoples to the early twentieth century. Included will be such topics as the ethnic, linguistic, and cultural composition of the region; art and architecture of medieval Russia; the Enlightenment; national revival movements; literature, music and painting; modernism; the cultural efflorescence of the early Soviet period.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Central and East European Studies 313 and History 493.19 will not be allowed.

Notes: May be offered as part of a group study program. Additional fees will be assessed to cover additional costs associated with this course.

CHEM 201.title: General Chemistry: Structure and Bonding
CHEM 201.description: An introduction to university chemistry from theoretical and practical perspectives, that focuses on an exploration of the fundamental links between electronic structure, chemical bonding, molecular structure and the interactions of molecules using inorganic and organic examples.
CHEM 201.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemistry 30 or 212 (or Continuing Education - Chemistry 2) and one of Mathematics 30-1, 212 or Mathematics 2 (offered by Continuing Education).

CHEM 203.title: General Chemistry: Change and Equilibrium
CHEM 203.description: An introduction to university chemistry from theoretical and practical perspectives that focuses on an exploration of the fundamental links between kinetics, equilibria and thermodynamics and explores acidity/basicity and redox behaviour using inorganic and organic examples.
CHEM 203.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemistry 30 or 212 (or Continuing Education - Chemistry 2) and one of Mathematics 30-1, 212 or Mathematics 2 (offered by Continuing Education).

CHEM 209.title: General Chemistry For Engineers
CHEM 209.description: Basic chemical concepts. Atomic and molecular structure. Chemical bonding. Chemical kinetics and equilibria. Acid-base and solubility equilibria. Oxidation-reduction phenomena and electrochemistry. The chemistry of water. The chemistry of energy sources. Basic environmental issues.
CHEM 209.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemistry 30 or 212 (or Continuing Education - Chemistry 2) and one of Mathematics 30-1 or Mathematics 2 (offered by Continuing Education) and admission to the Schulich School of Engineering.

CHEM 211.title: Foundations of Chemistry: Structure and Bonding
CHEM 211.description: Same core topics as Chemistry 201 but taught with a greater emphasis on critical thinking, scientific observation and problem solving and the application of chemistry to topics such as drug design and environmental issues.
CHEM 211.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): A grade of 80 per cent or higher in Chemistry 30 (or a grade of "B+" or higher in one of Chemistry 212 or Continuing Education - Chemistry 2) and one of Mathematics 30-1, 212 or Mathematics 2 (offered by Continuing Education).

CHEM 212.title: Chemical Ways of Thinking
CHEM 212.description: An exploration course that is designed to build up knowledge and bridge gaps in chemistry to prepare students for further study in chemistry and to meet the chemistry requirements for their program of study. This course parallels elements from high school chemistry and introductory university chemistry with Indigenous Ways of Knowing.
CHEM 212.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemistry 20 and admission to an Indigenous Pathway program.

CHEM 213.title: Foundations of  Chemistry: Change and Equilibrium
CHEM 213.description: Same core topics as Chemistry 203 but taught with a greater emphasis on critical thinking, scientific observation and problem solving and the application of chemistry to topics such as materials, explosives and medicine.

CHEM 301.title: The Chemical World
CHEM 301.description:
The focus is on developing a general awareness and appreciation of the chemistry all around us; where chemical principles are surveyed in a variety of current and everyday contexts.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Chemistry 301 and any of 201, 203, 209, 211, 213 or Engineering 204 will not be allowed. Registration in this course is not permitted for Honours, Majors or Minors in Chemistry programs or Environmental Science (Chemistry Concentration) or Natural Sciences (Chemistry Concentration).

Notes: This course is not in the field of Chemistry. May not be used for credit by Honours, Majors or Minors in Chemistry programs or Environmental Science (Chemistry Concentration) or Natural Sciences (Chemistry Concentration).

CHEM 311.title: Analytical Chemistry: Quantitative Analysis
CHEM 311.description: Lectures: Principles and practice of precision measurement in chemistry. Statistical treatment of data. Acid-base and oxidation-reduction equilibria. Complexometric analysis. Laboratory: Quantitative analysis of organic and inorganic materials.
CHEM 311.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemistry 201 or 211; and 203 or 213; and one of Mathematics 249, 265 or 275.

CHEM 315.title: Analy Chem:Intro Instrument Analy
CHEM 315.description: Lectures: Principles and practice of instrumental measurements for the quantitative determination of substances. Spectroscopic analysis. Analytical separations; liquid-liquid extraction, solid phase extraction, chromatography. Electrochemical methods: potentiometry, voltammetry, coulometry. Automated methods of analysis. Laboratory: Quantitative analysis of organic and inorganic materials using simple instrumental techniques.

CHEM 321.title: Environmental Chemistry
CHEM 321.description: A survey course of major aspects of environmental chemistry including the natural chemical cycles in the biosphere, geosphere, hydrosphere and atmosphere and the consequences of anthropogenic disturbances to these cycles. Topics discussed will include: Aquatic Chemistry and water pollution. Atmospheric Chemistry and its alteration. Soil Chemistry and the fate of pollutants. Hazardous waste. Toxicological Chemistry.

CHEM 351.title: Organic Chemistry I
CHEM 351.description: An introduction to Organic Chemistry from a mechanistic perspective. Structure, bonding, and function, e.g. physical properties and reactivity. Stereochemistry; kinetics and thermodynamics. Spectroscopy (nuclear magnetic resonance, infrared, ultra-violet/visible, and mass spectrometric techniques). Substitution and elimination reactions of saturated functional groups - the chemistry of alkanes, alkyl halides, alcohols and their derivatives. Laboratory: Practical techniques.

CHEM 353.title: Organic Chemistry II
CHEM 353.description: The concept and implications of aromaticity. The reactions of unsaturated functional groups via substitution, elimination and addition mechanisms - the chemistry of alkenes, alkynes, aromatics, aldehydes, ketones and carboxylic acids and their derivatives. Laboratory: Characteristic functional group reactivity, synthesis, and qualitative organic analysis.

CHEM 355.title: Organic Chemistry II (for Chemists)
CHEM 355.description: Mechanisms and synthetic applications of the reactions of alkenes, alkynes, aromatics, carbonyl compounds, carboxylic acids and derivatives, and conjugated systems such as 1, 3-dienes and enones. The concept of aromaticity and its effect on chemical behaviour. Laboratory: Emphasis on organic synthesis and the methods of qualitative organic analysis.
CHEM 355.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemistry 201 or 211; and 203 or 213; and 351 and admission to the Chemistry major.

CHEM 357.title: Industrial Organic Chemistry for Engineers
CHEM 357.description: The hybridization of the carbon atom and covalent bonding. Typical reactions of alkanes, alkenes, alkynes and industrial applications. Substitution; halogenation, nitration and oxidation of aromatic hydrocarbons; polymerization and industrial applications. Functional groups and their reactions; oxidation, reduction, addition and elimination reactions, and industrial applications.
CHEM 357.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemistry 209 or Engineering 204; or Chemistry 201 or 211, and 203 or 213.

CHEM 371.title: Physical Chemistry: Thermodynamics Chemistry
CHEM 371.description: Lectures: A study of the states of matter. The basic laws of thermodynamics and their applications. Development of the concept of chemical potential. Changes of state and phase diagrams of pure substances and mixtures. Equilibrium electrochemistry. Laboratory: Experimental measurements, interpretations, and calculations relating to the topics discussed in lectures.
CHEM 371.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemistry 201 or 211; and 203 or 213; Physics 223 or admission to a Major program offered by the Department of Physics and Astronomy and 6 units of Physics; and Mathematics 267 or 277.

CHEM 373.title: Physical Chemistry: Quantum Chemistry
CHEM 373.description: Elementary quantum mechanical treatment of atoms and molecules. Concepts of symmetry and quantization. Laboratory: Simulations, calculations, and interpretations relating to the topics discussed in lectures.
CHEM 373.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemistry 201 or 211; and 203 or 213; Physics 223 or 355; Mathematics 267 or 277.

CHEM 379.title: Materials Chemistry
CHEM 379.description: An introduction to materials chemistry with industrial applications. Theories of chemical bonding and the relationship between chemical structure and observable properties. Chemical and physical properties of mixtures and interfaces. Structure and applications of polymers and soft materials.
CHEM 379.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemistry 209 or Engineering 204; or Chemistry 201 or 211, and 203 or 213.

CHEM 399.title: Topics in Chemistry
CHEM 399.description:
Exploration of various areas in Chemistry. Topics will vary from year-to-year. It will be offered as required to provide the opportunity for students to engage in additional areas in Chemistry.

Prerequisites: Consent of the Faculty.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

CHEM 409.title: Applied Chemistry and Chemical Pathways for Engineers
CHEM 409.description: Analysis of industrial chemical processes based on reaction pathways to infer system performance including co-product formation and the role of catalysts. Examples from oil, gas, coal and petrochemical processing.
CHEM 409.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemistry 209 or Engineering 204; and Chemistry 357.

CHEM 417.title: Modern Chromatographic Analysis
CHEM 417.description: Fundamental concepts and methods of chromatographic separation science: partition theory, sample preparation, chromatographic theory, gas and liquid chromatography, principles of detection. Emerging concepts such as micro-fluidic separation platforms, column technology and novel mobile phases.

CHEM 423.title: Green Chemistry: Principles and Techniques
CHEM 423.description: Green chemistry focuses on best practices for the design of chemical processes and products that are environmentally benign. This course highlights the guiding principles of green chemistry and their application in creating processes that are safer, more efficient, and that reduce waste.

CHEM 425.title: Industrial Chemistry
CHEM 425.description: Electrochemical processes and the applications of some of their products. Unit operations and reactor types in the chemical industry. Petroleum refining including heavy oil and bitumen. Industrial organic synthesis including monomers for subsequent polymerization. Design of specialized polymers.

CHEM 431.title: Inorganic Chemistry: Main Group Elements
CHEM 431.description: Lectures: The structure of many-electron atoms. Bonding, stereochemistry and symmetry in inorganic compounds. Solid-state science and aspects of inorganic solution chemistry. The chemistry of the main group elements. Laboratory: Applications of chemical principles to inorganic synthetic and qualitative analytical problems.
CHEM 431.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Chemistry 201 or 211; and 203 or 213;, and 351. 

Also known as: (formerly Chemistry 331)

CHEM 433.title: Inorganic Chemistry: Transition Metals
CHEM 433.description: Lectures: Bonding models for metals and for transition metal compounds. Interpretation of redox and thermodynamic properties based on ligand field theory. Coordination and organometallic compounds of the transition metals. Metal complexes as catalysts in industry and biology. Laboratory: Synthesis, analysis, and physical investigations of transition metal compounds which illustrate their important properties.
CHEM 433.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Chemistry 201 or 211, and 203 or 213, and 331 or 431. 

Also known as: (formerly Chemistry 333)

CHEM 453.title: Advanced Organic Chemistry
CHEM 453.description: Introduction to MO theory.  Pericyclic reactions, the Woodward-Hoffmann rules. Photochemistry. Elucidation of reaction mechanism, reactive intermediates. Laboratory:  Multi step synthesis and computer modelling of organic reactions.

CHEM 471.title: Physical Chemistry: Kinetics and Spectroscopy
CHEM 471.description: Vibrational, electronic and magnetic resonance spectra. Reaction kinetics and transport properties in the gas phase and in solution. Catalysis. Laboratory: Experimental measurements, interpretations, and calculations relating to the topics discussed in lectures.

CHEM 499.title: Topics in Chemistry
CHEM 499.description:
Exploration of various areas in Chemistry. Topics will vary from year-to-year. It will be offered as required to provide the opportunity for students to engage in additional areas in Chemistry.

Prerequisites: Consent of the Faculty.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT.

CHEM 502.title: Research In Chemistry
CHEM 502.description: Research project in a specific field of chemistry under direction of a faculty member in the Department of Chemistry. Original and independent thought, practical research, and a written thesis and oral presentations on completion of this course.

CHEM 515.title: Advanced Instrumental Analysis
CHEM 515.description: Lectures: Fundamental aspects of modern instrumental methods. Spectroscopic methods: UV-visible and atomic absorption spectroscopy, flame and plasma emission methods. Chromatographic methods; liquid and gas chromatography. Mass spectrometry. Laboratory: Analysis of inorganic and organic samples using spectroscopic, electrochemical, and chromatographic instrumental methods.

CHEM 521.title: Introduction to Atmospheric Chemistry
CHEM 521.description: An introduction to Tropospheric and Stratospheric Chemistry. The detailed chemistry of the stratosphere and troposphere. Gas-phase chemical kinetics. Photochemistry and atmospheric radiation. Aerosols. Anthropogenic pollution and air quality. Climate forcing. Introduction to modelling and atmospheric transport.

CHEM 531.title: Advanced Inorganic Chemistry: Transition Metals
CHEM 531.description: Co-ordination and organometallic chemistry of the transition elements, incorporating the lanthanoids and actinoids. Fundamental and applied aspects, including characterization techniques, reaction mechanisms, catalysis and bioinorganic chemistry.
CHEM 531.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemistry 331 or 431; and 333 or 433; and one of 353 or 355.

CHEM 533.title: Advanced Inorganic Chemistry: Main Group Elements
CHEM 533.description: Chemistry of the s- and p-block elements. Interpretation of nuclear magnetic resonance, electron paramagnetic resonance, vibrational and mass spectra. Fundamental concepts and industrial uses of inorganic heterocycles and polymers, electron-deficient and organometallic compounds. Solid-state chemistry.
CHEM 533.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemistry 331 or 431; and 333 or 433; and one of 353 or 355.

CHEM 535.title: Advanced Inorganic Laboratory
CHEM 535.description: Advanced laboratory techniques for the synthesis and characterization of main group compounds, organometallics and solid-state materials using modern spectroscopic and structural methods. Includes a short project.
CHEM 535.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemistry 431, 433 and 453; and admission to the Chemistry major.

CHEM 541.title: (BCEM 541) Concepts in Biochemical Toxicology
CHEM 541.description: An interdisciplinary course focused on the diverse biomolecular mechanisms by which organic (e.g. PCB's) and inorganic pollutants (e.g. Cd, Hg, As) adversely affect cell function examined at multiple levels of organization, from molecules to whole organisms. Topics include how natural toxins exert toxicity, how toxins/light generate free radicals within cells, how the speciation of metals in the environment affects their bioavailability/toxicity, and the toxicity mechanisms that lead to homeostatic dysfunction.
CHEM 541.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemistry 311, 321 and 351; and one of Biochemistry 341 or 393.

CHEM 551.title: Organic Synthesis
CHEM 551.description: Concepts and strategies of synthesizing molecules with emphasis on carbon-carbon bond-forming reactions, protecting groups, chemo-, regio- and stereoselectivity

CHEM 552.title: Medicinal Chemistry
CHEM 552.description: Introduction to concepts in medicinal chemistry with a focus on synthesis while including lead discovery and rational drug design. Basic metabolism, physiochemical properties, and structural alerts in the context of drug development.
CHEM 552.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Chemistry 351 and 353

Also known as: (formerly Chemistry 599.21 Medicinal Chemistry)

CHEM 553.title: Bio-Organic Chemistry
CHEM 553.description: Organic chemistry applied to the understanding of biomolecules: selected topics from carbohydrate, peptide/protein, lipid and nucleoside chemistry, enzyme inhibition and drug design.

CHEM 555.title: Advanced Organic Laboratory
CHEM 555.description: Advanced laboratory techniques: Methods of purification and identification of products, purification of reagents, experimental design, working with air/moisture sensitive reagents. Includes a short research project.
CHEM 555.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemistry 453 and admission to the Chemistry major.

CHEM 559.title: Organic Spectroscopy
CHEM 559.description: The instrumentation, theory and practical aspects of spectroscopy (e.g. UV/vis, MS, IR, 1H and 13C NMR including 2D-techniques). The emphasis will be on the application for structural elucidation through a problem-solving approach.
CHEM 559.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemistry 351, and one of 353 or 355.

CHEM 571.title: Physical Chemistry Of Interfaces
CHEM 571.description: The chemical and electrical nature, as well as basic thermodynamics, of interfaces. Surface films and aqueous interfaces, including micelles and bilayers. Interfaces involving solids such as metals and semiconductors. Absorption phenomena and surface catalysis. Survey of experimental approaches for interfacial studies.

CHEM 573.title: Nature Condensed Phase Chemistry
CHEM 573.description: Theoretical models of liquids and solids. Dielectric continuum, polarizabilities and magnetism. Ionic crystal, insulators, conductors, semiconductors and super conductors.  Some aspects of scattering techniques for structure determination.

CHEM 575.title: Adv Electronic Structure Theory
CHEM 575.description: A discussion of the theories of modern electronic structure illustrated by applications to molecular structure and bonding, electronic spectroscopy, as well as chemical reactivity and dynamics.

CHEM 579.title: Surface and Colloid Chemistry for Engineers
CHEM 579.description: Introduces the fundamental and applied aspects of interfacial phenomena including capillarity, surface and interfacial tension, films, wetting and contact angles, adsorption, micellization, solubilization and emulsification. Examples drawn from colloids, foams, aerosols and macromolecules.
CHEM 579.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemistry 357 or 379; and Chemical Engineering 327.

CHEM 599.title: Selected Topics in Chemistry
CHEM 599.description: Study in advanced topics that may include reading projects, seminars, lectures, term papers and other aspects of training in theory or research methodology.
CHEM 599.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Faculty.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

CHEM 601.title: Research Seminar
CHEM 601.description: Reports on studies of the literature or of current research. Required of all graduate students in Chemistry.
CHEM 601.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s):  Consent of the Department.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

CHEM 603.title: Research Seminar
CHEM 603.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s):  Consent of the Department.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

CHEM 613.title: Electrochem Fund & Methodologies
CHEM 613.description: Origin, significance, and thermodynamics of interfacial potential differences; structure of the double layer; basic principles of electron transfer at interfaces, Butler-Volmer equation; mass transport control of electro-chemical reactions; controlled potential methods as applied to electrode surface reactions and homogeneous reactions coupled to electron-transfer processes.

CHEM 615.title: Analytical Separations
CHEM 615.description: Theory and practice of resolving mixtures into separate components for analysis. Basic theory; liquid-liquid extraction; high performance liquid chromatography; gas-liquid, open bed, ion exchange and exclusion chromatography; electrophoresis.

CHEM 617.title: Advanced Analytical Chemistry
CHEM 617.description: Consideration of principles and equilibria pertaining to aqueous and nonaqueous neutralization, redox, complexation, precipitation and potentiometric methods employed in analyses. Statistical considerations of analytical data and analysis.

CHEM 621.title: Organometallic Chemistry
CHEM 621.description: A detailed discussion of structure, bonding and preparative methods in organometallic chemistry including the industrial and synthetic applications of organometallic compounds.

CHEM 623.title: Chem Of The Main Group Elements
CHEM 623.description: The chemistry of electron-deficient, electron-precise, and electron-rich rings, inorganic polymers, and organometallic compounds of the main group elements; applications of spectroscopic techniques; industrial uses. Seminars on recent research developments.

CHEM 627.title: Theoretical Inorganic Chemistry
CHEM 627.description: Aspects of theoretical inorganic and organometallic chemistry including: quantitative and qualitative molecular orbital theory; the bonding and structure of molecules, clusters, and extended arrays; the fragments of organometallic species; orbital correlation diagrams in inorganic reactions; spectroscopic methods and their interpretation.

CHEM 630.title: Separations
CHEM 630.description: Basic theory and practice of resolving mixtures into separate components for analysis. Conventional methods of liquid and gas chromatography are examined. Modern alternative approaches such as electrophoresis and others may also be covered.

CHEM 631.title: Analytical Spectroscopy
CHEM 631.description: Topics may include electromagnetic spectrum, transitions and selection rules, instrumentation, atomic spectroscopy, molecular absorption, fluorescence, vibrational spectroscopy, applications of optical spectroscopy.

CHEM 632.title: Bioanalytical
CHEM 632.description: Application of advanced bioanalytical techniques for analysis of complex biological fluids, cell lysates and whole cell/tissue imaging techniques for relevant biomolecules will be covered. The diverse nature of available bio-analytes and essential sample preparation and chromatographic/electrophoretic bio-separation techniques will also be examined. Means of achieving qualitative and quantitative bio-analyte identification, common measurement pitfalls, and data interpretation in a biological context will be covered.

CHEM 633.title: Analytical Mass Spectrometry
CHEM 633.description: Theoretical and practical aspects of modern mass spectrometric techniques are covered. The design of mass spectrometry methods to obtain analyte structural information is also examined, as are the skills necessary in acquiring, analyzing, and interpreting mass spectrometric data. Modern hyphenated methods may also be explored.

CHEM 634.title: Electrochemistry
CHEM 634.description: This course provides introduction to the theory behind the thermodynamics, kinetics, and mass transport of electrochemical systems.  Experimental techniques such as potentiometry and cyclic voltammetry will also be covered.  Applications for real world systems and current literature may be discussed.

CHEM 635.title: Structure of Materials
CHEM 635.description: Theory and application of techniques such as X-ray diffraction, EXAFS, PDF, SAXS, and SEM/TEM, which are used to determine the structures of amorphous, nanocrystalline, porous, and crystalline materials will be discussed.

CHEM 636.title: Properties of Materials
CHEM 636.description: The theoretical origins of the properties of materials will be covered.  Examples include but are not limited to magnetism, conductivity, ferroelectric/piezoelectric, and optical properties.

CHEM 637.title: Hands on Materials
CHEM 637.description: This course focuses on the use of instrumentation pertaining to measuring materials structure/properties.  Examples include the SEM/AFM instruments in the NANS facility.

CHEM 638.title: Asymmetric Catalysis
CHEM 638.description: A description of stereochemical principles in organic chemistry, as well as their application to catalytic asymmetric and stereo-controlled reactions.

CHEM 639.title: Mass Spectrometry
CHEM 639.description: A survey of various mass spectrometric techniques applicable to the structure determination of various organic molecules.

CHEM 640.title: NMR
CHEM 640.description: Advanced NMR techniques for the determination of complex organic structures. Emphasis will be on practical aspects of acquiring spectra, advanced interpretation and reporting spectral data.

CHEM 641.title: Biochemical Toxicology
CHEM 641.description:
An interdisciplinary course focused on the diverse biomolecular mechanisms by which organic (e.g. PCB's) and inorganic pollutants (e.g. Cd, Hg, As) adversely affect cell function examined at multiple levels of organization, from molecules to whole organisms. Topics include how natural toxins exert toxicity, how toxins/light generate free radicals within cells, how the speciation of metals in the environment affects their bioavailability/toxicity, and the toxicity mechanisms that lead to homeostatic dysfunction.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Chemistry 641 and either Chemistry 541 or Biochemistry 541 will not be allowed.

CHEM 642.title: Total Synthesis
CHEM 642.description: A review of modern synthetic techniques in organic chemistry with emphasis on recent literature in the total synthesis of new complex molecules.

CHEM 643.title: Organometallic Synthesis
CHEM 643.description: A description of the bonding theory, properties, and synthetic methodology specific to the transition elements, with focus on modern developments and practical applications.

CHEM 644.title: Main Group Synthesis
CHEM 644.description: An incursion into the bonding theory, properties, and synthetic methodology specific to Group 1-2 and 13-18 elements, with focus on modern developments and practical applications.

CHEM 645.title: Catalysis
CHEM 645.description: A review of the principles and applications of metal-based catalysis, exemplified with classic processes and modern case studies.

CHEM 646.title: Tools for Mechanistic Study
CHEM 646.description: A survey of the modern theoretic and experimental methodology used to probe the mechanism of chemical reactions.

CHEM 647.title: Machine Learning in Chemistry
CHEM 647.description: A description of the basic types of machine learning (supervised, unsupervised, and reinforcement learning) complemented by examples of their application in chemistry. An overview of how these approaches 'learn' from data is described, as are common pitfalls encountered when putting them into practice.

CHEM 648.title: Density Functional Theory
CHEM 648.description: An applied introduction to density functional theory. Modern methods that are widely used are introduced, along with a discussion of their strengths and weaknesses, as demonstrated by applications seen in current literature.

CHEM 649.title: Surface Science
CHEM 649.description: An introduction to the theory of surface phenomena and methods pertinent to surface analysis, and how the behavior of atoms and molecules differ from the bulk. The basic principles of heterogeneous catalysis are described.

CHEM 650.title: Computational Packages
CHEM 650.description: An introduction to useful and time saving methods for data analysis and visualization found in widely available and/or open-source computational packages.

CHEM 651.title: Advanced Organic Stereochemistry
CHEM 651.description: Stereochemical principles in organic chemistry, including: geometry, bonding, symmetry, molecular isomerism, conformational analysis, asymmetric and stereocontrolled reactions.

CHEM 652.title: Special Topics in Modern Chemistry
CHEM 652.description: Topics include: analytical chemistry, inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry, organic chemistry, applied chemistry, and physical chemistry.

CHEM 653.title: Advanced Organic Spectroscopy
CHEM 653.description: Advanced spectroscopic techniques for the determination of complex organic structures. Emphasis will be on NMR methods, practical aspects of acquiring spectra, advanced interpretation and reporting spectral data.

CHEM 654.title: Mentoring and Collaboration in Chemistry
CHEM 654.description:
This course will teach first year graduate students the skills required for successful mentorship as both a mentor and mentee. It will also address collaborating with colleagues in diverse settings and applying these skills to their future career.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

CHEM 655.title: Advanced Organic Synthesis
CHEM 655.description: A review of modern synthetic reactions and methods in the field or organic chemistry with emphasis on the recent literature.

CHEM 657.title: Theoretical Organic Chemistry
CHEM 657.description: Theoretical principles of organic chemistry including stereochemistry, molecular orbital calculations, pericyclic processes (Woodward-Hoffmann rules), and PMO theory.

CHEM 681.title: Crystallography
CHEM 681.description: A general introduction to X-ray analysis of single crystals. Topics  include: Geometry of the crystalline state; diffraction of X-rays; Fourier synthesis; methods of structure solution; accuracy and precision of derived parameters.

CHEM 697.title: Special Topics
CHEM 697.description: Topics include: analytical chemistry, inorganic chemistry, organic chemistry, applied chemistry, and physical chemistry.
CHEM 697.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

CHEM 698.title: Independent Study
CHEM 698.description: Independent study under the direction of any chemistry faculty member. A course information sheet must be provided and a student report must be submitted on completion of the course.
CHEM 698.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

CHEM 402.01.title: Introduction to Research in Chemistry I
CHEM 402.01.description: A chemistry-based research project under the supervision of an academic staff member.
CHEM 402.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemistry 201 or 211, and 203 or 213, and consent of the Department.

CHEM 402.02.title: Introduction to Research in Chemistry II
CHEM 402.02.description: A chemistry-based research project under the supervision of an academic staff member.
CHEM 402.02.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemistry 201 or 211, and 203 or 213, and consent of the Department.

CHIN 205.title: Beginners' Chinese I
CHIN 205.description: Basic concepts of the Chinese National Language. Reading and writing of characters, essentials of grammar, basic vocabulary, and oral drills on normal speech patterns.
CHIN 205.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

CHIN 229.title: Intensive Beginners' Chinese
CHIN 229.description: Intensive development of conversational skills and the pronunciation of the Chinese National Language. Enhanced training in vocabulary acquisition, grammar and writing. For students with a background in a Chinese dialect.
CHIN 229.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

CHIN 280.title: Chinese Language in an Immersion Setting Beginners I
CHIN 280.description: An introductory course in Chinese stressing oral and aural skills in an immersion setting.
CHIN 280.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

CHIN 281.title: Chinese Language in an Immersion Setting Beginners II

CHIN 301.title: Continuing Chinese I
CHIN 301.description: Further acquisition of Chinese characters, and the development of conversational skills through reading and discussion of selected Chinese texts. Structural analysis of normal speech patterns. Preparation of written assignments. A continuation of Chinese 207.
CHIN 301.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chinese 207 or consent of the Department.

CHIN 303.title: Continuing Chinese II
CHIN 303.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chinese 301 or consent of the Department.

CHIN 304.title: Chinese Language in an Immersion Setting Continuing I
CHIN 304.description: A continuing-level course in Chinese stressing oral and aural skills in an immersion setting.
CHIN 304.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

CHIN 305.title: Chinese Language in an Immersion Setting Continuing II

CHIN 310.title: Topics in Chinese Culture in an Immersion Setting
CHIN 310.description: An introduction to contemporary Chinese culture and functional Chinese language.
CHIN 310.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

CHIN 317.title: Topics in Chinese Civilization
CHIN 317.description:
Distinctive features of Chinese civilization within the Asian context.

Notes: Taught in English.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

CHIN 331.title: Intermediate Chinese I
CHIN 331.description: An intermediate course giving equal emphasis to receptive and productive language skills.
CHIN 331.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chinese 303 or consent of the Department.

CHIN 333.title: Intermediate Chinese II
CHIN 333.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chinese 331 or consent of the Department.

CHIN 334.title: Chinese Language in an Immersion Setting Intermediate I
CHIN 334.description: An intermediate-level course in Chinese stressing oral and aural skills in an immersion setting.
CHIN 334.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

CHIN 335.title: Chinese Language in an Immersion Setting Intermediate II

CHIN 341.title: Introduction to Chinese Literature
CHIN 341.description: Introduction to Chinese literature through the reading and discussion of selected literary works.

CHIN 353.title: Introduction to Chinese Language and Linguistics
CHIN 353.description: An overview of Chinese linguistics. Provides an introduction to linguistic concepts and topics to enhance understanding of the structure of the Chinese language.

CHIN 355.title: Topics in Chinese Literature in Translation
CHIN 355.description:
Introduces the literary tradition of China by means of reading the English translations of representative works. Examines the historical and cultural background, as well as literary forms and aesthetics.

Notes: Taught in English.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

CHIN 357.title: Topics in Chinese Film
CHIN 357.description:
Chinese film from the perspectives of film theory and political and cultural history. The course may concentrate on a specific director, a period, or a genre in Chinese film.

Notes: Taught in English.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

CHIN 363.title: Chinese Language in the Cultural Context
CHIN 363.description: Study of the use and function of the Chinese language in its cultural context.
CHIN 363.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chinese 207 or consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

CHIN 371.title: Classical Chinese I
CHIN 371.description: An introduction to the grammar and vocabulary of the classical Chinese language. Readings of short texts selected from famous classical works.

CHIN 373.title: Classical Chinese II
CHIN 373.description: Further study of the grammar and vocabulary of the classical Chinese language. Readings of short texts selected from famous classical works.

CHIN 401.title: Advanced Chinese Conversation
CHIN 401.description: Development of Chinese oral communication skills through contemporary film, television programs and/or other audio materials.

CHIN 403.title: Advanced Readings and Writing in Modern Chinese
CHIN 403.description: Development of Chinese reading and writing skills on the basis of newspapers, magazines, social commentary and/or literary works.

CHIN 411.title: Foundations of Chinese Language Learning and Teaching
CHIN 411.description: Addresses theories in learning and teaching Chinese as a second/foreign language. Examines fundamental concepts and critical issues in the field such as learner strategies, motivation and teaching methods.

CHIN 412.title: Aspects of Chinese Language Teaching and Learning
CHIN 412.description: Addresses practice in learning and teaching Chinese as a second/foreign language.

CHIN 413.title: Topics in Experiential Chinese Language Teaching
CHIN 413.description: A course that integrates experiential teaching and explains how societal, educational and pragmatic contexts affect Chinese language teaching.

CHIN 431.title: Selected Topics in Chinese Literature
CHIN 431.description: Selected readings on various literary topics, such as contemporary Chinese literature, the Chinese diaspora experience, or readings by specific authors.
CHIN 431.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Chinese 403.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

CHIN 461.title: (JPNS 461) Japanese-Chinese Cultural Relations
CHIN 461.description: Discussion of the cultural relations and influences between Japan and China. Topics may include cultural identities and cross-influences, literary and artistic traditions, writing systems.
CHIN 461.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chinese 303 or higher (excluding Chinese 317 and Chinese 355).

CHIN 561.title: Research Seminar
CHIN 561.description: Engages senior students as members of a collaborative research team. Independent research, discussion, group presentations.

CMCL 201.title: Culture Foundations
CMCL 201.description:
A critical and inter-disciplinary examination, via classic texts, of the Greco-Roman and Judeo-Christian Heritage of Western Civilization (e.g., Homer, Sophocles, Plato, Augustine). Focus on major ideas, principles and their implications within the time frame of the Ancient and Medieval periods (i.e., 3000 B.C.E.--400 C.E.) and in comparison with non-Western traditions.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Communication and Culture 201 and 301 will not be allowed.

CMCL 203.title: Roads to Modernity
CMCL 203.description:
