Antirequisite(s): Credit for Computer Science 609 and either Computer Science 567 or Software Engineering 697 will not be allowed for programs offered by the Department of Computer Science.

CPSC 610.title: Compiler Code Generation and Optimization
CPSC 610.description:
Compiler code generation and optimization techniques, including register allocation, instruction selection, dataflow analysis, and code optimization techniques using intermediate representations. Implementation of special language features and tools for automated code generation.				

Notes: Lectures may run concurrently with the first semester of Computer Science 510[CPSC510].

CPSC 611.title: Complexity Theory
CPSC 611.description:
Deterministic and non-deterministic time and space complexity; complexity classes and hierarchies; NP-complete problems and intractable problems; axiomatic complexity theory.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Computer Science 611 and Computer Science 511 will not be allowed.

Notes: Computer Science 413 or equivalent is recommended as preparation for this course.

CPSC 615.title: Computational Techniques for Graphics and Visualization
CPSC 615.description:
Various case studies from the fields of graphics and visualization. Topics in numerical linear algebra, numerical optimization, and discrete differential geometry.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Computer Science 615 and 601.13 will not be allowed. 

Notes: Computer Science 453 or equivalent is recommended as preparation for this course.

CPSC 617.title: Category Theory For Cpsc
CPSC 617.description:
Introduction to category theory with applications in computer science. Functors, natural transformations, adjoints and monads, initial and final algebras. Introduction to 2-categories and fibrations.				

Notes: Computer Science 417, 513[CPSC513], 521[CPSC521] or equivalent is recommended as preparation for this course.

CPSC 619.title: Quantum Computation
CPSC 619.description:
Introduction to quantum computing. Quantum algorithms, quantum search, quantum Fourier transforms, quantum error correcting codes, quantum cryptography, nonlocality and quantum communication complexity, and quantum computational complexity.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Computer Science 619 and 519 will not be allowed.

Notes: Computer Science 413 or equivalent is recommended as preparation for this course.

CPSC 622.title: Randomized Algorithms
CPSC 622.description:
Design and analysis of randomized algorithms; discrete probability theory; randomized data structures; lower bound techniques; randomized complexity classes; advanced algorithmic applications from various areas.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Computer Science 622 and 522 will not be allowed.

CPSC 625.title: Principles of Computer Security
CPSC 625.description:
Security policies and protection mechanisms for a computing system, including such topics as design principles of protection systems, authentication and authorization, reference monitors, security architecture of popular platforms, formal modelling of protection systems, discretionary access control, safety analysis, information flow control, integrity, role-based access control. Legal and ethical considerations will be introduced as necessary.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Computer Science 625 and 525 will not be allowed.

CPSC 626.title: Network Systems Security
CPSC 626.description:
Attacks on networked systems, tools and techniques for detection and protection against attacks including firewalls and intrusion detection and protection systems, authentication and identification in distributed systems, cryptographic protocols for IP networks, security protocols for emerging networks and technologies, privacy enhancing communication. Legal and ethical issues will be introduced as necessary.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Computer Science 626 and 526 will not be allowed.

CPSC 629.title: Elliptic Curves and Cryptography
CPSC 629.description: An introduction to elliptic curves over the rationals and finite fields. The focus is on both theoretical and computational aspects; subjects covered will include the study of endomorphism rings, Weil pairing, torsion points, group structure, and effective implementation of point addition. Applications to cryptography will be discussed, including elliptic curve-based Diffie-Helman key exchange, El Gamal encryption, and digital signatures, as well as the associated computational problems on which their security is based.

CPSC 630.title: Information Theory and Security
CPSC 630.description:
Information theoretic concepts such as entropy and mutual information, and their applications to defining and evaluating information security systems including encryption, authentication, secret sharing and secure message transmission.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Computer Science 630 and 530 will not be allowed.

CPSC 635.title: Image Analysis and Computer Vision
CPSC 635.description:
Standard methods used in the analysis of digital images. Image acquisition and display: visual perception; digital representation. Sampling and enhancement. Feature extraction and classification methods. Object recognition.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Computer Science 635 and 535 will not be allowed.

CPSC 641.title: Perform Issues High Spd Networks
CPSC 641.description: An overview of current research in high speed networks. Topics covered will include the current Internet, the future Internet, wireless networks, optical networks, Asynchronous Transfer Mode (ATM), TCP/IP, network traffic measurement, Web server performance, and mobile computing. Emphasis will be placed on network performance issues for next-generation Internet protocols and applications.

CPSC 643.title: Modern Wireless Networks
CPSC 643.description: An introduction to the fundamentals and applications of wireless networks.

CPSC 653.title: Computational Geometry
CPSC 653.description: Geometric searching, hull proximity and intersection data structures and algorithms and their complexity.

CPSC 656.title: Machine Learning in Biometric and Cybersecurity
CPSC 656.description:
Principles of machine learning in biometric system design. Multi-modal, trustworthy and fuzzy decision fusion. Traditional machine learning methods and modern deep learning architectures. Applications in image processing, pattern recognition, data mining, medicine, human-computer interaction, oil and gas exploration, defense and cybersecurity.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Computer Science 656 and 556 will not be allowed.

Also known as: (formerly Computer Science 601.57)

CPSC 657.title: Modeling & Visualization Of Plant
CPSC 657.description:
Modeling And Visualization of Plants
Modeling, simulation and visualization of plants for computer graphics and biological purposes. Modeling of plants as an example of interdisciplinary research including computer science, biology, mathematics and physics. L-systems as a formal basis for model construction. Modeling languages. Information flow in plants.  Symmetry, self-similarity and allometry of plants. Descriptive models of plant architecture. Models integrating plant structure and function.  Simulation of plant development. Case studies: competition for space, phyllotaxis, tropisms, and biomechanical considerations. Reaction-diffusion models of morphogensis. Genotype-to-phenotype mapping.  Modeling of plant ecosystems. Rendering and visualization of the models. A survey of applications and research directions.

Notes: Computer Science 453 or 553 is recommended as preparation for computer science students taking this course.

CPSC 661.title: Algorithms for Distributed Computation
CPSC 661.description:
Fundamental algorithmic problems in distributed computation; impact of communication, timing, failures and other characteristics on computability and complexity of solutions.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Computer Science 661 and 561 will not be allowed.

CPSC 662.title: Agent Communications
CPSC 662.description:
An examination of communication paradigms in multi-agent systems. A number of paradigms will be covered including simple protocols, BDI (Believe, Desire, Intension), and social commitments.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Computer Science 662 and 568 will not be allowed.

CPSC 667.title: Computer Algebra
CPSC 667.description:
Fundamental problems, classical and modern algorithms, and algorithm design and analysis techniques of use in computer algebra. Integer and polynomial arithmetic. Additional problems in computer algebra, possibly including problems in computational linear algebra, factorization, and concerning systems of polynomial equations will be considered as time permits.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Computer Science 667 and 518 will not be allowed. 

Notes: Computer Science 413, 491 and Pure Mathematics 315, or equivalents, are recommended as preparation for this course.

CPSC 669.title: Cryptography
CPSC 669.description: An overview of the basic techniques in modern cryptography, with emphasis on fit-for-application primitives and protocols. Topics will include symmetric and public-key cryptosystems; digital signatures; elliptic curve cryptography; key management; attack models and well-defined notions of security.

CPSC 671.title: Database Management Systems
CPSC 671.description:
Design and implementation of modern database systems, including storage and indexing, query modification/optimization, recovery, concurrency, integrity, and distribution. Emphasis on data analysis, blockchain databases, and NoSQL databases. 

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Computer Science 671 and 571 will not be allowed.

CPSC 672.title: Fundamentals of Social Network Analysis and Data Mining
CPSC 672.description:
Introduction to data mining with emphasis on frequent pattern mining, clustering and classification, data collection, network construction, basic graph theory concepts and network analysis metrics, and case studies. 

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Computer Science 672 and 572 will not be allowed. 

Also known as: (formerly Computer Science 601.77)

CPSC 673.title: Distributed Database Systems
CPSC 673.description: Introduction to distributed database systems. Topics covered include: architecture, data design, query processing, transaction management, multidatabases, object-oriented databases and advanced system issues.

CPSC 681.title: Res Method In Human-Comp Interact
CPSC 681.description: Application of the theory and methodology of human-machine studies to real systems; theory and practice.

CPSC 682.title: Independent Research Project
CPSC 682.description: A research project conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. A report must be presented on completion of the course.
CPSC 682.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department

MAY BE REPEATED ONCE FOR CREDIT

CPSC 683.title: Information Visualization: Theory and Practice
CPSC 683.description:
The theory and development of interactive visual representations of abstract data for the purpose of amplifying cognition. Topics covered can include representational issues, perceptual issues, visual literacy, spatial abstraction, and interaction issues.

Notes: CPSC 583 or equivalent is recommended as preparation for this course.

CPSC 685.title: Developing Serious Extended Reality & Immersive Analytics Applications
CPSC 685.description:
The principles, technologies, and evaluation methodologies involved in developing applications for serious extended reality and immersive analytics. Cross-reality, mixed reality, augmented reality, virtual reality.

Also known as: (formerly Computer Science 601.51 (Immersive Analytics Apps))

CPSC 686.title: Research in Game Artificial Intelligence
CPSC 686.description:
AI techniques commonly used in video games, such as behaviour trees, search-based methods, and machine learning. Implementation of AI techniques in a commercial game engine and detailed exploration of research methods in these techniques.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Computer Science 686 and 586 will not be allowed.

Also known as: (formerly Computer Science 601.11 (Applied AI in Games))

CPSC 687.title: Computer Animation
CPSC 687.description:
Principles of traditional animation, key framing, parametric and track animation, free form deformation, inverse kinematics, dynamics, spring mass systems, particle systems, numerical integration, Lagrangian constraints, space time constraints, collisions, human animation, behavioural animation, metamorphosis, implicit animation techniques, animating liquids, gases and cloth, motion capture.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Computer Science 687 and 587 will not be allowed.

CPSC 688.title: Research in Physical and Tangible Human-Computer Interaction
CPSC 688.description:
Theory and practice of designing tangible user interfaces and physical computing systems.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Computer Science 688 and 588 will not be allowed.

Also known as: (formerly Computer Science 601.07 (Tangible and Physical HCI))

CPSC 689.title: Modelling for Computer Graphics
CPSC 689.description:
Parametric Modelling. B-splines and NURBS. Subdivision schemes. Surface subdivision. Multiresolution. Wavelets. Implicit modelling. Blends. Polygonization. Blobtree. Precise contact modelling. Solid modelling. CSG. Procedural modelling. Special topics, e.g. Differential geometry. Graph-based modelling. Topology.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Computer Science 689 and 589 will not be allowed.

CPSC 691.title: Rendering
CPSC 691.description:
Physical foundations of illuminations techniques. Colour. Radiometry and photometry. Reflection models. The rendering equation. Ray tracing. Monte Carlo techniques. Sampling and antialiasing. Texturing. Radiosity. Photon tracing. Volume rendering. Image-based rendering. Real-time shading.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Computer Science 691 and 591 will not be allowed.

CPSC 695.title: Data Management in Geographical Information Systems
CPSC 695.description: Examination of advanced geometric algorithms for representation, and visualization of Geographical Information Systems. Data structures such as progressive mesh, ROAM, multidimensional Delauney triangulization, quadtree and space partitioning. Algorithm techniques such as incremental, divide and conquer, sweep-plane, and dimension reduction. Algorithms for surface simplification, culling, quality measurement and reduction.

CPSC 696.title: Information Security Seminar
CPSC 696.description:
Topics in information security, possibly including security management, case studies, best practices, emerging threats, research frontiers. Includes a literature review and survey and a proposal writing component.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for both Computer Science 696 and 699 will not be allowed.

Notes: This course is intended to help students identify a project topic for Computer Science 698 and meets for one and one-half hours per week during the Fall and Winter terms.

CPSC 697.title: Biometric Security
CPSC 697.description:
Principles of biometric system design, technology and performance evaluation. Verification, identification and synthesis in biometrics. Traditional and emerging techniques for fingerprint matching, face recognition, iris modelling, signature authentication, and biometric pattern recognition. Multi-modal biometrics and biometric security.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Computer Science 697 and 577 will not be allowed.

CPSC 698.title: Information Security Project
CPSC 698.description: An information security project conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. A report must be written and presented on completion of the course.

CPSC 699.title: Research Methodology in Computer Science
CPSC 699.description:
An introduction to and survey of research areas and methods in Computer Science. Professional skills in computer science research such as reviewing, critical evaluation, and the preparation of research proposals.

Antirequisite(s): Not open to students with credit in Computer Science 696.

Notes: This course meets for one and one-half hours per week during the Fall and Winter Terms.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

CPSC 701.title: Research Topics in Computer Science
CPSC 701.description:
In depth course on a focused current research topic in Computer Science. Involves a significant research component and requires substantial background knowledge.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

CPSC 767.title: Adv Topics In Multiagent Systems
CPSC 767.description: An in-depth study of a selected subfield of multiagent systems including state-of-the-art research. This is a project-driven course.

CPSC 771.title: Current Trends in Database Technology
CPSC 771.description: Advanced topics chosen from state of the art trends in data management and analysis, including big data management, data mining, machine learning, network analysis and their applications in healthcare, homeland security, and business. There is a large project component.

CPSC 781.title: Adv Topic Human-Computer Interact
CPSC 781.description: The topics covered will change year by year depending on current advances in human computer interaction.

CPSC 789.title: Advanced Geometric Modelling
CPSC 789.description: Current research topics including spline modelling, Subdivision Surfaces, multiresolution, wavelets, analysis of the subdivision surfaces and reverse subdivision.

CPSC 502.01.title: Research Project in Computer Science
CPSC 502.01.description: A substantial research project under the guidance of a faculty member. A report must be written and presented on completion of the course.

CPSC 502.02.title: Research Project in Theoretical Computer Science
CPSC 502.02.description: A substantial research project under the guidance of a faculty member. A report must be written and presented on completion of the course.

CPSC 502.03.title: Research Project in Computer Graphics
CPSC 502.03.description: A substantial research project under the guidance of a faculty member. A report must be written and presented on completion of the course.

CPSC 502.04.title: Research Project in Information Security
CPSC 502.04.description: A substantial research project under the guidance of a faculty member. A report must be written and presented on completion of the course.

CPSC 502.05.title: Research Project in Scientific Computation
CPSC 502.05.description: A substantial research project under the guidance of a faculty member. A report must be written and presented on completion of the course.

CPSC 502.06.title: Research Project in Software Engineering
CPSC 502.06.description: A substantial research project under the guidance of a faculty member. A report must be written and presented on completion of the course.

CPSC 502.07.title: Research Project in Human Computer Interaction
CPSC 502.07.description: A substantial research project under the guidance of a faculty member. A report must be written and presented on completion of the course.

CPSC 502.08.title: Research Project in Networks and Distributed Computing
CPSC 502.08.description: A substantial research project under the guidance of a faculty member. A report must be written and presented on completion of the course.

CPSC 503.01.title: Project in Computer Science
CPSC 503.01.description: A research project conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. A report must be presented on completion of the course.

CPSC 503.02.title: Project in Theoretical Computer Science
CPSC 503.02.description: A research project conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. A report must be presented on completion of the course.

CPSC 503.03.title: Project in Computer Graphics
CPSC 503.03.description: A research project conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. A report must be presented on completion of the course.

CPSC 503.04.title: Project in InformationSecurity
CPSC 503.04.description: A research project conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. A report must be presented on completion of the course.

CPSC 503.05.title: Project in Scientific Computation
CPSC 503.05.description: A research project conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. A report must be presented on completion of the course.

CPSC 503.06.title: Project in Software Engineering
CPSC 503.06.description: A research project conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. A report must be presented on completion of the course.

CPSC 503.07.title: Project in Human Computer Interaction
CPSC 503.07.description: A research project conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. A report must be presented on completion of the course.

CPSC 503.08.title: Project in Networks and Distributed Computing
CPSC 503.08.description: A research project conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. A report must be presented on completion of the course.

DATA 201.title: Thinking with Data
DATA 201.description:
An introduction to tools and techniques for managing, visualizing, and making sense of data. Includes an introduction to data cleaning, basic statistics, exploratory visualization, sensemaking, and data presentation.

Also known as: (formerly Science 201)

DATA 211.title: Programming with Data
DATA 211.description: A hands-on introduction to basic coding skills, including core programming concepts and the fundamentals of reading, writing, and executing code -- with a focus on data manipulation. Emphasizes important tools and practices for programming with data, including development environments, source control, and debugging.

DATA 221.title: Introduction to Data Science
DATA 221.description: An introduction to commonly used programming tools and techniques for managing, visualizing, and making sense of data. Human implications of data collection, analysis, and use, including ethics, privacy, and alternate ways of knowing.

DATA 299.title: Topics in Data Science
DATA 299.description: Exploration of various areas in Data Science. Topics will vary from year-to-year. It will be offered as required to provide the opportunity for students to engage in additional areas in Data Science.
DATA 299.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Faculty.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

DATA 305.title: Computational Statistical Modelling
DATA 305.description: Random variables and their probability models. The Central Limit Theorem and parameter estimation. Statistical modelling of univariate and multivariate data with applications to discrete and continuous data. Data transformations. Introduction to simulation-based inference including randomization and permutation tests.
DATA 305.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Data Science 201 or 221; and 3 units from Data Science 211, Computer Science 217, 231 or 235; and 3 units from Statistics 205, 207, 327, Biology 315, Economics 395, Political Science 399, Psychology 300, Sociology 311, Engineering 319, Digital Engineering 319 or Linguistics 560.

DATA 311.title: Data Processing and Storage
DATA 311.description: An introduction to fundamental data structures, including lists, stacks, trees, hash tables, and graphs, and their application for data processing, analysis, and storage. Covers the fundamental state of the art data modelling and manipulation techniques, with emphasis on emerging characteristics of big data, including volume, velocity, variety and veracity.
DATA 311.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Data Science 201; and 3 units from Data Science 211, Computer Science 217, 231, 235, Engineering 233 or Digital Engineering 233.

DATA 335.title: Statistical Modelling I
DATA 335.description: An introduction to statistical computing and Bayesian modeling. Topics covered include random numbers generation, system/process simulation and evaluation, numerical integration, constrained and unconstrained optimization, Bayesian inference framework, single and multi-parameter models, regression models, Bayesian hierarchical modelling, Markov chain Monte Carlo.

DATA 398.title: Topics in Data Science
DATA 398.description:
Exploration of various areas in Data Science. Topics will vary from year-to-year. It will be offered as required to provide the opportunity for students to engage in additional areas in Data Science. 

Prerequisites: Consent of the Faculty.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT, NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

DATA 399.title: Topics in Data Science
DATA 399.description: Exploration of various areas in Data Science. Topics will vary from year-to-year. It will be offered as required to provide the opportunity for students to engage in additional areas in Data Science.
DATA 399.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Faculty.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

DATA 414.title: Ethics of Models, Metrics, Algorithms, and Data
DATA 414.description: Ethical frameworks pertaining to data science. Algorithmic fairness and bias. Explainable results in machine learning and artificial intelligence. Privacy and data governance for large datasets. Human implications of data science in Indigenous and underserved communities.

DATA 433.title: Essential Optimization
DATA 433.description: Unconstrained optimization and constrained optimization. Linear programing. Graph algorithms (including shortest-path and min-cut/max-flow) and integer programming. Simulated annealing and evolutionary algorithms. Other aspects of optimization as time permits.

DATA 443.title: Statistical Machine Learning
DATA 443.description: Core concepts of statistical machine learning, with an emphasis on the statistical background of the machine learning discipline. Classification and regression, nearest neighbours, Bayesian learning, decision tree, support vector machine, linear discriminant analysis, dimensionality reduction, and an introduction to neural networks.
DATA 443.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Data Science 305 and Computer Science 319.

DATA 471.title: Data Management for Data Scientists
DATA 471.description: Current mechanisms for data management. It investigates various types of data models for dealing with various types of data, including big data with all its V's (e.g., volume, velocity, variety, etc.). In particular, the current offering of the course covers, the conceptual model, the relational model, its standard query language SQL, and relational database design. Additionally, it covers NoSQL databases as well as ACID and BASE data management techniques, with emphasis on state-of-the-art platforms like HADOOP and SPARK.
DATA 471.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Data Science 221 and Computer Science 319.

DATA 479.title: Cloud-based Platforms for Data Science
DATA 479.description: Introduction to local and public cloud-based systems. Virtualization and containers. Creation, management, and cloud-based deployment of applications which solve data science problems. Privacy, security, and performance.

DATA 482.title: Data Visualization Fundamentals
DATA 482.description: Introduction to the theory and practice of data visualization with a focus on perception-based encoding choices and data mapping, chart authoring paradigms, visualization ethics and interpretation, and visual communication.
DATA 482.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Computer Science 319, 331, or Data Science 311.

DATA 499.title: Topics in Data Science
DATA 499.description: Exploration of various areas in Data Science. Topics will vary from year-to-year. It will be offered as required to provide the opportunity for students to engage in additional areas in Data Science.
DATA 499.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Faculty.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

DATA 501.title: Data Science Capstone
DATA 501.description: A substantial research project in the field of Data Science. The project will consist of all of the elements in the data cycle: collection, cleaning, exploratory analysis, statistical and computational analysis and presentation.
DATA 501.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Data Science 311 or Computer Science 471; 3 units from Data Science 305, Statistics 323, Biology 315, Sociology 315, Economics 395, Linguistics 560, Psychology 301 or 312; and admission to the Data Science Minor.

DATA 543.title: Deep Learning
DATA 543.description: Fundamental concepts in neural networks, convolutional and recurrent networks, as well as deep unsupervised learning. Common applications of neural networks and deep unsupervised learning.

DATA 582.title: Data Visualization Design and Development
DATA 582.description: Creative design strategies, technical implementation approaches, interaction techniques, evaluation methods, and reflective practices for visualizing novel datasets. Exploration of specialized approaches including geospatial, network, text, and uncertainty visualization.
DATA 582.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Computer Science 482 or Data Science 482.

DATA 599.title: Topics in Data Science
DATA 599.description: Exploration of various areas in Data Science. Topics will vary from year-to-year. It will be offered as required to provide the opportunity for students to engage in additional areas in Data Science.
DATA 599.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Faculty.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

DATA 601.title: Working with Data and Visualization
DATA 601.description: An introduction to fundamental data science concepts including basic data organization, data collection, and data cleaning. Provides a review of basic programming concepts in Python, as well as an introduction to problem-solving concepts including algorithmic complexity, recursion, vectorization, and regular expressions. Covers the fundamentals of data visualization and critical thinking.
DATA 601.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Fundamental Data Science and Analytics or the Master of Data Science and Analytics.

DATA 602.title: Statistical Data Analysis
DATA 602.description: An introduction to the foundations of statistical inference including probability models for data analysis, classical and simulation-based statistical inference, and implementation of statistical models with R.
DATA 602.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Fundamental Data Science and Analytics or the Master of Data Science and Analytics.

DATA 603.title: Statistical Modelling with Data
DATA 603.description: An introduction to the creation of complex statistical models, including exposure to multivariate model selection, prediction, the statistical design of experiments and analysis of data in R.
DATA 603.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Data Science 602 and admission to the Graduate Certificate in Fundamental Data Science and Analytics or the Master of Data Science and Analytics.

DATA 604.title: Working with Data at Scale
DATA 604.description: Explores the progression of data storage and processing, beginning with small, simple files and continuing to big, cloud-based databases. Data representation and simple file structures. An introduction to core database concepts with a variety of underlying data models, with a practical introduction to both SQL and NoSQL systems. Parallel and distributed storage and processing, including an introduction to cloud computing. Practical implications of storing and manipulating data at scale, with emphasis on ethics, privacy, and security.
DATA 604.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Data Science 601 and admission to the Graduate Certificate in Fundamental Data Science and Analytics or the Master of Data Science and Analytics.

DATA 605.title: Actionable Visualization and Analytics
DATA 605.description: Introduces deeper tools, skills, and techniques for collecting, manipulating, visualizing, analyzing, and presenting a number of different common types of data. With a data life-cycle perspective, looks into data elicitation and preparation as well as the actual usage of data in a decision-making context. Introduces techniques for visualizing and supporting the interactive analysis and decision making on large complex datasets. Focus on critical thinking and good analysis practices to avoid cognitive biases when designing, thinking, analyzing, and making decisions based on data.
DATA 605.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Data Science 601, 602, 603, 604 and admission to the Graduate Diploma in Data Science and Analytics or the Master of Data Science and Analytics with a specialization in Data Science.

DATA 606.title: Statistical Methods in Data Science
DATA 606.description: Design of surveys and data collection, bias and efficiency of surveys. Sampling weights and variance estimation. Multi-way contingency tables and introduction to generalized linear models with emphasis on applications.
DATA 606.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Data Science 601, 602, 603 and 604, and admission to the Graduate Diploma in Data Science and Analytics or the Master of Data Science and Analytics with a specialization in Data Science or Financial and Energy Markets Data Modelling.

DATA 607.title: Statistical and Machine Learning
DATA 607.description: Latent variable models for clustering and dimension reduction. Parametric and nonparametric methods for regression and classification including nave Bayes, decision trees, random forests, and boosting. Model assessment and selection. Deep learning.
DATA 607.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Data Science 601, 602, 603 and 604, and admission to the Graduate Diploma in Data Science and Analytics or the Master of Data Science and Analytics with a specialization in Data Science or Financial and Energy Markets Data Modelling.

DATA 608.title: Developing Big Data Applications
DATA 608.description: Provides advanced coverage of tools and techniques for big data management and for processing, mining, and building applications that leverage large datasets. Addresses database and distributed storage design for both SQL and NoSQL systems, and focuses on the application of distributed computing tools to perform data integration, apply machine learning, and build applications that leverage big data. Students will also examine the security and ethical implications of large-scale data collection and analysis.
DATA 608.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Data Science 601, 602, 603, 604 and admission to the Graduate Diploma in Data Science and Analytics, or the Master of Data Science and Analytics.

DATA 609.title: Modelling of Financial and Energy Markets Data
DATA 609.description: Coverage of main tools and techniques for modelling, machine learning and statistical analysis of big data in financial and energy markets. Topics will include: a simple financial and energy market models; risk-free and risky assets data modelling; discrete-time and continuous-time financial and energy market data modelling (CRR, Black-Scholes); modelling of forwards, futures, swaps in financial and energy markets; risk-neutral valuation, options, option pricing with financial and energy markets data; world energy data trends-crude oil, natural gas, and electricity; renewable energy data modelling: wind, solar, etc.
DATA 609.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Data Science 601, 602, 603 and 604, and admission to the Graduate Diploma in Data Science and Analytics or the Master of Data Science and Analytics with a specialization in Financial and Energy Markets Data Modelling.

DATA 610.title: Advanced Modelling of Financial and Energy Markets Data
DATA 610.description: More advanced coverage of tools and techniques for modelling of financial and energy markets data. Topics will include: modelling of dynamics for forwards and futures in energy and options in financial markets data; Black-76 and Margrabe's formulas for pricing of futures and options contracts; modelling paradigms beyond Black-76; data modelling with stochastic interest rates; one-, two- and three-factor Schwartz's models (with stochastic convenience yield and interest rate) for pricing forward and futures data in energy markets; modelling of high-frequency and algorithmic trading data.
DATA 610.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Data Science 601, 602, 603 and 604, and admission to the Graduate Diploma in Data Science and Analytics or the Master of Data Science and Analytics with a specialization in Financial and Energy Markets Data Modelling.

DATA 611.title: Predictive Analytics
DATA 611.description: Overview of the basic concepts and techniques in predictive analytics as well as their applications for solving real-life business problems in marketing, finance, and other areas. Techniques covered in this course include: decision trees, classification rules, association rules, clustering, support vector machines, instance-based learning. Examples and cases are discussed to gain hands-on experience.
DATA 611.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Data Science 601, 602, 603, 604 and admission to the Graduate Diploma in Data Science and Analytics or the Master of Data Science and Analytics with a specialization in Business Analytics.

DATA 612.title: Decision Analytics
DATA 612.description: Introduces fundamental concepts and modelling approaches to solve problems that are faced by decision makers in today's fast-paced and data-rich business environment. Different decision alternatives are analyzed and evaluated with the use of computer models. Topics include the most commonly used applied optimization, simulation and decision analysis techniques. Extensive use will be made of appropriate computer software for problem solving, principally with spreadsheets.
DATA 612.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Data Science 601, 602, 603, 604 and admission to the Graduate Diploma in Data Science and Analytics or the Master of Data Science and Analytics with a specialization in Business Analytics.

DATA 613.title: Introductory Data Analytics
DATA 613.description: Introduction to new tools for data analytics that can be used to discover, collect, organize, and clean the data to make it ready for analysis. Emphasis is placed on software tools used to interact with data sources and provision of user skills to create business applications that encompass a variety of business data sources; such as customers, suppliers, markets, competitors, and regulators. Software packages used to clean and organize the data for analysis will be introduced, as well as software to enable users' understanding of the data that is collected.
DATA 613.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Data Science 601, 602, 603, 604 and admission to the Graduate Diploma in Data Science and Analytics or the Master of Data Science and Analytics with a specialization in Business Analytics.

DATA 614.title: Advanced Data Analytics
DATA 614.description: Examination of tools and methods used in data analysis, including basic and advanced analytic tools, as well as machine learning techniques. One or more data analysis packages/programs are used to analyze different types of business data. Statistical and other analytic methods, such as data mining, machine learning and various techniques, and their application to business data analytics are explored.
DATA 614.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Data Science 601, 602, 603, 604, 611 and admission to the Graduate Diploma in Data Science and Analytics or the Master of Data Science and Analytics with a specialization in Business Analytics.

DATA 621.title: Advanced Statistical Modelling
DATA 621.description: An introduction to the fundamental statistical methods used in health data science including interpretation and communicating the results of these methods. Explores modelling using an epidemiological paradigm such as the assessment for modification and confounding. Introduces fundamental health research methods including study design and the evidence hierarchy.
DATA 621.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Data Science 601, 602, 603, 604 and admission to the Graduate Diploma in Data Science and Analytics or the Master of Data Science and Analytics with a specialization in Health Data Science and Biostatistics.

DATA 622.title: Machine Learning for Health Data Science
DATA 622.description: An introduction to the application of machine learning methods to problems in health data. The concepts of precision medicine and precision public health are introduced and the role of data science in these endeavors is explored. Using real examples from health data, various contemporary machine learning techniques are taught.
DATA 622.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Data Science 601, 602, 603, 604 and admission to the Graduate Diploma in Data Science and Analytics or the Master of Data Science and Analytics with a specialization in Health Data Science and Biostatistics.

DATA 623.title: Big Data in Health
DATA 623.description: Many of the major health data assets that exist in Alberta and Canada will be explored through hands-on experience with several datasets. Issues relating to access, confidentiality, privacy and data stewardship will be examined. Methodological challenges related to data linkage will be discussed. Students will work with large health databases including health administrative data, electronic medical record data and various other databases.
DATA 623.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Data Science 601, 602, 603, 604 and admission to the Graduate Diploma in Data Science and Analytics, or the Master of Data Science and Analytics.

DATA 624.title: Advanced Exploration and Visualization in Health
DATA 624.description: Explores the synthesis and summary of large volumes of information into interpretable and compelling results. Software packages useful for visualization of data are examined, including software for geographic information systems, augmented reality, and infographics. Data Science software commonly used in health industry is examined. Fundamental design principles are introduced to guide the approach to data presentation, communication, and interpretation.
DATA 624.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Data Science 601, 602, 603, 604 and admission to the Graduate Diploma in Data Science and Analytics or the Master of Data Science and Analytics with a specialization in Health Data Science and Biostatistics.

DATA 691.title: Integrated Topics in Data Science and Analytics
DATA 691.description: Provides a framework for students to initiate, perform and successfully complete a real-world project in Data Science and Analytics. This includes problem identification and formulation; discussion of legal, social, and ethical issues in data-driven projects; holistic processing and application of data; communication and data storytelling skills as well as leadership skills. In addition, students will be exposed to emerging topics in Data Science and Analytics.
DATA 691.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Data Science and Analytics and 24 units in 600-level Data Science courses.

DATA 692.title: Real World Applications of Data Science and Analytics
DATA 692.description: This course introduces students to end-to-end data science and analytics projects through applied case studies, emphasizing real-world implementation of artificial intelligence and other data-driven methodologies. By integrating applied methods with considerations of project management, communication, and professional skills, the course helps prepare students to design, manage, and deliver end-to-end data analytics projects.
DATA 692.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Data Science and Analytics and 24 units in 600-level Data Science courses.

Also known as: (formerly Data Science 691)

DATA 693.title: Professional Internship in Data Science and Analytics
DATA 693.description:
Students will integrate professional competencies and advanced analytical tools and apply them to a specific domain.

Prerequisite: Consent of Department. 

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Data Science 693 and 695 will not be allowed.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

DATA 695.title: Research Capstone in Data Science and Analytics
DATA 695.description:
Exposure to advanced data analytics methods and research methods applied to subdomains of data science, including business analytics and big data problems in healthcare.

Prerequisite: Consent of Department. 

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Data Science 695 and 693 will not be allowed.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

DEST 201.title: Introduction to Global Development Studies
DEST 201.description: An interdisciplinary course focusing on development in both a northern and international context. Explores factors that shape development processes; introduces concepts and issues such as poverty; colonialism and self-determination; human ecology and sustainable development; and appropriate technology. Examines the origins, purposes, and performance of contemporary national and international institutions and their effect on people in different geographical and socio-economic contexts.

DEST 301.title: Topics in Global Development Studies
DEST 301.description: Examination of selected issues in Global Development Studies.
DEST 301.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Global Development Studies 201 or Development Studies 201.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

DEST 302.title: Community Development
DEST 302.description: Examines the processes whereby communities take action to solve common problems in both urban and rural settings.
DEST 302.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Global Development Studies 201 or Development Studies 201.

DEST 375.title: Gender and Development
DEST 375.description: Examines development from the critical perspective of the key role played by gender in development. Case studies from Canadian and international contexts will provide illustrative material for analyzing the issues that emanate from the gendered nature of development processes and practices.
DEST 375.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Global Development Studies 201, Development Studies 201, Gender and Sexuality Studies 201, Women's Studies 201.

DEST 393.title: Theories & Applications of Development
DEST 393.description: A study of development theories and applications through northern and international case studies. Examines practical manifestations of those theories and approaches in development planning, implementation, and praxis including Modernization theory; dependency theory; basic needs approach; neo-liberalism; the staple thesis; globalization; women in development; gender and development.
DEST 393.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Global Development Studies 201 or Development Studies 201.

DEST 400.title: Field School
DEST 400.description: A field course for the on-site interdisciplinary study of a country or region with regard to issues of development, e.g., cultural, economic, environmental, geographical, historical and political perspectives.

DEST 401.title: Advanced Topics in Development Studies
DEST 401.description: Advanced examination of selected topics using theoretical and analytical tools to develop a critical understanding of contemporary development processes.
DEST 401.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Global Development Studies 201 and 3 units from courses labelled Global Development Studies.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

DEST 402.title: Global Food Politics
DEST 402.description: Examination of the socio-economic, ecological, and political implications of food and farming systems at local, regional, national, and international levels.
DEST 402.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Global Development Studies 201 and 3 units from courses labelled Global Development Studies.

DEST 403.title: Sustainability and Political Ecology in the Circumpolar Arctic
DEST 403.description: The history of northern development and resource management in Canada with emphasis on specific case studies involving sustainability and human ecology in the Circumpolar Arctic. The role of traditional environmental knowledge and its significance to northern development will be examined.  Participatory research methodologies may be introduced.
DEST 403.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Global Development Studies 393 or Anthropology 357.

DEST 405.title: Environment and Sustainable Development
DEST 405.description: Critical engagement with sustainability through study of the intersections between environment and development, including the relationship between economic growth and sustainable development, globalization and environmental change, and the role of nation-states and international organization to address the climate crisis.
DEST 405.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Global Development Studies 201 and 3 units from courses labelled Global Development Studies.

DEST 485.title: International and Intercultural Communication
DEST 485.description: Examines cross-cultural communication at the personal, organizational, societal, and international levels. Discusses the concept of \"Globalization\" and its implications for communication among different cultures; analyses various theoretical perspectives underlying intercultural communication; explores issues of power, identity and influence; examines intercultural encounters in the context of specific diversified settings; and helps students develop intercultural communication competence.
DEST 485.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Global Development Studies 201 and 3 units from courses labelled Global Development Studies.

DEST 501.title: Directed Research
DEST 501.description: Supervised individual study of a special topic.
DEST 501.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

DEST 591.title: Critical Perspectives on Development Practice and Research
DEST 591.description: An interdisciplinary consideration of selected issues and methodologies in development, providing the critical perspective and skills needed to conceptualize, design, implement and effectively manage community development projects and programs.
DEST 591.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Global Development Studies 302 or Development Studies 302; and Global Development Studies 393 or Development Studies 393.

DEST 593.title: Honours Seminar in Development Studies
DEST 593.description: Current theoretical and methodological issues will be explored in a discussion-based seminar format, with the aim of development of a research project.
DEST 593.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Global Development Studies 393 or Development Studies 393 and admission to the Development Studies Honours Program.

DRAM 203.title: Creativity
DRAM 203.description:
From the economy to the environment and from politics to entertainment, creativity is an endlessly renewable resource that offers benefits for all citizens and may well be the most important human element for our future. Students from all disciplines can investigate the practices and processes of creativity and explore the ways in which it can help enrich their lives.

Antirequisite(s): Not open to Drama majors or minors.

Notes: Attendance at selected arts events is mandatory. Students are responsible for the purchase of tickets. Affordability and accessibility will influence the selection of events.

DRAM 205.title: Story
DRAM 205.description:
An exploration of the elements of story present in the arts and beyond. Story is an exciting, creative, dynamic and universal form of human expression with the potential to engage and inspire students from across departments and disciplines.

Antirequisite(s): Not open to Drama majors or minors.

Notes: Attendance at selected arts events is mandatory. Students are responsible for the purchase of tickets.

DRAM 209.title: Introduction to Acting I
DRAM 209.description:
An introduction to creative resources and practices for the actor.

Antirequisite(s):  Credit for Drama 209 and 200 will not be allowed.

DRAM 210.title: Introduction to Acting II
DRAM 210.description: An introduction to the actor's interpretation and performance of texts for the theatre.

DRAM 223.title: Introduction to Theatre Production
DRAM 223.description:
An introduction to organizational principles of theatre production and technical theatre skills.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Drama 223 and 222 will not be allowed.

Notes: Participation on the production crews of Drama productions outside of scheduled class time is required.

DRAM 225.title: Introduction to Scenography
DRAM 225.description:
An introduction to performance design and the disciplines within it: scenery, props, lighting, costumes and sound. Includes a study of the history of theatre design and space. Topics regarding contemporary notions of scenography will be explored, for example performance art, ritual, etc.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Drama 225 and 222 will not be allowed.

DRAM 242.title: Introduction to the Study of Drama
DRAM 242.description:
An introduction to the study of drama, theatre and performance.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Drama 242 and 240 will not be allowed.

DRAM 243.title: Introduction to the Practice of Drama
DRAM 243.description: Continued study and practice of drama, theatre and performance.

DRAM 309.title: Foundations of Acting I
DRAM 309.description: Further development of an actor's interpretation and performance of dramatic text for the stage through investigation of "Naturalism" and contemporary scene study.
DRAM 309.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Drama 200 or 210, audition and consent of Division Lead, Drama.

DRAM 312.title: Foundations of Acting II
DRAM 312.description: A continued investigation of fundamental acting principles, continuing with contemporary contexts with an introduction to classical text.
DRAM 312.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Drama 316 and one of 301 or 309, audition and consent of Division Lead, Drama.

DRAM 313.title: Scenography I
DRAM 313.description:
Basic scenography including set, props, lighting and costume design theory, process and technique for a variety of theatre forms and performance styles.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Drama 319.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Drama 313 and either 415 or 417 will not be allowed.

DRAM 316.title: Foundations in Vocal Practice
DRAM 316.description: Foundations in vocal practice and development of the voice for live performance and public speaking.
DRAM 316.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Drama 210, audition and consent of Division Lead, Drama.

DRAM 317.title: Introduction To Stage Sound
DRAM 317.description: Basic principles of sound for the theatre: recording, reinforcement and reproduction techniques and methods used in creating a production design.

DRAM 318.title: Foundations in Physical Practice
DRAM 318.description: Foundations in physical practice and development of the body for stylized-live performance and public engagement.
DRAM 318.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Drama 210, audition and consent of Division Lead, Drama.

DRAM 319.title: Graphics and Model Building for Theatre
DRAM 319.description: An introduction to graphic and model building techniques for the theatre designer.

DRAM 320.title: Introduction to Lighting Design
DRAM 320.description:
Basic principles of lighting for live performance including conceptualization of the lighting approach, techniques in communication and skills in execution of a performance.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Drama 319.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for both Drama 320 and 315 will not be allowed.

DRAM 345.title: History of the Theatre: Origins to the Mid-Eighteenth Century
DRAM 345.description:
Theatre as an art and society phenomenon in selected cultures, emphasizing the development of Western traditions.

Antirequisite(s):  Credit for Drama 345 and 342 will not be allowed.

DRAM 346.title: Seminar in Drama I
DRAM 346.description: An introduction to play and production analysis, developing skills in critical thinking, research, and oral and written communication about drama and theatre.

DRAM 347.title: History of the Theatre: The Late Eighteenth Century to the Present
DRAM 347.description:
Theatre as an art and social phenomenon in selected cultures, emphasizing the development of Western traditions from the late 18th-century to the present.

Antirequisite(s):  Credit for Drama 347 and 344 will not be allowed.

DRAM 348.title: Seminar in Drama II
DRAM 348.description: Further development of skills and competencies, and critical and interpretive skills.

DRAM 355.title: IntroductiontoCanadian Theatre and Drama
DRAM 355.description: A studyof Canadian theatreand performance using both formal and theoreticalapproaches.

DRAM 358.title: Performance Creation in Applied Practices
DRAM 358.description:
Explorations in personal/group creative process; facilitation of performance forms that may include sound and movement exploration, storytelling, ritual, mask, puppetry, and the collaborative creation of original performance. Emphasis will be placed on collaborative practices and group communication.

Antirequisite(s): Not open to Drama majors or minors. Credit for Drama 358 and any of 360, 366 or 368 will not be allowed.

DRAM 365.title: Theatre for Young Audiences I
DRAM 365.description:
Study of the history and production of Theatre for Young Audiences (TYA), as well as the creation of original performances. Exploration of performances techniques specific to TYA content, forms and venues.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Drama 365 and 362 will not be allowed.

DRAM 367.title: Theatre for Young Audiences II
DRAM 367.description: Advanced exploration of performances techniques specific to Theatre for Young Audiences (TYA) content, forms and venues. There is a performance component that includes tours in the community.

DRAM 368.title: Introduction to Performance Creation
DRAM 368.description: Introduction to theatrical devising, focusing on the place of the individual within group creation contexts. Emphasis on personal physical awareness, expressivity, discovery of individual strengths and interests, and strategies for collaboration. Creation of short scenes for presentation.
DRAM 368.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a Drama program.

DRAM 371.title: Introduction to Playwriting
DRAM 371.description: Directed exercises in writing for the theatre; workshop sessions for developing and reworking material.

DRAM 382.title: Topics in Drama
DRAM 382.description:
Special topics in the study of drama. Topics may include Writing for Performance, Black Canadian Drama, and Solo Performance Creation.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

DRAM 391.title: Practicum I

DRAM 393.title: Practicum II

DRAM 409.title: Advanced Acting I
DRAM 409.description: Investigation and development of the actor's process with a deepening rigour toward integrating vocal and physical modalities as they connect to dramatic text. A study of best practice in rehearsal, and introduction to live-public performance.
DRAM 409.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Drama 302 or 310, 316, and 318, audition and consent of the Division Lead, Drama.

DRAM 411.title: Introduction to Directing
DRAM 411.description: Fundamental approaches and skills in directing covered through theory and practice.

DRAM 412.title: Advanced Acting II
DRAM 412.description: Intermediate practice of contemporary and stylized performance and acting techniques, in addition to personal practice associated with strong physical presence.

DRAM 413.title: Directing I

DRAM 416.title: Topics in Vocal Practice
DRAM 416.description: Topics in the development of vocal practice for live performance and public speaking. Exploration of contemporary and classical text.
DRAM 416.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Drama 316 or both 301 and 302, audition and consent of the Division Lead, Drama.

DRAM 418.title: Topics in Physical Practice for Performance
DRAM 418.description: Topics in the development of physical practice on stage in association to contemporary and classical performance. Exploring physical readiness for live performance.
DRAM 418.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Dram 318 or both 301 and 302, audition and consent of the Division Lead, Drama.

DRAM 468.title: Intermediate Performance Creation
DRAM 468.description: Examines a broad cross-section of approaches, both historical and contemporary, to performance creation, physical theatre and theatrical devising. Conceptual and practical introduction to a wide range of distinct models for training and creation.

DRAM 471.title: Playwriting
DRAM 471.description: Intermediate studies in writing for the theatre leading to the development of a one-act or full-length piece; workshop sessions for developing and rehearsing material.
DRAM 471.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Drama 371 and consent of the Division Chair, Drama.

DRAM 481.title: Advanced Topics in Theatre Practice
DRAM 481.description: Immersive Theatre, Wearable Electronics for Costume Design, Design for Devised Theatre, Professional Practice and Career Preparation, Intimacy Coaching, Stage Combat Choreography, Site-Specific Theatre, Advanced Mask and Puppetry, Codes of Performance in Ancient Drama, and Directing, Design and Dramaturgy.

DRAM 483.title: Advanced Topics in Theatre Studies

Possible topics include, but are not limited to: a particular historical period, genre, theme, playwright, or critical/theoretical approach. Recent topics have included Contemporary Women Playwrights and Gender, Sexuality, Modernism, and Performance.

DRAM 517.title: Scenography IV
DRAM 517.description: Advanced set, props, lighting, and costume design theory, process and technique for a variety of theatre forms and performance styles.

DRAM 568.title: Advanced Performance Creation
DRAM 568.description: Collaborative contribution to a focused creation process under the individual or team-based mentorship of a SCPA faculty member and/or guest artist. Students generate performance material towards a public presentation.
