DRAM 574.title: Advanced Topics in Drama
DRAM 574.description: Advanced studies exploring topics in Theatre Studies, Theatre Practice, or a combination.
DRAM 574.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Division Chair, Drama.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT.

DRAM 605.title: Methods In Theatre Research
DRAM 605.description: Methods in research in the four areas of specialization in the MFA Theatre program.

DRAM 611.title: Selected Problems in Directing I
DRAM 611.description:
Investigates both the theoretical and executive functions of the director. Emphasis will be placed on contemporary theatre practices through research and conceptual design, rehearsal and creation methods, and the development and articulation of a personal approach to theatre-making.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Drama 611 and 610 will not be allowed.

DRAM 613.title: Selected Problems in Directing II
DRAM 613.description: A continuation and deepening of the theories, techniques and practices from Drama 611. This course includes the research, development, rehearsal and presentation of a short pre-thesis project to be presented as part of the SCPA Alchemy Festival.

DRAM 615.title: Collaboration in Performance Creation
DRAM 615.description: A practical exploration of approaches to collaboration across roles in performance and theatre creation such as playwriting, directing, design, dramaturgy, and acting.

DRAM 631.title: Practicum in Design
DRAM 631.description: Supervised, experiential pre-thesis learning, designing lighting, sound, properties, set, or costumes for a production at the School of Creative and Performing Arts.

DRAM 641.title: Artistic Research
DRAM 641.description: A series of supervised practical research tasks and exercises, leading to student-led completion of artistic or empirical project plans, ethics protocols, and research instruments for pre-thesis or early thesis exploration.

DRAM 643.title: Dramaturgy
DRAM 643.description: An analytical and practical introduction to dramaturgical strategies of creation and composition with attention to their potential effect on audience experiences.

DRAM 645.title: Special Topics
DRAM 645.description:
Advanced studies in shifting topics such as Theory, Analysis, Praxis; Premodern Theatre; Theatre and Technology; Puppetry and Mask.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

DRAM 647.title: Studies in Modern Drama I
DRAM 647.description: Studies in the literature, history, theory and criticism of drama, theatre and performance from the late nineteenth century to the mid-twentieth century.

DRAM 649.title: Studies in Modern Drama II
DRAM 649.description: Studies in the literature, history, theory and criticism of drama, theatre and performance from the mid twentieth century to the present.

DRAM 675.title: Pre-thesis in Playwriting
DRAM 675.description: Advanced exploration of dramatic structure and character development is accomplished through completion of a one-act play.

DRAM 381.04.title: Costume Techniques
DRAM 381.04.description:
Special topics in the study of scenography and techniques for the scenographer.

Notes: A supplementary fee will be assessed for Drama 381.04 to cover additional costs associated with this course.

DRAM 381.05.title: Scenic Art
DRAM 381.05.description:
Special topics in the study of scenography and techniques for the scenographer.

Notes: A supplementary fee will be assessed for Drama 381.05 to cover additional costs associated with this course.

DRAM 381.06.title: Theatre and Technology
DRAM 381.06.description: Special topics in the study of scenography and techniques for the scenographer.

DRAM 381.08.title: Stage Combat
DRAM 381.08.description: Special topics in the study of scenography and techniques for the scenographer.

DRAM 381.09.title: Voice and Presence for Every Performance
DRAM 381.09.description: Special topics in the study of scenography and techniques for the scenographer.

DRAM 381.10.title: Mask and Puppetry
DRAM 381.10.description:
Special topics in the study of scenography and techniques for the scenographer.

Notes: A supplementary fee will be assessed for Drama 381.10 to cover additional costs associated with this course.

DSGN 201.title: Introduction to Design Thinking Studio I
DSGN 201.description: A foundational introduction to design thinking as applied to the built environment of buildings, cities, and landscapes. Emphasizes visual/spatial two- and three-dimensional abstract design thinking and problem-solving skills.
DSGN 201.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 203.title: Design Thinking and the City Studio
DSGN 203.description: Emphasis is given to the research, execution, and creation of small-scale, social innovation, design thinking interventions based in an urban setting.
DSGN 203.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 201 and admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 211.title: Introduction to Visual and Communications Studies
DSGN 211.description: Builds and develops awareness, skills and practice in visual representation of design work. Emphasis on orthographic drawings, visualizing objects, spaces and environments in a way that focuses on geometry/form/proportion.
DSGN 211.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 213.title: Introduction to Visualizing Complexity
DSGN 213.description: Development of skills in visualizing data sets, diagraming and simulating site conditions. Introduction to geographic information systems (GIS) as a platform for visualizing complex urban environments. Complex assemblies simulation -- parametric design intro (DATA).
DSGN 213.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 211 and admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 221.title: Histories of Innovation in the Designed Environment
DSGN 221.description: Historical studies addressing the global emergence of different modernities in the designed environment. Emphasizes themes such as industrialization and modernization, coloniality, nationalism and internationalism, and professionalization, as these relate to architecture, landscape architecture, and city planning.
DSGN 221.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 223.title: Shaping the Contemporary City I
DSGN 223.description: Examines the structures of society as determinants of urban form, including political systems and governance, economics and urban development, and social organization. Emphasizes the agency of individuals and groups, through such topics as power and resistance, spatial justice, multiculturalism, professions and the public.
DSGN 223.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 221 and admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 231.title: Introduction to Urban Infrastructure and Systems
DSGN 231.description: Introduces key infrastructure systems of a city. Examines current policies, challenges and practices in infrastructure sectors: water, sewage, waste management, open space, energy transportation and communication.
DSGN 231.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 241.title: Introduction to Sustainability in the Built Environment
DSGN 241.description: Introduction to sustainability in the built environment. Topics are aimed at broadly exploring how to minimize negative environmental impacts, promote resource efficiency, and create healthier, more resilient spaces.
DSGN 241.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 253.title: Introduction to Entrepreneurship for the Built Environment
DSGN 253.description: Introduction to innovative business and industry practices in architecture, planning and landscape architecture. Topics include social, cultural and green entrepreneurship in a built environment or community context.
DSGN 253.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 263.title: Introduction to Computational Design
DSGN 263.description: An introduction to tools and techniques for how various types of data can be handled and interpreted in design languages and geometries. Topics include basic programming and ways of thinking computationally.
DSGN 263.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 301.title: Transscalar Design Studio I - Small Scale
DSGN 301.description: This introductory transscalar design studio enables students to explore a particular thematic built environment issue at a small scale.
DSGN 301.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 203 and admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 302.title: Transscalar Design Studio I - Medium Scale
DSGN 302.description: This introductory transscalar design studio enables students to explore a particular thematic built environment issue at a medium scale.
DSGN 302.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 203 and admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 303.title: Transscalar Design Studio I - Large Scale
DSGN 303.description: This introductory transscalar design studio enables students to explore a particular thematic built environment issue at a large scale.
DSGN 303.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 203 and admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 304.title: Transscalar Design Studio II - Small Scale
DSGN 304.description: This intermediate transscalar design studio enables students to explore a particular thematic issue with a design intervention at a small scale.
DSGN 304.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 302 or 303, and admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 305.title: Transscalar Design Studio II  - Medium Scale
DSGN 305.description: This intermediate transscalar design studio enables students to explore a particular thematic issue with a design intervention at a medium scale.
DSGN 305.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 301 or 303, and admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 306.title: Transscalar Design Studio II  - Large Scale
DSGN 306.description: This intermediate transscalar design studio enables students to explore a particular thematic issue with a design intervention at a large scale.
DSGN 306.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 301 or 302, and admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 311.title: Geometry and Simulation
DSGN 311.description: Development of skills in digitally modelling and manipulating geometric assemblies, simulating environmental and performative aspects of designed objects, spaces and environments.
DSGN 311.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 213 and admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 313.title: Digital Modelling
DSGN 313.description: Development of skills in tools for exchanging digital information between various platforms for production, including animations, fabrication tools, digital twins, and parametric information models.
DSGN 313.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 311 and admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 321.title: Shaping the Contemporary City II
DSGN 321.description: Examines the built structures that shape contemporary cities, including architecture and infrastructure. Compares the urban morphology of cities globally and studies the factors that determine urban form.
DSGN 321.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 223 and admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 323.title: The Future of the Global City
DSGN 323.description: Explores the challenges facing global cities over the next half century. Projects possible futures for cities and the role of design in different scenarios, by reference to history and theory, sustainability, data science, technology, simulation and visualization.
DSGN 323.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 223 and admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 331.title: Introduction to Landscape Ecology
DSGN 331.description: Introduces key concepts in landscape ecology, flora, urban fauna, plant taxonomy, and planting design, with an emphasis on ecologies specific to the Calgary region.
DSGN 331.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 231 and admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 363.title: Computational Design for the Built Environment
DSGN 363.description: An exploration into the background, history, implementation, and use of algorithms in design, along with computational geometry techniques for generating design outcomes through modeling. Key topics include parametric, rule-based, agent-based, and learning-based systems.
DSGN 363.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 263 and admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 401.title: Transscalar Design Studio III - Small Scale
DSGN 401.description: This advanced transscalar design studio enables students to explore a particular thematic built environment issue with a design intervention at a small scale.
DSGN 401.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 302 or 303; and, 305 or 306; and admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 402.title: Transscalar Design Studio III - Medium Scale
DSGN 402.description: This advanced transscalar design studio enables students to explore a particular thematic built environment issue with a design intervention at a medium scale.
DSGN 402.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 301 or 303; and 304 or 306; and admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 403.title: Transscalar Design Studio III - Large Scale
DSGN 403.description: This advanced transscalar design studio enables students to explore a particular thematic built environment issue with a design intervention at a large scale.
DSGN 403.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 301 or 302; and 304 or 305; and admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 404.title: Disciplinary Studio in Architecture
DSGN 404.description: This architecture-focused studio explores concepts in architectural design and form making involving a sequence of skill building, visual and spatial thinking, and problem-solving exercises.
DSGN 404.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 402 and admission to the Architecture Concentration in the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 408.title: Disciplinary Studio in Landscape Architecture
DSGN 408.description: This landscape-focused studio addresses topical, issue-based problem(s) as the basis for a design intervention(s) in a landscape setting. Emphasizes a sense of place, landscape ecology, and sustainability.
DSGN 408.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 402 and admission to the Landscape Architecture Concentration in the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 414.title: Advanced Visualization in Architecture
DSGN 414.description: Develops advanced graphics and visualization techniques relevant to the architecture field, including but not limited to 3D modeling, rendering, parametric design, computational design, and digital fabrication.
DSGN 414.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 313 and admission to the Architecture Concentration in the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 418.title: Advanced Visualization in Landscape Architecture
DSGN 418.description: Develops advanced graphics and visualization techniques relevant to the landscape architecture field, including but not limited to 3D modeling, rendering, parametric design, computational design, and digital fabrication.
DSGN 418.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 313 and admission to the Landscape Architecture concentration in the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 421.title: Leadership in City Innovation
DSGN 421.description: Develops applied knowledge and skills to address the significant challenges to global cities in the present and future. Emphasizes research and communication, leadership and politics, advocacy and negotiation, and development and project delivery.
DSGN 421.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 223 and admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 431.title: Introduction to Building Science
DSGN 431.description: Introduces key concepts in building science: functioning of building enclosure, the physical behaviour of building components under thermal/pressure stresses; the fundamentals of acoustics; building materials and their behaviour properties relative to climatic cycles.
DSGN 431.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 331 and admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 434.title: Introduction to Structures
DSGN 434.description: Focus on structural analysis, including the characteristics and performance of various structural components and sub-assemblies, basic structural design calculations, and professional terminology and structural conventions.
DSGN 434.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 431 and admission to the Architecture concentration in the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 438.title: Site Grading and Landform Design
DSGN 438.description: Provides a working knowledge of grading, landform and storm water management systems and techniques. Covers fundamentals and advanced technologies including GPS grading and landform manipulation.
DSGN 438.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 431 and admission to the Landscape Architecture Concentration in the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 441.title: Transscalar Sustainability in the Built Environment
DSGN 441.description: Exploration of transscalar sustainability in the built environment. Topics include energy efficiency, waste reduction and recycling, water conservation, green technologies and social sustainability at the scale of buildings, landscapes, and cities. Emphasis is placed on the interconnectedness of environmental, social and economic considerations in the planning, design, and construction of the built environment.
DSGN 441.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 241 or Sustainability Studies 201 or University 207 and admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 463.title: Advanced Computational Design for the Built Environment
DSGN 463.description: Continuation of Computational Design for the Built Environment. Emphasis on utilizing computation as a leading agent in the design process. Students will draw from various design fields such as architecture, planning, or landscape architecture, and undertake computation to derive design outcomes.
DSGN 463.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 363 and admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 500.title: Experiential Learning in Design and City Innovation
DSGN 500.description: Thematic inquiry and design related to special topics in Design in City Innovation.
DSGN 500.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 72 units and admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

DSGN 501.title: Work Integrated Learning Design Studio
DSGN 501.description: Work Integrated Learning (WIL) studio in the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation. Students connect with community partners to address compelling local issues in the built urban environment.
DSGN 501.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 402 and admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 502.title: Work Integrated Learning  Studio in Architecture
DSGN 502.description: Work Integrated Learning (WIL) studio in the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation Architecture Concentration. Students connect with community partners to address compelling local issues in the built urban environment.
DSGN 502.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 404 and admission to the Architecture concentration in the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 503.title: Capstone Design Studio
DSGN 503.description: Capstone studio for students not registered in the architecture or landscape architecture concentrations. Students develop a capstone design project in their area of interest.
DSGN 503.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 501 and admission to the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 504.title: Capstone Studio in Architecture
DSGN 504.description: Capstone studio in the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation Architecture Concentration. Projects engage contemporary issues defining the built and natural environments.
DSGN 504.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 502 and admission to the Architecture concentration in the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 506.title: Work Integrated Learning Studio in Landscape Architecture
DSGN 506.description: Work Integrated Learning (WIL) studio in the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation Landscape Architecture Concentration. Students connect with community partners to address compelling local issues in the built urban environment.
DSGN 506.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 406 and admission to the Landscape Architecture Concentration in the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

DSGN 508.title: Capstone Studio in Landscape Architecture
DSGN 508.description: Capstone studio in the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation Landscape Architecture Concentration. Projects engage contemporary issues defining the built and natural environments.
DSGN 508.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Design 506 and admission to the Landscape Architecture Concentration in the Bachelor of Design in City Innovation program.

EALS 501.title: Advanced Research in East Asian Languages Studies
EALS 501.description: A research-oriented seminar to synthesize students' training in East Asian languages and cultures and bring it to bear on a particular subject in Chinese and/or Japanese, or on the relation between East Asian languages and their respective cultures.
EALS 501.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BA in East Asian Language Studies and consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

EASC 301.title: Topics in Human-Environment Interactions
EASC 301.description: Exploration of the interactions between humans and environment at different time scales and in different regions. Geographically distinct regions are selected to highlight how humans have adapted to climate change and hazardous natural events. Past adaptations will be examined in the modern context.

EASC 401.title: Topics in Methods in Earth Science
EASC 401.description: An introduction to field and laboratory methods used in earth surface processes research. Field excursions may involve travel and will provide the basis for laboratory exercises.

EASC 501.title: Research Project: Topics in Earth Science
EASC 501.description: An original research project that focuses on earth surface processes and may target local, regional, or global issues. Participants will be exposed to oral and written communication, field sampling techniques and strategies, laboratory techniques, strategies and limitations, and relevant statistical analysis and graphic communication.

EAST 201.title: Understanding Contemporary East Asia
EAST 201.description: An introductory exploration of the cultures of China, Japan, and Korea that outlines their shared characteristics as well as highlighting their differences. Subjects covered include physical environment, history, philosophy, social and political order, economy, and arts.

EAST 401.title: East Asia in a Global World
EAST 401.description: An investigation of East Asian countries and their relations with non-East Asian countries and global initiatives. The focus will be on either China, Japan or Korea and may include culture, politics, business, environment, etc.
EAST 401.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):East Asian Studies 201 and completion of 60 units

EAST 531.title: Issues and Methods in East Asian Studies
EAST 531.description: Contemporary social, philosophical, economic, political and/or international issues within East Asia and methodologies for analysis of the basis for interactions among East Asian countries will be presented in-depth.
EAST 531.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): East Asian Studies 201 and one of Chinese 317 or Japanese 317.

ECOL 413.title: Field Course in Ecology
ECOL 413.description: An examination of ecological principles and techniques through field exercises, including studies of terrestrial and aquatic populations, communities and ecosystems. The course is held at the Barrier Lake Field Station in the two weeks immediately prior to the commencement of the Fall Term.

ECOL 417.title: Aquatic Communities and Ecosystems
ECOL 417.description: Community composition and dynamics at the various trophic levels of aquatic ecosystems. Temporal and spatial changes in community composition, physical and chemical conditions, and their effects on the ecosystem. There will be a full week-end field trip, normally during the first or second week of the term.
ECOL 417.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biology 313; and Biology 315 or Environmental Science 401.

ECOL 419.title: Terrestrial Communities and Ecosystems
ECOL 419.description: Processes and patterns in above- and below-ground terrestrial communities. Ecosystem level processes in fluxes of carbon and nutrients. Methods for assessing biomass, productivity and biochemical pathways.
ECOL 419.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biology 313; and Biology 315 or Environmental Science 401.

ECOL 425.title: Quantitative Biology II
ECOL 425.description: Quantitative analysis as applicable to ecological research. Methodologies and models will be presented and analyzed. Particular emphasis will be placed on experimental design, regression analysis, and the study of spatial dispersion.

ECOL 429.title: Ecology of Individuals
ECOL 429.description: Ecological and evolutionary perspectives on physiology and behaviour. This course focuses on the influences on resource acquisition, maintenance, growth, and reproduction and their implications for survival and fertility.

ECOL 439.title: Ecology of Populations
ECOL 439.description: A conceptual and practical treatment of population ecology including: population growth, demography, life histories, population dynamics, competition, predation and mutualism.

ECOL 501.title: Ecological and Evolutionary Applications
ECOL 501.description: A class project course in which students apply their understanding of ecological and evolutionary concepts and their analytical skills to investigate selected problems in detail. Project topics vary from year-to-year and will include fundamental and applied problems. Formal written and oral reports will be presented as a necessary component of the course.
ECOL 501.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Ecology 425 and 429; and Ecology 417 or 419; and 75 units.

ECOL 527.title: Ecology of Fishes
ECOL 527.description: The ecology of fishes with an emphasis on freshwater systems. Fish will be used as models for examining ecological principles and theory at various levels of organization including physiological, behavioural, population and community ecology. Topics covered include: morphology, systematics, foraging, bioenergetics, life history strategies, population dynamics and the role of fish in aquatic food webs.
ECOL 527.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biology 313; and 3 units from Ecology 417, Zoology 403 or 477.02.

ECOL 528.title: Research Project in Ecology
ECOL 528.description: Research project under the co/supervision of faculty members in the Department of Biological Sciences. Original and independent thought, practical research, and written and oral reports presented on completion of this course.
ECOL 528.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 72 units and consent of the Department.

ECOL 529.title: Molecular Ecology and Evolution
ECOL 529.description: Molecular Ecology utilizes population genetics, phylogenetics, and genomics to address questions in ecology, evolution, behaviour and conservation. Topics will include principal and emerging molecular techniques for characterizing and analyzing genetic variation to test quantitative predictions from ecological and evolutionary theory.

ECOL 530.title: Honours Research Project in Ecology
ECOL 530.description: Research project under the co/supervision of faculty members in the Department of Biological Sciences. Original and independent thought, practical research, and written and oral reports presented on completion of this course. Open only to Honours Ecology students or Honours Biological Sciences students.
ECOL 530.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 72 units and consent of the Department.

ECOL 603.title: Advanced Behavioural Ecology
ECOL 603.description: Current problems and recent research in areas of particular significance. Topics will vary from year-to-year but may include natural selection, ecology, behaviour, economic decisions, optimal foraging, sexual selection, mate choice, sociality, parental care, altruism, cooperation, evolutionary game theory, communication, mating systems and tactics. Students will choose their own topics to work on and present to the class.

ECOL 507.01.title: Directed Research in Ecology I
ECOL 507.01.description: Directed training in field/laboratory methods and research.
ECOL 507.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 54 units and consent of the Department.

ECOL 507.02.title: Directed Research in Ecology II
ECOL 507.02.description: Directed training in field/laboratory methods and research.
ECOL 507.02.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 54 units and consent of the Department.

ECON 201.title: Principles of Microeconomics
ECON 201.description: Principles of choice under scarcity and the role of institutions, especially markets, for the production and distribution of goods and services: what and how much gets produced, how is it produced, and who gets what is produced.

ECON 203.title: Principles of Macroeconomics
ECON 203.description:
Measurement of economic activity, economic growth, money and financial systems, international economy and exchange rates, business cycles, unemployment and inflation, and macroeconomic policies.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Economics 201.

ECON 209.title: (ENGG 209) Engineering Economics
ECON 209.description: The basic tools and methodology of engineering economic studies. Topics include investment decisions, theory of replacement, economies of scale, externalities, social decision making and government regulation. Examples are drawn from engineering projects.
ECON 209.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Schulich School of Engineering with second-year standing or higher.

ECON 301.title: Intermediate Economic Theory - Microeconomics I
ECON 301.description: Economic methodology, consumer theory, theory of the firm, competitive markets, efficiency, and the role of economics in public policy.
ECON 301.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Economics 201, 203 and 3 units from Mathematics 249, 265 or 275.

ECON 303.title: Intermediate Economic Theory - Macroeconomics I
ECON 303.description: Determination of national output, unemployment, interest rates, inflation, and exchange rates. Analysis of short-term economic fluctuations, the role of expectations and stabilization policies.
ECON 303.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Economics 201, 203 and 3 units from Mathematics 249, 265 or 275.

ECON 311.title: Computer Applications in Economics
ECON 311.description: Use of spreadsheets for economics applications, including project evaluation with financial-economic functions, oil and gas prospect evaluation, investment portfolio management with database functions, database retrieval, and various topics in micro and macroeconomics.

ECON 321.title: The Global Trading System
ECON 321.description: Introduction to the theory of international trade; provides a basis for examining Canadian trade policy, and regional and world trade institutions such as the WTO and NAFTA. Topics include: tariffs, non-tariff barriers and enhancements, countervail and anti-dumping action, multinational enterprises and international joint ventures.

ECON 323.title: Natural Gas Markets
ECON 323.description: Operation of the natural gas industry in North America. Economics of exploration, development, production, marketing and transportation of natural gas. Impact of government regulations and deregulation.

ECON 328.title: Petroleum Economics
ECON 328.description: Crude oil production and markets in North America and globally. Refining economics and markets for refined products. Government policy including royalty regimes, trade quotas, transport infrastructure, conservation and the environment.

ECON 329.title: Electricity Markets
ECON 329.description: Economic analysis of the deregulated electric power industry including the pricing of power, energy and capacity, power supply and demand, market structure, market architecture, and the design and testing of market rules.

ECON 337.title: Development Economics
ECON 337.description: An introduction to developing economies: the meaning, significance and purpose of economic development, major theories of economic development, economic problems of developing countries.
ECON 337.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Economics 201 and 203 or consent of the Department.

ECON 339.title: Canadian EconomicHistory
ECON 339.description: The growth and development of the Canadian economy in relation to the endowment of natural resources, changing market conditions and technology, and Canadian public policy.
ECON 339.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Economics 201 and 203 or consent of the Department.

ECON 341.title: Money and Banking
ECON 341.description: Operation of financial markets and institutions: the principles of money creation, interest rate determination, and central banking.

ECON 345.title: Economic Analysis Of Law I
ECON 345.description: An introduction to the relationship between law and economics. Economic theory will be used to analyse property and tort law.
ECON 345.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Economics 201 or consent of the Department.

ECON 349.title: The Economics of Social Issues
ECON 349.description: Contribution that economic analysis can make to the understanding of selected current social issues such as poverty, aging, crime, drug abuse and discrimination.

ECON 353.title: Chinese Economy
ECON 353.description: Survey of the economic institutions and processes shaping the Chinese economy, including but not limited to fiscal and monetary policy, financial institutions and financial sector reforms, the restructuring of state-owned enterprises, and the provision of social welfare.

ECON 355.title: Canadian Public Finance
ECON 355.description: Examination of the institutions behind and economic rationale for Canadian government policy relating to public expenditures and taxation. Topics include the history and present structure of government spending and taxation, tax expenditures, the budgetary process, inter-jurisdictional issues, and program design.

ECON 357.title: Intermediate Economic Theory - Microeconomics II
ECON 357.description: Intertemporal choice and choice under uncertainty. General equilibrium and the welfare theorems. Public and social choice theory. Market failures: imperfect competition, externalities, public goods, and informational asymmetries.

ECON 359.title: Intermediate Economic Theory-Macroecononics II
ECON 359.description: Macroeconomic analysis based on microeconomic foundations. Analysis of short-term economic fluctuations under flexible and sticky prices, and the role of government policies. Theories of long-term economic growth.

ECON 371.title: Economic Analysis of Transportation
ECON 371.description: Modal choice by passengers, location choice by firms, capital investment choice. Cost, demand, and market structure related to the determination of transportation rates. Cost/benefit analysis of transportation projects. Analysis will be related to contemporary aspects of ocean shipping, air, rail, trucking, pipelines and urban transportation.

ECON 373.title: Game Theory and Strategic Thinking for the Social Sciences
ECON 373.description: Principles of game theory utilizing a non-mathematical and intuitive approach. Strategic reasoning and the use of game theory to explain social interaction. Game theory analysis is illustrated using applications and examples from economics and other social sciences.

ECON 377.title: Economics and the Environment
ECON 377.description: Analysis of environmental problems from an economic perspective. Efficient allocation of resources and its implications for air and water quality, waste management, biodiversity and endangered species will be addressed from local as well as global perspectives.

ECON 379.title: The Economics of Health
ECON 379.description: Theories and evidence regarding demand for health and health care, consumer and physician behaviour, asymmetric information in health care markets, and economic evaluation of health care programs.

ECON 387.title: Introduction to Mathematical Economics I
ECON 387.description: Mathematics for economics with an emphasis on economic modeling and equilibrium analysis. Multivariate calculus including comparative statics, unconstrained and constrained optimization, and their applications to resource allocation problems.
ECON 387.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Economics 201, 203 and 3 units from Mathematics 249, 265 or 275.

ECON 389.title: Introduction to Mathematical Economics II
ECON 389.description: Application of linear algebra to economic analysis and optimization. Integration and differential equations and their application in economic analysis.

ECON 395.title: Introduction to Econometrics
ECON 395.description: Two-variable and multi-variable linear regression models are introduced, developed and evaluated. Topics include basic data manipulation, econometric estimation of economic relationships, model specification and evaluation, hypothesis testing, and binary variables.

ECON 399.title: Introductory Topics in Economics
ECON 399.description: Examination of a particular topic. Examples include the economics of sports, the economics of the wine industry, and the economics of popular music.
ECON 399.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Economics 201 and 203.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ECON 401.title: Public Sector Economics: Expenditures
ECON 401.description: Theory of government spending. May include the nature of public goods and externalities, the pricing of public services, causes of growth of public expenditures, expenditure incidence, social insurance, social decision procedures, and political and bureaucratic influences.

ECON 403.title: Public Sector Economics: Taxation
ECON 403.description: Theory of taxation. May include the rationale for and the incentive effects of taxation, efficiency and equity aspects of taxation, partial and general equilibrium tax incidence, open economy effects, choice of governing instruments, and tax reform.

ECON 405.title: Political Economy of Public Policy
ECON 405.description: Introduction to the economic foundations of political economy and economic models of public sector policy formation. May include the role of institutions in policy design, theories of bureaucracy, political business cycles, the formation and behaviour of interest groups, and the strategic use of government debt.

ECON 411.title: Computational and Data Methods in Economics
ECON 411.description: Economic application and utilization of computational methods, programming, and data management. Introduction and use of programming in economic analysis, examples include VBA, R, Python, Mathematica, and MATLAB.
ECON 411.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Economics 311 or Management Studies 217 and 9 units in Economics 357, 359 and 395.

ECON 423.title: International Macroeconomics
ECON 423.description: Foreign exchange markets, and international macroeconomic connections with trade in assets as well as goods and services. May include: alternative exchange rate regimes; monetary and fiscal policy responses to problems of unemployment and inflation; balance of payments adjustment mechanisms; international debt; and Euro-dollar markets.

ECON 425.title: International Trade
ECON 425.description: The general equilibrium treatment of the gains from trade, comparative advantage and trade patterns provides a basis for examining topics such as: trade policy under imperfect competition, trade policy and the environment, trade policy and economic growth, and preferential trading arrangements.

ECON 427.title: Energy Economics and Policy
ECON 427.description: Microeconomic analysis of the allocation of energy resources with a focus on policy issues including the environment, OPEC, national security, price and entry regulation, market design, and the potential for new energy sources.

ECON 429.title: Advanced Electricity Markets
ECON 429.description: Market design of electricity markets; transmission regulation, investment and pricing; ancillary service demand, procurement, and regulation; retail competition; and distribution and distributed generation.

ECON 431.title: LabourEconomics
ECON 431.description: Economic analysis of migration, labour force participation, education, fertility, human resources policy, and the measurement and treatment of unemployment.

ECON 443.title: The Economics of Financial Markets
ECON 443.description: Basic functions and structure of financial markets. Economic analysis of trading strategies in financial markets and determinants of equilibrium prices. Institutional features, and analysis, of bond, stock, options, forward and futures markets.
ECON 443.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Economics 311 or Management Studies 217 and 9 units in Economics 341, 357 and 359.

ECON 453.title: Cost-Benefit Analysis
ECON 453.description: Theoretical basis for social cost-benefit analysis, appraisal techniques for investment projects and public policies, and selected applications.

ECON 457.title: The Economics of Business Fundamentals
ECON 457.description: The application of microeconomic theory to business practice with a focus on accounting and finance practice. Critical assessment of financial statements, financial markets, corporate finance, and project evaluation.
ECON 457.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  3 units from Economics 311 or Management Studies 217 and 6 units in Economics 357 and 359.

ECON 471.title: Industrial Organization
ECON 471.description: Behaviour of firms in imperfectly competitive markets. May include the theory of strategic competition; dynamic price competition and tacit collusion; product differentiation, product selection, and preemption; entry deterrence and capacity competition; information, reputation, and predation; the economics of research and development; international trade and imperfectly competitive markets.

ECON 475.title: Economics of Natural Resources
ECON 475.description: Application of economic theory to the problems of natural resource pricing, allocation and conservation. Rent theory, location theory, intertemporal maximization. Natural resource policy formulation. Contemporary Canadian resource problems.

ECON 477.title: Regulatory Economics
ECON 477.description: An introduction to economic regulation, its rationale, form and effects with a focus on the economic theory of regulation and on the practice, structure, and evolution of Canadian regulatory institutions.

ECON 479.title: Experimental Economics
ECON 479.description: Introduces students to the use of and insights gained from experiments in economic research. As part of the course, students will be participating in a variety of in-class experiments.

ECON 481.title: Behavioural Economics
ECON 481.description: Major factors underlying economic behaviour including: various views of the role of rationality in economic analysis and in the economic decision making of individuals and institutions; determinants of individual preferences and decision making procedures; the experimental analysis of economic behaviour; inter-relations between the operation of the economic system and feelings of subjective well-being.

ECON 483.title: History of Economic Thought
ECON 483.description: Traces the evolution of economic ideas from the earliest times up to and including the contributions of the classical economists and Marx. Emphasis will be on understanding these contributions both in terms of their historical context and their relationship to present-day theories and controversies.

ECON 485.title: Economics of the Welfare State
ECON 485.description: The focus is on ideas and economic analysis relevant to understanding the economics of the welfare state, where issues of income redistribution and social insurance are central.

ECON 487.title: Environmental Economics
ECON 487.description: Applies microeconomic theory to the examination of market failures as the source of environmental problems, and to designing and evaluating environmental policies to correct them.

ECON 489.title: Economics of the Movie Business
ECON 489.description: Applies microeconomic theory to the motion-picture industry, focusing on how information and extreme uncertainty shape the structure of economic transactions. The historical and institutional illustrations are set in the context of Hollywood.

ECON 491.title: Managerial and Decision Economics
ECON 491.description: Systematic economic analysis in managerial decision-making. Application of practical ideas to business decisions, integrating global business issues and practices with conceptually rigorous economic analysis.

ECON 493.title: Empirical Energy Economics
ECON 493.description: Students will study and learn how to apply methods of data analysis that are particularly useful in the context of energy economics.

ECON 495.title: Intermediate Econometrics
ECON 495.description: Theory and application of the multivariable linear regression model in time-series, panel data and limited dependent variable models. Least squares and maximum likelihood estimation. Identification issues, fixed and random effects, and instrumental variables.

ECON 497.title: Advanced Econometrics
ECON 497.description: Advanced application of statistics and mathematical modeling to make inferences and estimate the magnitude of causal effects.

ECON 499.title: Intermediate Topics in Economics
ECON 499.description: Examination of a particular topic. Examples include advanced game theory, ethics and economics, water resources, and selected topics from other fields of economics.
ECON 499.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Economics 357, 359 and 395.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ECON 527.title: World Oil Economics
ECON 527.description: Analysis of the world oil industry in the post-World War II period.

ECON 538.title: Trade, Growth and the Environment
ECON 538.description: Advanced examination of the linkages between international trade, the environment, and economic growth.
ECON 538.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Economics 395 and 3 units from Economics 425, 475 or 487.

ECON 541.title: Monetary Theory
ECON 541.description: A survey of recent work in monetary theory with primary emphasis on financial issues.

ECON 557.title: Advanced Microeconomic Theory
ECON 557.description: Advanced study of optimal decision rules, equilibrium, and efficiency. Partial and general equilibrium, fundamental welfare theorems, social choice theory, and market failures including market power, public goods, externalities, and asymmetries of information.

ECON 559.title: Advanced Macroeconomics
ECON 559.description: Methodological principles and models that underlie modern analysis of macroeconomics. Advanced study and modeling of the determination of aggregate economic activity and its fluctuations, stabilization policy (fiscal and monetary), the determinants of economic growth, the effects of policy on economic growth, and unemployment and the labour market.

ECON 571.title: Competition Policy
ECON 571.description: The law and economics of competition policy. An examination of the economics, jurisprudence and history of competition policy towards mergers, price fixing, vertical restraints, and monopolization, primarily in Canada and the United States.

ECON 588.title: Digital Economics Capstone
ECON 588.description: Digital economics research project. Students will use economic reasoning and apply econometric approaches to data to conceptualize and develop a data-based tool that provides value to an organization.

ECON 599.title: Advanced Topics in Economics
ECON 599.description: Examination of a particular topic. Examples include trade policy, monetary economics, time-series econometrics, and analysis of current issues in other fields of economics.
ECON 599.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Economics 357, 359, 395 and consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ECON 605.title: Computational Optimization & Economic Applications
ECON 605.description: Explores the theory and numerical implementation of mathematical programming, covering basic classes of optimization problems -- linear programming, non-linear programming and complementarity problems -- as ways to operationalize models of individual choice and decentralized equilibrium behaviour from economics. Applications will vary.

ECON 609.title: Political Economy
ECON 609.description: Provides a selective overview of modern political economy.  Gives an introduction to the basic theoretical models, empirical methodologies, and substantive findings in political economy. Covers theoretical and empirical research and the links between the two. Also treats a number of selected topics on the research frontier.

ECON 611.title: Special Topics in Economics
ECON 611.description:
Topics will vary from year to year. Consult the timetable or the Department for the topics available in a given year.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ECON 615.title: Econometrics
ECON 615.description: Provides a foundation of econometric theory relevant for empirical work in economics. Covers classical estimation and inference procedures, including linear regression, linear instrumental variables, differences-in-differences, and linear panel data techniques. Also covers the problem of causality and identification in empirical economics.
ECON 615.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Arts Economics program or permission of the Department.

ECON 619.title: Empirical International Trade
ECON 619.description: Examines issues from the economic literature on international trade. Focuses on quantitative and empircal analysis. Specific topics include the factor content of trade, firm level and multinational behaviour, empirical testing of political economy determinants of protection, and assessing the environmental impact of trade agreements.

ECON 621.title: International Trade
ECON 621.description: Focuses on the microeconomic aspects of international economics with emphasis on general equilibrium models commonly employed in international economics. Specific topics covered include theories of international specialization and exchange, trade policy and economic welfare, international factor movement, trade and growth, under both perfect competition and imperfect competition, and selected problems of trade policy in the international trading system.

ECON 627.title: Energy Economics
ECON 627.description: Applies the tools of microeconomics, institutional economics, and econometrics to energy markets and policies. Focuses on empirical studies of the energy business including markets for natural gas, crude oil, gasoline, electricity and coal.

ECON 633.title: Labour Economics
ECON 633.description: Emphasizes empirical implementation of theoretical models through the use of data and econometrics. Topics include labor supply theory, search theory, wage determination theories, and numerical methods for the estimation of dynamic models.

ECON 635.title: Regulatory Economics
ECON 635.description: An in-depth study of regulatory economics, defined as price and entry regulation. Price and entry regulation occurs when the state restricts who can provide services and approves the terms of service. A considerable part of the course will address regulatory restructuring in network industries, with case studies on electricity reform, local telecommunications, and pipelines.

ECON 641.title: Financial Economics
ECON 641.description: A review of  the main themes of financial economics and an introduction of  a number of frontier ideas that have marked the recent evolution of the discipline. The main focus is on asset pricing and the application of financial econometrics to modelling and prediction of financial data.

ECON 649.title: Empirical Public Economics
ECON 649.description:
Focuses on empirical research on the economics of the public sector, including material on taxation, public expenditures and social insurance. Gives a broad overview of this growing field and prepares for research in public economics.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for both Economics 649 and 611.48 will not be allowed.

ECON 651.title: Redistribution & Social Insurance
ECON 651.description: A focus on the economics of public expenditure programs designed to redistribute income or to provide social insurance against risks faced by households.

ECON 653.title: Public Revenue Analysis
ECON 653.description: A focus on the revenue side of public finance, primarily in the form of taxation. The equity and efficiency aspects of different taxes are considered, as is optimal tax design. Possible topics include the taxation of labour and capital, the impact taxation on savings and risk taking, and environmental and resource taxation.

ECON 655.title: Cost/Benefit Analysis
ECON 655.description: Theoretical and applied aspects of the use of cost-benefit techniques and applied welfare analysis in the evaluation of investment projects and public policies.

ECON 657.title: Microeconomic Theory
ECON 657.description: Introduction to advanced microeconomic theory. Topics include consumer theory, theory of the firm, general equilibrium, uncertainty, game theory, and informational economics.
ECON 657.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Arts Economics program.

ECON 659.title: Macroeconomic Theory
ECON 659.description: Introduction to the analysis of macroeconomics at an advanced level. Provides an overview of theories addressing the major questions of macroeconomic phenomena. Some coverage of applied topics, such as economic growth and government policy.
ECON 659.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Arts Economics program.

ECON 661.title: Behavioural Economics
ECON 661.description: Survey of research incorporating psychological evidence into economics. Topics include fairness, altruism, prospect theory, self-control, biases in probabilistic judgment, mental accounting, and the relationship between markets, incentives, and attention and various cognitive processes.

ECON 667.title: Industrial Organization
ECON 667.description: A focus on market power: its acquisition, maintenance, and exercise. Both theory and application, with an emphasis on how industrial organization does, and should, inform competition policy and antitrust law, will be examined.

ECON 669.title: Empirical Industrial Organization
ECON 669.description:
Firm behaviour in oligopolistic markets, as well as consumer and firm behaviour in environments with asymmetric information. Strong emphasis on combining economic models with econometric techniques to answer economic questions. Models of demand and supply, discrete static and dynamic games, production function estimation, single agent dynamic models and matching models.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for both Economics 669 and 611.71 will not be allowed.

ECON 675.title: Natural Resource Economics
ECON 675.description: Examines economic models of the structure and nature of natural resource industries and their interaction with the rest of the economy. Includes non-renewable and renewable resources and applies methods from capital theory, growth theory, public economics, and industrial organization to the study of natural resources.

ECON 677.title: Environmental Economics
ECON 677.description: Environmental economics describes the ways in which people interact with their natural environment and the policies that best achieve society's goals in this context. Topics vary from year to year and may include benefit-cost analysis, non-market valuation, choice of policy instruments, environmental taxation, trade growth and the environment, global warming and international environmental treaties.

ECON 679.title: Health Economics
ECON 679.description:
An overview of topics in health economics. An introduction to economic principles and techniques used in analysing and planning health policy, in particular the delivery of health services, and for understanding the health behaviour of individuals.

Antirequisite: Credit for ECON 679 and MDCH 661 will not be allowed.

ECON 691.title: Research Methods I
ECON 691.description: Survey of research methods in economics. For course-based MA students.

ECON 693.title: Research Methods II
ECON 693.description: Survey of research methods in economics. For course-based MA students.

ECON 695.title: Research Methods III
ECON 695.description: Master's research project. Identify an interesting and feasible research question, carry out an extensive literature review of the problem area, develop an economic/econometric model to address the problem, identify and collect appropriate data for empirical research.
ECON 695.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission into the Master of Arts Economics (course-based) program.

ECON 697.title: Research Methods IV
ECON 697.description: Master's research project. Continuing from Research Methods III, the economic/econometric model is fully developed with specific attention to identification issues and testable hypotheses. Appropriate econometric analyses, validation and testing are carried out, leading to a research paper reporting the problem, the model and the results.
ECON 697.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission into the Master of Arts Economics (course-based) program.

ECON 705.title: Advanced Econometrics I
ECON 705.description: Devoted to rigorous treatment of asymptotic theory as it applies to econometric practice. Provides a detailed treatment of the theory and practice of classical estimation procedures, including linear regression and instrumental variables, Maximum Likelihood, the General Method of Moments, as well as an extension to simulation based methods. The theory of hypothesis testing is also covered.
ECON 705.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the PhD program in Economics.

ECON 707.title: Advanced Microeconomic Theory I
ECON 707.description: Introduction to advanced microeconomic theory. Topics include consumer theory, theory of the firm, and general equilibrium.

ECON 709.title: Advanced Macroeconomic Theory I
ECON 709.description: Introduction to the basic structure of the dynamic general equilibrium framework that forms the backbone of most modern macroeconomics research. Selected topics include growth, business cycles, and monetary and labor economics.

ECON 715.title: Advanced Econometrics II
ECON 715.description: Focuses on the problem of causality and identification of treatment effects in empirical work in Economics. Topics include but are not limited to randomized trials, causality, instrumental variables, difference in differences, regression discontinuity designs. Students are introduced to empirical applications of these different approaches.

ECON 717.title: Advanced Topics in Econometrics
ECON 717.description: Studies cutting edge econometric tools used to evaluate the impacts of policies, extrapolate their effects to new environments, and predict the effects of policies that have never been tried. Methods from both the structural and treatment effect paradigms of policy evaluation will be considered.

ECON 723.title: Trade, Growth & the Environment I
ECON 723.description:
Covers relevant theoretical work on the environmental consequences of trade liberalization and economic growth, and the relationship between resource use and globalization, focusing on newly published research.  Participants are expected to present and discuss research. The specific choice of topics will be made based on research interests of the class.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for both Economics 723 and 611.10 will not be allowed.

ECON 725.title: Trade, Growth & the Environment II
ECON 725.description: Covers relevant empirical work on the environmental consequences of trade liberalization and economic growth, and the relationship between resource use and globalization, focusing on newly published research.  Participants are expected to present and discuss research. The specific choice of topics will be made based on research interests of the class.

ECON 757.title: Advanced Microeconomic Theory II
ECON 757.description: Building on Economics 707, a comprehensive treatment of game theory, the economics of uncertainty and information, and the theory of incentives will be introduced. Other topics may be included as time and interest allow.

ECON 759.title: Advanced Macroeconomics Theory II
ECON 759.description: Building on Economics 709, a survey of the ideas, controversies, and techniques that constitute modern macroeconomics. The principal issues it covers lie at the heart monetary and fiscal policy and of such important social problems as business cycles and unemployment. The empirical study of key issues raised in theoretical and political debates is also emphasized.

ECON 791.title: PhD Research Workshop
ECON 791.description:
Survey of research methods in economics.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

ECON 793.title: PhD Research Workshop II
ECON 793.description: Survey of research methods in economics.
ECON 793.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Economics 791 and admission to the PhD program in Economics.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

EDBT 601.title: Contemporary Education
EDBT 601.description: Examination of philosophical, historical and curricular constructions of contemporary Canadian and Albertan education.
EDBT 601.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bridge to Teaching program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

Also known as: (formerly Educational Research 696.01)

EDBT 602.title: Teaching in Alberta I
EDBT 602.description: Exploration of the core beliefs, values, and practices in contemporary educational environments, and how students can bridge from their own understanding to what is aimed for in Alberta learning environments.
EDBT 602.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bridge to Teaching program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

Also known as: (formerly Educational Research 696.02)

EDBT 603.title: Practicum Support Seminar I
EDBT 603.description: Examination of how to integrate previous teaching expertise and new learning with practicum experiences in Alberta.
EDBT 603.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bridge to Teaching program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

Also known as: (formerly Educational Research 696.03)

EDBT 604.title: Learning with Technology
EDBT 604.description: Examination of ways to create authentic and meaningful learning experiences through the implementation of digital technologies in classroom settings.
EDBT 604.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bridge to Teaching program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

Also known as: (formerly Educational Research 696.04)

EDBT 605.title: Teaching in Alberta II
EDBT 605.description: Further examination of teaching and learning in Alberta classrooms.
EDBT 605.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bridge to Teaching program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

Also known as: (formerly Educational Research 696.05)

EDBT 606.title: Practicum Support Seminar II
EDBT 606.description: Further examination of how to integrate previous teaching expertise and new learning with practicum experiences in Alberta.
EDBT 606.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bridge to Teaching program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

Also known as: (formerly Educational Research 696.06)

EDER 600.title: Research Methodology in Education
EDER 600.description: Examines the foundations of different research methodologies.
EDER 600.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research, or the consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

EDER 602.title: Program and Practice Evaluation
EDER 602.description: Introduction to evaluation as a discipline, as a profession, as a process, and as a product in a wide range of educational and social contexts.
EDER 602.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

EDER 603.title: Research Methods
EDER 603.description: Introduction to various approaches to research in education.
EDER 603.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

EDER 604.title: Collaboratory of Practice
EDER 604.description: Focus is on disciplined inquiry on a research problem and/or action research in an educational context. Research is carried out along with a systematic analysis, synthesis of collected information and findings are reported.
EDER 604.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research

EDER 606.title: Writing Educational Research
EDER 606.description: Introduction to forms and structures of academic writing and knowledge mobilization. Focus is on the exploration of various approaches to sharing research findings according to discipline standards.
EDER 606.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research

EDER 608.title: Research Methods in Education
EDER 608.description: Examines methods, issues of design, and ethical considerations in educational research.
EDER 608.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research

EDER 610.title: Case Study Research in Education
EDER 610.description: Exploration of case study as an approach, methodology, and design related to research in education.
EDER 610.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

EDER 612.title: Participatory Methodology in Education
EDER 612.description: An examination of participatory approaches to inquiry that is oriented toward meaningful, impactful, and sustainable action in educational contexts.
EDER 612.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

Also known as: Credit for Educational Research 612 and 603.27 will not be allowed.

EDER 613.title: Change and Innovation in Education
EDER 613.description: Examines both traditional and contemporary research literature relevant to change and innovation in educational settings.
EDER 613.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research.

EDER 614.title: Action Research in Education
EDER 614.description: Introduction to the intellectual and moral traditions, ideas, and approaches to action research. Knowledge and skills related to the design, implementation, critical reflection, and evaluation of action research are developed.
EDER 614.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

EDER 615.title: Special Topics in Educational Research
EDER 615.description: A survey of theory and research within disciplines in the field of educational research.
EDER 615.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research or the consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

EDER 616.title: Design-Based Research Methods in Education
EDER 616.description: Introduction to the emergence and application of design-based research in education. Explores complexity (systems) theory in addition to key principles and practices.
EDER 616.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

EDER 617.title: Organizational Theory and Analysis in Education
EDER 617.description: Human organization as the setting for the delivery of educational services.
EDER 617.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research.

EDER 618.title: Research Design and Statistics I
EDER 618.description: Introduction to descriptive and inferential univariate statistics, sampling distributions, hypothesis testing, and a variety of statistical techniques used in experimental and correlational methods of research in education and related social sciences.
EDER 618.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

EDER 619.title: Special Topics in Educational Leadership
EDER 619.description: Attends to the contemporary and timely debates that shape educational leadership at local, national and international levels. Topics are reflective of the pressing and current issues in educational leadership.
EDER 619.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

EDER 620.title: Introduction to Interpretive Inquiry
EDER 620.description: Introduction to interpretive approaches to qualitative inquiry such as phenomenology, hermeneutics, narrative inquiry, and interpretive forms of case study.
EDER 620.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

EDER 621.title: Assessment of Classroom Learning
EDER 621.description: Examines both traditional and emerging assessment techniques, including Performance Assessment and Learning Portfolios, for examining students' learning outcomes.
EDER 621.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research.

EDER 624.title: Introduction to Phenomenology and Hermeneutics
EDER 624.description: Advanced study of critical interpretive research methods, featuring phenomenology and hermeneutics as approaches to understanding and exploring engagement within educational research.
EDER 624.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

EDER 625.title: Teacher Evaluation
EDER 625.description: Examines the techniques for assessing teacher performance.
EDER 625.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research.

EDER 626.title: Ethnographic Research Approaches in Education
EDER 626.description: Introduction to ethnographic approaches to research in educational contexts. Explore historical, conceptual, theoretical, practical and ideological issues.
EDER 626.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

EDER 628.title: Indigenous Methodologies in Education
EDER 628.description: Introduction to key theoretical concepts, issues and methodologies based on Indigenous ways of knowing, being, and doing within the context of educational research.
EDER 628.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

EDER 629.title: Special Topics in Assessment/Evaluation
EDER 629.description: Examination of assessment and evaluation theories and practices.
EDER 629.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

EDER 630.title: Indigenous Research Methods in Education
EDER 630.description: An exploration of Indigenous research methods and related issues of design, and ethical considerations in conducting research.
EDER 630.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

EDER 631.title: Special Topics inAdult Learning
EDER 631.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

EDER 635.title: Topics in Adult Learning
EDER 635.description: Explores a variety of current topics and discourses pertaining to adult education and adult learning.
EDER 635.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

EDER 641.title: Research on the Reading Process
EDER 641.description: Examination of various theories about the teaching and learning of reading in the elementary school.
EDER 641.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research.

EDER 649.title: Special Topics in English Language Education
EDER 649.description: Explores a variety of theoretical perspectives and discourses in English Language Education.
EDER 649.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

EDER 650.title: Professional Ethics in School Based Wellbeing, Guidance and Counselling
EDER 650.description: Students will explore ethical, legal and professional issues in the practice and science of school counselling, school-based guidance and wellbeing promotion. Students will learn how to engage in systematic ethical decision-making informed by the professional ethics codes, provincial standards of practice and legislation, and existing school board policies and community partners.
EDER 650.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Master of Education, School Counselling Specialization.

EDER 651.title: Philosophy of Education
EDER 651.description: Philosophical topics in the context of education.
EDER 651.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Research.

Students will develop an understanding of the roles of teachers, counsellors, and other school personnel in promoting career development. The course will also enhance students' skills in implementing effective career guidance practice in school settings. The identification and appropriate application of specific skills for establishing and maintaining working alliances in the context of school-based guidance and wellness promotion will be emphasized.

Students will explore and create cases that address common scenarios in the school context (e.g., bullying, alcohol and drug misuse, domestic violence) and conceptualize possible interventions and practices to support child and youth mental health.
