NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

EDPS 665.title: Cognitive Assessment and Intervention
EDPS 665.description: The theory and practice of intellectual/cognitive, and memory assessment primarily through the use of individually administered standardized tests and evidence-based interventions aimed at promoting cognitive, academic, and neuropsychological development in children and youth.
EDPS 665.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.

EDPS 669.title: Social-Emotional Assessment and Intervention
EDPS 669.description: Focuses on the theory and practice of social, emotional, and behavioural assessment and on evidence-based interventions to enhance the mental health and behavioural well-being of children and youth.
EDPS 669.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Educational Psychology 665 and admission to a graduate program with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.

EDPS 676.title: Practicum in Social, Emotional, and Behavioural Assessment
EDPS 676.description: A supervised practicum in social, emotional, and behavioural assessment. Students will undertake comprehensive social, emotional, and behavioural assessment with children and youth presenting with various developmental disorders. Students will undertake this practicum experience within the Werklund School of Education's Centre for Wellbeing office.
EDPS 676.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Educational Psychology 696 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

EDPS 678.title: Art Therapy History
EDPS 678.description: Art therapy is examined from a broad perspective, from its beginnings as a treatment for mentally or emotionally disturbed people, to its development as a distinct profession in North America and Europe. The works of key authors are covered, along with their theoretical approaches and current trends in the field. Students will learn how the foundations of art therapy are incorporated by many disciplines, with applications in many settings.
EDPS 678.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Educational Psychology 642, 616, 638 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

EDPS 681.title: Theories and Skills of Counselling
EDPS 681.description: An introduction to the major theories of counselling as well as counselling micro-skills and interviewing skills.
EDPS 681.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to Educational Psychology graduate program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

EDPS 682.title: Special Topics: Counselling
EDPS 682.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

EDPS 683.title: Consultation in School Psychology
EDPS 683.description: The definition, purpose and skills of consultation, evaluation issues and strategies in consultation as well as the role of school psychologists relative to multidisciplinary school teams, school-based problems solving, and student development and learning.

EDPS 684.title: Advanced Seminar in the Domains of School Psychology Leadership and Function in the Schools
EDPS 684.description: Provides an advanced study of the domains and functions of school and applied child psychologists. Constituting the final course within the MEd program, students are required to demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of and competency in the ten domains identified by the National Association of School Psychologists as central to the school psychology profession. For each of the ten domains, students will complete a case study requiring the integration of theory, research, and skills.
EDPS 684.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MEd program with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.

EDPS 685.title: Child and Adolescent Counselling
EDPS 685.description: Introduces the theory and practice of counselling in school-based settings and fosters student development of rudimentary counselling and psychotherapy skills for school-based service delivery.
EDPS 685.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

EDPS 686.title: Counselling Graduate Seminar: Selected Topics
EDPS 686.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

EDPS 687.title: Developmental Psychopathology
EDPS 687.description: An examination of the history of psychopathology and abnormal psychology, and the DSM-V. An empirical and theoretical scope will be used to approach childhood disorders including issues with classification, etiology, and developmental course.
EDPS 687.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

EDPS 688.title: Cognitive and Affective Bases of Behaviour
EDPS 688.description: A survey of cognitive development in the first two decades of life. Topics may include biological bases of cognition, perception, memory, motivation, emotion, learning, language and motor.
EDPS 688.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

EDPS 689.title: Cognitive Assessment
EDPS 689.description: A focus on the history, theory and practice of cognitive assessment. This course also focuses on report writing and multicultural assessment within the context of cognitive evaluation.
EDPS 689.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Educational Psychology 653 and admission to the School and Applied Child Psychology graduate program.

EDPS 690.title: School-based Intervention and Consultation
EDPS 690.description: An exploration of school systems, evidence-based interventions, and theories of consultation.
EDPS 690.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the School and Applied Child Psychology graduate program.

EDPS 693.title: Graduate Seminar: Selected Topics
EDPS 693.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology or Educational Research.

EDPS 695.title: Graduate Practicum: Selected Topics
EDPS 695.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology with specialization in Counselling Psychology.

EDPS 696.title: Social, Emotional, and Behavioural Assessment and Intervention
EDPS 696.description: A focus on the assessment and intervention of children and youth who exhibit significant social, emotional, and behavioural needs in school and community settings.
EDPS 696.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.

EDPS 697.title: Practicum in Academic and Cognitive Assessment
EDPS 697.description: With a focus on academic and cognitive functioning, this practicum provides supervised experience to develop competencies aligned with the practice of school psychology including consultation, assessment, and intervention.
EDPS 697.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Educational Psychology 689 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.

EDPS 698.title: Pre-Master's Internship in School and Applied Child Psychology
EDPS 698.description: Within this 1200 hour full-time internship, Masters level interns will have opportunities to demonstrate under supervision their ability to apply their knowledge to develop specific skills needed for effective school psychological service delivery and integrate competencies that address various domains of professional preparation and practice in school psychology.
EDPS 698.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MEd with specialization in School and Applied Psychology and consent of the Academic Coordinator.

EDPS 706.title: Advanced Research Seminar in Counselling Psychology I
EDPS 706.description: Introduction to advanced issues in counselling psychology research.
EDPS 706.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a doctoral program in Educational Psychology. 

Also known as: (formerly Educational Psychology 704)

Note: Students will normally complete Educational Psychology 706 and 707 in the same academic year.

EDPS 707.title: Advanced Research Seminar in Counselling Psychology II
EDPS 707.description: Elaboration of counselling psychology research issues introduced in EDPS 706.
EDPS 707.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Educational Psychology 706 and admission to a doctoral program in Educational Psychology. 

Also known as: (formerly Educational Psychology 704)

Note: Students will normally complete Educational Psychology 706 and 707 in the same academic year.

EDPS 712.title: Program Evaluation and Consultation I
EDPS 712.description: Applied course in program planning, design, evaluation, and consultation for applied psychology contexts.
EDPS 712.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a doctoral program in Educational Psychology.

Also known as: (formerly Educational Psychology 711)

Note: Students will normally complete Educational Psychology 712 and 713 in the same academic year.

EDPS 713.title: Program Evaluation and Consultation II
EDPS 713.description:
Applied course in program planning, design, evaluation, and consultation for applied psychology contexts. 

Prerequisite(s) or Corequisite(s): Educational Psychology 712 and admission to a doctoral program in Educational Psychology.

Also known as: (formerly Educational Psychology 711)

Note: Students must complete Educational Psychology 712 and 713 in the same academic year.

EDPS 731.title: Clinical Supervision in Applied Psychology
EDPS 731.description: Provides students with formal training in clinical supervision with the intent of raising an awareness of supervision models, as well as a conceptual framework and vocabulary for thinking through their supervision practice.
EDPS 731.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a doctoral program in Educational Psychology.

EDPS 732.title: Advanced Seminar in School and Applied Child Psychology
EDPS 732.description: Seminar series that links theory and research with practice in the school psychology domains of professional competence.
EDPS 732.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a doctoral program in Educational Psychology.

EDPS 752.title: Advanced Practicum in Counselling  I
EDPS 752.description: Advanced practicum in counselling psychology, and related seminars.
EDPS 752.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a doctoral program in Educational Psychology with specialization in Counselling Psychology. 

Also known as: (formerly Educational Psychology 742)

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

EDPS 753.title: Advanced Practicum in Counselling  II
EDPS 753.description: The continuation of the advanced practicum in counselling psychology, and related seminars.
EDPS 753.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Educational Psychology 752 and admission to a doctoral program in Educational Psychology with specialization in Counselling Psychology.

Also known as: (formerly Educational Psychology 742)

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

Note: Students will normally complete Educational Psychology 752 and 753 in the same calendar year and at the same practicum site.

EDPS 760.title: Evidenced-Based Consultation for Intervention
EDPS 760.description: Develops advanced problem-solving consultation skills as an indirect service delivery model. Through role play and consultative work in clinic and/or school settings, students gain hands-on experience in problem identification, problem analysis, plan development/implementation, and plan evaluation/recycling.
EDPS 760.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a doctoral program in Educational Psychology.

EDPS 761.title: Advanced Doctoral Practicum in Clinical Assessment and Supervision
EDPS 761.description: Provides opportunities to apply and develop clinical knowledge and skill as well as best-practice approaches to supervision.
EDPS 761.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a doctoral program in Educational Psychology.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

EDPS 762.title: Advanced Assessment
EDPS 762.description: Builds advanced understanding of neuropsychological approaches to assessment and intervention and the use of the cognitive hypothesis testing model to formulate and test hypotheses.
EDPS 762.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a doctoral program in Educational Psychology.

EDPS 763.title: School- and Clinical-based Interventions
EDPS 763.description: Introduces behavioural, social, emotional, and counselling interventions with a particular focus on their application to school and clinical settings for use with children and adolescents.
EDPS 763.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Educational Psychology 685 and admission to a doctoral program in Educational Psychology.

EDPS 764.title: Doctoral Research Seminar
EDPS 764.description: Provides instruction in advanced statistical methods. Topics include, but are not limited to, multilevel/growth curve modelling, structural equation modelling, and topics related to the measurement of growth and change and the use of advanced statistical software.
EDPS 764.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a doctoral program in Educational Psychology.

EDPS 766.title: School-Based Practicum
EDPS 766.description: This advanced practicum will provide students with specialized assessment, intervention, analysis, and strategies in school settings under the supervision of registered school psychologists.
EDPS 766.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a doctoral program in Educational Psychology.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

EDPS 772.title: Advanced Practicum in Psychological Assessment I
EDPS 772.description: Advanced applied training in psychological assessment, including assessment of human personhood and standardized assessment. Students will participate in field experience under the supervision of registered psychologists.
EDPS 772.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Educational Psychology 615 and Educational Psychology 617 or 620, and admission to a doctoral program in Educational Psychology with specialization in Counselling Psychology. 

Also known as: (formerly Educational Psychology 743)

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA 

Note: Students will normally complete Educational Psychology 772 and 773 in the same academic year and at the same practicum site.

EDPS 773.title: Advanced Practicum in Psychological Assessment II
EDPS 773.description: A continuation of advanced applied training in psychological assessment, including assessment of human personhood and standardized assessment. Students will continue their field experience under the supervision of registered psychologists.
EDPS 773.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Educational Psychology 772, and admission to a doctoral program in Educational Psychology with specialization in Counselling Psychology. 

Also known as: (formerly Educational Psychology 743)

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA 

Note: Students will normally complete Educational Psychology 772 and 773 in the same academic year and at the same practicum site.

EDPS 793.title: Graduate Seminar: Selected Topics
EDPS 793.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a doctoral program in Educational Psychology.

EDPS 795.title: Advanced Practicum: Selected Topics
EDPS 795.description: Supervised counselling and school and applied child psychology field experience intended to enhance the professional practice skills of students.
EDPS 795.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a doctoral program in Educational Psychology.

EDPY 600.title: Practicum in Counselling Psychology II
EDPY 600.description: Supervised counselling experience and related seminars.
EDPY 600.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Educational Psychology (EDPS) 600, 601, 614, 615, 625, 647 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

EDPY 602.title: Practicum in Counselling Psychology III
EDPY 602.description: Supervised counselling experience and related seminars.
EDPY 602.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Educational Psychology (EDPS) 600, 601, 614, 615, 625, 647 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

EDUC 101.title: English Academic Success
EDUC 101.description: Students will relate their own life story and experiences to the wider human condition by reading a variety of literary texts and through writing in a variety of literary forms. Assignments will present opportunities for students to develop a critical understanding of literature in a personal context.
EDUC 101.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Bridging to Community-Based BEd stream.

EDUC 201.title: Introduction to Educational Studies
EDUC 201.description: An introduction to the breadth and complexity of educational studies. Unique among academic domains, educational studies not only arises in the intersections of many other fields -- including psychology, sociology, anthropology, and a range of disciplinary domains -- it must also be responsive to a rapidly changing world.
EDUC 201.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Education program or consent of the program.

EDUC 205.title: Reading Educational Research
EDUC 205.description: Focusing on students' reading skills, this course continues to develop awareness of academic language genres, formal versus informal language use, and the development of critical thinking and logical argumentation skills. Continuing development of study skills and approaches that foster long-term academic success are integrated into course materials.
EDUC 205.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Bridging to Community-Based BEd stream or consent of the program.

EDUC 207.title: How Children Learn to Read
EDUC 207.description: Examines how young children learn to read through their world of daily experiences.
EDUC 207.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Bridging to Community-Based BEd stream or the Community-Based Four-Year Early Childhood Education teachable or consent of the program.

EDUC 209.title: Supporting Children's Reading
EDUC 209.description: Students will explore strategies for promoting reading development through integrated experiential learning opportunities.
EDUC 209.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Bridging to Community-Based BEd stream or consent of the program.

EDUC 211.title: Academic Writing in Education
EDUC 211.description: Focusing on students' writing skills, this course develops awareness of academic language genres, formal versus informal language use, as well as the skills required for researching and referencing academic work in written texts. The development of study skills and approaches that foster long-term academic success are integrated with academic language skills development.
EDUC 211.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Bridging to Community-Based BEd stream or consent of the program.

EDUC 213.title: How Children Learn to Write
EDUC 213.description: Examines how young children learn to write through their world of daily experiences.
EDUC 213.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Bridging to Community-Based BEd stream or the Community-Based Four-Year Early Childhood Education teachable or consent of the program.

EDUC 215.title: Supporting Children's Writing
EDUC 215.description: Students will explore strategies for promoting writing development through integrated experiential learning opportunities.
EDUC 215.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Bridging to Community-Based BEd stream or consent of the program.

EDUC 216.title: Teaching and Learning in French as a Second Language
EDUC 216.description: Introducing approaches and strategies to learning French as a second language, engagement is promoted through affirming bi-multilingual identities and exploring literacy in digital contexts to critically construct and communicate meaning.

EDUC 305.title: (MATH 305) Inside Mathematics
EDUC 305.description: An exploration of the usually-tacit elements of mathematical concepts and processes, the course focuses on strategies for unpacking concepts and for sustained engagement in inquiry.
EDUC 305.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 18 units, including Mathematics 211 or 213; and 271 or 273.

Also known as: (Mathematics 305)

EDUC 307.title: Integrating Arts Education
EDUC 307.description: Preparation for individuals interested in understanding effective learning through the arts.  Specific knowledge and technique in arts-based processes will be acquired and applied through collaborative, creating learning tasks.  In this course students will experience, reflect upon, and learn about the processes and practices of arts integration.  Students will be exposed to and collectively explore a variety of contexts through the arts while acquiring knowledge, skills and abilities to plan and apply arts-based research methodologies in their practice.

EDUC 309.title: Early Childhood Development
EDUC 309.description: An examination of the science of early childhood and early brain development that accounts for the physical, cognitive, emotional, and social development of young children from birth to age eight, and a consideration of the implications with respect to children's healthy development and effective educational practices in the early school years.

EDUC 311.title: Language and Literacy, Learning in the Classroom
EDUC 311.description: An introduction to perspectives on the way children and adolescents become "literate", examining language and literacy from a development perspective and children's literature from a genre perspective.

EDUC 313.title: Starting with Story: Teaching and Learning with Indigenous Literatures
EDUC 313.description: With Indigenous literary arts as a doorway into engaging with Indigenous knowledge systems, languages, and communities, this course examines key texts, contexts, and theories to consider applications in educational settings.

EDUC 314.title: Mindfulness and Well-Being in Higher Education
EDUC 314.description: Drawing on secular mindfulness programs, this course offers a skills-based approach to navigating stresses. Students will learn a variety of practices, and research that supports them, to cultivate holistic well-being.

EDUC 420.title: Issues in Learning and Teaching
EDUC 420.description: Presents an overview of the central issues related to the nature of learning and teaching for those preparing for the teaching profession. Themes include: the nature of learning; current realities in society; patterns of growth and development; and the changing dynamics of the teaching profession.
EDUC 420.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BEd After-Degree pathway; or admission to the BEd Four-Year pathway and Education 201; or admission to the BEd Concurrent pathway and 90 units including Education 201 and 3 units of English or French Literature.

EDUC 430.title: Pragmatics of Learning and Teaching
EDUC 430.description: Examines the concomitant requirements within which teachers operate. The major components that will be addressed include the ways in which teachers work within the parameters of prescribed curricula and assessment requirements, follow system and school policies, participate in team teaching and school culture, and reflect one's work, values and goals.
EDUC 430.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BEd After-Degree pathway; or admission to the BEd Four-Year pathway and Education 201; or admission to the BEd Concurrent pathway and 90 units including Education 201 and 3 units of English or French Literature.

EDUC 435.title: Literacy, Language and Culture
EDUC 435.description: Course examines definitions of literacy and how children and youth develop as literate beings. Students will focus on the role of teachers in supporting meaningful engagement with reading, writing, speaking and listening in ways that are attuned to developmental appropriateness, linguistic and cultural diversity, and content area learning.
EDUC 435.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BEd After-Degree pathway; or admission to the BEd Four-Year pathway and Education 201; or admission to the BEd Concurrent pathway and 90 units including Education 201 and 3 units of English or French Literature.

EDUC 440.title: Field Experience I
EDUC 440.description: Students will engage in school settings through observation and assistance to explore the organization of learning in the school and the perspective of the learner and the teacher.
EDUC 440.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BEd After-Degree pathway; or admission to the BEd Four-Year pathway and Education 201; or admission to the BEd Concurrent pathway and 90 units including Education 201 and 3 units of English or French Literature.

EDUC 445.title: Individual Learning: Theories and Applications
EDUC 445.description: Covers contemporary theories regarding the nature of individual learning. Students will examine the ways educators guide and support learning, design effective learning experiences, and understand underpinning factors related to individual learning. The application of these theories will be examined using examples that demonstrate and exemplify individual learning.
EDUC 445.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Education 440 and admission to the BEd program.

EDUC 450.title: Diversity in Learning
EDUC 450.description: Includes key topics in diversity education from a critical social justice perspective. This course aims to foster equitable, diverse, and inclusive learning environments that are accessible to all and free from discrimination. Students will consider the multiple and contested ways in which diversity in learning has been conceived, implemented and evaluated in schools.
EDUC 450.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Education 440 and admission to the BEd program.

EDUC 456.title: Assessment
EDUC 456.description: Includes key topics related to assessment to help students develop professional competencies in relation to the philosophy, theory and pedagogical application of assessment practices for K-12 education.
EDUC 456.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Education 440 and admission to the BEd program.

EDUC 465.title: Field Experience II
EDUC 465.description: This block field experience will have major focus on the complexities of individual learning. Prospective teachers will have the opportunity to follow individual students through various classrooms within their assigned schools under the guidance of their university field instructors and partner school leadership teams.
EDUC 465.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Education 440 and admission to the Bachelor of Education program.

EDUC 521.title: Design for Learning
EDUC 521.description: Students will explore key design processes for pedagogical design in K-12 classrooms from multiple interdisciplinary perspectives and through various knowledge building experiences.
EDUC 521.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BEd/BEd Honours After-Degree pathway and Education 465; or the BEd/BEd Honours Four-Year pathway and Education 465; or admission to the BEd/BEd Honours Concurrent pathway and 120 units including Education 465.

EDUC 525.title: Ethics and Law in Education
EDUC 525.description: An introduction to the historical genesis and institutional structure of Alberta's system of education; an understanding of its legal underpinnings; an opportunity for dialogue; on current major issues in education; and discussion involving ethical decision-making surrounding educational issues.
EDUC 525.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BEd/BEd Honours After-Degree pathway and Education 465; or the BEd/BEd Honours Four-Year pathway and Education 465; or admission to the BEd/BEd Honours Concurrent pathway and 120 units including Education 465.

EDUC 530.title: Indigenous Education
EDUC 530.description: Students will be introduced to the national and international experiences and advances of Indigenous peoples as related to education. Particular attention will be given to understanding the histories and diversity of the First Nations, Mtis and Inuit peoples of Canada and the concomitant implications that this has for education policy and practice.
EDUC 530.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BEd/BEd Honours After-Degree pathway and Education 465; or the BEd/BEd Honours Four-Year pathway and Education 465; or admission to the BEd/BEd Honours Concurrent pathway and 120 units including Education 465.

EDUC 540.title: Field Experience III
EDUC 540.description: Students will engage in increased teaching experiences in a school setting under the guidance of a partner teacher, university field experience instructor and the school leadership team.
EDUC 540.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BEd/BEd Honours After-Degree pathway and Education 465; or the BEd/BEd Honours Four-Year pathway and Education 465; or admission to the BEd/BEd Honours Concurrent pathway and 120 units including Education 465.

EDUC 551.title: Comprehensive School Health and Wellness
EDUC 551.description: A healthy school community supports the wellness of all its members and healthy students make better learners. Within the broader evidence-based comprehensive school health framework, this course provides the theoretical foundations, research base, community resources, and experiential learning to create the capacity for future teachers to be health champions.

EDUC 556.title: Professional Development and Life-Long Learning
EDUC 556.description: Acts as a capstone course, enabling integration of theoretical understandings and field experiences. Students will be introduced to an iterative, knowledge building cycle that considers how student need informs teacher professional learning, builds teacher knowledge and skill and improves student outcomes. Participation in this cycle will strengthen understanding of the adaptive expertise needed to deepen teaching competence.
EDUC 556.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Education 540 and admission to the corresponding route in the BEd program.

EDUC 560.title: Field Experience IV
EDUC 560.description: Students will deepen their engagement in the role of teacher in a school setting under the guidance of a partner teacher, university field experience instructor and the school leadership team.

EDUC 561.title: Reading Instruction in the Elementary Classroom
EDUC 561.description: Students will be provided with both a theoretical understanding of the research and the practical strategies informing the ways in which children from Kindergarten to Grade 6 both learn to read and engage with literacy.

EDUC 562.title: Mathematics Instruction in the Elementary Classroom
EDUC 562.description: Students will gain both a theoretical understanding of the research and the practical strategies informing the ways in which children in grades K-6 positively engage with mathematics.

EDUC 563.title: Complex Classrooms
EDUC 563.description: Students will examine, both theoretically and pedagogically, the development of an inclusive classroom environment and the complexities that exist in K-12 classrooms.

EDUC 564.title: The First Year Teacher
EDUC 564.description: Students are provided with the opportunity to examine and consider the navigation of the common challenges and successes associated with the first year of teaching in the K-12 school system.

EDUC 565.title: Child Development from Grades K-12
EDUC 565.description: An examination of the science of child and youth development from Kindergarten to Grade 12 and brain development that accounts for the physical, cognitive, emotional, and social development across K-12.

EDUC 566.title: Humanities Instruction in the Secondary Classroom
EDUC 566.description: Practical aspects of teaching and theoretical underpinnings will be addressed and deepen student understanding of Humanities in classrooms from grades 7-12.

EDUC 567.title: Mathematics and Science Instruction in the Secondary Classroom
EDUC 567.description: Students will address and deepen student understanding of both the practical aspects of teaching and theoretical underpinnings of STEM instruction in classrooms from grades 7-12.

EDUC 568.title: Supporting English Language Learners
EDUC 568.description: Students will deepen their theoretical understanding and pedagogical knowledge in working with learners whose first language is one other than English from kindergarten to grade 12.

EDUC 569.title: Assessment as Learning in K-12
EDUC 569.description: Students will deepen their understanding of the role of assessment in designing and enacting learning for children and youth in kindergarten to grade 12.

EDUC 570.title: Field Experience for Certification
EDUC 570.description: An extended block field experience to lead a class with a mentor teacher. Students will be supervised by their University field instructors and partner teachers.

EDUC 571.title: Research Seminar in Educational Studies
EDUC 571.description: The opportunity to understand, implement and critique the research methods commonly associated with research in Education.
EDUC 571.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission into the Bachelor of Education (Honours) pathway.

EDUC 572.title: Bachelor of Education Independent Study
EDUC 572.description: An independent study course for Bachelor of Education Honours students under the supervision of a faculty member.
EDUC 572.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Education 571 and admission to the Bachelor of Education (Honours) pathway.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

EDUC 580.title: Indigenous Literacy Arts as a Doorway to Decolonizing Pedagogy and Practice: Starting with Story
EDUC 580.description: Build competencies in engaging with Indigenous knowledge systems and communities in teaching and learning. Educators will explore Indigenous literary arts along with relevant theories, contextual knowledge, and personal-professional reflexivity.

EDUC 581.title: Emerging Digital Pedagogies
EDUC 581.description: Provides educators with increased understanding of digital pedagogies and the literacies that can be implemented to support digital learning.

EDUC 582.title: Teaching Diversity in the Inclusive Classroom
EDUC 582.description: Provides educators with a strong foundational understanding of the role of diversity in K-12 education and will provide practical ideas for teaching about diversity in an inclusive classroom context.

EDUC 427.01.title: STEM Early Childhood Education
EDUC 427.01.description: An introduction to key elements of STEM Education, including curriculum, pedagogy, standards and assessment. Participants will learn how to engage students and integrate STEM topics across all subject areas.
EDUC 427.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BEd After-Degree pathway and corresponding route; or admission to the BEd Four-Year pathway and corresponding route and Education 201; or admission to the BEd Concurrent pathway and corresponding route and 90 units including Education 201 and 3 units of English or French Literature.

EDUC 427.02.title: STEM Elementary Route
EDUC 427.02.description: An introduction to key elements of STEM Education, including curriculum, pedagogy, standards and assessment. Participants will learn how to engage students and integrate STEM topics across all subject areas.
EDUC 427.02.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BEd After-Degree pathway and corresponding route; or admission to the BEd Four-Year pathway and corresponding route and Education 201; or admission to the BEd Concurrent pathway and corresponding route and 90 units including Education 201 and 3 units of English or French Literature.

EDUC 427.03.title: STEM Secondary Route
EDUC 427.03.description: An introduction to key elements of STEM Education, including curriculum, pedagogy, standards and assessment. Participants will learn how to engage students and integrate STEM topics across all subject areas.
EDUC 427.03.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BEd After-Degree pathway and corresponding route; or admission to the BEd Four-Year pathway and corresponding route and Education 201; or admission to the BEd Concurrent pathway and corresponding route and 90 units including Education 201 and 3 units of English or French Literature.

EDUC 427.04.title: STEM K-12 (Community-Based pathways only)
EDUC 427.04.description: An introduction to key elements of STEM Education, including curriculum, pedagogy, standards and assessment. Participants will learn how to engage students and integrate STEM topics across all subject areas.
EDUC 427.04.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BEd After-Degree pathway and corresponding route; or admission to the BEd Four-Year pathway and corresponding route and Education 201; or admission to the BEd Concurrent pathway and corresponding route and 90 units including Education 201 and 3 units of English or French Literature.

EDUC 460.01.title: Specialization I Elementary Early Childhood Education

EESS 601.title: Introduction to EESS
EESS 601.description: The course provides a structured overview to the interactions of energy systems and the environment. The lectures are taught collaboratively by several EESP EESS faculty. The course aims to foster a unified, scientific understanding of energy flows and transformations in industrial society and the natural world; a scientific overview of some of the most important links between energy and environmental systems; and an introduction to the business, legal and regulatory systems that shape the interactions between energy and environment.
EESS 601.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Energy and Environmental Systems specialization or instructor permission.

EESS 603.title: Project Course
EESS 603.description: Projects are applied interdisciplinary problem-solving courses in which students work as leaders or as members of project teams. Most course time is devoted to project management and presentations from students. The project course gives students experience working on weakly-structured, real-world problems that require teamwork and contributions from diverse disciplines. They are co-managed by students and faculty advisors and should be responsive to an external "client" or expert panel. Problem areas are abstracted from local, provincial and national situations and involve the interaction of energy systems, the environment and public policy. Oral and written presentations concerning the results of project studies are required.
EESS 603.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Energy and Environmental Systems specialization or instructor permission.

EESS 607.title: Tools for Systems Analysis
EESS 607.description: This course provides an introduction to analytical methods and software tools that are most frequently used for research in energy and environmental systems. Analytical methods include risk, uncertainty and decision analysis; an introduction to engineering economics; and an introduction to tools for environmental modeling. Software tools include Excel, and extensions such as Crystalball, general purpose systems such as Matlab and Mathematica; and GIS tools for non-specialists.
EESS 607.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Energy and Environmental Systems specialization or instructor permission.

EESS 619.title: Special Topics
EESS 619.description: Students will be provided with the opportunity to focus on advanced studies in specialized topics pertaining to energy system engineering, law, public policy or economics, or a combination of these issues.
EESS 619.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Energy and Environmental Systems specialization or instructor permission. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ENAE 410.title: Aerospace Analysis and Design
ENAE 410.description: Basics of aerospace performance and design. Introduction to various types of aerospace vehicles and their principles of operation. Performance and design of conventional fixed-wing aircraft with a focus on modern applications. A basic introduction to aerospace engineering principles related to aircraft configuration, aerodynamics, equations of motion, structural considerations, weight estimates, basic maneuvers, propulsion, and control are covered. Elements of the design process are introduced, including the concept of operations, setting engineering requirements, detailed design, verification and validation, and consideration of multidisciplinary factors.
ENAE 410.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Electrical Engineering 301, or Electrical Engineering 343 and 353; and admission to the Minor in Aerospace Engineering.

ENAE 411.title: Introduction to Aerospace Systems and Systems Engineering
ENAE 411.description: Introduction to aerospace systems covering the range of mechanical, electrical, electro-mechanical, management and engineering systems that enable safe operation of vehicles. Conventional aircraft systems are covered at varying levels of detail including air data, inertial data and inertial navigation, GPS, radio navigation and communication systems, primary and secondary radar. Essential systems to modern aircraft traffic management are also introduced.
ENAE 411.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Aerospace Engineering 410; and admission to the Minor in Aerospace Engineering.

ENCH 300.title: Process Engineering Fundamentals
ENCH 300.description: Engineering problem solving, critical thinking, and creative thinking. Basic engineering calculations. Material balances for non-reacting and reacting systems, with applications in energy, chemical, environmental, and biological processes. Processes, unit operations, and flow diagrams. Introduction to process equipment and the development and analysis of sustainable processes.

ENCH 307.title: Numerical Methods, Data Analysis, and Simulation
ENCH 307.description: The theory and use of numerical computational procedures to solve design and analysis problems. Methods for solution of nonlinear equations; solution of simultaneous linear equations; regression, curve fitting, and interpolation; optimization; numerical differentiation and integration; solution of ordinary differential equations; introduction to linear programming.
ENCH 307.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Engineering 233, Digital Engineering 233, 440, or Energy Engineering 370; and Mathematics 375 or 331.

ENCH 315.title: Chemical Engineering Process Calculation
ENCH 315.description:
Material and energy balances of physical and chemical systems for steady state and transient conditions. Introduction to analysis and synthesis of chemical processes.

Corequisite(s): Engineering 311.

ENCH 317.title: Materials Science for Chemical Engineers
ENCH 317.description: Classes of inorganic and polymeric materials and their applications, crystal structure determination, phase diagrams and phase transformation, defects and material properties, materials processing methods, characterization tools for materials engineers, nanotechnology.
ENCH 317.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Engineering 202 and Mathematics 275 or Applied Mathematics 217.

ENCH 327.title: Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics
ENCH 327.description: Review of first and second law principles; application to the properties of fluids and solutions; vapour liquid equilibria; the third law; applications to chemical equilibrium and chemical reactions.

ENCH 331.title: Process Fluid Dynamics
ENCH 331.description: Fluid Properties; Newtonian and non-Newtonian fluids. Fluid statics. Bernoulli equation; derivation and applications. Control volume and system representation. Differential analysis of Flows. The Navier-Stokes equation; applications. Dimensional analysis. Flow in conduits; laminar and turbulent flows; single-pipe and multiple-pipe systems. Forces on immersed bodies; fluidization. Metering.

ENCH 350.title: Introduction to Process Analysis and Design
ENCH 350.description: Strategies for the solution of engineering problems involving material and energy balances of physical and reactive chemical systems in steady state and transient conditions. Introduction to phase equilibria for multicomponent systems. Design and analysis of a large-scale process.

ENCH 400.title: Design for Economics and Sustainability
ENCH 400.description: Design of chemical processes, emphasizing trade-offs between technical, economic, and sustainability considerations. Measures of economic profitability and environmental impact. Markets and price formation. Estimation of capital investment, cost of production, taxes, depreciation, and cash flows. Sensitivity analysis and optimization techniques. Basic concepts in industrial ecology. Comparison of alternatives and decision making under uncertainty.

ENCH 401.title: Partial Differential Equations in Transport Processes
ENCH 401.description: Modelling of transport phenomena. Partial differential equations in different co-ordinate systems. Approximate and exact methods of solving equations. Similarity transform, Separation of variables. Laplace transform. Fourier series and Sturm-Liouville systems. Analysis and solution of steady state and transient diffusion problems including Fourier, Darcy and Fick's law analogies. Application to energy transfer in solids and pressure propagation in reservoirs.

ENCH 403.title: Heat Transfer
ENCH 403.description: A study of concepts involved in heat transfer. Applications of continuity and energy equations. Boundary layer theory. Conduction, convection and radiation heat transfer. Analogies among heat, mass, and momentum transfer. Boiling, condensation and evaporation. Heat exchanger calculations.

ENCH 405.title: Mass Transfer and Separation Processes
ENCH 405.description: Diffusion and convective mass transfer, mass transfer rates, and mass transfer coefficients. Analysis and modelling of separation processes involving phase equilibria and mass transfer. Batch and continuous separations. Tray and packed columns for distillation, absorption and stripping and other unit operations.

ENCH 407.title: Numerical Methods in Chemical and Oil & Gas Engineering
ENCH 407.description: The theory and use of numerical computational procedures to solve chemical and oil and gas engineering problems. Methods for solution of nonlinear equations, solution of simultaneous linear equations, regression, curve fitting, optimization, interpolation, differentiation, integration, solution of ordinary differential equations and partial differential equations are included.
ENCH 407.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): One of Engineering 233, Digital Engineering 233 or 440; and Mathematics 375 or 331.

ENCH 417.title: Materials Engineering
ENCH 417.description: Classes of inorganic and polymeric materials and their applications, crystal structure determination, phase diagrams and phase transformation, defects and material properties, materials processing methods, characterization tools for materials engineers, nanotechnology, composites, electronic materials, and construction materials

ENCH 421.title: Chemical Reaction Engineering
ENCH 421.description: Kinetics of homogeneous reactions and the interpretation of kinetic data; design of single and multiple reactors for simple, simultaneous and consecutive reactions; influence of temperature, pressure and flow on reactions and reactor design; introduction to heterogeneous reaction systems and catalyzed fluid reactions.
ENCH 421.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemical Engineering 327; and Chemical Engineering 307 or 407.

ENCH 423.title: Chemical Engineering Process Development
ENCH 423.description: Design of chemical processing units and plants; cost estimates and chemical process economics; optimization techniques; introduction to linear programming. Safety and environmental considerations in process design.

ENCH 427.title: Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics
ENCH 427.description: Review of first and second law principles; application to the properties of fluids and solutions; vapour liquid equilibria; the third law; applications to chemical equilibrium and chemical reactions.
ENCH 427.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Engineering 311 or Energy and Environment 311 and Chemical Engineering 315.

ENCH 429.title: Process Dynamics and Control
ENCH 429.description: Mathematical models describing transient response characteristics of basic process elements; design and analysis of feedback control systems, digital process control hardware and software; process automation and information flow in industrial plants; introduction to advanced control strategies; process control applications.
ENCH 429.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 375; and Chemical Engineering 315 or 350.

ENCH 450.title: Chemical Process Design and Simulation
ENCH 450.description: Process selection and synthesis; process engineering drawings; process modelling and simulation. Design of process equipment such as heat exchangers, pumps, piping, and separation units. Plantwide process control. Safety and hazard assessments. Completion of an open-ended design project involving the use of a steady-state process simulator to solve problems related to chemical processing, energy, and sustainability.

ENCH 500.title: Chemical Engineering Design I
ENCH 500.description: Team design project in which students integrate creative and critical thinking skills with the knowledge and experience gained from earlier courses to solve open-ended design problems while refining their skills in teamwork and project management. Preparation of a feasibility study of a chemical process or product including supply and demand forecasts, estimation of capital and operating costs, process drawings and recommendation as to the viability of the project.

ENCH 501.title: Transport Phenomena
ENCH 501.description: Simplification, scaling and dimensional reasoning. Error estimation. Heat, mass and momentum transfer analyses. Convective-Diffusive transport in open and porous media. Systems and process modelling. Analytical solutions by the lumped, integral and differential techniques.

ENCH 503.title: Crude Oil Upgrading and Refining
ENCH 503.description: Upgrading objectives; analysis and composition of non-distillable material and its relationship to upgrading; upgrading processes; refinery products and specifications.  Conventional, heavy oil and bitumen upgrading technology.
ENCH 503.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Third-year standing, or higher, in Chemical Engineering or Oil and Gas Engineering, or consent of department.

ENCH 505.title: Design of Separation Processes
ENCH 505.description: Application of mass and heat transfer, thermodynamics, and other fundamental concepts in chemical engineering to develop process design specifications for various unit operations which may include crystallization, humidification and cooling, drying, adsorption, and membrane processes.

ENCH 510.title: Chemical Process Design and Simulation
ENCH 510.description: Process selection and synthesis; use and recognition of the limitations of process simulation software; block diagrams, process flow diagrams and piping and instrumentation diagrams; shortcut methods for sizing process equipment; optimizing the design of distillation columns, reactors, etc., via steady-state simulation; economic design trade-offs between plant reaction and separation sections; plantwide process control; safety and hazard assessments; completion of open ended design projects.
ENCH 510.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemical Engineering 405, 421, 423, 429 and admission to the Chemical Engineering program.

ENCH 511.title: Chemical Process Design I
ENCH 511.description: Team design project applying principles of process engineering and project management; Gantt charts; critical path method; process simulation, degrees of freedom analysis; considerations in process selection; plant location; block flow diagrams; process flow diagrams; short cut process equipment design/sizing procedures; preliminary equipment cost estimating techniques.
ENCH 511.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemical Engineering 405, 421, 423, 429 and admission to the Chemical Engineering program.

ENCH 519.title: Special Topics
ENCH 519.description: Current advanced topics in Chemical Engineering.
ENCH 519.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ENCH 530.title: Electrochemical Engineering
ENCH 530.description: Electrochemical kinetics and thermodynamics. Mass transport in electrochemical cells. Design and modelling of electrochemical cells. Application of electrochemistry to fuel cells, batteries, and water treatment.

ENCH 531.title: Chemical Process Design II
ENCH 531.description: Team design project continuing from Chemical Engineering 511. Detailed design of large commercial plants involving the preparation of a process and instrumentation diagram; emphasis on computer design procedures; specification sheets for chemical processing equipment such as separators, pumps, compressors, columns and process piping. Other topics include operational considerations in design, plant safety; relief system design; waste treatment and pollution control processes; plant and equipment plot plans; control and computer simulation.

ENCH 535.title: Principles of Biochemical Engg
ENCH 535.description: Introduction to biochemistry, enzyme kinetics and cell growth and metabolism. Aspects of mass transfer, heat transfer and fluid flow related to the design of biological process equipment. Fermentations, sterilization and extraction techniques. Treatment of effluents. Introduction to bio-reactor design and scale-up. Introduction to process instrumentation and control.

ENCH 537.title: Computational Thermodynamics
ENCH 537.description: Amalgamation of thermodynamic models and computational techniques with application to industrially important thermodynamic problems such as multi-component flash calculations, reacting systems, phase stability and gas hydrates.
ENCH 537.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemical Engineering 427 or consent of the Department.

ENCH 539.title: Polymer Engineering
ENCH 539.description: Introduction to polymer science and technology. Molecular structure, processing, rheology, thermal, physical and mechanical properties. Synthetic polymers used in biomedical, manufacturing and other advanced technological applications.
ENCH 539.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemical Engineering 403 or Biomedical Engineering 455.

ENCH 550.title: Chemical Engineering Design II
ENCH 550.description: A continuation of the Chemical Engineering 500 capstone design project, where student teams build on their design work done in Part I. Focus may include detailed design, prototyping, pilot scale demonstration, hazard analysis, identification and mitigation of design inefficiencies and risks, process operability, and energy optimization

ENCH 551.title: Chemical Engineering Laboratory
ENCH 551.description: Experiments which demonstrate the operation of chemical process equipment involving heat and/or mass transfer, or kinetics. Lectures will cover experimental design and applied statistics.

ENCH 561.title: Machine Learning for Energy Systems
ENCH 561.description: Applications of Machine Learning, Artificial Intelligence and Optimization in Energy Systems. Review of Statistics, Probability and Data Science Concepts; Supervised and Unsupervised Learning in Python including Regression and Clustering; Data Engineering for Data Filtering and Feature Selection; Optimization. Focus on Application to Problems in the Energy Industry.
ENCH 561.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Engineering 319 or Digital Engineering 319; and 3 units from Engineering 407, Digital Engineering 407, Chemical Engineering 307 or 407.

ENCH 565.title: Process Sensors and Data Acquisition
ENCH 565.description: Introduction to chemical engineering sensors and information processing techniques. Basic concepts of process measurement methods and signals. Data acquisition hardware and software. Identifying errors and uncertainties in process measurements. Filtering and smoothing of process signals. Introduction to Fourier analysis. Devices for measuring temperature, pressure and chemical composition. Common failure modes and error sources. Process instrument calibration.
ENCH 565.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Engineering 319 or Digital Engineering 319; and 3 units from Engineering 407, Digital Engineering 407, Chemical Engineering 307 or 407.

ENCH 591.title: Research Thesis I
ENCH 591.description: A research project in which chemical engineering principles are applied to solve a complex, open-ended problem. Conducted under the supervision of a faculty member on a topic selected by the supervising faculty member and the student. The project may be experimental, computational, analytical, or have design emphasis. Includes an independent study component covering the scientific process, ethics, review of literature, and writing scientific proposals and manuscripts.
ENCH 591.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Fourth year standing, or higher.

ENCH 593.title: Research Thesis II
ENCH 593.description: A directed studies research project intended for students who have successfully completed a Chemical Engineering 591 project and wish to continue the assigned project. The course culminates with a written thesis and oral presentation.

ENCH 607.title: Natural Gas Processing Principles
ENCH 607.description:
Physical and chemical properties of natural gases; vapour-liquid equilibrium data and computations; flow of gas and gas-liquid mixtures; separation of gaseous mixtures; heat transfer in gas processing; production of natural gas and its associated liquids.

Notes: This course does not count towards the degree requirement of MSc and PhD students.

ENCH 609.title: Natural Gas Processing Technology
ENCH 609.description: Design and operational criteria in transporting and processing of natural gas; refrigeration and compression; cryogenics; hydrocarbon dew point control; LPG recovery; sulphur recovery; mechanical flow diagrams; process simulation.
ENCH 609.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemical Engineering 607 or an undergraduate degree in Chemical Engineering.

ENCH 613.title: Advanced Topics In Mass Transfer
ENCH 613.description: Advanced concepts in mass transfer in multiphase systems. Mass transfer with simultaneous chemical reaction and heat transfer.

ENCH 615.title: Model Predictive Control
ENCH 615.description: Review of process dynamics and control fundamentals (step response curves, PID control structures and PID controller tuning).  Identification of finite impulse response models from plant data.  Model predictive Control (MPC) algorithms (e.g. Dynamic Matrix Control).  Applications of Linear Programming to determine optimal MPC setpoints respecting unit constraints.  Computer simulation using the MATLAB MPC toolbox.  Introduction to univariate controller performance assessment techniques.

ENCH 617.title: Modelling and Identification Advanced Control
ENCH 617.description: First-principles dynamic models of complex chemical processes. Comparison of dynamic simulation models generated using MATLAB/Simulink with those imbedded in commercial process simulators. Consideration of operability in plant design. Introduction to time series analysis and closed-loop identification. Causality versus correlation. Multivariate regression methods for soft sensor design.

ENCH 619.title: Special Problems
ENCH 619.description:
Advanced studies on specialized topics in chemical, petroleum, biochemical and environmental engineering.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ENCH 620.title: Graduate Project
ENCH 620.description: Individual project in the student's area of specialization under the guidance ofa faculty member. A written proposal, one or more written progress reports, and a final written report are required. An oral presentation is required upon completion of the course. Open only to students in the MEng (course-based) program.

ENCH 621.title: Reservoir Simulation
ENCH 621.description: Enhanced recovery modelling (generalized black-oil models, compositional and miscible), well treatment, grid orientation. New developments in gridding, thermal models, naturally fractured reservoirs, modelling of induced fractures (hydraulic and waterflood), reservoir geomechanics, and practical aspects of conducting simulation studies.
ENCH 621.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Petroleum Engineering  429 or 523, or admission to the Master of Engineering with Reservoir Characterization specialization.

ENCH 623.title: Chemical Reactor Design
ENCH 623.description: Advanced study of design and operation of chemical reactors for both homogeneous and heterogeneous systems, batch, continuous flow stirred tank, tubular and multibed adiabatic reactors. Cold shot cooling in reactors. Optimal temperature gradients and yields. Catalyst effectiveness factors and optimal control with decaying catalysts. Analysis of sulphur plant reactor design including cost optimization.
ENCH 623.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemical Engineering 421 or consent of the Department.

ENCH 625.title: Advanced Topics in Heat Transfer
ENCH 625.description: Diffusive and convective transport of heat. Analytical and approximate solutions to steady state and transient conduction and convection problems. Superposition techniques. Forced convection of heat in laminar and turbulent regimes.

ENCH 627.title: Chemical Process Simulation
ENCH 627.description: Object oriented programming applied to the design of a steady state chemical process simulator via the sequential modular approach and by the equation based approach.  Material and energy balances for systems of process units.

ENCH 629.title: Secondary & Tertiary Recovery
ENCH 629.description: Displacement processes for improved recovery of hydrocarbons. Waterflooding, gas flooding, solvent flooding and chemical flooding. Performance prediction techniques. Comparative economics.
ENCH 629.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Petroleum Engineering 525 or consent of the Department.

ENCH 630.title: Electrochemical Engineering
ENCH 630.description:
Electrochemical kinetics and thermodynamics. Mass transport in electrochemical cells. Design and modelling of electrochemical cells. Application of electrochemistry to fuel cells, batteries, and water treatment.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Chemical Engineering 630 and any of 519.13, 519.14 or 651 will not be allowed.

ENCH 631.title: Advanced Topics in Fluid Mechanics
ENCH 631.description: Constitutive equations for viscous flow and methods of solution.   Laminar, transition and turbulent flows.  Hydrodynamic stability.  Vortices.  Boundary layers.

ENCH 633.title: Chemical Thermodynamics
ENCH 633.description: Advanced application of thermodynamic principles. Calculation of thermodynamic properties; ideal and non-ideal solution theory; calculation of phase equilibria; properties of reacting mixtures.
ENCH 633.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemical Engineering 427 or consent of the Department.

ENCH 638.title: Polymer Science & Engineering
ENCH 638.description:
Introduction to polymer science, molecular structure, processing, rheology, thermal, physical and mechanical properties; synthesis methods, molar mass distributions, polymer analytical techniques, solution and blend thermodynamics, lattice models, polymer processing, rubber thermodynamics; fluid mechanics/heat transfer fundamentals of melt processing operations, anomalies arising from melt elasticity; and advanced technological applications. 

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Chemical Engineering 638 and 539 will not be allowed.

Also known as: (formerly Chemical Engineering 619.38 Polymer Engineering)

ENCH 639.title: Applied Numerical Methods in Engineering
ENCH 639.description: Numerical solution of systems of linear and non-linear algebraic equations, eigenvalue problems. Numerical solution of systems of ordinary and partial differential equations. Initial value and boundary value problems. Finite difference and finites element methods.  Numerical stability.
ENCH 639.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Engineering 407 or consent of the Department.

ENCH 643.title: Air Pollution Control Engineering
ENCH 643.description:
Introduction to air quality and air pollution. Energy and air pollution. Fossil fuel combustion and related air pollution. Industrial air pollution control. Control of particulate matter. Control of VOCs, SOx, and NOx. Adsorption, absorption and biofiltration of air pollutants. GHG emission control. Recent advances on related topics. 

Notes: Credit for both Chemical Engineering 643 and Environmental Engineering 641 will not be allowed.

ENCH 645.title: Industrial and Produced Wastewater Treatment
ENCH 645.description:
Sources and characterization of industrial wastewater. Treatment objectives and regulations. Unit and process design.  Physical/chemical treatment including  sedimentation, coagulation, filtration, absorption, adsorption, ion exchange, membrane processes and pH adjustment.				

Notes: Credit for both Chemical Engineering 645 and Environmental Engineering 661 will not be allowed.

ENCH 647.title: Thermal Recovery Methods
ENCH 647.description: Oil sands and heavy oil resources. Fluid and rock properties. Heat transfer processes in porous media. Comparative analysis of viscous oil recovery methods: steam flooding, cyclic steam stimulation, in-situ combustion and steam-assisted-gravity-drainage. Surface equipment and operation. Laboratory and field performance evaluation of thermal recovery methods. Process economics.
ENCH 647.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Petroleum Engineering 429, 523 or 621, or admission to the Master of Engineering with Reservoir Characterization specialization.

ENCH 649.title: Naturally Fractured Reservoirs
ENCH 649.description: Classification and characterization of naturally fractured reservoirs.  Drilling and completion methods.  Production characteristics.  Tight gas reservoirs.  Reserve estimation. Emphasis is placed on the relationship between geology, log interpretation, well testing, and primary-secondary recovery of hydrocarbons from naturally fractured reservoirs.

ENCH 650.title: CO2 Capture, Utilization, and Storage (CCUS): Principles, Technologies, and Analysis
ENCH 650.description:
Introduction to the concepts of carbon cycle and sustainable development. Study principles, design, and application of various CCUS technology streams such as absorption, adsorption, membranes, oxy-fuel combustion, chemical looping combustion, and CO2 conversion. Overview of geological sequestration of CO2 and negative emission technologies such as DAC (Direct Air Capture), BECCS (Bio-Energy with CCS) and Indirect Ocean Capture. Introduction to the concepts of Life cycle and techno-economic assessment to analyze the feasibility of CCUS technologies. Discussion on sustainability aspects of CCUS with focus on policy & regulatory landscape for CCUS in Canada. 

Also known as: (formerly Chemical Engineering 619.66 CO2 Capture:Sci, Engg, Society)

ENCH 653.title: Horizontal Wells for Petroleum Production
ENCH 653.description: Drilling and completion methods for horizontal wells; mathematical analysis of steady state flow to horizontal wells and well combinations; pseudo steady state and constant well bore pressure models; theoretical comparisons of predicted performance and coning behaviour of horizontal and vertical well patterns; performance in fractured reservoirs; potential for horizontal wells in heavy oil and bitumen production; basic conceptual ideas of steam-assisted gravity drainage.
ENCH 653.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Petroleum Engineering 429 or Petroleum Engineering 523 or consent of the Department.

ENCH 657.title: Advanced Reservoir Engineering
ENCH 657.description: Formulation and solution of reservoir-engineering problemsincluding combination of variables, Laplace transform, approximate Integral methods, and solution methods of moving boundary problems. Examples from thermal processes (e.g. hot waterflooding, SAGD), different recovery mechanisms (e.g. imbibition, expansion drive, solution-gas drive), well testing problems and naturally fractured reservoirs.
ENCH 657.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Petroleum Engineering 429 or Petroleum Engineering 523, or admission to the Master of Engineering with Reservoir Characterization specialization.

ENCH 659.title: Advanced Cell and Tissue Engineering
ENCH 659.description: Current challenges in tissue engineering. Focus on specific tissues. Course topics include a brief biology review, cell fate processes, stem cells, tissue microenvironments and mass transfer, biomaterials, bioreactors, and clinical delivery of tissue engineered constructs.

ENCH 661.title: Geostatistics for Reservoir Characterization
ENCH 661.description: Statistical/probability concepts, exploratory data analysis, spatial structural analysis, estimation theory (Kriging), integration of auxiliary information and conditional stochastic simulation. Special emphasis on reservoir characterization and the particular problems encountered in that area. The geostatistical methodology for reservoir characterization will be demonstrated on a fluvial reservoir example.
ENCH 661.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Petroleum Engineering 429 or 523 or admission to either the Master of Engineering or the Master of Science, with a specialization in Reservoir Characterization.

ENCH 665.title: Wastewater Issues for the Oil & Gas Industry
ENCH 665.description:
Produced water characteristics,  regulations governing produced water management, management options.  Technologies used for produced water treatment, novel/emerging technologies.  Process design approaches and comparative evaluation of various technologies. Case Studies.

Notes: Credit for both Chemical Engineering  665 and Environmental Engineering 665 will not be allowed.

ENCH 669.title: Advanced Heat, Mass, and Momentum Transport
ENCH 669.description: Macroscopic balance equations. Differential and integral descriptions of both steady state and transient heat, mass and momentum transport. Analytical solutions of problems involving single and multi-modes of transport. Application of transport phenomena to chemical engineering problems. Introduction to the use of commercial numerical software for solving transport phenomena problems.

ENCH 671.title: Science and Technology of Catalysis
ENCH 671.description:
Catalytic Science and Kinetic Analysis, Thermodynamically and kinetically controlled catalytic processes, reaction modeling and catalyst deactivation. Essential techniques of catalysts preparation and characterization. Thermocatalysis, photocatalysis, electrocatalysis, biocatalysis, and hybrid systems will also be introduced.

Also known as: (formerly Chemical Engineering 619.56)

ENCH 673.title: Engineering Principles in Biotechnology
ENCH 673.description:
Introduction to industrial microbiology, cell biotechnology, cell growth, kinetic of biochemical reactions, bioreactor kinetics and scale-up of bioprocess. Cell culture bioprocesses and Biomanufacturing. Synthetic biotechnology. Bioproducts recovery and chromatographic operations in bio separation.

Also known as: (formerly Chemical Engineering 619.68)

ENCH 675.title: Data Science and Machine Learning in Chemical Engineering
ENCH 675.description:
Structure and techniques of machine learning, optimization deep learning, and reinforcement learning. Supervised and unsupervised learning. Supervised and unsupervised learning. Regression and clustering. Application to problems in chemical engineering.

Also known as: (formerly Chemical Engineering 619.89)

ENCH 677.title: Advanced Oil and Gas Engineering
ENCH 677.description: Problems related to production of conventional oil, heavy oil and natural gas; analysis of the interactions of oil, water and gas, effects of fluid properties, rock structure and capillary, gravity and viscous forces acting on the reservoir system; application to the design of improved oil and gas recovery methods. New processes in oil and gas recovery.
ENCH 677.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Petroleum Engineering 429 or Petroleum Engineering 523.

ENCH 678.title: CO2 Capture, Utilization and Storage - Principles and Technologies
ENCH 678.description: Exploring the role of carbon capture, utilization and storage in achieving net-zero emissions, with a focus on integrating foundational concepts of the carbon cycle with advanced technologies for capturing, converting, and storing CO2. Analyzing carbon capture systems (absorption, adsorption, membranes, oxy-fuel combustion, chemical looping), and CO2 utilization pathways (including physical, thermochemical, electrochemical, biological and photochemical conversion). Introduction to negative emission technologies.
ENCH 678.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Advanced Engineering Practice I or II, with a specialization in Carbon Capture, Utilization, and Storage.

ENCH 679.title: Subsurface Energy Engineering in a Low Carbon Future
ENCH 679.description: Subsurface energy engineering as a key enabler of the global energy transition, with a focus on the technical foundations, applications, and challenges of geological carbon  equestration. Introduction to the roles of underground hydrogen storage and geothermal energy in supporting climate change mitigation and global decarbonization efforts.
ENCH 679.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Advanced Engineering Practice I or II, with a specialization in Carbon Capture, Utilization, and Storage.

ENCH 680.title: Data Science and Machine Learning for CO2 Applications
ENCH 680.description: Introduces Machine Learning concepts, types, and workflow of a typical ML project. Popular ML libraries, supervised learning algorithms, unsupervised learning algorithms, representing data and engineering features, model evaluation and improvement. Application to problems in carbon capture, utilization and storage.
ENCH 680.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Advanced Engineering Practice I or II, with a specialization in Carbon Capture, Utilization, and Storage.

ENCH 687.title: Petroleum Economics
ENCH 687.description:
Economic principles and risk management practices in the petroleum industry. Project selection; investment ranking; budgeting; and portfolio development. Decision making under uncertainty and risk.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Chemical Engineering 687 and Petroleum Engineering 626 will not be allowed.

Also known as: (formerly Chemical Engineering 619.87)

ENCH 689.title: Drilling Advances, Modelling and Simulation
ENCH 689.description:
Application of drilling optimization simulator tools to optimize rate of penetration and minimize cost. Drilling hydraulics simulation, directional drill string torque and drag calculations, drilling fluid selection and analysis and real time drilling rate analysis.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Chemical Engineering 689 and either Chemical Engineering 619.91 or Petroleum Engineering 627 will not be allowed.

ENCH 698.title: Reservoir Characterization for Field Development
ENCH 698.description: A team-based, integrated reservoir description experience working with geophysical, geological, petrophysical, and engineering data to produce a field development plan.
ENCH 698.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemical Engineering 621, Geology 697 and Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 789 and admission to the Master of Engineering with Reservoir Characterization Specialization.

ENCH 699.title: Special Project
ENCH 699.description: Project study conducted under the guidance of a faculty member and intended to expose the student to the tools, techniques and basic aspects of research. A written comprehensive report and one or more written progress reports are required.

ENCH 701.title: Experimental Design and Error Analysis
ENCH 701.description: Statistical analysis and design of engineering experiments. Random variables and sampling distributions; estimation and hypothesis testing; concepts of central tendency, variability, confidence level; correlation, regression and variation analysis; robust estimation; experiments of evaluation; experiments of comparison; factorial experiments (analysis of variance); experimental designs (involving randomization, replication, blocking and analysis of covariance).
ENCH 701.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MSc or PhD in Chemical and Petroleum Engineering or consent of the Department.

Also known as: (Environmental Engineering 621)

ENCH 703.title: Advanced Mathematical Methods in Engineering
ENCH 703.description: Review of theory of linear algebra. Review of ordinary differential equations: linear, non-linear; series solutions; special exact solutions; applications. Partial differential equations: geometric interpretation; characteristic curves; separation of variables; the Sturm-Liouville problem and Fourier series; eigenfunction expansion; Fourier, Laplace and Hankel transforms; self-similarity; Green's function; applications.
ENCH 703.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MSc or PhD in Chemical and Petroleum Engineering or consent of the Department.

ENCI 300.title: Introduction to Civil Engineering Design
ENCI 300.description:
Introduction to engineering design theory, tools, and techniques, with application to civil engineering problems. Emphasis on the use of digital tools such as computer aided design, 3D printing and spreadsheets for analysis and design, and oral and written communication for technical reporting. Introduction to team based design and team management

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Civil Engineering 300 and 337 will not be allowed.

ENCI 317.title: Mechanics of Solids
ENCI 317.description: Axial-force, shear-force and bending-moment diagrams; stress and strain; stress-strain relations; elastic and plastic behaviour; elastic constants; simple statically indeterminate (one-degree) problems; review of moment of inertia, product of inertia and principal axes of inertia; elastic torsion of circular shafts; elastic and plastic bending about principal axes of beams with symmetrical cross-section; composite beams; shear stresses due to bending; Mohr's circle for stress; thin-walled pressure vessels; deflection of beams by integration; Euler buckling.

ENCI 400.title: Application of Civil Engineering Design Concepts
ENCI 400.description: Team-based design applying conceptual and preliminary design principles to civil engineering projects. Use of advanced digital tools to support the design. Application of the design process to open-ended projects that encompass the subdisciplines of civil engineering. Apply concepts of sustainability and environmental assessment to refine proposed design solution. Effective oral and written communication of the design proposal through engineering drawings, technical reports and presentations.

ENCI 402.title: Hydraulics
ENCI 402.description: Quantitative and qualitative investigation of pipe flow and free-surface fluid flow. Application of fundamental laws of mechanics to fluid flow, including conservation of mass, momentum, and energy. Use of theoretical and numerical analysis methods. Review of basic concepts of fluid motion; pressurized pipe network flow; open channel flow; uniform and non-uniform flow.

ENCI 413.title: Introduction to Civil Engineering Materials
