Performance parameters, such as thermal and propulsive efficiencies, specific fuel consumption, thrust-to-weight ratio, specific impulse, total impulse, characteristic velocity will be used to assess various propulsion concepts.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Mechanical Engineering 654 and either 574 or 619.61 (Aerospace Reaction Engines) will not be allowed.

ENME 661.title: Mechatronics Design Laboratory I
ENME 661.description:
A hands-on laboratory experience in the design and analysis of electro-mechanical components. Introduction to microprocessor-controlled electromechanical systems. Laboratory projects to configure, design, and implement a succession of mechatronic systems. Topics of lectures and labs include aliasing, quantization, electronic feedback, power amplifiers, digital logic, encoder interfacing, and motor control.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Mechanical Engineering 661 and any of 560, 561, 619.47 (Advanced Mechatronics I) or 660 will not be allowed. 

Also known as: (Mechanical Engineering 561)

ENME 662.title: Mechatronics Design Laboratory II
ENME 662.description:
Continuation of Mechanical Engineering 661, involving more sophisticated and in-depth topics in mechatronic systems design explored through laboratory exercises, and complemented by selected lecture topics including practical control aspects of saturation and tuning and machine learning introduction.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Mechanical Engineering 662 and any of 560, 562, 619.48 (Advanced Mechatronics II) or 660 will not be allowed.

ENME 663.title: (KNES/MDSC 663) Advanced Muscle Mechanics and Physiology
ENME 663.description: A look at problems associated within muscle mechanics and contractility. Also the use of muscle mechanics as a scientific discipline to critically learn and evaluate the scientific process. Basic anatomy and physiology of muscle contraction including the cross-bridge theory, and the force-length, force-velocity and force-time relationships of actively and passively contracting muscles will also be covered.

ENME 664.title: Pipeline Design
ENME 664.description: Function and types of pipeline systems; gathering, transmission, distribution. Design parameters and procedures: supply and demand considerations; design life; capacity planning; system planning and facilities. Hydraulic design. Mechanical design. Geotechnical design.
ENME 664.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Pipeline Engineering.

ENME 665.title: Advanced Materials Engineering
ENME 665.description: Covers a variety of material aspects and provides a fundamental understanding of Materials Science and Engineering. Emphasizes the understanding of advanced dislocation theory and its application in illustration of diffusion, deformation and fracture of metals. Fundamentals of material strengthening mechanisms are covered. Practical aspects that are relevant to material uses and failures, such as environmental-induced cracking, creep, fatigue, strain aging and corrosion, are discussed. Typical surface analysis techniques for material characterization are introduced.

ENME 667.title: Fracture Mechanics
ENME 667.description:
Basic fracture theory, failure criteria, overview of fracture mechanics, brittle and ductile failure, crack tip parameters, geometric considerations, methods of analysis, fracture toughness and testing standards. Applications in design, fatigue subcritical crack growth, creep and impact.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Mechanical Engineering 667 and either 619.74 (Failure and Fracture Mechanics Pipeline Industry) or 638 will not be allowed.

ENME 668.title: Pipeline Economics
ENME 668.description: Macroeconomics of system supply and demand, open season procedures, optimized sizing, J curves; CAPEX, OPEX, taxation, leasing, depreciation and capital cost allowance, developing revenue requirement, cost of service. Salvage and end of life cost. For utilities Allowance for Funds Used During Construction (AFUDC).
ENME 668.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Pipeline Engineering.

ENME 669.title: Fatigue of Materials
ENME 669.description: History and origin of fatigue. Stress life, strain life and fracture mechanics approaches. Low and high cycle fatigue. Low and high temperature fatigue. Combined stresses, initiation, and propagation of cracks. Environmental and statistical effects. Testing techniques and variables. Design and specific material behaviour. Mechanisms of fatigue.

ENME 670.title: Aerodynamics
ENME 670.description:
Kinematics and dynamics of viscous and inviscid flow; airfoil dynamics including thin airfoil theory and lifting line theory, finite wings, panel methods and airfoil parameters. Boundary layer theory and boundary layer control as applied in aerodynamics. Introduction to computational fluid dynamics and experimental aerodynamics.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Mechanical Engineering 670 and any of 519.06 (Aerodynamics), 570 or 619.31 (Aerodynamics) will not be allowed.

ENME 672.title: Computational Fluid Dynamics
ENME 672.description:
Topics include: finite volume and finite element approximations; overview of turbulence models, including Reynolds-Averaged Navier-Stokes (RANS), Large Eddy Simulation (LES), and Variational Multi-Scale (VMS); time-marching schemes; methods to solve system of linear equations (e.g. GMRES, Conjugate Gradient); grid generation and adaptation; and post-processing of the solution using VisIt and ParaView. Also includes an introduction to parallel computing.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Mechanical Engineering 672 and and any of 519.04 (Computational Fluid Dynamics), 572 or 619.22 (Computational Fluid Dynamics) will not be allowed.

ENME 674.title: Gas and Liquid Hydraulics
ENME 674.description: Properties of liquids and gases, steady-state, transient, multiphase, pressure drop due to friction, pressure required to transport, liquid pumping and gas compression, valves and flow measurement.
ENME 674.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Pipeline Engineering.

ENME 675.title: Materials Selection and Metallurgy
ENME 675.description: Fundamentals of physical metallurgy of carbon steels. Principles of steel strengthening. Evolution of pipeline steels. Composition, microstructures and properties of low- and high-grade pipeline steels. Thermo-mechanical controlling processing of high-strength pipeline steels. Performance and failure of pipeline steels in service.
ENME 675.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Pipeline Engineering.

ENME 676.title: Pipeline Stress Analysis
ENME 676.description: Introduction to the stress analysis and design of buried pipelines. Allowable working stress design and strain-based design. Considerations such as operating pressure/temperature, buoyancy, buckling, and pipe-soil interaction are examined. Pipeline flexibility analysis is explored using both analytical and numerical methods. Mitigation strategies for pipelines are discussed. The pertinent requirements of the current North American pipeline codes are addressed.
ENME 676.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Pipeline Engineering.

ENME 677.title: Geotechnical Aspects in Pipeline Engineering
ENME 677.description: Soil types and classification, soil testing, soil strength-deformation determination, safe burial depth, ground movement in on-shore and offshore, loading pattern on pipelines, soil-pipe interaction and monitoring (in moving slopes, muskeg, permafrost, seabed, and river crossing), performance assessment of pipelines under different in situ environmental loading, ALA and PRCI design guidelines.
ENME 677.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Pipeline Engineering.

ENME 678.title: Environmental Impact and Regulatory Matters
ENME 678.description: Examines pipelines as linear assets which cross a wide variety of ecosystems and communities; public concerns about health, safety, archeological and environmental protection, and participation of stakeholders with diverse interests, including First Nations; and the complexity of regulatory processes. Topics include environmental impact assessment, public consultation and roles and responsibility of regulators.
ENME 678.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Pipeline Engineering.

ENME 680.title: Operation and Maintenance
ENME 680.description: Automation overview, SCADA systems, station control, instrumentation and metering, custody transfer, nominations process, scheduling and batching multi products. Recommended practices for land usage, ROW patrols, pipeline repair: protocols; repair methods; codes and standards; reference technical papers.
ENME 680.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Pipeline Engineering.

ENME 682.title: Automation and Control Systems
ENME 682.description: The basics of industrial automation and control systems, with an emphasis on their application to the energy industry in the areas of safety and energy savings. The key technologies considered will be programmable logic controllers (PLC), supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA) systems, and distributed control systems (DCS).
ENME 682.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Pipeline Engineering.

ENME 683.title: Applications of 3D Rigid Body Mechanics in Biomechanics
ENME 683.description: Applications of 3D motion analysis and rigid body mechanics to musculoskeletal system locomotion, and movement. Experimental, theoretical and numerical methods for optical motion imaging, 3D analysis of joint kinematics and kinetics, joint angle representations, prediction of joint forces, data analysis and filtering, error propagation, inverse and forward dynamics approaches, and applications to clinical and orthopaedic engineering.

ENME 684.title: Corrosion, Cracking, and Coatings
ENME 684.description: Electrochemical principles of corrosion reactions. Internal and external corrosion of buried pipelines. Principle of cathodic protection. Evolution of pipeline coating technology. Coating performance in conjunction with cathodic protection. Failure modes and effect analysis of pipeline coatings. Stress corrosion cracking of pipelines, along with corrosion fatigue and hydrogen-induced cracking of pipeline steels.
ENME 684.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Pipeline Engineering.

ENME 685.title: (MDSC 685) Biomechanics of Human Movement
ENME 685.description: Introduction to the measuring methods (accelerometry, goniometry, film and film analysis, video systems) of biomechanical analysis of human movement (force and force distribution). Description of the mechanical properties of bone, tendon, ligaments, cartilage, muscles and soft tissues. The relation between structure and function of biomaterials. Introduction to descriptive analysis of human movement.

ENME 686.title: Integrity Management
ENME 686.description: Overview and implementation of the integrity management program, threat management, failure mode identification, baseline assessment plan, fitness-for-service assessment using direct assessment and condition monitoring such as inline inspections and pressure testing; defects; defect analysis; risk reduction approaches and corrective actions, upgrading.
ENME 686.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Pipeline Engineering.

ENME 688.title: Pipeline In-Line Inspection Technologies
ENME 688.description: Traditional in-line inspection (ILI) methods, including ultrasonic, EMAT, and MFL, and non-traditional ILI methods, such as eddy current, INS, and acoustic. Non-piggable lines. Discrepancies between reported vs. actual defects and anomalies.
ENME 688.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Pipeline Engineering.

ENME 689.title: Pipeline Leak Detection Technologies
ENME 689.description: Computational pipeline monitoring (CPM) methods and external leak detection techniques, such as fiber optic, acoustic, and polymeric composite sensors. The internal leak detection methods include volume balance, rate of changes, real time transient model (RTTM), and negative pressure.
ENME 689.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Pipeline Engineering.

ENME 698.title: Graduate Project
ENME 698.description: Individual project in the student's area of specialization under the guidance of the student's supervisor. A written proposal, one or more written progress reports, and a final written report are required. An oral presentation is required upon completion of the course.

ENME 699.title: Vibration and Machine Dynamics
ENME 699.description:
Linear vibration theory: free and forced vibration of single- and multi- degree-of-freedom systems; damping in machines; vibration absorbers; experimental modal analysis. Balance of rotating machinery: sources of unbalance, rigid rotors, flexible rotors, critical speeds, balancing principles. Lagrange equations: application to mechanical systems. Signal analysis: time and frequency domain. Introduction to statistical signal analysis. Vibration measurement and analysis for condition monitoring.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Mechanical Engineering 699 and 599 will not be allowed.

ENME 708.title: Turbulence
ENME 708.description: Provides an overview of turbulence in incompressible flows of Newtonian fluids. Topics include: the nature of turbulence; classical methods of analysis (Reynolds-averaging, spectral representations); the concept of scales; a review of isotropic and homogeneous turbulence; the energy cascade and the role of vorticity in turbulence canonical flows: boundary layers, jets, wakes and mixing layers; modern views of turbulence including coherent motions and inter-scale energy transfer.

ENME 713.title: Research Seminar II
ENME 713.description:
Students will develop written and oral communication skills required to disseminate their technical research results and to receive formative feedback on performance.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

ENMF 417.title: Manufacturing and Production Processes
ENMF 417.description: The role and characterization of manufacturing technology within the manufacturing enterprise. Overview of deformation processes, joining processes, consolidation processes, material-removal processes, and material alteration processes. Process selection and planning.

ENMF 501.title: Modelling & Simulation Of Manufacturing Systems
ENMF 501.description: General modelling of production systems. Spreadsheet modelling for capacity analysis.  Fundamentals of discrete-event simulation including: key concepts; simulation world views; the simulation study life cycle. Modelling and programming aspects of discrete-event simulation including: verification and validation; simulation animation; interfacing simulation software with other systems. Statistical aspects of discrete-event simulation including: random number and random variate generation; input process modelling; output analysis; variance reduction techniques. Applications of discrete-event simulation to the design and analysis of manufacturing systems.

ENMF 503.title: Computer-Aided Design and Manufacturing
ENMF 503.description: Hardware and software for computer-aided design and manufacturing (CAD/CAM) systems. Geometric modelling, transformation and visualization. Modelling of freeform curves and surfaces. Programming for computer numerically controlled (CNC) machining. Integration of CAD/CAM systems, Applications in motion analysis, structure analysis, optimization, rapid prototyping, reverse engineering and virtual engineering.

ENMF 509.title: Advanced Manufacturing Systems
ENMF 509.description: Manufacturing strategy and competitive manufacturing. Queuing theory and its application to manufacturing systems analysis (including rapid modelling tools). Linear programming and its application to manufacturing systems problems. Scheduling problems in manufacturing. Supply chain modelling and integration. Enterprise resource planning systems.

ENMF 514.title: Integrated Manufacturing Systems
ENMF 514.description: Fundamentals of integrated and competitive manufacturing. Manufacturing and operations strategy. Topics in production and operations management including: production planning and control systems; inventory management systems; process analysis and improvement; quality management systems.

ENMF 517.title: Experimental Design And Analysis
ENMF 517.description: Introduction to statistical Design of Experiments (DOE) techniques for efficient data collection, analysis and interpretation. Hypothesis testing, Analysis of Variance (ANOVA), including blocking and nesting, in both full and fractional factorial designs to identify and control sources of variability. Applications of these techniques to optimize product and process performance through data-driven experimentation.

ENMF 527.title: Project Engineering
ENMF 527.description:
The project lifecycle. Project planning, scheduling, and control. Resource considerations. Cost estimating, planning, and performance. Project risk. Project personnel and organizational structures.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Manufacturing Engineering 527 and either Engineering 515 or 684 will not be allowed.

ENMF 529.title: Introduction to Microelectromechanical Systems
ENMF 529.description:
Microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) and devices including microsensors and microactuators. Principles of operation, material properties, fabrication techniques including surface and bulk micromachining, IC-derived microfabrication techniques, sensing and actuation principles, sensor dynamics issues, circuit and system issues, packaging, calibration and testing. Illustrative examples include (1) micromachined inertial sensors and actuators for manufacturing processes, (2) microactuator arrays for \"smart surfaces\", (3) biosensors for medical applications, and (4) transducers for aerospace applications.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Manufacturing Engineering 529 and Mechanical Engineering 519.16 or Manufacturing Engineering 619.01 will not be allowed.

ENMF 602.title: Advanced Robotics
ENMF 602.description: Review of kinematics and dynamics of serial-link manipulators and the Euler-Lagrange method. Kinematics and dynamics of parallel manipulators. Position, force, and impedance control of manipulators. Lyapunov stability. Feedback linearization. Advanced path and trajectory planning. Redundant manipulators and trajectory optimization.

ENMF 605.title: Plan & Control Comp Inte Manufact
ENMF 605.description: Planning and Control of Computer Integrated Manufacturing Advanced techniques for the design, planning, and control of integrated manufacturing systems. Course elements include: a framework for manufacturing planning and control; data flow and structured modelling methodologies; hierarchical models of manufacturing; cellular manufacturing organization; databases and communications; forecasting, demand management, capacity planning and master production scheduling; materials requirements planning, manufacturing resource planning, Just-in-Time manufacture, and Optimized Production Technology; control of independent demand inventory items; production activity control, shop floor control, scheduling, order release and dispatching; simulation in planning and control.

ENMF 609.title: Design and Analysis of Experiments
ENMF 609.description:
Statistical Design of Experiments (DOE) techniques for efficient data collection, analysis and interpretation. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA), including blocking and nesting, in full and fractional factorial designs. Robust design, including classical response surface and Taguchi techniques. Applications to product and process improvement.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Manufacturing Engineering 609 and 517 will not be allowed.

ENMF 618.title: Manufacturing Optimization
ENMF 618.description:
Application of operations research techniques in manufacturing engineering: linear manufacturing optimization problems; transportation, assignment and transshipment problems; dynamic manufacturing programming problems; network problems; manufacturing decision problems.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Manufacturing Engineering 618 and 619.18 will not be allowed.

ENMF 619.title: Special Problems in Manufacturing Engineering
ENMF 619.description:
Designed to provide graduate students, especially at the PhD level, with the opportunity of pursuing advanced studies in particular areas under the direction of a faculty member. Students would be required to consider problems of an advanced nature.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Manufacturing Engineering 619.01 and either Mechanical Engineering 519.16 or Manufacturing Engineering 529 will not be allowed.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ENMF 623.title: CAD/CAM/CAE
ENMF 623.description:
Components of CAD/CAM/CAE systems. Geometric modeling. Development
of customized CAD systems. Complex shape modeling. Computer-aided process
planning. CNC machining. Rapid prototyping. Finite element analysis and motion
analysis. Engineering optimization. Virtual design and manufacturing.

ENMF 673.title: Manufacturing of Polymer Composites
ENMF 673.description:
Overview of the considerations and challenges in processing fibre-reinforced polymer composites.  Introduction and discussion of constituent materials, reactive polymer composites, thermoplastic composites, textile preforms, autoclave processing, pultrusion, thermoforming, filament winding, liquid composite molding, process modelling, testing and characterization techniques.

Also known as: (formerly Manufacturing Engineering 619.03)

ENMG 301.title: Electricity Regulation
ENMG 301.description: An examination of energy development and the business, law and policy issues arising from the development of different electricity sources (nuclear and renewable energy sources).
ENMG 301.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business or the Minor in Engineering Energy and Environment (Schulich School of Engineering) or the Energy Science Major, Minor, or Concentration (Faculty of Science).

ENMG 403.title: Overview of the Alberta Oil & Gas Industry
ENMG 403.description: Provides an understanding of the upstream petroleum industry and will focus on the development of petroleum resources by Alberta based corporations. Analysis of shale gas and oil development will be included.
ENMG 403.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 54 units.

ENMG 485.title: Oil and Gas Marketing
ENMG 485.description: Practical introduction to crude oil (light and heavy) and natural gas marketing. Marketing of refined oil products and retail gasoline are not covered.
ENMG 485.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Finance 317.

ENMG 487.title: Energy Risk Management
ENMG 487.description: This course provides an overview of key issues related to energy risk management. Some of the key topics to be addressed are: managing pricing risks associated with changing market conditions and deregulation; tools used to manage volatility, including futures and options for energy risk management; environmental risk management, and risk financing for the energy sector.
ENMG 487.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Finance 317.

ENMG 489.title: International Energy Development
ENMG 489.description: A focus on international energy development, energy contracts, sustainable development, and the management of environmental and corporate social responsibility issues.
ENMG 489.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business.

ENPE 310.title: Fundamentals of Subsurface Resource Engineering
ENPE 310.description:
Fundamental properties of rocks and fluids in the context of subsurface energy systems, with emphasis on how these properties influence the exploration, extraction, and storage of subsurface resources. Permeability, porosity, saturation, capillarity, wettability, relative permeability, interactions between rocks and fluids. Reservoir fluids classification, fluid models, properties, and phase behaviour for subsurface energy applications. Examples from diverse applications including geothermal energy, hydrocarbon recovery, and carbon sequestration.

Corequisite(s): Chemical Engineering 331.

ENPE 313.title: Introduction to Flow in Porous Media
ENPE 313.description:
Fluid flow in porous media: pore structure; porosity and absolute permeability capillarity; Darcy's Law and single phase flow; immiscible and miscible fluid flow; wettability; multiphase flow and relative permeability; pore level analysis of two-phase displacement; and integration of these properties with geological information; application of fundamental principles to hydrocarbon recovery from petroleum reservoirs.

Corequisite(s): Chemical Engineering 331 and admission to the Oil & Gas or Chemical Engineering with Petroleum Minor Program.	

Antirequisite(s): Credit for both Petroleum Engineering 313 and Petroleum Engineering 513 will not be allowed.

ENPE 410.title: Reservoir Characterization and Evaluation
ENPE 410.description: Basic petroleum geology and geophysics; geological depositional environments; petrophysical and geostatistical analysis. Fundamentals of wireline well logging and log interpretation techniques. Types of well logging devices; physics of operation and response characteristics of various well logging tools. Leakage monitoring using well logs, geothermal fluid leakage monitoring, applications of well log to subsurface energy pathways.

ENPE 415.title: Drilling and Completions
ENPE 415.description:
Drilling rig types, components and selection; overview of drilling operations; drilling fluids and mud systems; drilling hydraulics; casing design and casing seat selections; cementing; formation damage, well completions; geothermal well completion and design, drilling in high temperatures formations and high-temperature drilling challenges; Regulatory frameworks and permitting,
Innovations and technological advancements in geothermal drilling. Special topics including directional drilling; blowout control; logging and coring; hole stability; planning and cost control; underbalanced drilling; drilling geopressured reservoirs; coiled tubing drilling; offshore operations; health, safety, and environmental aspects.

ENPE 423.title: Oil & Gas Engineering Process Development
ENPE 423.description: Design of oil and gas processing units and plants; cost estimates and oil and gas process economics; optimization techniques; introduction to linear programming; safety and environmental considerations in process design.
ENPE 423.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemical Engineering 315 and admission to the Oil and Gas Engineering Program.

ENPE 429.title: Reservoir Engineering
ENPE 429.description: Steady, pseudo-steady and transient flow in reservoirs; reservoir types. Estimation of reservoir flow properties along vertical and lateral heterogeneities for formations in parallel and in series. Reserve estimation and management using volumetric and material balance methods in gas, gas-condensate and oil reservoirs. Reservoir drive mechanisms; frontal advanced theory; diagnosis and flow characteristics of gas; water influx in aquifer models; decline curve analysis. Principles of recovery mechanisms for low mobility reservoirs such as oil sands and shales.
ENPE 429.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Engineering 311, Chemical Engineering 331, and Petroleum Engineering 310.

ENPE 431.title: Modelling Multiphase Transport in Porous Media
ENPE 431.description: Principles of momentum, heat, and mass transport in porous media in a variety of engineering applications. Capillarity effect, multiphase fluid flow, diffusion, dispersion, convection, miscible and immiscible displacement, and the mathematical modeling of these processes in porous media. Development and coding of 1D and 2D simulation models for single-phase and multi-phase fluid flow. Applications in subsurface energy and environmental engineering, including geothermal energy harvesting, groundwater hydrology, oil and gas engineering, CO2 sequestration, and hydrogen storage.
ENPE 431.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemical Engineering 307, 401; and Petroleum Engineering 429.

ENPE 450.title: Subsurface Design and Simulation
ENPE 450.description: Team-based engineering design exercise. Principles and applications of engineering tools and simulators, data interpretation, production forecasting, and design of subsurface and associated surface facilities. Safety and hazard assessments. Written and oral communication. Project management. Completion of an open-ended design project involving the use of reservoir simulators to solve problems related to subsurface energy production.
ENPE 450.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Petroleum Engineering 429 and Chemical Engineering 400.

ENPE 500.title: Design for Energy Resources Development I
ENPE 500.description: Team design project applying principles of project engineering and management to the development of energy resources. Design considerations may include detailed reservoir characterization, recovery and production forecasting, preliminary drilling, completions and facilities design, and economic evaluation.

ENPE 505.title: Surface Production Operations
ENPE 505.description: Oil and gas treating process equipment, design and operation. Two-phase and three-phase separators; heater treaters. Fluid gathering and distribution systems. Pumps and compressors. Flow measurement and production testing. Natural gas dehydration and sweetening. Produced water treatment and disposal.

ENPE 507.title: Well Logging and Formation Evaluation
ENPE 507.description: Fundamentals of wireline well logging and the log interpretation techniques for oil and gas wells. Basic reservoir petrophysical parameters. Types of well logging devices; physics of operation and response characteristics of various well logging tools. Application of well logs for integrated petroleum reservoir management.
ENPE 507.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Third-year standing, or higher, in Chemical Engineering or Oil & Gas Engineering; or second-year standing in Energy Engineering.

ENPE 509.title: Well Testing
ENPE 509.description: Basic theory and current techniques for well testing. Drawdown and build up tests; diffusivity equation and various boundary conditions and flow regimes; superposition; single-rate and multi-rate testing; effect of boundaries; derivative analysis; fractured wells, fractured reservoirs and other flow models; wellbore dymanics; type curve matching; advanced decline curve analysis. Computer aided analysis and hands on experience in the computer laboratory.

ENPE 511.title: Design for Oil and Gas Engineering I
ENPE 511.description: Team design project applying principles of project engineering and management to the recovery and processing of hydrocarbons. Petroleum design considerations will include; detailed reservoir characterization; well test analysis; recovery and production forecasting; preliminary drilling, completions and facilities design, and economic evaluation.
ENPE 511.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemical Engineering 315 or 350; and Chemical Engineering 327 or 427; and Chemical Engineering 400 or 423 or Petroleum Engineering 423; and Petroleum Engineering 429 or 523 and admission to the Oil & Gas or Chemical Engineering with Petroleum Minor program.

ENPE 513.title: Flow In Porous Media
ENPE 513.description:
Fundamentals of fluid flow in porous media: pore structure; porosity and absolute permeability capillarity; Darcy's Law and single phase flow; immiscible and miscible fluid flow;wettability; multiphase flow and relative permeability. Concepts applied to hydrocarbon reservoirs and fluid migration in soils including; characterization of pore space, pore level modeling of porous media, routine and advanced core analysis. Similarities and differences between hydrocarbon reservoirs and soils.

Corequisite(s): Third-year standing, or higher, in Chemical Engineering or Oil & Gas Engineering.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for both ENPE 313 and ENPE 513 will not be allowed.

ENPE 515.title: Drilling and Well Completions
ENPE 515.description: An introduction to drilling; overview of petroleum engineering geology; basic rock properties. Fluid flow in porous media. Drilling rig types, components and selection; overview of drilling operations; drilling fluids and mud systems; drilling hydraulics; casing design and casing seat selections; cementing; formation damage, well completions. Special topics including: directional drilling; blowout control; logging and coring; hole stability; planning and cost control; underbalanced drilling; coiled tubing drilling; offshore operations, environmental aspects.
ENPE 515.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Engineering 311; 3 units from Chemical Engineering 317, Engineering 317 or Energy Engineering 360; and 3 units from Chemical Engineering 331, Mechanical Engineering 341 or Energy Engineering 480.

ENPE 519.title: Special Topics
ENPE 519.description: Current advanced topics in Petroleum Engineering.
ENPE 519.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ENPE 521.title: Introduction to Drilling Engineering
ENPE 521.description: Introduction to the physics of flow in porous media; overview of drilling operations; equipment; relevant processes and procedures; basic completion operation; environmental aspect of drilling and completion operations.
ENPE 521.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Engineering 311; and 3 units from Chemical Engineering 317, Engineering 317 or Energy Engineering 360; and 3 units from Chemical Engineering 331, Mechanical Engineering 341 or Energy Engineering 480.

ENPE 523.title: Introduction to Reservoir Engineering
ENPE 523.description: Basic concepts of fluid flow in porous media; important reservoir rock and fluid properties affecting productivity; reserve estimation using volumetric and material balance methods in gas, gas-condensate and oil reservoirs; discussion of different reservoir drive mechanisms; aquifer models; decline analysis; Darcy's Law and single phase flow through porous media. Introduction to well testing, solution of radial diffusivity equation corresponding to infinite-acting and pseudo-steady state flow of slightly compressible fluids and real gases.
ENPE 523.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Engineering 311 and 3 units from Chemical Engineering 331, Mechanical Engineering 341 or Energy Engineering 480.

ENPE 525.title: Enhanced Recovery
ENPE 525.description: Trapping and mobilization of residual oil; displacement theory; linear waterflood calculations; viscous fingering; flood patterns and sweep efficiency considerations; characterization of reservoir heterogeneity; analytical waterflood prediction models; black-oil reservoir simulation models; design engineering aspects of waterflooding; and overview of enhanced recovery methods.

ENPE 531.title: Design for Oil and Gas Engineering II
ENPE 531.description: Team Design Project continuing from Petroleum Engineering 511. Detailed design of large scale development and commercial exploitation of a petroleum resource. Topics considered will include: reservoir simulation; drilling and completion design; specification of petroleum processing equipment such as heaters, heat exchangers, contacting and separating equipment; safety and environmental issues; economic evaluation.

ENPE 533.title: Production Engineering
ENPE 533.description: Analysis of fluid flow between subsurface formation and surface facility. Reservoir inflow performance analysis. Wellbore and wellhead hydraulics and multiphase flow. Principles of oil and gas production statics and mechanics. Nodal analysis for production optimization. Acidizing and hydraulic fracturing. Water and gas coning. Diagnosis of production problems. Artificial lift; Sucker pumping; electrical submersible pumps; progressing cavity pumps; gas lift. Applications to flow injection for storage, disposal.

ENPE 543.title: Geological Characterization of Oil and Gas Reservoirs
ENPE 543.description: Static model for field development.  Review petroleum reservoir geology, geological depositional environments, petrophysical and geostatistical analysis, and reserves estimation.  Emphasis on data analysis and integration for a model suitable for reservoir simulation.

ENPE 550.title: Design for Energy Resources Development II
ENPE 550.description: Continuation of the Petroleum Engineering 500 capstone design project. Design considerations may include reservoir simulation; drilling and completion design; specification of surface processing equipment such as heaters, heat exchangers, contacting and separating equipment; safety and environmental issues; economic evaluation. Error analysis and uncertainties, risks identification and mitigation; decision-making under uncertainties.

ENPE 551.title: Petroleum Engineering Laboratory
ENPE 551.description: Experiments on Fluid Flow in Oil & Gas production. Measurements of porous rock and fluid properties, such as relative permeability, fluid dispersion, fluid phase behaviour and viscosity, unstable fluid displacement.
ENPE 551.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Chemical Engineering 327 or 427; and Petroleum Engineering 429 or 523.

ENPE 555.title: Oil and Gas Field Safety and Equipment
ENPE 555.description: Review of safety issues, blow outs, fire and other hazards, hydrate formation and decomposition, H2S and other toxic gases, safety standards, impact of petroleum operations on the environment, handling and safe transportation and disposal of petroleum wastes.

ENPE 561.title: Fuel Science and Technology
ENPE 561.description: Classification of fuels. Origin, geology, production and processing of fossil fuels. Supply, consumption and demand for fuels, historical patterns and future trends. Thermodynamics and reaction kinetics of combustion. Physical and chemical properties and influence on fuel utilization. Ecological, efficiency, safety, economic considerations. Non-conventional fuels. Transportation and handling.

ENPE 563.title: Corrosion in Engineering Applications
ENPE 563.description: Electrochemical principle of corrosion reactions. Corrosion thermodynamics and kinetics. Electrochemical corrosion measurement techniques. Passivity and pitting corrosion. Crevice corrosion and galvanic corrosion. Environmentally assisted cracking. Corrosion control techniques including cathodic protection, coatings and inhibitors. Material selection for corrosion resistance.

ENPE 571.title: Unconventional Oil Exploitation
ENPE 571.description: Description and analysis of heavy oil geology and heavy oil recovery technologies. Discussion of heavy oil production mechanisms and methods, recovery process design, transportation, facilities, marketing, economics, and environmental issues.

ENPE 573.title: Tight Oil and Unconventional Gas Exploitation
ENPE 573.description: Overview of tight oil and unconventional gas resources (tight gas, shale gas, tight oil, shale oil, coal bed methane, and natural gas hydrates) in a 'Total Petroleum System'. Geological aspects, drilling, completion and stimulation methods; reservoir characterization by petrophysics and well test analysis; forecasting methods; environmental and regulatory issues; economics and cost drivers.

ENPE 577.title: Unconventional Reservoirs
ENPE 577.description: Overview of heavy oil, tight oil, and unconventional gas resources (tight gas, shale gas, tight oil, shale oil, coal bed methane, and natural gas hydrates) in a 'Total Petroleum System'. Geological aspects, drilling, completion and stimulation methods; reservoir characterization by petrophysics and well test analysis; forecasting methods; discussion of production mechanisms and methods, recovery process design, transportation, facilities, marketing, economics, environmental and regulatory issues.

ENPE 621.title: Applied Reservoir Engineering
ENPE 621.description:
Basic reservoir engineering principles including fluid flow in porous media, rock and fluid properties; estimation of recovery under different operating conditions.

Notes:  This course does not count towards the degree requirements of MSc and PhD students.

ENPE 622.title: Subsurface Production Operations
ENPE 622.description:
Analysis of fluid flow from the formation to the surface including inflow performance, wellbore hydraulics, multiphase flows and well stimulation techniques.

Notes:  This course does not count towards the degree requirements of MSc and PhD students.

ENPE 623.title: Reservoir Analysis and Description
ENPE 623.description:
Data analysis and integration for reservoir modeling and simulation.

Notes:  This course does not count towards the degree requirements of MSc and PhD students.

ENPE 624.title: Enhanced Oil Recovery
ENPE 624.description:
Introduction to water and polymer flooding, miscible displacements and surfactant flooding with focus on case studies.

Notes:  This course does not count towards the degree requirements of MSc and PhD students.

ENPE 625.title: Natural Gas Engineering
ENPE 625.description:
Basic principles of natural gas production and processing including properties of natural gases, vapour-liquid equilibrium and separation techniques.

Notes:  This course does not count towards the degree requirements of MSc and PhD students.

ENPE 626.title: Economic Analysis of Energy Systems
ENPE 626.description:
Basic principles of analyzing the profitability and risk of energy projects including project selection, investment ranking, budgeting and portfolio development.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Petroleum Engineering 626 and Chemical Engineering 687 will not be allowed.

ENPE 627.title: Drilling Engineering
ENPE 627.description:
Overview of modern drilling technologies and techniques including drilling hydraulics, directional drilling, drilling fluid properties and selection, well control and completion methods.

Antirequisite(s):  Credit for Petroleum Engineering 627 and either Chemical Engineering 689 or Chemical Engineering 619.91 will not be allowed.

ENPH 301.title: Research and Design for Engineering Physics I
ENPH 301.description: Introduction to engineering design and testing; project management; teamwork; scientific inquiry; research skills and methods; identifying market and societal needs; innovating scientific techniques to analyze problems, and developing relevant technologies; intellectual property and regulatory issues; ethics in research and design, including documentation and treatment of data. Case studies as necessary.
ENPH 301.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BSc in Engineering Physics.

ENPH 388.title: Fundamentals of Circuits and Systems I
ENPH 388.description: Characterization of circuit devices and systems in the time-domain. Natural, step, and transient responses of RL, RC, and RLC circuits. Semiconductor theory and device modelling, including diodes and operational amplifiers. Continuous-time and discrete-time analysis of systems. Impulse response and convolution.
ENPH 388.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Physics 259 and Engineering 225; and Mathematics 375 or 376.

ENPH 401.title: Research and Design for Engineering Physics II
ENPH 401.description: A team-based design and research project carried out under the supervision of one or more faculty members, with a focus on design. The project can include designing experimental apparatus, developing technical devices, performing laboratory measurements, simulating systems or developing software, and building theoretical and physical models. Students will be required to submit a written report and deliver an oral presentation.

ENPH 488.title: Fundamentals of Circuits and Systems II
ENPH 488.description: Characterization of circuit devices and systems in the frequency-domain. Laplace transform methods for circuit analysis. Transfer functions and series and parallel resonance. Basic filter theory and Bode diagrams. Two-port circuits. Digital sampling theory and frequency-domain signal processing. Rectifier and clamping circuits, and introduction to transistors.

ENPH 491.title: Multiphysics Design of Electromechanical Systems
ENPH 491.description: Modelling, analysis, and design of dynamic systems involving multiple physical processes, including structural, electrical, fluidic, thermal, and mixed systems; introduction to and utilization of numerical techniques for solution of boundary-value problems; introduction to feedback control of dynamic systems; performance analysis and design to meet specifications.
ENPH 491.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Physics Engineering 383 and 435, Physics 449, Electrical Engineering 475, and Engineering Physics 488.

ENRE 301.title: Energy Pathways and Energy Transition
ENRE 301.description: Comprehensive overview of various energy pathways and their role in the global energy transition, including geothermal energy harvesting, compressed air energy storage, hydrogen storage, and CO2 sequestration. Invited industry experts. Emphasis on systems thinking, sustainability, stakeholder engagement including Indigenous perspectives on resource development, achieving net zero emissions, and interaction of technology and society.

ENRE 541.title: Emissions Reduction Engineering
ENRE 541.description: Principles and practices of air pollution control, with focus on process design for carbon-based energy sources. Methods for detecting emissions. Application of fundamental engineering principles to design and optimize processes that mitigate air pollution from the mining, exploration, production, transportation, and utilization of coal, oil, and natural gas. Design of unit operations, separation processes, treatment technologies, and carbon capture methods to control emissions of methane, volatile organic compounds, carbon dioxide, particulate matter, sulfur oxides, and nitrogen oxides.

ENRE 561.title: Data Science and AI in Energy Systems
ENRE 561.description: Applications of data science, machine learning, artificial intelligence and optimization in energy systems. Review of statistics, probability and data science concepts; confidence factors and error analysis. Supervised and unsupervised learning in python including regression and clustering; data engineering for data filtering and feature selection; optimization. Focus on application to problems in the energy industry.
ENRE 561.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Digital Engineering 319 and Chemical Engineering 307.

ENRE 563.title: Digital Energy Field and Cyber Security
ENRE 563.description: Introduction to Digital Energy Systems; Data acquisition and digital transformation; Role of IoT (Internet of Things) in energy management; Fundamentals of cyber security; Identifying and assessing cyber risks in energy systems; Strategies for risk mitigation and management.

ENRE 571.title: Hydrogen Production and Storage
ENRE 571.description: Overview of hydrogen as an energy carrier. Hydrogen Production Methods: Electrolysis, Steam Methane Reforming, Biomass Gasification, etc.; Hydrogen Storage methods: compressed gas storage, Liquid Hydrogen Storage, Solid-state Storage, Underground Storage. Hydrogen chemistry, reactivity, and safety. Economic and Environmental Considerations.

ENRE 573.title: Geothermal Energy Technology
ENRE 573.description: Current technologies in energy extraction from subsurface resources. Geoenergy vs. geothermal energy, power generation vs. heat distribution, open vs. closed loop systems, properties of working fluids (surface vs. subsurface) deep drilling and fracturing, applications at urban vs. remote communities, regulatory issues with geothermal energy, description of new technologies.

ENRE 575.title: CO2 Geological Sequestration
ENRE 575.description: Carbon dioxide emissions reduction, geological storage mechanisms, saline aquifers, depleted oil and gas fields, mineral trapping, reservoir characterization, site selection, injection techniques, rates and efficiencies of geological storage, monitoring and verification, risk assessment, regulatory frameworks, cost analysis, environmental impacts, and public perception, geological carbon sequestration technologies and their role in mitigating climate change.

ENRE 577.title: Critical Minerals Production
ENRE 577.description: Critical minerals and applications, sources, production capacities, supply chains, and disruption risks, extraction technologies for critical minerals and their environmental impact, emerging sustainable extraction technologies, recycling, circular economy. Extractive metallurgy, hydrometallurgy, separation technology, supply chain disruption, sustainable mineral extraction technologies.

ENSC 201.title: Introduction to Environmental Science
ENSC 201.description: Topical issues in environmental science including climate change, aquatic systems, agriculture, forestry, mining, energy, endangered species, and protected areas contextualized within the framework of law, policy, economics, sustainability, and the precautionary principle.

ENSC 401.title: Environmental Science Field Course I
ENSC 401.description: An introduction to the common field techniques in quantifying air, land and water quality, as well as data analysis and report writing. A field portion is held in the two weeks prior to the start of the regular Fall Term, partly based at the Biogeoscience Institute's Barrier Lake Field Station.
ENSC 401.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biology 315 or Statistics 327; and admission to the Environmental Science program.

ENSC 501.title: Environmental Science Field Course II
ENSC 501.description: The focus will be on disturbances to aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems. Site visits and data collection will be conducted to appropriate areas that have either undergone or are undergoing industrial disturbance to assess impacts. The course is held for two weeks immediately prior to the start of the regular Fall Term.
ENSC 501.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Environmental Science 401 and admission to the Environmental Science program.

ENSC 502.title: Special Problems In Environmental Management
ENSC 502.description: Aspectsof the professional practice of environmental science including environmental managementandassessment, sustainability,life cycle assessment,remediation/reclamation technologies, lawandregulations, ethics,philosophyandcommunication.Includes a major collaborative research project on a local environmental issue.
ENSC 502.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the Environmental Science program.

ENSC 503.title: Environmental Impact Assessment
ENSC 503.description: An introduction to federal and provincial environmental impact assessment (EIA).
ENSC 503.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Environmental Science program.

ENSC 504.title: Research Project in Environmental Science
ENSC 504.description: An independent study or research project under the supervision of one or more faculty members in the Environmental Science program. Originality is emphasized and laboratory and/or field studies are encouraged. Formal written and oral reports will be presented as a necessary component of this course.
ENSC 504.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Environmental Science Program Director.

ENSC 505.title: Special Problems in Environmental Science
ENSC 505.description: A research project under the supervision of one or more faculty members in the Environmental Science program. Formal written and oral reports will be presented as a necessary component of this course.
ENSC 505.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Environmental Science Program Director.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ENSF 300.title: Software Engineering Practices for Data Management
ENSF 300.description: Introduction to professional skills practices within software engineering. Individual software processes and reflection, resiliency and debugging skills, command line navigation, revision control. Foundations of database management systems. Types of data models, relational and entity-relationship models, integrity constraints, normalization, Structured Query Language (SQL). Data privacy, security, and ethical considerations.

ENSF 337.title: Programming Fundamentals for Software and Computer
ENSF 337.description: Key features of the C programming language. Pointers, memory models and memory management. Manipulation of text files and binary files. Introduction to recursion. Introduction to a modern object-oriented language. Development of basic program design skills with small projects.

ENSF 338.title: Practical Data Structures and Algorithms
ENSF 338.description: Introduction to foundational data structures such as stacks, queues, lists, heaps, hash tables,trees, and graphs. Sorting and searching algorithms. Complexity analysis. Applications for software development
ENSF 338.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Software Engineering for Engineers 300 and 337.

ENSF 380.title: Object-Oriented Principles for Software Development
ENSF 380.description: Fundamental object-oriented software design and development topics for software engineering.Object-oriented analysis, design and development. Inheritance, polymorphism, and applicationof common data structures. Best practices for tools for testing, debugging, and documentation.
ENSF 380.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Software Engineering for Engineers 300 and 337.

ENSF 381.title: Full Stack Web Development
ENSF 381.description: A practical survey of fullstack software development including front-end and back-end design and development, relevant libraries and framework, principles of devOps and cloud integration, in the context of agile software development. Introduction to Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery (CI/CD).
ENSF 381.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Software Engineering for Engineers 300 and 337.

ENSF 400.title: Software Engineering Industry Practices and Communication
ENSF 400.description: Continuation of professional skills within the field of software engineering. Application of common tools for efficient software practice, cloud, continuous integration, and deployment. Introduction to innovation and ethics in design and entrepreneurial mindset. Licensing, legal, and internationalization issues.

ENSF 409.title: Principles of Software Development
ENSF 409.description: A survey of software design and development topics for Engineering students. Topics include: key features of an object-oriented programming language, especially inheritance and polymorphism; elements of object-oriented design; programming and application of common data structures; strategies and tools for testing and debugging.
ENSF 409.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Computer Engineering 335, 339, Software Engineering for Engineers 337, or Geomatics Engineering 333.

ENSF 444.title: Machine Learning Systems
ENSF 444.description: Techniques for extracting, cleaning, and visualizing data from engineering applications. Basic numerical computation techniques underlying learning algorithms. Fundamental supervised and unsupervised learning algorithms. Emphasis will be on leveraging existing software libraries and frameworks to solve problems in various engineering disciplines.
ENSF 444.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Software Engineering for Engineers 300; and 3 units from Engineering 319, Digital Engineering 319 or Electrical Engineering 419; and 3 units from Software Engineering for Engineers 337, Computer Engineering 335, 339, or Geomatics Engineering 333.

ENSF 460.title: Embedded Software and Hardware Systems
ENSF 460.description: Embedded real-time applications and operations. Computer architecture, microcontrollers and their instruction sets. Control and interfacing for embedded systems applications (e.g. robotics, consumer electronics, industrial automation, etc) using common input/output devices, debugging and other software engineering practices. Strategies for interrupt handling and exception handling.

ENSF 461.title: Applied Operating Systems
ENSF 461.description: Fundamental principles of operating systems. Virtual memory and input/output. Processes, threads and CPU scheduling. Persistent storage. Concurrent programming techniques to address inter-process communication and synchronization. Discussion of security elements.
ENSF 461.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Software Engineering for Engineers 338 and Computer Engineering 369.

ENSF 462.title: Networked Systems
ENSF 462.description: Fundamental principles of computer networks including layered protocol stacks. Socket programming. Programming frameworks for developing secure distributed systems. Introduction to principles of software-defined networks.
ENSF 462.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Software Engineering for Engineers 338 and Computer Engineering 369.

ENSF 480.title: Principles of Software Design
ENSF 480.description: Brief overview of typical software development lifecycles. Systematic methods for designing large-scale, quality software. Concepts such as abstraction, modularity, and software modelling will be covered. Designing for non-functional properties of software will be introduced. Emphasis on individual skills.
ENSF 480.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Software Engineering for Engineers 380 or 409.

ENSF 520.title: Brain Machine Interfaces
ENSF 520.description: Introduction to principles and methodologies of creating brain-machine interfaces (BMI) components, functional architectures of the brain, tools of brainwave acquisition, methods of processing brainwaves, interfacing paradigms, BMI applications and research trends.
ENSF 520.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Electrical Engineering or Software Engineering and fourth-year standing.

ENSF 544.title: Data Science for Software Engineers
ENSF 544.description: Fundamental topics in data collection, preparation, exploration, mining and machine learning will be covered with a focus on software development.
ENSF 544.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Engineering 319, Digital Engineering 319 or Electrical Engineering 419; and 3 units from Software Engineering for Engineers 337, Computer Engineering 335 or 339; and Computer Science 471 or Software Engineering 300.

ENSF 545.title: Introduction to Virtual Reality
ENSF 545.description: Introduce VR technologies. Emphasize on engineering methodologies of creating VR systems. Characterize VR systems, hardware and software, user 3D interaction, and VR applications and future.
ENSF 545.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Software Engineering for Engineers 380, 409 or Computer Engineering 369, 370.

ENSF 555.title: Introduction to Quantum Theory, Computation, and Information
ENSF 555.description: Basics of quantum theory, including historical context.  Introduction to quantum information including quantum computation, communication, and cryptography.
ENSF 555.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 211 and admission to Software Engineering.

ENSF 592.title: Programming Fundamentals for Data Engineers
ENSF 592.description: An introductory course in programming with an emphasis on data engineering. Topics include: Basic data structures and algorithms; Loops and iterations; Files and I/O, Functions, Classes, Modules, and Packages; Strings and text manipulation; Data wrangling; Network and Web programming; Data visualization.
ENSF 592.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering or consent of the department.

ENSF 593.title: Principles of Software Development I
ENSF 593.description: A fundamental study of software design and development topics for Engineering students. Topics include: fundamental programming constructs; key features of an object-oriented programming language, especially inheritance and polymorphism, elements of object-oriented design; programming and application of common data structures; strategies and tools for testing and debugging.
ENSF 593.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering or consent of the department.

ENSF 594.title: Principles of Software Development II
ENSF 594.description: A fundamental study of software design and development topics for Engineering students. Topics include: parallel programming; event-driven programming; database programming; socket programming, and the development of client-server architectures; software engineering best practices.
ENSF 594.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering or consent of the department.

ENSF 603.title: Modeling and Measurement of Software Performance
ENSF 603.description: Performance-oriented review of computer systems; methodologies to evaluate software performance; fundamental performance laws; performance prediction using queuing network models; discrete event simulation of computer system performance, simulation input and output analysis; performance testing, monitoring and benchmarking; workload characterization; software performance engineering.
ENSF 603.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): ): Admission to the PhD in Electrical and Computer Engineering or the MSc in Electrical Engineering.

ENSF 604.title: Theoretical Foundations of Software Engineering
ENSF 604.description: Explores formal principles of software engineering based on the common recognition that software engineering is not constrained by any physical laws as we know. The transdisciplinary foundations of software engineering are presented from the facets of information, computing, mathematics, cognitive, and management sciences, software engineering philosophies; engineering, mathematical, computational, management science, cognitive informatics, computational intelligence foundations and approaches of software engineering. As a result, a coherent framework of software engineering theories is learnt.
ENSF 604.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the PhD in Electrical and Computer Engineering or the MSc in Electrical Engineering.

ENSF 606.title: Software Engineering Fundamentals
ENSF 606.description: Methodological foundation of software development principles from requirements analysis to software design and architecture.
ENSF 606.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering.

ENSF 607.title: Advanced Software Design and Architecture
ENSF 607.description: A study of software design topics including: abstraction, modularity, design patterns, software modelling, architectural patterns.
ENSF 607.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering and completion of Software Engineering for Engineers 692, 693 and 694; or admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering, foundation courses exempt cohort.

ENSF 608.title: Databases
ENSF 608.description: A study of topics related to architecting software systems: database design, methods and technologies for developing web-based software systems, and architecting systems for non-functional software properties.
ENSF 608.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering and completion of Software Engineering for Engineers 692, 693 and 694; or admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering, foundation courses exempt cohort.

ENSF 609.title: Team Design Project in Software Engineering I
ENSF 609.description: A team design project in either software development or software best practice and experience.
ENSF 609.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering and Software Engineering for Engineers 607, 608, 611 and 614; or admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering, foundation courses exempt cohort.

ENSF 610.title: Team Design Project in Software Engineering II
ENSF 610.description: A team design project in either software development or software best practice and experience.
ENSF 610.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering and completion of Software Engineering for Engineers 692, 693 and 694; or admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering, foundation courses exempt cohort.

ENSF 611.title: Machine Learning for Software Engineers
ENSF 611.description: Covers Machine Learning, which focuses on developing machine learning applications, specifically in the engineering domain. Covers basic techniques for supervised and unsupervised learning, with the emphasis on the applied aspects of the techniques.
ENSF 611.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering and completion of Software Engineering for Engineers 692, 693 and 694; or admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering, foundation courses exempt cohort.

ENSF 612.title: Engineering Large Scale Data Analytics Systems
ENSF 612.description: Sources and characteristics of large scale data, i.e., "big data", large scale data analysis, benefits of large scale data analysis to various industry domains, scalable data analysis frameworks, large scale data algorithms in selected application domains.
ENSF 612.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering and completion of Software Engineering for Engineers 692, 693 and 694; or admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering, foundation courses exempt cohort.

ENSF 613.title: Software Requirements Analysis and Process Management
ENSF 613.description: Introduction to software development process, product management, and software requirements analysis: Elicitation, modelling, and validation of requirements.
ENSF 613.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the PhD in Electrical and Computer Engineering or the MSc in Electrical Engineering.

ENSF 614.title: Advanced System Analysis and Software Design
ENSF 614.description: Advanced topics on principles of system analysis, system thinking, requirements engineering, essential elements of quality software design, design patterns, and system-level software analysis.
ENSF 614.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering and completion of Software Engineering for Engineers 692, 693 and 694; or admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering, foundation courses exempt cohort.

ENSF 615.title: Science and Technology of Brain-Machine Interface Systems
ENSF 615.description: Fundamental principles and methodologies of brain-machine interface (BMI) systems. Cover basic anatomy and functional architecture of the human brain, principles and tools of  brainwave acquisition, methodologies of processing and interfacing the brainwaves, state-of-the-arts of BMI systems, ethical aspects, and BMI applications and future applications.
ENSF 615.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Software Engineering for Engineers 545 or Electrical Engineering 602 or by approval of the course instructor. 

Antirequisite: Credit for Software Engineering for Engineers 615 and 520 will not be allowed.

Also known as: (formerly Software Engineering for Engineers 619.36)

ENSF 616.title: Software Development Using Open Source
ENSF 616.description: This course takes a two-pronged approach, addressing both the utilization of open source software development and the skills necessary for effective open source software development in industry. Learners will examine academic literature around the topic, and practice some technical skills associated with modern software development.
ENSF 616.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the PhD in Electrical and Computer Engineering or the MSc in Electrical Engineering.

ENSF 617.title: Introduction to Machine Learning
ENSF 617.description: Overview of the historical context that allowed deep learning to flourish. Different types of neural networks; how to train and deploy them in various problems; Fine-tuning pre-trained models to achieve state-of-the-art results in relevant applications; overview of the current trends in deep learning.
ENSF 617.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering.

ENSF 619.title: Special Topics
ENSF 619.description: A study of problems of particular interest to students specializing in Software Engineering.
ENSF 619.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the PhD in Electrical and Computer Engineering or the MSc in Electrical Engineering.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ENSF 692.title: Programming Fundamentals for Data Engineers
ENSF 692.description: An introductory course in programming with an emphasis on data engineering. Topics include: basic data structures and algorithms; loops and iterations; files and I/O, functions, classes, modules, and packages; strings and text manipulation; data wrangling; network and web programming; data visualization.
ENSF 692.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering.

ENSF 693.title: Principles of Software Development
ENSF 693.description: A fundamental study of software design and development topics for engineering students. Topics include: fundamental programming constructs; key features of an object-oriented programming language, especially inheritance and polymorphism, elements of object-oriented design; programming and application of common data structures; strategies and tools for testing and debugging.
ENSF 693.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering.

ENSF 694.title: Data Structures and Algorithm Analysis for Engineers
ENSF 694.description: A fundamental study of data structures and algorithms for engineering students. Topics include arrays, lists, stacks, queues, trees, hash tables, graphs, algorithms for searching and sorting, and introduction to algorithm analysis.
ENSF 694.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering.

ENTI 201.title: Introduction to Business Venturing
ENTI 201.description:
Introduction to the various business disciplines from the perspective of creating a new business venture. The primary learning methodology is a term project; students identify a business opportunity, research the opportunity, and write a business plan for the business.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Entrepreneurship and Innovation 201 and either Management Studies 217 or Strategy and Global Management 217 will not be allowed.

Notes: Not available for credit towards the Bachelor of Commerce. Required for the minor in Management and Society and the minor in Entrepreneurship and Enterprise Development.

ENTI 217.title: Design Your Life
ENTI 217.description: Course will address the "wicked problem" of designing your life and career journey. Students will develop frameworks, tools, and a sense of community through engagement with the UN Sustainable Development Goals.
ENTI 217.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

ENTI 317.title: Entrepreneurial Thinking
ENTI 317.description: Leaders in today's business environment are challenged to think entrepreneurially-to seek opportunities and find ways to turn opportunities into viable for-profit business ventures, social ventures or not-for-profit organizations. They are challenged to do more than just business; giving back to society is expected. The primary learning methodology is through a project in which an opportunity is identified, researched, and the results of a feasibility assessment are written and presented.
ENTI 317.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business Bachelor of Commerce program, Management Studies 217 and Strategy and Global Management 217.

ENTI 333.title: Generative AI and Prompting
ENTI 333.description: Learn to use generative AI effectively through prompting techniques and tools for the generation of content.  Emphasis on innovative and entrepreneurial applications.

ENTI 359.title: Selected Topics in Entrepreneurship and Innovation
ENTI 359.description: Investigation of selected topics related to entrepreneurship and innovation, emphasizing both generally applicable practical applications and academic research, as well as specific industries or contexts.
ENTI 359.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 24 units. For certain topics consent of the Haskayne School of Business will also be required.

ENTI 381.title: Innovation-Driven Entrepreneurship
ENTI 381.description: Hands-on overview of the processes involved in evaluating an innovative business idea for a start-up using a case: team formation, customer discovery-target market analysis, product-industry feasibility and business model validation.

ENTI 401.title: Opportunity Identification and Evaluation
ENTI 401.description: Introduction to the processes involved in idea generation and concept development for a business. Review an application of market, product-industry, operational and financial feasibility analysis to evaluate the viability of the business concept using market research.

ENTI 403.title: New Venture Planning
ENTI 403.description: A project-based course in developing and writing a business plan for an existing and/or growth-oriented venture. Focus will be given to the content, form and uses of a formal business plan.

ENTI 405.title: Start-Ups and Ecosystems
ENTI 405.description:
Introduction to concepts of community and innovation systems, to understand how
entrepreneurs lead through co-optation strategies and civic engagement in order to address ecosystem challenges and build organizations. Community-based experiential project.

ENTI 407.title: Digital Entrepreneurship Technology
ENTI 407.description: Explores emerging internet-based technologies and digital tools that support, improve and transform the nature of entrepreneurship. Involves hands-on exercises using various tools and practice providing technology recommendations.

ENTI 411.title: Technology Commercialization
ENTI 411.description: Investigation of building the founding team, marketing, financing, hiring human resources, and implementing growth strategies, emphasizing the practical application of theory and principles to a high technology business setting.

ENTI 413.title: Social Enterprise Strategies
ENTI 413.description: Social enterprise uses the logic of business to solve social challenges. Explores themes on entrepreneurial thinking, business model development, impact measurement, and other issues to create and improve social enterprises.

ENTI 415.title: Software Venturing
ENTI 415.description: Apply entrepreneurial thinking principles to launch a software venture in an experiential environment paired with Computer Science students to work in teams to mimic a software start-up.

ENTI 529.title: Applied Capstone Project
ENTI 529.description: Provides a framework to pursue an entrepreneurial thinking experience, to support knowledge, skills development and reflection. Outcomes will include a valuable project deliverable, and reflection writings. Includes placements, individual and/or team projects.
ENTI 529.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 84 units including Entrepreneurship and Innovation 201 or 317, and admission to the Embedded Certificate in Entrepreneurial Thinking or the Haskayne School of Business or the Management and Society Minor or the Minor in Entrepreneurship and Enterprise Development.

ENTI 531.title: Entrepreneurship Law
ENTI 531.description: Legal issues that commonly confront emerging businesses and the law impacting business decisions are addressed. Topics may include: corporate structure, directors' and officers' liability, financing and securities, intellectual property law, licensing, contractual interpretation and drafting, and other relevant legal issues.
ENTI 531.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Strategy and Global Management 395 or Entrepreneurship and Innovation 317 or 381.

ENTI 541.title: Social Enterprise in Practice
ENTI 541.description: A practical investigation of social enterprise and the ways in which it can tackle social issues, with emphasis on real-world case studies and service-based learning.
ENTI 541.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, 60 units and consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

ENTI 559.title: Selected Topics in Entrepreneurship and Innovation
ENTI 559.description: Investigation of selected topics related to entrepreneurship, venture development and family business, emphasizing the practical application of theory and principles to actual business situations and venture opportunities.
ENTI 559.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Entrepreneurship and Innovation 317 or 381. For certain topics consent of the Haskayne School of Business will also be required.

ENTI 601.title: Entrepreneurial Thinking
ENTI 601.description: Business leaders are challenged to think entrepreneurially - to seek opportunities and find ways to turn opportunities into viable ventures. These may be for-profit, not-for-profit, or social ventures. Students will engage in experiential learning to complete a feasibility assessment of such an opportunity, including the concept of giving back to society.

ENTI 607.title: Digital Entrepreneurship Technology
ENTI 607.description: Explores emerging digital tools and technologies that support, improve, and transform entrepreneurship and innovation. Students engage in hands-on exercises and tinkering using various tools and practice providing technology recommendations.

ENTI 609.title: Technology and Innovation Management
ENTI 609.description:
The dynamics of innovation as the primary driving force within firms and modern industrialized economies. Potential concepts are: incremental versus radical innovations, market-pull versus technology-push theories, dominant designs, technological trajectories, key factors for successful innovation. The emergence of new technologies; the importance of national and regional innovation systems; the role of science, regulations and social pressure in innovations dynamics; knowledge management; and implications for firms in rapidly changing industrial settings may be discussed.

Also known as: (formerly Entrepreneurship and Innovation 793)

ENTI 611.title: Technology Commercialization
ENTI 611.description:
The process of taking a technology product or service from development to the market, including market strategies, finding investors and potential early customers, the role of advisors, legal issues and the importance of the exit strategy for founders and early stage investors. Students will be required to complete a major project to write a feasibility study for a new technology or a case study of a successful technology venture.

Also known as: (formerly Entrepreneurship and Innovation 791)

ENTI 613.title: Strategies in Social Enterprise
ENTI 613.description:
A social enterprise focuses on solving complex societal problems through market-based solutions. With the changing political landscape, social enterprises blur the traditionally separate roles of governments, non-governmental organizations, for-profit companies, and charities.
