Concentration will be on for-profit models, but many of the principles and tools will be applicable to any entrepreneurial or intrapreneurial (new social or environmental change initiatives in existing organizations) endeavours with a social mission.

Also known as: (formerly Entrepreneurship and Innovation 668.01 Strategies in Social Enterprise)

ENTI 617.title: Opportunity Development
ENTI 617.description:
A project- and case-based course designed to explore concepts of opportunity development.

Also known as: (formerly Entrepreneurship and Innovation 783)

ENTI 621.title: Start-up Venture Analysis
ENTI 621.description:
Students learn firm formation, early-stage financing, and the development of massively scalable companies through lectures and interactions with ventures participating in the CDL-Rockies program.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Entrepreneurship and Innovation 621 and Finance 663 or 785 will not be allowed.

ENTI 623.title: Creative Destruction Lab - Rockies
ENTI 623.description: Students learn how to build a technology firm by providing hands-on assistance to CDL-Rockies ventures based on guidance provided by seasoned business mentors and investors.

ENTI 625.title: Introduction to Entrepreneurship
ENTI 625.description: Focus on idea generation, feasibility analysis, and business model development of early-stage businesses using experiential team-based projects and case analyses. The course is restricted to non-Haskayne graduate students.
ENTI 625.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

ENTI 627.title: Venture Development
ENTI 627.description:
A project-based course designed around the formation of business concepts in the formalization of a business plan.

Also known as: (formerly Entrepreneurship and Innovation 785)

ENTI 629.title: Applied Business Analysis
ENTI 629.description: Approaches to advising new and existing ventures on effective venture development. Projects will involve the student conducting analysis of several ventures and providing advice to them.
ENTI 629.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Marketing 601 or consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

Also known as: (formerly Entrepreneurship and Innovation 787)

ENTI 631.title: New Venture Law
ENTI 631.description:
Legal principles impacting business decisions regarding new venture creation, growth and routine business operations. Topics may include: corporate structure, directors' and officers' liability, financing, intellectual property law, contracts and regulations.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Entrepreneurship and Innovation 631 and 797.02 will not be allowed.

Also known as: (formerly Entrepreneurship and Innovation 731)

ENTI 633.title: Generative AI and Prompting
ENTI 633.description:
Learn to use generative AI effectively through prompting techniques and tools for the generation of content. Emphasis on innovative and entrepreneurial applications.

Also known as: (formerly Entrepreneurship and Innovation 668.03 (Generative AI and Prompting))

ENTI 668.title: Seminar in Entrepreneurship and Innovation
ENTI 668.description:
Study and discussion of current research literature and contemporary issues on topics related to Entrepreneurship and Innovation.

Also known as: (formerly Entrepreneurship and Innovation 789)

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ENTI 672.title: Thinking like an Entrepreneur
ENTI 672.description: Focuses on identifying and successfully exploiting opportunities by applying research and analytical tools. Some of the topics covered include design thinking and business modeling.
ENTI 672.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Management program.

ENTI 674.title: Technologies of Innovation
ENTI 674.description: Focuses on the use of leading edge technology for innovation, entrepreneurship and automation in different organizational contexts. Special emphasis on web-based software such as: Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) tools.
ENTI 674.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Management program.

ENTI 735.title: Cultivating Entrepreneurship Organizational Change and Innovation
ENTI 735.description: Explores dynamics and elements involved in creating, implementing, navigating and studying organizational change and innovation. Examines how to study and describe change and innovation and the respective processes in organizations.
ENTI 735.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Business Administration program.    

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

ENTI 797.title: Advanced Seminar in Entrepreneurship and Innovation
ENTI 797.description: Intensive study and discussion of current literature and research with respect to selected, advanced topics in Entrepreneurship and Innovation. May include formal academic or applied research project.
ENTI 797.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ENTI 799.01.title: Entrepreneurship: The State of the Art

ENTI 799.02.title: Concept Model & Thry New Vent Dev

ENTI 799.03.title: Special Topics in Entrepreneurship and Innovation

ERTH 209.title: Introduction to Earth
ERTH 209.description:
Basic concepts regarding the major features of Earth; its rock and mineral composition, processes controlling erosion, deposition and surface structures; formation of mountains, ocean basins and continents; internal structure of the Earth and plate tectonics. 

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Earth 209 and Geology 201 will not be allowed. 

Also known as: (formerly Geology 209)

Notes: Not open for credit to Honours, Majors or Minors in Geology, Geology (Petroleum Geology Concentration), Applied and Environmental Geology, Geophysics, Environmental Science (Geoscience Concentration) or Natural Sciences (Geoscience Concentration).

ERTH 210.title: Welcome to Earth
ERTH 210.description:
Our home planet is the only place we know of that is inhabited by living things. What makes Earth unique? By identifying rocks and minerals and interpreting evidence collected from geologic maps and models, students will uncover the materials that make up the Earth, their origin, age, distribution, and processes that recycle them over time including those operating below, at, and above Earth's surface. Students will also explore resource and environmental management.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Earth 210 and any of Geology 201, 202, or 376 will not be allowed.

ERTH 290.title: Field Methods and Safety
ERTH 290.description:
Focus on designing and performing field-based investigations; logistics of planning and running field activities; and field safety. Topics will include navigation, sampling, and field reports across a variety of topics within Earth, energy, and environmental sciences. 
  
NOT INCLUDED IN GPA.

Notes: This course is primarily lecture-based with field trips, which may occur in rugged conditions and varying weather, for which participants must be prepared and equipped. A supplementary fee will be assessed to cover additional costs associated with this course. The course will typically be offered in Spring and/or Summer terms over a period of up to three weeks.

ERTH 299.title: Topics in Earth
ERTH 299.description:
Lectures and study in Earth sciences.

Notes: This course is not part of the Field of Geology or the Field of Geophysics. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT 

Also known as: (formerly Geology 297)

ERTH 301.title: Geology of the Mountain Regions of Western Canada
ERTH 301.description: Selected topics encountered in introductory physical geology will be pursued in greater depth to explain the geology of Western Canadian Mountain Parks and adjacent areas.
ERTH 301.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Earth 209, 210, Geology 201 or 209.

Also known as: (formerly Geology 301)

ERTH 305.title: Introduction to Dinosaurs
ERTH 305.description:
Biology, evolution, and extinction of dinosaurs; geographic and temporal distribution, habitats, and ecology of the various dinosaur groups; preservation, exploration, collection, preparation, and identification of dinosaur fossils. 

Also known as: (formerly Geology 305)

ERTH 307.title: Geological History of Life
ERTH 307.description:
The history of life from the earliest records to the present. Fossils, geological time, extinction, basic paleontology. The rise and development of various animals and plants including dinosaurs, mammals and humans. 

Also known as: (formerly Geology 307)

ERTH 308.title: Geology and Human Health
ERTH 308.description: An overview of human health issues related to geological phenomena. Examples of possible topics include medical geology, heavy metals in groundwater, effects of volcanic eruptions, effects of asbestos-type minerals, acid mine drainage and soil nutrient deficiencies.
ERTH 308.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Earth 209, 210, Geology 201 or 209.
 
Also known as: (formerly Geology 308)

ERTH 309.title: Field Studies of Earth
ERTH 309.description: Field-based study of Earth oriented toward non-majors. Study and interpretation of geological and/or geophysical information in the field, and its significance to social and environmental issues. Field studies will normally be conducted away from Calgary in the spring or summer semester (destinations vary).

ERTH 310.title: Minerals and Rocks
ERTH 310.description: Systematic description and classification of minerals, rocks, and ores. Characterization of minerals using macroscopic and microscopic properties, especially structure and chemical composition. Use of textures and mineralogy to understand first-order conditions of formation of common sedimentary, igneous, metamorphic, and ore-related rocks.
ERTH 310.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Earth 210, Geology 201 or 202; and Chemistry 201 or 211; and Chemistry 203 or 213.

ERTH 320.title: Earth Surface Processes and Environments
ERTH 320.description: Earth surface and near-surface processes and the variety of environments they create and modify at a range of spatial and temporal scales. Investigation of systems and conditions that control the weathering, transport, and deposition of Earth materials, with emphasis on applications to the sedimentary rock cycle and soil formation.
ERTH 320.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Earth 210, Geology 201 or 202; Physics 211 or 221; and Chemistry 203 or 213.

ERTH 330.title: Water and Earth
ERTH 330.description: Processes controlling water movement and storage above, on, and beneath Earth's surface. Collection, analysis, and interpretation of hydrological, geophysical, and water quality data at a variety of spatial and temporal scales. Examination of impacts of natural and human activities on water resources, including issues related to water quality, availability, and sustainability.
ERTH 330.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Earth 210, Geology 201 or 202; and Chemistry 203 or 213; and Physics 211 or 221; and 3 units from Mathematics 249, 265, or 275.

ERTH 340.title: Rock Deformation and Structures
ERTH 340.description: Processes and mechanisms of rock deformation at plate tectonic to microscopic scales and a range of temporal scales (seconds to millions of years). Description of deformation features and analysis of the forces that cause them.
ERTH 340.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Earth 210, Geology 201 or 202; and Mathematics 211 or 213; and Physics 211 or 221.

ERTH 350.title: Climate, Evolution, and Deep Time
ERTH 350.description: Earth's climate system and life, and the geologic record of how they have changed through time. Investigation of the geologic data used to reconstruct past intervals of climate and biological upheaval with comparison to modern rates of change.
ERTH 350.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Earth 210, Geology 201 or 202.

ERTH 360.title: Global Geophysics and Planetary Geoscience
ERTH 360.description: Application of physical principles to understanding Earth and other bodies in the Solar System. Examination of evidence for Earth formation and structure considering thermodynamics, gravity, seismology, and magnetism. Analysis of Earth's lithosphere including plate motion, earthquakes, and comparison of oceanic and continental crust.
ERTH 360.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Earth 210, Geology 201 or 202; and 3 units from Chemistry 201, 203, 211 or     213; and Physics 211 or 221; and Mathematics 249 or 265; and 3 units from Computer Science 217, 231, 235 or Data Science 211.

ERTH 375.title: Natural Disasters and Critical Earth Phenomena
ERTH 375.description:
Causes of disasters such as earthquakes, tsunami, volcanic eruptions, mud flows, landslides, avalanches, flooding, tornadoes and hurricanes, and other critical phenomena such as sinkholes, ozone depletion and radiation, carbon dioxide and global warming, El Nio, toxic natural materials and pollution, and extraterrestrial impacts. Surveys of historic disasters and their effects on life on Earth. Methods of prediction and prevention of disasters and precautions for the mitigation of their effects. 

Notes: This course is not part of the Field of Geology or the Field of Geophysics.

Also known as: (formerly Geophysics 375)

ERTH 390.title: Geoscience Field School
ERTH 390.description: The development of field-based techniques in the collection, description, analysis, interpretation, and reporting of geoscientific field data and results. Includes navigation, geological mapping, field sampling, and geophysical methods. Multiple days of field work outside of the classroom in methods related to each of geology, hydrogeology, and geophysics.

ERTH 399.title: Topics in Earth
ERTH 399.description: Exploration of various areas in Earth. Topics will vary from year-to-year. It will be offered as required to provide the opportunity for students to engage in additional areas in Earth. Before registration, consult the Department of Earth for topics offered.
ERTH 399.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ERTH 570.title: Independent Study
ERTH 570.description: A written report based on independent study. Originality is emphasized, laboratory and field studies are encouraged.
ERTH 570.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Science 311; and consent of the Department and of a departmental faculty member. 

Also known as: (formerly Geology 509)

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT.

ERTH 580.title: Senior Thesis
ERTH 580.description: A written report based on extensive independent study. Originality is emphasized, laboratory and field studies are encouraged.
ERTH 580.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Science 311; and consent of the Department and of a departmental faculty member who will act as a supervisor.

Also known as: (formerly Geology 510)

ERTH 590.title: Advanced Field Methods
ERTH 590.description: Field-based study of complex geoscience topics. Advanced skills development in one or more aspects of field data collection, portrayal, description, analysis, and interpretation. Field work will normally be conducted away from Calgary in the spring or summer semester (destinations vary).
ERTH 590.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Earth 390 or Geology 337 and consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ERTH 599.title: Topics in Earth
ERTH 599.description: Courses are offered in contemporary topics in areas such as electrical and electromagnetic methods, exploration and environmental geophysics, geochemistry, gravity and magnetics, hydrogeology, integrated geophysical methods, mineralogy, paleontology, petroleum geology, petrology, quantitative geology, sedimentology, seismology, structural geology, and surficial geology.
ERTH 599.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 78 units and consent of the Department. 

Also known as: (formerly Geology 599)

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ESCI 201.title: Energy Use in the Modern World
ESCI 201.description: Overview of how the world's energy systems work and why these energy systems are essential to how society functions. Examination of benefits and drawbacks of the sources of energy people use; generation and distribution of electricity; energy efficiency; and environmental consequences of energy choices

ESCI 317.title: Energy Transformations and Heat Engines
ESCI 317.description: Introduction to the thermodynamics of how heat engines transform heat into useful forms of energy for electricity and transportation. Examination of using pV diagrams to calculate work; efficiency; waste heat; and changes in entropy.
ESCI 317.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Energy Science 201 or admission to Natural Science (Energy Science Concentration); and 3 units from Physics 211, 221, 227; and 3 units from Physics 223, 259, or 355.

Antirequisite(s) Credit for Energy Science 317 and Science 507.17 (Engines and Electricity) will not be allowed.

Also known as: (formerly Science 317)

ESCI 321.title: Climate Change Causes, Adaptations, and Mitigations
ESCI 321.description: Principles of climate change and the interplay between anthropogenic climate change and energy systems.  Earth's current changing climate; the effects of greenhouse gases and human activity; the impact of climate change on society and the environment; and climate change mitigation and adaptation.
ESCI 321.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Energy Science 201; 3 units from Physics 211, 221, 227; and 3 units from Physics 223, 259, or 355.

ESCI 399.title: Topics in Energy Science I
ESCI 399.description: Discussion of a particular topic on energy science at the 3XX level. The topic will be determined by the course instructor and will be communicated to students before the start of term.
ESCI 399.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Energy Science 201 and admission to Energy Science Major or Minor.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ESCI 421.title: Nuclear Energy
ESCI 421.description: Overview of nuclear energy production, including the nuclear fuel cycle, the workings of atomic nuclei, nuclear reactions, nuclear cross-section, reactor design, uranium mining, waste disposal, and both beneficial and harmful biological effects of radiation.
ESCI 421.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Energy Science 317, Physics 449, or Chemistry 371; or Engineering Energy and Environment 355 and admission to the Schulich School of Engineering.

Also known as: (formerly Science 421)

ESCI 423.title: Batteries and Fuel Cells
ESCI 423.description: Scientific principles behind batteries and fuel cells, including the electrochemistry of classic voltaic and electrolytic cells; thermodynamics, kinetics, and performance curves of batteries and fuel cells; and current applications and limitations.
ESCI 423.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Energy Science 317, Physics 449, or Chemistry 371; or Engineering Energy and Environment 355 and admission to the Schulich School of Engineering.

Also known as: (formerly Science 423).

ESCI 427.title: Solar Energy
ESCI 427.description: The science behind capturing and using solar energy for human utilization, covering sunlight energy conversion; solar photovoltaic systems; integration of solar power into energy systems; and environmental, societal, and economic issues related to solar project development.
ESCI 427.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Energy Science 317, Physics 449, or Chemistry 371; or Engineering Energy and Environment 355 and admission to the Schulich School of Engineering.

Also known as: (formerly Science 427)

ESCI 431.title: Energy from Water
ESCI 431.description: Introduction to the fundamentals of utilizing energy from water in the environment.   Examination of hydrology and fluid dynamics; electricity generation from rivers, ocean waves, tides, and ocean currents; pumped storage; and environmental, societal, and economic issues.
ESCI 431.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Energy Science 201; or Energy Science 317 and admission to Natural Science (Energy Science Concentration); and 3 units from Physics 211, 221, or 227; and 3 units from Physics 223, 259, or 355; or Engineering Energy and Environment 355 and admission to the Schulich School of Engineering.

Antirequisite: Credit for Energy Science 431 and Science 531 will not be allowed.

Also known as: (formerly Science 431)

ESCI 433.title: Geothermal Energy
ESCI 433.description: Overview of utilizing thermal energy from the ground, including low and high temperature geothermal systems; ground-source heat pumps; geothermal heating; and related technical, environmental, and socioeconomic issues.
ESCI 433.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Energy Science 201; or Energy Science 317 and admission to Natural Science (Energy Science Concentration); and 3 units from Physics 211, 221, or 227; and 3 units from Physics 223, 259, or 355; or Energy and Environment, Engineering 355 and admission to the Schulich School of Engineering.

ESCI 437.title: Energy from Biomass
ESCI 437.description: Overview of the energy from biomass, including  the production of biomass feedstocks; the conversion of biomass to energy or to feedstocks for other products; the use of biomass in transportation, electricity, and heat generation; its societal impacts such as air pollution; and economic and technical limitations.
ESCI 437.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Energy Science 317, Physics 449, or Chemistry 371; or Energy and Environment, Engineering 355 and admission to the Schulich School of Engineering.

ESCI 443.title: Coal, Oil, and Natural Gas
ESCI 443.description: Overview of fossil fuel energy and hydrocarbon systems.  Examining the history and geography of development of fossil fuel resources; upstream, midstream, and downstream components; conventional oil and gas, heavy oil and shale gas/oil resources; liquified natural gas (LNG); abatement of greenhouse gas emissions using carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS); and Indigenous perspectives on Canadian fossil fuel development and extraction.

ESCI 447.title: Wind Energy
ESCI 447.description: Overview of wind energy including generating electricity from wind, including turbine types and relevant fluid dynamics; limitations to wind power such as the Betz limit and variable supply; environmental consequences related to wind energy; interactions between wind power producers, the electricity system, and the environment.
ESCI 447.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Energy Science 201; or Energy Science 317 and admission to Natural Science (Energy Science Concentration); and Physics 211, 221, or 227; and Physics 223, 255, or 355; or Energy and Environment, Engineering 355 and admission to the Schulich School of Engineering.

ESCI 453.title: Critical Minerals for Energy Systems
ESCI 453.description: Overview of minerals that are critical to energy science, including economic importance and supply risk; decarbonizing energy systems and the digital economy; the exploration, production, processing, and distribution of critical minerals; and socioeconomic, Indigenous, and environmental perspectives.
ESCI 453.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Energy Science 317 or Geology 323; or Energy and Environment, Engineering 355 and admission to the Schulich School of Engineering.

ESCI 499.title: Topics in Energy Science II
ESCI 499.description: Discussion of a particular topic on energy science at the 4XX level. The topic will be determined by the course instructor and will be communicated to students before the start of term.
ESCI 499.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 6 units of courses labelled Energy Science (ESCI) and admission to Energy Science Major or Minor.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ESCI 517.title: Energy Policy
ESCI 517.description: Overview of the role of energy policy in energy systems including the history of energy policy, the policy making progress, principles of policy analysis and policy communication, and the impact of energy policy on energy systems. The course will cover different aspects of energy policy at the international, national, and subnational level including climate/emissions policy, environmental assessment and review current issues in energy policy.
ESCI 517.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Energy Science 321; and 6 units of courses labeled Energy Science (ESCI) at the 400-level or above.

ESCI 521.title: Energy Science Capstone Course
ESCI 521.description: Team-based course where students integrate the knowledge and skills from previous courses to critically evaluate local, national, and/or global energy-system scenarios to sustainably deliver the energy society needs into the future.
ESCI 521.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Economics 201; and 3 units from Indigenous Studies 303, 343, or 345; and Energy Science 321; and 12 units of courses labelled Energy Science at the 400 level or above.

ESCI 570.title: Independent Research in Energy Science
ESCI 570.description: An independent study course for students to research a topic related to energy working closely with a faculty member.
ESCI 570.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 15 units in the Field of Energy Science and consent of the Faculty.

ESCI 580.title: Research Project in Energy Science
ESCI 580.description: Research project under the co/supervision of faculty members in the Department of Biological Sciences. Original and independent thought, practical research, and written and oral reports presented on completion of this course.
ESCI 580.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 15 units of Energy Science and consent of the Faculty.

ESCI 599.title: Topics in Energy Science
ESCI 599.description: Discussion of a particular topic on energy science. The topic will be determined by the course instructor and will be communicated to students before the start of term.
ESCI 599.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 15 units of courses labelled Energy Science (ESCI) and admission to Energy Science Major or Minor.

FILM 201.title: Introduction to Film Studies
FILM 201.description: An introduction to thefoundationalissuesandvocabularyof film studies explored through a wide range of filmic texts. Privileging questions offilmtechnique and style, the course also considers cinemaas an institution that comprises an industrial system of production, social and aesthetic norms and codesandparticular modes of reception.

FILM 203.title: Introduction to Research in Film Studies
FILM 203.description:
An in-depth introduction to conducting research in film studies, emphasizing critical viewing, reading and writing through the examination of a specific topic, such as a film genre, a national cinema, or a filmmaker.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Film 201.

FILM 301.title: Topics in National Cinema
FILM 301.description:
Topics will explore various aspects of, or historical moments in, a particular nation's cinematic culture. Topics might include Quebecois cinema, current British cinema, German cinema Between the Wars, Canadian cinema, the History of Chinese cinema, etc.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

FILM 305.title: Topic in Genre
FILM 305.description:
Topics will focus on the style, narrative form, and historical evolution of selected genres, for example, the Documentary, the Western, the Melodrama, the Musical, etc.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

FILM 307.title: Topic in Cinema and Gender Studies
FILM 307.description:
Topics will explore the representation of gender and sexuality in cinema. Topics might include: Images of Women in the American 1940s, Lesbian Images in Current Cinema, The Queer 1950s, Comparative Images of Women in American and French Cinema, etc.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

FILM 321.title: History Of Popular Cinema
FILM 321.description: An assessment of the various ways in which the history of film production can be approached, including the development of filmmaking technologies, evolutions in cinematic style and narrative traditions, particularly as they relate to popular cinema, and changing industrial practices.

FILM 323.title: Issues in Film History
FILM 323.description: An introduction to key concepts in cinematic historiography. Emphasis will be placed upon non-traditional or non-canonical films and their relationship to dominant histories of filmmaking.

FILM 331.title: Film Theory up to 1950
FILM 331.description: An introduction to theoretical perspectives on film before the mid twentieth century. Connects film with broader debates on aesthetics, medium specificity, genre, and realism. Includes theories developed in the first half of the 20th century related to Silent Film, Formalism, Montage, Critical Theory, and Auteur theories.

FILM 333.title: Film Theory After 1950
FILM 333.description: An introduction to theoretical perspectives on film developed since the mid-twentieth century, specifically Structuralism, Linguistics, Psycholanalysis, Feminism, Post-structuralism, Cultural Studies, Post-colonialism and Queer Theory.

FILM 351.title: Canadian Film
FILM 351.description:
An introduction to key historical and theoretical aspects of Canadian film. Topics will include the study of Canadian film auteurs, documentary and social change, feature film genres, and the role of government regulations. Explores the central themes and issues facing Canadian filmmakers and audiences.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Film 351 and Canadian Studies 331 will not be allowed.

FILM 401.title: Topic in Film Theory
FILM 401.description: Topics will be organized around particular theorists, schools of theory, historical issues in film culture, or contemporary thought on film. Topics may include: Psychoanalysis and/as Film Theory; Kaja Silverman and Teresa de Lauretis; Modernism and Postmodernism; Feminist Film Theory; Queer Theory and Film; Postcolonial Theory and Film; Semiotics.
FILM 401.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Film 331 or 333.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

FILM 403.title: Topic in the Director's Cinema
FILM 403.description: Topics will examine the distinctive style and concerns of a particular director or directors.
FILM 403.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Film 201.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

FILM 405.title: Advanced Topics in Film Genre
FILM 405.description: Topics will be organized around a specific film generic tradition.
FILM 405.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Film 201 and 3 units from 305 or 321.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

FILM 407.title: Experiential Learning in Film
FILM 407.description: This course is designed to provide students with the opportunity to combine interests in film studies research with experiential learning opportunities in the community and workplace (internships, paid employment, approved film production training or volunteer position).
FILM 407.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Film 201, admission to the BA in Film Studies or the Bachelor of Film Studies and consent of the Department.

FILM 409.title: SpecialTopicsin Film Studies
FILM 409.description: Topic may be historical, theoretical or analytical in emphasis.
FILM 409.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Film 321, 331 or 333.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

FILM 441.title: The Film Festival
FILM 441.description: An exploration of the social practices (cultural tourism, tastemaking, identity formation, celebrity and star formation) and operational aspects (marketing, promotion, jurying, lobbying, audience cultivation) of film festivals. Students will be encouraged to participate in community service learning through volunteer opportunities with a particular festival.

FILM 451.title: The Canadian Film Industry: National and Global Perspectives
FILM 451.description: A study of the nature of the Canadian film industry. Emphasis will be on the evolution of the Canadian motion picture industry in the twentieth century and how it is situated in contemporary popular culture. Other topics include Canada's historic relationship to Hollywood, the audience for Canadian films, the role of the state in funding, distribution and production systems, the impact of new technologies, and how the structure of Canada's film industry compares with those of other countries.
FILM 451.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units of courses labelled Film, Communication and Media Studies, or Canadian Studies at the 300 level.

FILM 461.title: Film Audience and Reception
FILM 461.description: Explores aspects of spectatorship, audience and reception approaches as they intersect with the experience and study of cinema.

FILM 471.title: Experimental Film and Video
FILM 471.description: Explores the genre of experimental film and video. Particular emphasis will be given to the history and evolution of works in this genre with attention to Canadian contributions and the impact of digital and new media.

FILM 501.title: Independent Research in Film Studies
FILM 501.description: Supervised individual study of a special topic.
FILM 501.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

FILM 509.title: Advanced Special Topics in Film Studies
FILM 509.description: Selected topic in film studies suitable for advanced studies in the degree. Topic may be historical, theoretical or analytical in emphasis.
FILM 509.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 6 units of courses labelled Film at the 400 level.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

FILM 591.title: Capstone Seminar in Film Studies
FILM 591.description: Explores the variety of ways in which film and the technologies of motion pictures connect with social life with reference to a specific topic. Completion of a major project that will integrate understanding of film theory, history and genres.
FILM 591.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the BA in Film Studies and 78 units (13.0 full-course equivalents), of which, 6 units (1.0 full-course equivalent) must be taken from Film 321, 323, 331, or 333.

FILM 595.title: Honours Seminar
FILM 595.description: Individual research and seminar activities (e.g., critiques, presentations, and peer reviews of drafts) to produce a proposal and a paper to be used as the basis for the honours thesis.
FILM 595.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to BA Honours Film Studies.

FILM 597.title: Honours Thesis and Seminar
FILM 597.description: Supervised individual research and preparation of an honours thesis. Incorporating material from the Film 595 final paper, to complete the honours thesis. Seminar activities include progress reports, peer reviews, and support for poster presentations and oral exams.
FILM 597.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Film 595 and admission to BA Honours in Film Studies.

FNCE 317.title: Financial Management
FNCE 317.description: An introduction to the allocation of financial capital, from a theoretical as well as a practical perspective. The course builds on a modern understanding of how risk, time horizon, and market imperfections each affect the value of real and financial assets. Topics include time value of money, the risk-return trade off, financial investing, corporate financing, and corporate investing.
FNCE 317.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, 30 units including Mathematics 249 or 251 or 265 or 281, Economics 201 and 203, Statistics 213 and 217, Accounting 217 or 317, and Business and Environment 291 or Management Studies 217.

FNCE 341.title: Canadian Business Finance
FNCE 341.description: An introduction to business financial management practices in Canada including investment decision, capital markets, and sources, uses and costs of capital over short, intermediate and long run situations.

FNCE 343.title: Personal Financial Management
FNCE 343.description: An introduction to personal financial management practices in Canada. Topics discussed may include goal setting, personal financial statements, the mathematics of personal finance, taxation, general and life insurance, retirement planning, investments, and estate planning. Completion of the course should enable students to properly prepare and plan their own financial future.

FNCE 443.title: Security Analysis and Investments
FNCE 443.description: A comprehensive exploration of security analysis and investments aimed at advancing understanding of financial markets, valuation techniques, and portfolio selection under various investment objectives. Topics such as capital allocation, diversification, security (stocks, bonds, derivatives) valuation, and market efficiency are covered.
FNCE 443.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Finance 317.

FNCE 445.title: Futures and Options
FNCE 445.description: A study of financial contracts for which the payoffs are contingent upon or derived from the value pre-specified underlying economic variables. Typical underlying variables include the spot price of a commodity and the price of a stock. These contracts are used extensively for hedging and speculative purposes. They also provide useful information about forecasts of the underlying economic variable in a process called "price discovery".
FNCE 445.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Finance 317 and 443.

FNCE 447.title: Capital Budgeting
FNCE 447.description: Capital investment policies, real options, required rate of return calculation, tax factors, risk analysis, buy versus lease, abandonment considerations.
FNCE 447.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Finance 317 and 451.

FNCE 449.title: Trading and Market Data Management
FNCE 449.description: Introduction to accessing data feeds as they are used by professional financial market traders and analysts. Data for stock, bond, futures and options markets, accounting statements and securities commission filings, as well as real-time and historical news events and analysis will be studied.
FNCE 449.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Finance 317 and consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

FNCE 451.title: Corporate Finance
FNCE 451.description: A deeper understanding of topics such as capital budgeting, capital structure, valuation, payout policy, and financing decisions.
FNCE 451.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Finance 317.

FNCE 461.title: International Finance
FNCE 461.description: A study of the forces affecting the financial environment of the corporate sector which appear to stem from requirements in the international sector. Balance-of-payments problems, exchange rates, currency risk hedging techniques, international reserve creations and transfers are some of the major elements studied.
FNCE 461.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Finance 317 and 443.

FNCE 463.title: Portfolio Theory and Management
FNCE 463.description: Analysis of the major aspects of the grouping of financial assets. Portfolio analysis and its application to portfolio management, capital market theory and the measurement of financial performance in the presence of risk.
FNCE 463.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Finance 317 and 443.

FNCE 465.title: Mergers and Acquisitions
FNCE 465.description: A study of the economic theory and practical issues around takeover and takeover defence strategies. Valuation issues, corporate restructuring, corporate governance, and methods of ensuring congruence between management and shareholder goals are also discussed.
FNCE 465.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Finance 317 and 451.

FNCE 467.title: Financial Risk Management
FNCE 467.description: A framework for evaluating financial risks and managing them with the use of financial securities including derivatives. Includes firm valuation with risk management, value-at-risk, testing financial models, optimal hedging strategies, energy risk management, market risk, static versus dynamic strategies, interest rate risk, credit risk and liquidity risk. Case analysis of financial disasters due to risk management failures.
FNCE 467.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Finance 317 and 443.

FNCE 469.title: UCeed Haskayne Student Fund
FNCE 469.description: A comprehensive hands-on course on the financing of early-stage companies.  Students will be responsible for evaluating investment opportunities, performing due diligence, working as a team to select investment recommendations, writing investment recommendation reports to an Investment Advisory Group, and participating in quarterly Investment Review Meetings.
FNCE 469.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

FNCE 471.title: The Calgary Portfolio Management Trust
FNCE 471.description: Hands-on application of portfolio management theory. Students report to a board as fiduciary fund managers their evaluation of risk-return trade-offs, security selection, financial reporting, and program management.
FNCE 471.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business Bachelor of Commerce program and Finance 317, and consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

FNCE 473.title: New Venture Finance
FNCE 473.description: Application of financial theory and analysis to the valuation and financing of new ventures. Course balances learning of concepts, development of analytical skills, and practice in decision making. Opportunity to apply learning to live projects.
FNCE 473.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Finance 317.

FNCE 475.title: Management of Financial Institutions
FNCE 475.description: Management of funds and their allocation among cash, primary reserves, loans and investments to provide liquidity and earnings. Services to depositors. Consideration of factors involved in the lending decision, pricing of services, branch location, etc. Strategies for maintaining profitability and liquidity in the face of changing monetary policy.
FNCE 475.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Finance 317 and 451.

FNCE 477.title: Personal Financial Management in Canada
FNCE 477.description: An introduction to personal financial management in Canada. Topics covered may include goal setting, personal financial statements analysis, the time value of money, the Canadian personal income tax system, taxation issues for small businesses, risk management, an introduction to investments, retirement planning and estate planning. Students will be expected to display a comprehensive knowledge of the tools necessary to complete their own personal financial plan.
FNCE 477.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 48 units including Finance 317.

FNCE 479.title: Corporate Risk Management
FNCE 479.description: Introduction to the management of operational and hazard risks based on contemporary financial theories, including risk identification, loss estimation, risk control, risk financing with insurance and other techniques, and enterprise risk management.
FNCE 479.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Finance 317.

FNCE 481.title: FinTech
FNCE 481.description: Links conventional finance theory to FinTech-new technological innovations and their applications in finance. Topics include blockchain, cryptocurrency, smart contracts, crowdfunding, ICOs, machine learning, and other current topics.
FNCE 481.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Finance 317.

FNCE 483.title: Financial Analysis and Valuation
FNCE 483.description: Cross-disciplinary course merges the principles of corporate financial valuation and advanced financial statement analysis. Course delivery focuses on cases and practical, evidenced-based applications, and features interaction with industry experts.
FNCE 483.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Finance 317.

FNCE 559.title: Selected Topics in Financial Management
FNCE 559.description: Investigation of selected topics related to financial management, emphasizing the application of financial management principles to actual problems in the corporate sector.
FNCE 559.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Finance 317. For certain topics, consent of the Haskayne School of Business will also be required.

FNCE 601.title: Managerial Finance
FNCE 601.description: The major decision-making areas confronting modern financial managers today. Provides a general understanding of financial markets and how they can be used for personal finance. Covers traditional subjects such as capital budgeting, net present value, risk/return, capital structure and dividend policy. Topical areas covered are IPOs, mergers and acquisitions, derivatives and options. The course is integrated with current events from the financial world.

FNCE 611.title: Advanced Topics in Financial Administration
FNCE 611.description: Classical and contemporary topics in the theory and practice of financial management including capital structure, cost of capital, real options valuation, bankruptcy costs and debt holder-equity holder conflicts, corporate financial strategy, managerial incentives and financial decisions, information conveyed by financial decisions, and mergers and acquisitions.
FNCE 611.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Finance 601.

Also known as: (formerly Finance 751)

FNCE 613.title: Investment and Portfolio Management
FNCE 613.description: Theory and analysis of investment and portfolio management decisions. Main topics include capital allocation, diversification, risk-assessment, and security (stocks and bonds) valuation.
FNCE 613.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Finance 601.

Also known as: (formerly Finance 759)

FNCE 617.title: Personal Financial Management in Canada
FNCE 617.description: Introduction to personal financial management in Canada. Goal setting, personal financial statements analysis, the time value of money, the Canadian personal income tax system, taxation issues for small businesses, risk management, an overview of investments, retirement planning and estate planning. Completion of a personal financial plan by the end of the course.
FNCE 617.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Finance 601.

Also known as: (formerly Finance 777)

FNCE 631.title: FinTech
FNCE 631.description: An understanding of fast-moving recent technological improvements in various industries and how they change the conventional thinking and trading in the banking and finance industry.

FNCE 645.title: Futures and Options
FNCE 645.description: After presenting basic definitions, institutional details, and strategies, a general theory of derivative pricing based on the principle of No Arbitrage will be developed. This theory will then be applied to the basic derivative contracts (futures, forwards, put options and call option) as well as exotic options. Using the binomial model, as well as the continuous time model of Black Scholes, hedging and replication will also be examined.
FNCE 645.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Finance 601.

Also known as: (formerly Finance 745)

FNCE 646.title: Sustainable Finance
FNCE 646.description: Focuses on sustainability issues and their relationship to financing of corporate investments, asset valuation and management, based on case studies, supplemented with mini-lectures and guest speakers.

FNCE 647.title: Capital Budgeting
FNCE 647.description: Capital investment policies, real options, required rate of return calculation, tax factors, risk analysis, buy versus lease, abandonment considerations.
FNCE 647.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Finance 601.

Also known as: (formerly Finance 755)

FNCE 649.title: International Finance
FNCE 649.description: A study of the international financial environment and the issues firms face when operating in this environment. Currency regimes, currency crises, balance of payments, exchange rate and interest rate parity conditions, supernational agencies, political risks, management of foreign exchange exposure are some of the major topics studied.
FNCE 649.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Finance 601.

Also known as: (formerly Finance 795)

FNCE 653.title: Problems in Financial Management
FNCE 653.description: The application of financial management principles to real-world problems in the corporate sector, including such areas as working capital management, project financing, debt vs. equity financing, payout policy and reorganization. The course is based on case studies and company presentations, supplemented with mini-lectures and guest speakers.
FNCE 653.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Finance 601.

Also known as: (formerly Finance 753)

FNCE 657.title: Management of Financial Institutions
FNCE 657.description: Financial intermediaries such as banking and brokerage. Explains the risks faced by institutions and the integration through modern financial markets. Covers issues such as lending, trading, securitization, deposit insurance and the regulatory environment. Concludes with modern bank management from the shareholder value point of view.
FNCE 657.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Finance 601.

Also known as: (formerly Finance 757)

FNCE 659.title: Mergers and Acquisitions
FNCE 659.description: A study of economic theory and practical issues around takeover strategies, and takeover defence strategies. Valuation issues, corporate restructuring, corporate governance, and methods of ensuring congruence between management and shareholder goals are also discussed.
FNCE 659.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Finance 601.

Also known as: (formerly Finance 765)

FNCE 663.title: New Venture Finance
FNCE 663.description: Problems of valuing and financing new ventures. Emphasis on financial theory, best practices and modelling of new ventures. Case studies and opportunities to develop detailed financial plan for live new venture.
FNCE 663.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Finance 601 or consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

FNCE 667.title: Financial Risk Management
FNCE 667.description: A framework for evaluating financial risks and managing them with the use of financial securities including derivatives. Includes firm valuation with risk management, value-at-risk, testing financial models, optimal hedging strategies, energy risk management, market risk, static versus dynamic strategies, interest rate risk, credit risk and liquidity risk. Case analysis of financial disasters due to risk management failures.
FNCE 667.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Finance 601.

Also known as: (formerly Finance 767)

FNCE 668.title: Seminar in Financial Management
FNCE 668.description:
Intensive study and discussion of current literature and research with respect to selected, advanced topics in Finance.

Also known as: (formerly Finance 789)

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

FNCE 669.title: UCeed Haskayne Student Fund
FNCE 669.description: A comprehensive hands-on course on the financing of early-stage companies.  Students will be responsible for evaluating investment opportunities, performing due diligence, working as a team to select investment recommendations, writing investment recommendation reports to an Investment Advisory Group, and participating in quarterly Investment Review Meetings.
FNCE 669.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

FNCE 672.title: Introduction to Finance
FNCE 672.description: Covers the basic analytical tools and theoretical foundations for financial decisions. Topics include: financial markets and instruments, time value of money, valuation of assets and projects under certainty and uncertainty, corporate financing policy and financial risk management.
FNCE 672.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Management program.

FNCE 674.title: Special Topics in Finance
FNCE 674.description: Introduction to modern financial tools which may include: entrepreneurial finance, investment management, financial institutions, mergers and acquisitions, capital raising and investment banking. Some of the sub-topics will include: blockchain and bitcoin, equity crowdfunding and peer-to-peer lending, robo-dash advisors, big data in finance and early-stage financing.
FNCE 674.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Management program.

FNCE 797.title: Advanced Seminar in Finance
FNCE 797.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

FNCE 799.07.title: Topics in Asset Pricing and Corporate Finance

FREN 209.title: Beginners' French I
FREN 209.description:
Basic elements of the French language, including training in comprehension, speaking, reading and writing of French.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for French 209 and any of 20, 30, or 31 will not be allowed

Notes: See 4.59 Placement in Language Courses.

FREN 213.title: Intermediate French
FREN 213.description: Development of abilities in spoken and written French. Review of French grammar along with extensive oral and written practice.
FREN 213.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): One of French 211, 30, or N30.

FREN 225.title: La Grammaire par les textes I
FREN 225.description: Apprentissage des structures grammaticales et logiques du franais contemporain avec lectures de morceaux choisis de textes de la francophonie mondiale.
FREN 225.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Prrequis: French 30N ou 30S ou 31 (ou quivalents), ou French Language Arts 30, ou French 213 ou autorisation du Dpartement.

FREN 227.title: La Grammaire par les textes II
FREN 227.description: Suite du cours French 225 et mise en pratique des structures acquises.
FREN 227.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 
Prrequis: French 225 ou autorisation du Dpartement.

FREN 291.title: Francophonie: langue et culture I
FREN 291.description: tude de la langue et de la culture des pays francophones, y compris la France, le Canada et les pays de l'Afrique, de l'Asie et des Carabes. Introduction aux sources et aux outils de recherche ncessaires pour cette tude et pour la production de travaux crits et oraux.
FREN 291.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Prrequis: French 30N ou 30S ou 31 (ou quivalents), ou French Language Arts 30, ou French 213.

FREN 329.title: Expression crite et orale
FREN 329.description: Grammaire avance. Perfectionnement de techniques d'expression crite et orale. Introduction  la recherche.

FREN 339.title: Concepts littraires
FREN 339.description: Concepts fondamentaux de l'analyse littraire. L'accent sera plac principalement sur les traditions littraires des pays francophones. Initiation  l'utilisation de sources bibliographiques particulires  l'tude de la littrature de langue franaise.
FREN 339.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Prrequis: French 227 ou autorisation du Dpartement.

FREN 343.title: Cinma de langue franaise
FREN 343.description: Introduction  l'analyse de films en franais.

FREN 353.title: Histoire littraire
FREN 353.description: Aperu chronologique des priodes, mouvements et coles des littratures de langue franaise, accompagn d'tudes de textes.
FREN 353.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Prrequis: French 227 ou autorisation du Dpartement.

Also known as: (Anciennement French 359)

FREN 369.title: Introduction  la linguistique franaise
FREN 369.description: Initiation  l'approche scientifique (objective et systmatique) du langage humain. Fonctions du langage et rle des linguistes. Concepts de base de la linguistique: langage, langue, parole; synchronie vs diachronie; signifiant vs signifi; paradigmatique vs syntagmatique; double articulation; phonmes, monmes. Diffrents domaines de la linguistique.
FREN 369.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Prrequis: French 227 ou autorisation du Dpartement.

FREN 391.title: Francophonie: Langue et Culture II
FREN 391.description: tude de la langue franaise et de la culture des pays de la francophonie: France, Canada, pays d'Afrique, des Carabes et d'Asie. Recherche documentaire et production de textes crits.

FREN 393.title: Thmatiques en franais professionnel
FREN 393.description: Cours de langue franaise sur objectifs spcifiques et  vise professionnelle. Idal pour les domaines aussi varis que les affaires, le tourisme, le droit, la mdecine, les sciences, les relations internationales, la traduction, etc. Le format et le contenu peuvent varier d'une anne  l'autre.
FREN 393.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Prrequis: French 225 or 291.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

FREN 399.title: Thmatiques en langue, littrature et culture
FREN 399.description: tude des aspects de la langue franaise, de la littrature et de la culture. Les supports utiliss incluent les textes authentiques, la BD, la chanson, les media, etc. Exemples de sujets traits: le monde francophone, l'histoire de la langue franaise, etc. Le format et le contenu peuvent varier d'une anne  l'autre.
FREN 399.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Prrequis: French 227.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

FREN 411.title: Thmatiques en littrature au fil de l'histoire
FREN 411.description: Panoramas des littratures de langue franaise suivant un axe longitudinal priodis par sicles, sur lequel se dploient les mcanismes de l'histoire. Le format et le contenu peuvent varier d'une anne  l'autre.
FREN 411.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Prrequis: French 329, plus 339, 6 autres units de franais de niveau 300.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

FREN 412.title: Thmatiques littraires et culturelles
FREN 412.description: tude thmatique de productions littraires et culturelles de langue franaise. Le format et le contenu peuvent varier d'une anne  l'autre.
FREN 412.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Prrequis: French 329, plus 339, 6 autres units de franais de niveau 300.

FREN 413.title: Thmatiques en expression orale avance
FREN 413.description: Les arts du langage: dire, crire et s'exprimer en langue franaise. Le format et le contenu peuvent varier d'une anne  l'autre.
FREN 413.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Prrequis: French 329, plus 339, 6 autres units de franais de niveau 300.

FREN 499.title: Thmatiques en langue, littrature et culture II
FREN 499.description: tude des aspects de la langue franaise, de la littrature et de la culture. Les thmes de ce cours seront abords  l'aide de mthodes novatrices.
FREN 499.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Prrequis: French 329, plus 6 autres units puises dans les cours du niveau 300 qui portent l'tiquette French.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

FREN 501.title: Thmatiques spcialises de littratures franaise et francophone
FREN 501.description: Sminaire sur des questions ayant trait aux littratures de langue franaise : France, Canada francophone et francophonie internationale. Le format et le contenu peuvent varier d'une anne  l'autre.
FREN 501.prerequisitesText:

FREN 511.title: Thmatiques spcialises en approches thoriques et critiques
FREN 511.description: Prsentation de certaines thories contemporaines qui ont cours en tudes littraires et culturelles. Le format et le contenu peuvent varier d'une anne  l'autre.
FREN 511.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Prrequis: 9 units dans les cours du niveau 400 qui portent l'tiquette French.

FREN 579.title: Thmatiques spcialises de linguistique franaise
FREN 579.description: Sminaire sur des sujets avancs dans le domaine de la linguistique franaise. Le format et le contenu peuvent varier d'une anne  l'autre.
FREN 579.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Prrequis: 9 units puises dans les cours du niveau 400 qui portent l'tiquette French.

FREN 598.title: Mmoire de baccalaurat spcialis
FREN 598.description: Aprs consultation troite avec un des professeurs de la Division d'tudes franaises et francophones, chaque tudiant(e) rdigera un mmoire, comportant une cinquantaine de pages, sur un sujet qui le/la passionne. Ce sujet doit tre approuv par la Division.
FREN 598.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Prrequis: 9 units puises dans les cours du niveau 400 qui portent l'tiquette French, acceptation dans le programme du baccalaurat spcialis (Honours) et autorisation de la Division d'tudes franaises et francophones.

FREN 599.title: Thmatiques spcialises de langue, littrature ou culture
FREN 599.description: Questions d'actualit ayant trait  la langue,  la littrature ou  la culture au sens large. Exemples de sujets traits: l'histoire des ides, l'autobiographie, l'criture des femmes de langue franaise, le crole dans les crits de langue franaise, etc. Le format et le contenu peuvent varier d'une anne  l'autre.
FREN 599.prerequisitesText:

FREN 489.01.description: tude des diffrents aspects de la langue franaise. Mthodes d'analyse et de description. Le format et le contenu peuvent varier d'une anne  l'autre.
