GREK 602.01.title: Ancient Greek I
GREK 602.01.description: Introduction to grammar, vocabulary and translation skills.
GREK 602.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Greek 602.01 must be taken before Greek 602.02.

GREK 602.02.title: Ancient Greek II
GREK 602.02.description: Introduction to grammar, vocabulary and translation skills.
GREK 602.02.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Greek 602.01 must be taken before Greek 602.02.

GRST 205.title: Introduction to Greece and Rome
GRST 205.description: Introduction to the world of ancient Greece and Rome and to how we study these cultures. Emphases may vary according to the instructor's expertise.

GRST 209.title: Classical Mythology & Literature
GRST 209.description: An introduction to Greek and Roman myths as presented in classical literature and art, and to their cultural context.

GRST 211.title: Technical Terms of Medicine and the Life Sciences
GRST 211.description: The Greek and Latin elements of modern medical and life-sciences terminology, with a brief introduction to their history and cultural background.

GRST 305.title: (RELS 305)Greek Religion
GRST 305.description: A survey of religious beliefs and practices in the pre-Christian Greek world.
GRST 305.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Greek and Roman Studies 205, 209, Religious Studies 201, 205, 273.

Also known as: (Religious Studies 305)

GRST 306.title: Roman Religion
GRST 306.description: A survey of religious beliefs and practices in the pre-Christian Roman world.
GRST 306.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Greek and Roman Studies 205, 209, Religious Studies 201, 205, 273.

GRST 309.title: Comparative Mythology
GRST 309.description: An examination of Greek and Roman myths in comparison with myths of other cultures and societies.

GRST 311.title: Sport in Ancient Greece and Rome
GRST 311.description: A survey of sports practised in Greece and Rome and the role of sport as a cultural, political and historical phenomenon.

GRST 313.title: The Ancient Novel & its Predecessors
GRST 313.description: A surfey of ancient Greek and Roman 'novels' or romances, with reference to their roots in epic poetry and New Comedy.

GRST 315.title: Sexuality and Gender in Pre-Modern Mediterranean Society
GRST 315.description: Exploring sexuality and gender in pre-modern Mediterranean societies such as ancient Greece, ancient Rome, Spain, and Byzantium.

GRST 317.title: Humorous Prose:  From Rome to the Renaissance
GRST 317.description: A survey of ancient, medieval and Renaissance humorous prose, with reference to their roots in classical literature.

GRST 321.title: Ancient Technology
GRST 321.description: A survey of major technologies in antiquity (metallurgy, agriculture, hydraulics, pottery, textiles, transportation, writing, construction) with special emphasis on the technological achievements of the Bronze Age and the cultures of Greece and Rome.

GRST 323.title: Ancient Medicine and the Mind
GRST 323.description: A survey of ancient science and medicine, with special emphasis on early conceptions of the human mind, thought and knowledge.

GRST 325.title: Greek Art And Architecture
GRST 325.description: A survey of Greek art and architecture from the Bronze Age to the Hellenistic period.

GRST 327.title: Roman Art And Architecture
GRST 327.description: A survey of Roman art and architecture from the Etruscans to the beginning of the Christian Empire.

GRST 337.title: Early Greece
GRST 337.description: Early Greece from the late Bronze Age to the Persian Wars.

GRST 339.title: History Of Classical Greece
GRST 339.description: History of the Greek world from the Persian Wars to the conquests of Alexander the Great.

GRST 341.title: Rome's Imperial Republic
GRST 341.description: Exploring the history of the Roman Republic up to 30 BCE, and its imperialistic expansion in the ancient Mediterranean.

GRST 345.title: The Roman Empire
GRST 345.description: Exploring the history of the Roman Empire, starting from the reign of Augustus.

GRST 347.title: Late Antiquity
GRST 347.description: History of the Late Antique world between the third and seventh centuries CE.

GRST 355.title: Warriors and Love: Greek Literature in Translation
GRST 355.description: An introduction to Greek literature from Homer to the Hellenistic Period.

GRST 357.title: Myths, Slaves and Heroes: Roman Literature in Translation
GRST 357.description: An introduction to Roman literature from its beginnings to the 2nd century CE.

GRST 401.title: Topics in Sexuality and Gender in Pre-Modern Mediterranean Society
GRST 401.description:
Advanced study of sexuality and gender in pre-modern Mediterranean societies such as ancient Greece, ancient Rome, Spain, and Byanztium. Topics may vary from term-to-term.

GRST 423.description:
Topics will reflect developments in current research.

GRST 425.title: Topics: Greeks, Romans and Other Cultures
GRST 425.description:
Topics will reflect developments in current research.

GRST 431.title: Studies In Ancient Myths
GRST 431.description: Studies in the nature and functions of myth in ancient Greek and Roman culture and society. Topics will reflect developments in current research, will vary from session to session, and will be announced in advance.

GRST 432.title: Pompeii
GRST 432.description:
Advanced study of Pompeii's archaeological remains from the pre-Roman period to the tragic eruption of Vesuvius in 79.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Greek and Roman Studies 432 and 447.36 will not be allowed.

GRST 433.title: Topics in Greek and Roman Religion, Intellectual and Cultural History
GRST 433.description:
Topics will reflect developments in current research.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

GRST 434.title: Roman Comic Drama
GRST 434.description:
A close reading of selected Roman comic plays, with discussion of their staging, performance, social contexts, and legacy.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Greek and Roman Studies 434 and Greek and Roman Studies 457.04 will not be allowed.

GRST 435.title: Julius Caesar
GRST 435.description:
A detailed examination of the life of Julius Caesar and of his legacy in Roman, post-Roman, and modern contexts.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Greek and Roman Studies 435 and 415.3 (Julius Caesar) will not be allowed.

GRST 436.title: Augustan Rome
GRST 436.description:
A detailed examination of the dramatic transformation of Rome during the lifetime of its first emperor, Octavian Augustus.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Greek and Roman Studies 436 and 417.4 (Augustan Rome) will not be allowed.

GRST 445.title: Topics in Greek Art and Archaeology
GRST 445.description:
Topics will reflect developments in current research.

GRST 447.title: Topics in Roman Art and Archaeology
GRST 447.description:
Topics will reflect developments in current research.

GRST 455.title: Topics in Greek Literature in Translation
GRST 455.description:
Topics will reflect developments in current research.

GRST 457.title: Topics in Latin Literature in Translation
GRST 457.description:
Topics will reflect developments in current research.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

GRST 459.title: Ancient Greece & Rome on Film
GRST 459.description:
The reception of ancient Greek and Roman mythology and history through selected films.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

GRST 483.title: Practicum
GRST 483.description: Provides students with program-related experiential learning through practical activities such as teaching, editing, publishing, translating, performances, exhibitions, museum work, conferences, information and website development, and campus, school and community programs.
GRST 483.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

GRST 491.title: Field Work
GRST 491.description: Provides credit, when transfer credit is not available, for a half-course equivalent of program-related study or field work in Europe or the Mediterranean area. Preliminary readings and a substantial report are normally required.

GRST 494.title: Field Work
GRST 494.description: Similar to Greek and Roman Studies 491 but provides a full-course credit for appropriate projects.
GRST 494.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

GRST 499.title: Ancient & Mdv'l Historiography
GRST 499.description:
Topics will include the analyses of the methods, sources, and key themes of major ancient and medieval historians.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

GRST 501.title: Majors' Special Topic
GRST 501.description: Interdisciplinary, experiential, and comprehensive course to link knowledge and skills learned throughout the student's Greek and Roman studies.
GRST 501.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to one of Greek and Roman Studies or Ancient and Medieval History majors and completion of 90 units.

GRST 504.title: Honours Thesis
GRST 504.description: The Honours essay for Honours students in their final year.
GRST 504.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Honours programs in Greek and Roman Studies or Ancient and Medieval History and completion of 90 units and consent of the Department.

Also known as: (formerly Greek and Roman Studies 503)

GRST 525.title: Advanced Topics in Greek and Roman Studies
GRST 525.description: Research topics in Greek and Roman history, literature, art, and archaeology. Seminar discussions will require a high level of student participation.
GRST 525.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Greek and Roman Studies or Ancient and Medieval History majors and completion of 90 units.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

GRST 530.title: Advanced Topics in Advanced Material Culture
GRST 530.description: Developing specialized skills for studying ancient material culture, such as inscriptions, coins, artefacts, and art.
GRST 530.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Greek and Roman Studies or Ancient and Medieval History major and completion of 90 units.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

GRST 551.title: Directed Research
GRST 551.description: Qualified students will undertake supervised research projects individually or in small groups.
GRST 551.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

GRST 651.title: Directed Studies
GRST 651.description: Qualified students will undertake supervised research projects individually or in small groups.
GRST 651.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

GSXS 201.title: Talking Gender and Sexuality
GSXS 201.description:
An interdisciplinary and intersectional examination of the social and cultural constructions of gender and sexuality. Uses a series of case studies involving historical events and current affairs to discuss how ideas about gender and sexual identity shape our social systems, cultural expression, and political values. The Canadian context is emphasized. 

Also known as: (formerly Women's Studies 201)

GSXS 303.title: Topics in Feminism
GSXS 303.description:
Explores key issues in feminist theory and activism, including relevant related issues in gender, sexuality, race and others. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT 

Also known as: (formerly Women's Studies 303)

GSXS 305.title: Topics in Gender and Sexuality
GSXS 305.description:
Explores key issues in gender and sexuality studies. 

Also known as: (formerly Women's Studies 305)

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

GSXS 311.title: Theorizing Gender and Sexuality
GSXS 311.description:
Explores contemporary approaches to theorizing gender and sexuality, with attention to their historical bases. Includes consideration of feminist, queer, trans, and intersectional theories. 

Also known as: (formerly Women's Studies 311)

GSXS 315.title: Methods for Gender and Sexuality Research
GSXS 315.description:
Explores the scholarly and political implications of engaging in research on gender and sexuality by examining key feminist, queer, trans, and intersectional methods. 

Also known as: (formerly Women's Studies 315)

GSXS 401.title: Special Topics in Feminist, Gender, and Sexuality Studies
GSXS 401.description: An in-depth exploration of a specific area of research interest in feminist, gender or sexuality studies.
GSXS 401.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units of courses labelled Women's Studies or Gender and Sexuality Studies. 

Also known as: (formerly Women's Studies 401)

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

GSXS 405.title: Praxis Seminar
GSXS 405.description: Reflection upon best practices and theoretical paradigms for feminist, gender, and sexuality activism. Activist/volunteer work, outside of class-time, will be required.
GSXS 405.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units of courses labelled Women's Studies or Gender and Sexuality Studies. 

Also known as: (formerly Women's Studies 405)

GSXS 411.title: Special Topics in Theory
GSXS 411.description: In-depth study of a specific approach to theorizing gender and sexuality.
GSXS 411.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Women's Studies 311 or Gender and Sexuality Studies 311.

Also known as: (formerly Women's Studies 411)

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

GSXS 415.title: Special Topics in Research Methods
GSXS 415.description: In-depth study of specific group research methods used in feminist, gender, and/or sexuality studies.
GSXS 415.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Women's Studies 315 or Gender and Sexuality Studies 315.

Also known as: (formerly Women's Studies 415)

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

GSXS 420.title: Ecofeminism
GSXS 420.description: An immersive experience, both theoretical and experiential, of ecofeminist analyses.
GSXS 420.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units of course labelled Women's Studies or Gender and Sexuality Studies.

Antirequisitie(s): Credit for Gender and Sexuality Studies Women's Studies 420 and Women's Studies 303.02 will not be allowed.

Also known as: (formerly Women's Studies 420)

GSXS 501.title: Independent Research
GSXS 501.description: Supervised individual study of a special topic. Intended primarily for students in Gender and Sexuality Studies programs.
GSXS 501.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

Also known as: (formerly Women's Studies 501)

GSXS 503.title: Community Service Learning
GSXS 503.description: An opportunity for students to engage in activist work relating to feminist, gender, and sexuality studies, and to connect that work with important theoretical frameworks.
GSXS 503.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Women's Studies 201, 405 or Gender and Sexuality Studies 201, 405 and consent of the Department.

GSXS 590.title: Honours Thesis
GSXS 590.description: Supervised individual research and preparation of an Honours thesis.
GSXS 590.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Honours program in Gender and Sexuality Studies and consent of the Department. 

Also known as: (formerly Women's Studies 590)

HSOC 201.title: Introduction To Health & Society
HSOC 201.description: Introduction to public health, emphasizing the contributions of social research from several disciplinary traditions (anthropology, economics, epidemiology, geography, political science, psychology, and sociology). Students practice and refine several skill sets, including: library research, public speaking, teamwork, leadership and academic writing.

HSOC 301.title: Determinants of Health
HSOC 301.description: A broad-based, interdisciplinary overview of models of the determinants of health. Includes an analysis of evidence of the relative influence of environmental factors, health services, lifestyles and health behaviours, social and economic factors, biological predispositions, and the mechanisms involved in the societal uptake of various conceptions.

HSOC 311.title: Health Services and Health Systems
HSOC 311.description: Introduction to the Canadian health system, the health policy process, institutions and providers in the health system, health care insurance, financing and delivery of health care, population and public health, a systems approach to health in a national and international perspective

HSOC 401.title: Foundations of Social Science Method
HSOC 401.description: An examination of some philosophical principles underlying and debates involving methodology in the social sciences. Consideration will be given to features both common to the social sciences as well as to those which distinguish them. Where appropriate, applications to health phenomena will be emphasized.

HSOC 403.title: Advanced Topics in Social Determinants of Health
HSOC 403.description: Social determinants of health are key to understanding and intervening on health and disease in populations. This course builds on the understanding of the social determinants of health by exploring a few of these in greater depth. Topics will vary, buy may include racism, sexism and gender identity, Indigenous health inequities, or the built environment. Students will engage with research from a number of social science disciplines to explore the complexities and nuances that shape health inequities in a variety of environments in which people live and work. Case studies and contemporary events will be used to illustrate the interplay between a select few social determinants and health inequities each semester.
HSOC 403.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Health and Society 301 or Sociology 409 and admission to the Health and Society major or minor programs.

HSOC 408.title: Health Research Methods and Research Field Practicum
HSOC 408.description: An introduction to the research methods utilized in the Health Sciences. Students will begin to develop the knowledge and skills necessary to conduct research in the Health and Society field. The importance of research design, qualitative, quantitative and mixed methods and the theoretical constructs that inform these approaches will be emphasized.
HSOC 408.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Medical Science 308 with a minimum grade of "B-", and admission to the BHSc Honours program.

HSOC 591.title: Advanced Seminar in Health and Society
HSOC 591.description: An advanced seminar involving critical analysis of contemporary health issues. Topics vary from year-to-year, but are always drawn from the current academic literature, from the public policy arena, and/or from the popular media.
HSOC 591.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Health and Society 401, 408 and admission to the BHSc Honours Health and Society major.

HTST 200.title: Events and Ideas that Changed the World
HTST 200.description: Designed for non-history majors, this course introduces students to the historian's craft through a series of short lecture-based modules that focus on specific events, ideas, processes, or individuals that shaped the course of world history.

HTST 201.title: The History of Europe
HTST 201.description: Selected topics may include formation and breakdown of political structures:  cultural, social, and technological continuity and change; development of religious and secular belief systems; interactions among cultures.  Course content will vary each term.  Please consult the History Department for more specific information.

HTST 202.title: An Introduction to Military History
HTST 202.description: Significant events and themes in military history.

HTST 203.title: The World to 1500
HTST 203.description:
The development and rise of civilizations, their divergent and interacting patterns of belief, social and political organization and material and cultural life.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for History 203 and 301 will not be allowed.

HTST 204.title: The World, 1500-1800
HTST 204.description:
The political, economic, cultural, ecological and social connections among world regions.

Antirequisite(s):  Credit for both History 204 and 205 will not be allowed.

HTST 209.title: The History of China
HTST 209.description: A survey of thought in China from the cultural heroes to the present, with emphasis on philosophy, religion, and ideology.  Topics covered include Shang religion, Confucianism, Taoism, Mohism, minor schools of thought, Legalism, Buddhism, Neo-Confucianism, Qing textual studies, republican ideologies, nationalism, Marxism-Leninism Mao Zedong Thought, and late twentieth-century reformist movements.

HTST 211.title: Canada: Origins To 1867
HTST 211.description: An introduction to the dynamic themes in early Canadian history.  Special attention will be devoted to social, economic and political development, Indigenous-Settler relations and the settlement of the Maritimes and the Canadas, and the opening of the West.

HTST 213.title: Canada Since 1867
HTST 213.description: Themes in the development of the Canadian nation from Confederation to the present, with particular attention to federal-provincial relations, economic development, social movements and western political protest.

HTST 220.title: The Material Past: Medieval Worlds through Objects, Landscapes and Texts
HTST 220.description: Examines social, religious and intellectual systems of world cultures, ca. 400 CE to 1600 CE, through physical objects and spaces.

HTST 300.title: The Practice of History
HTST 300.description: Provides a grounding in the methods and practice of history.
HTST 300.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units in History, excluding History 200.

HTST 303.title: Great Explorations
HTST 303.description: The concept of exploration from the time of Columbus to the space voyages, based on the reading of primary sources. Topics include the idea of conquest, views of different races and religions, and myths and realities of explorers and discovered lands.

HTST 305.title: Slavery in the Americas
HTST 305.description:
History of the enslavement of Africans and their descendants in the New World from 1492 to 1888. Themes may include the slave trade, labor, culture and religion, resistance and rebellion, abolition, and slavery's legacy.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for History 305 and 207 will not be allowed.

HTST 307.title: The Contemporary World
HTST 307.description: The contemporary world from the nineteenth century era of industrialism and empire, through to twentieth century struggles of underdeveloped countries for independence. Focus on growing global interdependency and the rise and the erosion of western cultural, economic, and political hegemony.

HTST 308.title: Gender History
HTST 308.description: A global history of the construction of gender and sexual identities.  Examines how changing ideas about what it means to be male and female have influenced family structures, sexual mores, work life, military ideals, politics and culture.

HTST 312.title: History of Air Power
HTST 312.description:
An examination of the nature and development of air power across the world. Topics may include: technology; tactics; doctrine; the relationship between air power, weapons of mass destruction and precise attacks; the limits to air power and its role in war, peace, and deterrence.

(formerly History 486)

HTST 317.title: East Asia From 1800
HTST 317.description: The modern histories of China, Japan and Korea beginning with the Mid-Qing dynasty in China and the Late Tokugawa period in Japan.

HTST 320.title: The Early Middle Ages
HTST 320.description:
The rise of new states and cultures across the Barbarian West, Byzantium and the Middle East, ca. 400 CE to 1100 CE through objects, texts and spaces.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for History 320 and either 319 or 321 will not be allowed.

HTST 326.title: Late Middle Ages to the Early Modern Period
HTST 326.description:
Political, social, cultural, intellectual and religious developments that transformed Europe and the Middle East, from the thirteenth to the seventeenth centuries.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for History 326 and any of 321, 323 or 325 will not be allowed.

HTST 330.title: Death and Disorder: The History of Early Modern England
HTST 330.description:
An introduction to the history of early modern England with a focus on death and disorder.

Anti-requisite: Credit for History 330 and 332 or 336 will not be allowed.

HTST 333.title: The Age Of Totalitarianism
HTST 333.description: Europe from 1900 to the Cold War.  Emphasis will be placed on totalitarian regimes in Italy, Germany, and the Soviet Union; war and society in the two world wars; the Holocaust; and the Cold War.

HTST 337.title: Twentieth Century Canada
HTST 337.description: Explores major themes in the emergence of modern Canada, with emphasis on the rise of a national consciousness, military and diplomatic involvements, the role of the state, socio-economic developments and national unity.

HTST 338.title: Modern Britain 1714 To Present
HTST 338.description:
Modern Britain 1714 to Present
The Industrial Revolution; nationalism and imperialism; the rise of the middle and working classes; the social welfare state; emergence of modern British society, economy, politics, and constitution.

HTST 340.title: Ethnicity, Race and Immigration in Canada
HTST 340.description: Examines developments in and challenges to diversity in Canadafromtheeighteenth to twenty-firstcenturies with emphasis on ethnic and immigrant cultures in rural communities and urban centres.

HTST 341.title: History of Popular Culture in Canada, 1850-Present
HTST 341.description:
Selected themes in the historical development of popular culture in Canada. Topics include: leisure and recreation, sports and games, the arts, popular entertainment, travel and tourism, national heroes and icons, consumerism and the mass media.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for both History 341 and 449 will not be allowed

HTST 345.title: Canadian Indigenous History
HTST 345.description: Indigenous Canada, from the beginnings of contact with Europeans in the sixteenth century, to the present, with particular emphasis on Indigenous-Settler relations.

HTST 347.title: Western Canada
HTST 347.description: An exploration of Western Canadian history, including themes such as: the Indigenous peoples, European exploration, settlement, rural and urban society, social and political reform, the New West, and culture.

HTST 349.title: Canadian Military History
HTST 349.description: Survey of the history of the Canadian military in peace and war from 1867 to the present.  Emphasis will be placed on Canada's role in World War I and World War II and on the development of the Canadian military in the Cold War era.

HTST 354.title: Cities in Global History
HTST 354.description: History of the making of urban, landscapes in a global context. Topics may include the development of economic centres, urban technological and infrastructural innovations, and the complex relationships developing between the metropolis and its rural and wild hinterlands.

HTST 357.title: Wild West/Mild West?: Comparative History of the U.S. & Canadian Wests
HTST 357.description: The similarities and differences in the histories of the Canadian and U.S. Wests from the pre-colonial periods to the present.  Topics may include the place of frontier and the West in national historical narratives, myths, and imaginations; indigenous peoples; immigration and settlement; land policy and land use; and the social relationships and economies that characterize the U.S. and Canadian Wests.

HTST 359.title: The United States To 1877
HTST 359.description: A history of the United States from colonial settlement through the era of Reconstruction.

HTST 361.title: The United States Since 1877
HTST 361.description: A history of the American people since the era of Reconstruction.

HTST 365.title: Latin America Before Independence
HTST 365.description: The history of colonial Latin America with particular reference to political, social and economic themes such as race relations, imperial rivalries and the struggle for national independence.

HTST 367.title: Latin America Since Independence
HTST 367.description: A history of the Latin American nations since independence with special attention devoted to political change, economic dependency and modernization, social and economic revolution, and inter-American relations.

HTST 372.title: Ways of Knowing: Science, Technology, and Medicine
HTST 372.description:
A transnational examination of the relationships among these traditions in historical and cultural context. Topics may include: the scientific revolution; the early modern period; nineteenth-century technology and medicine; the emergence of the modern life sciences and neurosciences; changing scientific paradigms and research traditions.

Antirequisite(s): Not open to students with credit in History 371 and 373.

HTST 376.title: History of Death in Western Culture
HTST 376.description: Examines the social, cultural, political, intellectual and religious developments from the Roman Empire to the contemporary period that transformed western concepts of death.

HTST 381.title: Military History: The Era of Revolutionary War and Total War
HTST 381.description: Significant events and themes in military history from the early modern period to the end of the Second World War.

HTST 383.title: Military History: The Cold War Era and Beyond
HTST 383.description: Significant events and themes in military history from the Cold War through to recent post-Cold War history.

HTST 395.title: History of Energy: From Fire to Fossil Fuels and Beyond
HTST 395.description: Transnational examination of the sources and uses of energy through history and their social, political, economic, and environmental impacts.

HTST 398.title: Topics in History
HTST 398.description:
Exploration of select regional, thematic or methodological issues in history.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

HTST 402.title: Military History of Africa
HTST 402.description: Explores the history of warfare and military structures in Africa from earliest times to the present. Informed by what is often called the \"New Military History\", discussion takes place within the context of broader social, cultural, economic and political developments.

HTST 406.title: The Mongol World Empire
HTST 406.description: The rise of Chinggis Khaghan (Genghis Khan) in early thirteenth-century Eurasia, the growth and conquests of the Mongol world empire, and the individual khanates of Yuan dynasty China, the Golden Horde in Russia, the Il Khanate in the Middle East, and the Chagadai Khanate in Inner Asia.

HTST 408.title: The Global 1960s
HTST 408.description: Examines social, cultural, and political change in \"the long 1960s\" from a global perspective.

HTST 410.title: Topics in Great Cities of the World
HTST 410.description: An augmented experiential learning course where students integrate their own observations and experience with scholarly readings in a \"Great City\". The regional and theoretical focus of the class will vary with the subject city.

HTST 412.title: Russia and the Soviet Union
HTST 412.description: A short introduction to pre-nineteenth-century Russian history and a survey of the history of Russia and the Soviet Union in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, finishing with a brief examination of post-Soviet Russia.
HTST 412.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units in courses labelled History at the 300 level or Russian 317.

HTST 413.title: Modern Germany
HTST 413.description:
German political, social, and cultural history from the late nineteenth century to the present. Topics will include unification, both world wars, Nazism, the Holocaust, the division of Germany, society and politics in the Cold War, and reunification.

Antirequisite(s):  Credit for History 413 and 413.02 (Germany, ca. 1870 to the Present) will not be allowed.

HTST 416.title: The Holocaust
HTST 416.description:
A survey of the history of the Holocaust in its pan-European context. Highlights the central role of antisemitism and the Nazi regime's genocidal intentions towards Jews, takes a victim-centred approach and includes diversity of groups targeted by Nazi racial ideology.  

Anti-requisite: Credit for History 416 and 493.16 (The Holocaust) will not be allowed.

HTST 418.title: The Vikings
HTST 418.description:
Origins and impact of Viking raids in Europe, North America, and the Middle East from the eighth through eleventh centuries, using historical accounts, archeological reports, material culture, film and fiction.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for History 418 and History 493.13 (The Vikings) will not be allowed.

HTST 420.title: Early Medieval England, 500-1100
HTST 420.description: An examination of early medieval England from post-Roman settlement to the Viking incursions of the ninth century and the Norman Conquest. Investigation of events crucial to shaping many of the cultural, political, and religious patterns of English life that endured into the medieval and early modern periods.

HTST 422.title: Societies and Cultures in the Middle Ages
HTST 422.description: Explores the development and characteristics of Western medieval societies with regard to the social fabric, economic, religious, and intellectual life.

HTST 425.title: History of the Atlantic World
HTST 425.description: The history of Atlantic Ocean as a zone of contact, conflict, and cooperation between and among Europeans, Indigenous peoples of the Americas, and Africans, circa 1450-1800.

HTST 427.title: Ideas and Events that Shaped Modern Europe
HTST 427.description: Topics will vary to address major ideas and events that helped to shape modern Europe.

HTST 431.title: Canada During The World Wars
HTST 431.description: The nature, course and impact of Canada's involvement in the two world wars. Developments on both the home and battle fronts.

HTST 435.title: History of Religion in Canada
HTST 435.description: A historical analysis of the pluralistic character of Canadian religions. Themes will include missions, Indigenous religions, awakenings, revivalism and social reform, fundamentalism and modernism, secularization and belief.

HTST 437.title: Canadian Environmental History
HTST 437.description: Historical development of Canadian attitudes towards nature, from those of Indigenous people and first European settlers to those of the present day.

HTST 438.title: History of Women in Canadian Society
HTST 438.description:
Topics may include the role of women in the economy, politics, social reform, the law, health care, the domestic sphere, life course experiences, and culture.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for History 438 and 343 will not be allowed.

HTST 439.title: Topics in the Canadian West
HTST 439.description:
Thematic treatment of topics in Western Canadian history.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for History 439 and 441 will not be allowed.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

HTST 442.title: Activism and Protest in Canada, 1867-Present
HTST 442.description:
Examines cultures, ideas, and practices of activism and protest since Confederation. Topics include historical forms of political, ethnic, gender, religious, legal, and class-based meanings of equality and social justice.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for History 442 and 339 will not be allowed.

HTST 447.title: Northern Horizons: Subarctic and Arctic Canadian History
HTST 447.description:
Historical development of the region from the beginnings of European exploration to the present day. Themes include: the Indigenous peoples, Arctic exploration, Canadian sovereignty, and the politics of northern development.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for History 447 and 352 will not be allowed.

HTST 450.title: History of Social Policy in Canada
HTST 450.description: A historical analysis of the development of social policy in Canada from the colonial period to the present. Themes may include the relationship between citizens and government, changing perceptions on the role of the state, grassroots demands for government intervention, and the relationship between private and public programs.

HTST 452.title: Atlantic Piracy, 1500-1865
HTST 452.description:
Explores the origins, growth, and decline of piracy and other forms of non-state violence in the Atlantic Ocean and its environs between 1500 and 1865. 

Antirequisite(s) Credit for History 452 and 398.03 (Atlantic Piracy, 1500-1865) will not be allowed.

HTST 454.title: Topics in Indigenous History
HTST 454.description: Topics may include the political, economic, and social factors influencing Indigenous and Mtis development in Canada; Indigenous/settler relations in the United States; Inuit land claims in the Arctic.

HTST 458.title: The United States in the Era of Depression and WWII, 1900 to 1945
HTST 458.description: The history of the United States from the dawn of the twentieth century through World War II, a turbulent period of wars and economic depression at the end of which the U.S. had emerged as a global superpower. Major themes include the rise of liberal reform; the experience of the U.S. in two world wars; the interplay of race, class, and gender in shaping American identity; and the economics of boom and bust culminating in the Great Depression and wartime boom of the 1940s.

HTST 460.title: The United States Civil War Era
HTST 460.description: The political, economic and social history of the United States in the decades leading up to the Civil War, the military conflict itself and the aftermath of war.

HTST 462.title: United States Political History
HTST 462.description: Aspects of the history of American politics from the Revolution to the twentieth century. Emphasis on the process of governing; elections and party politics; legal and constitutional affairs.

HTST 463.title: United States, 1945 To Present
HTST 463.description: The development of a national consensus on the world at home and abroad and the breakdown of that consensus. Topics will include the Cold War, Korea and Vietnam; the social upheavals of the 1960s and 1970s, especially the Black revolution, the Feminist movement, the development of a Youth culture, and the evolution of the imperial presidency to the Watergate Crisis.

HTST 464.title: From Colonies to Nation: Making the United States
HTST 464.description: Explores the creation of the United States from its colonial origins through the Early National Period. Topics may include the political, military, diplomatic, legal, cultural and socio-economic challenges faced by the new nation.

HTST 467.title: Mexican History
HTST 467.description:
Themes of Mexican history from the founding of Spain's most important colony, New Spain, to the present.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for History 467 and 467.02 (Mexico:Modern Nation:1824-Present) will not be allowed.

HTST 471.title: The Military In Latin America
HTST 471.description: The history of warfare and the armed forces in Latin America from colonial times to the present. Emphasis upon modern wars, militarism, the rise of caudillos, and the impact of the military on society.

HTST 472.title: Latin American Revolutions
HTST 472.description: Thematic treatment of social revolutions in twentieth-century Latin America.

HTST 473.title: History of Crime and Criminal Justice in England
HTST 473.description: Crime and the development of the criminal courts and jurisdictions, the police, punishments, and correctional institutions, from medieval to modern times. Attention will be given to the relationship of criminality to moral attitudes and socio-economic conditions, and to the historic role of crime and punishment in local communities, society and the state.

HTST 476.title: A Cultural History of Biomedical Sciences
HTST 476.description:
Explores changing concepts about life, biology, and medicine from the European Renaissance to the twentieth century. Topics may include the rise of natural history, genetics, molecular biology, and neuroscience.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for History 476 and 477 will not be allowed.

HTST 483.title: World War I
HTST 483.description: An examination of the nature and course of the First World War (1914-1918), with an emphasis on the Western Front. Topics will include the historiography of the war, strategy and tactics, the impact of technology, and the effect of the war on the nations involved.

HTST 485.title: World War II
HTST 485.description: The nature, course and short-term results up to 1950 of the Second World War in its global dimensions. The political as well as the military side of the Allied/Axis conflict will be studied.

HTST 487.title: Brazilian History Since 1500
HTST 487.description: Economic development, political institutions, social and cultural trends, and the interaction between men and women and the environment.

HTST 488.title: Britain As Great Power, 1690-1970
HTST 488.description:
Great Britain as a Great Power, 1690-1970
A study of British military, diplomatic and imperial history between 1690 and 1970 with a focus on the roots of Britain's power.

HTST 490.title: Espionage and the State, 1939 to the Present
HTST 490.description:
Intelligence during the Second World War, the Cold War, and afterward. Changes in the role, importance and technology of attention will be assessed. The contribution of intelligence to political systems, international relations and military operations will be assessed.			

Antirequisite(s): Credit for History 490 and 489.02 (Espionage & State,1945 To Present) will not be allowed.

HTST 493.title: Intermediate Topics in History
HTST 493.description:
Selected topics in social, cultural, political, or military history. Previous topics have included the Vietnam War, the North American Petroleum Industry.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

HTST 494.title: Int'l History of Energy
HTST 494.description: Twentieth-century history of energy in an international context. Topics may include international relations and political economy focusing on governments, international institutions, and multinational corporations and the role of energy in international conflict and cooperation.

HTST 495.title: Film And History
HTST 495.description: Film as a historical document, in particular as a source of social and intellectual history. Topics include: the role of film at moments of decisive historical change; the content and dissemination of political ideologies and social values; film as a source of propaganda; changing attitudes to minority groups; preservation of historical detail.

HTST 496.title: Historical Methods and Philosophies of History
HTST 496.description: A seminar for honours students on the interrelationship between the philosophies of history and historical methodology.
HTST 496.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): History 300 and admission to Honours degree program.

HTST 511.title: Topics in Gender and Sexuality in History
HTST 511.description: An examination of gender theory and history with an emphasis on issues of sexuality. Topics and geographic concentrations will vary.
HTST 511.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): History 300.

Also known as: (formerly History 501)

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

HTST 517.title: Social & Political History of Modern Britain
HTST 517.description: Topics in social, cultural and political history in early modern and modern times: e.g., the rise of the gentry and the middle class, working class identity,  radical ideology and two-party politics.

HTST 518.title: Topics in Twentieth-Century German History
HTST 518.description: Topics may include: thematic explorations and/or comparisons of dictatorial regimes (Nazi Germany and the German Democratic Republic); the history of the GDR; the two Germanies during the Cold War; memory and memorialization in popular culture; the contested formation of a multicultural society; and social protest in the post-WWII period. For further information on specific topics to be offered in any year, consult the History Department.
HTST 518.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): History 300.

Also known as: (formerly History 508)

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

HTST 520.title: Canada & the First World War
HTST 520.description: Discussion topics will focus on the major themes in Canada's Great War military experience, including the Canadian Expeditionary Force's recruitment and training, leadership, tactical doctrine, and integration within the British Expeditionary Force, as well as developments in civil-military relations, conscription politics and the country's postwar military legacy.

HTST 521.title: Canadian Biography
HTST 521.description: A thematic approach to Canadian personalities, emphasizing the biographer's method and changing interpretations of major Canadian figures, e.g., the prime ministers, prominent women, radicals, prophets, scientists, explorers, entrepreneurs, journalists and artists.

HTST 526.title: The Canadian Military in the Second World War
HTST 526.description: Examination of the political parameters imposed by the Canadian government on the military, the quality of Canadian leadership, and the \"fit\" between British forms of military organization and the fighting quality of Canadian soldiers, sailors and aircrew during the Second World War.

HTST 528.title: Exchange, Trade, and Cultural Encounter in North America
HTST 528.description: The history of cross-cultural contact in North America from the late sixteenth through nineteenth centuries, examining cultures, economies, trading institutions and views of New and Old World people.

HTST 529.title: Topics in Indigenous History
HTST 529.description: A history of the Indigenous peoples of Canada: the First Nations, Inuit and Mtis.
HTST 529.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): History 300.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

HTST 530.title: Topics in Canadian Foreign and Defence Policy from 1919 to the Cold War Era
HTST 530.description: Selected topics in the history of Canadian foreign policy and defence policy from the end of World War I to the 1980's.
HTST 530.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): History 300 and one course in Canadian History. 

Also known as: (formerly History 527)

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

HTST 535.title: Topics in American History
HTST 535.description: Selected topics in the history of the United States from the colonial period to the present.
HTST 535.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): History 300 or consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

HTST 539.title: Oral History
HTST 539.description: Introduces students to the theory and practice of oral history. Topics include ethics, methodology, memory, and community-based research. Students will conduct oral histories as one of their assessments.

HTST 540.title: Topics in Medieval History
HTST 540.description: Selected topics in Medieval History. Subjects may include: the history of medieval families; collective and individual identities, the social fabric; economic, religious and intellectual life.
HTST 540.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): History 300.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

HTST 541.title: Topics in the History of Science
HTST 541.description: Selected aspects of the history of science, e.g., the scientific revolution, science and religion in the seventeenth century, history of scientific methods, studies of individual scientists such as Galileo, Boyle, Newton, or Darwin.
HTST 541.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): History 300.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

HTST 545.title: Topics in Military History
HTST 545.description: An examination of selected problems in modern military history. Topics may include: military theory; guerrilla warfare from the eighteenth century to the twentieth century; evolution of tactics in World War I; development of military medicine; innovation in European armies; colonial wars.
HTST 545.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): History 300 and 3 units from 349, 379, 381, 383, 431, 471, 481, 483, 485, 489, 491.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

HTST 546.title: Formation of Anglo-Saxon Kingdoms
HTST 546.description: The Anglo-Saxon period from the fifth through eleventh centuries, including invasion, the formation of kingdoms, conversion to Christianity, warfare and diplomacy, towns/trade, and West Saxon expansion under Alfred the Great.
HTST 546.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): History 300 and 3 units of History 319, 321, or Greek and Roman Studies 347.

HTST 547.title: Chinese Strategic Thought
HTST 547.description: The history of Chinese strategic thought from antiquity through modernity, with emphasis on the Seven Military Classics, Chinese military history, and recent scholarship on the extent of the connection between historical and modern Chinese strategic thought.

HTST 565.title: Slavery Lat Amer/Caribb:1492-1888
HTST 565.description: Themes may include the slave trade, plantation and urban slavery, resistance and rebellion, women, culture and religion, abolition, free people of colour in slave societies, and the post-abolition legacy.

HTST 569.title: Latin America & Outside World
HTST 569.description: The Latin American nations in world affairs with special reference to their intellectual, economic, and political relations with Europe, North America, Africa, and the Pacific Rim. Themes will be drawn from the sixteenth to the twentieth centuries.

HTST 573.title: Topics in African History
HTST 573.description: Selected topics in African history from pre-colonial times to the present. Topics may include the "Scramble for Africa", Africa and the World Wars, decolonization and African nationalism, and mass violence and genocide.
HTST 573.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): History 300.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

HTST 591.title: Directed Research
HTST 591.description: The analysis of historical problems and the use of primary sources.
HTST 591.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): History 300 and consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

HTST 593.title: Advanced Topics in History
HTST 593.description: Exploration of select regional, thematic, or methodological issues in history.
HTST 593.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): History 300.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

HTST 594.title: Topics in Legal History
HTST 594.description: An examination of issues in legal history. Topics and geographic concentrations will vary.

HTST 597.title: Honours Individual Study
HTST 597.description: Directed readings for Honours students in their third or fourth year.
HTST 597.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): History 300 and consent of the Department.

HTST 598.title: Honours Thesis
HTST 598.description: The Honours Thesis for Honours students in their fourth year.
HTST 598.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): History 300 and consent of the Department.

HTST 623.title: Topics in Canadian History
HTST 623.description:
An examination of crucial issues in Canada's political, economic, social and cultural history.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

HTST 639.title: Topics in History of Science
HTST 639.description:
Topics may include the scientific revolution, science and religion, and the reception of scientific ideas.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

HTST 641.title: Topics in Medieval or Early Modern European History

HTST 651.title: Research Essay I
HTST 651.description:
Provides course-based students an opportunity to propose their MRE projects to the other students, critique as a group their methods, sources and bibliographies, and present drafts of their projects for peer comment.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

HTST 653.title: Research Essay II
HTST 653.description: In consultation with their supervisor, the student completes an essay modelled on a scholarly research article, to be evaluated on use of primary sources, historiographical framing, and argumentation.

HTST 655.title: (STST 655)Classics Of Strategy
HTST 655.description:
Strategic thought from Sun Tzu to Clausewitz, Mahan to Corbett. Analyzes the writings of classic strategic thinkers, and then by way of case studies examines their theories as they pertain to military and political planners from the Peloponnesian War to the present.

Also known as: (Strategic Studies 655)

HTST 690.title: Historiography and the Theories of History
HTST 690.description: Historiography and the Theories of History

HTST 691.title: Conference Course in Special Topics
HTST 691.description:
Notes: Open only to graduate students.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

HTST 791.title: Conference Course in Special Topics (Advanced Level)
HTST 791.description:
Notes: Open only to graduate students.

HTST 795.description:
HTST795: H(3S-0)
Advanced Seminar in Historiographical Interpretations

HTST 397.01.title: African History
HTST 397.01.description: Antirequisite(s):  Students may not have credit for both History 397.01 and 309.

HTST 397.02.title: History of the Middle East
HTST 397.02.description: Antirequisite(s):  Students may not have credit for both History 397.02 and 390.

HTST 397.03.title: South Asian History
HTST 397.03.description: Antirequisite(s):  Students may not have credit for both History 397.03 and 403.

HTST 491.01.title: Diplomatic History: 1793-1918
HTST 491.01.description: A history of international relations and foreign policies of states in Europe and the world.

HTST 491.02.title: Diplomatic History Since 1919
HTST 491.02.description: A history of international relations and foreign policies of states in Europe and the world.

INDG 201.title: Introduction to Indigenous Studies
INDG 201.description: A mult-disciplinary, theoretical and empirical overview of the situations, perspectives and aspirations of selected indigenous peoples with a focus on the Canadian context.

INDG 303.title: Indigenous Ways of Knowing
INDG 303.description:
An introduction to various Indigenous peoples' ways of knowing (epistemology) with a special emphasis on the contextualization of knowledge-building. Deals with various aspects of building knowledge, such as listening, reflection, protocol, and experience; emphasis will normally be on local traditional knowledge.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Indigenous Studies 303 and either Social Work 553.30 or Social Work 553.33 will not be allowed.

Notes: Normally offered during Block Week. Field trip(s) and pre-term study are normally required. A supplementary fee may be assessed to cover additional costs associated with this course.

INDG 343.title: Indigenous Law in Canada
INDG 343.description: Examination of the special legal and constitutional principles, provisions and instruments that have an impact on Indigenous individuals, governments and organizations. Topics covered may include Indigenous legal traditions, Aboriginal law, fiduciary duties, the Royal Proclamation of 1763, the Indian Act, the 1982 Constitution, and pivotal court decisions.

INDG 345.title: Indigenous Research Ethics and Practice
INDG 345.description:
An examination of current research trends with, by, and for Indigenous peoples through the lens of Indigenous history, representation, activism, and self-determination.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Indigenous Studies 345 and 397.13 will not be allowed.

INDG 350.title: Introduction to Indigenous Art
INDG 350.description:
An introduction to Indigenous art that explores its application in both historical and contemporary ways of making. Technical approaches may include beading, quilling, or hide.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Indigenous Studies 350 and Art 365.03 will not be allowed.

Also known as: (Art 314)

INDG 351.title: Indigenous Relational Theory and Practice
INDG 351.description: An examination of the central concept of relationality in the field of Indigenous studies and its application to the building of good relations with humans, non-humans, lands, and waters.

INDG 395.title: Topics Indigenous Gender, Sexuality and Feminism
INDG 395.description:
Selected topics that engage the history, politics, and contemporary contexts of Indigenous feminisms, queer studies, two-spirit studies, maternity, and masculinities in Canada and throughout Indigenous North America.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

INDG 397.title: Topics in Canadian Indigenous Studies
INDG 397.description:
Selected themes in Canadian Indigenous studies.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

INDG 399.title: Topics in International Indigenous Studies
INDG 399.description:
Selected themes in International Indigenous studies. May focus on Indigenous peoples of only one country.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

INDG 400.title: Directed Research in International Indigenous Studies
INDG 400.description: Supervised study of a theme in the area of International Indigenous Studies.
INDG 400.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units in a course labelled Indigenous Studies at the 300 level.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

INDG 407.title: Comparative International Indigenous Communities
INDG 407.description: Social, economic, and political comparisons between selected Indigenous communities throughout the world.

INDG 415.title: Indigenous Ethics and Protocol
INDG 415.description: Covers applying Indigenous ways of knowing in a research context, Indigenous methodologies, and implementing relational research frames when collaborating with Indigenous peoples.
INDG 415.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Indigenous Studies 201 and an additional 3 units from the Core Courses in the Field of International Indigenous Studies.

INDG 492.title: (PSYC 492) Indigenous Psychology
INDG 492.description: An in-depth examination of research in psychology related to Indigenous populations, including the history of research, major topics, appropriate approaches to conducting research, and new directions.
INDG 492.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Psychology 200, 201, and admission to the International Indigenous Studies major.

Also known as: (Psychology 492)

INDG 493.title: Animal-Human Relationships
INDG 493.description: A study of the importance of animal roles in a blended approach to environmental sustainability. Topics may include decolonizing academic, bioresource, and environmental perspectives on animal-human relationships.
INDG 493.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Indigenous Studies 201 or 351.

INDG 494.title: International Indigenous Experiential Learning
INDG 494.description: Study Abroad course with a clear focus on Indigenous issues may be imported directly into an Indigenous Studies degree. Acceptance into the Study Abroad program may be included as an equivalent.

INDG 495.title: Treaty Matters, Then and Now
INDG 495.description: An examination of practices of treaty making and philosophies of treaty as a body of relational thought. Topics may include treaty history, including Treaty #7, politics, law, inter-Indigenous relations, and Indigenous-Settler relations.
INDG 495.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from courses constituting the Field of International Indigenous Studies.

INDG 496.title: Mtis Matters, Then and Now
INDG 496.description: A study of Mtis history and current affairs in the traditional Mtis homeland. Topics include Mtis law and court cases, identity, Mtis/First Nation relations and self-determination.
INDG 496.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from courses constituting the Field of International Indigenous Studies.

INDG 502.title: Advanced Topics in Canadian Indigenous Studies
INDG 502.description: Investigation of selected topics in Indigenous issues in Canada.
INDG 502.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 60 units, including 3 units in courses labelled Indigenous Studies at the 300 level or above.

INDG 503.title: Advanced Topics in International Indigenous Studies
INDG 503.description: In-depth investigation of selected topics in international Indigenous issues.
INDG 503.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 60 units, including 3 units in courses labelled Indigenous Studies at the 300 level.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

INDG 504.title: Advanced Seminar in Indigenous Gender Two-Spirit and Sexuality
INDG 504.description: An advanced seminar centering the multiplicity of Indigenous Gender/LGBTAIQ2S voices. Relationships framed as traditional, contemporary, and historical are discussed in the context of matriarchy, two-spirit, feminism, masculinity, health, and gender balance.

INDG 505.title: Advanced Seminar in International Indigenous Methodologies
INDG 505.description: An advanced seminar on critical and decolonized Indigenous methodologies. Topics may include health and wellbeing, Elder and Knowledge Keeper teachings, and Traditional Knowledge Systems.

INDG 507.title: Research Practicum
INDG 507.description: An advanced study of applied research conducted to provide solutions to real-world challenges. Built around experiential student projects that work with, by, and for Indigenous-focused organizations and/or Indigenous communities.

INDG 506.01.title: Blackfoot
INDG 506.01.description: An advanced study of how learning is done with the land and may be guided by Indigenous knowledge keepers. Material is offered from a variety of Nations' perspectives. May be held outside and/or off-campus.
INDG 506.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Indigenous Studies 201 and 3 units from Indigenous Studies 303 or 345.

INDG 506.02.title: Stoney Nakoda
INDG 506.02.description: An advanced study of how learning is done with the land and may be guided by Indigenous knowledge keepers. Material is offered from a variety of Nations' perspectives. May be held outside and/or off-campus.
INDG 506.02.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Indigenous Studies 201 and 3 units from Indigenous Studies 303 or 345.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

INDG 506.03.title: Tsuu T'ina
INDG 506.03.description: An advanced study of how learning is done with the land and may be guided by Indigenous knowledge keepers. Material is offered from a variety of Nations' perspectives. May be held outside and/or off-campus.
INDG 506.03.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Indigenous Studies 201 and 3 units from Indigenous Studies 303 or 345.

INDL 303.01.description: Continuation of Indigenous Languages 301, with special attention to grammatical structures and written materials.
INDL 303.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Indigenous Languages 301 and consent of the Linguistics Division of the School.

INDL 303.02.description: Continuation of Indigenous Languages 301, with special attention to grammatical structures and written materials.

INNO 321.title: Principles Of Innovation
INNO 321.description:
Innovation is a process through which knowledge and new ideas are applied to create new economic and social benefits. Students are introduced to definitions, contexts, language, dynamics, historical and contemporary examples, issues, aspects,  outcomes, pitfalls, and impacts of the innovation process from a multidisciplinary perspective. Literature on innovation is explored. Seeks to develop in students the intuitive and imaginative skills necessary for inventive processes, and to investigate the impact of the innovation process. Blend of face-to-face and web-based instruction. 

Notes: Open to students from all programs.

INNO 323.title: The Practice Of Innovation
INNO 323.description: Provides experience in the innovation process, to aid students to understand the nature of this creative process in different contexts, and to nurture innovative thinking. Hands-on project in multidisciplinary teams of students and professors. Student projects will take the form of case studies of and/or involvement in actual innovation processes in different contexts. Seeks to teach through experience and peer-based interaction the processes of invention. Session will end with an "innovation fair" of teams' presentations. Blend of face-to-face and web-based instruction.

INTE 606.title: Transformative Talent Graduate Internship I
INTE 606.description: Students registered full-time in a graduate program who undertake an approved Transformative Talent Internship will be registered in this course during all terms that coincide with the internship. This course cannot be used to substitute for other course requirements for a graduate degree program. This course is only available for students participating in an approved Transformative Talent Internship and is not available to students enrolled in programs with their own internship or co-op course.
INTE 606.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Faculty of Graduate Studies.

Note: each course represents 4 months of work experience.

INTE 630.03.title: Master of Engineering Graduate Internship III
INTE 630.03.description: Students registered in a course-based Master of Engineering program who undertake an approved full-time internship (of 21 hours/week or more) will be registered in this course during the term that coincides with the internship. This course cannot be used to substitute for other course requirements for a graduate degree program.
INTE 630.03.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to Master of Engineering Internship Program.      

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

Note: each course represents 4 months of work experience.

INTE 630.04.title: Master of Engineering Graduate Internship IV
INTE 630.04.description: Students registered in a course-based Master of Engineering program who undertake an approved full-time internship (of 21 hours/week or more) will be registered in this course during the term that coincides with the internship. This course cannot be used to substitute for other course requirements for a graduate degree program.
INTE 630.04.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to Master of Engineering Internship Program.      

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

Note: each course represents 4 months of work experience.

INTR 301.title: A Multidisciplinary Survey of International Relations
INTR 301.description: A survey of International Relations integrating the approaches applied in various Social Sciences disciplines.
INTR 301.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the International Relations program.

INTR 501.title: Advanced Seminar in International Relations
INTR 501.description: An integrative seminar on selected themes from the International Relations field.
INTR 501.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the International Relations program and completion of at least 60 units including International Relations 301.

INTR 597.title: Directed Study in International Relations
INTR 597.description: Study of a particular topic under the direct supervision of a faculty member.
INTR 597.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the International Relations program, completion of at least 60 units, and consent of the Program Co-ordinator.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

IPHE 501.title: Interprofessional Practice in Mental Health
IPHE 501.description: Students from different helping professions come together to examine selected issues of interprofessional practice in the area of mental health and co-occurring addictive disorders, focusing on the experience of mental illness, treatment alternatives, practice implications, advocacy and policy issues, and future challenges and change. Incorporates in-class and field experiences with consumers and families, employers and professionals, services and organizations.
IPHE 501.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): One of Community Rehabilitation 209, 435, Kinesiology 355, Nursing 303, 305, Psychology 203, 205, 3-units of courses labelled Social Work (SOWK).

Also known as: (Interprofessional Health Education 601)

IPHE 503.title: Interprofessional Practice in Addictions
IPHE 503.description: Students from different helping professions come together to examine aspects of addictions assessment, treatment and recovery and issues of co-occurring mental health disorders in an interprofessional context. Studies include the complex array of treatments, programs and supports available in a Canadian context, and critical examination of the ancillary issues of community care, and other support services that are required for successful recovery and relapse prevention for those with addictive disorders and co-occurring mental health issues.
IPHE 503.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): One of Community Rehabilitation 209, 435, Kinesiology 355, Nursing 303, 305, Psychology 203, 205, 3-units of courses labelled Social Work (SOWK).

Also known as: (Interprofessional Health Education 603)

IPHE 598.title: Selected Topics in Interprofessional Health Education
IPHE 598.description: Course topics focusing on interprofessional practice amongst health science professions.
IPHE 598.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Faculty.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

IPHE 601.title: Interprofessional Practice in Mental Health
IPHE 601.description: Inquiry based exposure to major areas of mental health practice and the impact of addictions. Consumer, families and professionals assist in teaching and field assignments.
IPHE 601.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of Instructor(s).

Also known as: (Interprofessional Health Education 501)

IPHE 603.title: Interprofessional Practice in Addictions
IPHE 603.description: Students from different helping professions come together to examine aspects of addictions assessment, treatment and recovery, and issues of co-occuring mental health disorders in an interprofessional context.  Studies include the complex array of treatments, programs and supports available in a Canadian context, and critical examination of the ancillary issues of community care, and other support services that are required for successful recovery and relapse prevention for those with addictive disorders and co-occurring mental health issues.
IPHE 603.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Instructor(s).

Also known as: (Interprofessional Health Education 503)

IPHE 605.title: Interprof App Assess,Diag, Treat Mntl Hlth Addict:Major Disorders Part A
IPHE 605.description: Complex facets of assessment and diagnosis (using DSM classification system) of depressive, anxiety, psychotic and alcohol disorders. Team investigation of treatment programs and supports available within a Canadian context.

IPHE 607.title: Personality Disorders and Special Populations - Part B
IPHE 607.description: Complex facets of assessment and diagnosis of personality disorders, developmental disorders, special populations and addictive disorders. Team investigation of treatment programs and supports available within a Canadian context.

IPHE 609.title: Psychiatric, Psychosocial &Recovery Approaches in Mental Health & Addictions
IPHE 609.description: Interprofessional approaches to culture, relationships, teams and roles in the delivery of mental health and addictions care.

IPHE 611.title: Special Topics in Interprofessional Mental Health Addictions
IPHE 611.description: Topics such as age or special populations, methods and systems will be added from existing faculty offerings or will be createdas needed through interfaculty collaboration.

ISEC 601.title: Applied Cryptography
ISEC 601.description: The basics of cryptographic algorithms and protocols including encryption and authentication algorithms and key establishment protocols. Security evaluation in computational and information theoretic settings, and attacks on cryptographic applications and systems.
ISEC 601.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Network Security, the Graduate Certificate in Data Privacy, or the Master of Information Security and Privacy.

ISEC 603.title: Network Security
ISEC 603.description: Review of cryptographic algorithms and protocols used in network security. Network security protocols. Network security architecture. Web and Internet security. Wireless security. Approaches and tools for network intrusion detection and prevention. Traffic analysis and privacy enhancing systems. Applications of artificial intelligence and data analytics. Network system virtualization.
ISEC 603.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Network Security or the Master of Information Security and Privacy.

ISEC 605.title: System and Application Security
ISEC 605.description: Operating systems security. Software vulnerabilities and their exploits. Malware. Computer system virtualization. Application-level security. Access control models. Identity and access management.
ISEC 605.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Software Security or the Master of Information Security and Privacy.

ISEC 611.title: Private Data Management
ISEC 611.description: Privacy issues in data collection, analysis and dissemination. Identify and mitigate threats to privacy in various data processing environments. Understand the scope of privacy issues and ethical/legal frameworks. Data anonymization protocols and their applicability.
ISEC 611.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Data Privacy or the Master of Information Security and Privacy.

ISEC 621.title: Ethical Hacking Laboratory
ISEC 621.description: Offensive security, including technical and social methods. Legal and ethical frameworks as well as best practices. Automation and tool use, and defensive techniques.
ISEC 621.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Network Security or the Master of Information Security and Privacy.

ISEC 623.title: Software Security Laboratory
ISEC 623.description: Practices and tools for preventing vulnerabilities in the software development life cycle, including threat modelling, secure coding idioms and secure design patterns, static analyzers for detecting vulnerabilities, fuzzing and other quality assurance practices.
ISEC 623.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Software Security or the Master of Information Security and Privacy.

ISEC 625.title: Mobile and Smart Device Security Laboratory
ISEC 625.description: Security architecture of common smartphone platforms and Internet-of-Things environments. Selected topics on threat modelling, penetration testing, and security-aware design for smartphones, home automation, wearables, vehicles and industrial control systems.
ISEC 625.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Software Security or the Master of Information Security and Privacy.

ISEC 631.title: Privacy by Design Laboratory
ISEC 631.description: Identification of privacy-critical components of large software systems. Design of privacy-focused systems. Privacy for data storage and compliance issues.
ISEC 631.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Data Privacy or the Master of Information Security and Privacy.

ISEC 641.title: Governance and Risk Management
ISEC 641.description: Information security strategy and its alignment with business goals. Business cases for information security investment. Legal and regulatory requirements. Roles and responsibilities in information security management. Security risk assessment and management.
ISEC 641.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Network Security, the Graduate Certificate in Software Security, or the Master of Information Security and Privacy.

ISEC 643.title: Policies, Standards and Programs
ISEC 643.description: Development of security and privacy policies. Policy compliance and enforcement in various legislative frameworks. Policy considerations for social engineering and insider attacks. Information security and privacy standards. Security/privacy awareness and training programs. Development of Privacy Impact Assessments.
ISEC 643.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Network Security, the Graduate Certificate in Software Security, the Graduate Certificate in Data Privacy or the Master of Information Security and Privacy.

ISEC 645.title: Incident Management and Forensics
ISEC 645.description: Design and implementation of process for identifying, analyzing and responding to information security incidents. Computer forensics. Organization and management of the incident response and forensics team. Tools and best practices.
ISEC 645.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Network Security, the Graduate Certificate in Software Security, or the Master of Information Security and Privacy.

ISEC 651.title: Topics in Security and Privacy
ISEC 651.description: Advanced topics in information security and privacy.
ISEC 651.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in in Network Security, the Graduate Certificate in Software Security, the Graduate Certificate in Data Privacy, or the Master of Information Security and Privacy.

Also known as: (formerly Information Security and Privacy 613)

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ISEC 681.title: Information Security and Privacy Capstone
ISEC 681.description: Integration of knowledge and skills by identifying and/or formulating and information security and privacy problem, and devising a solution informed by the latest research in computer science and information security and privacy. The final product of the capstone project will include a substantive, well-researched and professional document, and a presentation of findings.
ISEC 681.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Information Security and Privacy and consent of the Department.

ISEC 691.title: Information Security and Privacy Internship
ISEC 691.description: Information security and privacy internship at a business or organization.
ISEC 691.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Information Security and Privacy and consent of the Department.

ITAL 201.title: Beginners' Italian I
ITAL 201.description:
This course, designed for students with no previous knowledge of the language, provides training in the comprehension, speaking, reading and writing of Italian.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Italian 201 and Italian 30 will not be allowed.

Notes: Students must complete an online placement form before classes begin. For information, consult https://slllc.ucalgary.ca/placement.

ITAL 301.title: Second-Year Italian I
ITAL 301.description: An intensive course in reading, writing and oral practice.
ITAL 301.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Italian 203 or consent of the Department.

ITAL 303.title: Second-Year Italian II
ITAL 303.description: Further development of communication skills in Italian (listening, speaking, writing, reading), as well as the study of cultural issues in the Italian world with emphasis on reading.
ITAL 303.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Italian 301 or consent of the Department.

ITAL 305.title: Introduction To Textual Analysis
ITAL 305.description: Development of critical thinking and communicative skills through the analysis of selected literary and non literary texts.

ITAL 307.title: Communication
ITAL 307.description: Study of different types of communication (print and electronic media, correspondence, business). Analysis of relevant aspects of Italian contemporary life.

ITAL 309.title: Civilization: Culture and the Arts
ITAL 309.description: Aspects of Italian civilization and contemporary cultural issues in Italian Studies.
ITAL 309.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Italian 203 or consent of the Department.

ITAL 317.title: Topics in Italian Culture and Literature
ITAL 317.description:
A survey of Italian culture, inclusive of literary and non-literary texts, film, and popular culture. Topics such as Italian history and immigration, Italian cities, Italian food and fashion, and Italian Canadian literature and traditions, in Calgary and elsewhere are covered.

Notes: Taught in English.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ITAL 399.title: Topics in Italian Masterpieces: Film and Literature
ITAL 399.description:
Study of one or more Italian works of literature and film, focusing on Italian masterpieces that have had an influence on European culture as a whole. Students will read and analyze the work(s) in English translation, and place it in its historical, philosophical, social and political context.

Notes: Taught in English.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ITAL 401.title: Third-Year Italian I
