ITAL 401.description: A course in composition and conversation for advanced students in Italian. Selected readings from literary texts.
ITAL 401.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above.

ITAL 403.title: Third-Year Italian II
ITAL 403.description: Intensive study of Italian grammar with the goal of attaining greater proficiency in written and oral communication. Grammatical analysis, vocabulary enrichment and development of conversation skills dealing with cultural issues.
ITAL 403.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above.

ITAL 405.title: Selected Works in Italian Literature
ITAL 405.description: Introduction to Italian literature with particular emphasis on the novel and poetry.
ITAL 405.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ITAL 409.title: Italian Culture through Cinema
ITAL 409.description: Significant social, cultural and historical issues in Italian society through the medium of film.
ITAL 409.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above.

ITAL 499.title: Topics in Italian Studies I
ITAL 499.description: Selected topics in Italian language, literature or civilization.
ITAL 499.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ITAL 501.title: Interdisciplinary Study of Italian Culture
ITAL 501.description: Capstone project in Italian studies. Analytical discussion of selected topics each related to students' field of concentration.
ITAL 501.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above and consent of the instructor.

ITAL 502.title: Topics in Advanced Textual Analysis
ITAL 502.description: Discussion of selected topics in Italian language, literature or culture. Course designed to develop writing skills. Review of writing strategies, spelling, punctuation, expository and argumentative techniques, using various original sources taken from journalistic, scientific, and literary texts as well as from other media.
ITAL 502.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above.

ITAL 597.title: Directed Studies
ITAL 597.description: Directed studies for students in their third or fourth year. Qualified students will undertake research projects in their specified field of interest under the supervision of a faculty member.
ITAL 597.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ITAL 599.title: Topics in Italian Studies II
ITAL 599.description: A seminar course for advanced students.
ITAL 599.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

JPNS 201.title: Introduction to Japanese Popular Culture
JPNS 201.description:
An introduction to the major forms of popular visual and material culture from Japan in the 20th and 21st centuries.

Notes: Taught in English.

JPNS 205.title: Beginners' Japanese I
JPNS 205.description:
Basic concepts of modern Japanese. Reading and writing of characters, essentials of grammar, basic vocabulary, and oral drills on normal speech patterns.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Japanese 205 and Japanese 30 will not be allowed

Notes: Students must complete an online placement form before classes begin. For information, consult https://slllc.ucalgary.ca/placement.

JPNS 207.title: Beginners' Japanese II
JPNS 207.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Japanese 30 or Japanese 205 or consent of the Department.

JPNS 301.title: Continuing Japanese I
JPNS 301.description: Further acquisition of Japanese characters, and the development of conversational skills through reading and discussion of selected Japanese texts. Structural analysis of normal speech patterns. Preparation of written assignments. A continuation of Japanese 207.
JPNS 301.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Japanese 207 or consent of the Department.

JPNS 303.title: Continuing Japanese II
JPNS 303.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Japanese 301 or consent of the Department.

JPNS 310.title: Topics in Japanese Language in an Immersion Setting I
JPNS 310.description: Stresses oral skills and cultural understanding in an immersion setting. While the focus will be on speaking and aural comprehension, reading and writing will also be introduced.
JPNS 310.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Japanese 207 and consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

JPNS 312.title: Topics in Japanese Language in an Immersion Setting II
JPNS 312.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

JPNS 323.title: Critical Approaches to Manga and Anime
JPNS 323.description:
A critical introduction to Japanese manga (print comics) and anime (animation) in the 20th and 21st centuries.

Notes: Taught in English.

JPNS 325.title: Japanese Video Games and Gaming Culture
JPNS 325.description:
A critical introduction to the history, analysis, and social impact of video games from Japan and Japanese gaming culture worldwide.

Notes: Taught in English.

JPNS 327.title: Modern Japanese Literature in Translation
JPNS 327.description:
An introduction to the literature and literary history of modern Japan, with readings drawn from various literary genres, from 1868 to the present.

Notes: Taught in English.

JPNS 331.title: Intermediate Japanese I
JPNS 331.description: An intermediate course giving emphasis to both writing and oral skills. Some of the more difficult aspects of modern Japanese grammar will be studied.
JPNS 331.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Japanese 303 or consent of the Department.

JPNS 333.title: Intermediate Japanese II
JPNS 333.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Japanese 331 or consent of the Department.

JPNS 341.title: Intro To Japanese Literature
JPNS 341.description: Reading and discussion of selected works of modern Japanese literature.
JPNS 341.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Japanese 303 or consent of the Department.

JPNS 371.title: Intermediate Skills in Japanese Communication
JPNS 371.description: Targeted focus on further development of self-expression and communication skills through speaking and listening at an Intermediate level.
JPNS 371.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Japanese 301.

Antirequisite: Credit for Japanese 371 and any of 331, 333, 441 or 451 will not be allowed.

JPNS 373.title: Intermediate Skills in Japanese Writing
JPNS 373.description: Targeted focus on further development of productive (writing) skills for Japanese.
JPNS 373.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Japanese 301.

Antirequisite: Credit for Japanese 373 and any of 331, 333, 441 or 451 will not be allowed.

JPNS 423.title: Advanced Manga Studies
JPNS 423.description: Advanced study of manga (print comics) in the original Japanese supplemented with theories and methods in the study of East Asian visual and popular culture.

JPNS 441.title: Advanced Conversational Japanese
JPNS 441.description: Intensive development of Japanese oral communication skills through a variety of authentic materials.

JPNS 451.title: Japanese Through Texts
JPNS 451.description: Language practice and cultural analysis through the study of contemporary Japanese texts. Authentic material will be selected from documents and textbooks. Students will be able to improve their reading skills while enhancing their knowledge of Japanese culture.

JPNS 461.title: (CHIN 461)Japanese-Chinese Cultural Relations
JPNS 461.description: Discussion of cultural relations and influences between Japan and China. Topics may include cultural identities and cross-influences, literary and artistic traditions, and writing systems.

JPNS 471.title: Introduction to Classical Japanese
JPNS 471.description: Basic introduction to classical Japanese language, including core grammar structures, sample masterpieces, and handwriting.

JPNS 309.01.title: Wisdom, Imagination, and Creation
JPNS 309.01.description: Introduction to contemporary Japanese culture through research projects and life experience.
JPNS 309.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

JPNS 309.02.title: Longing, Memory, and Inheritance
JPNS 309.02.description: Introduction to contemporary Japanese culture through research projects and life experience.
JPNS 309.02.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

JPNS 317.01.title: Japanese Civilization
JPNS 317.01.description:
Distinctive features of Japanese civilization within the Asian context.

Notes: Taught in English.

JPNS 317.02.title: Japanese Cinema
JPNS 317.02.description:
Distinctive features of Japanese civilization within the Asian context.

Notes: Taught in English.

JPNS 317.03.title: Japanese Cultural History in the Present Day
JPNS 317.03.description:
Distinctive features of Japanese civilization within the Asian context.

Notes: Taught in English.

KNES 201.title: Activity: Essence and Experience
KNES 201.description: Participate in various activities and movement patterns and the study of the fundamental factors that influence the activities we choose and the way we move.

KNES 203.title: Activity: Health, Fitness, and Performance
KNES 203.description: Fundamentals of exercise physiology are used in a variety of theoretically supported activities to experience the benefits of exercise and an understanding of exercise prescription and evaluation.
KNES 203.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biology 30 or 212; and Chemistry 30 or 212.

KNES 213.title: Introduction to Research in Kinesiology
KNES 213.description: An introduction to research in kinesiology with an emphasis on understanding the research process, including basic statistical knowledge, and its relationship to critical thinking. Practical application of concepts through direct involvement in individual and group projects.
KNES 213.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biology 30 or 212; Chemistry 30 or 212; and Mathematics 30-1 or 212.

KNES 244.title: Sociology of Movement Cultures
KNES 244.description:
An introduction to sociological perspectives on movement cultures (e.g., sport, dance, physical education, exercise and fitness), with a particular focus on equity, diversity, and inclusion.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Kinesiology 244 and Sociology 399 will not be allowed.

KNES 251.title: Introduction to Human Motor Control and Learning
KNES 251.description: An introduction to principles underlying motor control and learning.

KNES 253.title: Introduction to Exercise and Sport Psychology
KNES 253.description: An introduction to the psycho-social concepts underlying an understanding of human behaviour in physical activity, sport, and health.

KNES 259.title: Human Anatomy and Physiology I
KNES 259.description: The instructional approach is a combination of systematic and regional anatomy and physiology with some surface anatomy and radiologic considerations. General cell physiology, bone anatomy, neurophysiology and muscular physiology, as well as skeletal structure, types of connective tissues, structure of joints and muscles of the axial and appendicular skeleton will be covered. Laboratories utilize human tissue materials, anatomical models, charts, and prosected cadavers and cadaver specimens.
KNES 259.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biology 30 or 212; Chemistry 30 or 212; and Mathematics 30-1 or 30-2 or 212.

KNES 260.title: Human Anatomy and Physiology II
KNES 260.description: The instructional approach is a combination of systematic and regional anatomy and physiology with some surface anatomy and radiologic considerations. Physiology and anatomy of the cardiovascular, pulmonary, endocrine, renal and gastrointestinal systems as well as anatomy of the reproductive and integumentary systems and special senses will be covered. Laboratories utilize human tissue materials, anatomical models, charts, and prosected cadavers and cadaver specimens.

KNES 263.title: Quantitative Biomechanics
KNES 263.description: Basic principles of force system analysis, impulse-momentum, work-energy and particle kinematics applied to biological structures, including extensive mathematical analyses.
KNES 263.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biology 30 or 212; Chemistry 30 or 212; and Mathematics 30-1 or 212.

KNES 303.title: Special Topics in Kinesiology
KNES 303.description: Topics may include, but are not limited to, studies in sport psychology, human physiology, biomechanics or leadership.
KNES 303.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): For certain topics consent of the Faculty of Kinesiology and/or specific course prerequisites will be required.

KNES 311.title: Leadership Foundations
KNES 311.description: Contemporary leadership best practices with a focus on physical activity, pedagogy and sport coaching. Linking leadership theory with critical reflection.
KNES 311.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Faculty of Kinesiology.

KNES 323.title: Integrative Human Physiology
KNES 323.description: This course builds upon fundamental principles of human systems physiology, with a focus on how the integration of these physiological systems provides the means by which our bodies maintain homeostasis from the systemic down to the cellular level.
KNES 323.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 260 and admission to the Faculty of Kinesiology.

KNES 331.title: Foundations of Coaching
KNES 331.description: The fundamental principles of creating an effective training environment for the developing athlete.
KNES 331.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 201 and admission to the Faculty of Kinesiology.

KNES 337.title: Introduction to Nutrition
KNES 337.description: Provides students with a basic understanding of the role of nutrition in health and fitness.

KNES 344.title: Gender, Sexuality, and Sport
KNES 344.description: Informed by feminist theoretical perspectives, exploring the different ways that sport functions to reproduce and challenge dominant ideas about gender and sexuality.
KNES 344.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 244, 245 or 303.44 (Found Socio-Cult Studies Sport) and admission to the Faculty of Kinesiology.

KNES 351.title: Foundations of Neural Control of Movement
KNES 351.description: An examination of the nervous system and its role in controlling movement. Emphasis is placed on understanding the basic anatomy and neurophysiology of the central and peripheral nervous systems. Topics include the properties of individual neurons and neural circuits that support human movement. This basic understanding is supplemented by discussion of neurological injuries, diseases and disorders that compromise human movement.

KNES 355.title: Human Growth and Development
KNES 355.description: The physiological, anatomical, emotional and social changes in human growth and development, with a view to the planning and selection of appropriate programs in physical education, sport, and dance.

KNES 363.title: Biomechanics of Biological Materials
KNES 363.description: Functional characteristics of muscle, bone, cartilage, tendon, ligament, and joints as they relate to movement and loading of the locomotor system.

KNES 365.title: Sensorimotor Neuroscience
KNES 365.description: An examination of how human movement is coordinated by the nervous system, beginning with a review of relevant neuroanatomy and neurophysiology. An emphasis is placed on contemporary scientific techniques throughout.

KNES 367.title: Adapted Physical Activity
KNES 367.description: An overview of neurodevelopmental conditions as it pertains to physical activity and physical literacy with support and modification considerations to provide effective physical activity engagement.
KNES 367.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 260 and admission to the Faculty of Kinesiology.

KNES 372.title: Foundations of Sport Medicine
KNES 372.description: An introduction to the common medical issues and injuries that affects the athlete related to sport and exercise.
KNES 372.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 260 and admission to the Faculty of Kinesiology.

KNES 373.title: Exercise Physiology
KNES 373.description: The physiology of muscular exercise, physical conditioning, and training. The course will cover aspects of the nervous, muscular, cardiovascular, and respiratory systems and also present the material in the context of the effects of exercise on an integrated system. Short- and long-term adaptations to exercise will be examined relative to health and human activity.
KNES 373.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 203, 213, 323 and admission to the Faculty of Kinesiology.

KNES 375.title: Tests and Measurements in Kinesiology
KNES 375.description: Establishment of tests, criteria for selection of tests, measurement devices used to evaluate physiological status, human growth, and skill levels in physical activity programs.
KNES 375.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 203 and 213 and admission to the Faculty of Kinesiology.

KNES 381.title: Computer Applications in Kinesiology
KNES 381.description: An introduction to the use of the computer in kinesiology which involves hands-on experiences with selected software packages.
KNES 381.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Faculty of Kinesiology.

KNES 395.title: Research Seminar II
KNES 395.description: Students attend, discuss, and critique a series of research seminars in the Human Performance Laboratory.
KNES 395.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 393.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

KNES 396.title: Research Seminar
KNES 396.description: Students attend, discuss, and critique a series of research seminars in the Human Performance Laboratory.
KNES 396.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 213, 263 and admission to the Faculty of Kinesiology.

KNES 397.title: Health and Exercise Psychology
KNES 397.description: An examination of psychological issues related to health, exercise, and physical activity.

KNES 399.title: Sport Psychology
KNES 399.description: An analysis of personality and social psychological variables affecting the athlete/coach in the context of sport.

KNES 402.title: Dance and Health Promotion
KNES 402.description: Evidence-informed lectures, as well as exposure to a range of dance experiences. Students will emerge with foundational skills in dance, and an ability to speak to the role of dance in health.

KNES 411.title: Advanced Leadership Practice
KNES 411.description: Students will advance their theoretical and practical understanding of effective leadership behaviors through experience, discussion, and systematic reflection. Learning is focused on developing self-awareness in relation to leadership practices and the capacity to facilitate leadership skills in others.

KNES 413.title: Motivation in Physical Activity, Exercise and Sport
KNES 413.description: Concepts related to motivation in physical activity, sport, and exercise settings. Antecedents, consequences, and processes of motivated behaviour are examined from theoretical, empirical, and applied perspectives.

KNES 420.title: Work Term in Kinesiology
KNES 420.description: Extensive unpaid work term focused on experiential learning in the field of kinesiology. Students must spend a total of 35-40 hours per week for 12-13 weeks in a workplace setting.
KNES 420.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 84 units and consent of the Faculty.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

KNES 431.title: The Art of Coaching
KNES 431.description: Advanced principles of the art of effective coaching.
KNES 431.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 331 and admission to the  Faculty of Kinesiology.

KNES 433.title: Health and Physical Activity
KNES 433.description: Exploration of the relationships between health, disease, and the benefits associated with physical activity and the various factors that can promote and maintain lifestyle change. Students will be required to complete a personal health report based on the following laboratory components: (1) blood lipid profile (a fasting blood draw), (2) nutritional record (dietary record analyzed), (3) health risk analysis (an online risk assessment) and risk factor concept (summary 1 - 3 with the inclusion of family/genetic background).

KNES 434.title: Race and Indigeneity in Movement Cultures
KNES 434.description: A critical socio-cultural and historical examination of race and Indigeneity in sport and physical culture.
KNES 434.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 344 and Admission to the Faculty of Kinesiology.

KNES 437.title: Advanced Nutrition
KNES 437.description: An examination of current nutritional strategies for sport performance and diet-related chronic diseases. Critical analysis of a wide variety of dietary supplements will be included.

KNES 441.title: Practicum A
KNES 441.description: Unpaid practicum placement focused on experiential learning in the field of Kinesiology. Students are required to complete 60 to 72 hours in a workplace setting, distributed evenly over the duration of the term.
KNES 441.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 60 units, admission to and consent of the Faculty of Kinesiology.

KNES 443.title: Practicum B
KNES 443.description: Unpaid practicum placement focused on experiential learning in the field of Kinesiology. Students are required to complete 60 to 72 hours in a workplace setting, distributed evenly over the duration of the term.
KNES 443.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 441 and consent of the Faculty.

KNES 444.title: Critical Perspectives on the Body
KNES 444.description: Critical considerations of the relationship between the body and historical, cultural, and political context.

KNES 445.title: Practicum C
KNES 445.description: aid practicum placement focused on experiential learning in the field of Kinesiology. Students are required to complete 60 to 72 hours in a workplace setting, distributed evenly over the duration of the term.
KNES 445.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 443 and consent of the Faculty.

KNES 451.title: Advanced Topics in Human Motor Control and Learning
KNES 451.description: A comprehensive examination of the nervous system and its role in learning and controlling movements. Topics include the properties of individual neurons and neural circuits and how their function is altered by motor learning. The course also covers contemporary methods and theories used to understand how humans learn and perform motor actions.

KNES 460.title: Laboratory Practicum: Anatomy
KNES 460.description: Detailed planning and anatomical dissection of human cadavers.
KNES 460.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 260, admission to and consent of the Faculty of Kinesiology.

KNES 463.title: Advanced Techniques in Biomechanics
KNES 463.description: Exploring basic concepts of analysis and modelling in biomechanics, including numerical implementation and solution.
KNES 463.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 363 and admission to the Faculty of Kinesiology.

KNES 464.title: Advanced Topics in Sensorimotor Neuroscience
KNES 464.description: Experience-based exploration of the methodologies applied in modern sensorimotor neuroscience research. Students will learn about cutting-edge techniques for stimulating and recording the nervous system, standard approaches for processing and analyzing this data, and how these methodologies fit within contemporary theories of motor control.

KNES 465.title: Adaptation to Environmental Stress
KNES 465.description:
Physiological effects of temperature and humidity fluctuations; principles of heat generation, conservation and transfer; acute and chronic effects of hypo and hyperbarometric pressures; special dietary considerations; and associated physio-psychological implications will be examined.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Kinesiology 323.

KNES 467.title: Sport Injury Prevention
KNES 467.description: Develop and advance sport injury prevention knowledge, with a focus on primary prevention, through critical engagement with current research and application of fundamental sport injury prevention strategies through experiential learning.

KNES 469.title: Topics in Sport Medicine
KNES 469.description: An examination of current medical topics in sport medicine as they relate to the athlete. The topics will include common medical problems and drugs in sport.

KNES 472.title: Sport Injury Rehabilitation
KNES 472.description: An introduction to the general principles of sport injury rehabilitation for kinesiology students.
KNES 472.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 372 and Admission to the Faculty of Kinesiology.

KNES 475.title: Physiology of Athletic Performance
KNES 475.description: The physiological factors and principles of training affecting performance will be reviewed and challenged on the scientific basis of experimental evidence.

KNES 478.title: Strength Training Science
KNES 478.description: Physiology of the neuromuscular system, the biomechanics of muscle strength and power, neuromuscular adaptations to resistance training, and the scientific basis for prescribing resistance training exercise. Fundamental knowledge on the science and practice of resistance training for health, performance and injury prevention.

KNES 479.title: Advanced Fitness Appraisal and Exercise Prescription
KNES 479.description: Advanced knowledge and skills necessary to assess physical fitness status of apparently healthy individuals, including cardiorespiratory fitness, muscular strength and endurance, body composition, and flexibility. Interpretation of fitness test results, development of appropriate exercise prescriptions, and communication skills necessary for effective counselling.
KNES 479.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 373 and admission to the Faculty of the Kinesiology.

KNES 485.title: Skeletal Muscle Properties
KNES 485.description: The structural organization, neural control, contractile consequences, and determinants of energy cost of contraction of skeletal muscle will be studied in detail.

KNES 486.title: Exercise and Brain Health
KNES 486.description: An in-depth examination of the effect of exercise on cognition and brain health across the lifespan, with a focus on understanding the potential underlying mechanisms.
KNES 486.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 323 and 355 and Admission to the Faculty of Kinesiology.

KNES 487.title: The Olympic Games
KNES 487.description: A critical analysis of the modern Olympic Games.

KNES 493.title: Epidemiology of Health and Physical Activity
KNES 493.description: An examination of physical activity/disease relationships through application of population-based methods including research design and interpretation of studies. The content will assist the student in identifying the quality and extent of research supporting the relationships between health, disease, and habitual physical activity and fitness.

KNES 495.title: Physiological Aspects of Aging, Disease, and Physical Activity
KNES 495.description: An examination of the interaction between aging, age-associated disease (e.g., cardiovascular disease) and physical activity. The major emphasis will be on the physiological processes involved.

KNES 497.title: Cancer and Exercise Research and Reviews
KNES 497.description: Examination of current literature and issues in cancer and exercise research.

KNES 498.title: Group Dynamics in Sport
KNES 498.description: An in-depth exploration of the unique psychological dynamics that emerge in sport groups.
KNES 498.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 399 and Admission to the Faculty of Kinesiology.

KNES 499.title: Applied Sport Psychology
KNES 499.description: Focus on applied sport psychology techniques and strategies to optimize performance, with the intent to bridge sport psychology related research with professional practice.

KNES 501.title: Sport and Law
KNES 501.description: An introduction and analysis of legal issues and concepts related to sport.
KNES 501.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):18 units of courses labelled Kinesiology (KNES) and Admission to the Faculty of Kinesiology.

KNES 503.title: Special Topics in Kinesiology
KNES 503.description: Topics may include, but are not limited to, studies in sport psychology, human physiology, biomechanics or leadership.
KNES 503.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): For certain topics consent of the Faculty of Kinesiology and/or specific course prerequisites will be required.

KNES 504.title: Directed Study
KNES 504.description: Intensive self-directed study of selected topics in Kinesiology.
KNES 504.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to and consent of the Faculty of Kinesiology.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

KNES 505.title: Concussion
KNES 505.description: The focus of this course will be on the detection, alterations, management, and prevention strategies associated with concussion.

KNES 506.title: Cerebral Blood Flow
KNES 506.description:
A comprehensive examination of brain blood flow regulation and how this system is affected by exercise.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Kinesiology 373.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Kinesiology 506 and 503.80 (Cerebral Blood Flow) will not be allowed.

KNES 565.title: Pediatric Exercise Science
KNES 565.description: Examines age and maturity related aspects of exercise physiology. It builds on basic exercise physiology and growth and maturation. A focus on physiological differences between children and adults during exercise, along with differential effects of age, sex, and maturity on physical activity and exercise training from childhood through adulthood.
KNES 565.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 355 and 373 and admission to the Faculty of Kinesiology.

KNES 566.title: Biomechanics Research Project
KNES 566.description: A capstone course where students assimilate their knowledge by designing and conducting a biomechanics research project.
KNES 566.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Biomechanics major.

KNES 585.title: Innovations in Wearable Technology
KNES 585.description: An introduction to core concepts of wearable technology, including an introduction to current markets and trends, wearable sensor applications, products and services, information and data delivery ecosystem, human-computer interaction, and recent advancements in products and their application to fitness and healthcare. Also covered are the topics of state-of-the-art technologies, market trends, and innovations in software development.
KNES 585.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 323 and Admission to the Faculty of Kinesiology.

KNES 590.title: Honours Thesis
KNES 590.description: Supervised individual research and preparation of an Honours thesis in Kinesiology.
KNES 590.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Statistics 205 or 213; and admission to the Kinesiology Honours program; and consent of the Faculty. 

(formerly Kinesiology 490)

KNES 593.title: Senior Practicum
KNES 593.description: An opportunity for students to gain personalized, applied research and/or work experience in kinesiology or related fields.
KNES 593.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to and consent of the Faculty of Kinesiology.

KNES 603.title: Special Topics
KNES 603.description: Intensive study of selected topics in human physical activity and related subjects as follows: Applied Sport Psychology; Biomechanics; Cognitive Science: Vision and Motor Behaviour; Exercise and Health Physiology; Health and Exercise Psychology; Motor Learning; Multi-Media Applications in Learning; Neuro-Motor Psychology; Nutrition, Metabolism and Genetics; Sport and Exercise Psychology; Sport History; Sport Medicine; Sport Sociology.
KNES 603.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s):  Admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

KNES 604.title: Directed Study
KNES 604.description: Intensive self-directed study of selected topics in Kinesiology.
KNES 604.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to and consent of the Kinesiology graduate program.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

KNES 605.title: Nutrition for Performance & Active Living
KNES 605.description: Nutritional requirements for sport performance and active living, including an overview of basic nutritional principles. Designed to use current research findings as a basis to examine the role of nutrition in sport performance. Nutrition for an active lifestyle will also be examined.
KNES 605.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

KNES 608.title: Innovations in Wearable Technology
KNES 608.description:
An introduction to core concepts of wearable technology, including an introduction to current markets and trends, wearable sensor applications, products and services, information and data delivery ecosystem, human-computer interaction, and introduction to data visualization. Also covers the topics of state-of-the-art technologies, market trends, and innovations in software development.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Kinesiology 608 and 603.40 (Innovation Wearable Tech) will not be allowed.

KNES 609.title: Statistical Techniques in Kinesiology
KNES 609.description: Basic concepts of statistical analysis as they apply to research methods used in various disciplines in kinesiology.
KNES 609.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 611 and admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

KNES 610.title: Qualitative Research Analysis
KNES 610.description: An introduction to qualitative research. Emphasis will be placed on critically evaluating qualitative literature, designing and conducting qualitative research, and qualitative analysis.
KNES 610.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

KNES 611.title: Research Methods in Kinesiology
KNES 611.description: An overview of research methods including study design, data collection, measurement, interpretation of data, scientific writing, and critical appraisal of the literature relevant to kinesiology.
KNES 611.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

KNES 613.title: Practical Skills for Applied Exercise Physiology I
KNES 613.description: To develop practical skill and techniques associated with applied exercise physiological measurement vs. measurements in the areas of body composition, cardio-respiratory and musculoskeletal fitness.
KNES 613.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

KNES 614.title: Practical Skills for Applied Exercise Physiology II
KNES 614.description: To develop practical skill and techniques associated with applied exercise physiological measurement vs. measurements in the areas of body composition, cardio-respiratory and musculoskeletal fitness.
KNES 614.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

KNES 615.title: Seminar in Applied Exercise Physiology I
KNES 615.description: Lectures and seminar presentations, discussion and critique of current research in applied exercise physiology and related subjects.
KNES 615.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s):  Admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

KNES 617.title: Seminar in Applied Exercise Physiology II
KNES 617.description: Lectures and seminar presentations, discussion and critique of current research in applied exercise physiology and related subjects.
KNES 617.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s):  Admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

KNES 618.title: Capstone
KNES 618.description: Instruction and discussion of issues in data collection, data analysis, and presentation of results in applied and non-traditional settings. Includes the successful completion of an independent applied project.
KNES 618.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

KNES 620.title: Collaborative Enquiry in Applied Exercise Physiology I
KNES 620.description: Instruction in critical enquiry, critical appraisal, applied problem solving frameworks, and research design within applied exercise physiology settings. Includes the successful development of an independent project proposal.
KNES 620.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

KNES 621.title: Collaborative Enquiry in Applied Exercise Physiology II
KNES 621.description: Instruction in critical enquiry, critical appraisal, applied problem solving frameworks, and research design within applied exercise physiology settings. Includes the successful development of an independent project proposal.
KNES 621.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 620 and admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

KNES 637.title: Nutrition for Physically Active Populations
KNES 637.description: An examination of current nutritional strategies for sport performance and diet-related chronic diseases. Critical analysis of a wide variety of dietary supplements will be included at an advanced level.
KNES 637.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

KNES 655.title: Kinanthropometry
KNES 655.description: The quantitative study of size, shape, proportion, composition, and maturation of the human body in relation to gross motor function in sport, physical activity, and the work place.
KNES 655.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 355 and admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

KNES 663.title: (Enme/Mdsc 663)Advanced Muscle Mechanics and Physiology
KNES 663.description: A look at problems associated within muscle mechanics and contractility. Also the use of muscle mechanics as a scientific discipline to critically learn and evaluate the scientific process. Basic anatomy and physiology of muscle contraction including the cross-bridge theory, and the force-length, force-velocity and force-time relationships of actively and passively contracting muscles will also be covered.
KNES 663.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

Also known as: (Mechanical Engineering 663) (Medical Science 663)

KNES 664.title: Bone and Joint Biomechanics
KNES 664.description: An examination of bone and joint biomechanics as they relate to bone fracture, joint injuries, and diseases with an emphasis on osteoarthritis. Basic bone, ligament, cartilage, and muscle structure and function will be discussed in the context of healthy tissues and in aging, disease, and post-trauma. Animal models of disease are explored.
KNES 664.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

KNES 673.title: Exercise Physiology
KNES 673.description: Topics in exercise physiology will include the effects of exercise on muscle, metabolism, hormones, respiration, and the cardiovascular system.
KNES 673.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Kinesiology 373 and admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

KNES 676.title: Clinical Exercise Physiology I
KNES 676.description: Exercise for clinical populations: exercise assessment and prescription for disease modification.
KNES 676.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 673 and admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

KNES 677.title: Clinical Exercise Physiology II
KNES 677.description: Exercise for clinical populations: exercise assessment and prescription for disease modification.
KNES 677.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 676 and admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

KNES 686.title: Practicum III
KNES 686.description: The practicum will consist of multiple experiences in applied physiology environments.
KNES 686.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 694 and admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

KNES 693.title: Practicum I
KNES 693.description: The practicum will consist of multiple experiences in applied physiology environments.
KNES 693.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

KNES 694.title: Practicum II
KNES 694.description: The practicum will consist of multiple experiences in applied physiology environments.
KNES 694.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 693 and admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

KNES 697.title: Exercise Psychology
KNES 697.description: Addresses the determinants and consequences of exercise and sport engagement within clinical and athletic populations. The focus will be on fostering effective behaviour change in varied populations, with hands-on skills and effective practice guidelines shared with the students.
KNES 697.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

KNES 698.title: Practicum IV
KNES 698.description: The practicum will consist of multiple experiences in applied physiology environments.
KNES 698.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 696 and admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

KNES 703.title: Special Topics
KNES 703.description: Intensive study of selected topics in Kinesiology.
KNES 703.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

KNES 704.title: Directed Study
KNES 704.description: Intensive self-directed study of selected topics in Kinesiology.
KNES 704.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a Graduate program in the Faculty of Kinesiology and consent of the Faculty.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

KNES 715.title: Seminar in Applied Exercise Physiology III
KNES 715.description: Lectures and seminar presentations, discussion and advanced critique of current research in applied exercise physiology and related subjects.
KNES 715.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

KNES 717.title: Seminar in Applied Exercise Physiology IV
KNES 717.description: Advanced critical appraisal of research in applied exercise physiology.
KNES 717.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

KNES 773.title: Integrative Exercise Physiology
KNES 773.description: The effects of exercise on the complex physiological interactions between different systems in the human body.
KNES 773.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Kinesiology 673 and admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

KNES 785.title: Training Strategies for Health and Sport
KNES 785.description: The science of improving health and athletic performance with appropriate periodized stress and recovery.
KNES 785.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Kinesiology 773 and admission to a Graduate Program in Kinesiology.

KNES 612.01.title: Practicum I
KNES 612.01.description:
Practicum placement focused on experiential learning in the field of wearable technology. The purpose is to broaden the students' scope of practice in the field of wearable technology, to translate classroom learning into an applied work-place setting, and to enhance self-discovery through experiential learning.

Notes: At the discretion of the specialization Director, and with the support of the student's supervisor, and supervisory committee, the student may extend their industry placement no more than twice. Enrolment in Kinesiology 612.02 and 612.03 may be in the form of an extended placement with the original practicum partner or with a new institution.

KNES 612.02.title: Practicum II
KNES 612.02.description:
Practicum placement focused on experiential learning in the field of wearable technology. The purpose is to broaden the students' scope of practice in the field of wearable technology, to translate classroom learning into an applied work-place setting, and to enhance self-discovery through experiential learning.

Notes: At the discretion of the specialization Director, and with the support of the student's supervisor, and supervisory committee, the student may extend their industry placement no more than twice. Enrolment in Kinesiology 612.02 and 612.03 may be in the form of an extended placement with the original practicum partner or with a new institution.

KNES 612.03.title: Practicum III
KNES 612.03.description:
Practicum placement focused on experiential learning in the field of wearable technology. The purpose is to broaden the students' scope of practice in the field of wearable technology, to translate classroom learning into an applied work-place setting, and to enhance self-discovery through experiential learning.

Notes: At the discretion of the specialization Director, and with the support of the student's supervisor, and supervisory committee, the student may extend their industry placement no more than twice. Enrolment in Kinesiology 612.02 and 612.03 may be in the form of an extended placement with the original practicum partner or with a new institution.

LAND 201.title: Landscape Architecture and the Future of Cities
LAND 201.description: An introduction to landscape architecture as a creative and technical discipline that shapes the future of cities and natural environments. The course examines the performative role that landscapes play in climate change mitigation, habitat restoration, water management, disaster resilience, and public health, as well as urban vitality and well-being. Students will develop an understanding of the critical role that nature and outdoor space plays in city building and how landscape architecture can affect positive future change.

LAND 600.title: Landscape Architecture History and Theory
LAND 600.description:
An introduction to the history, theory and contemporary issues of landscape architecture. Develop a critical awareness of major conceptual frameworks, and the socio-political contexts in which they developed, both conceptually and in realized projects.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design Landscape 629)

LAND 602.title: Plants in the Landscape
LAND 602.description:
Introduces students to plant taxonomy, plant identification, and planting design. Covers both natural and designed landscapes, and focuses on plant materials appropriate in the context of Calgary and the region.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design Landscape 645)

LAND 604.title: Landscape Architecture Studio I - Foundation
LAND 604.description: An integration of skills and processes developed to this point in the program through an investigation into a topical, issue-based problem, and development of solution(s) in a landscape context.
LAND 604.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Planning 606 or Environmental Design Planning 625.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design Landscape 667)

LAND 606.title: Site Technology I: Grading and Landform
LAND 606.description:
Provides a working knowledge of grading, landform and storm water management systems and techniques. Covers fundamentals and advanced technologies including GPS grading and landform manipulation.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design Landscape 603)

LAND 608.title: Landscape Responses to Climate Change, Energy and Water
LAND 608.description:
Identifies landscape-oriented solutions to local and global issues of climate change, energy, and water problems through research and project proposals. Provides the opportunity to identify the most pressing local, regional or international issues and develop solutions.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design Landscape 639)

LAND 610.title: Green Infrastructure/Winter City Design
LAND 610.description:
An introduction to the systems of urban and regional resource management through targeted green infrastructure projects, particularly in a winter city context. Provides background on current methods, the state-of-the-art, and research and development that will shape future technologies. Identifies contemporary approaches, and sociocultural, and ecological concepts for using plant material in landscapes, green roofs and biomass.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design Landscape 641)

LAND 612.title: Site Technology II: Construction and Materials
LAND 612.description:
Provides a working knowledge of landscape construction methods and materials through practical application of theories and techniques via a design project.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design Landscape 605)

LAND 614.title: Landscape Architecture Studio II - Intermediate
LAND 614.description:
An integration of skills and processes developed to this point in the program through an investigation into a topical, issue-based problem, and development of solution(s) in a landscape context. Builds on skills and knowledge from previous studios and is a progression in terms of complexity and design process.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design Landscape 668)

LAND 616.title: Professional Practice and Project Management for Landscape Architecture
LAND 616.description:
An introduction to the professional practice of landscape architecture. Includes the legal and ethical frameworks for practice, as well as project management.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design Landscape 643)

LAND 618.title: Advanced Graphics in Landscape Architecture
LAND 618.description: Focuses on professional practice skill development in graphics using advanced digital rendering techniques and software used in professional practice for design project rendering and modelling.

LAND 620.title: Synthesis Studio in Landscape Architecture
LAND 620.description: Focuses on the synthesis and integration of current landscape technologies, landscape construction materials, plant materials and planting design, using advanced design methods and graphic techniques to address complex issues in landscape architecture.

LAND 670.title: Experiential Learning in Landscape Architecture
LAND 670.description:
Thematic inquiry and design contextualized by experiential learning in landscape architecture.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

LAND 672.title: Experiential Learning in Landscape Architecture
LAND 672.description:
Thematic inquiry and design contextualized by experiential learning in landscape architecture.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LAND 674.title: Experiential Learning in Landscape Architecture
LAND 674.description:
Thematic inquiry and design contextualized by experiential learning in landscape architecture.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

LAND 676.title: Experiential Learning in Landscape Architecture
LAND 676.description:
Thematic inquiry and design contextualized by experiential learning in landscape architecture.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

LAND 680.title: Special Topics in Landscape Architecture
LAND 680.description:
Thematic inquiry and design related to special topics in landscape architecture.

MAYBE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LAND 682.title: Special Topics in Landscape Architecture
LAND 682.description:
Thematic inquiry and design related to special topics in landscape architecture.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LAND 686.title: Special Topics in Landscape Architecture
LAND 686.description:
Thematic inquiry and design related to special topics in landscape architecture.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

LAND 688.title: Special Studio Topics in Landscape Architecture
LAND 688.description:
Thematic inquiry and design related to special studio topics in landscape architecture.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LAND 700.title: Regional Landscape Systems Studio
LAND 700.description:
An introduction to landscape planning and design at the regional scale. Particular emphasis on the interrelationships between biophysical (i.e. ecological, geological) systems and anthropogenic (i.e. social, political, economic) systems and processes as agents of landscape transformation, and determinants of form.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design Landscape 767)

LAND 702.title: Landscape Architecture Studio III - Advanced
LAND 702.description:
A research-oriented project studio that explores contemporary themes in landscape architecture. Centres on a real world problem or project; the analysis of issues and context, and the formulation of a comprehensive design solution involving advanced methods, techniques and practices.

Also known as: (formerly Environmental Design Landscape 777)

LAND 790.title: Directed Study in Landscape Architecture
LAND 790.description: Thematic research, readings, or studio projects related to landscape architecture design topics.
LAND 790.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LAND 792.title: Directed Study in Landscape Architecture
LAND 792.description: hematic research, readings, or studio projects related to planning design topics.
LAND 792.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LAND 799.title: Preceptorship in Landscape Architecture
LAND 799.description: A Preceptorship is a study and training arrangement made between a student and an employer or an equivalent supervisor which has specific educational objectives, a method of evaluation, and is an integral part of a student's Program of Studies. Preceptorships offer a number of benefits: acquiring skills and knowledge which may be better obtained outside the University; developing first-hand experience of professional design practice; preparing for more focused studies in the Faculty; and conducting research.
LAND 799.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

LANG 200.title: Introduction to Second Language Learning
LANG 200.description: Introduction to the process of language learning with a focus on the development of learning strategies. Specific examples will be drawn from ancient and modern languages offered at the University of Calgary.

LANG 300.title: Introductory Topics in Translation Studies
LANG 300.description: Basics of translation theory and practice for students with sufficient second language background. Establishes a common critical vocabulary to discuss issues in translation.
LANG 300.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

LANG 301.title: Topics in Research Methods and Analysis
LANG 301.description:
Examination of different types of research that acquaint students with research design, data collection, research methods, analysis, and presentation of research outcomes.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LANG 400.title: Advanced Topics in Translation Studies
LANG 400.description: An in-depth study of the field of translation with a focus on the notions of aesthetics, comparative stylistics, grammar, and literary forms. The applied focus of the course will be on a high-quality translation along with a critical reflection on its production.
LANG 400.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Language 300.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LANG 451.title: Topics in Cross-Cultural Explorations
LANG 451.description: Study of languages and cultural products from a cross-cultural perspective. Students examine cultures, arts, and languages across historical periods and geographic locations, employing comparative analysis and theoretical perspectives.
LANG 451.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Completion of 60 units; or Language 301 and admission to the Language and Culture Major or Honours program.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LANG 501.title: Advanced Topics in the Study of Language and Culture
LANG 501.description: Students work with resources from their language(s) of study to reflect on and integrate their knowledge and skills, working individually and in groups through the planning, research, writing, and presentation of their work.
LANG 501.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Completion of 75 units; or Language 451 and admission to the Language and Culture Major or Honours program.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LANG 591.title: Honours Thesis
LANG 591.description: Students carry out a specific research project under the supervision of a staff member and submit a thesis acceptable to the area of concentration.
LANG 591.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Language and Culture Honours degree program and consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

LANG 599.title: Topics in the Study of Language
LANG 599.description: Topics will reflect developments in current research in second language acquisition and learning.
LANG 599.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LANG 605.title: Second Language Learning and Pedagogy
LANG 605.description: Theoretical and practical overview of the processes involved in acquiring a second language, with a focus on naturalistic language acquisition and on classroom strategies and classroom language learning.
LANG 605.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Consent of the home department.

LANG 615.title: Second Language Learning and Technology
LANG 615.description: Theoretical and practical aspects of incorporating technology into the language classroom. A general overview in the context of theories of second language acquisition of using the Web, electronic mail, on line chat discussion, and videoconferencing as tools in language teaching / learning; students will also learn to create their own web sites and web activities for teaching.
LANG 615.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Consent of the home department.

LANG 625.title: Second Language Learning and Cultural Understanding
LANG 625.description: An introduction to the interdisciplinary nature of "culture" as it pertains to second language teaching and learning.
LANG 625.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the home department.

LANG 699.title: Research Seminar in 2nd Language Learning
LANG 699.description: Centered round a professor's current research project, the course will engage students as members of a collaborative research team that will serve as a practical exposure to research methods in the area of second language learning and acquisition.
LANG 699.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Consent of the home department.

LAST 211.title: Latin America: People, Places and Popular Culture
LAST 211.description: An introduction to Latin America, one of the most diverse and dynamic regions in the world. What is the origin of this diversity? How does this diversity manifest itself in today's places and cultures? An interdisciplinary approach is taken to answering these questions, as the course material integrates archaeology, history, political science, economics, geography, anthropology, and cultural studies to introduce students to the region.

LAST 301.title: Field Study in Latin America
LAST 301.description: An experiential learning course, designed to provide a framework for the student's empirical learning experience during the Latin American Studies Field School. Provides a forum for the sharing of cross-cultural experiences among the students, as they analyze and reflect on the realities of life in Latin America. Students will be expected to live with a local family during the Field School, to take an active part in discussions, and to participate in events and field trips.
LAST 301.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Consent of the Program Coordinator.

LAST 303.title: Latin American Field Research
LAST 303.description: In a Latin American field setting, this course guides students in integrating their own observations and experiences with scholarly readings on themes of relevance and importance to the particular setting. Attention is paid to the archaeological and historical contexts as well as present day economic, political, and social issues of Latin America.  The regional and theoretical focus of the material will vary according to the location at which the course is given.
LAST 303.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Consent of the Program Coordinator.

LAST 311.title: Critical Contemporary Issues in Latin America
LAST 311.description: An analysis of critical issues that provides students with a framework for understanding Latin America today. Examines themes of contemporary importance, which may include human rights, indigenous issues, energy, the environment, democratization, poverty and inequality, social movements, migration, and the region's relationship with the United States.

LAST 401.title: Integrative Seminar in Latin American Studies
LAST 401.description: An advanced seminar involving research on a special Latin American topic integrating a variety of disciplinary and interdisciplinary perspectives (eg. political science, anthropology, geography, cultural studies).
LAST 401.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Latin American Studies 201 or 211, and 203 or 311, and completion of at least eight full-course equivalents or consent of the Program Coordinator.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LAST 501.title: Directed Study in Latin American Studies
LAST 501.description: Students devise a research question and carry out a program of independent research with a specialist on a topic in the area of Latin American Studies.
LAST 501.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 48 units and consent of the Program Co-ordinator.

LATI 201.title: Latin I
LATI 201.description:
This course for beginners provides the first steps towards reading Latin texts.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Latin 201 and 205 will not be allowed.

LATI 205.title: The Latin of Science I
LATI 205.description:
An introduction to Latin through ancient, medieval and modern scientific texts, designed for students in the Sciences and Engineering.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Latin 205 and 201 will not be allowed.

LATI 301.title: Latin III
LATI 301.description: Completes the study of basic grammar, vocabulary and translation skills.

LATI 303.title: Intermediate Readings in Classical and Post-Classical Texts
LATI 303.description: Translation and study of text(s) drawn from classical and/or post-classical Latin prose.

LATI 401.title: Topics in Latin Prose
LATI 401.description: Readings will normally be selected according to genres, such as Historiography, Oratory, Philosophic and Didactic Prose, the Novel, Epigraphy.
LATI 401.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Latin 303.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LATI 403.title: Topics in Latin Poetry
LATI 403.description: Readings will normally be selected according to genres, such as Epic, Drama, Lyric, and Satire.
LATI 403.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Latin 303.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LATI 551.title: Directed Studies in Latin
LATI 551.description: Readings may be selected from any genre of Latin at an advanced level.
LATI 551.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LATI 602.title: Introductory Language Class for Graduate Students
LATI 602.description:
Introduction to grammar, vocabulary and translation skills. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LATI 604.title: Intermediate Language Class for Graduate Students
LATI 604.description:
Consolidation of grammar, vocabulary and translation skills.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LAW 400.title: Constitutional Law
LAW 400.description: The basic elements of Canadian constitutional law. The nature of constitutions and constitutional processes; principles of constitutional interpretation; constitutional amendment; Federal-Provincial distribution of legislative powers including the federal general power, natural resources and public property, provincial property and civil rights, trade and commerce, provincial taxation, transportation, communications, and criminal law; the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms including principles of limitation, remedies, interpretation, application, fundamental freedoms, democratic and language rights, mobility rights, legal rights, equality rights, and aboriginal people's rights.

LAW 402.title: Contracts
LAW 402.description: A legal and policy analysis of the basic principles and fundamental concepts of the law of contracts as they relate to commercial and consumer transactions. The formation of contracts including offer and acceptance and, consideration; estoppel; privity; terms of contract, including exemption clauses; standard form contracts; bailment; mistake, misrepresentation and unconscionability; termination, including the doctrine of frustration; breach and remedies for breach; dispute resolution processes. Emphasis is placed not only on a knowledge of rules and principles, their historical derivation, rationale, efficacy and social validity, but also upon their creative use to both avoid and resolve disputes.

LAW 403.title: Legislation
LAW 403.description: The fundamentals of the legislative process: policy development, legislative drafting, public bill processes, statutory interpretation. The interaction of law and policy in the development of legislation and statutory interpretation. Substantive law connections are made with other first year courses. The functions of the lawyer within these processes are examined, including issues of professional responsibility. The course is taught through performance-based learning methods with emphasis on drafting.

LAW 404.title: Property
LAW 404.description: An examination of the fundamental concepts of property law and the types of property interests recognized by Anglo-Canadian law. The historical evolution of property concepts; the basic concepts of possession, ownership and title; estates and other interests in land such as joint and concurrent ownership, easements, covenants, licences, mortgages, future interests and perpetuities; the landlord and tenant relationship; the land titles system of registration of title to land; the social constraints upon property use and disposition; and property rights of aboriginal peoples.

LAW 406.title: Torts
LAW 406.description: An analysis and critique of the law of torts, primarily the law of negligence, with personal injury as the main focus, although other torts will also be introduced. The nature of tort law and its process; an anatomy of the law of negligence - the nature and extent of liability, defences, remedies, and the assessment of damages; intentional torts; economic torts; strict liability; bailment; the impact of private insurance on the tort system; alternative forms of compensation.

LAW 407.title: Foundations in Law and Justice I
LAW 407.description:
An introduction to: legal methods, systems and institutions; sources of law; legal and judicial reasoning; legal analysis, including case analysis and problem-solving skills; critical perspectives on the law, including legal theory and history; the role of the lawyer in system(s) of laws; access to justice. The course is taught on an intensive basis in the first three weeks of law school to provide students with foundational analytical and critical skills for the subsequent curriculum, and using performance-based learning methods.

Notes: This course is graded CR, D or F.

LAW 408.title: Foundations in Law and Justice II
LAW 408.description:
The fundamentals of legal research, writing, communication and advocacy, including: developing research strategies; identification and assessment of legal and non-legal information appropriate to a legal problem or issue; drafting of memorandum and/or facta; oral advocacy, including mooting; legal communication, including client interviewing and counselling. This course is taught on an intensive basis in the first three weeks of winter term using performance-based learning methods.

Notes: This course is graded CR, D or F.

LAW 410.title: Crime: Law & Procedure
LAW 410.description: An anatomy of criminal conduct and the law's treatment of it utilizing a limited range of criminal offences. The designation of human conduct as criminal and a consideration of the social, cultural and political forces involved; the development of the criminal process in English common law, its translation to Canada and embodiment in the Criminal Code; the substantive elements of a criminal offence including both the physical and mental elements; the common law and code defences; procedural, tactical, ethical and evidential problems associated with criminal prosecution at both the pre-trial and trial stages; the sentencing process; the position at law of the victim.

LAW 420.title: Foundations of Canadian Law
LAW 420.description: An introduction to: legal methods, systems and institutions; sources of law; legal and judicial reasoning; legal analysis, including case analysis and problem-solving skills; critical perspectives on the law, including legal theory, history, and Indigenous perspectives; the role of the lawyer in system(s) of laws; access to justice. The course provides students with foundational analytical and critical legal skills, and uses performance-based learning methods.
LAW 420.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Foreign Trained Lawyers Program post-bachelor's certificate.

LAW 430.title: Professional Development
LAW 430.description: Development of professional skills and competencies to facilitate integration into the Canadian legal profession. The course includes performance-based learning and assessment in relation to professional legal oral and written communication, marketing, advocacy, interviewing, client development and practice management. The course also examines the structure and organization of the Canadian legal profession, with a view to preparing students for entry into the Canadian legal services market.
LAW 430.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Foreign Trained Lawyers Program post-bachelor's certificate.

LAW 503.title: Administrative Law
LAW 503.description: This course introduces students to the general structure of administrative decision-making in Canada: how public administrators obtain power and how that power is exercised both at the level of individual adjudication and at the level of the establishment of public  policy. It also introduces students to the checks which courts place on the exercise of administrative power. The course discusses the procedures that courts require of administrative agencies and public officials as well as the substantive grounds on which courts may review the decisions of administrative agencies and public officials.

LAW 505.title: Civil Procedure
LAW 505.description: A detailed examination of issues which arise in the progress of a civil action from first meeting the client through to judgment in the Alberta Court of Queen's Bench. The Alberta Rules of Court are set in the context of the values underlying them. What sort of civil litigation system do we want? What sort of system do we in fact have? Particular attention if paid to the linkages between the apparently discrete components of the process as set out in the Rules, linkages at the levels of both the underlying values and of actual practice. The use of procedures under the Rules to anticipate and resolve evidence problems that might arise at trial is stressed. Interprovincial and international aspect of the civil litigation process are also considered.

LAW 507.title: Evidence
LAW 507.description: An examination of the fundamental concept of evidence law, including the traditional rules as compared to the emerging principled approach, and such core and primary topicss as: the adversary system; relevance and discretionary exclusion; privelege; burdens of proof; character evidence; judicial notice; competence and compellability; examination of witnesses; hearsay; opinion evidence.

LAW 508.title: Negotiation
LAW 508.description:
Instruction in dispute resolution theory and practice with a focus on negotiation, mediation and topics such as collaborative law and judicial dispute resolution, and application of those processes to a substantive area of law. Taught in a three week intensive format through performance-based learning methods. Evaluation will include a mock negotiation and written exercises such as the preparation of a client-advising memo in the substantive area.

Notes: This course is graded CR, D or F.

LAW 509.title: Business Associations
LAW 509.description: The common forms of business organization, including the law of agency, partnerships, limited partnerships, and societies and corporations, with a focus on the corporation and the rights and responsibilities of shareholders and directors. Topics will include fiduciary relationships in a commercial context.

LAW 510.title: Ethical Lawyering
LAW 510.description: An introduction to issues of legal ethics and professional responsibility. Students should become competent at ethical reasoning in the context of legal practice. To achieve this goal the course covers selected topic in the \"law of lawyering\" (e.g. the Law Society of Alberta's Code of Professional Conduct) but also address the general question of what it means to be an ethical lawyer. Students are expected to develop their awareness of the various moral values underlying the legal system, and to practice how to weigh and apply those values, and the law of lawyering, to ethical problems. The course also covers selected topics relating to the regulation of lawyers' ethics.

LAW 511.title: Criminal Process
LAW 511.description: A survey and critical examination of core aspects of criminal process law. A focus on legislation relating to jurisdiction and modes of trial including obligations of and options available to prosecution and accused. Other topics include arrest, search and seizure, investigative detention, and right to counsel and silence, all within the context of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.

LAW 515.title: Family Law
LAW 515.description: An analysis of the legal principles affecting the rights and responsibilities of the members of the family. Topics include constitutional issues, marriage, marriage contracts, common law marriage, child neglect and abuse, custody and access, guardianship, adoption, separation, divorce, nullity, spousal and child maintenance, and matrimonial property. Stress is placed on the process of family law and the appropriate role for lawyers and judges.

LAW 519.title: Jurisprudence
LAW 519.description: A critical inquiry into the nature and functions of law and justice, including natural law, legal positivism, sociological jurisprudence, legal realism, and contemporary theorists.

LAW 521.title: Real Estate Transactions
LAW 521.description: An examination of the estate transactions. Topics include the purchase and sale of property, mortgaging and other ways to finance land transactions, commercial leasing arrangements, and the Land Titles Act as it relates to land development.

LAW 525.title: Bankruptcy & Restructuring Law
LAW 525.description: Receivership, consumer and commercial arrangements and bankruptcy under the Bankruptcy Act and the Company Creditors Arrangements Act.

LAW 527.title: Basic Tax Law
LAW 527.description: The basic language and concepts of taxation and  identification of taxation issues. Topics include the unit of taxation, the meaning and taxation of income, taxation of benefits, the type and scope of  deductions available for business income, and the taxation of capital gains including gains (and losses) on taxpayer assets.

LAW 529.title: Biotechnology and the Law
LAW 529.description: The legal, ethical, and policy issues relating to biotechnology. Topics include genetically modified foods, animals and plants, synthetic genomics, animal-human combinations, xenotransplantation, human cloning, pharmacogenetics, biofuels, assisted human reproduction, stem cells, tissue engineering, genetic therapy, and genetic enhancement.

LAW 530.title: Mining Law
LAW 530.description: The law governing the exploration, financing and development of minerals in Canada. Topics include mining legislation; title; aboriginal rights, including the duty to consult; environmental obligations; mining agreements; and, international transactions.

LAW 531.title: Environmental Law
LAW 531.description: Legal theories, concepts, principles, and processes relevant to environmental protection. Topics include ecological and ethical dimensions, jurisdictional issues, common law rights and remedies, environmental assessment, public participation, contaminated sites, enforcement and compliance, economic approaches, endangered species and protected spaces, land use planning, and environmental dispute resolution.

LAW 533.title: Wills And Estates
LAW 533.description: The preparation, execution, interpretation, and administration of wills; testamentary capacity; alteration, revocation and republication of wills; intestate succession; dependants' relief; and estate administration.

LAW 535.title: Secured Transactions
LAW 535.description: The modern law of secured transactions and the financing of personal property, with a focus on Alberta's Personal Property Security Act. Other topics include Bank Act security, the Farm Implement Act, and the Fair Trading Act.

LAW 536.title: International Criminal Law
LAW 536.description: The law related to international and transnational crimes.  Topics may include crimes against humanity, war crimes, genocide, aggression, extradition, terrorism, human trafficking, drug trafficking, cybercrime, state sovereignty and impunity, money laundering, and organized crime.

LAW 537.title: Sale Of Goods
LAW 537.description: The sale and supply of goods, including an examination of the provincial Sale of Goods Act, consumer protection issues, and the Vienna International Sales Convention.

LAW 543.title: Intellectual Property
LAW 543.description: Intellectual property, including the law of patents, copyrights, and trade-marks.

LAW 547.title: Human Rights Law
LAW 547.description: A survey of national and provincial human rights laws and practice as distinct from the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, and an introduction to the main international and transnational human rights instruments and standards.

LAW 549.title: International Law
LAW 549.description: The elements of public international law, including sources, the role of customary law, the law of treaties, recognition, state responsibility, and the roles and powers of international organizations.

LAW 551.title: Unjust Enrichment
LAW 551.description: Unjust enrichment as an independent source of legal obligation.  Topics include elements of the right of action and defences; restitution as the remedy, with particular emphasis on personal versus proprietary restitution; and disgorgement of wrongful gain, distinguished from restitution using breach of fiduciary obligation as the primary example.

LAW 553.title: Insurance Law
LAW 553.description: The various types of insurance (e.g. fire, life, sickness and accident, motor vehicle, and liability). Topics include the nature and formation of the insurance contract, the role of insurance agents, insurable interest, misrepresentation and non-disclosure, and the rights of third parties against the insurer.

LAW 557.title: Commercial Arbitration Law
LAW 557.description: Private (between individuals) and mixed (investor/state) arbitration. Coverage includes domestic and international arbitration rules, includiing UNCITRAL and International Centre for the Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID) rules.

LAW 559.title: Critical Legal Theories
