LAW 559.description: An examination of critical theoretical perspectives on the nature and functions of law, and of the possibilities and limitations of law as a strategy for social change. Perspectives may include feminist legal theories, critical race theories, post-colonial theories, Aboriginal legal theories, critical disability theories, queer theories, and postmodernism.

LAW 561.title: Employment Law
LAW 561.description: The law governing non-unionized workplaces in Canada. Topics include constitutional jurisdiction, defining the employment relationship and employer/employee status, the employment contract, implied rights and obligations, termination, reasonable notice of dismissal, constructive dismissal, cause for summary dismissal, human rights, and employment standards legislation.

LAW 563.title: International Human Rights and Humanitarian Law
LAW 563.description: International human rights law, covering the main global instruments (such as the International Covenants, as well as the regional human rights systems of the Americas and Europe), with an introduction to the principles and concepts of International Humanitarian Law. Topics include women's human rights, death penalty, massive human rights violations, human rights and counter-terrorism, the rights of the child, the rights of indigenous peoples and minorities, and the role of non-state actors.

LAW 565.title: Internet Law
LAW 565.description: The Internet as a technology, a place for social interaction, and a marketplace. Topics include internet governance, network neutrality, end to end and layered principles, the domain name system, peer production and distribution, information security and privacy, ISP regulation, regulation of internet content, electronic commerce, VOIP regulation, and anti-circumvention law.

LAW 567.title: Law and Economics
LAW 567.description: An examination of the practical and theoretical implications arising from the application of economic reasoning to law. Topics include the economic method of legal analysis, the scope of its application, and the major critical responses in both traditional legal fields of economic influence (such as tort, contract and corporate law) and more novel areas (such as family and criminal law).

LAW 569.title: Law and Literature
LAW 569.description: The ways in which literary studies inform law and legal analysis, and the ways in which law and legal themes have informed literature.

LAW 571.title: Oil and Gas Law
LAW 571.description: The upstream oil and gas industry. Topics include ownership of oil and gas and split estates; coalbed methane; the legal character of the private oil and gas lease; the anatomy of the various clauses of the oil and gas lease; and Crown disposition systems, including the Alberta (conventional and oil sands) and federal legislation and related policy question.

LAW 573.title: Public Lands & Natural Resources Law
LAW 573.description: The protection, exploitation, and management of Crown-owned lands and renewable and non-renewable natural resources (other than oil and gas, and including forestry, rangeland, minerals, wildlife, fisheries, wilderness, recreational, and heritage). Discussion of the nature of public ownership, public and private values, economic approaches, and inter-jurisdictional management.

LAW 575.title: Remedies
LAW 575.description: Judicial remedies at common law and equity for tort and breach of contract, including personal injury and property damage. Themes include compensating loss, disgorging gain, and punishing civil wrong; prohibiting and compelling defendant behaviour; loss-based, gain-based, and punitive damages; and injunctions and specific performance.

LAW 577.title: Tax Policy
LAW 577.description: Principles of tax policy (efficiency, equity, and simplicity) and applications related to income, sales, and payroll taxes.  Topics include the economic and distributive effects of taxes, auditing and legal compliance, and political economy.

LAW 579.title: Legal Theory, Selected Topics
LAW 579.description:
Critical examination of the main theoretical writings in a major doctrinal area or group of doctrinal areas, such as private law (tort, contract and unjust enrichment); public law (criminal, Constitutional and administrative law); tort; contract; evidence; property; Constitutional; or criminal law.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LAW 581.title: Unsecured Creditor's Remedies
LAW 581.description: The remedies available to the unsecured creditor for the collection of debts and the protections offered to debtors, including prejudgment remedies, garnishment, execution against real and personal property, fraudulent preferences and conveyances, and the regulation of collection and credit agencies.

LAW 583.title: Water Law
LAW 583.description: Water resources and management, including the historical and current legal and policy frameworks governing surface and groundwater rights. Topics include responses to scarcity, alternative water management models and plans, industrial use and re-use of water, wetlands, protection of aquatic resources, aboriginal water rights, economic instruments, water as a human right, watershed approaches, and inter-jurisdictional or international issues.

LAW 585.title: Alberta Court of Appeal Moots
LAW 585.description: The development of appellate advocacy and other lawyering skills in the context of preparation for and participation in the Alberta Court of Appeal Moot, in the areas of criminal law; civil law (contract, property or tort law); and constitutional law.

LAW 587.title: Kawaskimhon National Aboriginal Moot
LAW 587.description: The development of advocacy, consensus building, and other lawyering skills in the context of a non-competitive moot conducted in a circle arrangement and using a moot problem based on contemporary issues in Aboriginal-Government relations. Includes a writing requirement.

LAW 589.title: Labour Arbitration Moot
LAW 589.description: The development of advocacy and other lawyering skills in the context of preparation for and participation in an arbitration conducted under a collective agreement. Includes a writing requirement.

LAW 591.title: Provincial Court Clerkships
LAW 591.description: Placements in the Provincial Court performing research, preparing memoranda, and meeting and discussing with a supervising Judge.

LAW 593.title: Health Law
LAW 593.description: The regulation, structure, and financing of the health care system. Topics include licensing and regulation of health care professionals (including medical malpractice claims as a form of regulation); regulation of biomedical research; approval processes for drugs; complementary therapies and medical devices; resource allocation and access to health care; market considerations; privatization and deregulation of health care; and consent and confidentiality.

LAW 594.title: Indigenous Peoples and the Law
LAW 594.description: The law governing the relationship between indigenous peoples and settler society. Topics include recognition of aboriginal laws and custom, self-determination and other applicable principles of international law, self-government, common law recognition of aboriginal title, treaties, the honour of the Crown, the fiduciary duty of the Crown, the Crown's duty of consultation and accommodation, constitutional protection of aboriginal and treaty rights, application of provincial laws, the Indian Act, land surrenders, and exemptions from seizure and taxation.

LAW 595.title: Canadian Legal History
LAW 595.description: Migration of European law in the colonial context and its impact in pre-Confederation Canada (settled and conquered colonies); the role of trading companies, particularly the Hudson's Bay Company; the impact of the United States both before and after Confederation; Confederation and the development of Canadian legal culture and law. Jurisdictions may include British Columbia, Alberta, Ontario, Quebec, and Nova Scotia.

LAW 596.title: Feminist Legal Theory
LAW 596.description: A critical inquiry into the nature and function of law from a variety of different perspectives within feminist legal theory. Topics include the role of rights and of legal discourse, and the possibilities and limitations of law as a strategy for social transformation.

LAW 597.title: International Trade Law
LAW 597.description:
The public law framework for international trade, with emphasis on the WTO and NAFTA. Topics include national treatment, most favoured nation treatment, anti-dumping and countervail actions, and dispute resolution.

Also known as: (formerly Law 665)

LAW 598.title: Trusts
LAW 598.description: The concept of the trust and its development in equity and its relationship to other legal concepts. Topics include the various types of trusts; constituting, administering and terminating the trust; trustee duties and powers; variation of trusts; breach of trust; and the doctrine of tracing.

LAW 599.title: Legal Practice, Selected Topics
LAW 599.description:
A variety of subject matters related to the practice of law.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LAW 601.title: Advanced Criminal Law
LAW 601.description: An in-depth examination of case authorities, primarily through an examination of case authorities, certain concepts in criminal law the understanding of which is essential for a criminal practitioner Topics covered may include mens rea, sexual offences, assault, sentencing, conspiracy, driving offences, and identification.

LAW 602.title: Advocacy
LAW 602.description:
A development of core competencies through the practice of advocacy. Each student will apply legal knowledge, critical analysis, communication and resolution skills as well as ethical understanding, to trial fundamentals situated in real trial scenarios. Participants will choose to represent parties in either a civil or criminal trial.

Notes: This course is graded CR, D or F.

LAW 605.title: Oil and Gas Contracts
LAW 605.description:
Selected problems in oil and gas law including industry contracts (pooling, farmout, joint operating, purchase and sale and royalty agreements); fiduciary duties; and title review.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Law 571.

LAW 606.title: Moot in French
LAW 606.description: Preparation for and participation in a French language moot.

LAW 607.title: Advanced Legal Research
LAW 607.description: This course builds on legal research instruction in the first year of the program and affords further opportunities to learn and practice research skills. The course provides instruction in research methodology, citation, print and electronic research/databases, covering case law, statute law, texts, periodicals and web-based materials.

LAW 608.title: Common Law en Franais
LAW 608.description: The acquisition of French legal terminology through the study of general principles in criminal law, advocacy, language rights and business law.

LAW 610.title: Internship in French
LAW 610.description: Participation in a French language clinical experience.

LAW 612.title: Advanced Private Law
LAW 612.description:
Advanced issues in private law (property, contract, tort, unjust enrichment and equity), including contemporary controversies over appropriate rights and remedies when different causes of action either converge or intersect.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Law 402, 406 and 551.

LAW 613.title: Conflict Of Laws
LAW 613.description: The doctrines and rules governing legal disputes cutting across provincial or national boundaries. Topics include jurisdiction, distinctions between substantive and procedural rules, the recognition and enforcement of foreign judgments, domicile, proof of foreign law, and the choice of law rules relating to private law (torts, contracts, property, succession and family law).

LAW 614.title: Advanced Topics French Common Law
LAW 614.description: A deeper review of French legal terminology through contextual and experiential learning. Topics include family law, jurisprudence, private international law, and appellate advocacy.

LAW 615.title: Advanced Civil Procedures
LAW 615.description:
The strategic use of the Alberta Rules of Court in civil proceedings with reference to related legislation and ethical requirements. Topics include commencement of proceedings, interlocutory and ex parte applications, discovery of persons and records, trial preparation, and the roles of the court.
Prerequisite or Corerquisite: Law 505.

LAW 616.title: Public Interest Theory
LAW 616.description:
The seminar component of the Public Interest Law Clinic examines public interest lawyering with coverage of legal principles and process. Topics include defining the public interest, the role of morality and ethics of public interest lawyers, how structures in the legal system shape opportunities for strategic litigation, and varying perspectives on justice, democracy, and the rule of law.

Corequisite(s): Law 620.

LAW 617.title: Alternative Energy Law: Renewable Energy & Efficiency
LAW 617.description:
The renewable energy and energy efficiency sectors. Topics include federalism, wind, small hydro, solar, biomass etc., energy conservation and demand side management, and access to energy infrastructure.
Prerequisite or Corerequisite(s): Law 503.

LAW 618.title: Corporate Finance Law
LAW 618.description:
Legal aspects of corporate finance transactions, including applicable regulatory frameworks. Topics may include equity and debt financing, secured transactions, asses and/or share purchase anad sale agreements, and takeover bids.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Law 509.

LAW 619.title: Estate Planning
LAW 619.description:
Personal dispositions of property, both inter vivos and on death, to achieve estate and succession planning objectives. Topics include trusts, corporations, wills, life insurance, buy-sell arrangements, income splitting, estate freezing, and tax deferral plans.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Law 527.

LAW 620.title: Public Interest Practice
LAW 620.description:
The practice component of the Public Interest Law Clinic offers experiential learning through supervised provision of legal services to clients dealing with public interest litigation and law reform matters. Lawyering skills developed include interviewing, legal research, advocacy, and file management.

Corequisite(s): Law 616.

Notes: This course is graded CR, D or F.

LAW 621.title: Corporate Governance & Litigation
LAW 621.description:
The principal concepts in corporate governance and their evolution in Canada; the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 and the related rules of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York Stock Exchange; the securities regulatory response of Canada to the adoption of Sarbanes-Oxley in the United States; and other current topics in corporate governance.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Law 505 and 509.

LAW 622.title: Law of the Sea
LAW 622.description: An examination of the key legal norms, actors, and institutions that govern international relations concerning maritime affairs, focusing on the 1982 UN Convention on the Law of the Sea.

LAW 623.title: Environmental Impact Assessment Law
LAW 623.description:
Environmental impact assessment (EIA) law and practice in Canada. Topics include the role of EIA in the regulatory process and as a planning tool, federalism, triggers, equivalency, harmonization, joint assessment, implementation of assessment decisions, adaptive management, strategic environmental assessment, the role of traditional knowledge, and public participation.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Law 503.

LAW 624.title: Environmental Law & Ethics
LAW 624.description: The ethical underpinning of enrionmental law, with a consideration of various views, including the land ethic, deep and shallow ecology, instrumental and utilitarian approaches, and inherent value.

LAW 625.title: Intellectual Property Transactions
LAW 625.description: Intellectual property transactions and strategies in a variety of industries in energy, information technology, and life sciences. Topics include open source IP, IP governance, management and best practices, valuation, ownership, improvements, co-ownership and collaboration, patent pools and standard setting organizations, software licensing and IT transactions, licensing, infringement management, and warranties.

LAW 626.title: International Development Law
LAW 626.description:
The role of law in promoting social and economic growth, with a focus on the rule of law as an instrument of development and the dialogue between the developed and less developed worlds through international agreements. Topics include the rules of international trade and finance, intellectual property, the environment and natural resources, and the war on terrorism.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: One of Law 549, 597 or 563.

LAW 627.title: International Environmental Law
LAW 627.description: The customary and treaty law rules applicable to global and transboundary environmental issues. Topics include air pollution, climate change, international wildlife law and trade, the international chemicals agreements liability regimes, and shared resources.

LAW 628.title: International Investment Law
LAW 628.description:
Investor protection in customary law and treaties, in particular NAFTA Chapter 11, bilateral investment treaties (BITs), and the Energy Charter; the main disciplines, including national treatment, most favoured nation treatment, fair and equitable treatment, and the rules pertaining to expropriation; soft law norms pertaining to investment; and relevant domestic law, including the Investment Canada Act.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Law 549 or 597.

LAW 630.title: International Petroleum Transactions
LAW 630.description: International business transactions in the context of the petroleum industry, including the various forms of state agreements; confidentiality agreements; study and bidding agreements; international joint operating agreements; agency agreements; and participation agreements; with attention to the key legal, business and ethical issues raised in negotiations.

LAW 631.title: International Tax Law
LAW 631.description:
The tax implications of both inbound and outbound investment and implications for structuring affiliates, with consideration of international tax treaties and foreign tax credit mechanisms.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Law 527.

LAW 632.title: Entrepreneurial Law
LAW 632.description: The legal and economic aspects of building a new venture, and the norms around legal and contractual structures in Canada and the United States. The focus is on advising an entrepreneur client in a start-up. Topics include creating the corporate structure, raising capital, hiring new employees, protecting intellectual property, founder-proofing the venture, and getting to acquisition or other liquidity event.

LAW 634.title: Law of Species and Spaces
LAW 634.description:
The principal federal and provincial laws governing the management of biological diversity, including protected area legislation and endangered species legislation. Explores the constitutional and common law fundamentals of wildlife law as well as contemporary disputes about species protection, ecosystem-level land management, and game ranch operations.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Law 503.

LAW 636.title: Municipal Law
LAW 636.description:
The legal position of local governments, including cities and regional governments. Topics include the powers of Municipal Councils and Districts, the duties and responsibilities of elected and appointed municipal officials, conflicts of interest, elections, the regulation and licensing of businesses, proprietary and contractual powers, tort and the public body, subdivision, land use planning, and the role of the courts.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Law 503.

LAW 637.title: Energy Law
LAW 637.description:
An overview of energy regulation, focusing on competition and pricing. Topics include the theory and process of energy regulation, regulatory jurisdiction, judicial review of energy regulation, regulation of natural gas and electricity prices, market restructuring, and deregulation. The course will familiarize students with the legal issues that arise when the legislature and regulators respond to market failures, and/or protect the public interest, in the provision of natural gas and electricity services.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Law 503.

LAW 638.title: Climate Change Law
LAW 638.description: An exploration of the international and domestic legal and policy framework relating to climate change. Students will learn how to address developing legal challenges associated with integrating climate change considerations into other areas of law.

LAW 640.title: Energy Transportation and Infrastructure
LAW 640.description: An exploration of transportation law and the governance of networked infrastructure from the perspective of the energy industry. Topics include the legal and policy aspects arising from the transportation of energy commodities, and the construction and regulation of infrastructure.

LAW 641.title: Oil & Gas & Mining Taxation
LAW 641.description: The resource regime rules of the Income Tax Act as applied to the oil and gas and mining sectors. Topics include: operations subject to the resource regime; the treatment of property costs and common industry expenditures (i.e. applicable "tax pools" and their characteristics): resource industry "subsidies" (e.g. flow-through share financing, investment tax credits); the avoidance provisions (e.g. the successor rules); and the treatment of foreign operations of a Canadian resident taxpayer.

LAW 642.title: Law and Development
LAW 642.description: An examination of the relationship between law and development, and the critical question of how law furthers or hinders development objectives. Such objectives include economic growth and wealth creation, but also human rights, equality, and the environment.

LAW 644.title: National Security Law Lab
LAW 644.description: The laws and policies governing national security operations and institutions in Canada. Emphasis is on anti-terrorism laws, espionage, cyber, and emergency response mandates and authorities.

LAW 645.title: Pollution Control & Waste Management Law
LAW 645.description:
The provincial and federal pollution control regimes for air and water pollution and for the handling, storage, treatment, and disposal of hazardous and non-hazardous wastes.  Topics include federalism; regulatory and non-regulatory approaches to pollution from "point" and "non-point" sources; cumulative pollutant loads; the "precautionary" and "polluter pays" principles; and liability for contaminated sites.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Law 503 and 531.

LAW 646.title: Bennett Jones Health Law Moot
LAW 646.description: The development of advocacy and other lawyering skills in the context of health law in Canada.

LAW 647.title: Regulatory Theory & the Law
LAW 647.description:
The main theories that explain or justify government regulation, including correction for market failure, political economy or public choice, and deliberative democracy. The relationship between those theories and the development and implementation of regulatory legislation, regulation, and public policy.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Law 503.

LAW 648.title: Securities Law
LAW 648.description: The regulation of capital market participants; the issuance of, and trades in, securities of companies, with an emphasis on Alberta and the National Instruments enacted by the Canadian securities regulator; the theory of securities regulation; as well as enforcement and compliance.

LAW 650.title: Business Skills for Lawyers
LAW 650.description: The non-legal skills required by lawyers working in-house or with business clients.  Topics may include reading and analyzing financial statements; understanding cash flow models; business valuation; negotiation; capital markets; crisis management; project management.

LAW 652.title: Willms & Shier Environmental Law Moot
LAW 652.description: The development of advocacy and other lawyering skills in the context of environmental law.

LAW 653.title: Directed Research
LAW 653.description: A supervised research project involving the in-depth examination of a legal problem or area of concern not normally covered in a substantive or procedural course and which provides the basis for an article, research paper, brief, memorial, draft legislation, etc. Admission to this course depends on the availability of a Faculty member to supervise the particular projects.
LAW 653.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Faculty.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LAW 654.title: Bowman National Tax Moot
LAW 654.description: The development of advocacy and other lawyering skills in the context of Canadian tax law.

LAW 656.title: Mergers and Acquisitions
LAW 656.description: Key legal and financial concepts for mergers and acquisitions.  Topics may include structuring transactions, the required legal documentation, securities legislation, director and officer responsibilities, negotiations, financing, defensive tactics, due diligence, employment and other issues.

LAW 660.title: Selected Topics in Aboriginal and Indigenous Law
LAW 660.description: Aboriginal or Indigenous focused subject areas, either doctrinal or theoretical.
LAW 660.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the JD program.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LAW 663.title: Dispute Resolution Clinical
LAW 663.description:
Interest-based, consensus-building dispute resolution processes to enhance understanding of dispute resolution theory, which will be applied through placements drawing on the mentorship of lawyers and dispute resolution practitioners engaged in court-annexed or private mediation, facilitation, collaborative law, and other processes.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Law 508.

Notes: This course is graded CR, D or F.

LAW 667.title: Advanced Public Law
LAW 667.description: Selected issues in constitutional law at the advanced level. Topics may include constitutional amendment, comparative approaches to rights, comparative federalism, the role of international law in constitutional interpretation, the legitimacy of judicial review, evidentiary issues in constitutional litigation, the role of social movements, and strategic litigation in securing constitutional rights.

LAW 673.title: Jessup Moot
LAW 673.description: Preparation for and participation in the Philip C. Jessup International Law Moot Court Competition.

LAW 674.title: Business Venture Clinic
LAW 674.description:
A clinical seminar where students work with startup companies and entrepreneurs. Students may prepare memos and drafts of business agreements. Students receive feedback on their written work from practicing lawyers.

Notes: This course is graded CR, D or F.

LAW 676.title: Corporate Law Summer Institute
LAW 676.description:
Successful Canadian companies are nearly always oriented towards large international markets. They depend on their lawyers to assist them in operating around the world, including entering into transactions with partners in other markets. Students will explore international business transactions and the legal issues arising from these transactions while studying abroad in locations such as London, England. 
 
Prerequisite: Consent of the Faculty.

Notes: Students will also be required to obtain Faculty Consent to drop or withdraw from this course. 
 
MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LAW 677.title: Canadian Corporate/Securities Law Moot
LAW 677.description: The development of appellate advocacy and other lawyering skills in the context of corporate and securities law in Canada.

LAW 678.title: The Gale Cup Moot
LAW 678.description: The development of appellate advocacy and other lawyering skills in the context of preparation for and participation in the national Gale Cup Moot.

LAW 683.title: Advanced Family Law
LAW 683.description:
Selected topics in family law, including matrimonial property; division of pensions; international family law; and the law relating to children, including regulatory aspects (e.g. child welfare).

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Law 515.

LAW 685.title: Business Clinical
LAW 685.description:
The skills employed by a corporate solicitor in the context of one or more transactions. Skills covered may include drafting, negotiating, research, advocacy, and transaction management, in simulated or real transactions.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Law 509.

Notes: This course is graded CR, D or F.

LAW 686.title: SLA Clinical Theory
LAW 686.description:
Student Legal Assistance. Learn elements of good lawyering, forming your professional identity, ethical and practical issues in serving disadvantaged people in a variety of areas of law.

Corequisite(s): Law 688.

LAW 687.title: Criminal Justice Clinical
LAW 687.description:
A clinical seminar in elements of criminal law covering topical, practical, and ethical issues in the practice of criminal law. Three short placements with Crown and defence lawyers and a provincial court judge.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Law 511.

Notes: This course is graded CR, D or F.

LAW 688.title: SLA Clinical Practice
LAW 688.description:
Student Legal Assistance. Advanced experiential learning in a clinical setting. Learn to effectively represent disadvantaged clients while developing interviewing, counselling, practice management and courtroom advocacy skills.

Corequisite(s): Law 686.

Notes: This course is graded CR, D or F.

LAW 689.title: Family Law Clinical Seminar
LAW 689.description:
A clinical seminar in elements of family law practice. The clinical experience may be obtained through simulated exercises, supervised handling of files and/or placements. Topics include Chambers advocacy, marital dispute consultations and drafting of a settlement.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Law 515.

Notes: This course is graded CR, D or F.

LAW 690.title: Western Canada MacIntyre Cup Trial Competition
LAW 690.description: The development of trial advocacy and other lawyering skills in the context of preparation for and participation in the Western Canada Trial Competition. Credit for this competition does not preclude credit for the Sopinka Cup.

LAW 691.title: Natural Resources, Energy and Environmental Law Clinical
LAW 691.description:
A clinical seminar involving placements in any one of the following practice areas: energy law, resources law, water law, and environmental law.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: One of Law 531, 571, 573, 583 or 637.

Notes: This course is graded CR, D or F.

LAW 692.title: Selected Topics I
LAW 692.description:
A variety of subject areas, either doctrinal or theoretical. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LAW 693.title: Selected Topics II
LAW 693.description:
A variety of subject areas, either doctrinal or theoretical. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LAW 694.title: Selected Topics III
LAW 694.description:
A variety of subject areas, either doctrinal or theoretical. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LAW 695.title: External Competitions
LAW 695.description: The development of advocacy and other lawyering skills in the context of preparation for and participation in an external competition not otherwise the subject of a course. A written component is generally required.

LAW 696.title: Clinical Studies
LAW 696.description: Participation in a clinical experience not otherwise the subject of a clinical course.

LAW 697.title: Corporate Tax
LAW 697.description:
The provisions of the Income Tax Act applicable to corporations and their shareholders. Topics include the classification of corporations for tax purposes, the taxation of corporate income, the taxation of corporate distributions, and the taxation of various types of corporate reorganizations.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Law 509 and 527.

LAW 698.title: Immigration & Refugee Law
LAW 698.description:
Basic principles, policies, and procedures governing immigration and refugee law. Topics include refugee law and status; selection and admission of immigrants; inadmissible and removable classes; exemptions and minister's permits; and appeals and judicial review in the federal court, including Charter issues.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Law 503.

LAW 699.title: Labour Law
LAW 699.description:
The law governing unionized workplaces in Canada. Topics include freedom of association, the status of participants, union organization and certification, unfair labour practices, collective bargaining, the collective agreement and arbitration, industrial conflict, the duty of fair representation, and interaction between the labour law regime and the common-law of employment.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Law 503.

LAW 703.title: Graduate Seminar in Legal Research and Methodology
LAW 703.description: Preparation for developing, researching and writing a thesis or major research paper. The distinctive nature of legal scholarship and its professional context will be explored. Students will be introduced to specific research techniques and to the challenges of comparative and cross-cultural work.
LAW 703.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the LLM or PhD program.

LAW 705.title: Graduate Seminar in Legal Theory
LAW 705.description: An exploration of schools of legal theory, with the goal of helping students situate their graduate research within one or more of those approaches to legal scholarship. The seminar is structured around a series of readings describing different theoretical approaches and applying these approaches to areas of research.
LAW 705.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the LLM or PhD program.

LAW 707.title: Major Research Paper I
LAW 707.description: Reflects extensive research on a topic in law and proposes a solution to a problem or presents a critical evaluation of an issue in this area of law. Law 707 establishes the foundations of the major research paper, providing opportunities for course-based LLM students to propose their research projects to other students and to acquire feedback on methods, sources and secondary literature.
LAW 707.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Graduate Director.

Also known as: (formerly Law 706)

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

LAW 708.title: Major Research Paper II
LAW 708.description:
Building on Law 707 and in consultation with their supervisors, students complete an original research paper.

Corequisite(s): Law 707.

Also known as: (formerly Law 706)

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

LAW 709.title: Special Topics in Law
LAW 709.description:
Directed readings course aimed at preparing doctoral students for writing their proposals or for acquiring legal knowledge in their area of research.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LEAD 401.title: Foundations in Ethical Leadership
LEAD 401.description: Evidence-based approach to leadership with an emphasis on self-awareness and personal development. Students will learn the behaviours that predict leader emergence and leadership effectiveness.

LEAD 501.title: Leadership Studies Capstone
LEAD 501.description: Students advance their practical understanding of effective leadership behaviours, and build capacity to facilitate leadership skills in others.
LEAD 501.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Embedded Certificate in Leadership Studies, and Leadership Studies 401 or Management Studies 453.

LING 201.title: Introduction to Linguistics I
LING 201.description:
Introduction to the scientific study of language, including the analysis of word, sentence, and sound structure, and the exploration of language as a human, biological, social, and historical phenomenon.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Linguistics 201 and either 205 or 207 will not be allowed.

LING 202.title: Introduction to Linguistics II
LING 202.description: Further introduction to the scientific study of language. Topics include: language change, language acquisition, language families and areas, sociolinguistics, psycholinguistics, bilingualism, and writing systems.

LING 221.title: Modern English Grammar
LING 221.description:
A comprehensive exploration of contemporary English. The course is based on modern linguistic analysis, but also includes traditional grammatical terminology, as well as language change, attitudes to language varieties and problems in usage.

Also known as:  (formerly Linguistics 321)

LING 223.title: Language and Advertising
LING 223.description: An investigation of the nature of persuasive messages from the perspective of linguistic theory. Topics may include truth and falsity, implication, ambiguity, and context-dependence.

LING 225.title: Varieties of English
LING 225.description: Survey and analysis of the varieties of English currently spoken in the world, including various dialects, especially Canadian and American, and English-based pidgins and creoles.

LING 227.title: Rap Linguistics
LING 227.description: The leading music genre known as rap is dominated by language. Explores how this creatively flourishing art-form relates to language science. An examination of the manipulation of sounds, words, grammar, and meaning in rap, and what it reveals about language in the mind and in society.

LING 301.title: Syntax I
LING 301.description: Introduction tosyntax.Emphasis on tree-drawing and basic argumentation skills. Topics may include: syntactic categories; grammatical, thematic, and structural relations; syntactic movement.

LING 302.title: Language in Humans & Machines
LING 302.description: Overview of key properties of the learning and use of language in humans and machines, discussing both overlap and divergence, as well as the implications for machines as language partners for humans. No previous background in Linguistics or Computer Science is required.

LING 303.title: Phonology I
LING 303.description: Theory and practice of phonological analysis: the classical phoneme; distinctive features and their organization; methods of analysis; underlying and surface representations; rules and derivations.

LING 309.title: Language And Power
LING 309.description: The nature of the linguistic resources used to create, enhance and justify positions of dominance or subordination, or to influence and persuade populations. Examples drawn from the discourse of gender and ethnic relations, government and business.

LING 316.title: Language Acquisition I
LING 316.description: Introduction to basic ideas and issues in first- and second-language acquisition. Adopts a linguistic approach, viewing language acquisition as the acquisition of a "mental grammar", looking at examples from sound, sentence structure, word learning and meaning. Focus on defining the essential properties of an explanatory theory of language acquisition.

LING 319.title: Introduction To Semantics
LING 319.description: Introduction to the study of conventional meaning Topics may include: word meaning,, propositional and predicate logic, properties of quantifiers, definite and indefinite descriptions, and pragmatics.

LING 337.title: Introduction to Speech-Language Pathology
LING 337.description: A comprehensive overview of the subject including: basic components of speech and language, normal language development, communication disorders, and current professional issues.

LING 341.title: Phonetics I
LING 341.description: Intensive practice in the perception, production and transcription of speech sounds accompanied by an introduction to the physiology and acoustics of speech.

LING 349.title: Language and Mind
LING 349.description:
An overview of central issues in the study of language and its relationship to the human mind. Topics may include the
nature/nurture debate, human specialization for language, and theories of mental representation. 
Prequisite: Linguistics 201.

LING 353.title: Historical Linguistics I
LING 353.description: Central topics in the study of language change including: principles and methods of linguistic reconstruction; universals, typologies, and the explanation of language change; sources of language change with a consideration of acquisitional and sociolinguistic factors.

LING 373.title: Introduction to Sociolinguistics
LING 373.description: Social differentiation of language in terms of the gender, socio-economic status and geographical distribution of speakers.

LING 377.title: Introduction to Pragmatics
LING 377.description: An introduction to the study of context-dependent meaning. Topics may include: deixis, reference, implicature, presupposition, speech acts, and information structure.

LING 381.title: (ENGL 381) The History of English
LING 381.description: An introduction to important changes and stages in the history of English including its Indo-European and Germanic origins and a consideration of Modern English grammar and orthography from a historical perspective.
LING 381.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Linguistics 201.

Also known as: English 381.

LING 401.title: Syntax II
LING 401.description: A theoretically grounded approach to syntax using data from a variety of languages. Constructing and evaluating syntactic hypotheses. May involve collecting data from a native speaker of a foreign language.

LING 407.title: Morphology I
LING 407.description:
An introduction to the study of word-structure. Inflectional and word-formation morphology, morphological processes, morphological organization, interfaces with phonology and syntax. Practical problems in word analysis.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Linguistics 303.

LING 416.title: Language Acquisition II
LING 416.description: In-depth investigation of issues in language acquisition. Topics include differentiating populations of learners (monolingual, bilingual and delayed first-language learners, child and adult second-language learners, heritage language learners) and the exploration of different kinds of research tasks and methods.

LING 419.title: Advanced Semantics
LING 419.description: Continuing study of conventional meaning accompanied by an introduction to some technical tools used in the field of semantics. Topics may include: compositionality, sets and functions, tense, aspect, modality, and event semantics.

LING 441.title: Phonetics II
LING 441.description: Continuing study of the anatomy, physiology and acoustics of speech and related issues in speech research, paralleled by laboratory work in the acoustic and physiological analysis of speech.

LING 451.title: History of Linguistic Thought
LING 451.description: A survey of major schools of linguistic thought. Focus on the origin and development of concepts central to contemporary linguistic theory.

LING 453.title: Historical Linguistics II
LING 453.description: Theoretical approaches to current topics in the field of historical linguistics. Research methods and practical skills in data collection and analysis.

LING 455.title: Typology
LING 455.description: Study of the unity and diversity of the world's languages. How do the grammars of individual languages differ from each other, and in what ways are they all alike? Which characteristics are common across languages, and which are rare? An overview of the methodology and main results of typological research. Students work with data from unfamiliar languages.

LING 467.title: (PSYC 467) Psycholinguistics
LING 467.description: Exploration of the cognitive, neuropsychological, and social processes that underlie language abilities, with reference to linguistic theory.

LING 505.title: Field Methods for Indigenous Languages
LING 505.description: Principles and techniques of collecting, editing and analysing elicited linguistic data and associated problems. Practical experience with language consultant(s).

LING 507.title: Morphology II
LING 507.description: A survey of issues in morphological theory.
LING 507.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Linguistics 401 and 407, or consent of the Department.

LING 511.title: Advanced Syntactic Analysis
LING 511.description: A survey of current work in syntactic theory.

LING 512.title: Advanced Phonological Analysis
LING 512.description: An advanced course on current work in phonological theory.

LING 516.title: Topics in Language Acquisition
LING 516.description: Exploration of a selected topic related to current research in language acquisition. Topics may include current research on a specific population of learners, a particular research methodology, and the acquisition of a specific learning problem (e.g., phonotactics, intonation, binding, quantification).
LING 516.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Linguistics 416.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LING 519.title: (PHIL519)Formal Semantics of Natural Language
LING 519.description: Central issues in the logical semantics of natural language, focusing on topics such as quantification, scope, and the interpretation of pronouns.

LING 531.title: Survey of Indigenous Languages of the Americas
LING 531.description: A survey of the indigenous languages of the Americas, including classifications of language families and structural analysis of selected languages.

LING 542.title: Topics in Phonetics
LING 542.description: Exploration of a selected topic related to current research in phonetics. Topics may include theories of speech perception, speech production, the relationship between phonetics and phonology, sources of phonetic variation, or experimental methodologies used in phonetics research.
LING 542.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Linguistics 441

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LING 551.title: Topics in Linguistic Analysis
LING 551.description: Linguistic analysis of a language or language family.
LING 551.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Linguistics 301 or 303.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LING 553.title: Topics in Historical Linguistics
LING 553.description: An advanced course in the theory of historical linguistics.
LING 553.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Linguistics 453.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LING 560.title: Statistics for Linguistic Research
LING 560.description: Introduction to basic statistical concepts, methods of analysis, and quantitative modelling techniques, with a focus on their application to the unique properties of language research and linguistic data.

LING 571.title: Corpus and Experimental Methods for Syntax and Semantics
LING 571.description: Introduction to programming methods for the development and searching of text corpora, as well as the design and implementation of studies using open source software. Study design will be introduced through critical reading of studies covering a range of syntactic and semantic phenomena.

LING 598.title: Honours Seminar
LING 598.description: Students carry out a specific research project under the supervision of a staff member and submit a thesis acceptable to the Linguistics Division of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
LING 598.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Linguistics Honours degree program.

LING 599.title: Advanced Topics in Linguistics
LING 599.description: Seminar in linguistics for advanced students.
LING 599.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Linguistics Division of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LING 600.title: Introduction to Graduate Studies in Linguistics
LING 600.description:
This course provides an introduction to areas of research and theoretical orientations in which faculty in this department specialize, as well as to research and professional skills.				

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

LING 605.title: Field Methods
LING 605.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.  

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT.

LING 611.title: Advanced Syntactic Analysis
LING 611.description: An advanced course in syntactic theory with focus on analytical and critical skills required for conducting syntactic research.

LING 613.title: Advanced Phonological Analysis
LING 613.description: An advanced course in phonological theory with focus on analytical and critical skills required for conducting phonological research.

LING 635.title: Analysis of a Language or Language Family
LING 635.description: Seminar in the analysis of a selected language or language family

LING 660.title: Quantitative Modeling of Linguistic Data
LING 660.description: Introduction to basic statistical concepts, methods of analysis, and quantitative modeling techniques, with a focus on their application to the unique properties of language research and linguistics data.

LING 671.title: Methods for Corpus and Experimental Studies in Syntax and Semantics
LING 671.description: Introduction to programming methods for the development and searching of text corpora, as well as the design and implementation of studies using open source software. Study design will be introduced through critical reading of studies covering a range of syntactic and semantic phenomena. Programming skills to convert experiment software output into a format suitable for statistical analysis will also be covered.

LING 699.title: Conference and Reading Course
LING 699.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the program.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LING 797.title: Senior Doctoral Seminar
LING 797.description: A forum for discussing and presenting candidacy paper research, thesis research, and conference presentations/publications in preparation.
LING 797.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

LING 631.01.title: Phonetics
LING 631.01.description: Seminar in core areas of theoretical linguistics.

LING 631.02.title: Phonology
LING 631.02.description: Seminar in core areas of theoretical linguistics.

LING 631.03.title: Morphology
LING 631.03.description: Seminar in core areas of theoretical linguistics.

LING 631.04.title: Syntax
LING 631.04.description: Seminar in core areas of theoretical linguistics.

LING 631.05.title: Semantics
LING 631.05.description: Seminar in core areas of theoretical linguistics.

LLAC 600.title: Introduction to Graduate Studies in Languages, Literatures and Cultures
LLAC 600.description: An introduction to research and professional skills. Students will learn about and apply skills in research information sources, including the library; source citation; grant and conference proposal writing; presenting research in a range of venues; and preparing for a diversified job market.
LLAC 600.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the LLAC graduate program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

LLAC 601.title: Additional Language Pedagogy
LLAC 601.description: An introduction to the field of second language teaching and learning with a historical overview of the field. Presents concepts from the related fields of applied linguistics, psychology and education. Students will have the opportunity to observe university language courses, analyze language textbooks, and develop a statement of teaching philosophy.
LLAC 601.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the LLAC graduate program.

LLAC 602.title: Research Methods in Applied Linguistics
LLAC 602.description: An overview of theory and research methods with a focus on empirical research in the field of applied linguistics. Students will read and critique recent studies, develop research questions, and explore ways in which to answer their questions.
LLAC 602.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the LLAC graduate program.

LLAC 603.title: Theory and Methods of Literary and Cultural Studies
LLAC 603.description: Examines theories and approaches in literary, cultural and film criticism. Students will develop research questions and explore ways in which to answer these questions as they relate to cultural artefacts (literary and filmic) in languages other than English.
LLAC 603.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the LLAC graduate program.

LLAC 612.title: Topics in Applied Linguistics
LLAC 612.description: An introduction to research in a specific area of applied linguistics.
LLAC 612.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the LLAC graduate program.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LLAC 614.title: Topics in Transcultural Studies
LLAC 614.description: An introduction to research in a specific area of transcultural studies.
LLAC 614.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the LLAC graduate program.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LLAC 699.title: Directed Studies
LLAC 699.description: Includes a general or specific applied linguistic or transcultural studies topic; or the detailed study of an author, period, genre; or any literary problem not dealt with in the existing graduate courses.
LLAC 699.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the LLAC graduate program.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LWFT 402.title: Contracts
LWFT 402.description:
A legal and policy analysis of the basic principles and fundamental concepts of the law of contracts as they relate to commercial and consumer transactions. The formation of contracts including offer and acceptance, and consideration; estoppel; privity; terms of contract, including exemption clauses; standard form contracts; bailment; mistake, misrepresentation and unconscionability; termination, including the doctrine of frustration; breach and remedies for breach; dispute resolution processes. Emphasis is placed not only on a knowledge of rules and principles, their historical derivation, rationale, efficacy and social validity, but also upon their creative use to both avoid and resolve disputes.

Prerequisite: Admission to the Foreign Trained Lawyers Program and consent of the Faculty of Law. 

Also known as: Law 402

LWFT 404.title: Property
LWFT 404.description:
An examination of the fundamental concepts of property law and the types of property interests recognized by Anglo-Canadian law. The historical evolution of property concepts; the basic concepts of possession, ownership and title; estates and other interests in land such as joint and concurrent ownership, easements, covenants, licences, mortgages, future interests and perpetuities; the landlord and tenant relationship; the land titles system of registration of title to land; the social constraints upon property use and disposition; and property rights of aboriginal peoples.

Prerequisite: Admission to the Foreign Trained Lawyers Program and consent of the Faculty of Law. 

Also known as: Law 404

LWFT 406.title: Torts
LWFT 406.description:
An analysis and critique of the law of torts, primarily the law of negligence, with personal injury as the main focus, although other torts will also be introduced. The nature of tort law and its process; an anatomy of the law of negligence - the nature and extent of liability, defences, remedies, and the assessment of damages; intentional torts; economic torts; strict liability; bailment; the impact of private insurance on the tort system; alternative forms of compensation.

Prerequisite: Admission to the Foreign Trained Lawyers Program and consent of the Faculty of Law. 

Also known as: Law 406

LWFT 505.title: Civil Procedure
LWFT 505.description:
A detailed examination of issues which arise in the progress of a civil action from first meeting the client through to judgment in the Alberta Court of Queen's Bench. The Alberta Rules of Court are set in the context of the values underlying them. What sort of civil litigation system do we want? What sort of system do we in fact have? Particular attention if paid to the linkages between the apparently discrete components of the process as set out in the Rules, linkages at the levels of both the underlying values and of actual practice. The use of procedures under the Rules to anticipate and resolve evidence problems that might arise at trial is stressed. Interprovincial and international aspect of the civil litigation process are also considered.

Prerequisite: Admission to the Foreign Trained Lawyers Program and consent of the Faculty of Law. 

Also known as: Law 505

LWFT 507.title: Evidence
LWFT 507.description:
An examination of the fundamental concept of evidence law, including the traditional rules as compared to the emerging principled approach, and such core and primary topics as: the adversary system; relevance and discretionary exclusion; privilege; burdens of proof; character evidence; judicial notice; competence and compellability; examination of witnesses; hearsay; opinion evidence.

Prerequisite: Admission to the Foreign Trained Lawyers Program and consent of the Faculty of Law. 

Also known as: Law 507

LWFT 509.title: Business Associations
LWFT 509.description:
The common forms of business organization, including the law of agency, partnerships, limited partnerships, and corporations, with a focus on the corporation and the rights and responsibilities of shareholders and directors. Topics will include fiduciary relationships in a commercial context.

Prerequisite: Admission to the Foreign Trained Lawyers Program and consent of the Faculty of Law. 

Also known as: Law 509

LWFT 515.title: Family Law
LWFT 515.description:
An analysis of the legal principles affecting the rights and responsibilities of the members of the family. Topics include constitutional issues, marriage, marriage contracts, common law marriage, child neglect and abuse, custody and access, guardianship, adoption, separation, divorce, nullity, spousal and child maintenance, and matrimonial property. Stress is placed on the process of family law and the appropriate role for lawyers and judges.

Prerequisite: Admission to the Foreign Trained Lawyers Program and consent of the Faculty of Law. 

Also known as: Law 515

LWFT 527.title: Basic Tax Law
LWFT 527.description:
The basic language and concepts of taxation and identification of taxation issues. Topics include the unit of taxation, the meaning and taxation of income, taxation of benefits, the type and scope of deductions available for business income, and the taxation of capital gains including gains (and losses) on taxpayer assets.

Prerequisite: Admission to the Foreign Trained Lawyers Program and consent of the Faculty of Law. 

Also known as: Law 527

LWFT 575.title: Remedies
LWFT 575.description:
Judicial remedies at common law and equity for tort and breach of contract, including personal injury and property damage. Themes include compensating loss, disgorging gain, and punishing civil wrong; prohibiting and compelling defendant behaviour; loss-based, gain-based, and punitive damages; and injunctions and specific performance.

Prerequisite: Admission to the Foreign Trained Lawyers Program and consent of the Faculty of Law. 

Also known as: Law 575

LWFT 598.title: Trusts
LWFT 598.description:
The concept of the trust and its development in equity and its relationship to other legal concepts. Topics include the various types of trusts; constituting, administering and terminating the trust; trustee duties and powers; variation of trusts; breach of trust; and the doctrine of tracing.

Prerequisite: Admission to the Foreign Trained Lawyers Program and consent of the Faculty of Law. 

Also known as: Law 598

LWSO 201.title: Introduction To Legal Studies
LWSO 201.description: Overview of the role of law in society. Examination of different concepts of law. Study of legal rules, institutions, processes and personnel in social context. Discussion of construction and exercise of the power of law. Emphasis on Canadian law and legal system.

LWSO 203.title: Introduction to Legal Knowledge
LWSO 203.description: Examination of the philosophy and science of law as tools of social engineering. Students will be introduced to tort, contract, property and criminal law and will review different schools of thought and legal movements specific to these areas of law. Current legal developments (including decided Canadian cases) will be covered to illustrate how concepts such as risk, negligence, neighbour principle, contractual obligations, offer and acceptance, consideration, remedies and punishment play out in contemporary Canadian society.

LWSO 313.title: Research Methods in Law and Society
LWSO 313.description: Research and writing methods including legal research basics, legal analysis, qualitative strategies in socio-legal studies, academic writing, and academic methodology.

LWSO 335.title: Equality Issues
LWSO 335.description: An examination of the ability of the law to guarantee equality. Issues of gender, racial and class equality will be explored. Topics may include employment law, civil law, criminal law, reproductive rights and family law. All material is studied as it pertains to the Canadian legal culture.

LWSO 337.title: Self-Regulation
LWSO 337.description: Examines how individuals and groups create, maintain, and follow non-legal codes of conduct and, in turn, regulate themselves and society. Students will be introduced to concepts of self-governance and moral regulation found in social manners, community standards, religious beliefs, as well as, consciously "legislated" group mechanisms such as professional codes of conduct, mission statements, and corporate governance practices.

LWSO 401.title: Special Topics in Law and Society
LWSO 401.description: An examination of selected topics in Law and Society.
LWSO 401.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units in courses labelled Law and Society at the 300 level.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LWSO 413.title: Liberalism
LWSO 413.description: An examination of the fundamental conceptions of rights and freedoms in the works of J.S. Mill and twentieth- and twenty-first-century philosophers. The treatment of these concepts in contemporary law and their role in contemporary legal and social issues are explored as well.
LWSO 413.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 45 units including Law and Society 335 and 337, and admission to the Law and Society program.

LWSO 415.title: Socio-legal Issues in Contemporary Liberal Societies
LWSO 415.description: An examination of the ways in which fundamental premises of legal liberalism, such as fairness, equality, and individual liberty, intersect with each other and with other key social values and premises. May include privacy, the nature of the rights attached to property, the different understandings of democracy operating in different countries, and the extent to which the state should support religion.
LWSO 415.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 45 units including Law and Society 413, and admission to the Law and Society program.

LWSO 425.title: Law and Technology
LWSO 425.description: Examines the relationship between law and legal institutions on the one hand, and science and technology on the other. Through close readings of texts and in-depth class discussion, students will investigate thematic issues such as the role of law in regulating science and technology; challenges to law raised by scientific discoveries and new technologies; and the influence of science and technology on law and legal institutions.
LWSO 425.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 60 units including Law and Society 335, 337.

LWSO 501.title: Directed Study
LWSO 501.description: Supervised individual study of a special topic.
LWSO 501.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

LWSO 590.title: Law and Society Honours Thesis and Seminar
LWSO 590.description: Students will conduct an independent research project under the direction of a supervisor. In the seminar, students will discuss and present their projects and other topics relevant to conducting research.
LWSO 590.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from the list of Research Methods Courses within Courses Constituting the Field of Law and Society; admission to the Law and Society Honours program; and consent of the Department.

LWSO 591.title: Integrative Seminar
LWSO 591.description: An advanced seminar integrating philosophical, theoretical, social, and legal approaches to understanding the relationship between law and society.
LWSO 591.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  78 units including Law and Society 413 and 415, and admission to the Law and Society major.

MATH 177.title: Further Topics from Mathematics 277
MATH 177.description: An overview of the basic notions in multivariate calculus: vector functions and differentiation, curves and parametrization, functions of several variables, partial differentiation, differentiability, implicit functions, extreme values.

MATH 205.title: Mathematical Explorations
MATH 205.description: A mathematics appreciation course. Topics selected by the instructor to provide a contemporary mathematical perspective and experiences in mathematical thinking. May include historical material on the development of classical mathematical ideas as well as the evolution of recent mathematics.
MATH 205.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 30-1, 30-2, 212 or Mathematics 2 (offered by Continuing Education).

MATH 209.title: Applied and Computational Linear Algebra for Energy Engineers
MATH 209.description: An introduction to systems of linear equations, vectors in Euclidean space, matrix algebra, linear transformations, eigenvalues and engenvectors. Geometrical applications and computing techniques will be emphasized. Students will complete a project using mathematical software.
MATH 209.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Energy Engineering Program.

MATH 211.title: Linear Methods I
MATH 211.description: An introduction to systems of linear equations, vectors in Euclidean space and matrix algebra. Additional topics include linear transformations, determinants, complex numbers, eigenvalues, and applications.
MATH 211.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 30-1, 212 or Mathematics 2 (offered by Continuing Education).

MATH 212.title: Mathematical Ways of Thinking
MATH 212.description: A mathematical exploration course focused on investigating fundamental mathematical concepts and their applications. The course is designed to prepare students for further study in mathematics and to meet the mathematical requirements for their program of study. Learners will build conceptual understanding together with technical skill in applying the ideas covered in the course to solve problems. This course pairs elements from high school mathematics and introductory university mathematics with Indigenous Ways of Knowing.
MATH 212.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 20-1, 20-2 or 30-2 and admission to an Indigenous Pathway program.

MATH 213.title: Linear Algebra I
MATH 213.description: A rigorous introduction to the theory of vector spaces, with an emphasis on proof writing and abstract reasoning. Topics include fields, subspaces, bases and dimension, linear transformations, determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors.
MATH 213.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): A grade of 90 per cent or higher in both Mathematics 30-1 and Mathematics 31 or consent of the Department.

MATH 249.title: Introductory Calculus
MATH 249.description: An introduction to single variable calculus. Limits, derivatives and integrals of algebraic, exponential, logarithmic and trigonometric functions play a central role. Additional topics include applications of differentiation; the fundamental theorem of calculus, improper integrals and applications of integration.
MATH 249.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 30-1, 212 or Mathematics 2 (offered by Continuing Education).

MATH 265.title: University Calculus I
MATH 265.description: An introduction to single variable calculus intended for students with credit in high school calculus. Limits, derivatives, and integrals of algebraic, exponential, logarithmic and trigonometric functions play a central role. Additional topics include applications of differentiation; the fundamental theorem of calculus, improper integrals and applications of integration. Differential calculus in several variables will also be introduced.
MATH 265.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 30-1, 212 or Mathematics 2 (offered by Continuing Education); and Mathematics 31 or Mathematics 3 (offered by Continuing Education).

MATH 267.title: University Calculus II
MATH 267.description: A concluding treatment of single variable calculus and an introduction to calculus in several variables. Single variable calculus: techniques of integration, sequences, series, convergence tests, and Taylor series. Calculus of several variables: partial differentiation, multiple integration, parametric equations, and applications

MATH 271.title: Discrete Mathematics
MATH 271.description: An introduction to proof techniques and abstract mathematical reasoning: sets, relations and functions; mathematical induction; integers, primes, divisibility and modular arithmetic; counting and combinatorics; elements of probability, discrete random variables and Bayes' theorem.

MATH 273.title: Numbers and Proofs
MATH 273.description: A rigorous introduction to proof techniques and abstract mathematical reasoning with an emphasis on number systems: functions, sets and relations; the integers, prime numbers, divisibility and modular arithmetic; induction and recursion; real numbers; Cauchy sequences and completeness; complex numbers.
MATH 273.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): A grade of 90 per cent or higher in both Mathematics 30-1 and 31 or consent of the Department.

MATH 275.title: Calculus for Engineers and Scientists
MATH 275.description: An extensive treatment of differential and integral calculus in a single variable, with an emphasis on applications. Differentiation: derivative laws, the mean value theorem, optimization, curve sketching and other applications. Integral calculus: the fundamental theorem of calculus, techniques of integration, improper integrals, and areas of planar regions. Infinite series: power series, Taylor's theorem and Taylor series.
MATH 275.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 30-1 or Mathematics 2 (offered by Continuing Education); and Mathematics 31 or Mathematics 3 (offered by Continuing Education).

MATH 277.title: Multivariable Calculus for Engineers and Scientists
MATH 277.description: An introduction to calculus of several real variables: curves and parametrizations, partial differentiation, the chain rule, implicit functions; integration in two and three variables and applications; optimization and Lagrange multipliers.

MATH 305.title: (EDUC 305) Inside Mathematics
MATH 305.description: An exploration of the usually tacit elements of mathematical concepts and processes, the course focuses on strategies for unpacking concepts and for sustained engagement in inquiry.

MATH 307.title: Complex Analysis I
MATH 307.description: An initial treatment of complex analytic functions in a single variable. Topics include differentiation, Cauchy-Riemann equations, line integration, Cauchy's theorem and Cauchy's integral formula, Taylor's theorem, the residue theorem, and applications to definite integrals.
MATH 307.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 211 or 213; and Mathematics 267 or 277; and Mathematics 271 or 273.

MATH 311.title: Linear Methods II
MATH 311.description: An introductory course in the theory of abstract vector spaces: linear independence, spanning sets, basis and dimension; linear transformations and the rank-nullity theorem; the Gram-Schmidt algorithm and orthogonal diagonalization; and other applications.

MATH 315.title: Algebra I
MATH 315.description: A broad overview of the elementary theory of groups, rings and fields. Group theory: cyclic, symmetric, alternating, dihedral and classical matrix groups, cosets and Lagrange's theorem, group homomorphisms, normal subgroups, quotient groups and the isomorphism theorem. Rings and fields: the integers modulo n, polynomial rings, ring homomorphisms, ideals, quotient rings the isomorphism theorem, unique factorization domains, principal ideal domains, Euclidean domains and the construction of finite fields.

MATH 318.title: Introduction to Cryptography
MATH 318.description: The basics of cryptography, with emphasis on attaining well-defined and practical notions of security. Symmetric and public-key cryptosystems; one-way and trapdoor functions; mechanisms for data integrity; digital signatures; key management; applications to the design of cryptographic systems. Assessment will primarily focus on mathematical theory and proof-oriented homework problems; additional application programming exercises will be available for extra credit.
MATH 318.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 211 or 213; and Mathematics 271 or 273.

MATH 319.title: Transformation Geometry
MATH 319.description: Geometric transformations in the Euclidean plane: Symmetry, Frieze, and Wallpaper groups.
MATH 319.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 211 or 213; and Mathematics 271 or 273.

Also known as: (formerly Pure Mathematics 319)

MATH 322.title: Curves and Surfaces
MATH 322.description: The fundamentals of the theory of curves and surfaces in three dimensional space. The theory of curves studies global properties of curves such as the four vertex theorem. The theory of surfaces introduces the fundamental quadratic forms of a surface, intrinsic and extrinsic geometry of surfaces, and the Gauss-Bonnet theorem.
MATH 322.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 271 or 273; and Mathematics 367; and Mathematics 375 or 376.

Also known as: (formerly Pure Mathematics 423)

MATH 325.title: Introduction to Optimization
MATH 325.description: An example driven overview of optimization problems: quadratic forms, minimum energy and distance, least squares, generalized inverses, location and classification of critical points, variational treatment of eigenvalues, Lagrange multipliers and linear programming.
MATH 325.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 311 and Mathematics 367.

Also known as: (formerly Applied Mathematics 425)

MATH 327.title: Number Theory
MATH 327.description: Divisibility and the Euclidean algorithm, modular arithmetic and congruences, quadratic reciprocity, arithmetic functions, distribution of primes.
MATH 327.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 271 or 273.

Also known as: (formerly Pure Mathematics 427)

MATH 331.title: Advanced Calculus for Energy Engineering
MATH 331.description: A broad introduction to ordinary differential equations, multivariable calculus and elements of vector calculus. Differential equations: linear ordinary differential equations, and systems of linear ordinary differential equations. Calculus of several variables: partial differentiation, the chain rule, double and triple integrals. Vector Calculus: vector fields, line integrals, and flux integrals.
MATH 331.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 209 and admission to the Energy Engineering program.

MATH 335.title: Analysis I
MATH 335.description: A rigorous treatment of the theory of functions of a single real variable: functions, countable and uncountable sets; the axioms and basic topology of the real numbers; convergence of sequences; limits of functions, continuity and uniform continuity; differentiability and the mean value theorem; the Riemann integral and the fundamental theorem of calculus; series and convergence tests.
MATH 335.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 267 or 277; and Mathematics 271 or 273.

MATH 367.title: University Calculus III
MATH 367.description: An overview of differential calculus in several variables and vector calculus. Functions of several variables; limits, continuity, differentiability, partial differentiation, applications including optimization and Lagrange multipliers. Vector calculus: vector functions, line integrals and surface integrals, Green's theorem, Stokes' theorem, and the Divergence theorem.
MATH 367.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 267 or 277; and Mathematics 211 or 213.

MATH 371.title: Combinatorics and Graph Theory
MATH 371.description: Counting techniques, generating functions, inclusion-exclusion, introduction to graph theory.
MATH 371.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 271 or 273; and 3 units from Mathematics 249, 265 or 275.

Also known as: (formerly Pure Mathematics 471)

MATH 375.title: Differential Equations for Engineers and Scientists
MATH 375.description: Definition, existence and uniqueness of solutions; first order and higher order equations and applications; Homogeneous systems; Laplace transform; partial differential equations of mathematical physics.
MATH 375.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 277 or 367 or both Mathematics 267 and 177.

MATH 376.title: Differential Equations I
MATH 376.description: Classification of ordinary differential equations, first and second order equations with applications, series solutions about regular points and singular points, special functions, Laplace transform.

MATH 383.title: Introduction to Mathematical Finance
MATH 383.description: An introduction to the fundamental concepts of mathematical finance in an elementary setting. Topics include: risk, return, no arbitrage principle; basic financial derivatives: options, forwards and future contracts; risk free assets, time value of money, zero coupon bonds; risky assets, binomial tree model, fundamental theorem of asset pricing; portfolio management and capital asset pricing model; no arbitrage pricing of financial derivatives; hedging.
MATH 383.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Statistics 321.

Also known as: (formerly Applied Mathematics 481)

MATH 391.title: Numerical Analysis I
MATH 391.description: Interpolation and approximation, numerical integration and differentiation, numerical methods for the solution of non-linear equations, systems of linear equations and the eigenvalue problem, introduction to a scientific computing software.
MATH 391.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 211 or 213; and Mathematics 267 or 277; and 3 units from Computer Science 217, 231, 235 or Data Science 211.

MATH 399.title: Topics in Mathematics
MATH 399.description: Exploration of various areas in Mathematics. Topics will vary from year-to-year. It will be offered as required to provide the opportunity for students to engage in additional topics in Mathematics.
MATH 399.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Faculty. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MATH 411.title: Linear Methods III
MATH 411.description: Canonical forms. Inner product spaces, invariant subspaces and spectral theory. Quadratic forms.
MATH 411.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Mathematics 311 or a grade of "B+" or higher in Mathematics 213; and Mathematics 267 or 277; and Mathematics 271 or 273.

MATH 413.title: Introduction to Partial Differential Equations
MATH 413.description: First order partial differential equations, Sturm-Liouville systems, Fourier series, Double Fourier series, Fourier integrals, Applications to boundary value problems in bounded and unbounded domains, Bessel function with applications.
MATH 413.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 375 or 376; and Mathematics 367.

Also known as: (formerly Applied Mathematics 413)

MATH 429.title: Cryptography: Design and Analysis of Cryptosystems
MATH 429.description: Review of basic algorithms and complexity. Designing and attacking public key cryptosystems based on number theory. Basic techniques for primality testing, factoring and extracting discrete logarithms. Elliptic curve cryptography.
