Additional topics may include knapsack systems, zero knowledge, attacks on hash functions, identity-based cryptography, and quantum cryptography.
MATH 429.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 315; and Mathematics 318 or Computer Science 418.

Also known as: (formerly Pure Mathematics 429)

MATH 431.title: Algebra II
MATH 431.description: An intermediate course in the theory of groups and fields. Group theory: group actions, Sylow theorems, solvable, nilpotent and p-groups, simplicity of alternating groups and PSL(n,q). Field theory: algebraic and transcendental extensions, separability and normality, Galois theory, insolvability of the general quintic equation, and computation of Galois groups over the rationals.
MATH 431.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 315; and Mathematics 311.

Also known as: (formerly Pure Mathematics 431)

MATH 445.title: Analysis II
MATH 445.description: An intermediate course in the theory of metric spaces and the continuous functions that act on them: metric spaces and normed vector spaces; complete metric spaces and the Baire category theorem; continuous functions on compact metric spaces and uniform convergence; the contraction mapping principle and applications; theorems of Stone-Weierstrass and Arzel-Ascoli; differentiability on Euclidean spaces and the implicit function theorem.
MATH 445.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 367; and Mathematics 311; and Mathematics 335 or 355.

MATH 476.title: Differential Equations II
MATH 476.description: Existence and uniqueness theorems, comparison and oscillation theorems, Green's functions, Sturm-Liouville problems, systems of equations, phase portraits, stability.
MATH 476.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 375 or 376; and Mathematics 367; and Mathematics 335 or 355.

Also known as: (formerly Applied Mathematics 411)

MATH 493.title: Numerical Analysis II
MATH 493.description: Numerical solution of ordinary differential equations, single and multi-step methods, numerical solution of boundary value problems, numerical solution of partial differential equations, stability analysis.
MATH 493.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 375 or 376; and Mathematics 413; and 3 units from Mathematics 391, Computer Science 491 or Geophysics 419.

Also known as: (formerly Applied Mathematics 493)

MATH 499.title: Topics in Mathematics
MATH 499.description: Exploration of various areas in Mathematics. Topics will vary from year-to-year. It will be offered as required to provide the opportunity for students to engage in additional topics in Mathematics.
MATH 499.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Faculty. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MATH 501.title: Measure and Integration
MATH 501.description: Abstract measure theory, basic integration theorems, Fubini's theorem, Radon-Nikodym theorem, Lp Spaces, Riesz representation theorems.
MATH 501.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 445 or 447; and 3 units Mathematics course in the Field of Mathematics at the 400 level or higher.

MATH 502.title: Topics in Mathematics
MATH 502.description: Topics will be chosen according to the interests of instructors and students.
MATH 502.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 6 units of Mathematics courses in the Field of Mathematics at the 400 level or above.

Also known as: (formerly Pure Mathematics 503)

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MATH 503.title: The Mathematics of Wavelets, Signal and Image Processing
MATH 503.description: Continuous and discrete Fourier transforms, the Fast Fourier Transform, wavelet transforms, multiresolution analysis and orthogonal wavelet bases, and applications.
MATH 503.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Mathematics 391, Computer Science 491 or Geophysics 419; and 6 units of Mathematics in the Field of Mathematics at the 400 level or above.

Also known as: (formerly Applied Mathematics 503)

MATH 511.title: Algebra III
MATH 511.description: An introduction to modules over rings using the language of category theory with a special emphasis  on commutative rings, including Noetherian rings and modules, the tensor product, the theory of localization, and an introduction to homological algebra.
MATH 511.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 431; and Mathematics 361 or 411; and 3 units of Mathematics in the Field of Mathematics at the 400 level or higher.

MATH 515.title: Foundations
MATH 515.description: Set theory, mathematical logic, and category theory. Topics covered will vary based on interests of students and instructor.
MATH 515.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 431; and Mathematics 335 or 355.

Also known as: (formerly Pure Mathematics 415)

MATH 516.title: Senior Project
MATH 516.description: A capstone course intended for Mathematics students in the final year of study (excluding those in the honours program or the statistics concentration). Students will investigate scientific or social issues by applying mathematical methods acquired in previous mathematics courses. A final project will be submitted at the end of the term and its contents summarized in a presentation.
MATH 516.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 6 units in the Field of Mathematics at the 400 level or above.

MATH 518.title: Honours Thesis
MATH 518.description: A capstone course intended for Honours Mathematics students in their final year of study. Students will produce and present a substantial thesis under the supervision of a faculty member. The emphasis is on how to address theoretical or real world scientific or social issues by applying the various mathematical methods acquired in the earlier years in a unified and appropriate way.
MATH 518.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 6 units in the Field of Mathematics at the 400 level or above.

MATH 521.title: Complex Analysis II
MATH 521.description: A rigorous study of function of a single complex variable. Holomorphic function, Cauchy integral formula and its applications. Conformal mappings. Fractional linear transformations. Argument principle. Schwarz lemma. Conformal self-maps of the unit disk.
MATH 521.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 307; and Mathematics 445 or 447; and 3 units of Mathematics in the Field of Mathematics at the 400 level or above.

MATH 525.title: Introduction to Algebraic Topology
MATH 525.description: An introduction to the algebraic invariants that distinguish topological spaces. Specifically, the course focuses on the fundamental group and its applications, and homology. Students will be introduced to the basics of homological algebra.

MATH 527.title: Computational Number Theory
MATH 527.description: An investigation of major problems in computational number theory, with emphasis on practical techniques and their computational complexity. Topics include basic integer arithmetic algorithms, finite fields, primality proving, factoring methods, algorithms in algebraic number fields.

MATH 545.title: Analysis III
MATH 545.description: Sequences and series of functions; Lebesgue integration on the line, Fourier series and the Fourier transform, pointwise convergence theorems, distributions and generalized functions.
MATH 545.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 445 or 447; 3 units of Mathematics in the Field of Mathematics at the 400 level or above.

MATH 581.title: Stochastic Calculus for Finance
MATH 581.description: Martingales in discrete and continuous time, risk-neutral valuations, discrete- and continuous-time (B,S)-security markets, Cox-Ross-Rubinstein formula, Wiener and Poisson processes, Ito formula, stochastic differential equations, Girsanov's theorem, Black-Scholes and Merton formulas, stopping times and American options, stochastic interest rates and their derivatives, energy and commodity models and derivatives, value-at-risk and risk management.
MATH 581.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 383; and 6 units of Mathematics in the Field of Mathematics at the 400 level or above.

MATH 583.title: Computational Finance
MATH 583.description: Review of financial asset price and option valuation models; model calibration; tree-based methods; finite-difference methods; Monte Carlo simulation; Fourier methods.

MATH 585.title: Stochastic Processes
MATH 585.description: Stochastic processes are fundamental to the study of mathematical finance, but are also of vital importance in many other areas, from neuroscience to electrical engineering. Topics to be covered: Elements of stochastic processes, Markov chains and processes, Renewal processes, Martingales (discrete and continuous times), Brownian motion, Branching processes, Stationary processes, Diffusion processes, The Feynman-Kac formula, Kolmogorov backward/forward equations, Dynkin's formula.

MATH 599.title: Topics in Mathematics
MATH 599.description: Exploration of various areas in Mathematics. Topics will vary from year-to-year. It will be offered as required to provide the opportunity for students to engage in additional topics in Mathematics.
MATH 599.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Faculty. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MATH 601.title: Measure and Integration
MATH 601.description: Abstract measure theory, basic integration theorems, Fubini's theorem, Radon-Nikodym theorem, Lp spaces, Riesz representation theorem.
MATH 601.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 602.title: Research Seminar I
MATH 602.description: A professional skills course, focusing on the development of technical proficiencies that are essential to succeed as practicing mathematicians in academia, government, or industry. The emphasis is on delivering professional presentations and using modern mathematical research tools. A high level of active student participation is required.
MATH 602.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics.

Also known as: (formerly Mathematics 600)

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MATH 603.title: Analysis III
MATH 603.description: Sequences and series of functions; Lebesgue integration on the line, Fourier series and the Fourier transform, pointwise convergence theorems, distributions and generalized functions.
MATH 603.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 604.title: Research Seminar II
MATH 604.description: A professional skills course, focusing on the development of technical proficiencies that are essential to succeed as practicing mathematicians in academia, government, or industry. The emphasis is on delivering professional presentations and using modern mathematical research tools. A high level of active student participation is required.
MATH 604.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics.

Also known as: (formerly Mathematics 600)

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MATH 605.title: Differential Equations III
MATH 605.description: Systems of ordinary differential equations. Existence and uniqueness. Introduction to partial differential equations.
MATH 605.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 607.title: Algebra III
MATH 607.description: A sophisticated introduction to modules over rings, especially commutative rings with identity. Major topics include: snake lemma; free modules; tensor product; hom-tensor duality; finitely presented modules; invariant factors; free resolutions; and the classification of finitely generated modules over principal ideal domains. Adjoint functors play a large role. The course includes applications to linear algebra, including rational canonical form and Jordan canonical form.
MATH 607.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 617.title: Functional Analysis
MATH 617.description: Introduction to Hilbert and Banach spaces, linear operators, weak topologies, and the operator spectrum.
MATH 617.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 621.title: Complex Analysis
MATH 621.description: A rigorous study of function of a single complex variable. Holomorphic function, Cauchy integral formula and its applications. Conformal mappings. Fractional linear transformations. Argument principle. Schwarz lemma. Conformal self-maps of the unit disk.
MATH 621.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 625.title: Introduction to Algebraic Topology
MATH 625.description: Introduction to the algebraic invariants that distinguish topological spaces. Focuses on the fundamental group and its applications, and homology. Introduction to the basics of homological algebra.
MATH 625.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 627.title: Algebraic Geometry
MATH 627.description: The objective of this course is to provide an introduction to modern algebraic geometry sufficient to allow students to read research papers in their fields which use the language of schemes. Topics will include Spectra of rings; the Zariski topology; affine schemes; sheaves; ringed spaces; schemes; morphisms of finite type; arithmetic schemes; varieties; projective varieties; finite morphisms, unramified morphisms; etale morphisms.
MATH 627.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 635.title: Geometry of Numbers
MATH 635.description: The interplay of the group-theoretic notion of lattice and the geometric concept of convex set, the lattices representing periodicity, the convex sets geometry. Topics include convex bodies and lattice points, the critical determinant, the covering constant and the inhomogeneous determinant of a set, Star bodies, methods related to the above, and homogeneous and inhomogeneous forms.
MATH 635.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 637.title: Infinite Combinatorics
MATH 637.description: An excursion into the infinite world, from Ramsey Theory on the natural numbers, to applications in Number Theory and Banach Spaces, introduction to tools in Model Theory and Logic, fascinating homogeneous structures such as the rationals and the Rado graph, and possibly further explorations into the larger infinite world.
MATH 637.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 643.title: Computational Number Theory
MATH 643.description: An investigation of major problems in computational number theory, with emphasis on practical techniques and their computational complexity. Topics include basic integer arithmetic algorithms, finite fields, primality proving, factoring methods, algorithms in algebraic number fields.
MATH 643.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 667.title: Introduction to Quantum Information
MATH 667.description: Focus on the mathematical treatment of a broad range of topics in quantum Shannon theory. Topics include quantum states, quantum channels, quantum measurements, completely positive maps, Neumarks theorem, Stinespring dilation theorem, Choi-Jamiolkowski isomorphism, the theory of majorization and entanglement, the Peres-Horodecki criterion for separability, Shannon's noiseless and noisy channel coding theorems, Lieb's theorem and the strong subadditivity of the von Neumann entropy, Schumacher's quantum noiseless channel coding theorem, and the Holevo-Schumacher-Westmoreland theorem.
MATH 667.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 681.title: Stochastic Calculus for Finance
MATH 681.description: Martingales in discrete and continuous time, risk-neutral valuations, discrete- and continuous-time (B,S)-security markets, the Cox-Ross-Rubinstein formula, Wiener and Poisson processes, It's formula, stochastic differential equations, Girsanov's theorem, the Black-Scholes and Merton formulas, stopping times and American options, stochastic interest rates and their derivatives, energy and commodity models and derivatives, value-at-risk and risk management.
MATH 681.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 683.title: Computational Finance
MATH 683.description: Basic computational techniques required for expertise quantitative finance. Topics include basic econometric techniques (model calibration), tree-based methods, finite-difference methods, Fourier methods, Monte Carlo simulation and quasi-Monte Carlo methods.
MATH 683.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 685.title: Stochastic Processes
MATH 685.description: Stochastic processes are fundamental to the study of mathematical finance, but are also of vital importance in many other areas, from neuroscience to electrical engineering. Topics to be covered: Elements of stochastic processes, Markov chains and processes, Renewal processes, Martingales (discrete and continuous times), Brownian motion, Branching processes, Stationary processes, Diffusion processes, The Feynman-Kac formula, Kolmogorov backward/forward equations, Dynkin's formula.
MATH 685.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 699.title: Topics in Mathematics
MATH 699.description: Topics will be chosen according to the interest of the instructors and students.
MATH 699.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MATH 631.01.title: Discrete Geometry
MATH 631.01.description: Discrete Geometry: Euclidean, spherical and hyperbolic n-spaces, trigonometry, isometries, convex sets, convex polytopes, (mixed) volume(s), classical discrete groups, tilings, isoperimetric inequalities, packings, coverings. Graph Theory: connectivity; trees; Euler trails and tours; Hamilton cycles and paths; matchings; edge colourings; vertex colourings; homomorphisms; plane and planar graphs; extremal graph theory and Ramsey theory.
MATH 631.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 631.03.title: Graph Theory
MATH 631.03.description: Discrete Geometry: Euclidean, spherical and hyperbolic n-spaces, trigonometry, isometries, convex sets, convex polytopes, (mixed) volume(s), classical discrete groups, tilings, isoperimetric inequalities, packings, coverings. Graph Theory: connectivity; trees; Euler trails and tours; Hamilton cycles and paths; matchings; edge colourings; vertex colourings; homomorphisms; plane and planar graphs; extremal graph theory and Ramsey theory.
MATH 631.03.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 641.01.title: Algebraic Number Theory
MATH 641.01.description: Algebraic Number Theory: an introduction to number fields, rings of integers, ideals, unique factorization, the different and the discriminant. The main objective to the course will be to prove the finiteness of the class number and Dirichlet's Unit Theorem.
MATH 641.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 641.03.title: Analytic Number Theory
MATH 641.03.description: Analytic Number Theory: students will learn tools to aid in the study of the average behaviour of arithmetic functions, including the use of zeta functions, to prove results about the distribution of prime numbers.
MATH 641.03.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 647.01.title: Classical Perspective on Modular Forms
MATH 647.01.description: Modular forms and automorphic representations and their L-functions. Modularity Theorem from two perspectives. Introduction to modular curves as moduli spaces for elliptic curves and as differential forms on modular curves. A study of L-functions attached to modular forms and the modularity theorem.An Introduction to Automorphic Representations: introduction to the Langlands Programme. A study of partial L-functions attached to automorphic representations and known instances of the Langlands Correspondence.
MATH 647.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 647.03.title: An Introduction to Automorphic Represenations
MATH 647.03.description: Modular forms and automorphic representations and their L-functions. Modularity Theorem from two perspectives. Introduction to the Langlands Programme. A study of partial L-functions attached to automorphic representations and known instances of the Langlands Correspondence.
MATH 647.03.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 661.01.title: Convex Optimization
MATH 661.01.description: An introduction to modern convex optimization, including basics of convex analysis and duality, linear conic programming, robust optimization, and applications.
MATH 661.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 661.03.title: Scientific Computation
MATH 661.03.description: An introduction to both the methodological and the implementation components underlying the modern scientific computations with the natural emphasis on linear algebra, including modern computing architecture and its implications for the numerical algorithms.
MATH 661.03.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 661.05.title: Numerical Differential Equations
MATH 661.05.description: Fundamentals of solving DEs numerically addressing the existence, stability and efficiency of such methods.
MATH 661.05.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 663.01.title: Interior Point Methods
MATH 663.01.description: Exposes students to the modern IPM theory with some applications, to the extent that at the end of the course a student should be able to implement a basic IPM algorithm.
MATH 663.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 663.03.title: Theoretical Numerical Analysis
MATH 663.03.description: Provides the theoretical underpinnings for the analysis of modern numerical methods, covering topics such as linear operators on normed spaces, approximation theory, nonlinear equations in Banach spaces, Fourier analysis, Sobolev spaces and weak formulations of elliptic boundary value problems, with applications to finite difference, finite element and wavelet methods.
MATH 663.03.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 663.05.title: Differential Equations
MATH 663.05.description: Essential ideas relating to the analysis of differential equations from a functional analysis point of view. General topics include Hilbert spaces and the Lax-Milgram's theorem, variational formulation of boundary value problems, finite element methods, Sobolev spaces, distributions, and pseudo-differential operators.
MATH 663.05.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 669.01.title: Wavelet Analysis
MATH 669.01.description: Covers the design and implementation of wavelet methods for modern signal processing, particularly for one- and two-dimensional signals (audio and images).
MATH 669.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 669.03.title: Mathematical Biology
MATH 669.03.description: Introduction to discrete models of mathematical biology, including difference equations, models of population dynamics and the like. Topics include stability of models describe by difference equations, continuous spatially homogeneous processes and spatially distributed models.
MATH 669.03.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 691.01.title: Lvy Processes in Finance
MATH 691.01.description: Topics include specific areas of mathematical finance and build on Mathematics 681. Fundamental concepts associated with LP such as infinite divisibility, the Lvy-Khintchine formula, the Lvy-It decomposition, subordinators, LP as time-changed Brownian motions, and also dealing with semi-groups and generators of LP, the It formula for LP, the Girsanov theorem, stochastic differential equations driven by LP, the Feynman-Kac formula, applications of LP and numerical simulation of LP.
MATH 691.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 681 and admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 691.03.title: Credit Risk
MATH 691.03.description: Topics include specific areas of mathematical finance and build on Mathematics 681. Corporate bond markets, modelling the bankruptcy risk of a firm, and understanding how corporate bonds are priced.
MATH 691.03.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 681 and admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 691.05.title: Stochastic Optimal Control and Applications in Finance
MATH 691.05.description:
Topics include specific areas of mathematical finance and build on Mathematics 681.

Lvy Processes (LP): fundamental concepts associated with LP such as infinite divisibility, the Lvy-Khintchine formula, the Lvy-It decomposition, subordinators, LP as time-changed Brownian motions, and also dealing with semi-groups and generators of LP, the It formula for LP, the Girsanov theorem, stochastic differential equations driven by LP, the Feynman-Kac formula, applications of LP and numerical simulation of LP.

Credit Risk: corporate bond markets, modelling the bankruptcy risk of a firm, and understanding how corporate bonds are priced.

Stochastic Optimal Control and Applications in Finance: An introduction to the theory of stochastic optimal control and applications in finance and economics. Dynamic programming approach to optimal controls, solutions to several classes of typical optimal control problems, and application of the general theory to some classical models in finance and economics.
MATH 691.05.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 681 and admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics.

MATH 693.01.title: Monte Carlo Methods for Quantitative Finance
MATH 693.01.description: Topics include specific areas of mathematical finance and build on Mathematics 681 and 683. Random number generation, simulation of stochastic differential equations, option valuation, variance reduction techniques, quasi-Monte Carlo methods, computing 'greeks', valuation of path-dependent and early-exercise options; applications to risk management; Markov Chain Monte Carlo methods.
MATH 693.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 681 and 683 and admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 693.03.title: Energy, Commodity and Environmental Finance
MATH 693.03.description: Topics include specific areas of mathematical finance and build on Mathematics 681 and 683. Energy and commodity markets; spot, futures, forwards and swap contracts; the theory of storage; stochastic models for energy prices; model calibration; emissions market modelling; weather derivatives; energy risk management; energy option valuation.
MATH 693.03.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 681 and 683 and admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

MATH 693.05.title: Advanced Topics in Mathematical Finance
MATH 693.05.description:
Topics include specific areas of mathematical finance and build on Mathematics 681 and 683.

Monte Carlo Methods for Quantitative Finance: random number generation, simulation of stochastic differential equations, option valuation, variance reduction techniques, quasi-Monte Carlo methods, computing `greeks', valuation of path-dependent and early-exercise options; applications to risk management; Markov Chain Monte Carlo methods.

Energy, Commodity and Environmental Finance: energy and commodity markets; spot, futures, forwards and swap contracts; the theory of storage; stochastic models for energy prices; model calibration; emissions market modelling; weather derivatives; energy risk management; energy option valuation.

Advanced Topics in Mathematical Finance: An introduction to some of the main ideas in mathematical and computational finance through a guided reading of some seminal papers from the last 100 years, starting with Bachelier's 1900 thesis, and including papers by Samuelson, Markowitz, Black & Scholes, Merton, Hull & White, Schwartz, Glasserman, and others.
MATH 693.05.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 681 and 683 and admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics.

MDBT 601.title: Business Fundamentals
MDBT 601.description: An overview of the primary business aspects involved in the health care product development industry, including company creation, intellectual property, financing, regulatory and clinical affairs, valuations and exit strategies. The principal objective is to develop a general understanding of how these different aspects integrate to form a functioning business.
MDBT 601.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Biomedical Technology program.

Also known as: (formerly Medical Graduate Education 601)

MDBT 602.title: Intellectual Property
MDBT 602.description: Examines what it means to develop an Intellectual Property (IP) strategy for creating value in a business, as well as for reducing business risk. Provides foundational knowledge on the various forms of IP, including patents, trade secrets, industrial designs, trademarks and copyright, with a focus on critical analysis of patents, along with types of agreements used for transacting IP.
MDBT 602.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Biomedical Technology program. 

Also known as: (formerly Medical Graduate Education 602)

MDBT 603.title: Project Management and Corporate Leadership
MDBT 603.description: A workshop-based approach to build knowledge and skills across project management tools and techniques, to enable project planning and delivery. Explanation of corporate, personal and team leadership as well as principles applicable to larger organizations will be discussed.
MDBT 603.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Biomedical Technology program.

Also known as: (formerly Medical Graduate Education 603)

MDBT 604.title: Finances in Biomedical Technology
MDBT 604.description: Explores how the financial community views and values biotechnology business opportunities, and the concepts and skills required to do the financial analysis. Covers some of the issues surrounding the investment process and expectations when interacting with potential investors, reading and analyzing financial statements, estimating and forecasting cash flows, and value investment and financing proposals.
MDBT 604.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Biomedical Technology program. 

Also known as: (formerly Medical Graduate Education 604)

MDBT 605.title: Advancing Innovation: The Role of Regulatory Affairs
MDBT 605.description: Explores the importance of regulatory strategy and how regulatory decisions can impact the overall strategic direction of a business. Students will learn through real life examples and case studies, with a focus on biopharmaceuticals, medical devices, health tech and diagnostics/tools. An emphasis will be placed on Health Canada, the US Food and Drug Administration, the European Medicines Agency, and the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (United Kingdom). Students will gain an understanding of the regulatory requirements needed for the development and commercialisation of products, case studies, and group presentations.
MDBT 605.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Biomedical Technology program. 

Also known as: (formerly Medical Graduate Education 605)

MDBT 606.title: Clinical Trials
MDBT 606.description: Provides a general understanding and overview of clinical trials, their conduct and how they are regulated. An emphasis will be placed on regulatory obligations and current trends.
MDBT 606.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Biomedical Technology program. 

Also known as: (formerly Medical Graduate Education 606)

MDBT 607.title: Product Commercialization: Go to Market Strategies
MDBT 607.description: Provide a comprehensive understanding of the dynamic and interconnected field of product development, marketing and sales in highly regulated industries. Overview of effective sales and marketing strategies in the commercialization of products in biotech and pharma industries.
MDBT 607.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Biomedical Technology program. 

Also known as: (formerly Medical Graduate Education 607)

MDBT 608.title: Biotechnology Case Studies
MDBT 608.description: Examines strategic planning, business model and priorities of biotechnology companies. Explores the business aspects, scientific and technological innovation, and corporate strategies in the biotech industry. Critical evaluation and in-depth analysis of publicly traded biotechnology companies for multiple stakeholders such as the executive leadership team and investors.
MDBT 608.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Biomedical Technology program. 

Also known as: (formerly Medical Graduate Education 608)

MDBT 609.title: Business Integration
MDBT 609.description: Integrating lessons learned in prior business modules and extrapolating to the corporate environment, plus business pitches.
MDBT 609.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Biomedical Technology program. 

Also known as: (formerly Medical Graduate Education 609)

MDBT 615.title: Communicating Science and Innovation
MDBT 615.description: An introduction to the fundamental principles of communication with an emphasis on effectively conveying scientific, technological, and innovative ideas to diverse audiences and stakeholders. Explore a wide range of communication channels and digital technologies to optimize communication strategies. Examine the impact and implication of science communication on a broader audience.
MDBT 615.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Biomedical Technology Graduate Program. 

Also known as: (formerly Medical Graduate Education 615)

MDBT 662.title: Careers in Biotechnology I
MDBT 662.description: A series of talks and workshops designed to provide students with practical knowledge of the biotechnology industry. In collaboration with the University of Calgary Career Services, the course covers personal and professional development planning, resume writing, networking, negotiation and interviewing skills and job search strategies specifically for the biotechnology field.
MDBT 662.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Biomedical Technology program. 

Antirequisite: Credit for Medical Biomedical Technology 662 and Medical Science 673 will not be allowed.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA 

Also known as: (formerly Medical Science 662)

MDBT 664.title: Careers in Biotechnology II
MDBT 664.description: A series of workshops building upon skills provided in Medical Biomedical Technology 662. Students learn about negotiation, interviewing skills and job search strategies specifically for the biotechnology field.
MDBT 664.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine Biomedical Technology 662. 

Also known as: (formerly Medical Science 673) 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA 

Also known as: (formerly Medical Science 664)

MDBT 670.title: Practicum in Biomedical Technology
MDBT 670.description: A full course carried out in an academic or industrial setting for a period of at least three months. Students have an opportunity to apply the principles and methods of investigation learned during the Master of Biomedical Technology program and carry out related research. Practicum projects can be focused on any of the following aspects of the commercialization process: patent filing, research and development, business development, manufacturing to clinical trials, marketing and sales.
MDBT 670.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Biomedical Technology Graduate Program.

MDBT 688.title: Project in Biomedical Technology
MDBT 688.description:
Covers basic principles of project management as well as biotech lab theory and practical aspects. Includes commercial technology reviews, tours, demos and practical labs. Includes development of the scientific aspects of a project based on a disease, pharmaceutical, or device of current interest, culminating in presentations of the science and business aspects. 

Course Hours: 6 units; (1-3-1T)
MDBT 688.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Biomedical Technology Graduate Program.

Also known as: (formerly Medical Science 688)

MDBT 674.01.title: Physiological and Pharmacological Aspects of Therapeutics Development
MDBT 674.01.description: The principles of molecular and cell biology, pathology, physiology, pharmacology, microbiology and immunology as applied to new diagnostics, vaccines or therapeutics. Lectures in the two courses are complementary. Both courses are required components of the MBT program. The goal of the course, with an emphasis on cellular and molecular mechanisms in health and disease, is to provide students with the skills to interface with individuals in these disciplines in the biotechnology industry. Complemented by special lectures that provide industry perspectives in these disciplines.
MDBT 674.01.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Biomedical Technology program.    

Also known as: (formerly Medical Science 674)

MDBT 674.02.title: Molecular, Cellular and Microbial Biology and Immunology
MDBT 674.02.description: The principles of molecular and cell biology, pathology, physiology, pharmacology, microbiology and immunology as applied to new diagnostics, vaccines or therapeutics. Lectures in the two courses are complementary. Both courses are required components of the MBT program. The goal of the course, with an emphasis on cellular and molecular mechanisms in health and disease, is to provide students with the skills to interface with individuals in these disciplines in the biotechnology industry. Complemented by special lectures that provide industry perspectives in these disciplines.
MDBT 674.02.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Biomedical Technology program.    

Also known as: (formerly Medical Science 674)

MDCH 600.title: Introduction to Community Health Sciences
MDCH 600.description: An introduction to the Department as well as a general orientation to the education and research programs in Community Health.
MDCH 600.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences or Public Health and Preventative Medicine program or Mathematics and Statistics graduate program (Biostatistics specialization).

MDCH 602.title: Practicum in Public Health and Preventative Medicine
MDCH 602.description: Clinical or field-based practicum for the Master of Community Medicine Program of the Community Health Sciences graduate program.
MDCH 602.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission the Master of Community Medicine specialization or the Public Health and Preventative Medicine program.

MDCH 603.title: Practicum in Healthcare Epidemiology
MDCH 603.description: Clinical or field-based practicum for the Healthcare Epidemiology specialization of the Community Health Sciences graduate program.
MDCH 603.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program's Healthcare Epidemiology specialization.

MDCH 604.title: Practicum in Community Health Sciences
MDCH 604.description: Clinical or field-based practicum for students in any specialization of the Community Health Sciences graduate program.
MDCH 604.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 605.title: (VETM605)Introduction to Biostatistical Methods
MDCH 605.description: Analysis and design of research related to biological sciences. Emphasis is placed upon formulating good research questions, evaluating the appropriateness of different statistical methods for analyzing results, and performing and interpreting such statistical analyses. Statistical analyses will be carried out using modern statistical software.
MDCH 605.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Cumming School of Medicine.

Also known as: (Veterinary Medicine 605)

MDCH 607.title: Indigenous Health Leadership
MDCH 607.description: A foundation in Indigenous health and anti-racism, including pertinent topics impacting the social, cultural, political, and historical determinants of Indigenous health.

MDCH 610.title: Biostatistics I: Essentials of Biostatistics
MDCH 610.description: Introduces the fundamental concepts of summarizing data and statistical inference, including graphical displays, hypothesis testing, p-values, and confidence intervals. Specific topics include comparisons of means and proportions, non-parametric tests, sample size determination, power calculations, analysis of variance, and linear regression. Additional topics include a brief introduction to logistic regression and multivariable regression analysis. Examples are given using STATA and R statistical software, and students will be taught how to interpret output from STATA or R. Prior knowledge of STATA and R is not a prerequisite.
MDCH 610.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program or Public Health and Preventative Medicine program.

MDCH 611.title: Biostatistics II: Models for Health Outcomes
MDCH 611.description: Extends the fundamental concepts to modelling health outcomes using modern regression analysis techniques. Logistic and linear regressions, and their extensions, are covered in detail. The rationale, formulation, and statistical assumptions underlying each regression technique are discussed. Methods for selecting and assessing models are included. Additional topics include a brief introduction to models used in the analysis of repeated measures, longitudinal studies, and time-to-event data. STATA statistical software is used to analyze data. Required course for Biostatistics and Epidemiology specializations.
MDCH 611.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Community Health Sciences 610 or Medical Science 643.01 and admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 612.title: Biostatistics III: Models for Repeated Measures Studies and Time-to-Events Studies
MDCH 612.description: Discusses techniques for analyzing data collected at more than one point in time (repeated measures) and time-to-event (survival) data. Topics include generalized linear models (GLM), generalized additive models (GAM), Poisson regression, generalized estimating equations (GEE), and proportional hazards regression with time-varying covariates. STATA statistical software is used to analyze data.
MDCH 612.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program and Community Health Sciences 611 or Medical Science 643.02.

MDCH 615.title: (DATA624)Machine Learning for Health Data Science
MDCH 615.description: An introduction to machine learning with a focus on health applications. While the theoretical foundation behind each machine learning method will be covered, emphasis will be on hands-on skills and practical applications. Individual work on in-class quizzes and computer assignments to learn basic knowledge and hands-on skills as well as interactive class discussions and teamwork.
MDCH 615.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Data Science 603, 604 and admission to the Graduate Diploma in Data Science and Analytics; or proficiency in Python programming and successful completion of at least one mathematics course at either the undergraduate or graduate level and consent of the program.

MDCH 624.title: Specialization Theory and Practice: A Collaborative Inquiry Capstone
MDCH 624.description: Students refine a topic of inquiry, prepare background working papers, invite reactions from stakeholders/experts and report on their experience to stakeholder audience, fellow students and faculty. This is not a research course but an opportunity for students to own their knowledge and find ways to share their experience and education with others in a collaborative manner.
MDCH 624.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program. Consent of the instructor is required for all other students.

Also known as: (formerly Community Rehabilitation 624)

MDCH 627.title: Medical Education Assessment & Measurement
MDCH 627.description: Approaches to assessment and measurement within the context of competency-based medical education.
MDCH 627.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Medical Education Specialization of the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 628.title: Teaching, Learning, and Curriculum Design
MDCH 628.description: Overview of context in which medicine is taught and learned, the theory related to learning and change, the key elements of curriculum design and evaluation, and examine traditional and innovative methods used to enhance student and practitioner knowledge, skills and attitudes.
MDCH 628.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Medical Education Specialization of the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 629.title: Foundations of Practice and Science in Medical Education
MDCH 629.description: Foundational academic concepts in the science of medical education including an overview of the philosophy of science, history of medical education and medical education scholarship along with fundamental concepts in medical education scholarship such as ethics and professionalism, critical appraisal and academic leadership.
MDCH 629.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Medical Education Specialization of the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 630.title: Designing Medical Education Research
MDCH 630.description: Why and how of research in medical education including core components of research, ethical issues, project management, the research proposal, reviewing the literature, data collection and analysis, reports and dissemination.
MDCH 630.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Medical Education Specialization of the Community Health Sciences graduate program or consent of the program.  

Also known as: (formerly Community Health Sciences 621)

MDCH 631.title: Implementation of Medical Education Research
MDCH 631.description: Technical aspects of conducting a study including writing questions, selecting methods that are aligned with the research questions and approaches to analyzing quantitative and qualitative data.
MDCH 631.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Medical Education Specialization of the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 635.title: Foundations and Futures of Community Rehabilitation and Disability Studies
MDCH 635.description: History, current issues, and futures of intervention, activism, and academic study related to disability. This will include the systems and changing roles of those traditionally served, professionals, the teams they generate and society.
MDCH 635.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program. Consent of the instructor is required for all other students.

Also known as: (formerly Community Rehabilitation 630)

MDCH 636.title: (DATA624)Advanced Exploration and Visualization in Health
MDCH 636.description: Introduction of deeper tools, skills, and techniques for collecting, manipulating, visualizing, analyzing, and presenting a number of different common types of data in the context of health and biostatistics. Techniques for visualizing and supporting interactive analysis and decision making for a variety of different types of data, including text, networks, and geographic, and temporal datasets will be introduced. There will be a focus on critical thinking, problem-solving, and good analysis practices to avoid cognitive biases when designing, thinking, analyzing, and making decisions based on data.
MDCH 636.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Data Science 603, 604 and admission to the Graduate Diploma in Data Science and Analytics; or Proficiency in Python and R programming, and successful completion of at least one mathematics course at either the undergraduate or graduate level and consent of the program.

MDCH 637.title: Politics of Inclusion and Exclusion of Disability and Community Studies
MDCH 637.description: Current topics relevant to inclusion and exclusion will be reviewed. An examination of research in disability provides an opportunity for the student to learn, understand, and compare legislation, policy, and ethical frameworks that inform action. Frameworks of choice, respect, consultation, collaboration, and co-operation will be examined.
MDCH 637.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program. Consent of the instructor is required for all other students.     

Also known as: (formerly Community Rehabilitation 631)

MDCH 638.title: Leadership and Innovation
MDCH 638.description: The changing personal, organizational, and societal, leadership role and its importance for innovation in the field of disability and community studies.
MDCH 638.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program. Consent of the instructor is required for all other students

Also known as: (formerly Community Rehabilitation 632)

MDCH 639.title: Social Construction: Health Capacity and Disability
MDCH 639.description: A constructivist exploration of language, political structures, and sense of self to deepen the understanding of health capacity and disability
MDCH 639.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program. Consent of the instructor is required for all other students.

Also known as: (formerly Community Rehabilitation 633)

MDCH 640.title: Fundamentals of Epidemiology
MDCH 640.description: Principles and methods of descriptive and analytic epidemiology. Emphasizes the underlying concepts and approaches of epidemiological research and critical appraisal of epidemiologic studies including: observational study designs and their vulnerabilities to bias, measures of frequency and association, basic methods for addressing sampling variability, confounding, and effect modification. Concepts related to causal judgment in epidemiology are also introduced.
MDCH 640.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program or Public Health and Preventative Medicine program, or Mathematics and Statistics graduate program (Biostatistics specialization).

MDCH 641.title: Introduction to Clinical Trials
MDCH 641.description: An introduction to methodological issues in the design and conduct of randomized controlled trials. Topics include ethics, blinding, randomization, sample size determination, sequential designs, data monitoring, and the logistical and organizational aspects of single centre and multi-centre trials.
MDCH 641.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Community Health Sciences 610 and 640; or Medical Science 643.01 (Biostatistics I) and 647.01 (Fundamentals Of Epidemiology); and admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 642.title: Psychiatric Epidemiology
MDCH 642.description: An overview of the context, principles and methods of psychiatric epidemiology. Basic concepts of bias and random error will be applied specifically to problems encountered in conducting psychiatric epidemiological studies. An additional objective is for students to gain a basic understanding of psychiatric terminology and nosology, including a basic understanding of the clinical features of major diagnostic categories.
MDCH 642.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Community Health Sciences 610 and 640 and admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 643.title: Research in Healthcare Epidemiology and Infection Control
MDCH 643.description: Focus on research in health-care epidemiology with particular emphasis on Infection Prevention and Control. Research aspects of health-care epidemiology, including epidemiologic and biostatistical techniques and their application in various health-care environments will be presented. Topics will include surveillance, quantitative and qualitative methods, economic analyses, behaviour change, developing and assessing education programs and ethical practice.
MDCH 643.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 644.title: Surveillance I:  Data Handling for Infection Control
MDCH 644.description: Focuses on the skills needed for data handling related to Infection Control in various settings. The primary aims are: (1) to develop the skills to properly manage data using various tools and technology; (2) to use basic statistical tools to analyze data used in Infection control; (3) to properly interpret and draw appropriate conclusions from data used in infection control.
MDCH 644.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 645.title: Surveillance II: Principles of Surveillance
MDCH 645.description: Focuses on the practice of surveillance for Infection Prevention and Control in various settings. The primary aims are: (1) to be able to base surveillance on an appropriate rationale; (2) to understand and use various methods of surveillance; (3) to make recommendations and follow up on the results of surveillance; (4) to be able to evaluate a surveillance program and incorporate into quality improvement.
MDCH 645.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Community Health Sciences 644 or Medical Science 647.10 (Surveillance I: Data Handling for Infection Control); and admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 646.title: Introduction to Public Health Surveillance
MDCH 646.description: Surveillance is a public health function. Topics included in this online course include definition and overview of public health surveillance, indicators, frameworks and principles for the planning and evaluation of surveillance systems; analysis and interpretation of surveillance data; communication of public health information; and legal and ethical issues relevant to surveillance systems.
MDCH 646.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Community Health Sciences 610 and 640; or Medical Science 643.01 (Biostatistics I) and 647.01 (Fundamentals Of Epidemiology); and admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 647.title: Clinical Epidemiology
MDCH 647.description: Designed for students who have some familiarity and experience in epidemiology, biostatistics and who have a background in clinical health care or related field. It focuses on the application of epidemiologic methods to clinical health issues.
MDCH 647.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Community Health Sciences 610 and 640; or Medical Science 643.01 (Biostatistics I) and 647.01 (Fundamentals Of Epidemiology); and admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program with a clinical background.

MDCH 648.title: On-line Basic Infection Control
MDCH 648.description: Focuses on providing novice Infection Control Professionals (ICPs) with the basic knowledge, tools and strategies needed to do Infection control in a board range of health care environments from health care institutions to the community. The purpose of this entry to practice course is (1) to identify and describe the scope of infection prevention and control problems and issues for novice ICPs and (2) to examine and integrate their current expertise with the basic knowledge, tools and strategies needed to examine problems and develop practical solutions in Infection Control.
MDCH 648.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 649.title: (MDSC650)Epidemiology of Infectious Diseases
MDCH 649.description: Focuses on the principles of epidemiology that are of relevance to infectious diseases. The course emphasizes the research aspects of infectious diseases epidemiology and how the basic techniques of epidemiology and biostatistics are applied to understanding communicable diseases. The course will introduce knowledge and skills in clinical and community-based epidemiology, infectious diseases, antimicrobial therapy, microbial pathogenesis, molecular epidemiology, and evaluation of relevant health-care services
MDCH 649.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 650.title: Adapting Curriculum and Instruction from K-12
MDCH 650.description: A variety of practical strategies for developing meaningful curriculum and instructional methods for students with severe disabilities. The strategies are premised on using the content of typical community collaborative team approaches to planning and implementing programs for students. Involving parents as part of the Learning Team will be emphasized
MDCH 650.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program. Consent of the instructor is required for all other students.

Also known as: (formerly Community Rehabilitation 650)

MDCH 651.title: Challenging Behaviours in the Classroom: Inclusive Education
MDCH 651.description: Examines and builds upon the participant's belief systems about challenging behaviour. Participants will be offered opportunities to learn about successful strategies for supporting difficult students within a classroom setting.
MDCH 651.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program. Consent of the instructor is required for all other students.

Also known as: (formerly Community Rehabilitation 651)

MDCH 652.title: Collaboration, Ethics, Management: Inclusive Education
MDCH 652.description: Each year a topic is negotiated with the education sector in partnership with provincial advocacy organizations.
MDCH 652.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program. Consent of the instructor is required for all other students.

Also known as: (formerly Community Rehabilitation 652)

MDCH 653.title: Advanced Seminar: Assessment and Intervention for Families with Children with Special Needs
MDCH 653.description: Exploration of cognitive, social/emotional, motor, language/communication development and assessment of children with disabilities in the context of their families and communities.
MDCH 653.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program. Consent of the instructor is required for all other students.

Also known as: (formerly Community Rehabilitation 653)

MDCH 654.title: Health Research, Emerging Technologies and Marginalized Groups
MDCH 654.description: Provides an in-depth view of the impact of new emerging technologies and the governance of science and technology and health research on social policy, disability studies, disability research and the lives of disabled people and other marginalized groups.
MDCH 654.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program. Consent of the instructor is required for all other students.

Also known as: (formerly Community Rehabilitation 654)

MDCH 655.title: Bioethics and People with Disabilities
MDCH 655.description: Provides an in-depth view of the impact of bioethics on social policy, disability studies, disability research and the lives of disabled people.
MDCH 655.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program. Consent of the instructor is required for all other students.

Also known as: (formerly Community Rehabilitation 655)

MDCH 658.title: Special Topics in International Disability Research and Policy
MDCH 658.description: Selected topics in disability research and policy provide an opportunity for the student to learn, understand, and compare the policies in two or more countries.
MDCH 658.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program. Consent of the instructor is required for all other students.

Also known as: (formerly Community Rehabilitation 641)

MDCH 660.title: Foundations of Health Services Research
MDCH 660.description: An introduction to the fundamental concepts of health services research including topics related to health systems and methods in health services research, as well as evaluation of health systems performance, with emphasis on knowledge translation and health policy creation and analysis.
MDCH 660.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 661.title: Health Economics I
MDCH 661.description: Application of basic concepts from economics to examination of health and health care policy issues, such as why we have the kind of health-care system we have, various aspects of health care reform, promotion of health, and evaluation of interventions.
MDCH 661.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 662.title: Economic Evaluation
MDCH 662.description: Designed for students interested in being able to critically interpret economic evaluation studies of health or health care interventions and beyond. The aim of the course is to introduce students to the concepts and methods of economic evaluation, provide an introduction to how it may serve as a useful tool in health and health care decision-making, and to enable students to critically appraise the economic evaluation literature.
MDCH 662.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 663.title: Decision Analysis in Health Economic
MDCH 663.description: Students will be introduced to the concepts of decision analysis and how it may serve as a useful tool in health care economics evaluation. Through attention to a clinical question or health care policy issue, students will develop the skills necessary to perform an economic evaluation to address it.
MDCH 663.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Community Health Sciences 662 or Medical Science 659.08 and admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 664.title: Administrative Data Analysis Methodology
MDCH 664.description: Administrative data have been used widely for decision making and research. Analysis of the data requires knowledge of the data features and unique analytical skills since the data are not collected for research purposes.  This course is designed to provide these skills.  Through analyzing available administrative data, students will write manuscripts suitable for publications at peer-reviewed journals.
MDCH 664.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Minimum grade of \"B+\" in Community Health Sciences 610 and 640 or Medical Science 643.01 and 647.01 and consent of the program.

MDCH 665.title: Leadership in Health Care Organizations
MDCH 665.description: A foundation for developing management and leadership skills in health care organizations. The curriculum includes: fundamentals of leadership; formal and informal components of organizations; strategic, operational, financial and project planning; managing change and conflict; human resources; and evaluating organizational performance. A variety of learning opportunities are incorporated including: reading materials, student seminars, self-assessment tools, case studies, team assignments, guest speakers and class discussion.
MDCH 665.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 666.title: Health Policy
MDCH 666.description: An advanced level course focused on developing and deepening participants' understanding of critical policy issues affecting health and health services. The course will primarily review health policy in the context of Canadian populations and systems. However, a more global comparative frame of reference will be used to test, challenge and contrast both the historical and current underpinnings of health policy in Canadian jurisdictions.
MDCH 666.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 667.title: Introduction to the Legal and Ethical Framework of Health Care in Canada
MDCH 667.description: An introduction to two integrated aspects of health care in Canada: the legal dimensions and the ethical dimensions. No formal background or training in law or ethics is presupposed. Successful students will gain grounding in the ethico-legal complexity of health care and health research in Canada.
MDCH 667.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 676.title: Consultation in Human Services and Systems
MDCH 676.description: Qualitative and quantitative evaluation research informs the design and implementation of a collaborative evaluation of a rehabilitation program, policy or system.
MDCH 676.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program. Consent of the instructor is required for all other students.

Also known as: (formerly Community Rehabilitation 676)

MDCH 680.title: Foundations of Population/Public Health
MDCH 680.description: Students will learn, discuss, and apply critical thinking around foundational content in population and public health, focusing on the Canadian context. Foundational content includes history, structure, functions, concepts, theories, and debates.
MDCH 680.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program or Public Health and Preventative Medicine program.

MDCH 681.title: Health Research Methods
MDCH 681.description: Introduction to health research, including research design, measurement, data collection, proposal and grant writing.
MDCH 681.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to in the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 683.title: Introduction to Qualitative Health Research for the Health Sciences
MDCH 683.description: A focus on understanding and appraising published examples of qualitative research on health topics as well as analyzing qualitative findings in health research. The importance of both methods and theories for ensuring rigor will be emphasized. Examples of relevance to people's experiences of health, illness and health care as well as the social and structural determinants of health will be considered.
MDCH 683.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 687.title: Enivironmental Health
MDCH 687.description: Examination of the interaction between natural and man-made environments in human health/illness.
MDCH 687.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program or the Public Health and Preventative Medicine program.

MDCH 689.title: Global Health & Development
MDCH 689.description: An examination of health, the determinants of health, and approaches to health policy and programming in the context of less developed country populations. The course provides an overview of the history and evolution of primary health care and the role of health in development and examines current trends and issues related to global development. Cross-cutting themes include: international perspectives and trends in health sector reform, globalization, policy programming and financing, public participation in decision making, governance, health human resources, gender, human rights, partnerships and information-education-communication among others.
MDCH 689.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 700.title: Community Health Directed Study
MDCH 700.description: Independent study in special topics at an advanced level in Community Health Sciences.
MDCH 700.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the program.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MDCH 710.title: Advanced Topics in Biostatistics
MDCH 710.description: Advanced topics and methods used in biostatistics.

MDCH 720.title: Pro Doctoral Seminar
MDCH 720.description: Pertinent topics discussed to prepare students for thesis preparation.

MDCH 730.title: Doctoral Medical Education Research Seminar
MDCH 730.description: An exploration of medical education research as an emerging field with multiple overlapping discourses, methods, philosophies, and ideologies.
MDCH 730.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Medical Education Specialization in the PhD program in Community Health Sciences.

MDCH 740.title: Advanced Epidemiology
MDCH 740.description: Expands understanding of epidemiological research methods such as the assessment and management of threats to validity and approaches to causal assessment. Topics include handling of large data files, management of design effects, data linkage, identification and control of confounding, prevention of systematic and random (e.g. Type I, Type II) error, and addressing the problems associated with missing data. Includes an introduction to causal graphs, counterfactual reasoning, prediction, sample size calculations, risk-set sampling and meta-analysis.
MDCH 740.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Community Health Sciences 640 or Medical Science 647.01 and admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 741.title: Systemic Reviews & Meta-Analysis
MDCH 741.description: An exposure to all steps involved in the conduct of a systematic review and meta-analysis.
MDCH 741.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Community Health Sciences 610 or Medical Science 643.01 and Community Health Sciences 640 or Medical Science 647.01 and admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 742.title: Advanced Topics in Epidemiology
MDCH 742.description: Advanced topics and methods used in Epidemiology.
MDCH 742.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Community Health Sciences 640 or Medical Science 647.01 and consent of the program.

MDCH 760.title: Advanced Topics in Health Services Research
MDCH 760.description: Advanced topics and methods used in health services research.
MDCH 760.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Community Health Sciences 660 or Medical Science 645.18 and consent of the program.

MDCH 761.title: Advanced Methods in Health Research
MDCH 761.description: Advanced health research designs and measurement techniques.
MDCH 761.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Community Health Sciences 681 or Medical Science 659.02 and admission to the Community Health Sciences graduate program.

MDCH 780.title: Advanced Topics in Population/Public Health
MDCH 780.description: Advanced topics and methods used in population/public health.
MDCH 780.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Community Health Sciences 680 or Medical Science 651.04 and consent of the program.

MDCN 331.title: Fundamentals 1
MDCN 331.description: Presents the fundamentals of how our body's organs and tissues generate energy from oxygen and glucose. Components feature glucose metabolism and follow the path of an oxygen molecule from our lungs to our heart, through our arteries, capillaries, and then our veins. All anatomy and clinical skills related to the topics covered will be included.
MDCN 331.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Medical Doctor (MD) Program. 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 332.title: Fundamentals 2
MDCN 332.description: Continuation of concepts on glucose metabolism and the delivery of oxygen from the heart to tissues. The concepts of cardiac output to the regulation of blood pressure will be covered, as well as sodium homeostasis. All anatomy and clinical skills related to the topics covered will be included.
MDCN 332.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Medical Doctor (MD) Program. 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 333.title: Fundamentals 3
MDCN 333.description: Focus will be on the two main broad causes of fever: infections and inflammation. The normal function of the immune system, how our body regulates temperature, and the body's inflammatory response to injury or immune attack will be covered. Various immune deficiency states and the consequences of such deficiencies will be presented. All anatomy and clinical skills related to the topics covered will be included.
MDCN 333.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Medical Doctor (MD) Program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 334.title: Fundamentals 4
MDCN 334.description: Concepts of bone marrow, liver disease, lung pathology with new concepts such as genitourinary anatomy and the mechanism of action/indication of anticoagulant medications, will be presented. Both physiological and non-physiological bleeding and the impact of coagulation abnormalities will be covered. All anatomy and clinical skills related to the topics covered will be included.
MDCN 334.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Medical Doctor (MD) Program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 335.title: Fundamentals 5
MDCN 335.description: The clinical presentation of weight loss as a symptom of several disease processes and organ systems, including the gastrointestinal system, the endocrine system and neoplasia, and chronic conditions such as HIV and obstructive lung diseases will be covered. All anatomy and clinical skills related to the topics covered will be included.
MDCN 335.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 331, 332, 333, 334, and 397.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 336.title: Fundamentals 6
MDCN 336.description: A "head-to-toe" approach for the common pain clinical presentations will be a focus of this section. There will be an introduction to the peripheral nervous system, including sensory pathways and the concept of dermatomes. Pain presentations in specific organs, including those commonly seen in "generalist" care, will be covered. All anatomy and clinical skills related to the topics covered will be included.
MDCN 336.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 331, 332, 333, 334, and 397.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 337.title: Fundamentals 7
MDCN 337.description: A focus on the fields of Obstetrics & Gynecology and Pediatrics. This section will review key O & G topics, as well as conception, fertility, and pregnancy. The Pediatrics component will focus on neonatal care, newborn assessment, normal feeding, and development, with a strong focus on genetics. All anatomy and clinical skills related to the topics covered will be included.
MDCN 337.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 331, 332, 333, 334, and 397.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 338.title: Fundamentals 8
MDCN 338.description: A review of key topics from the previous units, presented from the perspective of two generalist practices: Family Medicine and Emergency Medicine. All anatomy and clinical skills related to the topics covered will be included.
MDCN 338.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 331, 332, 333, 334, and 397.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 397.title: The Professional Role I
MDCN 397.description: A variety of experiences including one-on-one student/preceptor clinical encounters in Family Medicine, community-engaged learning as well as exploration of careers in medicine, physician health, and longitudinal scholarship opportunities.
MDCN 397.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Medical Doctor (MD) Program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 398.title: The Professional Role II
MDCN 398.description: A continuation of a variety of experiences including one-on-one student/preceptor clinical encounters in Family Medicine, community-engaged learning as well as exploration of careers in medicine, physician health, and longitudinal scholarship opportunities.
MDCN 398.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 331, 332, 333, 334, and 397.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 399.title: The Professional Role III
MDCN 399.description: Students continue with a variety of experiences including one-on-one student/preceptor clinical encounters in Family Medicine, community-engaged learning as well as exploration of careers in medicine, physician health, and longitudinal scholarship opportunities.
MDCN 399.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 331, 332, 333, 334, 335, 397, and 398

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 441.title: Fundamentals 9
MDCN 441.description: The focus of this section will be critical elements necessary for normal gait including our bones, musculoskeletal system, and neurological system. The Neurology component will include topics such as the sympathetic nervous system, action potential/neuromuscular junction, as well as content related to the corticospinal tract, cerebellum, basal ganglia, and cerebral circulation. All anatomy and clinical skills related to the topics covered will be included.
MDCN 441.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 331, 332, 333, 334, 335, 336, 337, 338, 397, 398, and 399.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 442.title: Fundamentals 10
MDCN 442.description: This focus of this course is on the brain, with content related to the mental status examination and mental health disorders. This course will make the important distinction between delirium, an acute perturbation of state of mind, versus dementia, a more chronic disorder of memory. All anatomy and clinical skills related to the topics covered will be included.
MDCN 442.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 331, 332, 333, 334, 335, 336, 337, 338, 397, 398, and 399.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 443.title: Fundamentals 11
MDCN 443.description: The 120 (+/- 5) ways a patient can present to a physician are sometimes based on a symptom, a sign, or an asymptomatic laboratory test. The focus of this course will be on asymptomatic laboratory tests, based on Endocrinology and Nephrology. All anatomy and clinical skills related to the topics covered will be included.
MDCN 443.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 331, 332, 333, 334, 335, 336, 337, 338, 397, 398, and 399.
