NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 444.title: Fundamentals 12
MDCN 444.description: A focus of this section will be the cranial nerves, brainstem and functions of the eyes and ears. Higher cortical functions of speech and their associated neural pathways will be presented. Dermatological symptoms and conditions, as well as sensory symptoms will be highlighted. All anatomy and clinical skills related to the topics covered will be included.
MDCN 444.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 331, 332, 333, 334, 335, 336, 337, 338, 397, 398, and 399.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 499.title: The Professional Role IV
MDCN 499.description: One-on-one student/preceptor clinical encounters in family medicine, community-engaged learning as well as exploration of careers in medicine, physician health, and longitudinal scholarship opportunities.
MDCN 499.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 331, 332, 333, 334, 335, 336, 337, 338, 397, 398, and 399.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 500.title: Clinical Re-orientation
MDCN 500.description: Clinical re-orientation allows students who are transferring from another program or who have had an extended time away from the Medical Doctor Program to transition back into the program. Participation in this course will be part of the students' return to their study learning plan and will include communication, physical examination, review sessions and evaluations in clinical settings as required.
MDCN 500.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Medical Doctor (MD) Program. 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 513.title: Clerkship Selectives
MDCN 513.description: Clerkship Selectives is a two-week rotation based course that provides clerks an opportunity to pursue their own interest in the following sub-speciality areas including but not limited to Radiology, Pathology, Oncology, Neurology, and Anesthesia.
MDCN 513.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 441, 442, 443, 444 and 499. 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 514.title: Clerkship Electives
MDCN 514.description:
During these mandatory 16 weeks of clerkship, clerks will choose electives from the range of potential medical domains. Sixteen weeks of mandatory elective time must be completed during the clerkship year with a minimum of two weeks on any one elective block.

Clerks will spend one week each in Interprofessional Education (IPE) and Community Engaged Learning (CEL) electives. In IPE, students will spend time with one or more allied health professionals to better understand the role that these individuals play in the multidisciplinary health care system. In CEL, students will be exposed to community partner organizations that serve disadvantaged groups in society. Students will be exposed to concepts in didactic sessions related to health care inequality and social disadvantage; students will then complete time working with a partner organization to see how these factors affect community members.
MDCN 514.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 441, 442, 443, 444 and 499.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 520.title: Comprehensive Clinical Skills Curriculum for Clerkship
MDCN 520.description: Apply and build upon knowledge and skills gained during the foundational courses in medicine, improve diagnostic reasoning, strengthen communication and team collaboration. Content is delivered via multiple, interactive formats including high-fidelity simulation, standardized patient cases, procedural skills sessions, podcasts and small-group workshops over three sequential terms, spanning the duration of the clerkship year.
MDCN 520.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 441, 442, 443, 444 and 499.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 551.title: Clerkship 1
MDCN 551.description: A comprehensive and immersive experience across ten mandatory clinical experiences: Psychiatry, Emergency Medicine, Obstetrics & Gynecology, Family Medicine, Internal Medicine, Surgery, Pediatrics, Anesthesia, electives and selectives. Over four sequential terms, students will engage in hands-on learning, clinical skills development, and multidisciplinary teamwork, allowing them to apply theoretical knowledge in real-world healthcare settings.
MDCN 551.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): MDCN 441, 442, 443, 444, 499.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 553.title: Clerkship 2
MDCN 553.description: A continuation of MDCN 551 as is designed to provide medical students with a comprehensive and immersive experience across ten mandatory clinical experiences: Psychiatry, Emergency Medicine, Obstetrics & Gynecology, Family Medicine, Internal Medicine, Surgery, Pediatrics, Anesthesia, electives and selectives. Over four sequential terms, students will engage in hands-on learning, clinical skills development, and multidisciplinary teamwork, allowing them to apply theoretical knowledge in real-world healthcare settings.
MDCN 553.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 551.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 555.title: Clerkship 3
MDCN 555.description: A continuation of Medicine 553 as is designed to provide medical students with a comprehensive and immersive experience across ten mandatory clinical experiences: Psychiatry, Emergency Medicine, Obstetrics & Gynecology, Family Medicine, Internal Medicine, Surgery, Pediatrics, Anesthesia, electives and selectives. MDCN 571.title: Clerkship Extension Spring
MDCN 571.description: Allows extended clerks and students with modified schedules to continue with clerkship in the following ten mandatory disciplines: Psychiatry, Emergency Medicine, Obstetrics & Gynecology, Family Medicine, Internal Medicine, Surgery, Pediatrics and Anesthesiology, electives and selectives.

MDCN 502.01.title: Family Medicine
MDCN 502.01.description: Two placements in urban or regional/rural community family medicine practice. Common clinical problems associated with family medicine are emphasized along with the diverse roles, as defined by CanMeds-FM, that a family physician may play in their particular community and for their patients. Two experiential learning projects are completed during the block that explore specific topics relevant to family medicine.
MDCN 502.01.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 441, 442, 443, 444 and 499.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 502.99.title: Family Medicine - Repeat
MDCN 502.99.description: Two placements in urban or regional/rural community family medicine practice. Common clinical problems associated with family medicine are emphasized along with the diverse roles, as defined by CanMeds-FM, that a family physician may play in their particular community and for their patients. Two experiential learning projects are completed during the block that explore specific topics relevant to family medicine.
MDCN 502.99.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 441, 442, 443, 444 and 499.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 504.01.title: Internal Medicine
MDCN 504.01.description: Develop diagnostic, problem-solving, and management skills by participating in a variety of clinical experiences and formal teaching rounds. Students will have the opportunity to be at the front-lines of patient care, and will often be the primary representative of the medical team to their patients. The clinical experiences will consist of one of the following options: 1. One four-week Medical Teaching Unit rotation, and two two-week rotations on an outpatient/consultative subspecialty. 2. One four-week Medical Teaching Unit rotation and one four-week ICU rotation. Formal teaching sessions include weekly bedside teaching, formal teaching sessions during protected time, and rotation-specific rounds.
MDCN 504.01.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 441, 442, 443, 444 and 499.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 504.99.title: Internal Medicine - Repeat
MDCN 504.99.description:
Develop diagnostic, problem-solving, and management skills by participating in a variety of clinical experiences and formal teaching rounds. Students will have the opportunity to be at the front-lines of patient care, and will often be the primary representative of the medical team to their patients. The clinical experiences will consist of one of the following options:

1. One four-week Medical Teaching Unit rotation, and two two-week rotations on an outpatient/consultative subspecialty.

2. One four-week Medical Teaching Unit rotation and one four-week ICU rotation.

Formal teaching sessions include weekly bedside teaching, formal teaching sessions during protected time, and rotation-specific rounds.
MDCN 504.99.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 441, 442, 443, 444 and 499.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 506.01.title: Surgery
MDCN 506.01.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 441, 442, 443, 444 and 499.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 506.99.title: Surgery - Repeat
MDCN 506.99.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 441, 442, 443, 444 and 499.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 508.01.title: Paediatrics
MDCN 508.01.description: Experience in paediatric medicine, emphasizing clinical skills and problem-solving pertaining to common paediatric problems. Will build upon knowledge and skills (including history-taking and physical examination of newborns, infants, children, adolescents) previously gained in the first two years of the medical undergraduate curriculum, and will prepare the student for subsequent residency. The experiences shall be broad-based involving both ambulatory and hospital-based patients, and shall include newborn care, and care of children and adolescents up to the age of 18 years.
MDCN 508.01.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 441, 442, 443, 444 and 499.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 508.99.title: Paediatrics - Repeat
MDCN 508.99.description: Experience in paediatric medicine, emphasizing clinical skills and problem-solving pertaining to common paediatric problems. Will build upon knowledge and skills (including history-taking and physical examination of newborns, infants, children, adolescents) previously gained in the first two years of the medical undergraduate curriculum, and will prepare the student for subsequent residency. The experiences shall be broad-based involving both ambulatory and hospital-based patients, and shall include newborn care, and care of children and adolescents up to the age of 18 years.
MDCN 508.99.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 441, 442, 443, 444 and 499.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 510.01.title: Psychiatry
MDCN 510.01.description: Develop understanding of the psychiatric patient, the skills to perform a psychiatric assessment and the management of psychiatric clinical presentations with integration of basic knowledge obtained from the non-clinical setting. Clerks will perform a variety of assessments including: child and adolescent behavioural and learning assessments, elderly cognitive function, competency assessments, safety assessments for suicide, abuse, and mental status examinations. They will order appropriate investigations including: collateral information, diagnostic imaging, laboratory and psychological and other functional assessments, etc. Four weeks of the rotation are spent in adult psychiatry and two weeks in child psychiatry.
MDCN 510.01.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 441, 442, 443, 444 and 499.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 510.99.title: Psychiatry - Repeat
MDCN 510.99.description: Develop understanding of the psychiatric patient, the skills to perform a psychiatric assessment and the management of psychiatric clinical presentations with integration of basic knowledge obtained from the non-clinical setting. Clerks will perform a variety of assessments including: child and adolescent behavioural and learning assessments, elderly cognitive function, competency assessments, safety assessments for suicide, abuse, and mental status examinations. They will order appropriate investigations including: collateral information, diagnostic imaging, laboratory and psychological and other functional assessments, etc. Four weeks of the rotation are spent in adult psychiatry and two weeks in child psychiatry.
MDCN 510.99.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 441, 442, 443, 444 and 499.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 512.01.title: Obstetrics and Gynaecology
MDCN 512.01.description: A broad exposure to women's health and focus on the practice of obstetrics and gynaecology. Develop history taking and physical examinations skills appropriate to obstetrics and gynaecology patients and participate in deliveries, fetal assessment, maternal fetal medicine, colposcopy, low risk obstetrics, infertility and urogynaecology in both outpatient and inpatient settings. Clerks will spend time at either a community hospital in Calgary or Medicine Hat Regional hospitals, or at a tertiary care hospital.
MDCN 512.01.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 441, 442, 443, 444 and 499.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 512.99.title: Obstetrics and Gynecology - Repeat
MDCN 512.99.description: A broad exposure to women's health and focus on the practice of obstetrics and gynaecology. Develop history taking and physical examinations skills appropriate to obstetrics and gynaecology patients and participate in deliveries, fetal assessment, maternal fetal medicine, colposcopy, low risk obstetrics, infertility and urogynaecology in both outpatient and inpatient settings. Clerks will spend time at either a community hospital in Calgary or Medicine Hat Regional hospitals, or at a tertiary care hospital.
MDCN 512.99.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 441, 442, 443, 444 and 499.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 515.01.title: Clerkship Elective 1-26 weeks
MDCN 515.01.description: During extended clerkship student are required to complete mandatory weeks of clerkship electives based on the decision by the Student Academic Review Committee (SARC). Clerks will choose electives from the range of potential medical disciplines. Mandatory elective time must be completed during the extended clerkship year with a minimum of two weeks on any one elective block.
MDCN 515.01.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 441, 442, 443, 444 and 499.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 515.02.title: Clerkship Elective 1-26 weeks
MDCN 515.02.description: During extended clerkship student are required to complete mandatory weeks of clerkship electives based on the decision by the Student Academic Review Committee (SARC). Clerks will choose electives from the range of potential medical disciplines. Mandatory elective time must be completed during the extended clerkship year with a minimum of two weeks on any one elective block.
MDCN 515.02.prerequisitesText:

MDCN 515.03.title: Clerkship Elective 1-26 weeks
MDCN 515.03.description: During extended clerkship student are required to complete mandatory weeks of clerkship electives based on the decision by the Student Academic Review Committee (SARC). Clerks will choose electives from the range of potential medical disciplines. Mandatory elective time must be completed during the extended clerkship year with a minimum of two weeks on any one elective block.
MDCN 515.03.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 441, 442, 443, 444 and 499.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 516.01.title: Anesthesia
MDCN 516.01.description: Students work daily with a preceptor in the hospital setting. Four areas of anaesthesia will be covered: procedural skills, resuscitation, pharmacology as well as an overview of anaesthesia topics including: preoperative assessment, pain management and others. Clerks will practice intravenous cannulation, bag and mask ventilation, jaw thrust, laryngeal mask and airway insertion and airway and endotracheal intubation in a controlled setting.
MDCN 516.01.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 441, 442, 443, 444 and 499.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 516.99.title: Anesthesia - Repeat
MDCN 516.99.description: Students work daily with a preceptor in the hospital setting. Four areas of anaesthesia will be covered: procedural skills, resuscitation, pharmacology as well as an overview of anaesthesia topics including: preoperative assessment, pain management and others. Clerks will practice intravenous cannulation, bag and mask ventilation, jaw thrust, laryngeal mask and airway insertion and airway and endotracheal intubation in a controlled setting.
MDCN 516.99.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 441, 442, 443, 444 and 499.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 522.01.title: Emergency Medicine
MDCN 522.01.description: Diagnostic and therapeutic challenges offered by emergency medicine, including the assessment and management of life-threatening illness. Access to all elements of health-care delivery, including discharge planning, outpatient care and referrals, direct interaction with consultants, ambulatory care and inpatient facilities, as well as diagnostic imaging. A minimum of seven shifts in an urban emergency room are scheduled at two teaching sites.
MDCN 522.01.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 441, 442, 443, 444 and 499.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDCN 522.99.title: Emergency Medicine - Repeat
MDCN 522.99.description: Diagnostic and therapeutic challenges offered by emergency medicine, including the assessment and management of life-threatening illness. Access to all elements of health-care delivery, including discharge planning, outpatient care and referrals, direct interaction with consultants, ambulatory care and inpatient facilities, as well as diagnostic imaging. A minimum of seven shifts in an urban emergency room are scheduled at two teaching sites.
MDCN 522.99.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine 441, 442, 443, 444 and 499.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDGE 610.title: Foundations of Bioinformatics
MDGE 610.description: An exploration of the algorithmic foundations of established and emerging bioinformatics techniques, spanning dynamic programming, stochastic processes, probabilistic modelling, Bayesian inference, machine learning, and other topics from computational statistics. Big versus small data, divergent philosophical perspectives, and recent controversies in genomics are addressed through in-class discussions, current literature, and self-directed workshops.
MDGE 610.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bioinformatics specialization of the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology graduate program; or some computational background including programming or scripting ability and consent of the faculty.

Also known as: (formerly Medical Science 679)

MDGE 612.title: Foundations of Machine Learning
MDGE 612.description: Basic statistical/computational theories and current libraries for machine learning will be introduced. Content may evolve according to the progress of the field but includes: 1. History and current status of machine learning. 2. Linear models and regularization. 3. Support vector machine and kernel methods. 4. Neural networks (including deep learning). The module introduces both theories and implementations, with a focus on applying the techniques to biological and medical big-data. The level of difficulties may be adjusted according to the diverse backgrounds of the attendees.

MDGE 614.title: Biology for Bioinformatics
MDGE 614.description:
An introduction to how biologists approach the study of the problems of life, with an emphasis on sub-organismal scales (molecular and cell biology, biochemistry, and genetics), model organisms, and evolutionary processes.

Notes: This course is intended for students in the Bioinformatics specialization of the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology graduate program who lack prior significant course work in the life sciences.

MDGE 620.title: The Essentials of Cancer Science
MDGE 620.description: A comprehensive overview of the fundamentals of cancer, encompassing the hallmarks of cancer, cancer epidemiology and prevention, the basics of early cancer detection, historical-to-modern standards of cancer patient care and anti-cancer therapy, and the essentials of data science in the cancer paradigm.
MDGE 620.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of course co-ordinator. Preference will be given to those in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology graduate program or the Cancer Biology Specialization of the Medical Science graduate program.

Also known as: (formerly Medical Graduate Education 621)

MDGE 622.title: Principles and Applications of Proteomics
MDGE 622.description: An overview of proteomics, focussing on the objectives of these disciplines, the technologies, methods and informatics used in biological mass spectrometry as applied to the 'omics. This involves the practical analysis of a protein sample provided to (or by) the student in a laboratory environment, and the generation of an informatics report.
MDGE 622.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of course co-ordinator. Preference will be given to those in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology graduate program or the Cancer Biology Specialization of the Medical Science graduate program.

MDGE 623.title: Tumour Immunology and Immunotherapy
MDGE 623.description: Introductory topics in tumour immunobiology and immunotherapy will be covered. Fundamental and translational topics including, tumour immunogenicity, tumour immune surveillance and editing, immune escape, active immunotherapy, passive immunotherapy, virotherapy and viral vaccines, therapies targeting immunosuppressive mechanisms, and personalized immunotherapy.
MDGE 623.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of course co-ordinator. Preference will be given to those in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology graduate program or the Cancer Biology Specialization of the Medical Science graduate program.

MDGE 624.title: Cell Cycle Regulation in Cancer and Aging
MDGE 624.description: The links between cancer and aging, the experimental definition of the cell cycle, major events in G0, G1, S, G2, M, drivers and regulators of the cell cycle including oncogenes and tumour suppressors, cyclins, CDKs, CDIs and links to the cell cycle through tumour suppressors will be covered. An overview of biological and replicative aging including recent developments regarding the role of epigenetic modifications in cancer and aging.
MDGE 624.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of course co-ordinator. Preference will be given to those in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology graduate program or the Cancer Biology Specialization of the Medical Science graduate program.

MDGE 625.title: Epigentics & Chromatin Dynamics
MDGE 625.description: Fundamentals of eukaryotic chromatin assembly, dynamic chromatin regulation and post-translational modifications that comprise epigenetics. DNA methylation, histone post-translational modifications, histone variants, regulatory siRNA, nucleosome remodelling and higher-order chromatin organization. Cancer and disease-associated epigenetic alterations will be discussed in detail.
MDGE 625.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of course co-ordinator. Preference will be given to those in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology graduate program or the Cancer Biology Specialization of the Medical Science graduate program.

MDGE 626.title: DNA Damage Signalling & Repair
MDGE 626.description: DNA repair pathways, highlighting the cellular responses to ionizing radiation will be covered, including: base excision repair, mismatch repair, nucleotide excision repair, and DNA single strand and double strand break repair. The relationship of replication stress and telomere maintenance to genomic instability in a cancer context will be covered.
MDGE 626.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of course co-ordinator. Preference will be given to those in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology graduate program or the Cancer Biology Specialization of the Medical Science graduate program.

MDGE 628.title: Tumour Microenvironment Dynamics
MDGE 628.description: An overview of how tissue microenvironments influence tumour formation, evolution, progression and metastasis, and how to study this in the laboratory. May include tumour-stroma interplay, epithelial-mesenchymal transitions, angiogenesis, tumour metastasis and the effects of the tumour microenvironment on cancer therapy and diagnosis.
MDGE 628.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of course co-ordinator. Preference will be given to those in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology graduate program or the Cancer Biology Specialization of the Medical Science graduate program.

MDGE 629.title: Molecular Cancer Signalling Networks
MDGE 629.description: A systematic review of the molecular events underlying cancer formation and evolution, including cancer-driving changes to inter- and intra-cellular growth signalling networks, key growth receptor molecular mechanisms and cancer-specific alterations to cell nutrient response pathways.
MDGE 629.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of course co-ordinator. Preference will be given to those in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology graduate program or the Cancer Biology Specialization of the Medical Science graduate program.

MDGE 630.title: Anti-Cancer Therapeutics and Clinical Trials
MDGE 630.description: An overview of current anti-cancer therapeutics, including radiation, immuno- and chemo-therapeutic options, as well as the use of personalized medicine approaches to improving patient outcomes. Learning objectives include how to design preclinical studies to support human clinical trials, with a major focus on ethics considerations.
MDGE 630.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of course co-ordinator. Preference will be given to those in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology graduate program or the Cancer Biology Specialization of the Medical Science graduate program.

MDGE 631.title: Fundamentals of Brain Development, Physiology and Disease
MDGE 631.description: A systemic overview of how the brain develops and functions at the cellular, biochemical and molecular level, but in the context of the etiology of prevalent and rare diseases, including neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative syndromes, as well as paediatric and adult brain tumours.
MDGE 631.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of course co-ordinator. Preference will be given to those in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology graduate program or the Cancer Biology Specialization of the Medical Science graduate program.

MDGE 635.title: Hereditary and Environmental Causes of Cancer
MDGE 635.description: A summary of major sources and drivers of cancer, including the interplay between hereditary cancer predisposition and genetics, the relationship between metabolism and environmental carcinogens, viral and microbial sources of cancer, major chemical and radiation carcinogens, and modifiers of cancer risk, including behaviours, policies and interventions.
MDGE 635.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of course co-ordinator. Preference will be given to those in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology graduate program or the Cancer Biology Specialization of the Medical Science graduate program.

Also known as: (formerly Medical Graduate Education 627)

MDGE 651.title: Microbial Virulence Factors
MDGE 651.description: Virulence factors used by microbial pathogens to cause disease. Topics include microbial adherence mechanisms, toxigenic infections, virulence factor secretion systems, microbial gene expression.
MDGE 651.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Medical Science 611 or Cellular, Molecular and Microbial Biology 431.

MDGE 652.title: Microbial Interactions at Epithelial Surfaces
MDGE 652.description: Strategies used by microbial pathogens to target mucosal surfaces, and their contribution to disease. Topics include microbial disruption of epithelial barrier function, interactions with the host microbiome, microbial adaptation to host defenses, and invasion and intracellular survival strategies.
MDGE 652.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Medical Science 611 or Cellular, Molecular and Microbial Biology 431.

MDGE 653.title: Antimicrobials & Resistance
MDGE 653.description: Mechanism of action of antimicrobials, and resistance genes. Topics will also include transmission of resistance and discovery of new antimicrobials.
MDGE 653.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Medical Science 611 or Cellular, Molecular and Microbial Biology 431.

MDGE 654.title: Infection and Immunity
MDGE 654.description: Interactions with microbial pathogens with the innate and adaptive immune systems. Topics include immune evasion, pathogen clearance, and vaccine development.
MDGE 654.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Program Director.

MDGE 655.title: Autoimmunity & Immunodeficiency
MDGE 655.description: Advanced course focusing on the cellular and molecular mechanisms of systemic and organ-specific autoimmunity, acquired immunodeficiencies including those in the context of organ transplantation, and immunomodulatory therapies.
MDGE 655.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Program Director.

MDGE 721.title: Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: Scientific Method, Data Analysis and Communication
MDGE 721.description: Covers the scientific landscape in biochemistry and molecular biology (BMB), new and evolving BMB technologies, and how these can be implemented into modern research programs. Application of the scientific method, technical and ethical considerations surrounding data analysis, and essential skills for communicating scientific discoveries in the realm of peer-reviewed publication, presentation and grant application contexts.
MDGE 721.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the course co-ordinator. Preference will be given to those in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology graduate program.

MDGE 722.title: Nucleic Acids, DNA Replication, Transcription and RNA Signalling
MDGE 722.description: Covers the detailed structure and basic biochemical features of DNA, as it is folded and as it functions inside the eukaryotic nucleus. Topics will include how the 2-metre-long human genome is packaged by "chromatin", how transcription factors are able to choose particular DNA sequences and how this choice leads to active transcription of specific genes, how various classes of transcribed RNA are synthesized and processed, how RNAs function as regulatory molecules, and how the entire genome is replicated in eukaryotic cells.
MDGE 722.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the course co-ordinator. Preference will be given to those in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology graduate program.

MDGE 723.title: Translation, Protein Folding and Post-Translational Modification
MDGE 723.description: Covers cellular protein synthesis, modification and degradation. Topics include the molecular basis of mRNA translation, and its regulation at different stages, how proteins are folded and may be modified post-translationally by enzymatic and non-enzymatic means, regulation of proteostasis and protein degradation. Emerging technologies in the study of protein synthesis and post-translational modifications at a molecular level are reviewed.
MDGE 723.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the course co-ordinator. Preference will be given to those in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology graduate program.

MDGE 724.title: Introduction to Bioinformatics Resources
MDGE 724.description: Covers key bioinformatics concepts, practices, and analytical resources for graduate-level biologists who are not bioinformatics specialists. Introduces essential bioinformatics terminologies and discusses the use of bioinformatics to infer information about organisms and populations from their genomes and transcriptomes. Provides practical experience with bioinformatics tools and develop basic skills in the collection and presentation of bioinformatics data.
MDGE 724.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the course co-ordinator. Preference will be given to those in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology graduate program.

MDGE 725.title: Applied Genomics
MDGE 725.description: Covers high throughput DNA sequencing technologies and genome-wide association genetics. Provides an overview of the available genomics technologies and their applications for high throughput discovery in biology (model organisms) and medicine (cancer and Mendelian disease genomics). Discussions will also encompass research ethics considerations for collecting, storing and using human genomic data.
MDGE 725.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the course co-ordinator. Preference will be given to those in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology graduate program.

MDGE 726.title: Applied Structural Biology
MDGE 726.description: Students will learn how to describe structures of biological macromolecules and explain the most commonly occurring methods for determination and analysis of the three-dimensional structure of biomolecules. Provides an overview of biophysical and structural methods used to study the regulation and function of biomolecules, tutorials on commonly available structural visualization software and resources and how structure-guided drug design is being used for pre-clinical drug discovery.
MDGE 726.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the course co-ordinator. Preference will be given to those in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology graduate program.

MDGE 755.title: Directed Studies
MDGE 755.description: Lectures, seminars, term papers or training in theoretical and/or laboratory methods at the advanced level in the medical sciences.
MDGE 755.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Program Director. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MDGE 799.title: Topics in Medical Sciences
MDGE 799.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Program Director. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MDPA 640.title: Pediatric Pathology Practicum
MDPA 640.description: Practical training in the technical skills of grossing a surgical specimen from the pediatric population in a safe and appropriate manner, as well as grossing placentas and performing fetal autopsies. Skill development will include quality management, ancillary techniques, and medical photography.
MDPA 640.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Pathologists' Assistant program. 

Also known as: (formerly Medical Science 747)

MDPA 744.title: Human Pathology
MDPA 744.description: The principles of basic pathology, including cellular responses to injury, inflammation, tissue reaction, hemodynamic, basic genetics, and neoplasia are taught through a series of interactive lectures and seminars which are applied to examine the human system and the diseases that affect it.
MDPA 744.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Pathologist's Assistant graduate program.

Also known as: (formerly Medical Science 744)

MDPA 745.title: Human Histology
MDPA 745.description: Normal histology of the human body and how it relates to the pathologic mechanisms of function and disease will be discussed and presented in small group format.
MDPA 745.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Pathologists' Assistant program. 

Also known as: (formerly Medical Science 745)

MDPA 746.title: Integrated Pathologists' Assistant Skills
MDPA 746.description: A series of discussions and workshops to solidify the knowledge gained throughout the Pathologists' Assistant Master's program that will provide practical knowledge of the Pathologists' Assistant profession, in particular focusing on laboratory management skills, quality control and quality assurance, and the legal and accreditation requirements for medical laboratories.
MDPA 746.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Pathologists' Assistant program. 

Also knowns as: (formerly Medical Science 746)

MDPA 751.title: Surgical Dissection and Autopsy Techniques
MDPA 751.description: An introduction to basic principles of the Pathologists' Assistant profession, designed to strategically facilitate the transition from the didactic lessons delivered in the first year of classes to the practical aspects applied in the second year. Immersed in interdisciplinary laboratory environments, students will be acquainted with various concepts affiliated with surgical pathology and autopsy services. Under the direct supervision of trained Pathologists' Assistants, students will be exposed to the daily workflow in the surgical pathology service, as they are introduced to basic human tissue dissection, description, and sampling techniques.
MDPA 751.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Pathologists' Assistant program.

Also known as: (formerly Medical Science 751.43)

MDPA 630.01.title: Surgical Pathology Practicum I
MDPA 630.01.description: The primary goal of the surgical pathology practicum component is to learn how to gross surgical specimens in a safe and appropriate manner. Secondary goals include skill development in quality management, ancillary techniques, frozen section cutting, and medical photography.
MDPA 630.01.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Pathologists' Assistant program.

Also known as: (formerly Medical Science 748)

MDPA 630.02.title: Surgical Pathology Practicum II
MDPA 630.02.description: The primary goal of the surgical pathology practicum component is to learn how to gross surgical specimens in a safe and appropriate manner. Secondary goals include skill development in quality management, ancillary techniques, frozen section cutting, and medical photography.
MDPA 630.02.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Pathologists' Assistant program.

Also known as: (formerly Medical Science 748)

MDPA 630.03.title: Surgical Pathology Practicum III
MDPA 630.03.description: The primary goal of the surgical pathology practicum component is to learn how to gross surgical specimens in a safe and appropriate manner. Secondary goals include skill development in quality management, ancillary techniques, frozen section cutting, and medical photography.
MDPA 630.03.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Pathologists' Assistant program.

Also known as: (formerly Medical Science 748)

MDPA 630.04.title: Surgical Pathology Practicum IV
MDPA 630.04.description: The primary goal of the surgical pathology practicum component is to learn how to gross surgical specimens in a safe and appropriate manner. Secondary goals include skill development in quality management, ancillary techniques, frozen section cutting, and medical photography.
MDPA 630.04.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Pathologists' Assistant program.

Also known as: (formerly Medical Science 748)

MDPA 631.01.title: Autopsy Pathology Practicum I
MDPA 631.01.description: The primary goal of the autopsy practicum component is to learn how to perform autopsies under the supervision of a pathologist. Knowledge from anatomy, physiology, histology, and human pathology will be incorporated in the training.
MDPA 631.01.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Pathologists' Assistant program.

Also known as: (formerly Medical Science 749)

MDPA 631.02.title: Autopsy Pathology Practicum II
MDPA 631.02.description: The primary goal of the autopsy practicum component is to learn how to perform autopsies under the supervision of a pathologist. Knowledge from anatomy, physiology, histology, and human pathology will be incorporated in the training.
MDPA 631.02.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Pathologists' Assistant program.

Also known as: (formerly Medical Science 749)

MDPA 631.03.title: Autopsy Pathology Practicum III
MDPA 631.03.description: The primary goal of the autopsy practicum component is to learn how to perform autopsies under the supervision of a pathologist. Knowledge from anatomy, physiology, histology, and human pathology will be incorporated in the training.
MDPA 631.03.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Pathologists' Assistant program.

Also known as: (formerly Medical Science 749)

MDPA 631.04.title: Autopsy Pathology Practicum IV
MDPA 631.04.description: The primary goal of the autopsy practicum component is to learn how to perform autopsies under the supervision of a pathologist. Knowledge from anatomy, physiology, histology, and human pathology will be incorporated in the training.
MDPA 631.04.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Pathologists' Assistant program.

Also known as: (formerly Medical Science 749)

MDPA 750.01.title: Pathologists' Assistant Research Project I
MDPA 750.01.description: Guided work with practical research, encouraging independent thought and collaboration with pathologists and clinical colleagues. Requires completion of written reports and oral presentation on research performed.
MDPA 750.01.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Pathologists' Assistant program. 

Also known as: (formerly Medical Science 750)

MDPA 750.02.title: Pathologists' Assistant Research Project II
MDPA 750.02.description: Guided work with practical research, encouraging independent thought and collaboration with pathologists and clinical colleagues. Requires completion of written reports and oral presentation on research performed.
MDPA 750.02.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Pathologists' Assistant program. 

Also known as: (formerly Medical Science 750)

MDPH 623.title: Radiotherapy Physics I
MDPH 623.description: Concepts basic to the use of radiation for treatment of cancer patients.  Dose quantities, calculation systems, protocols and measurement.  Treatment machines.  Planning external beam and brachytherapy treatments.  Time-dose fractionation relationships.  Special techniques and therapies.  Exotic particle therapy including protons and neutrons.

MDPH 625.title: Radiation Oncology Physics
MDPH 625.description: Clinical photon and electron beams, brachytherapy, treatment planning, radiation therapy devices, special techniques.
MDPH 625.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Medical Physics 623 and consent of the Department.

MDPH 632.title: Clinical Rotation in Radiation Oncology Physics
MDPH 632.description: Clinical observation of radiotherapy for cancer. Students observe the treatment process, including immobilization, CT simulation and radiotherapy treatment. Treatments observed include conventional radiotherapy, intensity modulated radiotherapy, total body irradiation, stereotactic radiosurgery, brachytherapy.
MDPH 632.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medical Physics 623 and consent of the Department.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPH 633.title: Radiation Oncology Physics Lab
MDPH 633.description: Absorption dose determination, dose descriptors, photon beam modelling, quality control.
MDPH 633.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Medical Physics 625 and consent of the Department.

MDPH 637.title: Anatomy and Statistics for Medical Physicists
MDPH 637.description: Introduction to medical statistics and mathematical methods in medical physics. Specific topics include: probability, statistical inference, hypothesis testing, rejection, regression, Monte Carlo methods, analysis of variance, nonparametric statistics, clinical trials, survival analysis, receiver-operator characteristic curves and optimization. Introduction to anatomy and physiology emphasis is placed on image-based anatomy, the major organ systems, and the physiology of therapeutic and oncological processes.

MDPH 638.title: Imaging for Radiation Oncology Physics
MDPH 638.description: An overview of the imaging modalities used for Radiation Oncology including: CT, MRI, planar X-ray, nuclear medicine and ultrasound. Course will cover basic physics, instrumentation and application.

MDPH 639.title: Radiobiology and Radiation Safety for Medical Physicists
MDPH 639.description: Overview of relevant subjects in Radiobiology (the study of the effects of ionizing radiation on living things) and Radiation Safety. Radiobiology topics covered include cell kinetics, cell survival curves, radiation pathology and dose fractionation. Radiation Safety includes regulations and best practices meant to protect staff and members of the public from unsafe exposure to radiation. Material covered is drawn from the reports of multiple regulatory bodies and will include discussions of treatment vault shielding and design in Radiation Therapy facilities.

MDPH 711.title: Clinical Competency I
MDPH 711.description: Consists of rotations through areas of clinical physics under the supervision of adjunct faculty. Objectives are set, in conjunction with the student, at the commencement of the three rotations comprising this course. Student performance is evaluated by the course mentors at the conclusion of each rotation and by a final oral examination.

MDPH 712.title: Clinical Competency II
MDPH 712.description: Consists of rotations through more complex areas of clinical physics under the supervision of adjunct faculty. Objectives are set, in conjunction with the student, at the commencement of the three rotations comprising this course. Student performance is evaluated by the course mentors at the conclusion of each rotation and by a final oral examination.
MDPH 712.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Medical Physics 711 and consent of the Department.

MDPH 721.title: Clinical Projects I
MDPH 721.description: Includes completion of multiple clinical projects in the disciplines of external beam radiotherapy, stereotactic radiosurgery, brachytherapy, and treatment planning. These clinical projects aim to build the student's understanding of implementing advanced technologies in a radiotherapy clinic. Projects have clearly defined objectives established by mutual agreement between the student and project supervisor. The project culminates in written reports and oral presentations.

MDPH 722.title: Clinical Projects II
MDPH 722.description: Includes completion of multiple clinical projects in the disciplines of external beam radiotherapy, stereotactic radiosurgery, brachytherapy, and treatment planning. These clinical projects aim to build the student's understanding of implementing advanced technologies in a radiotherapy clinic. Projects have clearly defined objectives established by mutual agreement between the student and project supervisor. The project culminates in written reports and oral presentations.
MDPH 722.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Medical Physics 721 and consent of the Department.

MDPH 731.title: Radiation Oncology Physics Tutorials
MDPH 731.description: Requires the student to prepare written answers to pre-set questions published by the Canadian College of Physicists in Medicine as part of the certification process in Radiation Oncology Physics.

MDPH 741.title: Treatment Planning
MDPH 741.description: Designed to nurture knowledgeable and clinically competent treatment planning physicists. Develops background understanding of the mechanisms of dose calculation and radiation deliverability. As well, site specific treatment planning is a focus to ensure students are ready to practice as clinically competent medical physicists. The practical component allows the resident to train under the direct supervision of physicists and dosimetrists.

MDPR 600.title: Foundations of Precision Health
MDPR 600.description: A key skill in the field of precision health is the ability to critically analyse precision health through the lens of person-centred care and transdisciplinary perspectives, including the role that education, innovation, data literacy, technology, and ethical leadership have in the precision health ecosystem.
MDPR 600.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Precision Health, the Graduate Diploma in Precision Health, or the Master of Precision Health.

MDPR 601.title: Ethics and Law of Precision Health
MDPR 601.description: The practice of precision health raises unique ethical and legal questions. Explore: a) the bioethical and legal principles underlying precision health; b) consent, privacy, and use of data; c) the social impact of precision health; d) patient safety and the responsibilities of health professionals and organizations; and e) equitable access, stewardship of resources, and the development of health technology.
MDPR 601.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Precision Health, the Graduate Diploma in Precision Health, or the Master of Precision Health.

MDPR 603.title: Health System Leadership
MDPR 603.description: A critical examination of leadership development in the era of precision health as it relates to individual leadership practices, multi-disciplinary teams and the broader healthcare system. Exploration of new frameworks to facilitate collaborative decision making and effecting change and using critical appraisal to identify the most relevant research and make evidence-based decisions to problem-solve around real issues in health systems.
MDPR 603.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Precision Health, the Graduate Diploma in Precision Health, or the Master of Precision Health.

MDPR 604.title: Managing Complex Projects in Precision Health
MDPR 604.description: Explore complexity from system and project perspectives and link complexity to the design and delivery of precision health projects. Apply project management approaches and tools for planning and executing complex innovation and change projects. Emphasis is placed on innovative (novel and useful) precision health ideas and projects.
MDPR 604.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Precision Health, the Graduate Diploma in Precision Health, or the Master of Precision Health.

MDPR 610.title: Omics Applications for Clinical Practice
MDPR 610.description: Omics technologies have revolutionized data collection, patient diagnosis, and disease management. A number of key omics technology platforms will be introduced, with a particular focus on the clinical use of genomic data and their application in research.
MDPR 610.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Precision Health, the Graduate Diploma in Precision Health, or the Master of Precision Health.

MDPR 611.title: Pharmacogenomics
MDPR 611.description: An introduction to clinical pharmacogenomics, including nomenclature, guidelines, software tools, and considerations for clinical implementation of pharmacogenetic testing. Activities and assessments will reflect real-world application of pharmacogenomics.
MDPR 611.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Medical Precision Health 610 and admission to the Graduate Certificate in Precision Health, the Graduate Diploma in Precision Health, or the Master of Precision Health.

MDPR 612.title: Precision Oncology
MDPR 612.description: An introduction to the genetics and immunology of cancer and how genetics are being used for diagnosis, prognostication, and treatment. Topics include: clinical applications of precision oncology; molecular concepts and databases relevant to clinical care and research; cancer clinical trials; ethical considerations in the application of precision oncology; and the multidisciplinary nature of the field.
MDPR 612.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Medical Precision Health 610 and admission to the Graduate Certificate in Precision Health, the Graduate Diploma in Precision Health, or the Master of Precision Health.

MDPR 613.title: AI Applications in Precision Health
MDPR 613.description: Concepts and ideas in artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning -- including statistical approaches, visualization, and human-computer interactions. Applications of AI techniques and software tools. This will primarily involve exploring recent examples of AI and Machine Learning tools being specifically used to aid in clinical practice.
MDPR 613.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Precision Health, the Graduate Diploma in Precision Health, or the Master of Precision Health.

MDPR 619.title: Advanced Precision Medicine
MDPR 619.description: An advanced seminar course covering recently published examples of precision medicine. Students will critically evaluate the subjects of discussion, creatively explore ways in which precision medicine studies and tools could be developed, and will focus on ways in which they can lead health system transformation such that the benefits of precision medicine are more widely realized for their patients.
MDPR 619.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Precision Health, Precision Medicine specialization.

MDPR 620.title: Quality Management
MDPR 620.description: Quality management principles and science will be introduced starting with quality management frameworks and theory that will guide and rationalize students' learning. Quality management tools for data analysis, prioritization, improvement and change management will be introduced and described which will help students succeed in quality improvement projects.
MDPR 620.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Precision Health, the Graduate Diploma in Precision Health, or the Master of Precision Health.

MDPR 621.title: Safety Management
MDPR 621.description: An introduction to safety science and the key concepts for managing patients' safety in the healthcare system. Topics will include the exploration of proactive and reactive safety management, recognizing the similarities and differences with quality management and learning concepts of managing a serious patient harm event with a focus on system analysis.
MDPR 621.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Precision Health, the Graduate Diploma in Precision Health, or the Master of Precision Health.

MDPR 629.title: Advanced Quality and Safety Leadership
MDPR 629.description: Understanding the theories and principles of quality management will provide you with an opportunity to acquire the skills required to design, implement, and evaluate a quality improvement or safety analysis project.
MDPR 629.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Precision Health, Quality and Safety Leadership specialization.

MDPR 630.title: Health Professional Teaching and Learning
MDPR 630.description: Students will learn how to adapt teaching and assessment practices in response to changing contexts, new research, and advancing technologies. Emphasis is placed on health professional education in precision health contexts and competency-based medical education.
MDPR 630.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Precision Health, the Graduate Diploma in Precision Health, or the Master of Precision Health.

MDPR 631.title: Curriculum Oversight and Stewardship
MDPR 631.description: Acquiring the ability to review health professional curriculum ensures that it aligns with the requirements of accreditors, legislators, and other governing bodies. Topics include: quality improvement for curriculum, with a particular emphasis on modifications for Precision Health initiatives.
MDPR 631.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Precision Health, the Graduate Diploma in Precision Health, the Master of Precision Health.

Note: With permission from the Graduate Program Director, course is open to other students.

MDPR 632.title: Leadership in Health Professional Education
MDPR 632.description: Engage with concepts in curriculum leadership with a particular attention to leading adaptations of educational curricula in response to external forces. You Students will be supported to work with teams to maximize strengths and establish a space that fosters advancements in health professional education. There is a specific focus is on the skills needed to lead new education initiatives for precision health.
MDPR 632.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Precision Health, the Graduate Diploma in Precision Health, or the Master of Precision Health.

MDPR 639.title: Advanced Curriculum Design in Precision Health
MDPR 639.description: Create, implement and evaluate an innovative curriculum in the field of precision health, based on sound principles of curricular design and delivery. This course invites consideration of interprofessional learning, equity, diversity and inclusion, and integration of advanced technologies.
MDPR 639.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Precision Health,  Health Professional Education Leadership specialization.

MDPR 640.title: Entrepreneurial Thinking and Innovation in Precision Health
MDPR 640.description: Application of entrepreneurial thinking principles to develop innovative ideas in a range of contexts: private or public sector, for-profit or non-profit. Particular emphasis is placed on generating innovative (novel and useful) ideas in a precision health context and bringing those to market.
MDPR 640.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Precision Health, or the Graduate Diploma in Precision Health, the Master of Precision Health.

MDPR 641.title: Sustainable Business Cases for Precision Health Innovations
MDPR 641.description: Building strong cases for innovative ideas in precision health systems, based on objective and holistic analysis through the application of business model analysis, economic analysis, benefit realization, and health technology assessments. The course addresses internal projects within healthcare systems and new venturing ideas.
MDPR 641.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Precision Health, the Graduate Diploma in Precision Health, or the Master of Precision Health.

MDPR 642.title: Implementing Innovations in Precision Health
MDPR 642.description: Planning and organizing the execution of precision health innovation projects within health care systems, including budgeting, mobilizing financial resources, and strategic planning. Concentration on both internal projects within healthcare systems and new venturing ideas. An emphasis is placed on publicly funded healthcare systems.
MDPR 642.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Precision Health, the Graduate Diploma in Precision Health, or the Master of Precision Health.

Note: With permission from the Graduate Program Director, course is open to other students.

MDPR 643.title: Managing Technology Development in Precision Health
MDPR 643.description: Planning and organizing the implementation of technology development projects in precision health (e.g., software, wearable devices, big data applications, etc.). Particular topics include technology development approaches, planning for execution, budgeting, and minimal viable products.
MDPR 643.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Precision Health, the Graduate Diploma in Precision Health, or the Master of Precision Health.

MDPR 649.title: Advanced Innovation and Entrepreneurship
MDPR 649.description: Application of insights from the research literature for selecting appropriate approaches for planning and executing system-level innovative projects in precision health. Particular topics include barriers to healthcare innovations and frameworks (financial, organizational, informational) for implementing system-level innovations.
MDPR 649.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Precision Health, Innovation and Entrepreneurship specialization.

MDPR 672.title: Data Interpretation and Presentation
MDPR 672.description: Data visualization skills enhance the ability to interpret and communicate facts to stakeholders. Students will work with quantitative and qualitative data to derive meaning and present options for decision-making, develop data-informed health care questions, identify measures, analyze data sets, and discuss how to work with data analysts and patient partners.
MDPR 672.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Precision Health, the Graduate Diploma in Precision Health, or the Master of Precision Health.

MDPR 673.title: Human Factors
MDPR 673.description: An understanding of human skills and limitations can improve the ability to design better healthcare systems that reduce the likelihood of errors and improve patient outcomes. Explore the theory and data pertaining to the relationships between humans, technology, and environments.
MDPR 673.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Precision Health, the Graduate Diploma in Precision Health, or the Master of Precision Health.

MDPR 685.title: Experiential Learning: Project Planning and Implementation
MDPR 685.description: Develop a project proposal and implement a capstone project with a community partner or researcher, applying existing knowledge and skills at an advanced level.
MDPR 685.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Precision Health.

Also known as: (formerly Medical Precision Health 682 and 683)

MDPR 686.title: Experiential Learning: Implementation and Evaluation
MDPR 686.description: Evaluate the experiential learning capstone project by synthesizing data collected, then reflecting and synthesizing key findings.
MDPR 686.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medical Precision Health 685 and admission to the Master of Precision Health. 

Also known as: (formerly Medical Precision Health 684)

MDPS 611.title: Fundamentals I - Health Across the Life Cycle
MDPS 611.description: Building on the knowledge of basic sciences, anatomy, physiology and introductory clinical skills, this course highlights the comprehensive understanding of healthcare principles and practices across various life stages. It encompasses the care of individuals from birth through adulthood and into old age, emphasizing the holistic approach to healthcare.
MDPS 611.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MPAS program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 612.title: Fundamentals II - Acute Care
MDPS 612.description: This course delves deeper into clinical sciences and practical applications, and the management of both acute and chronic diseases. It equips students with the skills and expertise needed to address a wide range of medical conditions, from sudden, critical illnesses to long-term health challenges across various life stages.
MDPS 612.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine, Physicians Assistant 611, 621, 631 and admission to the MPAS program. 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 613.title: Fundamentals III - Complex and Chronic Care, Part I
MDPS 613.description:
In this course, students engage with advanced clinical concepts and gain insights into complex care scenarios. This component prepares them to navigate intricate patient cases, tackle multifaceted challenges, and transition towards more immersive learning experiences within the healthcare landscape.

Prerequisites: Medicine, Physicians Assistant 612, 622, 632, and admission to the MPAS program 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 614.title: Fundamentals III - Complex and Chronic Care, Part II
MDPS 614.description:
In this course, students will build on the knowledge gained in Medicine, Physicians Assistant 613 and continue to engage with advanced clinical concepts and complex care scenarios. Students deepen their understanding of multiple complex chronic conditions and patients with comorbidities. Students also learn how socio-economic, cultural, and environmental dimensions play a significant role in complex and chronic care.

Prerequisites: Medicine, Physicians Assistant 613, 623, 633 and admission to the MPAS program. 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 621.title: Foundations of Practice I
MDPS 621.description:
Foundations of Practice I provides students with a comprehensive understanding of the multifaceted aspects that underpin their future roles as healthcare professionals. Students will be introduced to the concept of interprofessional collaboration and teamwork, ethical considerations in healthcare, advocacy, health equity, social and structural determinants of health, the needs of marginalized populations, critical appraisal of medical literature, and the role of the physician assistant as part of the health care team. Students may shadow other healthcare professions or collaborate with various organizations, thereby gaining invaluable real-world insights.

Prerequisites: Admission to the MPAS program. 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 622.title: Foundations of Practice II
MDPS 622.description:
Foundations of Practice II allows students to delve deeper into the multifaceted aspects that underpin their future roles as healthcare professionals. Students will gain in-depth knowledge of the concept of interprofessional collaboration and teamwork, critical appraisal of medical literature, the physician assistant role within healthcare, and incorporate ethical considerations in decision making. Students will apply knowledge of advocacy, health equity, social and structural determinants of health, and the needs of marginalized populations as part of the health care team. Students may shadow other healthcare professions or collaborate with various organizations, thereby gaining invaluable real-world insights.

Prerequisites: Medicine, Physicians Assistant 611, 621, 631 and admission to the MPAS program. 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 623.title: Foundations of Practice III, Part I
MDPS 623.description:
Foundations of Practice III provides students the opportunity to engage in immersive and diverse learning experiences in the multifaceted aspects that underpin their future roles as healthcare professionals. Students synthesize knowledge of interprofessional collaboration and teamwork, critical appraisal of medical literature, the physician assistant role within healthcare, and ethical considerations in decision making in comprehensive healthcare situations. In addition, students will apply knowledge of advocacy, health equity, social and structural determinants of health, and the needs of marginalized populations as part of the health care team. Students may shadow other healthcare professions or collaborate with various organizations, thereby gaining invaluable real-world insights.

Prerequisites: Medicine, Physicians Assistant 612, 622, 632 and admission to the MPAS program. 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 624.title: Foundations of Practice III, Part II
MDPS 624.description:
Foundations of Practice III - Part II builds on the knowledge acquired in MDPS 623 and provides students the opportunity to engage in immersive and diverse learning experiences in the multifaceted aspects that underpin their future roles as healthcare professionals. Students synthesize knowledge of interprofessional collaboration and teamwork, critical appraisal of medical literature, the physician assistant role within healthcare, and ethical considerations in decision making in comprehensive healthcare situations. In addition, students will apply knowledge of advocacy, health equity, social and structural determinants of health, and the needs of marginalized populations as part of the health care team. Students may shadow other healthcare professions or collaborate with various organizations, thereby gaining invaluable real-world insights.

Prerequisites: Medicine, Physicians Assistant 613, 623, 633 and admission to the MPAS program. 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 627.title: Foundations of Practice VI, Part I
MDPS 627.description: Foundations of Practice VI provides students the opportunity to consolidate the experiences gained through immersive and diverse learning experiences by applying knowledge in the multifaceted aspects that underpin their future roles as healthcare professionals. Students further apply evidence- based knowledge in quality improvement within practice. In addition, students participate in interprofessional collaboration and teamwork, and elaborate on the physician assistant role within healthcare, while applying ethical considerations in decision making in comprehensive healthcare situations. Finally, students will continue to apply knowledge of advocacy, health equity, social and structural determinants of health, and the needs of marginalized populations as part of the health care team.
MDPS 627.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine, Physicians Assistant 630 and admission to the MPAS program. 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 628.title: Foundations of Practice VI, Part II
MDPS 628.description:
Foundations of Practice VI - Part II builds on the knowledge acquired in Medicine, Physicians Assistant 626 and provides students the opportunity to consolidate the experiences gained through immersive and diverse learning experiences by applying knowledge in the multifaceted aspects that underpin their future roles as healthcare professionals. Students further apply evidence-based knowledge in quality improvement within practice. In addition, students participate in interprofessional collaboration and teamwork, and elaborate on the physician assistant role within healthcare, while applying ethical considerations in decision making in comprehensive healthcare situations. Finally, students will continue to apply knowledge of advocacy, health equity, social and structural determinants of health, and the needs of marginalized populations as part of the health care team.

Prerequisites: Medicine, Physicians Assistant 627 and admission to the MPAS program. 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 629.title: Foundations of Practice IV
MDPS 629.description: Foundations of Practice IV provides students the opportunity to engage in immersive and diverse learning experiences through the application of knowledge in the multifaceted aspects that underpin their future roles as healthcare professionals. Students apply evidence-based knowledge in quality improvement within practice. In addition, students participate in interprofessional collaboration and teamwork, and elaborate on the physician assistant role within healthcare, while applying ethical considerations in decision making in comprehensive healthcare situations. In addition, students will apply knowledge of advocacy, health equity, social and structural determinants of health, and the needs of marginalized populations as part of the health care team.
MDPS 629.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine, Physicians Assistant 614, 624, 634 and admission to the MPAS program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 630.title: Foundations of Practice V
MDPS 630.description: In this course, students further engage in immersive and diverse learning experiences through the application of knowledge in the multifaceted aspects that underpin their future roles as healthcare professionals. Students participate in interprofessional collaboration and teamwork and deepen their knowledge around the physician assistant role within healthcare, while applying ethical considerations in decision making in comprehensive healthcare situations. In addition, students will apply evidence- based knowledge in quality improvement within practice. Finally, students will apply knowledge of advocacy, health equity, social and structural determinants of health, and the needs of marginalized populations as part of the health care team.
MDPS 630.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medicine, Physicians Assistant 629 and admission to the MPAS program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 631.title: Clinical Skills I
MDPS 631.description: Clinical Skills I introduce MPAS students to the practical and hands-on skills essential for successful healthcare practice. Students will acquire a solid foundation in interpersonal and communication skills required for effective history-taking, physical examination, communication, and medical documentation skills necessary for patient assessment. Students will delve into the critical skill of interpreting diagnostic tests and building procedural skills, bridging the gap between clinical assessment and evidence-based decision-making. This course also includes the requirement of the Medical Terminology Module.
MDPS 631.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MPAS program.
 
NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 632.title: Clinical Skills II
MDPS 632.description:
In this course, students engage in the practical and hands-on skills essential for successful healthcare practice. Students will expand on the foundation gained in interpersonal and communication skills required for effective history-taking, physical examination, communication, and medical documentation skills necessary for patient assessment. Students will further delve into the critical skill of interpreting diagnostic tests and building procedural skills, bridging the gap between clinical assessment and evidence-based decision-making.

Prerequisites: Medicine, Physicians Assistant 611, 621, 631 and admission to the MPAS program. 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 633.title: Clinical Skills III, Part I
MDPS 633.description:
In this course, students engage in the practical and hands-on skills essential for successful healthcare practice. Students will expand on the foundation gained in interpersonal and communication skills required for effective history-taking, physical examination, communication, and medical documentation skills necessary for patient assessment. Students will further delve into the critical skill of interpreting diagnostic tests and building procedural skills, bridging the gap between clinical assessment and evidence-based decision-making.

Prerequisites: Medicine, Physicians Assistant 612, 622, 632 and admission to the MPAS program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 634.title: Clinical Skills III, Part II
MDPS 634.description:
In this course, students will build on the knowledge acquired in Medicine, Physicians Assistant 633 and engage in practical and hands-on skills essential for successful healthcare practice. Students will expand on the foundation gained in interpersonal and communication skills required for effective history-taking, physical examination, communication, and medical documentation skills necessary for patient assessment. Students will further delve into the critical skill of interpreting diagnostic tests and building procedural skills, bridging the gap between clinical assessment and evidence-based decision-making.

Prerequisites: Medicine, Physicians Assistant 613, 623, 633, and admission to the MPAS program. 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 641.title: Urban Family Medicine Rotation
MDPS 641.description:
MPAS students will gain skills required for the provision of care for family medicine patients across the life span, within the urban area. Under the supervision of a preceptor, they engage in the diagnosis, management, and treatment of acute, chronic, and the provision of preventive medical care to family medicine patients.

Prerequisites: Admission to the MPAS program. 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 642.title: Rural Family Medicine Rotation
MDPS 642.description:
MPAS students will gain skills required for the provision of care for family medicine patients across the life span in rural areas. This supervised clinical practice experience enables students to assess patients seeking medical care within community-based environments with an emphasis on caring for the acutely and chronically ill patients, in addition to providing preventive medical care to family medicine patients.

Prerequisites: Admission to the MPAS program.
 
NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 646.title: Emergency Medicine Rotation
MDPS 646.description:
This clinical rotation provides the MPAS student with clinical experience required to triage, evaluate, diagnose, and manage patients with life-threatening illness in urgent care and emergency settings. Students will gain experience and skills in all elements of health-care delivery for diverse patients across the lifespan.

Prerequisites: Admission to the MPAS program.
 
NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 647.title: Psychiatry Rotation
MDPS 647.description:
This clinical rotation exposes the MPAS student to the principles and practice of psychiatry, behavioral, and mental health. Students will develop skills in the recognition, clinical evaluation, and diagnosis of psychiatric illness, and collaborate in the management of patients with psychiatric clinical presentations across the lifespan.

Prerequisites: Admission to the MPAS program. 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 648.title: Obstetrics and Gynecology Rotation
MDPS 648.description:
This clinical rotation exposes the MPAS student with practical clinical experience to women's health with a focus on obstetrics and gynaecology. Students will develop skills in history taking, physical examinations, and collaborating in making medical decisions for a broad range of patients with diverse socio-economic status.

Prerequisites: Admission to the MPAS program. 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 651.title: Internal Medicine Core Rotation
MDPS 651.description: This core rotation offers hands-on clinical experience in an acute inpatient internal medicine unit, focusing on the diagnosis, management, and problem-solving for patients with acute and chronic illnesses. Students will also develop skills in preventive care and patient education. As part of an interdisciplinary healthcare team, students will actively contribute to the comprehensive care of adult patients, enhancing their ability to deliver effective and patient-centered management in a collaborative environment.
MDPS 651.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MPAS program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 652.title: Internal Medicine Selective Rotation
MDPS 652.description: Immersion in a subspecialty of Internal Medicine, offering focused exposure to complex and specialized patient care scenarios. Students will enhance their proficiency in diagnosing, managing, and treating subspecialty conditions while collaborating with multidisciplinary teams. Emphasis is placed on integrating advanced clinical reasoning and evidence-based approaches within the chosen subspecialty, fostering skill development in specialized patient management, communication, and teamwork in diverse healthcare settings.
MDPS 652.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MPAS program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 653.title: Pediatrics Core Rotation
MDPS 653.description: Practical clinical experience with pediatric patients. Students will gain skills in the process of evaluating, diagnosing, managing, and delivering care to a pediatric population. The experiences will be broad including newborn care and care of children and adolescents up to the age of 18.
MDPS 653.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MPAS program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 654.title: Pediatrics Selective Rotation
MDPS 654.description: Specialized clinical exposure within a subspecialty of pediatrics. Building on foundational pediatric competencies, students will deepen their expertise in the evaluation, diagnosis, and management of complex conditions specific to a pediatric subspecialty. Emphasis is placed on collaborative care, evidence-based practices, and developing advanced clinical reasoning skills to address the unique needs of children and adolescents in specialized healthcare settings.
MDPS 654.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MPAS program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 655.title: General Surgery Core Rotation
MDPS 655.description: The core surgical rotation provides the MPAS student with practical clinical experience in the concepts and principles of general surgery. Students will gain clinical skills in the process of evaluating, diagnosing, managing, and making appropriate surgical referrals under the supervision of preceptors within this field.
MDPS 655.prerequisitesText:
