Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MPAS program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 656.title: General Surgery Selective Rotation
MDPS 656.description: This clinical rotation offers MPAS students focused clinical experience within a surgical subspecialty. Building on the principles of general surgery, students will refine their skills in evaluating, diagnosing, managing, and collaborating on surgical care for patients with complex and specialized conditions. Emphasis is placed on hands-on learning, procedural competencies, and multidisciplinary collaboration under the supervision of surgical specialists.
MDPS 656.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MPAS program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 657.title: Family Medicine Selective Rotation
MDPS 657.description:
This rotation provides MPAS students with the opportunity to gain focused clinical experience in a specialized area of family medicine, ideally as aligned with the Certificates of Added Competence (CAC) framework. Under the supervision of a family physician preceptor, students will enhance their diagnostic, management, and treatment skills within the chosen specialty, such as emergency medicine, care of the elderly, palliative care, or sports medicine. The rotation emphasizes patient-centered care across diverse practice settings, fostering adaptability and advanced competency in the delivery of comprehensive, evidence-based medical care.

Prerequisites: Admission to the MPAS program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 661.title: Special Topics in Physician Assistant Practice I
MDPS 661.description:
This course provides an overview of various topics within Physician Assistant practice. Through hands- on learning and exploration, students explore topics within the course.

Prerequisites: Admission to the MPAS Program and consent of the Graduate Program Director. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 662.title: Special Topics in Physician Assistant Practice II
MDPS 662.description:
This course provides an opportunity for students to examine connections between various topics in Physician Assistant practice. Students engage in critical thinking and hands-on practice in the exploration of topics within the course.

Prerequisites: Admission to the MPAS Program and consent of the Graduate Program Director. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 663.title: Special Topics in Physician Assistant Practice III
MDPS 663.description:
This course takes a critical approach in the exploration of diverse topics withing Physician Assistant practice. Students will engage in various activities to gain an in-depth knowledge of topics within this course.

Prerequisites: Admission to the MPAS Program and consent of the Graduate Program Director. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 664.title: Special Clinical Topics in Physician Assistant Practice I
MDPS 664.description:
This course provides an opportunity for MPAS students to explore topics in Physician Assistant practice. Students will engage in critical thinking as they review course concepts and examine relationships across various topics.

Prerequisites: Admission to the MPAS Program and consent of the Graduate Program Director. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 665.title: Special Clinical Topics in Physician Assistant Practice II
MDPS 665.description:
This course provides an opportunity for MPAS students to examine the integrated topics in Physician Assistant practice. Students will engage in critical thinking and hands-on learning as they develop a strong understanding of the various topics within the clinical setting.

Prerequisites: Admission to the MPAS Program and consent of the Graduate Program Director. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 668.title: Special Clinical Topics in Physician Assistant Practice IV
MDPS 668.description: This course critically examines diverse topics within clinical settings in Physician Assistant practice. Students will engage in critical thinking and exploratory learning as they delve into topics within the course.
MDPS 668.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MPAS Program and consent of the Graduate Program Director.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 649.01.title: Elective Rotation I - Acute Care
MDPS 649.01.description: This clinical rotation is an opportunity for MPAS students to explore an area of medical or surgical interest beyond the required clinical rotations within the program. Students work under the supervision of a licensed clinical preceptor to engage in experiential learning experiences within healthcare.
MDPS 649.01.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MPAS program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 649.02.title: Elective Rotation I - Medicine
MDPS 649.02.description: This clinical rotation is an opportunity for MPAS students to explore an area of medical or surgical interest beyond the required clinical rotations within the program. Students work under the supervision of a licensed clinical preceptor to engage in experiential learning experiences within healthcare.
MDPS 649.02.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MPAS program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 649.03.title: Elective Rotation I - Surgery
MDPS 649.03.description: This clinical rotation is an opportunity for MPAS students to explore an area of medical or surgical interest beyond the required clinical rotations within the program. Students work under the supervision of a licensed clinical preceptor to engage in experiential learning experiences within healthcare.
MDPS 649.03.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MPAS program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 649.04.title: Elective Rotation I - Primary Care
MDPS 649.04.description: This clinical rotation is an opportunity for MPAS students to explore an area of medical or surgical interest beyond the required clinical rotations within the program. Students work under the supervision of a licensed clinical preceptor to engage in experiential learning experiences within healthcare.
MDPS 649.04.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MPAS program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 650.01.title: Elective Rotation II - Acute care
MDPS 650.01.description:
This clinical rotation is an opportunity for MPAS students to explore an area of medical or surgical interest beyond the required clinical rotations within the program. Students work under the supervision of a licensed clinical preceptor to engage in experiential learning experiences within healthcare and gain additional or new clinical experience.

Prerequisites: Admission to the MPAS program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 650.02.title: Elective Rotation II - Medicine
MDPS 650.02.description:
This clinical rotation is an opportunity for MPAS students to explore an area of medical or surgical interest beyond the required clinical rotations within the program. Students work under the supervision of a licensed clinical preceptor to engage in experiential learning experiences within healthcare and gain additional or new clinical experience.

Prerequisites: Admission to the MPAS program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 650.03.title: Elective Rotation II - Surgery
MDPS 650.03.description:
This clinical rotation is an opportunity for MPAS students to explore an area of medical or surgical interest beyond the required clinical rotations within the program. Students work under the supervision of a licensed clinical preceptor to engage in experiential learning experiences within healthcare and gain additional or new clinical experience.

Prerequisites: Admission to the MPAS program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDPS 650.04.title: Elective Rotation II - Primary Care
MDPS 650.04.description:
This clinical rotation is an opportunity for MPAS students to explore an area of medical or surgical interest beyond the required clinical rotations within the program. Students work under the supervision of a licensed clinical preceptor to engage in experiential learning experiences within healthcare and gain additional or new clinical experience.

Prerequisites: Admission to the MPAS program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDSC 201.title: Applied Tools in Bioinformatics
MDSC 201.description: To familiarize students with computational approaches to studying biology. Topics to be covered include common tools, databases, and search engines for storing, sharing, and analyzing biological information. Students will complete an original project analyzing publicly available data using publicly available computational tools.
MDSC 201.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bioinformatics major of BHSc Honours program.

MDSC 203.title: Developing Health Research Literacy I
MDSC 203.description: Stuidents will be introduced to the interdisciplinary scope of health research through reading and writing assignments. Students will learn the basics of academic research enquiry and practice academic writing and presentation skills through individual and team assignments.
MDSC 203.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BHSc Honours program.

MDSC 205.title: Developing Health Research Literacy II
MDSC 205.description: Students will develop their critical thinking skills and their ability to write logically, well-argued research papers. Students will learn the fundamentals of logical reasoning as well as how to analyze theoretical issues in science, medicine, and philosophy.
MDSC 205.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Medical Science 203 and admission to the BHSc Honours program.

MDSC 301.title: Bioinformatics
MDSC 301.description: This introductory course will familiarize students with algorithms and computational techniques for bioinformatics applications. Topics to be covered include algorithm and search engines for the analysis of nucleic acid and protein sequences and structures; machine learning techniques for biological data analysis; systems biology approaches for computational modelling.
MDSC 301.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 6 units in Computer Science at the 300 level; or Medical Science 341; or 6 units in Biological Sciences at the 300 level.

MDSC 307.title: Science, Philosophy and Society
MDSC 307.description: A survey of underlying ideas concerning the objectives, methods, ambitions and responsibilities of the natural and social sciences.
MDSC 307.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Second-year standing or higher in the BHSc Honours program.

MDSC 308.title: Interdiscliplinary Research Approaches
MDSC 308.description: An introduction to the questions, methods and research techniques used across the different majors of Biomedical Sciences, Bioinformatics and Health and Society. Sessions will support the development of a broad perspective on health issues and introduce students to the history and the rules governing the ethical conduct of science and research on humans.
MDSC 308.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Medical Science 205 and admission to the BHSc Honours program.

MDSC 309.title: Science and Politics
MDSC 309.description: An exploration of the ways in which scientific information plays a role when governments debate and implement policies related to health, the environment and industry. An examination of these questions surrounding the interface between science and politics through readings from the sociology of science and by discussing contemporary examples.
MDSC 309.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Second-year or higher standing in the BHSc Honours program.

MDSC 321.title: Introduction to Immunology
MDSC 321.description: This introductory course is designed to expose students to the study of how the immune system encounters, recognizes, and responds to various infectious and pathogenic conditions. Emphasis will not solely focus on how components of the immune system interact with each other to generate an effective host response but also will be placed on how this immune response may be used to generate new therapies for human disease, how evolving and emerging pathogens interact with, and challenge the immune system, and how our knowledge of immunity has impacted society.

MDSC 341.title: Principles of Human Genetics
MDSC 341.description: Introduction to principles in human genetics including Mendelian and chromosomal basis of inheritance, chromosomal abnormalities, pedigree analysis, mutations, and molecular, metabolic, population and clinical genetics. Studies of model organisms and genomics will be included as required. Incorporates problem-based learning to establish analytical skills in genetics.
MDSC 341.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biology 241, 243, and admission to the BHSc Honours program.

MDSC 351.title: Honours Cellular and Molecular Biology
MDSC 351.description: Introduction to principles in cellular and molecular biology. Emphasizes how structure underlies and determines function in the cell and how complex processes are organized and regulated at the molecular level.
MDSC 351.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Medical Science 341 and admission to the BHSc Honours program.

MDSC 397.title: Independent Studies in Health Sciences
MDSC 397.description: Guided work fostering independent thought, practical research and the completion of written reports for first- and second-year BHSc students.
MDSC 397.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): A maximum of 45 units and consent of the BHSc Honours program.

MDSC 402.title: Organismal Biology
MDSC 402.description: Organismal structure from the cellular to the organism level focusing on vertebrates with a particular emphasis on humans. Topics covered include cell biology, histology, vertebrate development and anatomy. This course is inquiry-based and will consist of lectures, small group sessions and interactive laboratory sessions.
MDSC 402.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biology 241, 243, Medical Science 351 and admission to the BHSc Honours program.

MDSC 403.title: Computation for Bioinformatics
MDSC 403.description: A focus on current computational and statistical methods in bioinformatics. Topics will shift as computational and statistical methods in bioinformatics shift. The underlying philosophy of how to use computational and statistical techniques to solve biological questions will be elaborated using hands-on examples and inquiry-based projects. The course will build basic skills for both upstream computational processing and downstream statistical characterization.
MDSC 403.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Medical Science 301 or 401: and Statistics 321.

MDSC 404.title: Integrative Human Physiology
MDSC 404.description: Physiology is defined as the study of how living organisms function and encompasses the integration of processes from molecules to the whole-organism. Provides fundamental principles and concepts about the physiology of the major human organ systems.
MDSC 404.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BHSc Honours program.

MDSC 407.title: Statistics and Research Design in Health Sciences
MDSC 407.description: An introduction to the study of research design and statistical analysis including a broad overview of the variety of methods for research in health sciences. Students will be introduced to a variety of research tools through lecture and tutorial components.
MDSC 407.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BHSc Honours program.

MDSC 408.title: Research Design in Molecular Biology and Bioinformatics
MDSC 408.description: An introduction to the research methods utilized in the Health Sciences. Students will begin to develop the knowledge and skills necessary to conduct research in their respective fields. The importance of research design, qualitative, quantitative and mixed methods and the theoretical constructs that inform these approaches will be emphasized.
MDSC 408.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Medical Science 308, with a minimum grade of "B-", and Medical Science 341 and admission to the BHSc Honours program.

MDSC 409.title: Brain and Society
MDSC 409.description: Topics will include neuronal mechanisms of addiction, neuronal mechanisms of learning and memory, aging in the human brain and behavioural consequences and mind/brain dichotomy.
MDSC 409.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BHSc Honours program.

MDSC 415.title: Introduction to Epidemiology
MDSC 415.description: An introduction to the basic concepts of epidemiology needed to understand and critically analyze research pertaining to health and disease in populations. Methods used in descriptive and analytic epidemiological studies, including the design, analysis and interpretation of results for observational studies and clinical trials will be discussed. Case studies and contemporary events will be used to illustrate epidemiology in action and to highlight the social aspects of applying epidemiology in public health.

MDSC 425.title: Global Health Field Course
MDSC 425.description: Provides students experiential learning about Global Health through a combination of classroom and field work in a Low and Middle Income Country (LMIC) country setting.
MDSC 425.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the instructor.

Note: A supplementary fee will be assessed to cover additional costs associated with this course. Students will require consent of the department to drop this course. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MDSC 501.title: (BIOL501)Principles and Mechanisms of Pharmacology
MDSC 501.description: Basic principles of pharmacology with a focus on pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics, pharmacogenomics, and mechanisms of action and signal transduction pathways for major drug classes. Clinical applications of these pharmacological principles will be explored and may include consideration of sex, genetics, age, adverse drug reactions and disease states.
MDSC 501.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BHSc Honours program; and Biochemistry 341 or 393; and Zoology 463 or Medical Science 404.

Also known as: (Biology 501)

MDSC 503.title: (BIOL503)Pharmacology of Organ Systems
MDSC 503.description: Through analysis and discussion of research literature, this course explores topics in pharmacology including the nervous, cardiovascular, renal, respiratory and immune systems, as well as anti-cancer therapies.
MDSC 503.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medical Science 501 (Biology 501).

Also known as: (Biology 503)

MDSC 507.title: Special Problems in Health Science
MDSC 507.description: Exploration of a health science topic of interest. To include original and independent thought, practical research and the completion of written and oral reports.
MDSC 507.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the BHSc Honours program.

MDSC 508.title: Honours Thesis and Research Communication
MDSC 508.description: Capstone research course in the BHSc to be conducted through any one of the basic research departments. Students would be expected to conduct research. Course also involves weekly small group sessions aimed at building research communication skills. Course culminates with submission of a written thesis that is presented and defended in front of a panel of faculty members in an oral examination.
MDSC 508.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BHSc Honours program; and Health and Society 408 with a minimum grade of B- or Medical Science 408 with a minimum grade of B-; and a minimum cumulative 3.30 GPA.

MDSC 515.title: (BIOL515)Cellular Mechanisms of Disease
MDSC 515.description: The cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying basic human disease processes and how these can be influenced by lifestyle and environmental factors. The ways in which this knowledge can be used in the laboratory diagnosis of disease.
MDSC 515.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Biochemistry 341 or 393; and Biology 331 or Medical Science 351.

Also known as: (Biology 515)

MDSC 517.title: Introduction to Biotechnology Business and Profession
MDSC 517.description: An overview of the biotechnology sector from several perspectives: product development, regulatory, intellectual property, market analysis, and finance. This course will include two modules. The first is a series of lectures by faculty and local entrepreneurs to provide the necessary background for the assignments in the second module. The second module will include student-selected case studies and an analysis of a small biotechnology company.

MDSC 519.title: Advanced Bioinformatics
MDSC 519.description: Designed to develop student ability to perform bioinformatics analyses of datasets and develop their knowledge of the current literature. The course will emphasize careful study of recent methodologies for chromatin immunoprecipitation followed by sequencing (ChIP-seq) dataset analysis. The course will include lectures, literature review sessions and a self-directed bioinformatics research project.
MDSC 519.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Medical Science 301 or 401; and 3 units from Computer Science 217, 219, 231 or 233.

MDSC 521.title: Human Anatomy
MDSC 521.description: An inquiry-based exploration of clinically significant human anatomy. The course will follow a systems-based approach, and will make use of multiple learning formats. Each week, the instructor will lead classroom and laboratory sessions that explore an anatomical system from developmental, functional, and clinical perspectives.
MDSC 521.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Fourth-year standing in the BHSc Honours program.

MDSC 523.title: AI Applications in Health
MDSC 523.description: A focus on concepts and ideas in artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning, including statistical approaches, visualization, and human-computer interactions. An exploration of current research in AI and machine learning with a specific focus on applications to health.
MDSC 523.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Medical Sciences 301 or 401; and 3 units from Computer Science 217, 219, 231 or 233.

MDSC 525.title: Global Survey Analysis
MDSC 525.description: Focusing on an important global health issue, this course provides hands-on experience analyzing and interpreting publicly available national health survey data obtained from selected low- or middle-income countries. Students will explore contextual factors of the issue in their chosen country and present the results of their investigation.
MDSC 525.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Medical Science 407 (minimum B- grade) or Statistics 207 (minimum B- grade) or Statistics 213 (minimum B-grade) or Statistics 321.

MDSC 528.title: Independent Studies in Health Science
MDSC 528.description: Exploration of a health science topic of interest. To include original and independent thought, practical research and the completion of written and oral reports.
MDSC 528.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the BHSc Honours program.

MDSC 535.title: Psychosocial Oncology
MDSC 535.description: Focuses on developing the understanding in health care practitioners of the central concepts related to caring for cancer patients and their families.

MDSC 541.title: Advanced Genetics I
MDSC 541.description: Principles of genetics and epigenetics and current techniques in the fields of regenerative and precision medicine will be discussed. Topics will focus on human and model organism genetics, breakthrough publications and their significance for current genetics research and applications. Students will explore significant recent discoveries and their social implications.

MDSC 543.title: Advanced Cyto-Molecular Genetics
MDSC 543.description: An advanced course in cyto-molecular genetics. Topics include the human genome and its complexity, chromosomal anomalies, genomic variation and mechanisms leading to disease, mitochondrial genetics, pharmacogenomics, and cyto- and molecular techniques used in the diagnosis of genetic disorders.

MDSC 545.title: Genomics
MDSC 545.description: Examine the strategies and techniques, including massively parallel sequencing, used in genomic and genetic studies. Review how model systems and genome editing are used to establish the functional consequences of genomic variation. Students can expect to gain a comprehensive understanding and broad appreciation of the significance of genomic information in context of rare and common human diseases, and genome biology.
MDSC 545.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Medical Science 408 or Cellular, Molecular and Microbial Biology 413.

MDSC 561.title: (CMMB 561)Cancer Biology
MDSC 561.description: Advances in methodology and in theoretical concepts have permitted continuing breakthroughs in our understanding of the organismal, cellular and molecular biology of cancer cells, and in the development of novel strategies for cancer prevention, diagnosis and treatment. These advances will be presented in a comprehensive overview of cancer including issues of demographics and incidence, causation and detection, origins and progression and therapeutic approaches. Emphasis will be placed on the cell and molecular biology of cancer and on the interaction of the cancer cell with the host organism.
MDSC 561.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BHSc Honours program; and Biochemistry 341 or 393; and Medical Science 341 or Biology 311; and Medical Science 351 or Biology 331; and Medical Science 408 or Cellular, Molecular and Microbial Biology 411.

Also known as: (Cellular, Molecular and Microbial Biology 561)

MDSC 565.title: (CMMB565) Advanced Topics in Microbial Pathogenesis and the Microbiome
MDSC 565.description: Provides a fuller understanding of bacterial diseases using a systems approach and illustrating key paradigms via the consideration of specific pathogens. Topics include: strategies for bacteria surviving host immune responses, bacterial invasion strategies, opportunistic infections, disease Pathogenesis, and antibiotic resistance, challenges of dealing with emerging infections. Lectures, small group interactive sessions, specified readings.
MDSC 565.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Cellular, Molecular and Microbial Biology 343 and 431.

Also known as: (Cellular, Molecular and Microbial Biology 565)

MDSC 567.title: (Cmmb 567)Advanced Topics in Immunology
MDSC 567.description: New and emerging themes in immunology, with an emphasis on disease processes such as inflammation in the gut, kidney and lung. Topics include: innate immunity, the inflammasome, sterile inflammation, process and mechanism of immune cell recruitment in different tissues, T cell biology, B cell biology, regulatory immune cells, mucosal immunity, airways responses to virus, mechanisms of food allergies, inflammatory bowel disease. Lectures, small group interactive sessions, specified readings.
MDSC 567.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Cellular, Molecular and Microbial Biology 527 or Medical Science 321.

Also known as: (Cellular, Molecular and Microbial Biology 567)

MDSC 569.title: Advanced Topics in Physiology
MDSC 569.description: Designed for undergraduates with a general understanding of human physiology who wish to pursue advanced topics in a physiological system(s). The physiological system offered will vary from year-to-year and students should contact the instructor for more information prior to enrolling in the course. There will be a review and then build on basic physiological principles through a series of lectures and/or discussion groups. An examination of the specified area of physiology in-depth by introducing students to research methodologies and pathological processes.
MDSC 569.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medical Science 404 or Zoology 463.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MDSC 603.title: Biology of Laboratory Animals
MDSC 603.description: Based on the Canadian Council of Animal Care Syllabus \"Basic Principles of Laboratory Animal Science for Research Scientists.\" In addition to the study of common, research, farm and exotic animals, topics covered include ethical considerations, regulation and legislation, animal models, animal facilities and husbandry, hazard control, surgery, anaesthesiology, euthanasia and post-mortem examinations. Practical sessions will provide experience in handling and restraint of specific laboratory animals, injections, blood collection, anaesthesiology and surgery.

MDSC 604.title: Integrative Human Physiology
MDSC 604.description: Physiology is the study of how living organisms function and encompasses the integration of processes from molecules to the whole-organism. Designed to provide the student with fundamental principles and concepts about the normal function of the major human organ systems. At the end of this course, the student should be well equipped to apply his/her acquired knowledge to solve complex physiological problems related to integrative human physiology.

MDSC 605.title: (Cpsc 605)Info Store Proc Bio Sys
MDSC 605.description:
Information Storage and Processing in Biological Systems
Examination of complex biological systems; concepts and fundamentals of biological solutions to information storage and processing: modelling and computer simulation of biological systems; information storage in biological molecules; genetic networks; hierarchical organization of biological information processing in signal transduction, development, evolution, and ecology; biological control systems.

MDSC 611.title: Medical Microbiology
MDSC 611.description: The course materials will cover basic principles of medical microbiology and the pathogenesis of infectious disease and of clinically important microbial pathogens including bacteria, viruses, parasites and fungi. Recent concepts will be discussed, and students will be expected to present and critically evaluate research advances from the current research literature through written assignments and case presentations.
MDSC 611.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Cellular, Molecular and Microbial Biology 343 and consent of the Faculty. 

Also known as: (formerly Medical Science 612)

MDSC 620.title: Topics in Systems Physiology
MDSC 620.description: Designed for students undertaking research in physiology or related disciplines with only limited prior exposure to the discipline. Introduces and discusses fundamental and current issues in physiology ranging from the basic physiological systems through to translational clinical topics. Encompasses the basic physiological mechanisms with emphasis on the role of the autonomic nervous system. Subject areas will include basic physiology of the cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, renal, endocrine and reproductive systems.

MDSC 621.title: Principles and Mechanisms of Pharmacology
MDSC 621.description: Basic principles of pharmacology with a focus on pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics, pharmacogenomics, plus mechanisms of action and signal transduction pathways for major drug classes. Clinical applications of pharmacological principles will be explored and include consideration of sex, genetics, age, adverse drug reactions and disease.

MDSC 622.title: Neurobiology of Mental Illness
MDSC 622.description: Students are exposed to up-to-date research regarding the neurobiological theories of various mental illnesses (such as depression, anxiety disorders, schizophrenia, etc.). The seminar format will involve discussion in both research and review articles. The focus of discussion will be on both preclinical research and clinical studies that shed insight into the neurobiology of mental illnesses or their treatments.
MDSC 622.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Medical Science 619.02 and admission to a Cumming School of Medicine graduate program.

MDSC 624.title: Neuroanatomy
MDSC 624.description: Detailed introduction to neuroanatomy using Homo sapiens as the primary experimental species but relying on other vertebrates for additional details. Detailed anatomic aspects of each major brain region, along with major connections and functions related to those regions will be presented. Laboratories will examine gross specimens, virtual microscopic images, and other anatomic images.
MDSC 624.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medical Science 619.02.

Also known as: (formerly Medical Science 751.42 Neuroanatomy)

MDSC 628.title: Introduction to Computational Neuroscience
MDSC 628.description: Introduces the mathematical foundations of computational neuroscience. This includes how to model and simulate neurons (Hodgkin-Huxley or conductance-based neurons, integrate-and-fire neurons, fitting neurons to data), how to connect neurons into networks (spiking neural networks, artificial neural networks, recurrent neural networks), analytical and computational simplifications to these networks (mean-field modelling), and includes a brief introduction to techniques machine learning. This course is intended for students with a quantitative background, with a particular emphasis on dynamical systems theory, ordinary differential equations, and linear algebra.
MDSC 628.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 213, 313, 367 and 375 or equivalent.

Also known as (formerly Medical Science 755.10)

MDSC 630.title: Principles and Applications of Light Microscopy
MDSC 630.description: Targeted to students who have little formal training in optical microscopy but need a strong understanding of this subject matter for their thesis work. Students will learn: widefield fluorescence, confocal, two-photon, lightsheet, STED superresolution and up-to-date image analysis methods such as machine learning/deep learning. The course project can also be tailored to the student's own thesis work.
MDSC 630.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the instructor.   

Anti-requisite: Credit for Medical Science 630 and Medical Graduate Education 632, 633 and 634 will not be allowed.

MDSC 631.title: Muscle Physiology
MDSC 631.description: Contractile processes, excitation-contraction coupling, the control of contraction and energetics in smooth, cardiac and skeletal muscle. Molecular studies of the contractile process and of the process of excitation contraction coupling.

MDSC 632.title: Evolution and Development
MDSC 632.description: Provides an overview of evolutionary developmental biology by exploring the key concepts that link evolution and development, their history, and their arrangement into explanatory frameworks, research agendas and narratives. The course also deals with the future of this field and its relationship to neighbouring disciplines, most especially genetics and the biomedical study of disease. The format is group discussion and lectures. Background in evolutionary biology or developmental biology is required.

MDSC 635.title: Psychosocial Oncology
MDSC 635.description:
A seminar-based course focusing on the possible causes of psychosocial problems in cancer patients and families (medical, psychological and social) and on how patients and families are helped through the difficult transitions resulting from a cancer diagnosis, treatment, recurrent disease, and end of life care. The course is open to health professionals and researchers, and to advanced undergraduate students in relevant disciplines. 
Course Hours: 3 units; (3-0)

MDSC 636.title: Advanced Topics in Physiology
MDSC 636.description: Provides a general understanding in physiological systems and will present advanced topics in specified physiological system(s) for further depth of understanding. Review and build on basic physiological principles through a series of lectures and discussion groups and will examine a specified area of physiology in-depth by introducing students to research methodology and pathological processes in the system.
MDSC 636.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Medical Science 404 or Zoology 463.

Also known as: (Medical Science 569)

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MDSC 638.title: Mucosal Pathophysiology
MDSC 638.description:
An independent study course that focuses on the physiology and pathophysiology of the gastrointestinal tract, lung and other mucosal tissues. A particular emphasis will be placed on inflammatory processes in these tissues, and how they contribute to symptom generation and tissue dysfunction. Involves independent research on the part of the students, small group tutorials, written assignments and laboratory exercises. The course will be divided into three sections.				
Medical Science 637.01 recommended.

MDSC 640.title: Introduction to Immunology
MDSC 640.description: Introductory immunology course for graduate students who had no background in immunology in their undergraduate studies. It provides a comprehensive overview of the immune responses: antibody-antigen interaction, antibody structure, genetics and synthesis, cellular immunology, MHC, phagocytosis, and tolerance. Using this basic understanding of fundamental immune processes the involvement of the immune response in autoimmunity, hypersensitivity, tissue rejection, tumor biology, vaccine production, viral, bacterial, fungal and parasitic infections will be discussed. Additionally, methods for the study of immunology will be covered.

MDSC 650.title: (MDCH649)Epidemiology of Infectious Diseases
MDSC 650.description: Focuses on the principles of epidemiology that are of relevance to infectious diseases. The course emphasizes the research aspects of infectious diseases epidemiology and how the basic techniques of epidemiology and biostatistics are applied to understanding communicable diseases. The course will introduce knowledge and skills in clinical and community-based epidemiology, infectious diseases, antimicrobial therapy, microbial pathogenesis, molecular epidemiology, and evaluation of relevant health-care services.
MDSC 650.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Medical Science 611 or Cellular, Molecular and Microbial Biology 421 or 521.

MDSC 660.title: Extreme Physiology and Neurotechnology
MDSC 660.description: The stages of the commercialization of neurotechnology and physiology will be covered. Experts will discuss the commercialization of neurotechnology and teaches how to develop neuroscience discoveries into commercializable concepts. This course is intended to provide insight into Extreme Physiology by surveying several different physiological systems and develop an understanding of how innovation and commercialization of neurotechnology by companies can transform this space.

MDSC 663.title: (Enme/Knes 663)Advanced Muscle Mechanics and Physiology
MDSC 663.description: A look at problems associated within muscle mechanics and contractility. Also the use of muscle mechanics as a scientific discipline to critically learn and evaluate the scientific process. Basic anatomy and physiology of muscle contraction including the cross-bridge theory, and the force-length, force-velocity and force-time relationships of actively and passively contracting muscles will also be covered.
MDSC 663.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Faculty.

Also known as: (Kinesiology 663) (Mechanical Engineering 663)

MDSC 675.title: Bioinformatics Resource Biologist
MDSC 675.description: This introductory graduate level course will familiarize biologists with algorithms and search engines used to analyze nucleic acid and protein sequences and structures.

MDSC 676.title: Scripting and Database Querying for Molecular Biologists
MDSC 676.description:
Intended for biologists who wish to improve their bioinformatics analysis capabilities by learning just a small amount of query and programming syntax. The focus is on practicality rather than programming theory. The course explores how to use existing tools (on the command-line and on the Web) to gather and process large datasets all at once, rather than doing many individual analyses manually.

Notes: No prior programming experience is required.

MDSC 677.title: Directed Study in Biomedical Technology
MDSC 677.description: Lectures, seminars, term papers or training in theoretical and/or laboratory methods at the advanced level in biomedical technology or medical sciences.
MDSC 677.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of both the faculty member who will supervise and the MBT faculty member who will co-supervise the chosen study and must be registered in the Master of Biomedical Technology program.	

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MDSC 678.title: Project in Biomedical Technology
MDSC 678.description: Covers basic principles of project management as well as biotech lab theory and practical aspects. Includes commercial technology reviews, tours, demos and practical labs. Includes development of the scientific aspects of a project based on a disease, pharmaceutical, or device of current interest, culminating in a poster presentation and business pitch of the science and business aspects.
MDSC 678.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Biomedical Technology Graduate Program or consent of the instructor(s).

MDSC 685.title: Biomechanics of Human Movement
MDSC 685.description: Introduction to the measuring methods (accelerometry, goniometry, film and film analysis, video systems) of biomechanical analysis of human movement (force and force distribution). Description of the mechanical properties of bone, tendon, ligaments, cartilage, muscles, and soft tissues. The relation between structure and function of biomaterials. Introduction in descriptive analysis of human movement.

MDSC 701.title: Advanced Topics in Reproductive Health
MDSC 701.description: A series of topics, ranging from basic sciences to clinical topics (including ethical issues) to increase awareness and comprehension regarding current issues in reproductive health.
MDSC 701.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Consent of course co-ordinator and students supervisor, if applicable.

MDSC 703.title: Human Anatomy: Concepts, Exploration and Teaching
MDSC 703.description: Introductory course for graduate students with an interest in mammalian morphology, human anatomy concepts and educational strategies within the medical professional curriculum. Weekly lectures and discussions supplement a cadaver dissection-based course intended for students interested in pursuing an academic and clinical career in a medically related field.

MDSC 708.title: Theory & Practice of Interprofessional Psychosocial Oncology
MDSC 708.description: Provides graduate students with a multidisciplinary introduction to the field of psychosocial oncology.  Emphasis will be placed on understanding and interpreting the experience of cancer informed by theory, evidence and illness narratives.  Case based learning in small interprofessional groups will allow students to explore a variety of key learning themes relevant to psychosocial oncology including distress assessment, depression, anxiety, adjustment and coping, sexuality, loss and grief.  Attention to diversity will be integrated throughout the course.

MDSC 710.title: Business and Careers in Biotechnology
MDSC 710.description: An overview of the biotechnology sector from several perspectives: product development, regulatory, intellectual property, market analysis and finance. This course will include series of lectures and discussions to provide both the necessary background about the biotechnology industry and an understanding of careers in the biotechnology industry.
MDSC 710.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a thesis-based Master's or Doctoral program in the Cumming School of Medicine or graduate programs in Veterinary Medicine or Biomedical Engineering.

MDSC 713.title: Topics in Mountain Medicine and High Altitude Physiology
MDSC 713.description: A tutorial-based course focused on high altitude medicine and physiology.  The aim of the course is to introduce the students to the physiological adaptations of, and pathophysiology associated with, the hypoxia of altitude.  Students will be introduced to several diseases associated with the hypoxia of high altitude (i.e., Acute Mountain Sickness; High Altitude Pulmonary Edema, High Altitude Cerebral Edema), and the pathophysiology underlying these diseases.

MDSC 740.title: Smooth Muscle Structure Function
MDSC 740.description: An inquiry-based approach used to provide students with a broad background for the study of smooth muscle and to introduce students to current trends in the field. Students will also be introduced to the spectrum of research on smooth muscle ongoing at the University of Calgary. The subjects to be included range from the molecular biology and biochemistry of individual proteins to the function and regulation of integrated smooth muscle systems. A number of methodological approaches that are being used for the study of smooth muscle will also be discussed.

MDSC 755.title: Directed Study
MDSC 755.description: Lectures, seminars, term papers or training in theoretical and/or laboratory methods at the advanced level in the medical sciences.

MDSC 417.01.title: Genetics I
MDSC 417.01.description: Provides students with the basic conceptual framework, knowledge and skill set to work and think independently in a medical science or life science research environment in their topic area. The course will include lectures in the various topic areas, group sessions and self-directed research project in the topic area.
MDSC 417.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Medical Science 308, 341 and admission to the BHSc Honours program.

MDSC 417.02.title: Microbiology, Immunology and Infection I
MDSC 417.02.description: Provides students with the basic conceptual framework, knowledge and skill set to work and think independently in a medical science or life science research environment in their topic area. MDSC 419.01.title: Genetics II
MDSC 419.01.description: Provides students with the basic conceptual framework, knowledge and skill set to work and think independently in a medical science or life science research environment in their topic area. The course will be a continuation of the courses topic areas, and will for the most part consist of the self-directed laboratory research project started in the topic area in Medical Science 417.
MDSC 419.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Corresponding Medical Science 417 course taken in the immediately preceding semester of study.

MDSC 419.02.title: Microbiology, Immunology and Infection II
MDSC 419.02.description: Provides students with the basic conceptual framework, knowledge and skill set to work and think independently in a medical science or life science research environment in their topic area. MDSC 419.07.title: Neuroscience II

MDSC 419.08.title: Special Topics II
MDSC 419.08.description: Provides students with the basic conceptual framework, knowledge and skill set to work and think independently in a medical science or life science research environment in their topic area. The course will be a continuation of the courses topic areas, and will for the most part consist of the self-directed laboratory research project started in the topic area in Medical Science 417.
MDSC 419.08.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Corresponding MDSC 417 course taken in the immediately preceding semester of study.

MDSC 609.02.title: Genes and Development
MDSC 609.02.description: Genetic control and cellular basis of development. Topics include an introduction to the major genetic model organisms, the regulation of gene expression and pattern formation by developmental signals, and the cellular basis of cell signalling, cell and tissue polarity, and morphogenesis.
MDSC 609.02.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the program. A strong background in undergraduate genetics and developmental biology is recommended.

MDSC 619.01.title: Cellular, Molecular and Developmental Neuroscience
MDSC 619.01.description: Introductory neuroscience courses covering aspects of cellular, molecular, and systems physiology, neuroanatomy, and neurodevelopment.
MDSC 619.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Neuroscience Graduate Program or consent of the instructor.

MDSC 619.02.title: Systems Neuroscience and Neuropathology
MDSC 619.02.description: Introductory neuroscience courses covering aspects of cellular, molecular, and systems physiology, neuroanatomy, and neurodevelopment.
MDSC 619.02.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Neuroscience Graduate Program or consent of the instructor.

MDSC 623.01.title: Pulmonary Mechanics and Gas Exchange
MDSC 623.01.description: Respiratory physiology;including topics such as cellular, morphology, mechanics, control of breathing, and respiratory muscles, necessary to an understanding of respiration and respiratory failure. As well, core physiology and molecular biology underlying critical illness.

MDSC 623.02.title: Physiology of Respiration and Critical Illness
MDSC 623.02.description: Respiratory physiology;including topics such as cellular, morphology, mechanics, control of breathing, and respiratory muscles, necessary to an understanding of respiration and respiratory failure. As well, core physiology and molecular biology underlying critical illness.

MDSC 623.03.title: Respiratory Science: Basic
MDSC 623.03.description: Respiratory physiology;including topics such as cellular, morphology, mechanics, control of breathing, and respiratory muscles, necessary to an understanding of respiration and respiratory failure. As well, core physiology and molecular biology underlying critical illness.

MDSC 623.04.title: Respiratory Science: Applied
MDSC 623.04.description: Respiratory physiology;including topics such as cellular, morphology, mechanics, control of breathing, and respiratory muscles, necessary to an understanding of respiration and respiratory failure. As well, core physiology and molecular biology underlying critical illness.

MDSC 637.01.title: Organization and Function of the GI Tract
MDSC 637.01.description: Physiology of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract at all levels from the cell to the intact system. Medical Science 637.01 has three components: 1) An introductory series of lectures covering the basic physiological principles of the regulation of the GI tract and the individual organs associated with it. A mid-term exam is held on the content delivered; 2) A written term paper on a subject of the students' own choice and pre-approved by the course co-ordinator that will also be presented orally to the class; and 3) A series of special GI-associated topic areas and journal club sessions presented and discussed with invited experts in the field. Assessment includes written critiques of primary research articles.

MDSC 639.02.title: Cellular and Molecular Immunology
MDSC 639.02.description: Introductory and advanced courses in immunology that cover humoral and cellular immunity and the inflammatory response at the cellular, molecular, and whole organism level. Basic mechanisms that lead to immunity or to inflammatory responses. The contribution of immunological and inflammatory processes in the immunopathogenesis of disease.
MDSC 639.02.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Cellular, Molecular and Microbial Biology 527.

MDSC 639.04.title: Inflammation
MDSC 639.04.description: Introductory and advanced courses in immunology that cover humoral and cellular immunity and the inflammatory response at the cellular, molecular, and whole organism level. Basic mechanisms that lead to immunity or to inflammatory responses. The contribution of immunological and inflammatory processes in the immunopathogenesis of disease.
MDSC 639.04.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Cellular, Molecular and Microbial Biology 527.

MDSC 641.01.title: Advanced Genetics I
MDSC 641.01.description: Principles of genetics and epigenetics and current techniques in the fields of regenerative and precision medicine will be discussed. Topics will focus on human and model organism genetics, breakthrough publications and their significance for current genetics research and applications. Students will explore significant recent discoveries and their social implications.

MDSC 641.03.title: Advanced Human Cyto-Molecular Genetics
MDSC 641.03.description: Principles of genetics and epigenetics and current techniques in the fields of regenerative and precision medicine will be discussed. Topics will focus on human and model organism genetics, breakthrough publications and their significance for current genetics research and applications. Students will explore significant recent discoveries and their social implications.

MDSC 641.04.title: Genomics
MDSC 641.04.description: Principles of genetics and epigenetics and current techniques in the fields of regenerative and precision medicine will be discussed. Topics will focus on human and model organism genetics, breakthrough publications and their significance for current genetics research and applications. Students will explore significant recent discoveries and their social implications.

MDSC 689.01.title: Medical Imaging Techniques
MDSC 689.01.description: Introduction to the theory and practical applications of medical imaging. Specific courses focus on an overview of modern diagnostic imaging techniques (689.01), as well as advanced study of specific techniques including magnetic resonance imaging (689.02) and medical image processing (689.03), and medical imaging applications (689.11).
MDSC 689.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program with specialization in Medical Imaging.

MDSC 689.02.title: Advanced Magnetic Resonance Imaging
MDSC 689.02.description: Introduction to the theory and practical applications of medical imaging. Specific courses focus on an overview of modern diagnostic imaging techniques (689.01), as well as advanced study of specific techniques including magnetic resonance imaging (689.02) and medical image processing (689.03), and medical imaging applications (689.11).
MDSC 689.02.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program with specialization in Medical Imaging.

MDSC 689.03.title: Advanced Medical Image Processing
