Specific courses focus on an overview of modern diagnostic imaging techniques (689.01), as well as advanced study of specific techniques including magnetic resonance imaging (689.02) and medical image processing (689.03), and medical imaging applications (689.11).
MDSC 689.03.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program with specialization in Medical Imaging.

MDSC 689.11.title: Medical Imaging Applications
MDSC 689.11.description: Introduction to the theory and practical applications of medical imaging. Specific courses focus on an overview of modern diagnostic imaging techniques (689.01), as well as advanced study of specific techniques including magnetic resonance imaging (689.02) and medical image processing (689.03), and medical imaging applications (689.11).
MDSC 689.11.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program with specialization in Medical Imaging.

MDSC 689.99.title: Medical Imaging Project
MDSC 689.99.description: Introduction to the theory and practical applications of medical imaging. Specific courses focus on an overview of modern diagnostic imaging techniques (689.01), as well as advanced study of specific techniques including magnetic resonance imaging (689.02) and medical image processing (689.03), and medical imaging applications (689.11).
MDSC 689.99.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program with specialization in Medical Imaging.

MDSC 706.01.title: Theory and Practice of Family Therapy I: Systemic Approaches
MDSC 706.01.description: Overview of different family therapy approaches focusing on systemic assessment and systemic intervention through therapeutic interviewing. The development of student knowledge and skills in family therapy utilizing social constructionist, narrative, systemic, collaborative, and pro-feminist ideas while fostering the professional identity of the therapist.
MDSC 706.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in the Cumming School of Medicine.

MDSC 706.02.title: Theory and Practice of Family Therapy II: Postmodern Approaches
MDSC 706.02.description: Overview of different family therapy approaches focusing on systemic assessment and systemic intervention through therapeutic interviewing. The development of student knowledge and skills in family therapy utilizing social constructionist, narrative, systemic, collaborative, and pro-feminist ideas while fostering the professional identity of the therapist.
MDSC 706.02.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in the Cumming School of Medicine.

MDSC 707.01.title: Family Therapy I
MDSC 707.01.description: The development of conceptual and experiential expertise in working therapeutically with families.
MDSC 707.01.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Faculty.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDSC 707.02.title: Family Therapy II
MDSC 707.02.description: The development of conceptual and experiential expertise in working therapeutically with families.
MDSC 707.02.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Faculty.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MDSC 722.01.title: Vascular Biology
MDSC 722.01.description: Modular course offering advanced knowledge at the cellular, molecular, and whole organism levels including the hormonal regulation of the vascular system, the interaction between endothelium and smooth muscle in the blood vessel, the molecular mechanisms underlying smooth muscle contraction and relaxation, differentiation and dedifferentiation, and the pathogenesis of vascular diseases including hypertension and atherosclerosis. Drug treatments for vascular diseases and their molecular mechanisms will also be covered.
MDSC 722.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in the Cumming School of Medicine.

MDSC 722.02.title: Vascular Pharmacology
MDSC 722.02.description: Modular course offering advanced knowledge at the cellular, molecular, and whole organism levels including the hormonal regulation of the vascular system, the interaction between endothelium and smooth muscle in the blood vessel, the molecular mechanisms underlying smooth muscle contraction and relaxation, differentiation and dedifferentiation, and the pathogenesis of vascular diseases including hypertension and atherosclerosis. Drug treatments for vascular diseases and their molecular mechanisms will also be covered.
MDSC 722.02.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in the Cumming School of Medicine.

MDSC 751.07.title: The Physiological Development of the Fetus and Newborn

MGST 217.title: Introduction to Business Analytics
MGST 217.description: Introduction to data representation and analysis. Students will think critically about business problems, gather, evaluate, analyze and synthesize relevant data, and create insightful models to improve the quality of decisions. Communicating and presenting quantitative analysis to lead managerial decision making will be emphasized while continuing to advance both individual and group leadership skills.
MGST 217.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business.

MGST 301.title: Research Methodologies
MGST 301.description: Introduction to how research is being done in the field of business, through critical exploration of research language, ethics and approaches. Quantitative, qualitative and mixed methods approaches presented by faculty researchers. Students experiment with various research methods, identify problems, develop hypotheses and research questions, specify variables and choose from various research design tools such as experiments, survey, content analysis, focus groups and in-depth interviews.
MGST 301.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business Bachelor of Commerce (Honours) program.

MGST 303.title: Personal Career Strategies
MGST 303.description: Focus on workplace skill development, including career management, workplace communication and ethics, career readiness competencies, and leadership development through experiential learning. Students will make connections between their skills, interests, values, strategies, and habits that contribute to professional success.
MGST 303.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 24 units.

MGST 359.title: Selected Topics in Management
MGST 359.description: Examination of selected topics in management.
MGST 359.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 24 units. For certain topics consent of the Haskayne School of Business and/or admission to the Haskayne School of Business will also be required.

MGST 391.title: Business Analytics
MGST 391.description: Business Analytics uses data, information technology, statistical analysis, and quantitative methods to build models that help managers gain improved insight about their business processes and make better, fact-based decisions. Analysis of complex business problems and application of higher-level modelling techniques including optimization, simulation, decision analysis, queuing theory and forecasting.
MGST 391.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Mathematics 249 or 251 or 265 or 281, Statistics 217, Management Studies 217 and Strategy and Global Management 217.

MGST 451.title: Corporate Governance and Ethical Decision-Making
MGST 451.description: Develop an increased awareness of the importance of corporate governance systems and strong financial decision-making systems in developing effective business enterprises. Specific emphasis on the resolution of agency problems, the role of the board of directors, compensation systems and financial modelling.
MGST 451.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 54 units including Finance 317.

MGST 453.title: Ethical Leadership
MGST 453.description: Apply a variety of different leadership frameworks to problems and develop an understanding of when various frameworks are most applicable. Critical thinking skills will be honed using film, short cases, readings, class discussions, and written opinion. Identify components of leadership behaviours and explore the complex interaction between leaders and members in the context of different ethical quandaries. Witness, experience, and "consume" leadership as it progresses from individual to team to organizational to community levels.
MGST 453.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 84 units, including Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 317.

MGST 501.title: Capstone Applied Research Project I
MGST 501.description: Preparation for conducting an applied research project. Focus is on practical research issues such as choosing appropriate applied research topics, designing a research question, and applying the appropriate research methods. Development of the applied research project through identification of a potential client or organization and a field expert to work with.
MGST 501.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business Bachelor of Commerce (Honours) program and Management Studies 301.

MGST 503.title: Capstone Applied Research Project II
MGST 503.description: Continuation of work on the applied research project. Knowledge production and dissemination of insights from research. Analysis of data and communication of results to business and university stakeholders. Preliminary development of insights using collected data, critical evaluation of the project limitations and contribution, and delivery of results in an Honours undergraduate thesis.
MGST 503.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business Bachelor of Commerce (Honours) program, Management Studies 301 and 501.

MGST 559.title: Selected Topics in Management
MGST 559.description: Examination of selected topics in management.
MGST 559.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 60 units. For certain topics, consent of the Haskayne School of Business will also be required.

MGST 571.title: Management of International Trade
MGST 571.description: Concepts and skills required to conduct international transactions in goods and services, including contracts, transportation, financing, insurance, customs clearance, compliance with import/export regulations and dispute resolution.
MGST 571.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 60 units.

MGST 597.title: Directed Study in Management Studies
MGST 597.description: In-depth study in one of the functional areas of business.
MGST 597.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to and consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

MGST 611.title: Managerial Economics
MGST 611.description: Introduction to economic models for business decision making. Models from microeconomics are applied to provide insight in understanding costs, pricing, industry structure, and competitive interaction. Information economics is used to illustrate principal-agent problems that commonly arise in a business context. Macroeconomic models of supply and demand are applied to illustrate how government policy affects inflation and exchange rates.

MGST 613.title: Managerial Decision Modeling
MGST 613.description: The transformation of raw data into useful information for decision-making. Quantitative models are implemented with spreadsheets to develop skills in generating managerial insight from data and in dealing with uncertainty. Topics covered include basic probability and statistics, decision trees, regression analysis, optimization, and simulation.

MGST 615.title: Strategic Business Analysis
MGST 615.description: Integrates learning from various management disciplines through \"field experience\" projects.  Students work with project sponsors and others in the organization, providing deep analysis and evidence-based recommendations on challenges and opportunities.
MGST 615.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Strategy and Global Management 601 and completion of 30 units offered by the Haskayne School of Business at the 600 level.

Also known as: (formerly Management Studies 715)

MGST 616.title: Master of Business Administration Graduate Internship
MGST 616.description: Students registered in this course will undertake a full-time internship.
MGST 616.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MGST 623.title: Corporate Governance
MGST 623.description: Building on established theory, this course will use lectures, cases, and real world examples to identify how corporate governance systems have evolved to help mitigate agency issues within an organization.

MGST 631.title: Prescriptive Analysis in Business
MGST 631.description: Advanced quantitative decision-making and problem-solving skills in business environments with data and fact-based analysis. Techniques such as data-driven optimization, deterministic and probabilistic modeling, and simulation are covered through case studies.

MGST 641.title: Business Process Improvement and Creative Problem Solving
MGST 641.description: Business process improvement and creative problem solving as critical components of competitiveness. The adjective \"business\" is used to indicate that the course emphasizes improvements in non-manufacturing processes (of relevance to all organizations) in such areas as development, distribution, financial accounting/planning, order entry, personnel, and purchasing. Topics covered include the relationship to Total Quality Management and Time-Based Competition, incremental versus radical improvement, selection of key processes for study (including bench-marking and the role of capacity constraints), process flow diagramming, Pareto analysis, cause-and-effect analysis, statistical control charts, affinity diagrams, and steps in creative problem solving.
MGST 641.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Operations Management 601.

Also known as: (formerly Management Studies 741)

MGST 643.title: Study Tour
MGST 643.description: Examines effects of globalization on International and Canadian business. Normally encompasses visits to two international destinations. The class participates in the selection of destinations and researches relevant industries.
MGST 643.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Operations Management 601.

Also known as: (formerly Management Studies 743)

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MGST 651.title: Global Energy Finance and Accounting
MGST 651.description: Problems related to evaluating and financing energy enterprises. Financial and accounting principles applied to valuing and financing energy projects. Financial reporting, managerial control systems, theory of financing, valuation, and deal structuring. Focus on private sector energy enterprises.
MGST 651.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Accounting 603 and Finance 601.

Also known as: (formerly Management Studies 751)

MGST 667.title: Directed Masters Study in Management Studies
MGST 667.description: Coverage of various topics on the basis of student and faculty interest.
MGST 667.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MGST 668.title: Seminar in Management Studies
MGST 668.description: Intensive study and discussion of current literature and research with respect to selected topics in Management Studies.
MGST 668.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): For certain topics, consent of the Haskayne School of Business will also be required.

Also known as: (formerly Management Studies 789)

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MGST 670.title: Work Integrated Learning Topics in Management Studies
MGST 670.description: Coverage of various topics in management studies with an outside partner or organization.
MGST 670.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Management program.

MGST 672.title: Introduction to Business
MGST 672.description: Introduces the functional areas of business and their integration for the effective and efficient operation of organizations. Provides the foundation for the discipline based courses.
MGST 672.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Management program.

MGST 674.title: Integrated Decision Making
MGST 674.description: Integrative capstone course that challenges students to effectively respond to multi-functional problems.
MGST 674.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Management program.

MGST 676.title: Business Analytics
MGST 676.description: Analytical tools and techniques for managerial decision, and their application to decision scenarios that parallel common business decisions.
MGST 676.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Management program.

MGST 677.title: Master of Management Graduate Internship
MGST 677.description: Students registered in this program will undertake a full-time internship.
MGST 677.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Master of Management Program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MGST 678.title: Storytelling with Data
MGST 678.description: Examines how data visualizations are critical for understanding the messages the data is trying to communicate and ensuring the right visuals are crafted to deliver insights to stakeholders.
MGST 678.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Management program.

MGST 679.title: Topics in Management Studies
MGST 679.description: Coverage of various topics in management studies.
MGST 679.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Management Program

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MGST 703.title: Philosophy of Science for Business Administration
MGST 703.description: Examines processes of development and discussion of theories, with a focus on business management research. Exploration of three main questions: (i) what is the role of theory in science; (ii) what makes good management theories; and (iii) how can theories in management or related disciplines be developed and tested. Classical philosophy of science, management research papers focused on scientific theory and explanation, and prescriptive studies with strategies or methods for theory development in management and related disciplines, are reviewed.
MGST 703.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Business Administration program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MGST 705.title: Introduction to Research
MGST 705.description: Provides critical insights into the research process through the development of skills associated with the evaluation and use of extant research. Emphasis is on critical reading of introductions, theoretical arguments, methods and results sections of experimental and non-experimental research papers. The focus is on relating the methodology and findings to the theoretical and conceptual arguments presented. Discussions regarding the validity and appropriateness of the methodologies utilized are used to facilitate an understanding of research contributions.
MGST 705.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Business Administration program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MGST 707.title: Research Development and Design
MGST 707.description: Advanced study of research methodologies. Students will actively take a research project from its beginnings to completion. Emphasis will be placed on research design, ethical considerations, ruling out conflicting theories, and situating within the engaged scholarship space. Students will be required to write a scholarly paper and to present their results to a panel of students and faculty.
MGST 707.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Business Administration program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MGST 709.title: Qualitative Research Methods
MGST 709.description: Development of skills to conduct qualitative research in the context of business. Focus on research design and the processes of collecting and analyzing qualitative data as well as drawing conclusions and reporting research findings. Specific emphasis is given to case study research, ethnographic, and focus group research. Grounded theory, action research, narrative, and discursive research is also introduced.
MGST 709.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Business Administration program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MGST 711.title: Quantitative Design and Analysis
MGST 711.description: Development of skills associated with the design and implementation of experimental and non-experimental research. Focus is on building capacity to conduct quantitative research.
MGST 711.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Business Administration program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MGST 714.title: Engaged Scholarship and the Use of Evidence
MGST 714.description: Sets out a clear framework and guidelines for carrying out soundly based and useful research. Establishes strong links between research and practice and develops understanding of the nature of evidence.
MGST 714.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Business Administration program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MGST 746.title: Topics in Business Management
MGST 746.description: Covers various topics such as business economics, international business or risk management. Focuses on understanding academic research on the course topics and the implications of such research to management practice.
MGST 746.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Business Administration program.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MGST 748.title: Topics in Advanced Business Management
MGST 748.description: Covers selected topics with a more in-depth critical examination of the academic research. Discusses the implications of such critical examination for management practice.
MGST 748.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Business Administration program.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MGST 754.title: Linear Models I
MGST 754.description: Concepts, applications, and implementation of the general linear model in behavioural science research: Multiple regression, multiple and partial association, categorical predictors (ANOVA/ANCOVA), hypothesis testing, use of computer software.
MGST 754.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Haskayne School of Business. 

Also known as: (formerly Management Studies 799.25 (The General Linear Model))

MGST 755.title: Linear Models II
MGST 755.description: Extensions of the general linear model in behavioural science research: Dichotomous and ordinal outcome models, exploratory and confirmatory factor analysis (covariance structure modeling), multilevel modeling, use of computer software.
MGST 755.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Management Studies 754 and consent of the Haskayne School of Business. 

Also known as: (formerly Management Studies 799.26 Multivariate Analysis)

MGST 756.title: Advanced Linear and Multilevel Modelling
MGST 756.description: This is an advanced statistics course on linear and multilevel modelling, with a practical "how-to" focus using advanced software packages. Topics include linear and multilevel regression, CFA/SEM, and longitudinal analyses.
MGST 756.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Psychology 615 or Management Studies 754; and Psychology 617 or Management Studies 755; and consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

Also known as: (formerly Management Studies 799.12 (Linear and Multilevel Modeling in Mplus))

MGST 771.title: Occupational Health Psychology
MGST 771.description: Occupational health psychology (OHP) focuses on applying psychology to improving quality of work life and enhancing the health, safety, and well-being of employees, their families, and their communities. This course provides exposure to seminal readings and current and emerging issues in OHP. The primary research literature is critically examined, focusing on appropriateness of design, analysis, interpretation, contribution and future research directions, as well as practical implications of this work.
MGST 771.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Haskayne School of Business

Also known as: (formerly Management Studies 799.14 Occupational Health Psychology)

MGST 773.title: Advanced Multivariate Analysis
MGST 773.description: Advanced graduate course in multivariate data analysis including specialized topics. In-depth treatment of techniques includes model assumption, formulation, estimation, statistical tests, and validation. Knowledge of matrix and linear algebra is required.
MGST 773.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

MGST 781.title: Philosophy of Science in Management Studies
MGST 781.description: Historical and critical perspectives of classical issues in philosophy of science, nature of scientific explanation, confirmation of scientific theories, theories of truth, distinctions between science and non-science.
MGST 781.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Haskayne School of Business

MGST 782.title: Systematic Review and Meta Analysis
MGST 782.description: Covers the practical fundamentals of systematic review and meta-analysis, such as for a masters or PhD theses, from conception to write-up. Individuals should leave with a conference level review.
MGST 782.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

Also known as: (formerly Management Studies 787.01 Systematic Review and Meta Analysis)

MGST 783.title: Advanced Research Methodology and Methods
MGST 783.description: Research methodology relevant to examination and testing of theoretical and applied issues in management. The development and testing of research concepts; research operations, designs and analysis.
MGST 783.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

MGST 784.title: Statistical Mediation Analysis
MGST 784.description: Quantification and testing of hypotheses about the mechanisms underlying causal effects from a linear modeling perspective. Direct, indirect, and total effects, inference, model specification and interpretation, implementation with computer software.
MGST 784.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Psychology 615 or Sociology 611 or 3 units at the 600 level or above in regression analysis/linear models and consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

Also known as: (formerly Management Studies 799.17 Statistical Mediation Analysis)

MGST 785.title: Statistical Moderation Analysis
MGST 785.description: Quantification and testing of hypotheses about the contingencies of effects from a linear modeling perspective. Unconditional and conditional effects, moderation/interaction, visualizing and probing models, multiple moderators, use of computer software.
MGST 785.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Psychology 615 or Sociology 611 or 3 units at the 600 level or above in regression analysis/linear models and consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

Also known as: (formerly Management Studies 799.18 Statistical Moderation Analysis)

MGST 791.title: Management Education Seminar
MGST 791.description: Curricular and course design, instructional techniques, instructional tools, teaching styles, career planning and professional ethics. Nature, role and function of universities, and business schools, business school relations.
MGST 791.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MGST 793.title: Conceptual Frameworks of the Enterprise
MGST 793.description: Advanced, comparative institutional analysis to explain the choice of the firm's boundaries, the governance mechanisms to manage the interface with the external environment and the internal organizational design, so as to reduce transaction costs and facilitate value creation.
MGST 793.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

MGST 794.title: Theory Development
MGST 794.description: Processes of building, testing, and disseminating business management theories. Focus on the elements that constitute a theory, requirements for theory validation, and the role of theory in business management research. Analysis of mainstream theories in business management research. Readings include philosophy of science and management research materials on theory development and dissemination.
MGST 794.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

MGST 795.title: Research Development
MGST 795.description: Development of research skills through participation in a well-defined project under the direct supervision of an experienced researcher.
MGST 795.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Management Studies 781 or 783.

Also known as: (formerly Management Studies 792)

MGST 797.title: Directed Doctoral Study in Management
MGST 797.description: Coverage of various topics on the basis of student and faculty interest.
MGST 797.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MGST 799.title: Topics in Management Studies
MGST 799.description: Coverage of various topics on the basis of student and faculty interests.
MGST 799.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s):  Consent of the Haskayne School of Business

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MHST 201.title: Intro Museum & Heritage Studies
MHST 201.description:
This course introduces the field of Museum and Heritage Studies by examining heritage sites, museums, art galleries, zoos, natural parks and others.  Traditional institutions will be examined along with new forms including virtual museums.

Notes: Students may be required to attend off-campus events outside of class time.

MHST 331.title: Collections and Exhibitions in Museum and Heritage Institutions
MHST 331.description: Examines the nature of collecting, curating, exhibiting and interpreting material and non-material culture in museums and heritage institutions.

MHST 333.title: Ethics in Museum and Heritage Studies
MHST 333.description: Introduction to ethics in museums and heritage studies. An examination of some recent museums and heritage resources crises. Also museum/heritage processes including the acquisition of artifacts, exhibitions and the representation of indigenous and other minority peoples, interpretation, the appropriateness of conservation, and museum management.

MHST 401.title: Topics in Museum and Heritage Studies
MHST 401.description: An examination of selected topics in Museum and Heritage Studies.
MHST 401.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Museum and Heritage Studies 201.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MHST 433.title: Management and Planning in Museum and Heritage Institutions
MHST 433.description: Examines theoretical and practical issues relating to the management of museum and heritage resources. Topics may include: exhibition planning, human resources, ethics and social responsibility, fundraising, collections, and audience development etc.

MHST 501.title: Directed Research in Selected Topics
MHST 501.description: Supervised individual study of a special topic.
MHST 501.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Program Coordinator.

MHST 533.title: Practicum
MHST 533.description:
Placement at a museological or heritage institution.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisites or Corequisites: Museum and Heritage Studies 433 and consent of the Museum and Heritage Studies Program Co-ordinator.

Notes: Students must contact the Museum and Heritage Studies Program Co-ordinator for consent at least three weeks prior to the start of classes to arrange for placement at a host institution.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MKTG 317.title: Foundations of Marketing
MKTG 317.description: An introductory marketing course designed for management students to introduce the principles and practices of marketing. Topics will cover basic marketing concepts, societal issues, and the decision-making process of marketers in developing marketing strategies and plans. The focus of the course will be on the implementation of specific product, pricing, distribution and communication strategies for specific market situations.
MKTG 317.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, and 30 units including Strategy and Global Management 217.

MKTG 341.title: Introduction to Marketing
MKTG 341.description:
An introductory marketing course designed for non-Management students to introduce the broad principles and practices of marketing from both an organizational and societal perspective. Topics will cover basic marketing concepts, societal issues, and the decision process of marketers in developing, pricing, promoting and distributing their products.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Marketing 341 and 317 will not be allowed.

Notes: Not available for credit towards the Bachelor of Commerce degree. Preference in enrolment is given to students who have declared a Management and Society Minor.

MKTG 431.title: Retail Management
MKTG 431.description: A strategic approach to the retail industry. Managing the retail operation, including site selection, store design, consumer behaviour in retail situations, buying, inventory management, and visual merchandising. The role of retailing in the global economy.
MKTG 431.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Marketing 317.

MKTG 433.title: Business-To-Business Marketing
MKTG 433.description: Marketing management and theory applied to the purchase of products and services by organizations. Topics include industrial market dynamics, organizational buying behaviour, relationship development, technology, and the importance of innovation.
MKTG 433.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Marketing 317.

MKTG 435.title: Marketing Communications
MKTG 435.description: Evaluations of the roles of various communication tools including advertising, sales promotion, personal selling and public relations.
MKTG 435.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Marketing 317.

MKTG 437.title: Marketing Analytics
MKTG 437.description: Introduction to data-driven marketing strategies, covering market research, marketing mix modelling, segmentation, social media analytics, and data analysis techniques. Course uses R and involves hands-on experience with real-world databases.
MKTG 437.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Marketing 317.

MKTG 449.title: Sales Management
MKTG 449.description: Strategic and managerial aspects of professional selling and sales force management. Topics include sales forecasting, recruitment, training, motivation, compensation and territory management, CRM, integration of technology, sales professionalism/ethics.
MKTG 449.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Marketing 317.

MKTG 465.title: Marketing Research
MKTG 465.description: Understanding how to conduct and evaluate research for management decision making. Emphasis on research design, measurement concepts, sample design, fieldwork, statistical concepts, data analysis and reporting research findings. Practical application by doing a field research study.
MKTG 465.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Marketing 317.

MKTG 467.title: International Marketing
MKTG 467.description: A course on the environment and basic principles underlying the design and implementation of marketing strategies across national and cross-cultural boundaries. Topics will follow the decision process of international marketers in researching the environment, planning the entry strategy and designing their activities on product, distribution, promotion and pricing.
MKTG 467.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Marketing 317.

MKTG 475.title: Digital Marketing
MKTG 475.description: Examination of specific digital strategies, tactics and platforms to understand the concepts of digital and interactive marketing. Topics include social media, user-generated content, mobile marketing and display advertising.
MKTG 475.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Marketing 317.

MKTG 477.title: Strategic Brand Management and Innovation
MKTG 477.description: An in-depth examination of brand management including brand concept, strategic innovation, product portfolio, and new product/service development.
MKTG 477.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Marketing 317.

MKTG 483.title: Consumer Behaviour
MKTG 483.description: Study of factors influencing consumer behaviour. Topics include consumer judgement and decision-making, persuasion, emotional, motivational, social, cultural and contextual influences on decision-making, as well as methods of gaining consumer insights.
MKTG 483.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Marketing 317.

MKTG 487.title: Services Marketing
MKTG 487.description: Application of the managerial practices and theory related to services marketing. Topics include management and measurement of service quality, service recovery. The linking of customer measurement to performance measurement, and cross-function issues through integration of marketing with disciplines such as operations and human resources.
MKTG 487.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Marketing 317.

MKTG 493.title: Strategic Marketing
MKTG 493.description: Marketing strategy is explored in the context of overall corporate strategy. Integrates the aspects of the market mix into formal planning systems. The focus of the course is on strategic responses to changing customer needs and competitive activities.
MKTG 493.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 84 units including Marketing 317.

MKTG 559.title: Selected Topics in Marketing
MKTG 559.description: Investigation of selected topics in Marketing.
MKTG 559.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 54 units including Marketing 317. For certain topics, consent of the Haskayne School of Business will also be required.

MKTG 601.title: Marketing Management
MKTG 601.description: An introductory course on marketing management with an emphasis on marketing concept as the focus of business strategy. The decision variables as well as functional frameworks used by marketing managers are emphasized by concentrating on the relationship between business and consumers.

MKTG 631.title: Marketing Analytics
MKTG 631.description: Introduction to empirical data-driven marketing strategies through data analytics. Topics include hypothesis testing, linear and choice models, clustering, and classification, using R programming for hands-on analysis with real-world databases.

MKTG 635.title: Marketing Communications
MKTG 635.description: Evaluation of strategic roles of a variety of communication disciplines - such as advertising, direct response advertising, sales promotion and public relations - and how companies combine those disciplines to provide clarity, consistency, and maximum impact.
MKTG 635.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Marketing 601.

Also known as: (formerly Marketing 735)

MKTG 641.title: Business-To-Business Marketing
MKTG 641.description: Management issues in the marketing of products and services to business, government and industrial customers. Topics include organizational buying behaviour, industrial market segmentation, demand analysis and sales forecasting, development and implementation of an industrial marketing mix.
MKTG 641.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Marketing 601.

Also known as: (formerly Marketing 741)

MKTG 653.title: Consumer Behaviour
MKTG 653.description: Study of factors influencing consumer behaviour. Topics include consumer judgment and decision making, persuasion, emotional, motivational, social, cultural, and contextual influences on decision making, as well as methods of gaining consumer insights.
MKTG 653.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Marketing 601.

Also known as: (formerly Marketing 761)

MKTG 655.title: Marketing Research
MKTG 655.description: Study of research as a process for gathering market information to aid problem solving. Steps in the research process reviewed include problem definition, research design, data collection, data analysis and report preparation.
MKTG 655.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Marketing 601.

Also known as: (formerly Marketing 763)

MKTG 663.title: New Venture Marketing
MKTG 663.description: Within the context of high-potential, high growth ventures, examines four pillars of new product/new business opportunity. How to create value for the customer, solve significant problems through product and service design, measure sustainable financial value, and assess fit of new ideas with entrepreneur/organization. Emphasis on discovering market opportunities and exploring product or service feasibility.
MKTG 663.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Marketing 601.

Also known as: (formerly Marketing 785)

MKTG 665.title: Strategic Marketing
MKTG 665.description: Strategic market planning in a corporate context. Developing marketing strategies and understanding implementation. Examining the market management process.
MKTG 665.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Marketing 601.

Also known as: (formerly Marketing 793)

MKTG 667.title: International Marketing
MKTG 667.description: Design and implementation of marketing strategies across countries. Focuses on the global marketing environment and decision issues on foreign market entry, local marketing and global management of marketing activities.
MKTG 667.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Marketing 601. 

Also known as: (formerly Marketing 795)

MKTG 668.title: Seminar in Marketing Management
MKTG 668.description: Intensive study and discussion of current literature and research with respect to selected, advanced topics in marketing.
MKTG 668.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Marketing 601.

Also known as: (formerly Marketing 789)

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MKTG 672.title: Strategic Marketing
MKTG 672.description: Introduction to traditional marketing concepts such as segmentation, positioning, product development, and pricing. It also includes omnichannel marketing, permission and inbound marketing, personalization and customer relationship management, and content marketing.
MKTG 672.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Management program.

MKTG 674.title: Consumer Insights
MKTG 674.description: Provides in-depth analysis of why consumers behave the way they do, with practical implications for the practice. Also examines different tools and techniques for uncovering consumer insights.
MKTG 674.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Management program.

MKTG 797.title: Advanced Seminar in Marketing
MKTG 797.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MRSC 321.title: Introduction to Marine Science
MRSC 321.description: Exploring the ocean environment, marine organisms, marine ecosystems and the impact of humans on the sea.

MRSC 420.title: Marine Phycology
MRSC 420.description: A survey of the marine algae, with emphasis on the benthic forms in the vicinity of the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre. Lectures, laboratory work, field collecting, identification and observation. The study of living specimens is emphasized both in the laboratory and in the field.

MRSC 430.title: Marine Ecology
MRSC 430.description: An analytical approach to biotic associations in the marine environment. Opportunities will be provided for study of the intertidal realm in exposed and protected areas and of beaches and estuaries in the vicinity of the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre; plankton studies and investigations of the subtidal and benthic environments by diving and dredging are envisaged.

MRSC 450.title: Introduction to Biological Oceanography
MRSC 450.description: The biology of the oceans; supporting coverage of relevant physics and chemistry; plankton biology, community structure and life histories and influencing environmental factors. Collections will be made from sheltered inlets through Barkley Sound to offshore waters; field and laboratory studies of plankton organisms.

MRSC 500.title: Directed Studies
MRSC 500.description: Directed studies under the supervision of a member of the faculty. Involves a research project approved by the supervisor in the field of interest of the student, and will be designed to take maximum advantage of the laboratory and/or field opportunities offered by the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre.

MRSC 501.title: Topics in Marine Biology
MRSC 501.description: This course will be offered, as opportunities arise, by distinguished scientists visiting at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre who are prepared to offer a course extending over a 3 week period.
MRSC 501.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MRSC 502.title: Topics in Marine Biology
MRSC 502.description: This course will be offered, as opportunities arise, by distinguished scientists visiting at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre who are prepared to offer a course extending over a 6-week period.
MRSC 502.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MRSC 507.title: Directed Studies
MRSC 507.description: Directed studies under the supervision of a member of the faculty. Involves a research project approved by the supervisor in the field of interest of the student, and will be designed to take maximum advantage of the laboratory and/or field opportunities offered by the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre.

MRSC 511.title: Papers and Seminar in Marine Science
MRSC 511.description: The purpose of this course is to provide a forum for students to integrate the knowledge they are obtaining from the other courses in this program. It will be a combination of presentations by resident and visiting researchers followed by discussion, discussion of original papers selected by the instructor(s), and short critiques of original papers by each student.

MRSC 513.title: Applied Data Analysis in Marine Science
MRSC 513.description: Principles of study design and data analysis illustrated by lecture material, current research and research seminars. Students will acquire experience using the statistical computing language R.
MRSC 513.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department. Students are expected to have completed at least 54 units of a Biology program.

MRSC 515.title: Structure and Function in Marine Animals
MRSC 515.description: This course will use marine invertebrates and vertebrates to explore the structural plans of animals in a functional framework. Rather than providing a comprehensive survey of diversity in the animal kingdom, specific taxa will be chosen that exemplify specific systems (e.g., respiratory, skeletal, nervous, etc.). The major taxa will be discussed together with minor groups that have peculiarities that are of general biological importance. This course will combine the disciplines of classification, evolution, morphology, biomechanics, physiology and biochemistry. The emphasis placed on each discipline will depend on the interests of the instructor. Field work will be integrated with the laboratory exercises.

MRSC 525.title: Ecological Adaptations of Seaweeds
MRSC 525.description: An exploration of morphological, physiological, genetic and reproductive adaptations of seaweeds to their natural and man-altered environments. Daily lectures and laboratory exercises will complement frequent field observations.
MRSC 525.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department. Students are expected to have completed at least 54 units of a Biology program and to have successfully completed courses in organismal diversity, introductory genetics, cell biology and/or biochemistry. Statistics is recommended.

MRSC 537.title: Population and Community Ecology of Marine Organisms
MRSC 537.description: An introduction to the concepts of marine plant, animal and community ecology. Emphasis will be on organism/physical and chemical environmental interactions, organismal interactions, and concepts of biological diversity. Daily lectures and laboratory exercises will be complemented by frequent field excursions.
MRSC 537.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department. Students are expected to have completed at least 54 units of a Biology program. Statistics is recommended.

MRSC 540.title: Biology of Marine Birds
MRSC 540.description: A study of the interrelationship of birds and the marine environment. Lectures will emphasize the systematics and ecological relationships, behaviour, life histories, movements and conservation of marine birds. Census techniques and methods of study of marine birds in the field will be considered. Seabird identification, classification, morphology, plumage and moult will be examined in the laboratory.
MRSC 540.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Zoology 403 and consent of the Department.

MRSC 572.title: Marine Invertebrate Zoology
MRSC 572.description: A survey of the marine phyla emphasizing natural history, morphology and systematics of the local invertebrate fauna. The course will include lectures, laboratory work, field collection, identification and observation. The study of living specimens is emphasized both in the laboratory and in the field.
MRSC 572.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

Also known as: (Marine Science 410)

MRSC 574.title: Biology of Fishes
MRSC 574.description: Classification, physiology, ecology, behaviour and zoogeography of fishes with particular emphasis on those in the marine environment of the British Columbia coast. Involves some field projects.

MRSC 600.title: Directed Studies
MRSC 600.description: A course of directed studies under the supervision of a member of faculty, involving a research project approved by the supervisor. Each study will be designed to take maximum advantage of laboratory and/or field opportunities offered by the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre.
MRSC 600.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

Also known as: (Marine Science 500)

MRSC 601.title: Special Topics (3 weeks)
MRSC 601.description: Courses of a specialized nature offered, as opportunities arise, by distinguished scientists visiting the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre.
MRSC 601.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MUED 331.title: Conducting I
MUED 331.description: Basic conducting techniques with the use of the baton; simple and condensed scores for selected choral and instrumental works.

MUED 333.title: Conducting II
MUED 333.description: Continuation of Music Education 331; the full score and more difficult choral and instrumental works.

MUED 341.title: Popular Music Pedagogy
MUED 341.description:
Strategies for integrating popular music into the curriculum, including popular music listening strategies, pedagogical approaches and hand-on experience with modern band instruments including guitar, bass, keyboard, drum set, vocals and technology.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Music Education 341 and 417.04 (Popular Music Pedagogy) will not be allowed.

MUED 343.title: Elementary Music Education
MUED 343.description:
Strategies for teaching music at the elementary level both in schools following the Alberta curriculum and community contexts. Learning experiences will help students design lessons with a strong emphasis on music making appropriate for young learners.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Music Education 343 and 417.06 (Elementary Music) will not be allowed.

MUED 401.title: Instrumental and Band Techniques I
MUED 401.description: Performing and teaching techniques for instruments used in the schools.

MUED 403.title: Instrumental and Band Techniques II
MUED 403.description: Continuation of Music Education 401. Musical and practical aspects of band conducting, including teaching skills, curriculum and appropriate teaching strategies.

MUED 413.title: Vocal Music in the School: Teaching Methods and Materials
MUED 413.description: Introduction to a comprehensive vocal program for elementary and secondary classrooms, including teaching methods and materials.

MUED 415.title: Vocal Music in the School: Curriculum and Teaching Strategies
MUED 415.description: Continuation of Music Education 413. Musical and practical aspects of vocal music in the classroom, including teaching skills, curriculum and appropriate teaching strategies.

MUED 417.title: Topics in Music Education
MUED 417.description: Various topics such as advanced band techniques and literature, choral techniques and literature, philosophy and foundation of music education or jazz for the classroom.
MUED 417.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Music 213 or Music Theory and Composition 203.

MUED 419.title: Topics in Music Education
MUED 419.description:
Various topics such as technology in the classroom, community music practices, curricular design, educational philosophy and world music pedagogy. 

Notes: This course is normally offered over a six-week period.

MUED 420.title: Music Technology for Educators
MUED 420.description:
Exploration of the various ways in which music technology can be incorporated into the classroom, including navigating digital audio workstations to produce music, designing new musical interfaces and performing music using technologies/instruments introduced in the course.

Also known as: (formerly Music Education 417.01 Rehearsal Techniques)

MUED 655.title: Independent Study
MUED 655.description: Individual study in a selected music education area.
MUED 655.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Division Chair, Music.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MUED 671.title: Selected Topics in School Music
MUED 671.description: Selected topics with emphasis upon practical application relevant to the field of music education. Various topics are regularly offered under this title, such as early childhood, Kodaly pedagogy, administration of school music programs and techniques of school music supervision.
MUED 671.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Division Chair, Music.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MUED 695.title: Practicum In School Music I
MUED 695.description: Practical application of teaching techniques studied in graduate level school music courses. Will include various topics such as early childhood, Kodaly, choral and instrumental.

MUED 755.title: Independent Study
MUED 755.description: Individual directed study in an area of Music Education (doctoral level).
MUED 755.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Division Chair, Music.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MUED 771.title: Select Topics In Music Education
MUED 771.description: Selected topics with emphasis upon practical application relevant to the field of Music Education. Possible topics may include early childhood musical development, Kodaly pedagogy, folk music studies, choral and instrumental pedagogy and the role of new technologies within the discipline.
MUED 771.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Division Chair, Music.

MUSI 127.title: Class Piano
MUSI 127.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a BMus program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA; NO CREDIT TOWARDS DEGREES

MUSI 203.title: Jazz History
MUSI 203.description: Directed listening and analysis of jazz forms from the early beginnings of jazz to the present. Styles examined range from Early Jazz to Jazz-Rock Fusion. Major figures considered include: Louis Armstrong, Duke Ellington, Count Basie, Lester Young, Charlie Parker, Miles Davis and John Coltrane.

MUSI 209.title: Introduction to Music Theory for Non-Majors
MUSI 209.description:
Introduction to the materials of music through development of both aural and written skills.

Antirequisite(s): Music majors and minors may not count this course toward their degree requirements.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

MUSI 213.title: Diatonic Harmony
MUSI 213.description: Part-writing and analysis with an emphasis on diatonic harmony and modulation in the music of the eighteenth century.
MUSI 213.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Music 211 or successful completion of the Music Theory Diagnostic exam.

MUSI 214.title: Chromatic Harmony
MUSI 214.description: Part-writing and analysis with an emphasis on chromatic harmony and modulation in the music of the nineteenth century.
MUSI 214.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Music 213.

Also known as: (formerly Music 311)

MUSI 221.title: Performance Practicum I
MUSI 221.description: Applied instruction in instrument or voice.
MUSI 221.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BMus program.

MUSI 223.title: Performance Practicum II
MUSI 223.description: Continuation of applied instruction in instrument or voice.
MUSI 223.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Music 221 and admission to the BMus program.

MUSI 225.title: Musicianship I
MUSI 225.description: Development of skills in rhythm, intonation and sight-singing. Performance of two-part contrapuntal exercises with diatonic modulation.
MUSI 225.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Music major or minor.

MUSI 230.title: Music History and Literature I
MUSI 230.description: Music from the Medieval through early Baroque periods.
MUSI 230.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Music major or minor.

MUSI 232.title: Musical Cultures of the World
MUSI 232.description: Detailed ethno-musicological examination of non-Western traditions.
MUSI 232.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BMUS or BA MUSI program.

MUSI 255.title: Introduction to Music Technology
MUSI 255.description: An exploration of current technology for music making and appreciation including recording hardware and software, MIDI-based devices for integration with sound systems and interactive/media performance, audio file formats, score preparations and basic audition theory.

MUSI 306.title: Topics in Music and Popular Culture
MUSI 306.description:
Selected topics examining popular music from a critical perspective. Examines the meaning and messages of popular music and its impact on present-day culture. Topics may include the examination of the work of specific creators or performers, the recording industry, the impact of specific instruments (e.g. guitar, percussion, electronic media, etc.), or cross-cultural influences. Attendance at relevant musical concerts and lectures may be required.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Music 306 and any of 301, 302, 304, 402 will not be allowed.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MUSI 307.title: Topics in World Music
MUSI 307.description:
Selected topics examining non-western musical traditions from a historical, sociological, analytical or performative perspective. Topics may include the study of particular musical traditions and repertoire or the study of an instrument or performance practice that appears among many traditions (e.g., hand-drumming). Attendance at relevant musical concerts and lectures may be required.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Music 307 and either 303 or 403 will not be allowed. Credit for Music 307.1 and Music 232 will not be allowed.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MUSI 308.title: Topics in Composers and Musical Culture
MUSI 308.description:
In-depth study of selected composers, their music, and their relationship to intellectual history (e.g., Mozart and the French Revolution), and/or examination of specific western or non-western musical cultures (e.g., Music in India, Music in post-war Germany) and their impact.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Music 308 and any of 304, 305, 401 or 405 will not be allowed.

Notes: Attendance at relevant musical concerts and lectures may be required.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

MUSI 309.title: The Art of Music Listening
MUSI 309.description:
An introduction to the sensuous and structural elements of music, leading to a greater appreciation for the art of music in a global multi-cultural context.

Antirequisite(s): Music majors and minors (except Sonic Arts Minors) may not count this course toward their degree requirements.

MUSI 313.title: Materials of Twentieth-Century Music
MUSI 313.description: Compositional and analytical approaches to post-tonal music from the twentieth century to the present.

MUSI 321.title: Performance Practicum III
MUSI 321.description: Continuation of applied instruction in instrument or voice.
MUSI 321.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Music 223 and admission to the BMus program. Students not admitted to a BMus program may register with an audition and consent of the Division Lead, Music.

MUSI 323.title: Performance Practicum IV
MUSI 323.description: Continuation of applied instruction in instrument or voice.
MUSI 323.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Music 321 and admission to the BMus program. Students not admitted to a BMus program may register with an audition and consent of the Division Lead, Music.

MUSI 325.title: Musicianship II
MUSI 325.description: Further development of skills in rhythm, intonation and sight-singing. Introduction to atonal exercises and improvisation.

MUSI 329.title: Jazz Musicianship
MUSI 329.description: Musicianship in the jazz idiom, stressing the aural perception of jazz scales and modes, seventh-chord and harmonic extensions, common jazz progressions and jazz rhythms.

MUSI 330.title: Music History and Literature II
MUSI 330.description: Music from the Late Baroque, Classical and Romantic periods.

MUSI 341.title: Composition I
MUSI 341.description: Basic compositional techniques, and study of selected twentieth-century compositions.

MUSI 343.title: Composition II
MUSI 343.description: Continued study of compositional techniques and study of selected twentieth-century compositions.

MUSI 351.title: Sonic Arts
MUSI 351.description: An introduction to the creative use of computers and digital media in sonic arts.

MUSI 355.title: Sound Recording
MUSI 355.description: An introduction to the practice and theory of sound and music recording.

MUSI 415.title: Form and Analysis
MUSI 415.description: Investigations into hierarchical relations in music. Study of how various levels of musical structure relate in order to form a whole.

MUSI 417.title: Advanced Harmonic Analysis
MUSI 417.description: Investigation of the expanded harmonic resources and analytical systems used by composers from the late nineteenth century to the present.

MUSI 421.title: Performance Practicum V
MUSI 421.description: Continuation of applied instruction in instrument or voice.
MUSI 421.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Music 323 and admission to the BMus (Composition, Music History and Theory, or Integrated Studies) program. Students not admitted to the stated BMus programs may register with an audition and consent of the Division Lead, Music.

MUSI 423.title: Performance Practicum VI
MUSI 423.description: Continuation of applied instruction in instrument or voice.
MUSI 423.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Music 421 and admission to the BMus (Composition, Music History and Theory, or Integrated Studies) program. Students not admitted to the stated BMus programs may register with an audition and consent of the Division Lead, Music.

MUSI 427.title: Professional Seminar in Music Performance I
MUSI 427.description: Practical experience in music performance in a team teaching master class format.
MUSI 427.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Music 323 and admission to the BMus (Performance) program.

MUSI 429.title: Jazz Improvisation
MUSI 429.description: Topics in jazz improvisation, stressing improvisational tools, melody, rhythm, and ear development for the blues progression.
MUSI 429.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Music 213 and admission to the music major or minor.

MUSI 441.title: Composition III
MUSI 441.description: Advanced creative work with an emphasis upon either chamber music composition or studio composition.
MUSI 441.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Music 343 and consent of the Division Lead, Music.

MUSI 443.title: Composition IV
MUSI 443.description: Continued advanced creative work with an emphasis upon either chamber music composition or studio composition.
MUSI 443.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Music 441 and consent of the Division Lead, Music.

MUSI 445.title: Counterpoint
MUSI 445.description: Practical study of contrapuntal technique, including species counterpoint and eighteenth-century counterpoint.

MUSI 447.title: Orchestration
MUSI 447.description: Practical study of instrumentation and scoring, including orchestral and wind ensemble textures.

MUSI 451.title: Electroacoustic Music
MUSI 451.description: Practical study of electroacoustic and computer music with an emphasis on creative work in the medium.

MUSI 453.title: Computer Applications in Music
MUSI 453.description: Use of computers in music composition, performance, education and interdisciplinary media.

MUSI 462.title: Junior Performance Project
MUSI 462.description: Applied instruction in instrument or voice in connection with junior recital.
MUSI 462.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BMus (Performance) program.

MUSI 511.title: Selected Topics in Theory and Composition
MUSI 511.description: Advanced topics in music theory and composition selected from such subjects as: analysis of tonal or post-tonal music, rhythmic analysis, acoustics, critical approaches to music theory, electroacoustic music, orchestration, counterpoint and fugue.

NANS 301.title: Introduction to Nanoscience and Nanotechnology
NANS 301.description: Functional definitions of nanoscience and nanotechnology. Understanding/predicting the behaviour of nanomaterials. Investigation of nanomaterials whose properties depend on size. Exploration of a building up approach to design and fabrication of functional nanomaterials. Examination of applications of nanoscience and nanotechnology in society.
NANS 301.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Mathematics 249, 265 or 275; and 3 units from the Faculty of Science or the Schulich School of Engineering.

NANS 401.title: Design in Nanoscience
NANS 401.description: The fundamental understanding of Nanoscience gained in Nanoscience 301 will be extended and applied to designing experiments and simulations to test hypotheses regarding Nanoscience.

NANS 443.title: Quantum World of Nanoscience
NANS 443.description: Using nanotechnology examples, the fundamentals of quantum mechanics that are relevant to nanoscience and nanotechnology are covered.
NANS 443.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Mathematics 249, 265 or 275; and Mathematics 211 or 213; and Physics 233 or 355.

NANS 502.title: Nanoscience Methods
NANS 502.description: This laboratory course will place the students in a nanotechnology setting. Students will design and execute self-directed projects and will present results to their peers.

NANS 511.title: Integration of Nanotechnology and Biology for Medical Applications
NANS 511.description: The applications of nanotechnology in drug delivery and medical imaging will be explored.

NANS 512.title: Nanotechnology: Nanofabrication, Nanodevices, and Surfaces
NANS 512.description: An introduction to nanofabrication processes to obtain nanodevices based on thin films, nanotubes, nanowires, and / or two-dimensional materials such as graphene. The working principles, functioning, applications, and reliance on surface properties of these nanodevices will be discussed. Devices discussed can include solar cells, nanotransistors, nanotribology, photonic crystals.

NANS 522.title: Seminar in Nanoscience and Nanotechnology
NANS 522.description: A discussion of current topics in Nanoscience and Nanotechnology. This seminar course will place the student in a setting where best practices of scientific presentation are imparted through giving presentations related to Nanoscience.
NANS 522.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Nanoscience 301. 

Antirequisite: Credit for Nanoscience 522 and 599 will not be allowed.

NANS 598.title: Special Topics in Nanoscience
NANS 598.description: Study in advanced topics that may include reading projects, seminars, lectures, term papers and other aspects of training in theory or research methodology.
NANS 598.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Program.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NANS 599.title: Special Problems in Nanoscience and Nanotechnology
NANS 599.description: A discussion of current topics in Nanoscience and Nanotechnology. This seminar course will place the student in a setting where best practices of scientific presentation are imparted through giving presentations related to Nanoscience
NANS 599.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Nanoscience 401 and admission to the Nanoscience minor.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NEUR 201.title: Introduction to Neuroscience
NEUR 201.description: A survey of clinical, cognitive, behavioural, systems, cellular and molecular neuroscience, with emphasis on applied, translational, and basic research.
NEUR 201.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biology 30 and admission to the Neuroscience program.

NEUR 321.title: How the Brain Works
NEUR 321.description:
An introduction to the fundamentals of brain function for students outside of the Neuroscience program. Students completing this course will be able to describe the molecular, cellular and systems underpinnings of nervous systems. Students will be able to discuss the functioning of brain systems underlying sensation, cognition, behaviour, and disease.

Antirequisite(s): Not open to students in the Neuroscience program. Credit for Neuroscience 321 and Psychology 375 will not be allowed.

NEUR 399.title: Topics in Neuroscience
NEUR 399.description: Lectures, seminars, term papers and training in theoretical and/or laboratory methods.
NEUR 399.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 30 units and admission to the Neuroscience program and consent of the Program Director.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NEUR 401.title: Adv Neuroscience Laboratory
NEUR 401.description: Advanced neurophysiological, behavioural, molecular biological, and histological techniques used to investigate nervous system function will be covered. The course is delivered in the form of hypothesis-driven research projects.
NEUR 401.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Zoology 461 and admission to the Neuroscience program.

NEUR 411.title: Cellular & Systems Neuroscience
NEUR 411.description: Structure and function of the nervous system examined through neurochemistry, intracellular signal transduction, mechanisms of communication, and functional organization of the nervous system at the cellular and systems levels.
NEUR 411.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Zoology 461 and admission to the Neuroscience program, or a minimum grade of "B+" in Zoology 461.

NEUR 421.title: Neuroscience: History, Ethics and Society
NEUR 421.description: An exploration of topics in the history of neuroscience, aspects of ethics as they apply to studies of the brain and how neuroscience fits into society.
NEUR 421.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 48 units and admission to the major in Neuroscience, Biological Sciences, Health Science or Psychology.

NEUR 499.title: Topics in Neuroscience
NEUR 499.description: Lectures, seminars, term papers and training in theoretical and/or laboratory methods.
NEUR 499.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 45 units, admission to the Neuroscience program and consent of the Program Director.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NEUR 500.title: Honours Thesis in Neuroscience
NEUR 500.description: Research project undertaking critical assessment of data collected testing and hypothesis derived from the literature. To be conducted under the direction of one or more faculty members from departments participating in the Neuroscience program. Formal written and oral reports must be presented on completion of the course.
NEUR 500.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Neuroscience Program and completion of 75 units.

NEUR 506.title: Topics in Neuroscience
NEUR 506.description: Lectures, seminars, term papers and training in theoretical and/or laboratory methods.
NEUR 506.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 60 units, admission to the Neuroscience program and consent of the Program Director.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NEUR 507.title: Topics in Neuroscience
NEUR 507.description: Lectures, seminars, term papers and training in theoretical and/or laboratory methods.
NEUR 507.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 60 units, admission to the Neuroscience program and consent of the Program Director.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NEUR 511.title: Neuroscience Seminar
NEUR 511.description: Students will attend the weekly Hotchkiss Brain Institute seminars. Following each seminar, students will discuss the presentation under the tutelage of a moderator familiar with the field of enquiry.
NEUR 511.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Neuroscience Program and completion of 75 units in the Neuroscience program.

NEUR 528.title: Introduction to Computational Neuroscience
NEUR 528.description: Introduces the mathematical foundations of computational neuroscience. This includes how to model and simulate neurons (Hodgkin-Huxley or conductance-based neurons, integrate-and-fire neurons, fitting neurons to data), how to connect neurons into networks (spiking neural networks, artificial neural networks, recurrent neural networks), analytical and computational simplifications to these networks (mean-field modelling), and includes a brief introduction to techniques machine learning. Intended for students with a quantitative background, with a particular emphasis on dynamical systems theory, ordinary differential equations, and linear algebra.
NEUR 528.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 211; 3 units from Mathematics 249, 265, 275; and Neuroscience 411.

NEUR 543.title: Degenerative Neurological Disorders
NEUR 543.description: Examines the clinical aspects of degenerative neurological disorders including dementia, movement disorders, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), multiple sclerosis, and traumatic brain injury. There will be an emphasis on translational sciences through exploring examples of basic neurosciences research translating into radiological, diagnostic, and therapeutic advances in clinical neurosciences.
NEUR 543.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 479 and admission to the Neuroscience program.

NEUR 545.title: Paroxysmal Neurological Disorders
NEUR 545.description: Examines the clinical aspects of paroxysmal neurological disorders including stroke, epilepsy, multiple sclerosis, neurological infections, headache/migraines, and autoimmune neurological diseases. There will be an emphasis on translational sciences through exploring examples of basic neurosciences research translating into radiological, diagnostic, and therapeutic advances in clinical neurosciences.
NEUR 545.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 479 and admission to the Neuroscience program.

NEUR 599.title: Topics in Neuroscience
NEUR 599.description: Lectures, seminars, term papers and training in theoretical and/or laboratory methods.
NEUR 599.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 60 units, admission to the Neuroscience program and consent of the Program Director.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NRSG 201.title: Introduction to Nursing
NRSG 201.description: An introduction to the ways of knowing, history of nursing, nursing identity, and diverse contexts for nursing practice.

NRSG 202.title: Indigenous Health Studies
NRSG 202.description: Enhance awareness of and relationship to Indigenous ways of knowing, being, doing, and connecting. Develop foundational knowledge of the ongoing impacts of colonial violence, structures, and systems that influence Indigenous peoples' health in Canada.

NRSG 203.title: Anatomy and Physiology I
NRSG 203.description:
An introduction to foundational anatomy and physiology. Topics to be covered include general cell physiology and the anatomy and physiology of the skeletal, nervous and muscular systems.  Emphasis will be on the integration of body systems to regulate physiological function and homeostasis.   Includes laboratory and simulation learning.

Prerequisites: Science 30 or Chemistry 30; and Biology 30; and Mathematics 30-1 or 30-2 or Pure Math 30.

Antirequisite: Credit for Nursing 203 and any of Kinesiology 259, 260, Biology 305, Medical Science 404, Zoology 461 or 463 will not be allowed.

NRSG 204.title: Anatomy and Physiology II
NRSG 204.description:
An introduction  to anatomy and physiology of systems. Topics to be covered include the anatomy and physiology of the cardiovascular, pulmonary, immune, endocrine, reproductive, renal, and gastrointestinal systems.  Emphasis will be on the integration of body systems to regulate physiological function and homeostasis.   Includes laboratory and simulation learning.

Prerequisites: Nursing 203.

Antirequisite: Credit for Nursing 204 and any of Kinesiology 259, 260, Biology 305, Medical Science 404, Zoology 461 or 463 will not be allowed.

NRSG 305.title: Microbiology and Biochemistry
NRSG 305.description: The application of biochemistry to defined health problems and establishes the foundations of microbiology and biochemistry for nursing practice.

NRSG 310.title: Foundations of Relationship
NRSG 310.description: An introduction to foundational concepts associated with the practice of registered nurses including caring science and caring practice, the scope of professional practice, professional communication, reflective practice, introduction to ethics, compassion, foundations of nursing knowledge, introduction to the nursing process and assessment, foundations of patient as partner, family centred care/family nursing, practicing amid difference and managing complexity.
NRSG 310.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

NRSG 320.title: Care of the Aging Adult
NRSG 320.description: An introduction to the relationship between health and aging, the physiology of aging, and care of the aging adult.
NRSG 320.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

NRSG 321.title: Health Promotion
NRSG 321.description: An introduction to population health trends and health promotion practices.
NRSG 321.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

NRSG 330.title: Nursing Amid Complexity
NRSG 330.description:
Explores the multi-dimensional influences on health.   

Prerequisites: Admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

Corequisite(s): Nursing 331, 332, 352.

NRSG 331.title: Pathophysiology I
NRSG 331.description:
First in a sequence of three pathophysiology courses that cover processes associated with disease or injury. 

Prerequisites: Admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

Corequisite(s): Nursing 330, 332, 352.

NRSG 332.title: Pharmacology I
NRSG 332.description:
An introduction to pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics. 

Prerequisites: Admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

Corequisite(s): Nursing 330, 331, 352.

NRSG 350.title: Care of the Aging Adult Practicum
