NRSG 350.description: A focus on care of the aging adult in continuing care. Experiential learning for care of aging adults. Introduction to nursing interventions pertinent to this patient population.
NRSG 350.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

NRSG 351.title: Health Promotion Practicum
NRSG 351.description:
Exploring care in the context of community with a focus on the adult population. Students undertake practicum learning in a variety of community adult placements. Introduces students to assessments and interventions pertinent to professional nursing practice and community-based care.

Prerequisites: Admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

Corequisite(s): Nursing 305, 310, 320, 321, 350.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

NRSG 352.title: Acute Care Nursing Practicum I
NRSG 352.description:
An introduction to the context of acute care, with a focus on tertiary care of the adult population. Experiential learning that focuses on building students' abilities to conduct assessment. Introduction to nursing process, developing clinical reasoning, and skills pertinent to practice in an acute care context.  

Prerequisites: Admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

Corequisite(s): Nursing 330, 331, 332.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

NRSG 401.title: Evidence-Informed Nursing
NRSG 401.description:
An exploration of forms of evidence for nursing practice with a focus on evidence appraisal and utilization. Introduction to qualitative and quantitative research methods, knowledge translation, and knowledge mobilization in nursing and healthcare. 

Prerequisites: Admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

Corequisite(s): Nursing 430, 450.

NRSG 410.title: Nursing as Ethical Practice
NRSG 410.description: An introduction to foundational theory for nursing practice. Focus on health law and ethics, the code of ethics for registered nurses, principles of and practices associated with patient advocacy.
NRSG 410.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

NRSG 420.title: Health through Collaboration
NRSG 420.description: An opportunity to collaborate with others to advance health.
NRSG 420.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

NRSG 421.title: Mental Health and Illness
NRSG 421.description: An introduction to the care of patients who experience mental illness.
NRSG 421.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

NRSG 430.title: Pharmacology II
NRSG 430.description:
To further develop understanding of pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics. 

Prerequisites: Nursing 332 and admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

Corequisite(s): Nursing 401, 450.

NRSG 450.title: Consolidated Practicum
NRSG 450.description:
An introduction to the context of acute care, with a focus on tertiary care of the adult population. Experiential learning that supports students to consolidate their development in assessment, intervention, skill development, and developing clinical reasoning abilities.  

Prerequisites: Admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

Corequisite(s): Nursing 401, 430.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

NRSG 501.title: Nursing Leadership
NRSG 501.description:
An exploration of the knowledge, characteristics, and practices associated with nursing leadership in healthcare systems. 

Prerequisites: Admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

Corequisite(s): NRSG 531.

NRSG 510.title: Resilience in Practice
NRSG 510.description:
Prepares students for the transition to professional practice. Strategies for addressing moral and ethical challenges of practice; role and transition shock; working and learning within a preceptorship model; identifying and meeting ongoing learning and support needs; supporting and mentoring others. 

Prerequisites: Admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

Corequisite(s): NRSG 560.

NRSG 520.title: Care in Perinatal
NRSG 520.description:
A focus on nursing practice with maternal and newborn populations. Includes content associated with maternal care, perinatal care, and postpartum. 

Prerequisites: Admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

NRSG 521.title: Care in Pediatrics
NRSG 521.description:
A focus on care of the pediatric population. Includes content associated with pediatric health and illness, the relationship between human development, brain, behaviour, and health. 

Prerequisites: Admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

NRSG 530.title: Pathophysiology II
NRSG 530.description: Building understanding of pathophysiology as it informs nursing care.
NRSG 530.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): NRSG 331 and admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

NRSG 531.title: Pathophysiology III
NRSG 531.description:
Continuation of pathophysiology as it informs nursing care. 

Prerequisites: NRSG 530 and admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

Corequisite(s): NRSG 501.

NRSG 550.title: Acute Care Nursing Practicum II
NRSG 550.description: Building knowledge, skills, and attributes to care for adult patients in the context of tertiary care. Experiential learning that builds upon knowledge and skills associated with nursing practice with adults in acute care.
NRSG 550.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): NRSG 352 and admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

NRSG 551.title: Mental Health Practicum
NRSG 551.description:
An introduction to to nursing practice with people experiencing mental illness in tertiary and community contexts. Experiential learning introducing knowledge and skills for nursing practice with people who experience mental illness.

Prerequisites: Admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

NRSG 552.title: Care in Perinatal Practicum
NRSG 552.description:
A focus on nursing practice in perinatal, labour and delivery, and postpartum contexts Experiential learning introducing knowledge and skills for nursing practice with maternal and newborn populations.

Prerequisites: Admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

NRSG 553.title: Care in Pediatrics Practicum
NRSG 553.description:
Learning in acute care and community pediatrics. Experiential learning introducing knowledge and skills for nursing practice with pediatric populations. 

Prerequisites: Admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

NRSG 560.title: Final Preceptorship Practicum
NRSG 560.description:
Preparation for entry to practice through supporting consolidation, integration, and application of students' nursing knowledge, skills, and attributes. Opportunity to refine and enact complex communication and relationship building skills, high-level assessment and clinical reasoning, nursing care planning, implementation, and evaluation. 

Prerequisites: Admission to the Bachelor of Science in Nursing.

Corequisite(s): NRSG 510.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

NURS 485.title: The Discipline and Profession of Nursing III: Furthering Inquiry and Scholarship in Nursing
NURS 485.description: Focus on strategies for the development of evidence-informed nursing practice.  Examination of strategies to critique and facilitate the use of evidence for practice. Introduction to basic quantitative and qualitative methods used in nursing research.
NURS 485.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Nursing program.

NURS 487.title: The Science of Health III: People Experiencing Life-Threatening Health Challenges
NURS 487.description: Theoretic understanding of the holistic experience of acuity and life-threat for individuals and families is presented. Epidemiology, pathophysiology, diagnostic studies, complex physical and other nursing assessments relevant to common life-threatening health challenges, including mental health disorders.
NURS 487.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Nursing program.

NURS 488.title: Supporting Health III: People with Life-Threatening Health Challenges
NURS 488.description: Addresses nursing practices in acute unstable illness, injury and disease. The study of application of nursing assessments, technological interventions and best evidence nursing practices in common major acute illnesses in individuals of all age groups, set within the context of their families and communities. Emphasis is on attaining knowledge of secondary and tertiary prevention strategies. Pharmacological applications to major acute disease conditions.
NURS 488.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Nursing program.

NURS 489.title: Integrating Nurs Role & Prac III: Learning, Praxis and Scholarship in the Practicum Setting
NURS 489.description: Integration and application of theoretic knowledge in simulated and nursing practice settings. The focus in this course is nursing care of clients and families experiencing life-threatening health challenges. Development of skills of complex communication and relationship building, high-level assessment and clinical reasoning, and nursing care planning and implementation.
NURS 489.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Nursing program.

NURS 495.title: Discipline & Prof of NURS IV: Understand Challenges of Leadership & Systems of Care
NURS 495.description: This course explores knowledge related to the current health care system, systems of care responsive to the needs of clients with chronic health disruptions, and nursing roles of leadership and delegation.  Evidence examining the efficacy of systems of care and the efficacy of nursing roles, practices, and contributions are highlighted.   Examination of selected approaches to nursing research.
NURS 495.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Nursing program.

NURS 497.title: The Science of Health IV: People Experiencing Chronic Health Challenges
NURS 497.description: Experience of living with chronic health challenges, including common complications.  Epidemiology, pathophysiology, diagnostic studies, complex physical and other nursing assessments relevant to common chronic health challenges, including mental health disorders.  A holistic perspective is taken to examine the challenges of ongoing health management faced by populations of chronically ill individuals and their families.
NURS 497.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Nursing program.

NURS 498.title: Supporting Health IV: People With Chronic Health Challenges
NURS 498.description: Nursing practices in caring for the chronically ill.  A focus on practices to achieve healthful transitions and preservation of quality of life are emphasized.  Common treatment modalities are presented including nursing therapeutics and pharmacological approaches to management of common chronic diseases. Tertiary prevention is emphasized and concepts and approaches to ongoing health assessment, health education, self-management, harm reduction, support, restoration, and   palliation are addressed.
NURS 498.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Nursing program.

NURS 499.title: Integrate Nurs Roles and Practices IV: Learn, Praxis & Scholarship in Practicum Setting
NURS 499.description: Integration and application of theoretic knowledge in simulated and nursing practice settings.  Long-term nursing care of individuals, families and populations with chronic health challenges.  Implementation of effective therapeutic relationships, complex assessments, reasoned clinical decision-making, client and family health education, client self-management and collaborative practice models.
NURS 499.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Nursing program.

NURS 503.title: Selected Topics in Nursing
NURS 503.description:
Courses provide an in-depth exploration of nursing related to a clinical population and quality care topic.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NURS 517.title: Philosophy and Practice in Palliative Care
NURS 517.description: Examination of the philosophy of palliative/hospice care, taught by faculty from many disciplines. An important focus includes the students' self-exploration of their own beliefs, values, and attitudes about life, illness, death, and dying, and how this self-exploration shapes interactions with those we care for.
NURS 517.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Nursing program.

NURS 544.title: Exploring Cancer and the Role of the Nurse
NURS 544.description: Issues associated with caring for cancer patients and their families across their illness trajectory including prevention, screening, diagnosis, treatment, ambulatory care, survivorship, reoccurrence, palliative, hospice and bereavement. Applying recent research findings and best evidence available through the supportive care framework and the standards of care established by the Canadian Association of Nurses in Oncology (CANO) to how nursing knowledge, skills, abilities, attitudes and judgments assist individuals and families
NURS 544.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Nursing program.

NURS 546.title: Older Adult Nursing: Managing Complexity
NURS 546.description: Develop the reasoning, knowledge and skills required to respond to the unique presentation of acute illness in older adults. The demystification of popular aging beliefs and related care practices offers Students the opportunity to develop care that combines theory, best practice, research and experience in caring for individuals impacted by acute health crises as they age.
NURS 546.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Nursing program.

NURS 547.title: Perinatal Nursing Care: Emerging Trends and Issues
NURS 547.description: Maternity and infant health is examined within the context of the family. The role of family centered nursing addressing wellness patterns and alterations in perinatal family health will be investigated from a multi-setting, multicultural and holistic perspective. Current perinatal trends will be addressed.
NURS 547.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Nursing program.

NURS 550.title: Promoting Health in Vulnerable Populations
NURS 550.description: Focused on the health of those facing significant barriers, such as poverty, addictions, displacement, trauma, and systemic discrimination across the lifespan. An exploration of historically significant sociopolitical factors that precede health inequities, uncover existing strengths and internal capacity, and critically examine existing strategies that seek to promote the health of selected vulnerable populations in Canada including: Indigenous Peoples, immigrants and refugees, people who are homeless, people living with disabilities and who are sexually exploited.
NURS 550.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Nursing program.

NURS 551.title: Rural Health I Assessment and Management of Acute and Chronic Conditions in Rural Communities
NURS 551.description: Develop clinical reasoning, knowledge and skills needed to respond to the unique challenges of acute and chronic illness experienced by rural residents across the lifespan. The scope of practice and role of the rural nurse as an expert generalist will be examined in the context of assessing and managing common conditions related to cardiac, respiratory, trauma, obstetrical, end of life care, mental health and addictions. Interdisciplinary collaboration in rural settings will also be explored.
NURS 551.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Nursing program.

NURS 552.title: Principles of Teaching and Learning for Nursing Practice: Nurse as Educator
NURS 552.description: Offers an exploration of the role of the nurse as educator relative to the concept of health education as an intervention to empower clients to achieve their wellness potential and ultimately to improve quality of care outcomes and quality of life. The nurse as educator role will also be explored as it relates to nursing education of students and intra-disciplinary colleagues; emphasizing quality of care practices and the phenomena of competency and leadership as they contribute to quality of care outcomes.
NURS 552.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Nursing program.

NURS 554.title: Rural Health II Foundational Knowledge of Rural Health
NURS 554.description: Exploring the role of the rural nurse as a leader and change agent. Focusing on the implementation of evidence informed practice in the rural health care setting, students will examine the role of the rural nurse and the complexities of caring for rural community members. Using a social determinants of health perspective to enhance understanding of the impact of relational ethics, and geographical, economic and political variables that impact rural health care. Community assessment will be used to assist in identifying the strengths and health inequities of rural communities.
NURS 554.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Nursing program.

NURS 585.title: The Discipline and Profession of Nursing V: Preparing for Professional Role Transition
NURS 585.description: This course focuses on the integration of senior students into the environment of professional nursing practice with an evidence-informed emphasis on the essentials of leadership, relational and practice ethics, effective inter and intra-professional collaboration, communication and conflict management for the purpose of facilitating a healthy transition to the role of a new graduate professional nurse within a contemporary health-care climate.
NURS 585.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Nursing program.

NURS 589.title: Integrating Nurs Role & Prac V: Learning, Praxis & Scholarship in the Practicum Setting
NURS 589.description: This focused clinical experience, supported by two corequisite substantive nursing option theory courses, is aimed at refining critical thinking and competent use of theoretic frameworks and evidence to support clinical reasoning processes including: comprehensive assessment, holistic analysis and interpretation of client data, and competence and confidence in clinical decision-making. Students will choose a focused area of nursing practice.
NURS 589.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the Bachelor of Nursing program.

NURS 599.title: Integrating Nursing Roles and Practices VI: Transition to Nursing Practice
NURS 599.description: Synthesis, application and further acquisition of knowledge, skills, and attitudes in a selected nursing practice setting. Emphasis on complexity of nursing care with clients (individuals, families, and/or aggregates). Selection of focus area will be made through consultation with faculty.
NURS 599.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s):  Nursing 585 and 589, two Senior Nursing Option courses and current CPR Health Care Provider Level (HCP).

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

NURS 601.title: Seminar on Special Topics Related to Health Care and Nursing
NURS 601.description: An in-depth investigation into a selected topic in Nursing.
NURS 601.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Faculty.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

NURS 602.title: Theoretical Perspectives in Older Adults and Aging Societies
NURS 602.description: Overview of contemporary and emerging issues associated with aging populations. Students will consider the provision of health and possible systems transformation across different care continuums and explore their roles in the care of older adults at individual, community, and population levels.
NURS 602.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Contemporary Topics in Aging Specialization (Certificate in Advanced Nursing I/II).

NURS 604.title: Comprehensive Assessment and Care of the Older Adult
NURS 604.description: Philosophy and principles of assessing and caring for the aging person. The impact of age-related changes that contribute to older adults' presentation and the responses to therapeutic management will be explored. Students will utilize this knowledge and explore how it relates to advanced practice.
NURS 604.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Nursing 602 and admission to Contemporary Topics in Aging Certificate.

NURS 606.title: Focused Studies in Aging: Enhancing Quality Initiatives
NURS 606.description: Explores contemporary clinical issues of significance to an older adult population..  Also covers principles of practice development and practice improvement using a quality improvement framework and initiates development of a practice project plan.
NURS 606.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Nursing 604 and admission to Contemporary Topics in Aging Certificate.

NURS 607.title: Independent Guided Study
NURS 607.description: Guided special topic for graduate students.

NURS 608.title: Specialized Practice Demonstration: Quality Initiative Plan for Older Adults
NURS 608.description: Integrates content knowledge with practice development or improvement processes, in order to enact a specialized workplace practice demonstration. Students will be supported by faculty to undertake their practice demonstration and to evaluate the effects of change on key stakeholders.
NURS 608.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Nursing 606 and admission to Contemporary Topics in Aging Certificate. 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

NURS 611.title: Theoretical Knowledge for Advanced Nursing Practice
NURS 611.description: Introduction to substantive theory related to advanced nursing practice. As students identify their population focus they will examine frameworks for advanced nursing practice that inform their care for individuals, families and communities of practice.
NURS 611.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Master of Nursing (thesis based).

NURS 612.title: Theories and Models of Addiction and Mental Health Assessment
NURS 612.description: Selected theories and models of addiction and mental health relevant to advancing specialized nursing practice including current disorders and trauma informed care in relation to advanced assessment, screening and implications for practice innovation and leadership.
NURS 612.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Addiction and Mental Health Certificate.

NURS 614.title: Therapeutic Practices: Treatment Planning and Recovery
NURS 614.description: Selected interventions and therapeutic practices for symptom management and optimizing functioning in recovery framework including: therapeutic relationships, counseling (individual, group, family), motivational interviewing, cognitive behavioral therapy, psychopharmacology, and mindfulness  .
NURS 614.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Nursing 612 and admission to Addiction and Mental Health Certificate.

NURS 616.title: Integration of Addictions and Mental Health Knowledge, Values, and Practices
NURS 616.description: Specialized seminar focused on integration of advanced knowledge, practice, and ethics; and development of a proposal for a focused demonstration of advanced knowledge and practice in addictions and mental health.
NURS 616.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Nursing 614 and admission to Addiction and Mental Health Certificate.

NURS 618.title: Specialized Practice Demonstration: Advancing Addictions and Mental Health Practice
NURS 618.description: Students implement and evaluate, report, and formulate ongoing recommendations associated with a focused demonstration of advanced knowledge and practice in addictions and mental health nursing.
NURS 618.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to Addiction and Mental Health Certificate and Nursing 616.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

NURS 622.title: Foundational Philosophy for Teaching and Learning Across Contexts
NURS 622.description: Prepares students to teach in direct settings, simulation, online, as well as conventional classrooms. Focuses on building a philosophy for teaching and learning that incorporates foundational teaching and learning theory applicable to a variety of student contexts.
NURS 622.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Innovations in Teaching and Learning Certificate.

NURS 623.title: Hermeneutic Research
NURS 623.description: Inquiry into the philosophical and historical influences that have shaped hermeneutic phenomenology as an approach to nursing and health care research.  Exploration of interpretive practices essential to the conduct of hermeneutic research.

NURS 624.title: Explorations of People, Places, and Relationships in Teaching and Learning
NURS 624.description: Involves the critical examination of teaching and learning specific to advancing professional practice with emphasis on cultivating relationships for learning, learning across diverse context. Also focuses on generation of possibilities for change and innovation and consolidation of preferred teaching and learning practices in a select context of practice.
NURS 624.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Nursing 622 and admission to Innovations in Teaching and Learning Certificate.

NURS 626.title: Current Trends in Teaching and Learning
NURS 626.description: Introduces specialized topics in teaching and learning and provides an opportunity to engage in critical reflection and analysis through a personal learning experience. Students will explore a variety of teaching and learning strategies within multiple contexts to develop their individualized teaching practice.
NURS 626.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Nursing 624 and admission to Innovations in Teaching and Learning Certificate.

NURS 628.title: Specialized Practice Demonstration: Teaching and Learning Grand Challenge
NURS 628.description: Students will draw on their teaching philosophy and current trends in teaching and learning to address a teaching and learning grand challenge. Building on the skills and knowledge developed throughout the certificate, students will provide a demonstration of innovative teaching and learning strategies within a focused context.
NURS 628.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Nursing 626 and admission to Innovations in Teaching and Learning Certificate.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

NURS 630.title: Quantitative Research and Statistics
NURS 630.description: Critical analysis of quantitative research methods. Emphasis on the study of research designs appropriate to clinical nursing problems, measurement, and data analysis. Students will learn critical appraisal skills and will develop an understanding of the conceptual basis, use, and pitfalls of common methods used in the analyses of data.
NURS 630.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Master of Nursing (course based or thesis based).

NURS 632.title: Writing Proposals for the Nursing Profession
NURS 632.description: Introduction to writing proposals for clinical quality improvement or research projects to address nursing practice challenges. Experience will be provided in synthesizing evidence and developing elements of a comprehensive proposal.
NURS 632.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Master of Nursing (course based or thesis based).

NURS 635.title: Implementation Science for Health Professionals
NURS 635.description: Introduction to the principles and practices of developmental evaluation, implementing change in the healthcare setting, and evaluating the adoption, outcomes and sustainability of evidence-based interventions and programs. Experience will be provided in addressing real world problems using implementation science.
NURS 635.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Nursing 660 and admission to Master of Nursing (course-based).

NURS 652.title: Healthcare Information and Big Data
NURS 652.description: Introduces many of the key concepts, and methods used in the management and use of large healthcare data assets, focusing on data integration, health informatics and the role of artificial intelligence. Issues relating to access, confidentiality, privacy and data stewardship will be examined. Focuses on application and implications of big data use within the healthcare context and is not intended as a methods course.
NURS 652.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Healthcare Innovation and Design Certificate.

NURS 654.title: Design in Healthcare
NURS 654.description: Examines design in healthcare from a variety of facets. Principles and practices of digital health and architectural design innovation will be explored. User-centered design and prototype development approach will be demonstrated.  Opportunities for transdisciplinary collaboration and end-user engagement in the design of a healthcare innovation will be highlighted in a hackathon experience.
NURS 654.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Nursing 652 and admission to Healthcare Innovation and Design Certificate.

NURS 656.title: Emerging Technologies in Healthcare
NURS 656.description: Explores emerging healthcare technology trends and issues. Case studies and exemplars will be used to expand understanding of the intended and unintended consequences of the integration of technology in healthcare. Prototypes developed in Nursing 654 will be assessed within the context of a learning health system and healthcare quality.
NURS 656.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Nursing 654 and admission to Healthcare Innovation and Design Certificate.

NURS 658.title: Specialized Practice Demonstration: Health Design Project
NURS 658.description: Teams collaborate in the development of a healthcare design project that addresses a real-life healthcare challenge posed by industry partners and healthcare leaders. Focuses on application and synthesis of learning from previous courses to improve the quality of healthcare delivery.
NURS 658.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Nursing 656 and admission to Healthcare Innovation and Design Certificate.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

NURS 660.title: Cultivating Personal Leadership I
NURS 660.description: Exploration of relational leadership including self-awareness and development of leadership capacity. Students will explore their personal leadership values and the influence of leadership on workplace cultures, team dynamics and quality of health-care delivery.
NURS 660.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Leadership for Health System Transformation Certificate or Master of Nursing (thesis-based).

NURS 662.title: The Future of Nursing: The Future of Health Systems
NURS 662.description: Examines the health delivery system focusing on differing aspects of care quality. Students will apply leadership principles to challenges inherent in a complex and dynamic health care system. Focuses on the role of nurses as leaders and transformers of health systems.
NURS 662.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Nursing 660 and admission to Leadership for Health System Transformation Certificate.

NURS 664.title: Innovation in Health Systems
NURS 664.description: Focused exploration of the principles of innovation, and practices for leading innovation applied to complex healthcare environments. Students will apply design thinking, entrepreneurial practices and examine the value proposition and challenges of innovation in a health system context.
NURS 664.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Nursing 662 and admission to Leadership for Health System Transformation Certificate.

NURS 668.title: Specialized Practice Demonstration: Healthcare Grand Challenge
NURS 668.description: Formulation of a bold and innovative proposal developed through team collaboration and leadership that addresses a systemic problem to improve the quality of healthcare. Drawing on previous learning of personal and professional competencies, students will be presented with a grand challenge associated with leading and improving a complex health system.
NURS 668.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Nursing 664 and admission to Leadership for Health System Transformation Certificate.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

NURS 670.title: Philosophy and Principles of Palliative Care
NURS 670.description: Provides foundational knowledge of palliative and end of life care philosophy and practice principles as an integrative approach to care, from diagnosis of a life-threatening illness to end of life crossing primary, tertiary and hospice settings. Focus will be on application and the implications for advanced nursing practice to help advocate change around improved integration of palliative care.
NURS 670.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Palliative and End of Life Care Certificate.

NURS 672.title: Optimizing Comfort and Quality of Living in Palliative and End of Life Care
NURS 672.description: Advanced specialized palliative care knowledge of common symptoms with the goal of developing expertise in optimizing comfort and quality of life for individuals and families.  Focus will be on knowledge in assessing and treating complex symptoms relevant to patient/family goals of care.
NURS 672.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Nursing 670 and admission to Palliative and End of Life Care Certificate.

NURS 674.title: Exploration of Concepts, Populations and Challenges in Palliative Care
NURS 674.description: Exploration of special populations and complex challenges in palliative care that are significant to the practice and delivery of palliative care. Topics will include: Complex Practice/Ethical Issues at the end of life (cardiopulmonary resuscitation, suffering, withholding and withdrawing life-sustaining treatments, palliative sedation, medical assistance in dying); and Challenges and Care for Special Populations in Palliative Care (the bereaved, pediatrics, older adults, poverty/homelessness, rural populations, indigenous populations).
NURS 674.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Nursing 672 and admission to Palliative and End of Life Care Certificate.

NURS 676.title: Specialized Practice Demonstration: Design and Leading Change in Palliative Care
NURS 676.description: Students will creatively design and offer a presentation of their palliative care topic to their peers. From the synthesis of literature and conversations with stakeholders students will apply principles of design thinking methods and leadership practices in in a palliative care context. There will be an opportunity to explore the use of these frameworks in a real-world project.
NURS 676.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Nursing 674 and admission to Palliative and End of Life Care Certificate.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

NURS 677.title: Creating and Leading Business Opportunities Within Healthcare Contexts
NURS 677.description: Leverage clinical expertise to develop entrepreneurial and leadership skills necessary to start and manage a successful professional practice with a focus on addressing the unique challenges and opportunities faced within the healthcare sector. Practical applications will be used to evaluate entrepreneur readiness, establish success criteria tailored to professional goals, and navigate regulatory and stakeholder influences.
NURS 677.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Professional Practice Entrepreneurship Certificate.

NURS 678.title: Business Operations Within Complex Healthcare Landscapes
NURS 678.description: Exploration of essential skills to operate a business within complex healthcare landscapes. There will be a focus on financial management, accounting, and human resource skills needed to launch and sustain a successful professional practice in healthcare. Developing marketing plans and learning strategies to streamline practice operations and ensure patient satisfaction will also be explored.
NURS 678.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Nursing 677 and admission to Professional Practice Entrepreneurship Certificate.

NURS 679.title: Technology, Compliance, and Risk in Healthcare Entrepreneurial Spaces
NURS 679.description: A comprehensive overview of managing risks, ensuring compliance, and utilizing technology in a professional healthcare practice. Learn to identify and evaluate risks in practice and patient safety, understand regulatory requirements, and safeguard patient information. The effective use of technology, including electronic medical records (EMRs) will also be covered.
NURS 679.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Nursing 678 and admission to Professional Practice Entrepreneurship Certificate.

NURS 680.title: Advanced Oncology Nursing Practice
NURS 680.description: Nursing roles in oncology are dynamic and expanding, largely based on the growing complexity of oncology care. The variety of oncology nursing roles will be identified and discussed. Key concepts regarding these roles and evidence of the impact of these roles on patient experience and outcomes will be explored.
NURS 680.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Oncology Nursing Certificate.

NURS 682.title: Person-Centred Approaches
NURS 682.description: The variety of ways that oncology nurses can contribute to person-centred care delivery will be examined. In this context, students will explore principles and practices of leadership and system transformation that can be advanced by specialized oncology nursing practice.
NURS 682.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Nursing 680 and admission to Oncology Nursing Certificate.

NURS 683.title: Qualitative Designs And Analyses
NURS 683.description: Exploration of research methods based primarily on inductive reasoning. Methods, issues and techniques of sampling, data collection, analysis, and interpretation will be explored.  Experience will be provided in data collection, management, and analysis.
NURS 683.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Master of Nursing (course-based or thesis-based).

NURS 684.title: Nursing Roles in Oncology Research
NURS 684.description: An exploration of nursing roles in oncology research to explore trends and issues in nursing research. Students will utilize case studies and exemplars to expand their understanding of the variety of roles nurses play in oncology research.
NURS 684.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Nursing 682 and admission to Oncology Nursing Certificate.

NURS 686.title: Specialized Practice Demonstration: Advanced Oncology Nursing Design Project
NURS 686.description: Formulation of an oncology nursing design project to systematically address a real-life practice challenge aimed at improving the quality of cancer care. In groups, students will select a project topic explored in Nursing 684. Health-care leaders and practice mentors may be consulted as needed.
NURS 686.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Nursing 684 and admission to Oncology Nursing Certificate.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

NURS 688.title: Professional Practice Business Strategy and Growth
NURS 688.description: Build on clinical expertise, knowledge of business development, and operations management to create a business strategy to grow a professional practice. A strategic plan will be developed outlining current practice state, desired future state, and the steps needed to achieve goals. By the end of the course, participants will be able to formulate a comprehensive strategy to drive the growth and development of their professional practice.
NURS 688.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Nursing 679 and admission to Professional Practice Entrepreneurship Certificate.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

NURS 690.title: Cultivating Personal Leadership II
NURS 690.description: Exploration of relational leadership including self-awareness and development of leadership capacity. Students will explore their personal leadership values and the influence of leadership on workplace cultures, team dynamics and quality of healthcare delivery.
NURS 690.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a Master of Nursing program.

NURS 692.title: Fundamentals of Rural and Remote Nursing
NURS 692.description: An examination of the relevant elements related to healthcare in rural and remote areas. Students will learn about the state of rural and remote nursing including facilitators and challenges to rural and remote nursing practice.
NURS 692.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Rural and Remote Nursing Certificate.

NURS 694.title: Special Issues in Accessing Healthcare in Rural and Remote Areas
NURS 694.description: An exploration and examination of the contextual issues faced by persons residing in rural and remote areas who are seeking health care. Current approaches to mitigating challenges and potential future solutions will be examined.
NURS 694.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Nursing 692 and admission to Rural and Remote Nursing Certificate.

NURS 696.title: Special Issues in Provision of Healthcare in Rural and Remote Areas
NURS 696.description: An exploration and examination of the contextual and workforce issues faced in the healthcare system and by healthcare providers in rural and remote areas. Current approaches to mitigating challenges and potential future solutions will be examined.
NURS 696.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Nursing 694 and admission to Rural and Remote Nursing Certificate.

NURS 698.title: Rural and Remote Nursing Practice Project
NURS 698.description: In groups of up to 4, students will apply and synthesize learning from previous courses to systematically address a selected topic (clinical or administrative) in rural and remote healthcare. Healthcare leaders and practitioners may be consulted as needed.
NURS 698.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Nursing 696 and admission to Rural and Remote Nursing Certificate.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

NURS 701.title: Doctoral Special Topics
NURS 701.description: An in-depth investigation into a selected topic in Nursing.
NURS 701.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to PhD in Nursing or Doctor of Nursing.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

NURS 707.title: Directed Study
NURS 707.description: Directed special topic for graduate students.
NURS 707.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to PhD in Nursing or Doctor of Nursing.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NURS 721.title: Advanced Quantitative Research Methods
NURS 721.description: Opportunities for developing nurse scientists and other health professional doctoral students to increase understanding of, and ability to utilize, quantitative research methods for scientific inquiry.  Focuses on identifying issues/dilemmas arising during the research process and methods to address these challenges.
NURS 721.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to PhD in Nursing.

NURS 723.title: Hermeneutic Research
NURS 723.description: Inquiry into the philosophical and historical influences that have shaped hermeneutic phenomenology as an approach to nursing and health care research.  Exploration of interpretive practices essential to the conduct of hermeneutic research.

NURS 724.title: Philosophy, Knowledge and Research in Nursing
NURS 724.description: Exploration of types of knowledge that inform nursing practice, using philosophical ideas to articulate value and application of knowledge and to link to methodologies of knowledge creation through research.
NURS 724.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to PhD in Nursing.

NURS 726.title: Developing a Scholarly e-Portfolio
NURS 726.description: An examination of elements associated with successful academic careers. Students will initiate and maintain an e-portfolio that demonstrates their academic growth.
NURS 726.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to PhD in Nursing.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

NURS 741.title: Leading Innovation & Transformation
NURS 741.description: Focuses on the role of leaders as change agents. An in-depth examination of change theory and analysis of practical application in real world scenarios. Critiques leadership theories in creating and sustaining complex healthcare system innovation. Examines organizational culture and dynamics with a focus on professional relationships that foster transformation and innovation in healthcare.
NURS 741.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Nursing program.

NURS 742.title: Technology & Healthcare Information
NURS 742.description: Explores and critiques emerging trends and issues in healthcare technology and state of the science of healthcare information. Utilizing case studies and exemplars learners will expand their understanding of the role of healthcare leaders in supporting the integration of technology and big data use in healthcare. Introduces many of the key concepts and methods used in the management and use of large healthcare data assets and technologies.
NURS 742.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Nursing program.

NURS 743.title: The Business of Healthcare
NURS 743.description: Focuses on examining and evaluating the business and managerial skills necessary for mid-level and senior leadership roles in healthcare organizations. Topics will include organizational structures; strategic, operational, financial and project planning; human resources; and evaluating organizational performance.  Competencies for entrepreneurship and intrapreneurship in the context of healthcare service delivery will also be explored.

NURS 744.title: Health Policy & Advocacy
NURS 744.description: In-depth examination of policy and advocacy within Canadian healthcare systems. Introduces the political, organizational, and economic dimensions of healthcare policy with emphasis on strategies that support innovative policy and practice.
NURS 744.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Nursing program.

NURS 745.title: Innovation, Improvement & Implementation Science
NURS 745.description: Examines and critiques the state of science in innovation, quality improvement and implementation practices. Through case studies and applied projects, learners will explore the nexus of these three practices within the context of complex health systems towards improved systems efficiencies, outcomes, and impact.
NURS 745.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Nursing program.

NURS 746.title: Seminar I Project Development
NURS 746.description: Writing the proposal for the work integrated project. Analysis of elements of a successful proposal.
NURS 746.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Nursing program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

NURS 747.title: Seminar II Knowledge Mobilization
NURS 747.description: Examines elements of knowledge translation in organizational and academic contexts.
NURS 747.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Nursing program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

NURS 783.title: Advanced Qualitative Research Methods
NURS 783.description: Exploration of the philosophical foundations and practice of qualitative research methods in health care inquiry.  Emphasis on interpretive assumptions and practices relevant to the conduct of qualitative research.
NURS 783.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to PhD in Nursing.

OBHR 317.title: Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources
OBHR 317.description: Examines individual, interpersonal and group processes to explain behaviour in organizations to better predict employee behaviour, and to interpret how context influences such behaviour. Topics may include motivation, groups and teams, decision-making, personality, power and influence, negotiation, leadership and stress.
OBHR 317.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Strategy and Global Management 217.

OBHR 321.title: Foundations in the Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources
OBHR 321.description:
Energies, skills and abilities of people to meet the challenge of today's organizations; diagnostic skills to recognize and analyze organizational problems; the linkage between effective management of people and goal accomplishment for organizations; current challenges in organizational forms, diverse environments and cultures; foundation for further study of Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources concepts.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 317 will not be allowed.

Notes: Not available for credit towards the Bachelor of Commerce degree. Preference in enrolment is given to students who have declared a Management and Society Minor.

Also known as: (formerly Human Resources and Organizational Dynamics 321)

OBHR 401.title: Strategic Human Resource Management
OBHR 401.description: Provides the conceptual basis and skills to make strategic human resource decisions. Learning to think strategically about human resource management practices and policies such as reward systems, performance management, and hiring.
OBHR 401.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 317.

Also known as: (formerly Human Resources and Organizational Dynamics 401)

OBHR 405.title: Labour Relations
OBHR 405.description: Examination of the nature and role of labour relations in the resolution of issues affecting employers, employees and the public interest.
OBHR 405.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 317.

Also known as: (formerly Human Resources and Organizational Dynamics 405)

OBHR 407.title: Rationality & Decisions
OBHR 407.description: An overview of key concepts in the decision sciences including normative, descriptive and prescriptive models of judgment and choice. This course emphasizes real-world applications of different decision making and decision support models.
OBHR 407.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 317.

Also known as: (formerly Human Resources and Organizational Dynamics 407)

OBHR 409.title: Talent Management
OBHR 409.description: Examines how organizations can proactively manage their talent pool, from the recruitment phase through to screening, assessing, interviewing, and selecting top talent using scientifically valid and legally defensible practices.
OBHR 409.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 317.

OBHR 411.title: Training and Development
OBHR 411.description: Examines how to enhance job-relevant knowledge and skills to improve job performance. Topics include needs assessment, learning and transfer of training, training methods and evaluation.
OBHR 411.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 317.

OBHR 413.title: Compensation and Performance Management
OBHR 413.description: Systematically design compensation systems that improve employee engagement and performance. Topics include job analysis and evaluation, pay systems, and benefits.
OBHR 413.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 317.

OBHR 415.title: Critical Perspectives on Work and Society
OBHR 415.description: Explores the philosophical and historical roots of work and its evolving societal meaning. Examines how values, economic systems, and cultural norms shape our understanding, including unpaid, risky, nomadic, and underground labour.
OBHR 415.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 317.

OBHR 417.title: Ethical Dilemmas in Human Resources Management
OBHR 417.description: Develops critical thinking for navigating HR ethical dilemmas, covering favoritism, compensation disparities, harassment, discrimination, discipline, and appraisals, using real-world case studies to balance organizational goals with ethics.
OBHR 417.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 317.

OBHR 419.title: Strategic Change Leadership
OBHR 419.description: Focuses on strategic perspectives, leadership in human resources, governance principles, alignment with organizational goals, and change management strategy development.
OBHR 419.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 317.

OBHR 421.title: Interpersonal Behaviour
OBHR 421.description: Focus on increasing self-awareness, self-understanding and presentation of self. Interpersonal skills development necessary for group effectiveness and team management provide basis for performance leadership. Format involves learning in small groups.
OBHR 421.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 317.  

Also known as: (formerly Human Resources and Organizational Dynamics 421)

OBHR 423.title: Healthy Work
OBHR 423.description: Explore strategies, interventions, and evidence-based practices to promote physical and mental well-being, prevent burnout and create supportive and healthy work environments.
OBHR 423.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 317.

OBHR 425.title: Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion in Organizations
OBHR 425.description: Understand and implement principles and practices to foster inclusive, equitable, and diverse organizations, enhancing employee attitudes, behaviours, and organizational effectiveness.
OBHR 425.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 317.

OBHR 427.title: Human Resource Management Analytics
OBHR 427.description: Analyze and interpret human resource data using statistical methods and software to make evidence-based decisions and optimize human resource practices.
OBHR 427.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 317.

OBHR 447.title: Haskayne Wilderness Retreat
OBHR 447.description: A wilderness intensive retreat combining experiential outdoor activities and personal growth challenges with cross-cultural teachings and ceremonies guided by Indigenous Knowledge Keepers. Delivers core leadership skills for corporate social responsibility in sustainable development.
OBHR 447.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, consent of the Haskayne School of Business, and 60 units.

OBHR 449.title: Arbitration of Employment Disputes
OBHR 449.description: Workplace dispute resolution using arbitration. Topics include discipline, drug testing, surveillance, dress codes, discrimination, absenteeism, employment contracts. Emphasis on legal principles in employment arbitration, data base research, and advocacy skills using simulations, case law and guest speakers.
OBHR 449.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 317.  

Also known as: (formerly Human Resources and Organizational Dynamics 449)

OBHR 491.title: Lifework Planning and Career Assessment
OBHR 491.description: Persons demonstrate competency in personal and career development by their ability to take personal responsibility for the quality of their lives. Assess skills and values and plan for personal and career development after graduation.
OBHR 491.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 317.

OBHR 493.title: Business Negotiations
OBHR 493.description: The major concepts and theories of bargaining and negotiation; the dynamics of interpersonal and intergroup conflict; analysis of bargaining and conflict relationships and exploration of individual bargaining styles. Application to a variety of negotiation situations. Use of simulations and written assignments.
OBHR 493.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 60 units including Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 317.

Also known as: (formerly Human Resources and Organizational Dynamics 493)

OBHR 517.title: Indigenous Peoples and Sustainable Development
OBHR 517.description: An introduction to indigenous peoples and sustainable development, framed within business ethics relevant to energy and extractive industries. Treaties, government policy and land-use address the duty to consult and accommodate indigenous peoples, emphasizing reconciliation with intercultural competence for indigenous corporate relations and professional capacity building.

OBHR 519.title: The Haskayne Leadership Expedition
OBHR 519.description: Develop practical skills through an outdoor mountain backpacking expedition. Tackle challenges, receive feedback, and cultivate transferable leadership skills in a dynamic environment.
OBHR 519.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, consent of the Haskayne School of Business, and Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 317.

OBHR 559.title: Selected Topics in Management and Organizations
OBHR 559.description: Examination of selected topics in management and organizations.
OBHR 559.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 317. For certain topics, consent of the Haskayne School of Business will also be required.

OBHR 601.title: Organizational Behaviour
OBHR 601.description:
Evidence-based approach to leadership and organizational behavior. Begins with self-assessment and then uses experiential learning to develop leadership techniques, including: motivation, team processes, negotiation, and decision-making.

Also known as: (formerly Human Resources and Organizational Dynamics 601)

OBHR 621.title: Advanced Leadership
OBHR 621.description: Examines leadership theories relevant to advanced leadership (e.g., ethical leadership, humble leadership, charismatic leadership). Delves into concepts that leaders must consider when making decisions and implementing strategy (e.g., power, influence, change-management).
OBHR 621.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 601.

Also known as: (formerly Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 721)

OBHR 623.title: Organizational Change and Development
OBHR 623.description: Diagnosing organizational situations where the need for change exists and facilitating such changes. Utilization of behavioural science knowledge for organizational problem-solving.
OBHR 623.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 601.

Also known as: (formerly Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 723)

OBHR 632.title: Lifework Planning and Career Assessment
OBHR 632.description: Persons demonstrate competency in personal and career development by their ability to take personal responsibility for the quality of their lives. Students will clarify their competencies and values and plan for dealing with the challenges faced by mature adults.
OBHR 632.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 601.

Also known as: (formerly Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 731)

OBHR 641.title: Managerial Decision Making
OBHR 641.description:
Examines how decisions are made in organizations and how these decisions can be made more effectively, particularly at the top management and Board levels. Decision making in current business contexts are explored by way of simulations, case analyses, discussions, debates and written assignments.

Also known as: (formerly Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 741)

OBHR 645.title: Cross-Cultural Leadership and Human Resources Management
OBHR 645.description:
Leadership of human resources in a cross-cultural and international context; the nature of cultural differences; influence on organizational processes and practices such as communication, leadership, decision-making, team dynamics, staffing, performance management and organizational design, and implications for those holding international managerial roles.

Also known as: (formerly Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 745)

OBHR 647.title: Business Negotiations
OBHR 647.description: The major concepts and theories of negotiation; the dynamics of interpersonal and intergroup conflict; analysis of negotiation strategies and individuals styles. Application to a broad range of business negotiations. Use of simulations and written assignments.
OBHR 647.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 601.

Also known as: (formerly Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 793)

OBHR 649.title: Rediscovering Leadership: The Haskayne Wilderness Retreat
OBHR 649.description:
One-week intensive wilderness retreat combines experiential outdoor activities and personal growth challenges with cross-cultural First Nations teachings and 
ceremonies to deliver core leadership skills for social responsibility and sustainable development.

Also known as: (formerly Business and Environment 649)

OBHR 668.title: Seminar in the Management of Human Resources
OBHR 668.description: Intensive study and discussion of current literature, research and issues with respect to selected topics in the management of human resources.
OBHR 668.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 601 or consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

Also known as: (formerly Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 789)

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

OBHR 672.title: Working with People
OBHR 672.description: Focuses on employment in different organizational contexts (e.g. established and start-up organizations, public and privately owned, or government and not-for-profit).
OBHR 672.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Management program.

OBHR 674.title: Navigating the Organization
OBHR 674.description: Development of negotiation, power and influence, politics, and conflict resolution skills leading to increased effectiveness with internal and external stakeholders.
OBHR 674.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Management program.

OBHR 676.title: Leadership
OBHR 676.description: Examines leadership theories and delves into concepts that leaders must consider when making decisions and implementing strategy.
OBHR 676.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Management program.

OBHR 733.title: Leadership
OBHR 733.description: Provides insight into the science of leadership. Themes include: the social psychological evidence based on popular leadership models, measurement of leadership and its outcomes, development of leadership and effective versus ineffective leadership programs.
OBHR 733.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Business Administration program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

OBHR 797.title: Advanced Seminar in Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources
OBHR 797.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Haskayne School of Business.  

Also known as: (formerly Human Resources and Organizational Dynamics 797)

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

OBHR 799.01.title: Organizational Behaviour
OBHR 799.01.description: Also known as: (formerly Human Resources and Organizational Dynamics 799)

OBHR 799.02.title: Organization Theory
OBHR 799.02.description: Also known as: (formerly Human Resources and Organizational Dynamics 799)

OBHR 799.03.title: Industrial Relations
OBHR 799.03.description: Also known as: (formerly Human Resources and Organizational Dynamics 799)

OBHR 799.05.title: Interorganizational Relationships: Creating and Managing Strategic Alliances
OBHR 799.05.description: Also known as: (formerly Human Resources and Organizational Dynamics 799)

OPMA 301.title: Introduction to Operations and Supply Chain Management
OPMA 301.description: A survey of the decision processes in production and operations management and their relationship to other business functions. Topics include project planning and scheduling, inventory management, quality management, capacity planning, facilities layout, and supply chain management.
OPMA 301.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Any 200-level Mathematics or Statistics 213 (or equivalent, excluding Statistics 201), and Entrepreneurship and Innovation 201.

OPMA 317.title: Fundamentals of Operations and Supply Chain Management
OPMA 317.description: An introduction to operations and supply chain management's strategic importance, wide applicability, and sustainability integration. Topics include management of inventory, quality, global supply chains, capacity, projects and process improvement.
OPMA 317.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Business and Environment 291 or Management Studies 217, and Statistics 213.

OPMA 401.title: Production & Materials Management
OPMA 401.description: An in-depth treatment of inventory and production within an organization. Topics covered include inventory control, sales and operations planning, materials requirements planning, and lean processes. Recent advances in manufacturing may also be discussed.
OPMA 401.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Operations Management 317 and Management Studies 391.

OPMA 403.title: Managing Quality in Products and Services
OPMA 403.description: An in-depth treatment of quality management practices and techniques for products and services. Topics and techniques covered include designing and assuring quality, quality issues in the supply chain, statistical quality measurement, and continuous process and quality improvement.
OPMA 403.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Operations Management 317.

OPMA 405.title: Service Operations Management
OPMA 405.description: The management of service businesses from both a qualitative and quantitative perspective. Topics may include service design and performance measurement, service quality and recovery, managing people in service industries, service demand forecasting, scheduling, managing lineups, yield management, network optimization, and the role of information technology. Industry examples include travel and hospitality, professional services, retail, communication and transportation and banking.
OPMA 405.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Operations Management 317 and Management Studies 391.

OPMA 407.title: Project Management
OPMA 407.description: The management of projects in a variety of settings such as software development and installation, disaster relief, new product development, advertising campaigns and financial auditing are examined. Material from the organizational, planning, technical, financial, informational, and logistical aspects of project management will emphasize the interdisciplinary nature of projects. Use of commercial computer software for planning and scheduling projects is learned.
OPMA 407.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Operations Management 317 and Management Studies 391.

OPMA 409.title: Computer Simulation For Business
OPMA 409.description: Learn to analyze and improve operational processes regarding the flow of products and people with computer simulations and become a consultant for environments where uncertainty plays a role in decision-making.
OPMA 409.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Operations Management 317 and Management Studies 391.

OPMA 411.title: Field Investigation in Operations & Supply Chain Management
OPMA 411.description: Project-based experiential learning on operational improvements within an organization in operations or supply chain management. Students work in teams on a single project. Oral and written presentation skills are developed.
OPMA 411.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, and 60 units including Operations Management 317, Management Studies 391 and two 400-level Operations Management or Supply Chain Management courses.

OPMA 415.title: Prescriptive Models in Business Analytics
OPMA 415.description: Identification of data requirements for analytical decision-making. Case studies used throughout to develop insight for decision making while dealing with incomplete and ambiguous data. Introduction to VBA-enabled spreadsheet modelling to design and implement optimization models without/with uncertainty as well as advanced Monte Carlo simulation.
OPMA 415.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Management Studies 391.

OPMA 419.title: Predictive Models in Business Analytics
OPMA 419.description: Prediction and classification models with machine learning to identify patterns and the likelihood of future outcomes. Techniques may include visualization, cluster analysis, regression- based models, classification trees and neural networks.
OPMA 419.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Management Studies 391.

OPMA 421.title: Business Data Visualization
OPMA 421.description: Leverage business data to create effective visualizations in order to communicate valuable and actionable insights to support managers in their decision-making.
OPMA 421.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Management Studies 391.

OPMA 559.title: Selected Topics in Operations Management
OPMA 559.description: Investigation of selected topics in Operations Management.
OPMA 559.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Operations Management 317 and Management Studies 391. For certain topics, consent of the Haskayne School of Business will also be required.

OPMA 601.title: Operations Management
OPMA 601.description: Management of the production and/or service delivery system of the organization in concert with marketing, human resources, finance, and information systems. Management decision making on a continuum from day-to-day operating decisions such as quality control to long-term strategic decisions such as capacity planning. Topics covered in the course may include operations strategy, project management and inventory and supply chain management.

OPMA 631.title: Predictive Analytics in Business
OPMA 631.description: Application of data-driven predictive models to solve real-life business problems in operations, marketing, finance and other business functions. Techniques covered include decision trees, classification and association rules, and cluster analysis.

OPMA 635.title: Operations Planning and Supply Chain Management
OPMA 635.description: Examines supply chain management in an environment where multiple companies are involved in the sourcing, production, distribution and sales of materials and products; and proper planning and managing of the supply chain. Presents cases of real-world situations calling for appropriate state-of-the-art models and solution methods for the design, planning, control and improvement of supply chain operations. The main concepts and terminology in the domain of supply chain management are explored and then applied to a given situation.
OPMA 635.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Operations Management 601 and Management Studies 613.

Also known as: (formerly Operations Management 745)

OPMA 641.title: Quality in Products and Services
OPMA 641.description:
Quality management practices and techniques for products and services. Topics covered include
designing and assuring quality, quality issues in the supply chain, statistical quality measurement,
continuous process and quality improvement.

OPMA 645.title: Project External Issues
OPMA 645.description:
Projects will focus on the effects of external factors on business. External factors may include: corporate influences; financial interfaces; sources of funds; lending environment, owner's and lender's risks; government involvement; regulatory requirements; public interfaces; public information; compensation; project commissioning.

Also known as: (formerly Strategy and Global Management 619)

OPMA 647.title: Fundamentals of Project Management
OPMA 647.description:
Application of management principles to the project environment; planning, control, scope, time and cost processes; project organization and human resource issues. Students review a current major capital project and submit and defend a project report.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Operations Management 647 and Engineering 684 will not be allowed.

Also known as: (formerly Strategy and Global Management 691)

OPMA 649.title: Project Procurement and Logistics
OPMA 649.description:
Project procurement and logistics management in engineering, construction management and manufacturing, both nationally and internationally. Topics include fundamentals of procurement management, preparation of request for proposals, the selection of bidders, the evaluation of bids, supplier selection, contract management, control of inventory, handling of material flow and management of warehousing, logistics strategy and global issues.

Also known as: (formerly Operations Management 719)

OPMA 668.title: Selected Topics in Operations Management
OPMA 668.description: Investigation of selected topics in Operations Management.
OPMA 668.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Operations Management 601.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

OPMA 672.title: Operations and Supply Chain Management
OPMA 672.description: Technology infrastructure, collaborations in business-to-business relationships, and customization in business to client relationships.
OPMA 672.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Management program.

OPMA 743.title: Simulation of Operational Systems
OPMA 743.description: Simulation provides a means for imitating the behaviours of real-world situations in the computer environment, allowing for 'what-if' analyses of different scenarios. The emphasis is on hands-on experience in transforming a real situation into a simulation model and obtaining reliable results. The course will focus on discrete-event simulation, with the introduction of other techniques such as advanced Monte Carlo simulation.
OPMA 743.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Operations Management 601 and Management Studies 613.

OPMA 761.title: Inventory Management
OPMA 761.description:
Single and multi-echelon inventory planning models in supply chains. Deterministic lot sizing models, newsvendor model, periodic and continuous review stochastic models, and multi-echelon inventory models.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Operations Management 761 and 797.11 will not be allowed.

OPMA 771.title: Optimization
OPMA 771.description:
Presents basic theory and methods for Constrained Optimization. Emphasis is on the main theoretical and structural results, such as optimality conditions, duality, post-optimality analysis, and computational complexity.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Operations Management 771 and 797.10 will not be allowed.

OPMA 775.title: Markov Decision Processes
OPMA 775.description:
Many sequential decision-making problems can be modeled as Markov decision processes (MDPs). Topics include: formulating and solving MDP models with standard techniques and approximate dynamic programming.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Operations Management 775 and 797.09 will not be allowed.

OPMA 797.title: Advanced Seminar in Operations Management
OPMA 797.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

PHEN 381.title: Continuum Mechanics I
PHEN 381.description: Review of linear algebra and introduction to vector calculus. Physical space, bodies, configurations, motions and displacement fields. Velocity and the substantial derivative, acceleration. Deformation, strain and their rates. Master balance equation, balance of mass, balance of linear momentum, balance of angular momentum, balance of mechanical power. Rigid body mechanics as a particular case: velocity distribution, linear momentum, angular momentum, tensor of inertia. Constitutive equations: constitutive principles, Stokesian fluids, elastic solids. Introduction to Lagrangian and Hamiltonian mechanics for discrete and continuum systems.
PHEN 381.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Engineering 202 and Mathematics 211; and Mathematics 265 or 275.

PHEN 383.title: Continuum Mechanics II
PHEN 383.description: Elements of Solid Mechanics: linear elastic solid; the De Saint Venant beam: axial and shear forces, torsion, bending, beam deflection and statically indeterminate structures, Euler buckling. Elements of Fluid Mechanics: Bernoulli equation, Navier-Stokes equation, static forces on surfaces, buoyancy, stability, control-volume analysis, dimensional analysis and physical similarity, introduction to external flows and flow through pipes.
PHEN 383.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Engineering 349; and Physics Engineering 381 or Biomedical Engineering 381; and Mathematics 375 or Mathematics 376.

PHEN 435.title: Mathematical Methods for Engineering Physicists
PHEN 435.description: Applications of advanced mathematics to problems of physics and engineering; introduction to abstract vector spaces and inner product spaces in linear algebra; eigenvalues and eigenvectors and their physical interpretation; solutions for partial differential equations and boundary value problems; Sturm-Liouville theory; orthogonal polynomials; generalized Fourier Series; special functions.

PHEN 501.title: Research and Design for Engineering Physics III
PHEN 501.description: A continuation of Engineering Physics 401, with a focus on research. A team-based design and research project carried out under the supervision of one or more faculty members. The project can include designing experimental apparatus, developing technical devices, performing laboratory measurements, simulating systems or developing software, and building theoretical and physical models. Students will be required to submit a written report and deliver an oral presentation.

PHIL 201.title: Mind, Matter and God
PHIL 201.description: An introduction to philosophy through discussion of selected topics such as skepticism, perception, personal identity, free will and determinism, God.

PHIL 249.title: Morality, Virtue and Society
PHIL 249.description: An introduction to philosophy through discussion of morality, virtue and the role of morality in society.

PHIL 259.title: Sex, Love and Death
PHIL 259.description: Topics to be addressed may include the nature of sex, love, and death, the relation between sex and love, sexual ethics, sexual perversion, sexual harassment and pornography, abortion, suicide, euthanasia and the value of life.

PHIL 264.title: How Do We Know?
PHIL 264.description: An investigation of belief, knowledge, and error in everyday life and the sciences, including discussion of topics such as the nature of knowledge; patterns of valid reasoning and sources of error; the influence of bias on belief and knowledge; scientific reasoning and theory building, and the distinction between science and pseudo-science.

PHIL 279.title: Logic I
PHIL 279.description:
Sentential and first-order logic from both deductive and semantic points of view. Some elementary metatheorems.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Philosophy 279 and 377 will not be allowed.

PHIL 301.title: The Classical Period
PHIL 301.description: The study of a selection of philosophers from the Pre-Socratics, through Plato and Aristotle, to the Hellenistic and Roman philosophers.
