PLAN 676.description:
Thematic inquiry and design contextualized by experiential learning in planning.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

PLAN 680.title: Special Topics in Planning
PLAN 680.description:
Thematic inquiry and design related to special topics in planning.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

PLAN 682.title: Special Topics in Planning
PLAN 682.description:
Thematic inquiry and design related to special topics in planning.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

PLAN 684.title: Special Topics in Planning
PLAN 684.description:
Thematic inquiry and design related to special topics in planning.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

PLAN 686.title: Special Topics in Planning
PLAN 686.description:
Thematic inquiry and design related to special topics in planning.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

PLAN 688.title: Special Studio Topics in Planning
PLAN 688.description:
Thematic inquiry and design related to special studio topics in planning.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

PLAN 790.title: Directed Study in Planning
PLAN 790.description: Thematic research, readings, or studio projects related to planning design topics.
PLAN 790.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

PLAN 792.title: Directed Study in Planning
PLAN 792.description: Thematic research, readings, or studio projects related to planning design topics.
PLAN 792.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

PLAN 799.title: Preceptorship in Planning
PLAN 799.description: A Preceptorship is a study and training arrangement made between a student and an employer or an equivalent supervisor which has specific educational objectives, a method of evaluation, and is an integral part of a student's Program of Studies. Preceptorships offer a number of benefits: acquiring skills and knowledge which may be better obtained outside the University; developing first-hand experience of professional design practice; preparing for more focused studies in the Faculty; and conducting research.
PLAN 799.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

PLBI 401.title: Plant Biotechnology
PLBI 401.description: The theory, application and history of plant biotechnology. Plant genome structure and the regulation of gene expression. Transcript, protein and metabolic profiling. Recombinant gene transfer into the plant genome. Biotechnological approaches to crop improvement, soil remediation and value-added traits.
PLBI 401.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biology 331, 371, and 3 units from Biochemistry 341 or 393.

PLBI 403.title: Plant Physiology
PLBI 403.description: An integrative examination of the major physiological and metabolic processes in plants from the cellular to the whole-plant level. Emphasis on internal and external controls of growth and development; photosynthesis; nutrient assimilation; plant hormone metabolism and action; and stress physiology.

PLBI 421.title: Plant Cell Biology and Anatomy
PLBI 421.description: Study of plants at the cell and tissue level. Focus is on subcellular organization and dynamics, and on the structural and functional roles of cell and tissue systems. Lab sessions will emphasize brightfield and fluorescence microscopy imaging.

PLBI 427.title: Systematics and Diversity of Plants
PLBI 427.description: The diversity, form and function of plants ranging from algae, bryophytes (non-vascular land plants) and psilophytes to the angiosperms. Examples chosen to understand the origin of land plants and their subsequent evolution leading to highly diversified flowering plants.

PLBI 528.title: Research Project in Plant Biology
PLBI 528.description: Research project under the co/supervision of faculty members in the Department of Biological Sciences. Original and independent thought, practical research, and written and oral reports presented on completion of this course.
PLBI 528.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 72 units and consent of the Department.

PLBI 530.title: Honours Research Project in Plant Biology
PLBI 530.description: Research project under the co/supervision of faculty members in the Department of Biological Sciences. Original and independent thought, practical research, and written and oral reports presented on completion of this course. Open only to Honours Botany students or Honours Biological Sciences students.
PLBI 530.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 72 units and consent of the Department.

PLBI 541.title: Taxonomy of the Seed Plants
PLBI 541.description: A study of plants in relation to classification, phylogeny, evolution and identification. Students are required to make a plant collection of fifty plant specimens for identification in the laboratory. It is recommended that the collection be made in the preceding summer.

PLBI 543.title: Plant Signaling and Development
PLBI 543.description: Physiology, biochemistry, molecular and cellular aspects of plant growth and development. Emphasis on the co-ordinated regulation of gene expression, cell-cell communication, and signalling during development. Discussion on the methods used to study development, such as mutants of Arabidopsis and other model systems.
PLBI 543.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biology 331 and Plant Biology 403 or 421.

PLBI 599.title: Topics in Plant Biology
PLBI 599.description: Exploration of various areas in Plant Biology. Topics may vary from year-to-year. It will be offered as required to provide the opportunity for students to engage in additional areas in Plant Biology.
PLBI 599.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Faculty.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

PLBI 507.01.title: Directed Research in Plant Biology I
PLBI 507.01.description: Directed training in field/laboratory methods and research.
PLBI 507.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 54 units and consent of the Department.

PLBI 507.02.title: Directed Research in Plant Biology II
PLBI 507.02.description: Directed training in field/laboratory methods and research.
PLBI 507.02.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 54 units and consent of the Department.

PLMA 473.title: Energy Business Agreements
PLMA 473.description: Legal requirements in the acquisition, disposition, deployment, exploration of and production from energy rights and contracts in Canada. Sustainability, renewables, Indigenous/First Nations, and basis data analytics are covered.
PLMA 473.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 54 units.

PLMA 475.title: Introduction to Professional Land Management
PLMA 475.description: Professional land management including both technical and economic considerations in the search for and development and marketing of energy resources. Sustainability, renewables, and Indigenous/First Nations are covered.
PLMA 475.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 54 units.

PLMA 479.title: Professional Land Management Strategy
PLMA 479.description: Prepare graduates to effectively contribute to the management or energy asset portfolios throughout the life of renewable and non-renewable properties through corporate project analysis and property valuation techniques.
PLMA 479.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 54 units.

PLMA 483.title: Management of Energy Regulation
PLMA 483.description: Overview of key regulations and surface regulatory principles important to energy resources.
PLMA 483.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 54 units.

PLMA 487.title: Cases in Professional Land Management
PLMA 487.description: A "hands-on" case approach to the typical situations and decision-making processes faced by commercial energy negotiators. Aspects of renewables, sustainability, and Indigenous/First Nations are covered.
PLMA 487.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 54 units.

PLUR 201.title: Introduction to Pluralism
PLUR 201.description: An introduction to concepts and issues associated with pluralism with emphasis on critical self-reflection on assumptions, values and norms, and developing skills to engage with culturally diverse teams. Includes curriculum-based experiential learning components.

PLUR 401.title: Capstone in Pluralism and Global Citizenship
PLUR 401.description: Integrative project with a major experiential learning component involving respectful engagement with a local or global community. The focus of projects could range from improving workplace civility to seeking creative, socially just, and bold outcomes through social activism and innovation, cultural research, entrepreneurial thinking, thought leadership, and/or community development.
PLUR 401.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Pluralism 201 and completion of 60 units.

POLI 201.title: Introduction to Government and Politics
POLI 201.description: A systematic introduction to the basic concepts and institutions of the process of politics.

POLI 213.title: Political Ideologies
POLI 213.description: An introduction to the study of legacy and contemporary political ideologies such as nationalism, socialism, liberalism and fascism.

POLI 279.title: Politics Of The Global South
POLI 279.description:
Politics of the Global South
An introduction to political issues common to the developing regions of Africa, Asia, Latin America and the Middle East, with special emphasis on topics such as democratization, globalization, development, and human rights.

POLI 283.title: Issues & Trends In World Politics
POLI 283.description: Major trends and issues in world politics, such as international tensions, migration, ethnic conflicts, human rights and sustainable development.

POLI 302.title: Topics in Politics
POLI 302.description:
Introductory examination of a topic in Political Science with a Canadian Politics, Comparative Politics, International Relations, or Political Theory focus.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

POLI 321.title: Politics and Government in Canada
POLI 321.description: An examination of institutions and political processes in Canada. Significant attention is paid to key institutions such as Parliament, the executive, federalism, the Constitution, and the courts. Emphasis is also placed on the way that political processes are shaped by these and other institutions.

POLI 326.title: Western Political Thought I: Ancient
POLI 326.description:
An introduction to Western political thought's origins through selected thinkers and works from the ancient Mediterranean world.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Political Science 326 and 310 will not be allowed.

POLI 328.title: Western Political Thought II: Modern
POLI 328.description:
An introduction to Western modernity's new ways of thinking about political life and its possibilities through selected thinkers and works from the fifteenth- to twentieth centuries.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Political Science 328 and 310 will not be allowed.

POLI 338.title: Indigenous Politics in Canada
POLI 338.description:
An introduction to historical and contemporary socio-political issues associated with Indigenous peoples and state-society relations in Canada.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Political Science 338 and either 422 or 424 will not be allowed.

POLI 342.title: Law and Politics
POLI 342.description:
An introduction to the interplay between legal and political personnel, institutions, and processes. Examination of these connections in democratic states focusing on Canada in comparative perspective, authoritarian regimes, transitional and hybrid regimes, and the international system.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Political Science 342 and 343 will not be allowed.

POLI 357.title: Introduction to Public Policy Analysis
POLI 357.description: An introduction to themes and methods in public policy studies. The practical and normative problems facing governments in initiating, formulating, enacting, and implementing policy will be discussed. May include case studies.

POLI 359.title: Introduction to Comparative Politics
POLI 359.description: An introduction to the central concepts, problems, and approaches that comprise the field of comparative politics. Emphasis may also be placed on key analytical challenges, competing methods, and basic governance systems in selected parts of the world.

POLI 369.title: Govt & Poli Of Middle East
POLI 369.description: A survey and analysis of the organization and functioning of governments and politics of the contemporary Middle East, with emphasis on the social and economic environments which influence them.

POLI 371.title: Govt & Poli Of Africa
POLI 371.description: Political institutions of selected African states. The influence of class and tribal structure; political parties; elections, the source and nature of ideologies; and economic and social policies.

POLI 379.title: The Politics of Development
POLI 379.description: A comparative survey of contemporary approaches to development theory and economics such as: modernization, neoliberalism, post-development, critical globalism, gender and development, environment and development. Issues treated include poverty, cultural diversity, sustainability, and the role of state, market, NGOs, and science and technology.

POLI 381.title: Intro To International Relations
POLI 381.description: The structures and processes of international relations and foreign policy.

POLI 397.title: Introduction to Research Methods
POLI 397.description: Introduction to the questions, strategies and rationales of political science research methods. Emphasis on the practical and theoretical advantages and disadvantages of quantitative, qualitative, and mixed-methods approaches.

POLI 398.title: Qualitative Research Methods
POLI 398.description: An introduction to qualitative research methods in Political Science. Topics may include qualitative methodology, elite interviewing, focus groups, content analysis, case studies and qualitative data analysis.

POLI 399.title: Quantitative Research Methods
POLI 399.description: Quantitative research design, measurement, data collection, and data analysis, as conducted in Political Science.

POLI 402.title: Advanced Topics in Politics
POLI 402.description: Advanced examination of a topic in Political Science with a Canadian Politics, Comparative Politics, International Relations, or Political Theory focus
POLI 402.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units in courses labelled Political Science at the 300-level or above.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

POLI 406.title: Greek Love and Wisdom
POLI 406.description: A study of Ancient Greek attempts to address the relationship between love, sex, marriage, friendship, and how we might best lead our lives in a political community. Works by Aristophanes, Plato, Xenophon, Aristotle, Plutarch and others may be covered.

POLI 407.title: Classical Political Thought
POLI 407.description: An examination of selected classical texts from historians, dramatists and political philosophers with special focus upon the concepts relevant to political problems in the twentieth century.

POLI 408.title: Indigenous Governance
POLI 408.description: An examination of the institutions and logics of Indigenous governance structures in Canada. Emphasis will be placed on understanding how inter-Indigenous modes of governance contrast with institutions created by non-Indigenous politicians and bureaucrats. Attention will be paid to kinship, gender relations, war and conflict, and treaty land management.

POLI 409.title: Freedom in Modern Political Thought
POLI 409.description: The study of Western political philosophy's justifications for individual freedom and the limits of shared life. Works by Rousseau, Kant, J.S. Mill, and others may be covered.

POLI 411.title: Recent Critics and Defenders of Modernity
POLI 411.description: A study of debates in recent political thought between theorists who take a strong stand against the universalistic and rational foundations of Enlightenment-based political thought (such as poststructuralists, postmodernists, communitarians, and Far Right populists) and defenders of Enlightenment modernity (such as liberals and Frankfurt School Critical Theorists).

POLI 413.title: Politics and Literature
POLI 413.description: Political analysis of how selected works of literature articulate visions of order and disorder.
POLI 413.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units of courses labelled Political Science.

POLI 415.title: Politics through Film
POLI 415.description: An examination of the complex relationship between politics and film, through selected fictional and documentary works.
POLI 415.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units in courses labelled Political Science.

POLI 417.title: Feminist Political Theory
POLI 417.description: A comparative and critical survey of the main contemporary feminist approaches to political theory: this may include liberal feminism, radical/cultural feminism, socialist/Marxist feminism, and post-modern/post-colonial feminism.
POLI 417.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Political Science 310, 328 or 453.

POLI 418.title: Paradoxes of Modernity
POLI 418.description: A study of the ways in which modernity's highest values (equality, autonomy, and peace) seem to produce their opposites (hierarchy, domination, and violence). Based on selected works and thinkers from the sixteenth-to nineteenth centuries.

POLI 420.title: Legislatures and Executives in Canada
POLI 420.description: The role and operation of Canada's parliamentary system of government. Includes the role of parliament and parliamentarians, critiques of the parliamentary system, and proposals to address its shortcomings.

POLI 425.title: City Government
POLI 425.description: A study of both institutions and political processes relating to city politics.
POLI 425.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Political Science 321 or consent of the Department.

POLI 426.title: Federalism
POLI 426.description: Theoretical and empirical examination of federalism in Canada and other selected states.

POLI 427.title: Government & Politics of Alta
POLI 427.description: An analysis of the institutions and processes of Alberta's government as well as activities in selected policy areas. The examination will include historical as well as contemporary references.
POLI 427.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Political Science 321 or consent of the Department.

POLI 428.title: Comparative Provincial Politics
POLI 428.description: An analysis of provincial politics in Canada focusing on the distinctive political environments as well as similarities and differences in provincial political cultures, party systems and elections, and selected policy areas.
POLI 428.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Political Science 321 or consent of the Department.

POLI 429.title: Electoral Behaviour
POLI 429.description: An examination of how and why citizens engage with their governments. Topics may include individual and group influences on citizen participation, electoral choice, and political behaviour in Canada and other democracies.
POLI 429.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Political Science 321 or 399.

POLI 430.title: Public Opinion
POLI 430.description: An investigation of theories of public opinion in representative democracies and of survey techniques employed in their examination. A portion of the course will normally be devoted to developing and administering a public opinion survey.
POLI 430.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units in courses labelled Political Science.

POLI 431.title: Canadian Political Parties
POLI 431.description: An examination of political parties and party systems in Canada. Party history is reviewed and attention is given to issues relating to organization, finance, representation and electoral competition.
POLI 431.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Political Science 321 or consent of the Department.

POLI 432.title: Selecting and Removing Political Leaders
POLI 432.description: An examination of the processes political parties use to choose and remove their leaders. The focus is on Canadian parties with comparisons to selected parties in other countries.

POLI 433.title: UrbanPolicyandGovernance
POLI 433.description: Examination of policy issues in Canadian cities, with a special focus on domains involving complex governance challenges. Emphasis on the consequences of policy governance for urban public policy, political authority, and democratic accountability.
POLI 433.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units in courses labelled Political Science at the 300 level or above.

POLI 435.title: Canada And World Politics
POLI 435.description: An analysis and evaluation of Canada's role on the international scene; main objectives of Canadian foreign policy; security and defence policies; Canada's participation in universal international organizations; the influence of Canada as a middle power upon world events.
POLI 435.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Political Science 381 or consent of the Department.

POLI 439.title: Strategic Studies
POLI 439.description: An analysis of the causes of war, the meaning of security and defence in the post-Cold War era, including the use and control of military force.
POLI 439.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Political Science 381 or consent of the department.

POLI 440.title: Campaigns and Elections
POLI 440.description: Explores election campaigns in Canada through case studies of key elements such as the selection of candidates, the building of campaign teams and the strategies and tactics parties use to elect candidates and win general elections.

POLI 444.title: Constitutional Law and Politics
POLI 444.description: The law and politics of the Canadian constitution, including the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, the federal division of powers, and responsible parliamentary government.

POLI 447.title: Comparative Public Policy
POLI 447.description: An examination of a range of public policy issues from a comparative perspective. Topics include social policy, family policy, immigration and multiculturalism, and environmental policy across the advanced industrialized democracies.

POLI 451.title: Public Administration
POLI 451.description: Theories of public administration and their practical application in Canada and selected countries.

POLI 453.title: Women and Politics
POLI 453.description:
An examination of current trends in women's political participation in Canada and around the world. Topics may include: women's political behaviour, women's political represenation, and women's movements' engagement with political instituitions. 

Prerequisite(s); Political Science 359 or 321.

Also known as: (formerly Political Science 553)

POLI 455.title: Protest, Rebellion & Revolution
POLI 455.description: A study of the origins, processes, and outcomes of peaceful and violent forms of political protest, rebellion and revolution. Cases may include historical and contemporary examples from around the world.

POLI 463.title: Politics of Post Industrial States
POLI 463.description: Comparative analysis of the political dynamics of post-industrial states. Focus on problems associated with post-industrialization and on explanations for political stability and change.

POLI 464.title: European Politics
POLI 464.description: An introduction to the governments and politics of the states and societies of Europe, including the importance of their membership in the European Union.
POLI 464.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Political Science 359 or consent of the Department.

POLI 465.title: Chinese Politics
POLI 465.description: An introduction to the politics of the Chinese communist party-state. Topics may include: the Mao era leadership debates on socialist development; the post-Mao reforms of Den Xiaoping and his successors; and the emerging challenges associated with market reforms and China's integration into the global capitalist economy.
POLI 465.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): POLI 359 or consent of the Department.

POLI 469.title: Middle East:Contemp Poli Problems
POLI 469.description: An in-depth analysis of selected political, economic and social problems and issues affecting individual nations and the area in general.
POLI 469.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Political Science 369 or consent of the Department.

POLI 470.title: Genocide
POLI 470.description: An introduction to comparative genocide studies. Examines the causes, structures, and dynamics of genocide and mass violence.
POLI 470.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Political Science 359, 381 or Law and Society 201.

POLI 471.title: Africa: Contemporary Political Problems
POLI 471.description: An analysis of political problems in selected political systems of Africa. Topics will include the politics of rural development, political elites and the state in Africa, political institutions, constraints on development, and urban politics.
POLI 471.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Political Science 371 or African Studies 201.

POLI 473.title: Latin American Politics
POLI 473.description: An analysis of how selected Latin American states and societies are addressing both old and new problems such as the transitions from and legacies of dictatorship, political and criminal violence, as well as the construction of democratic institutions and inclusive citizenship.

POLI 477.title: American Politics
POLI 477.description: A study of the institutions and processes of American politics.
POLI 477.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Political Science 359, or consent of the Department.

POLI 479.title: Intl Relations Contemp Arab World
POLI 479.description: An examination of the Arab regional system, with emphasis on regional interaction, regional organizations, and external linkages. The specific cultural, political, ideological, and strategic characteristics of the system will be analysed.
POLI 479.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Political Science 369 or consent of the Department.

POLI 481.title: The Politics of Human Rights
POLI 481.description: An analysis of the origins, evolution, and contemporary politics of human rights. Topics may include the philosophic and religious roots of human rights; international and domestic human rights laws; and struggles to promote and protect human rights in specific contexts around the world.

POLI 483.title: International Law
POLI 483.description: The basic concepts, principles, and functions of international law.
POLI 483.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Political Science 381 or consent of the Department.

POLI 485.title: Global Political Economy
POLI 485.description: Analysis of the politics of international economic relations. Topics may include the politics of trade and money relations, energy, multinational corporations, and the New International Economic Order.
POLI 485.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Political Science 381 or consent of the Department.

POLI 487.title: International Organizations
POLI 487.description: An analysis of international governmental organizations with main emphasis on the United Nations and selected regional organizations.
POLI 487.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Political Science 381 or consent of the Department.

POLI 491.title: US Security Policy
POLI 491.description: Examination of US security policy, with emphasis on how it is made and on contemporary security issues the US faces.

POLI 492.title: Foreign Policy Analysis
POLI 492.description: Theoretical and empirical examination of how states' foreign policies are shaped by individual, domestic, and international factors.

POLI 502.title: Advanced Topics Seminar in Politics
POLI 502.description: Advanced seminar on a topic in political science with a Canadian politics, comparative politics, international relations, or political theory focus.
POLI 502.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Completion of 60 units including 3 units in courses labelled Political Science at the 300 level or above. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

POLI 503.title: Selected Topics in Political Theory
POLI 503.description: Focus on perennial questions from classical to contemporary political theory, such as justice, the use of violence, and the goals of political life.
POLI 503.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 60 units including Political Science 310, or both 326 and 328.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

POLI 505.title: Sexual Ethics
POLI 505.description: An examination of attempts to theorize those things associated with human sexuality using works of historical and contemporary political philosophy. Topics may include: the nature of love and friendship, the good of marriage, limits of sexuality, and the place of justice, equality, and shame.
POLI 505.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 60 units including Political Science 310 or both 326 and 328.

POLI 506.title: Social and Global Justice
POLI 506.description: An examination of contemporary theories and debates in social and global justice. Topics may include: the redistribution-recognition dilemma, multiculturalism, intersectionality, identity/post-identity politics, globalization, transnationalization, and post-Westphalian approaches to governance and democracy.
POLI 506.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 60 units including 3 units from Political Science 310, 328, 379, 381, 481, 417.

POLI 508.title: Topics in Canadian Political Development
POLI 508.description: In-depth examination of the development and transformation of Canadian institutions and politics. Topics may include elections and electoral systems, political parties, federalism, Indigenous-state relations, urban politics, provincial politics, and parliamentary institutions.
POLI 508.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Completion of 60 units including Political Science 321.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

POLI 509.title: Public Policy and Politics
POLI 509.description: Advanced seminar on the main theories and approaches to the study of public policy in political science. Topics may include health, welfare, immigration, and morality policy.
POLI 509.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Completion of 60 units including Political Science 357 or 447.

POLI 515.title: Advanced History of Political Thought
POLI 515.description: An intensive study of selected major political thinkers within the history of political thought.
POLI 515.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 60 units including Political Science 310, or both 326 and 328.

POLI 519.title: Interpretation and War
POLI 519.description: An examination of the philosophical justifications offered to defend the use of military force, based particularly on the analysis of texts in the history of Western political philosophy.

POLI 521.title: Canadian Federalism
POLI 521.description: An examination of the dynamics of Canadian Federalism including relations among provinces and between provinces and the federal government.
POLI 521.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Completion of 60 units including 3 units from Political Science 321, 426, 427, 428.

POLI 523.title: Canada & the Circumpolar World
POLI 523.description: An examination of critical national and international issues in the circumpolar world.
POLI 523.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Completion of 60 units including Political Science 381.

POLI 524.title: Advanced Seminar in Indigenous Politics in Canada
POLI 524.description: Engagement with the contributions made by Indigenous scholars to rethinking Canadian politics. Emphasis on Indigenous scholars' critiques of colonialism and settler-colonialism in Canada, and the decolonizing potential of Indigenous political thought.
POLI 524.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 60 units including Political Science 338 or 408 or Indigenous Studies 407.

POLI 531.title: Parties, Elections & Representation
POLI 531.description: An examination of political parties and elections in both established and emerging democracies as a means of understanding the nature of political representation in modern representative democracies.
POLI 531.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Completion of 60 units including Political Science 431.

POLI 543.title: Law and Armed Conflict
POLI 543.description: An examination of key texts and topics concerning the evolution, conceptualization, codification, and practical application of the laws of armed conflict. Topics may include the historical and philosophical development of the customary and codified laws of armed conflict, military law and military training and education, and the use of law to punish and deter war crimes.
POLI 543.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Completion of 60 units including Political Science 342 or 483.

POLI 551.title: Women in Canadian Politics
POLI 551.description: A political history of women in Canada in the twentieth and twenty first centuries. Topics include campaigns for suffrage, legal personhood and equality rights, women's political activism, the evolution of public policy concerning women, and the participation of women in public life.
POLI 551.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Completion of 60 units including Political Science 321.

POLI 554.title: Women and Public Policy
POLI 554.description: An examination of the impact of public policies on gender relations from a comparative perspective. Topics may include family and social policies, gender and the workplace, reproductive rights, and gender-based violence.
POLI 554.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Completion of 60 units including 3 units from Political Science 357, 359, 453.

POLI 565.title: Indigenous Politics in the Global South
POLI 565.description: Advanced examination of the competing theoretical explanations for the sudden and unexpected rise of Indigenous peoples as key political actors in countries of the Global South.May include Indigenous rights struggles in Africa, Asia, and Latin America.
POLI 565.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Completion of 60 units including Political Science 359 or Indigenous Studies 407.

POLI 569.title: Selected Topics in Middle East Politics
POLI 569.description: Emphasis will be on foreign-policy development and application in the Middle East.
POLI 569.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Completion of 60 units including Political Science 369 and 3 units of Courses Constituting the Field of Political Science in Comparative Politics or International Relations at the 400 level. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

POLI 575.title: Intelligence and Policy
POLI 575.description: An examination of the role and limits of intelligence in policymaking.
POLI 575.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Completion of 60 units including Political Science 381.

POLI 579.title: Political Economy Of Development
POLI 579.description: Global South development projects, programs, and policies in Africa, Asia and Latin America, intended to raise the standard of living and enhance political participation.
POLI 579.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 60 units including Political Science 359 or 379.

POLI 581.title: Selected Topics in International Law and Organizations
POLI 581.description: An advanced seminar on international order and on co-operative and competitive efforts by states and other international actors to create, maintain and change that order.
POLI 581.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Completion of 60 units including Political Science 483 or 487.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

POLI 585.title: Preventing the Spread of Nuclear Weapons
POLI 585.description: An analysis of the politics of the international regime governing the control of nuclear weapons, including case studies of states that pose a challenge to that regime.
POLI 585.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Completion of 60 units including Political Science 381.

POLI 586.title: Advanced Studies in Global Political Economy
POLI 586.description: Advanced analysis of selected themes in global political economy. Topics may include trade, migration, exchange rates, and foreign direct investment.
POLI 586.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Completion of 60 units including Political Science 485.

POLI 587.title: International Ethics
POLI 587.description: An examination of ethical reasoning and moral norms in political decision making, institutions, and processes in international politics. Topics such as justice in relation to war and terrorism, sovereignty, intervention and human rights, globalization and global poverty, and the environment may be analyzed.

POLI 590.title: Honours Seminar
POLI 590.description: An examination of classic works in political science.
POLI 590.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Political Science Honours program and completion of 75 units, including Political Science 397, 398 and 399.

POLI 591.title: Honours Thesis
POLI 591.description: Preparation of an honours thesis under the supervision of a faculty member who will assign the final grade.

POLI 592.title: Complex Governance
POLI 592.description: Draws on complex systems theories to consider the strengths and limitations of a broad range of existing forms of governance and the potential of emerging new ones.
POLI 592.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 60 units including 3 units from Political Science 359, 379, 381.

POLI 593.title: Advanced Quantitative Analysis of Politics
POLI 593.description: Examination of advanced empirical research methods and techniques of multivariate quantitative analysis in the study of political phenomena.

POLI 597.title: Directed Study in Political Science
POLI 597.description: Study of a particular topic under the direct supervision of a faculty member.
POLI 597.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Completion of 60 units and consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

POLI 605.title: Advanced Introduction to Sexual Ethics
POLI 605.description:
An advanced introduction to theorizing human sexuality using works of historical and contemporary political philosophy. Topics may include: the nature of love and friendship, the good of marriage, limits of sexuality, and the place of justice, equality, and shame.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for both Political Science 605 and 505 will not be allowed.

POLI 606.title: Social and Global Justice
POLI 606.description: An examination of contemporary theories and debates in social and global justice. Topics may include: the redistribution-recognition dilemma, multiculturalism, intersectionality, identity/post-identity politics, globalization, transnationalization, and post-Westphalian approaches to governance and democracy.

POLI 615.title: Advanced History Of Political Thought
POLI 615.description: An intensive study of selected major political thinkers within the history of political thought.

POLI 617.title: Advanced Political Theory
POLI 617.description:
Discussion of contemporary topics in political thought. Emphasis on analysis of problems rather than history of ideas.

Notes:  Students should consult the Department regarding enrollment in this course.

POLI 619.title: War and Interpretation
POLI 619.description: An examination of the philosophical justifications offered to defend the use of military force, based particularly on the analysis of texts in the history of Western political philosophy.

POLI 621.title: Canadian Political Institutions
POLI 621.description: Examination of the structure and operation of the central institutions of the Canadian state, including the constitution, federalism, parliamentary government, and political parties.

POLI 623.title: Canadian Political Process
POLI 623.description: Examination of Canadian political behaviour within its institutional context, including political parties, interest groups, voting and socialization.

POLI 624.title: Advanced Seminar on Indigenous-State Relations in Canada
POLI 624.description: Structure and operation of colonialism and settler-colonialism in Canada, and Indigenous resistance to those structures of oppression. Attention will be paid to the reconciliation debates, Indigenous gender oppression, and the politics of decolonization in Canada.

POLI 631.title: Parties Election & Representation
POLI 631.description: An examination of political parties and elections in both established and emerging democracies as a means of understanding the nature of political representation in modern representative democracies.

POLI 633.title: US Security Policy
POLI 633.description: An examination of US security policy, with an emphasis both on how US security policy is made and on the main contemporary security issues the US faces today.

POLI 641.title: Selected Topics In Public Law
POLI 641.description:
Examination of the political, philosophical, and institutional dimensions of selected public law issues, with particular reference to judicial and quasi-judicial tribunals as policy-making institutions. Consult the Department for information on choice of topics.

Notes:  Students should consult the Department regarding enrollment in this course.

POLI 643.title: Law and Armed Conflict
POLI 643.description: An examination of key texts and topics concerning the evolution, conceptualization, codification, and practical application of the laws of armed conflict. Topics may include the historical and philosophical development of the customary and codified laws of armed conflict, military law and military training and education, and the use of law to punish and deter war crimes.

POLI 651.title: Politics and Public Policy
POLI 651.description: An examination of the main theories and approaches to the study of public policy.

POLI 653.title: Gender and Public Policy
POLI 653.description: Explores the gendered impact of a range of public policies and also explores the influence of gender norms and ideas on the formulation of public policy. Topics covered include gender-based policy analysis, gender and the welfare state, family and child-care policies, policies to address gender inequalities in the labour market and workplace, and reproductive rights policies.

POLI 665.title: Advanced Seminar on Indigenous Politics in the Global South
POLI 665.description: Advanced examination of the competing theoretical explanations for the sudden and unexpected rise of Indigenous peoples as key political actors in countries of the Global South. In-depth case studies may include Indigenous rights struggles in Africa, Asia, and Latin America.

POLI 671.title: Comparative Politics of Development in the Global South
POLI 671.description: An examination of the major issues, theories, and debates about development and politics in the Global South.

POLI 673.title: Comparative Politics: Theories and Methods
POLI 673.description: An examination of the main theories, methods, and debates in the field of Comparative Politics.

POLI 675.title: Selected Topics in Advanced Comparative Politics
POLI 675.description:
Selected regions and topics in Comparative Politics.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

POLI 681.title: Advanced Analysis of International Relations
POLI 681.description: An examination of the main theories, issues, and approaches in the study of International Relations.

POLI 683.title: Adv Studies In Foreign Policy
POLI 683.description:
Selected themes in the formation and implementation of foreign policies. 

Notes:  Students should consult the Department regarding enrollment in this course.

POLI 684.title: Human Rights & Humanitarianism
POLI 684.description:
An advanced introduction to the principal contemporary debates in the field of human rights and humanitarian politics.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for both Political Science 684 and 571 will not be allowed.

POLI 685.title: Strategic Studies
POLI 685.description:
Advanced seminar in major topics in strategic studies, such as arms control, deterrence, and other military doctrines.

Notes:  Students should consult the Department regarding enrollment in this course.

POLI 686.title: Advanced Seminar in Global Political Economy
POLI 686.description: Covering in-depth major debates in global political economy, provides an advanced exploration of the causes and effects of globalization, including the determinants of foreign economic policymaking (such as trade, money, migration, global production, finance, and foreign aid) as well as the subsequent impact of these policies.

POLI 687.title: Advanced Studies in Canadian Arctic Security
POLI 687.description:
The Canadian Arctic is an emerging area of concern due to changes scarcely imaginable even a few years ago. Examines the nature of some of these changes--e.g., climate change and the northern seas' dramatically changing ice conditions, growing recognition of the regions' resource wealth, and evolving international relations in the circumpolar region--and what they mean for Canadian Arctic security.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Political Science 687 and 523 will not be allowed.

POLI 689.title: Unconventional Warfare
POLI 689.description: Analysis of warfare conducted by, or against, sub-state groups. This may include in-depth studies of guerrilla warfare, asymmetric conflict, or terrorism.

POLI 691.title: Quantitative Analysis In Political Science
POLI 691.description: Examination of empirical research methods and techniques of quantitative analysis in the study of political phenomena. Computer use is required.

POLI 692.title: Complex Governance
POLI 692.description: This course draws on complex systems theories to consider the strengths and limitations of a broad range of existing forms of governance and the potential of emerging new ones.

POLI 693.title: Advanced Quantitative Analysis in Political Science
POLI 693.description: Examination of empirical research methods and techniques of multivariate quantitative analysis in the study of political phenomena.
POLI 693.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Political Science 691 or consent of the Department.

POLI 697.title: Major Research Paper
POLI 697.description: Preparation of a major research paper under the supervision of a faculty member who will assign the grade.

POLI 699.title: Qualitative Analysis in Political Science
POLI 699.description: An introduction to qualitative research methods in Political Science. Topics may include qualitative methodology, elite interviewing, focus groups, content analysis, case studies and qualitative data analysis.
POLI 699.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Political Science 691 or consent of the Department.

POLI 723.title: Spec Topics Political Science
POLI 723.description:
No course description

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

POLI 791.title: Scope and Methods in Political Science
POLI 791.description:
Advanced seminar covering various approaches, topics, methods and theories employed in the discipline of political science. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

PPOL 600.title: The Study of Public Policy
PPOL 600.description: Provides an introduction to the study of public policy, focusing on defining the boundaries of public policy and approaches to the study of public policy. Introduces the research, communication and professional competencies of public policy professionals.

PPOL 604.title: Communicating Policy
PPOL 604.description:
Examines aspects of communication and persuasion in the context of policy, including the impact of new modes of communication on the development and dissemination of public policy. Theoretical and practical actions in communicating to persuade; the nature and object of public opinion research; crisis communications; the role of trust in effective communication; the impact and management of the turn to social media; and the theory and practice of political communication. Course evaluation focuses on pragmatic skills and the ability to apply theoretical concepts under real-world conditions.

Also known as: (formerly Public Policy 621)

PPOL 605.title: Markets and Public Policy
PPOL 605.description: The role of markets in the allocation of resources and the determination of income. Sources of market failure, and the appropriate public policy response to those failures, are examined. Students learn how private firms make decisions, and how they respond to policy initiatives.

PPOL 607.title: Politics and Strategy
PPOL 607.description: How public policy issues emerge and how they are developed, refined, and influenced by the political process. The roles and influences of NGOs, interest groups, the media, political parties, and social protest on the development of new public policies. Development of advocacy and government relations strategies. Genres of persuasive policy writing and communications.

PPOL 608.title: Markets and Public Policy
PPOL 608.description:
Examines the working of the aggregate economy and uses concepts from micro-economic theory to allow for informed discussion of complex public policy problems. Topics include contrasting macroeconomics and microeconomics; gross domestic product; economic growth and business cycles; unemployment; monetary policy and inflation; welfare and efficiency; government interventions in markets; externalities; public goods; labour markets and wages; inequality and redistribution; and uncertainty. 

Also known as: (formerly Public Policy 602)

PPOL 609.title: Decision Analysis
PPOL 609.description: The focus is on the foundations, applications and use of quantitative methods commonly used in decision making in the public and private sectors. Included are methods such as impact analysis, cost-benefit analysis, surveys, game theory and risk management tools.

PPOL 615.title: Public Finances
PPOL 615.description: An overview of government finances and the restrictions on policy choices resulting from the need for governments to satisfy a budget constraint. Tax policy, the appropriate design of expenditure policies, policies with respect to deficits and debt, and issues of intergovernmental relations will be examined.

PPOL 617.title: Regulation and the Law
PPOL 617.description: The role of international and national legal institutions in determining public policy choices. Legal research and interpretation.

PPOL 619.title: Governance, Institutions and Public Policy
PPOL 619.description: Indigenous governance, federalism and multi-level governance. Research using government documents. Formal genres of policy writing and communications.

PPOL 620.title: Capstone Preparation
PPOL 620.description:
To prepare for their capstone research project, students learn how to outline a research proposal and plan including choosing appropriate methodologies for research and analysis within Public Policy.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

PPOL 621.title: Communicating Policy
PPOL 621.description: Examines all aspects of communication in the context of policy, including the impact of new modes of communication on the development and dissemination of public policy. The new role of blogs, on-line communities, and web-based media at marshalling and influencing public opinion and the changing role of print media are discussed and evaluated. Implications for copyright policies, media concentration, privacy, and advertising are among the issues examined.

PPOL 623.title: Capstone Project
PPOL 623.description:
Students apply the skills they have learned to the completion of a capstone project which investigates a well-defined issue of public policy. The final capstone project is expected to be a substantive, well-researched, focused and highly professional document. Work on the capstone project will be guided by a School of Public Policy faculty member and may include input provided by an expert from the private sector or public sector.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

PPOL 699.title: Topics in Public Policy
PPOL 699.description:
Study of selected topics related to Public Policy and related subjects.  Specific course(s) will reflect changing faculty interests.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

PSYC 200.title: Principles of Psychology I
PSYC 200.description:
A survey of topics associated with psychology's role as a biological science, including neuroscience, sensation and perception, cognition, learning, memory, and language.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Psychology 200 and 205 will not be allowed.

PSYC 201.title: Principles of Psychology II
PSYC 201.description:
A survey of topics associated with psychology's role as a social science, including personality, motivation, health, social, developmental, industrial/organizational and clinical psychology.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Psychology 201 and 205 will not be allowed.

PSYC 203.title: Psychology for Everyday Life
PSYC 203.description: Provides students with an understanding of the key theories, research methods, and discoveries in coping and resilience, identity development, interpersonal relationships, and mental health with an emphasis on developing the knowledge and skills necessary to be effective consumers of psychological theory and research. Through a focus on adjustment issues that arise in everyday life, this course will demonstrate some of the ways in which psychology can be used to benefit students' wellbeing in their personal and professional lives.

PSYC 204.title: Human Sexuality
PSYC 204.description: Examination of contemporary knowledge and attitudes toward human sexuality, relying on theoretical and empirical psychological research. Multiple perspectives are presented, including psychosocial, cross-cultural, and psychobiological. Sexuality across the life span is examined, including issues pertaining to sexual differentiation, intimacy and communication, gender role development, varieties of sexual relationships and behaviour, and legal and ethical issues.

PSYC 300.title: Research Methods and Data Analysis in Psychology I
PSYC 300.description: Research methods in psychological research, with an introduction to data analysis.
PSYC 300.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): One of Mathematics 30-1, 30-2, 31, or Mathematics 2 (offered by Continuing Education); Psychology 200; and Psychology 201 or Neuroscience 201.

PSYC 301.title: Research Methods and Data Analysis in Psychology II
PSYC 301.description: An integration of research methods and statistics in psychological research, with an emphasis on conducting and interpreting inferential statistical techniques.

PSYC 305.title: History Of Psychological Thought
PSYC 305.description: The roots of psychological thought in Western culture, and the relationship between theories of human nature and changing social institutions.

PSYC 321.title: Industrial & Organizational Psychology
PSYC 321.description: Understanding and predicting behaviour and attitudes within an organizational setting. Topics normally include: personnel selection, attraction to organizations and job choice, person-organization fit, organizational culture, motivation and decision-making, employee attitudes, deviant behaviour in organizations, leadership, team behaviour, and personality in the workplace.

PSYC 345.title: Social Psychology
PSYC 345.description: Social psychological approaches to understanding social influence, social perception and cognition, attitudes and group dynamics.

PSYC 349.title: Language Development
PSYC 349.description: Research into language development in typically developing children, with consideration of environmental and other factors that influence acquisition. Consideration also given to atypical language development.

PSYC 352.title: Lifespan Developmental Psychology
PSYC 352.description: An examination of biological, cognitive, and social aspects of psychological development across the lifespan from birth to death, highlighting theory, research, and current issues in the field.

PSYC 365.title: Cognitive Psychology
PSYC 365.description: A survey of research and theory in cognitive psychology. Research in pattern recognition, attention, memory, language, thinking, and other cognitive abilities is explored, with discussion of associated brain mechanisms.

PSYC 369.title: Sensation & Perception
PSYC 369.description: The psychological and physiological bases of sensory and perceptual processes, including vision, audition, taste, smell, touch, proprioception, and basic psychophysics. Provides a background for advanced courses in sensory and perceptual processing, human factors, and environmental psychology.

PSYC 373.title: Motivation
PSYC 373.description: A survey of theories, models, and research on the psychological aspects of human motivation from social, cognitive, behavioural, and biological perspectives.

PSYC 375.title: Brain and Behaviour
PSYC 375.description: The neural basis of learning, memory, language and thinking, as well as pathological, sexual, aggressive, and emotional behaviour that arises from neural and hormonal malfunctioning.

PSYC 383.title: Personality
PSYC 383.description: Approaches to the study of personality.

PSYC 385.title: Psychopathology
PSYC 385.description: A critical review of major concepts and theories in the study of psychopathology throughout the lifespan, with an emphasis on historical, cultural and contextual factors influencing assessment, diagnosis, and treatment.

PSYC 391.title: Academic Competencies in Psychology
PSYC 391.description: Students acquire personal and academic competencies to support program success including effective communication, critical thinking, information literacy, and techniques to set realistic goals.
PSYC 391.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 200, 201 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 393.title: Professional Development in Psychology
PSYC 393.description: Students acquire professional and career development skills to prepare for the transition into the workplace. Students explore career options and develop materials to increase success in professional and job opportunities.
PSYC 393.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 200, 201 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 405.title: Contemporary Theories in Psychology
PSYC 405.description: An analysis of what constitutes a "theory," "model" and "explanation" in psychology as a science. Survey of major theoretical positions in twentieth-century psychology.
PSYC 405.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 200 and 201, 3 units in a course labelled Psychology at the 300 level or above, and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 407.title: Psychometrics
PSYC 407.description: Theory and application of methodological and statistical issues in psychological assessment. Topics include: theories of psychological measurement, scale development, item analysis, item bias, reliability, validity, and test fairness.
PSYC 407.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 411.title: Design and Analysis in Psychological Research
PSYC 411.description: Experimental design problems and techniques for analysis of psychological data.
PSYC 411.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 412.title: Multiple Regression in Psychological Research
PSYC 412.description: Theory and application of multiple regression to experimental and non-experimental research, including mediation and moderation analysis.
PSYC 412.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 415.title: Qualitative Inquiry in Psychology
PSYC 415.description: Qualitative approaches to psychological research such as phenomenology, grounded theory, and discourse analysis. Specific topics include research interviews, ethics, and evaluating qualitative research.
PSYC 415.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 425.title: Human Factors
PSYC 425.description: Application of psychological research and theory to people-system relationships and the work environment; display and control devices, design and evaluation of the built environment, human skills and limitations, work schedules, safety, and research methods in human factors engineering.
PSYC 425.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 427.title: Environmental Psychology
PSYC 427.description: The theory and data pertaining to the relationship between human behaviour and the physical environment, both natural and built. Particular emphasis is placed on the implications of current knowledge for the management of the human-environment interface. A research project is an integral part of the course.
PSYC 427.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 429.title: Adolescence
PSYC 429.description: An in-depth examination of the physical, cognitive, emotional, and social changes occurring during adolescence, drawing upon theory and relevant research.
PSYC 429.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301; and 3 units from 351, 352; and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 430.title: Psychophysiology in Health Research
PSYC 430.description: An examination of the impact of emotions on physiological activity and risk for disease, including coronary heart disease, ulcers, asthma, cancer and other immune-related disorders, with an emphasis on the discussion and understanding of empirical research. Hands-on experience with psychophysiological measurement equipment and procedures commonly used in stress research will be provided.
PSYC 430.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301, 375 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 431.title: Current Issues in Psychopathology
PSYC 431.description: Discussion of current developments and controversies in the assessment, etiology, and treatment of psychopathology. Emphasis will be on teaching students how to strengthen their critical thinking skills using controversial issues in the fields of abnormal and clinical psychology as a basis for discussion and debate.
PSYC 431.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301, 385 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 433.title: Clinical Psychology
PSYC 433.description: Assessment and treatment problems in clinical settings.
PSYC 433.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301, 385 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 435.title: Behaviour Therapy
PSYC 435.description: Theory, principles, and practices of contemporary behaviour therapy/behaviour modification as applied to a representative range of disorders, problems, and child and adult populations.
PSYC 435.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301, 385 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 437.title: Health Psychology
PSYC 437.description:
Health psychology involves the discipline and principles of psychology and human behaviour in understanding how the mind, body, and behaviour interact in health and disease. Class topics include psychosocial models of health and disease, stress and coping, health enhancing and health damaging behaviours, pain management, and a variety of specific behaviour-related medical illnesses (e.g., heart disease, cancer, insomnia).

Psychology 300, 301, 375 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

Also known as: (formerly Psychology 330)

PSYC 439.title: Psychology of Gender
PSYC 439.description: An analysis of psychological theory and research on gender situated within the interdisciplinary field of gender studies. Topics include the meaning of gender, psychological development and gender, and gender and interpersonal relationships.
PSYC 439.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301; and 3 units from Psychology 345, 351, 352; and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 442.title: Intergroup Relations
PSYC 442.description: In-depth exploration of intergroup relations from a social psychological perspective. Theory and research about the processes involved in stereotyping, prejudice, and discrimination.
PSYC 442.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301, 345, and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 443.title: Interpersonal Relationships
PSYC 443.description: Application of social psychological theory and methodology to a variety of topics in the area of interpersonal relationships such as attraction, close relationships, interpersonal conflict, communication, and power. Course projects will be an integral part of the course.
PSYC 443.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301, 345 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 444.title: Social Influence and Persuasion
PSYC 444.description: Focus on the psychology of social influence, persuasion, and compliance gaining.
PSYC 444.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301, and 345 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 445.title: Psychology of Morality
PSYC 445.description: An exploration of the origins and nature of moral conduct from the perspective of psychological theory and research. Examination of the naturalistic basis for why people care about morality, behave morally or not, and the psychological bases of moral judgment. Topics may include the evolutionary basis for morality, moral intuitionism, moral development, and moral judgment.
PSYC 445.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 447.title: Advanced Topics in Personality or Social Psychology
PSYC 447.description: An examination of current research topics in personality or social psychology or gender.
PSYC 447.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 449.title: Social-Personality Development
PSYC 449.description: Socialization processes and behaviours from birth to adolescence; observational learning, altruism, moral development, sex-roles, dependency, emotional development, and social motivation.
PSYC 449.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301; and 3 units from 351, 352; and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 451.title: Cognitive Development
PSYC 451.description: Current and classic research in the area of cognitive development is explored. Topics may include sensory and perceptual development, language acquisition, symbolic representation, concept formation, memory, and social-cognitive development.
PSYC 451.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301; and 3 units from 351, 352; and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program or to the minor in Speech-Language Sciences for Linguistics Majors.

PSYC 455.title: Sensory, Perceptual, and Cognitive Aspects of Aging
PSYC 455.description: Basic research and contemporary issues in the age-related changes in sensation, perception, attention, learning and memory, intelligence and problem-solving.
PSYC 455.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301; and 3 units from 352, 353; and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 457.title: Social and Clinical Aspects of Aging
PSYC 457.description: Stability and change in the later years of life with a focus on social and clinical areas of aging.
PSYC 457.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301; and 3 units from 352, 353; and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 459.title: Developmental Psychopathology
PSYC 459.description: A critical examination of developmental psychopathology during childhood and adolescence with an emphasis on the characteristics of the disorders, their determinants, and outcomes. Current theories and research, and recent trends in intervention and prevention will be emphasized.
PSYC 459.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301, 385; and 3 units from 351, 352, 353; and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 463.title: Memory
PSYC 463.description: Current memory research is explored. Topics include how memories are encoded, and retrieved. Laboratory projects introduce methodologies used in memory research.
PSYC 463.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301, 365 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 467.title: (LING 467) Psycholinguistics
PSYC 467.description: Exploration of the cognitive, neuropsychological, and social processes that underlie language abilities, with reference to linguistic theory.
PSYC 467.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program or to the minor in Speech-Language Sciences for Linguistics Majors.

PSYC 469.title: Vision
PSYC 469.description: A systematic examination of vision and its role in our interactions with the natural environment. Topics may include: the physics of light; optics; eye and retina; visual pathways and visual brain; perception of colour, space, change and motion; visual development and aging; art and vision; visual disorders; and recovery from blindness.
PSYC 469.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301, 369 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 471.title: Auditory Cognitive Neuroscience
PSYC 471.description: Exploration of auditory perception from an auditory cognitive neuroscience perspective, using music and speech as domains of inquiry. Focus on acoustics, psychophysics, cognitive psychology, cognitive development, neurophysiology, and neuropsychology. Includes hands-on exercises in sound manipulation and experimentation.
PSYC 471.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301, 369 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program or to the minor in Speech-Language Sciences for Linguistics Majors or the Concentration in Speech-Language Sciences for Linguistics Majors.

PSYC 473.title: Evolution and Human Behaviour
PSYC 473.description: An examination of the scientific synthesis of evolutionary biology and modern psychology, which offers a novel approach to such issues as short-term and long-term human mating strategies, short-term sexual strategies, conflict between the sexes, parental investment, aggression, and social dominance.
PSYC 473.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 474.title: Neuroscience of Learning and Memory
PSYC 474.description: An examination of learning and memory from a neuroscience perspective. Molecular, cellular, systems-level, and behavioural approaches will be applied to themes such as consolidation, amnesia, and pathological processes.
PSYC 474.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301, 375 and admission to the Psychology or Neuroscience  program.

PSYC 475.title: Drugs and Behaviour
PSYC 475.description: The behavioural effects of drugs specifically employed to affect the nervous system, as seen in the treatment of mental disorders, behavioural disorders, and other conditions such as Parkinson's, Huntington's and Alzheimer's diseases. Neuro-pharmacologic agents will be discussed as they relate to the biochemistry and physiology of putative neurotransmitters.
PSYC 475.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301, 375 and admission to the Psychology or Neuroscience program.

PSYC 477.title: Sleep and Biological Rhythms
PSYC 477.description: Behaviours are temporally co-ordinated and occur in a rhythmic fashion. The most obvious rhythmic behaviour humans engage in is sleeping; we spend one-third of our lives asleep. This course will survey the behavioural, physiological, and clinical aspects of sleep and biological rhythms.
PSYC 477.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301, 375 and admission to the Psychology or Neuroscience program.

PSYC 478.title: Behavioural Neuroscience
PSYC 478.description: An examination of the neural underpinnings of behaviour. Experimental approaches, neural mechanisms, and health implications will be explored through both lecture material and laboratory exercises.
PSYC 478.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301, 375 and admission to the Psychology or Neuroscience program.

Credit for Psychology 478 and Neuroscience 478 will not be allowed.

PSYC 479.title: Human Neuropsychology
PSYC 479.description: Integration of the literature on human brain damage with the evidence from animal research. Topics include developmental neuropsychology; cognitive deficits associated with frontal, parietooccipital, and temporal lobes; origins and mechanisms in the determination of cerebral dominancy; disorders of learning and memory; long-term effects of cerebral lesions.
PSYC 479.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301, 375 and admission to the Psychology or Neuroscience program or to the minor in Speech-Language Sciences for Linguistics Majors.

Credit for Psychology 479 and Neuroscience 479 will not be allowed.

PSYC 491.title: Cross-Cultural Cognition
PSYC 491.description: Theory and research on the interaction of culture and human cognition. Topics include cross-cultural research in perception, language processing, memory, concepts, and reasoning.
PSYC 491.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301, 365 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 492.title: (INDG 492) Indigenous Psychology
PSYC 492.description: An in-depth examination of research in psychology related to Indigenous populations, including the history of research, major topics, appropriate approaches to conducting research, and new directions.
PSYC 492.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

Also known as: (Indigenous Studies 492)

PSYC 493.title: Psychology and Law
PSYC 493.description: Consideration of the contributions of psychological theory and research to the understanding of crime investigation, courtroom dynamics, and the legal system. Specific topics may include eyewitness testimony, police practices, judge and jury decision making, lie detection and confessions, and expert testimony. Topics will be discussed from the perspectives of social and cognitive psychology.
PSYC 493.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 495.title: Consumer Psychology
PSYC 495.description: Consideration of the psychological concepts used to understand the processes involved in consumer behaviour. Specific topics may include research methodology, individual and group influences, marketing strategies, and consumer decision making. Topics will be discussed from the perspectives of cognitive and social psychology.
PSYC 495.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 497.title: Consciousness
PSYC 497.description: An exploration of the origin, nature, and function of consciousness as informed by research on conscious and unconscious processes, psychological disorders, neuropsychological case studies, consciousness-altering drugs, hypnosis, meditation, state-dependent memory, sleep, and dreams.
PSYC 497.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300 and 301; one of 365 or 375 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 501.title: Honours Topics Seminar in Psychology
PSYC 501.description: Selected topics from one or more areas in psychology.
PSYC 501.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301, admission to the Psychology Honours program and consent of the Department.

PSYC 502.title: Selected Topics in Psychology with Lab
PSYC 502.description: Selected topics from one or more areas in psychology.
PSYC 502.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 503.title: Selected Topics in Psychology
PSYC 503.description: Selected topics from one or more areas in psychology.
PSYC 503.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 504.title: Directed Research in Psychology
PSYC 504.description: Research project in psychology conducted under the supervision of a faculty member.
PSYC 504.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301, admission to the Psychology major or Honours program and consent of the Department.

PSYC 508.description: Research project in psychology conducted under the supervision of a faculty member.
