PSYC 521.title: Cognitive and Clinical Neuroscience
PSYC 521.description: An examination of how the human central nervous system controls higher order, complex behaviours. Experimental and clinical evidence for the neurobiological regulation of memory, language, attention, perception and emotion will be evaluated.
PSYC 521.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301, 375 and admission to the Psychology or Neuroscience program.

Credit for Psychology 521 and Neuroscience 521 will not be allowed.

PSYC 531.title: Nervous System Development
PSYC 531.description: This course will cover the fundamental principles of the development of nervous systems, integrating anatomical, cellular, molecular, genetic, and behavioural approaches.
PSYC 531.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Psychology 475 and admission to the Psychology Psychology or Neuroscience program.

Credit for Psychology 531 and Neuroscience 531 will not be allowed.

PSYC 585.title: Advanced Themes in Psychopathology
PSYC 585.description: Examination of assessment, phenomenology, etiology, and/or treatment of common psychological disorders. Course will cover few disorders in greater detail.
PSYC 585.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301, 385, 433 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

PSYC 591.title: Advanced Topics in Cognitive Psychology
PSYC 591.description: A detailed examination of current research topics in cognitive psychology. Topics may include one or more of the following: human memory, thinking, attention, language processing, and computer modelling.
PSYC 591.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Psychology 300, 301, 365 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

PSYC 598.title: Honours Thesis and Seminar
PSYC 598.description: Research project under the direction of a member of the Department. In the seminar, students will present and discuss their projects and other topics of current relevance.
PSYC 598.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Psychology Honours degree program.

PSYC 600.title: Professional Development
PSYC 600.description: Professional development seminar series to prepare students for diverse careers in Psychology. The goals of the seminars are to build transferable skills relating to academic topics, mental health and wellness, and career development.

PSYC 601.title: History of Psychology
PSYC 601.description: History of psychological concepts in Western culture, major theoretical systems of twentieth century psychology, foundational assumptions of theories in contemporary psychology.

PSYC 607.title: Advanced Research Design and Methodology in Psychology
PSYC 607.description: Survey of advanced topics in the conduct of psychological research including issues in philosophy of science; origins of research ideas; validity and reliability; measurement; experimental, quasi-experimental and non-experimental designs; survey research; specialized methods such as online data collection, and cognitive procedures; and ethics.

PSYC 611.title: Advanced Qualitation Inquiry in Psychology
PSYC 611.description: Qualitative research designs and historical research in psychology. Advanced study of selected qualitative approaches in psychology to include research design, methods, and analysis. Specific topics covered include foundations of qualitative research, evaluation and practical techniques including computerized analysis.

PSYC 613.title: Signal and Systems Analysis in Behavioural Research
PSYC 613.description: Application of signal and systems analysis to behavioural neuroscience and psychophysics.
PSYC 613.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Restricted to Psychology or Clinical Psychology students only, and Computational Neuroscience students by permission.

PSYC 615.title: Analysis of Variance
PSYC 615.description: Applications of the general linear model to research design and analysis. Topics include analysis of variance, regression, and analysis of covariance.
PSYC 615.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Restricted to Psychology or Clinical Psychology students only, and Computational Neuroscience students by permission.

PSYC 617.title: Multivariate Data Analysis
PSYC 617.description: Multivariate techniques and design issues, including canonical correlation, discriminant analysis, multivariate analysis of variance, multivariate regression, principal components analysis and factor analysis.
PSYC 617.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Restricted to Psychology or Clinical Psychology students only, and Computational Neuroscience students by permission.

PSYC 619.title: Special Topics in the Design of Psychological Research
PSYC 619.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

PSYC 620.title: Advanced Topics in Brain and Cognitive Sciences
PSYC 620.description: An advanced survey of some of the fundamental issues and recent developments in the Brain and/or Cognitive Sciences. Topics will vary.
PSYC 620.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Restricted to Psychology or Clinical Psychology students only, and Computational Neuroscience students by permission.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

PSYC 623.title: Functional Neuroanatomy
PSYC 623.description: Human neuroanatomy and the development of the central nervous system. Functional relationships between brain and behaviour in a variety of domains (sensorimotor, language, memory, affective processing, social behaviour, etc).
PSYC 623.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Restricted to Psychology or Clinical Psychology students only, and Computational Neuroscience students by permission.

PSYC 625.title: Clinical Neuropsychology
PSYC 625.description: Examination of brain disorders across the lifespan. Epidemiology, etiology and pathogenesis, phenotypic expression, and assessment and treatment of these disorders will be considered.
PSYC 625.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Restricted to Psychology or Clinical Psychology students only, and Computational Neuroscience students by permission.

PSYC 627.title: Neuropsychological Testing
PSYC 627.description: The clinical assessment of neuropsychological functioning in children and adults using a hypothesis-testing model. Fundamentals of administration, scoring, and interpretation of core tests used in neuropsychological assessment.
PSYC 627.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Clinical Psychology graduate program.

PSYC 630.title: Advanced Topics in Social and Theoretical Psychology
PSYC 630.description: An advanced survey of some of the fundamental issues and recent developments in Social and/or Theoretical Psychology. Topics will vary.
PSYC 630.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

PSYC 639.title: Adv Industrial & Organize Psyc
PSYC 639.description: Application of psychological principles, research and methods relating to human interactions and performance in work settings.
PSYC 639.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 637 or consent of the Department.

PSYC 651.title: Development and Psychopathology
PSYC 651.description: Current theory, issues, and research regarding the epidemiology, etiology, diagnosis, and prognosis of psychopathology in children, adolescents and adults. Implications for assessment and treatment.

PSYC 652.title: Clinical Research Seminar I
PSYC 652.description: Provides foundational knowledge and practical skills essential for conducting clinical research.
PSYC 652.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Clinical Psychology graduate program. 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

PSYC 654.description: Provides foundational knowledge and practical skills essential for conducting clinical research.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

PSYC 659.title: Ethics and Professional Issues
PSYC 659.description: Ethical and legal standards for clinical psychologists. An introduction to professional issues in contemporary clinical practice.

PSYC 671.title: Adult Assessment
PSYC 671.description: Theory, administration and interpretation of assessment procedures for adults including interviews, behavioural assessments, and selected intellectual and personality tests. Supervised experience in conducting assessments in a relevant clinical setting.
PSYC 671.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Clinical Psychology graduate program.

PSYC 673.title: Child Assessment
PSYC 673.description: Theoretical, professional and ethical issues in the psychopathology and psychological assessment of child clinical populations. Instruction and supervised practical experience in the administration and interpretation of child assessment procedures.
PSYC 673.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Clinical Psychology graduate program.

PSYC 685.title: Adult Psychotherapy
PSYC 685.description: Presents evidence-based psychological interventions. Includes specific competencies related to adult treatment modalities. The laboratory component includes supervised exposure to the practice of psychological interventions in a relevant clinical setting.
PSYC 685.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Clinical Psychology graduate program.

PSYC 687.title: Child Psychotherapy
PSYC 687.description: Presents evidence-based psychological interventions. Includes specific competencies related to child, adolescent, and family treatment modalities. The laboratory component includes supervised exposure to the practice of psychological interventions in a relevant clinical setting.
PSYC 687.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 685 and admission to the Clinical Psychology graduate program.

QFIN 601.title: Quantitative Foundations for Finance
QFIN 601.description:
Provides the mathematical and statistical foundations that are required to successfully complete the Master of Finance and ensure that students are equipped to take full advantage of the subsequent courses in the program. 

Prerequisites: Admission to the Master of Finance program.

QFIN 602.title: Financial Economics
QFIN 602.description: Exploration of the theoretical foundations of finance. Topics include the neoclassical theory of decision making under uncertainty, the role of time and uncertainty in investment decisions, contingent pricing and the arbitrage principle, portfolio selection and equilibrium asset pricing, and the role of incentives and information frictions in price formation and resource allocation.
QFIN 602.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Finance program.

QFIN 603.title: Financial Accounting
QFIN 603.description: Provides students with an understanding of accounting principles and practices used in the preparation of financial information. Additionally, students will develop a critical approach to analyzing and interpreting financial information.
QFIN 603.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Finance program.

QFIN 604.title: Institutions, Regulation and Ethics for Finance
QFIN 604.description: Provides a broad understanding of the regulatory and institutional framework that underpins the corporate sector and the financial and commodities markets. Students will also be exposed to the ethical and social issues that underlie financial decision-making.
QFIN 604.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Finance program.

QFIN 605.title: Corporate Finance
QFIN 605.description: Examination of investment and financial decisions at the firm level. The course will revolve around core topics such as capital budgeting, valuation, capital structure, and payout policy. The course will pay particular attention to the role of incentives and informational issues in these financial policies.
QFIN 605.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Quantitative Finance 602 and admission to the Master of Finance program.

QFIN 606.title: Financial Investments
QFIN 606.description: Examination of the features of financial securities and of their trade, including the role and investment strategies of various players in financial markets. Students will also be advised on asset allocation decisions and the pricing of risk.
QFIN 606.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Quantitative Finance 602 and admission to the Master of Finance program.

QFIN 607.title: Derivative Securities
QFIN 607.description: Exploration of the distinguishing features and pricing of core financial derivatives (options, futures, and forwards). The course will develop a deep understanding of contingent payoffs, strategies for hedging and speculation with financial derivatives, and pricing of derivatives using binomial trees and the Black-Scholes model.
QFIN 607.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Quantitative Finance 602 and admission to the Master of Finance program.

QFIN 608.title: Financial Econometrics
QFIN 608.description: Focus on the econometric techniques used in empirical finance and quantitative investing. Topics include properties of asset returns, estimation and inference of linear and multivariate time series models, and the estimation and inference of heteroscedastic volatility models. Emphasis on computer-based programming applications.
QFIN 608.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Quantitative Finance 606 and admission to the Master of Finance program.

QFIN 609.title: Quantitative Investing
QFIN 609.description: Explore modern research in asset pricing. Topics include anomalies in the cross section of asset returns such as the value premium and momentum, and in the time series of assets returns such as the equity risk premium puzzle. The course will also extend students' skill set to include asset pricing tests and back testing of new strategies. Emphasis on computer-based programming applications.
QFIN 609.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Quantitative Finance 606 and admission to Master of Finance program.

QFIN 610.title: Financial Modeling, Valuation and Real Options
QFIN 610.description: Overview of methods for utilizing financial data and applying valuation techniques to make strategic and financial decisions. The course draws on the real options framework to examine the value of flexibility and the trade-offs between flexibility and commitment in corporate decision making. The course will make extensive use of the tools built into Excel and VBA.
QFIN 610.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Quantitative Finance 605 and admission to the Master of Finance program.

QFIN 611.title: Mergers, Acquisitions and Restructuring
QFIN 611.description: Overview of the process and value implications arising from change of control transactions (e.g., mergers and acquisitions) and corporate restructuring activities (e.g., divestitures and bankruptcy). The course examines motivations for these transactions, valuation and financial aspects of deal structuring, and the role of institutional investors and advisors.
QFIN 611.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Quantitative Finance 605 and admission to the Master of Finance program.

QFIN 612.title: Decentralized Finance
QFIN 612.description: Introduction to the functionality of blockchain and smart contract technology and familiarize students with the workings of basic decentralized finance protocols such as exchanges and lending. Students will measure profitability of smart contract platforms, learn about tokennomics, identify the optimal design of token based decentralized platforms, and learn how fintech platforms compete with traditional financial institutions.
QFIN 612.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Quantitative Finance 605, 606 and admission to the Master of Finance program.

QFIN 613.title: Technology of Financial Innovation
QFIN 613.description:
Explore key technologies behind recent innovations in fintech such as cryptography, consensus algorithms, smart contracts, and blockchain bridges. Students will learn to code and analyze blockchain data with a specific focus on decentralized finance applications. 

Prerequisites: Quantitative Finance 605, 606 and admission to the Master of Finance program.

QFIN 614.title: Entrepreneurial Finance
QFIN 614.description:
Understand financial theory and principles and apply them to the analysis, valuation, and financing of new ventures. Topics include the tools to evaluate early-stage business opportunities, highlight the main ways that new ventures are financed, and examine the structure of venture capital funds and exit options for early-stage investors (IPOs, acquisitions, secondary sales, buybacks, write-offs). 

Prerequisites: Admission to the Master of Finance program.

QFIN 615.title: Economics of Financial Technology
QFIN 615.description:
Examination of the broader implications of fintech for the future of finance. Students learn about blockchain technology, the main decentralized finance platforms, peer-to-peer lending, payments, and Central Bank Digital Currency. 

Prerequisites: Admission to the Master of Finance program.

QFIN 621.title: Professional Development I
QFIN 621.description: Develop the fundamentals required to understand the job market, identify career paths, develop and refine their personal brand, build their business acumen, and practice professional written communication skills.
QFIN 621.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Finance program. 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

QFIN 622.title: Professional Development II
QFIN 622.description: Master the fundamentals required to navigate career paths, practice professional individual and group presentation skills, and work in teams. Build networks through opportunities to meet with industry and practice interviewing.
QFIN 622.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Finance program. 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

QUAC 601.title: Essentials of Quantum Computing
QUAC 601.description: Pure quantum states; unitary maps; projective measurements; quantum algorithms; quantum circuits; quantum resources; quantum complexity.
QUAC 601.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Quantum Computing or the Master of Quantum Computing.

QUAC 603.title: Quantum Software I
QUAC 603.description: Quantum software stack; learning current quantum and hybrid software platforms; comparing with non-quantum software.
QUAC 603.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Quantum Computing or the Master of Quantum Computing.

QUAC 605.title: Applications of Quantum Computing
QUAC 605.description: Combinatorial optimization; linear equation solvers; factorization; searches; simulation; chemistry; and machine learning.
QUAC 605.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Quantum Computing or the Master of Quantum Computing.

QUAC 607.title: Business of Quantum Computing I
QUAC 607.description: The fundamentals of how quantum computing is used in industry. Topics covered include: trends in adoption of quantum computing and how it could affect organizations and external stakeholders; future uses cases; and the structure and economics of platforms for quantum computing. Students will create a project proposal for a specific use case.
QUAC 607.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Quantum Computing or the Master of Quantum Computing.

QUAC 609.title: Quantum Software II
QUAC 609.description: Applying current quantum software and assessing utility for solving industry problems.
QUAC 609.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Quantum Computing 601, 603, 605 and 607, and admission to the Graduate Diploma in Quantum Computing or the Master of Quantum Computing.

QUAC 611.title: Quantum Hardware
QUAC 611.description: Principles of building quantum computers; universal quantum computers; quantum annealers; current commercial quantum computers; roadmap for development of quantum computers.
QUAC 611.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Quantum Computing 601, 603, 605 and 607, and admission to the Graduate Diploma in Quantum Computing or the Master of Quantum Computing.

QUAC 613.title: Practical Quantum Computing
QUAC 613.description: Noise; decoherence; loss; imperfect measurement; error mitigation; error correction; fault-tolerance; gate benchmarking.
QUAC 613.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Quantum Computing 601, 603, 605 and 607, and admission to the Graduate Diploma in Quantum Computing or the Master of Quantum Computing.

QUAC 615.title: Business of Quantum Computing II
QUAC 615.description: Quantum computing start-ups including: business ventures; principles of entrepreneurship and technology commercialization; and principles of business technology management in existing organizations.
QUAC 615.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Quantum Computing 601, 603, 605 and 607, and admission to the Graduate Diploma in Quantum Computing or the Master of Quantum Computing.

QUAC 692.title: Emerging Trends in Quantum Computing
QUAC 692.description: Modules exploring applied quantum computing and deep tech through case studies of promising platforms, major investments, and barriers to adoption.
QUAC 692.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Quantum Computing program and completion of 24 units of 600-level Quantum Computing courses.

Also known as: (formerly Quantum Computing 691)

QUAC 693.title: Professional Internship in Quantum Computing I
QUAC 693.description: Professional internship in the area of quantum computing in industry.
QUAC 693.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Quantum Computing program, completion of 24 units of 600-level Quantum Computing courses and consent of the Department.

QUAC 694.title: Professional Internship in Quantum Computing II
QUAC 694.description: Professional internship in the area of quantum computing in industry.
QUAC 694.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Quantum Computing 691 and 693, and consent of the Department.

QUAC 695.title: Research Internship in Quantum Computing I
QUAC 695.description: Research internship in the area of quantum computing in an academic research group.
QUAC 695.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Quantum Computing program, completion of 24 units of 600-level Quantum Computing courses and consent of the Department.

QUAC 696.title: Research Internship in Quantum Computing II
QUAC 696.description: Research internship in the area of quantum computing in an academic research group.
QUAC 696.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Quantum Computing 691 and 695 and consent of the Department.

REAL 317.title: Real Estate Development & Urbanization
REAL 317.description: Overview of the real estate industry value chain, from raw land and built form through asset management. Addresses different sectors and business models, environmental, political, social and technology considerations and trends.
REAL 317.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 30 units.

REAL 359.title: Selected Topics in Real Estate Studies
REAL 359.description: Examination of selected topics in Real Estate Studies.
REAL 359.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 24 units. For certain topics, consent of the Haskayne School of Business will also be required.

REAL 427.title: Real Estate Investment & Analysis
REAL 427.description: Introduction to the instruments, techniques, and institutions of real estate finance, sources of funds and mortgage risk analysis. Residential and commercial real estate contracting fundamentals are also covered. Examination of the risk and rewards when investing in and financing both commercial and residential real estate deals. Concepts include investment, financing, site analysis, appraisals, lending, and management of real estate portfolios and corporate real estate.
REAL 427.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 60 units including Finance 317.

REAL 437.title: Land Development & Planning
REAL 437.description: Introduction to the urban planning process and what is required to gain government approvals for land development proposals, from small-scale redevelopment projects to large-scale complete new communities. Topics will include: an overview of planning legislation; municipal processes and timelines; the risks and costs associated with planning approvals; stakeholder engagement; developing political acumen; and new trends in managing growth and achieving sustainability goals.
REAL 437.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 60 units.

REAL 447.title: Real Estate Legal and Operating Environment
REAL 447.description: Foundation of legal, regulatory and stakeholder issues affecting real estate. Topics include: real estate transactions, real estate brokerage, real property ownership interests, illegal discrimination in residential and commercial transactions, and other legal transactions involving real estate, such as sales and leases. Challenges within approvals processes based on government relations and stakeholder perceptions are also a focus.
REAL 447.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 60 units including Strategy and Global Management 395.

REAL 457.title: Real Estate Marketing
REAL 457.description: Marketing is essential to the success of any real estate development project. In this course, students review the role that marketing plays at each step in the development process, gain an understanding of changing real estate markets, and learn how to utilize market research information, develop and manage a marketing program, create unique project identities, and undertake an effective advertising and communications program.
REAL 457.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 60 units including Marketing 317.

REAL 559.title: Selected Topics in Real Estate Studies
REAL 559.description: Investigation of selected topics in Real Estate Studies.
REAL 559.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 54 units including Real Estate Studies 317. For certain topics, consent of the Haskayne School of Business will also be required.

REAL 567.title: Project-Based Capstone
REAL 567.description: Application of classroom learnings to a project relevant to the real estate industry. Sectors may include: commercial developers, brokerage firms, residential developers (greenfield and infill), municipal government and consulting firms.
REAL 567.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Bachelor of Commerce Real Estate Studies concentration, Real Estate Studies 317 and 427.

REAL 607.title: Fundamentals of Real Estate
REAL 607.description: Overview of the real estate industry value chain, from raw land and built form through asset management. Addresses different sectors and business models, environmental, political, social and technology considerations and trends.
REAL 607.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Business Administration program.

REAL 627.title: Real Estate Investment and Analysis
REAL 627.description: Structure and operations of the Canadian mortgage and asset-backed securities markets. Topics include instruments, techniques, and institutions of real estate finance, sources of funds, mortgage risk analysis, and fundamentals of residential and commercial real estate contracting. Examination of the risks and rewards when investing in and financing both commercial and residential real estate deals. Concepts include investment, financing, site analysis, appraisals, lending, and management of real estate portfolios and corporate real estate.
REAL 627.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Business Administration program and Finance 601.

REAL 637.title: Land Development and Planning
REAL 637.description: Introduction to urban planning. Topics will include planning legislation, municipal processes and timelines, the risks and costs associated with planning approvals, stakeholder engagement, developing political acumen, and new trends in managing growth and achieving sustainability goals.
REAL 637.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Business Administration program.

REAL 647.title: Legal and Operating Environment
REAL 647.description: Foundation of legal, regulatory and stakeholder issues affecting real estate. Topics will include real estate transactions, real estate brokerage, real property ownership interests, illegal discrimination in residential and commercial transactions, and other legal transactions involving real estate, such as sales and leases. Governance models, legislation, policies and by-laws in relation to the business of real estate and land development.
REAL 647.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Business Administration program.

Also known as: (formerly Real Estate Studies 737)

REAL 657.title: Real Estate Marketing
REAL 657.description: Coverage includes real estate marketing programs based on theoretical principles, an understanding of changing real estate markets, marketing methods, research approaches and marketing program development.
REAL 657.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Marketing 601 and admission to the Master of Business Administration program.

Also known as: (formerly Real Estate Studies 747)

REAL 667.title: Real Estate Advanced Capstone
REAL 667.description: Preparation of a comprehensive development proposal or project in the real estate industry. Includes market and financial analyses, development planning and design, presentations, and contact with key industry sources.
REAL 667.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Business Administration program and Real Estate Studies 607 or 707.

REAL 668.title: Selected Topics in Real Estate Studies
REAL 668.description: Investigation of selected topics in Real Estate Studies.
REAL 668.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Business Administration program and Real Estate Studies 607 or 707.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

RELS 200.title: Religious Myths & Worldviews
RELS 200.description: Readings (in English translation) from the classical literatures of middle Eastern and Asian religions.  Introduction to the evolving mythological traditions from three geo-cultural centres (the middle East, India, and China) by examining religious themes:  cosmology; existential values and goals; destinies of humans, the world, and the cosmos.

RELS 201.title: Jews, Christians and Muslims
RELS 201.description: Introduction to Judaism, Christianity and Islam.

RELS 203.title: Asian Religions
RELS 203.description: Introduction to Eastern religions such as Jainism, Hinduism, Sikhism, Buddhism, Confucianism and Taoism.

RELS 205.title: Religion and the Good Life
RELS 205.description:
An introduction to the academic study of religion with particular emphasis on the nature of religion, its role as a response to existential questions, and the relationship of religion to contemporary thought and culture.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for both Religious Studies 205 and 350 will not be allowed.

RELS 300.title: Classical Hebrew I
RELS 300.description:
Classical or Biblical Hebrew language; the development of ability in the critical reading of ancient texts. No attempt will be made to provide any competence in medieval or modern Hebrew.

Also known as: (formerly Religious Studies 207)

RELS 301.title: Studies In Hebrew Bible/Old Testament
RELS 301.description: An introduction to the critical study and reading of the books of the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament in English translation. The course focuses on the Bible as religious literature.

RELS 302.title: Classical Hebrew II
RELS 302.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Religious Studies 300.

Also known as: (formerly Religious Studies 209)

RELS 303.title: Hindu Traditions
RELS 303.description: A historical survey of Hindu traditions from the ancient religion of the Vedas through 19th century devotional movements through Hindu literature in English translation.

RELS 305.title: (GRST 305)Greek Religion
RELS 305.description:
A survey of religious beliefs and practices in the pre-Christian Greek World.

Also known as: (Greek and Roman Studies 305)

RELS 307.title: Popular Hinduism
RELS 307.description: An introductory survey of the contemporary practices of Hinduism in South Asia and in diaspora Hindu communities throughout the world. Focus on recent ethnographic research and the diversity of popular Hindu practices with special attention to differences defined by region, language, caste, and gender. Topics may include the structure of social and family life, the organization of sacred space and time, ritual practices, and the influence and impact of modernity in Hindu life.

RELS 309.title: Religious Experience
RELS 309.description: A study of philosophical and psychological theories of the nature and function of religious experiences and an introduction to a variety of religious experiences, which may include theophany, mysticism, enlightenment, conversion, and guilt.

RELS 310.title: Sanskrit I
RELS 310.description:
Classical Sanskrit language; the development of ability in the critical reading of ancient Hindu or Buddhist texts.

Also known as: (formerly Religious Studies 211)

RELS 312.title: Sanskrit II
RELS 312.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Religious Studies 310 or consent of the Department.

Also known as: (formerly Religious Studies 213)

RELS 313.title: Introduction to Buddhism
RELS 313.description: Buddhist developments from the time of Buddha to the development of Mahayana.

RELS 314.title: Tibetan I
RELS 314.description:
Classical Tibetan language; the development of ability in the critical reading of ancient Bon and Buddhist texts.

Also known as: (formerly Religious Studies 215)

RELS 316.title: Tibetan II
RELS 316.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Religious Studies 314 or consent of the Department.

Also known as: (formerly Religious Studies 217)

RELS 320.title: Classical Chinese for Religious Texts I
RELS 320.description:
Introduction to Classical Chinese language, with emphasis on developing the ability to read ancient Chinese religious texts.

Also known as: (formerly Religious Studies 219)

RELS 322.title: Classical Chinese for Religious Texts II
RELS 322.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Religious Studies 320 or consent of the Department.

Also known as: (formerly Religious Studies 221)

RELS 323.title: Mahayana Buddhism
RELS 323.description: Mahayana developments in India, China, Tibet or Japan.

RELS 327.title: Tibetan Religious Traditions
RELS 327.description: The religious developments in Tibet, with emphasis on religious history, literature and philosophy and their contemporary implications.

RELS 329.title: Buddhism In East Asia
RELS 329.description: The history, doctrines, literature and leading figures of Buddhism in China and Japan.

RELS 333.title: Rels Perspect Death & Afterlife
RELS 333.description: An examination of various religious perspectives on the nature of death and life after death.

RELS 335.title: Ritual and Religion
RELS 335.description: A major form of religious expression is the various practices and rituals performed by individuals and the community.  Various ritual theories and approaches will be examined along with different examples of religious ritual expressions.

RELS 338.title: Atheism
RELS 338.description: A consideration of various historical and thematic critiques of religion, including the development of modern agnosticism, atheism and in recent times, the 'new atheism'.

RELS 339.title: Transformations of Religion in Africa
RELS 339.description: Nature of religion through a study of religious transformations in Africa.

RELS 340.title: Religion, Truth, Pluralism
RELS 340.description: Examinations of issues arising out of communication across boundaries of belief, practice, and value-systems. Topics may include theories of \"Truth\", inter-religious dialogue, identity politics, intersectionality, and pluralism.

RELS 341.title: New Religious Movements
RELS 341.description: An examination of the beliefs, practices and developments of new religious movements of both Eastern and Western origins (e.g. Krishna Consciousness, Transcendental Meditation, Unification Church, Children of God, etc.).

RELS 342.title: Sisters, Saints & Sinners
RELS 342.description:
Challenges assumptions and misconceptions about premodern women through an examination of female contributions to religious culture (e.g., Hildegard of Bingen) in medieval Christianity. 

Antirequisite: Credit for Religious studies 342 and 373.15 (Sisters, Saints and Sinners) will not be allowed.

RELS 343.title: Religion and Social Morality
RELS 343.description: Critical examination of social theories of religion and religious perspectives on ethical issues of social, economic, and political consequence in contemporary cultures.

RELS 344.title: The Bible as Literature
RELS 344.description: An exploration of the various literary genres that make up the sixty-six books of the Bible, understood as a compilation of human literature reflecting millennia of communal struggle, vision, and engaged reception.

RELS 349.title: Religion and Politics
RELS 349.description: A study of the complex relationship between religion and politics, including nationalism and political religions. Topics may include the origin of apartheid in South Africa, Black Theology, the rise of the New Christian Right in America, Hindu and Islamic political movements, and various forms of Fascism including the Nazi movement.

RELS 356.title: Introduction to Sikh Tradition
RELS 356.description:
Introduction to the central texts, ideas, practices, and history of the Sikh tradition.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Religious Studies 356 and 373.12 (Introduction to Sikhism) will not be allowed.

RELS 357.title: Islam
RELS 357.description: A survey of the basic religious ideas, texts, figures, and practices in Islam, including their historical development.

RELS 359.title: East Asian Religious Traditions
RELS 359.description: The history, doctrines and literature of the major religious traditions of China, Korea and Japan.

RELS 360.title: Buddhist Practice Traditions
RELS 360.description: An introduction to different kinds of meditation practices in Buddhist traditions, through their historical trajectories and their related devotional and ritual aspects. The material is organized according to principal contemporary areas (Vipassana, Chan/Zen/Son, Pure Land, Tibetan).

RELS 369.title: Introduction To Judaism
RELS 369.description: An introduction to the major practices, beliefs, institutions and religious literature of the Jewish religion, as developed from antiquity to modern times.

RELS 370.title: Gods, Demons, and Monsters
RELS 370.description:
A comparative and theoretical examination of the concepts/roles of god, divinities, monsters, demons and other supernatural objects of belief, devotion and fear.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Religious Studies 370 and either 345 or 346 will not be allowed.

RELS 373.title: Topics in Religious Studies
RELS 373.description: Topics may include an overview of a specific religious tradition, an examination of religious expressions in a particular context, a thematic study of a religion or religions, or a methodological approach to the study of religion.

RELS 377.title: Research and Critical Inquiry in Religious Studies
RELS 377.description: Systematic instruction in research methods, academic writing, and the practice of critical analysis in the field of Religious Studies. Besides practical instruction, students will be introduced to a variety of methods and theories used in the academic study of religion.
RELS 377.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to Religious Studies major or minor.

RELS 381.title: Gender, Sex and Religion
RELS 381.description:
An examination of the complex interrelationship between understandings and constructions of gender, sexuality and Religion as they arise in the context of several religious traditions.

Antirequisite(s): Not open to students with previous credit for Religious Studies 373.09.

RELS 383.title: From Jesus toChrist
RELS 383.description: Thestudyof formative Christianityup to 200 CEin its political, social and religious contexts.

RELS 385.title: PagansandChristians
RELS 385.description: Examination ofthe evolution ofancient 'pagan' (Greek and Roman non-Christian) andearly Christianreligions from 200-800 CE, exploring their similarities, differences, andinteractions, and situating them in their social, economic, cultural,andpoliticalcontext.

RELS 387.title: Christian Monks, Mystics and Reformers
RELS 387.description: An overview of medievalChristian monasticism andmysticism, including female mystics such as Margery Kempe and Julian of Norwich, as well as humanists such as Erasmus, and early modern ProtestantandCatholic Reformers.

RELS 397.title: Religion And Science
RELS 397.description: The relationship between religion and science with emphasis on contemporary discussions regarding the intersection of religious thought and theories in the natural sciences.

RELS 398.title: Religion and the Environment
RELS 398.description: Consideration of issues of public environmental concern from the perspectives of religious studies and ethics. Possible topics include climate change, water depletion, environmental pollution, animal stresses, species/ecosystem decimation, and the climate refugee problem.

RELS 399.title: Religion in Popular Culture
RELS 399.description:
The intersection of religion with popular culture is explored through specific topics.

Notes: May be counted only once towards the major field requirements in Religious Studies.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

RELS 417.title: Topics: Recent Religious Thought
RELS 417.description:
Detailed examination of a selected writer, topic, or intellectual current in recent religious thought.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

RELS 418.title: Esoteric Buddhism
RELS 418.description:
The development of Vajrayana, Tantric and other esoteric traditions of Buddhism in India, Tibet, China, Japan and in the West from medieval times to the present. 

Also known as (formerly Religious Studies 319).

RELS 424.title: Zen Buddhism
RELS 424.description:
An exploration of the thought and practice of Chan (Chinese) and Zen (Japanese) Buddhism, including twentieth-century developments in the west. 

Also known as: (formerly Religious Studies 324).

RELS 425.title: Buddhism and Psychology
RELS 425.description:
Buddhist contemplative techniques examined in therapeutic contexts, including mindfulness, applied phenomenology, spiritual practice, and cognitive science. May include topical issues such as gender and identity formation, therapeutic psychedelics, and artificial intelligence.

Also known as (formerly Religious Studies 525)

RELS 440.title: Religion and Economic Systems
RELS 440.description: A consideration of the relationship between religious practices and systems of exchange, credit, and economic rationalization. Historical documents will be used to illustrate the complex nature of religion and economics.

RELS 444.title: Existentialism
RELS 444.description: An examination of existentialist thinkers from the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, contextualizing their work within both modernity and theist/atheist discourses.

RELS 445.title: Advanced Studies in Asian Thought
RELS 445.description: A critical examination of Asian philosophical and religious thinkers.

RELS 447.title: Theories Of Religion
RELS 447.description: A critical examination of various theories used in the academic study of religion.

RELS 451.title: Advanced Topics in Hinduism
RELS 451.description:
In-depth study of the historical developments of Hinduism (Vedic, Classical, Medieval, Modern) in a seminar or independent study format.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

RELS 453.title: Advanced Topics in Buddhism
RELS 453.description:
A seminar course that focuses on selected traditions, or philosophical or historical themes, such as Madhyamaka, Yogacara, T'ien T'ai, Hua Yen, Zen, Pure Land, Nyingma, Kargyud, Abhidharma, Tathagatagarbha, and Dhyana.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

RELS 456.title: Sikh Diaspora and Migration
RELS 456.description:
The religious history and developments of Sikhism based on colonial and post-colonial global Sikh migration patterns.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Religious Studies 456 and 417.08 (Sikh Diaspora) will not be allowed.

RELS 469.title: Advanced Topics in Judaism
RELS 469.description:
Selected topics in Jewish practices, institutions, beliefs and religious literature. Possible topics include: Jewish Movements of the Second Temple Era; Jewish Rituals and Observances; Midrash and Jewish Biblical Interpretation; Law and Religion in Judaism; Jewish Philosophy and Theology; Judaism in the Modern World; Kabbalah and Jewish Mysticism.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

RELS 473.title: Advanced Topics in Islam
RELS 473.description:
Thematic considerations of topics, such as Islamic philosophy, mysticism, theology, or contemporary trends, based on primary sources. Although no knowledge of Arabic is required, students with backgrounds in Arabic will have the option of working with texts in their original languages.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

RELS 474.title: Advanced Topics in Religious Studies
RELS 474.description:
Topics may include an overview of a specific religious tradition, an examination of religious expressions in a particular context, a thematic study of a religion or religions, or a methodological approach to the study of religion.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

RELS 479.title: Contemporary Issues in Women and Religion
RELS 479.description: A topical examination of developments in current research in such areas as: gender theory, post-colonialism, philosophy and religion, feminist theology, feminist evaluation of traditional religious structures, or interdisciplinary work in the reconstruction of women's religiosity.

RELS 484.title: Advanced Topics in Christianity
RELS 484.description:
A seminar course examining topics, personalities and movements in Christianity from its origins to its modern and contemporary developments.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

RELS 494.title: Secularism and Religious Diversity
RELS 494.description: Examinations of current theories, issues and discourses of religious pluralism, multiculturalism, and secularism, including the role of religion in the public square, identity and intersectionality, and diversity issues in contemporary social life.

RELS 496.title: Hindu Mythology
RELS 496.description:
Examines the three major literary sources of Hindu mythology: the Vedas, Epics, and Puranas, covering both the historical evolution and critical analysis of this literature.

Antirequisite: Credit for Religious Studies 496 and 373.13 (Hindu Mythology) will not be allowed.

RELS 497.title: Sacred Places of India
RELS 497.description:
Explores the religious geography of the Indian subcontinent and the pilgrimage traditions and ritual practices associated with religious sites.

Antirequisite: Credit for Religious Studies 497 and 373.05 (Sacred Places of India) will not be allowed.

RELS 537.title: Hermeneutics
RELS 537.description: Significance of the hermeneutical tradition for an understanding of religious issues and traditions with attention to the thought of Schleiermacher, Dilthey, Husserl, Heidegger, Gadamer, and Ricoeur among others.
RELS 537.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units of courses labelled Religious Studies at the 300 level. 

Also knowns as: (formerly Religious Studies 437)

RELS 577.title: Religion Lab
RELS 577.description: Experience-based learning project, under the guidance of a faculty supervisor and graduate student mentors, in partnership with community partners, focusing on complex social and other problems.
RELS 577.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Religious Studies 377 and 6 units of courses labelled Religious Studies at the 400 or 500 level and admission to the Religious Studies major or minor.

RELS 590.title: Honours Thesis
RELS 590.description: Students compose a major research paper under the close supervision of a member of the Department and defend the thesis before an examining committee.
RELS 590.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Religious Studies 377 and 6 units of courses labelled Religious Studies at the 400 or 500 level and admission to the Honours program in Religious Studies or Ancient and Medieval History.

RELS 591.title: Topics: Reading Religious Texts in Primary Languages
RELS 591.description: Independent or small group study of religious texts in original languages such as Hebrew, Sanskrit, Tibetan, Chinese or Japanese.
RELS 591.prerequisitesText:

RMIN 317.title: Introduction to Risk Management and Insurance
RMIN 317.description: An overview of how organizations assess and manage risks using tools such as loss control, hedging, insurance and employee benefits.
RMIN 317.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business or the Actuarial Science program, and 30 units including Economics 201.

RMIN 439.title: Protecting Your Family and Wealth
RMIN 439.description: The use of life and health insurance, wills, estate planning, and other tools for securing financial futures.  Examination of family security, business value, wealth transfer, succession planning, income protection, and tax considerations.
RMIN 439.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business or the Actuarial Science program and Finance 317 or Risk Management and Insurance 317.

RMIN 449.title: Employee Benefits & Social Insurance
RMIN 449.description: Examination of employee benefits as a major component of compensation packages, including pensions and other retirement programs, group life, and group health insurance. Overview of social insurance programs including workers' compensation and unemployment insurance.
RMIN 449.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business or the Actuarial Science program and Finance 317 or Risk Management and Insurance 317.

RMIN 459.title: Managing Commercial Property and Liability Risks
RMIN 459.description: Examines risk management for commercial property and liability exposures. The first half of the course focuses on common property loss exposures that firms face and examines methods of handling such risks. The second half focuses on liability exposures of commercial enterprises, including premises and operations liability, product liability, employment practices liability and director's and officers' liability.
RMIN 459.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the Haskayne School of Business or the Actuarial Science program.

RMIN 559.title: Selected Topics in Risk Management and Insurance
RMIN 559.description: Combines a fundamental understanding of insurance and risk management with current issues confronting the insurance industry and risk managers.
RMIN 559.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Risk Management and Insurance 317. For certain topics, consent of the Haskayne School of Business will also be required.

RMIN 579.title: Advanced Topics in Risk Management and Insurance
RMIN 579.description: Study of the various methods used to finance the hazard and operational risks of commercial enterprises. Key topics addressed include: alternative risk financing, reinsurance, and environmental risk management.
RMIN 579.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Risk Management and Insurance 317.

RMIN 663.title: Managing Risks and Disasters
RMIN 663.description: Risk management strategies with emphasis on the management of operational and hazard risks. Topics include risk identification and assessment; organizational responsibility for risk management; risk mitigation; risk financing; crisis management, and business continuity planning.
RMIN 663.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

Also known as: (formerly Finance 763)

ROST 299.title: Romance Culture
ROST 299.description: Study of Mediterranean cultures: France, Italy and Spain.

ROST 341.title: Ital Literature Of Renaissance
ROST 341.description:
Major authors of the Italian Renaissance whose works have influenced artists and writers in England, France and Spain.

Note: This course is given in English and no knowledge of Italian is required.

ROST 399.title: Topics in Romance Languages
ROST 399.description:
Topics in Romance Languages, Literatures and Cultures.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ROST 499.title: Advanced Topics in Language and Culture
ROST 499.description: Discussion of selected topics dealing with Romance languages, literatures and cultures.
ROST 499.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units from French 227, Italian 303 or Spanish 303.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

RUSS 201.title: Introductory Russian I
RUSS 201.description:
Introduction to Russian in its cultural context. Four-skills language learning (reading, listening, speaking, writing) covering the principal elements of modern Russian. Focuses on Russian pronunciation and intonation, the Cyrillic alphabet, the foundations of Russian grammar, as well as basic vocabulary.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Russian 201 and Russian 30 will not be allowed.

Notes: Students must complete an online placement form before classes begin. For information: https://arts.ucalgary.ca/languages-linguistics-literatures-cultures/language-placement.

RUSS 209.title: Introductory Russian II
RUSS 209.description: A further introduction to the basics of the Russian language, including its differences from and similarities to English, within the cultural and historical context. Structured according to various aspects of everyday life, such as family, university, professions, etc.

RUSS 301.title: Continuing Russian I
RUSS 301.description: Furthers acquisition of the basic level of the language, enabling function in a variety of everyday situations by building comprehensive knowledge of grammar, expanding active vocabulary, and providing cultural information.

RUSS 303.title: Continuing Russian II
RUSS 303.description: Further strengthens knowledge of the basics of the language enabling advancement to a more advanced stage of language mastery.

RUSS 309.title: Russian Urban Culture in Immersion Setting
RUSS 309.description: Introduction to contemporary urban Russian culture through research projects and life experience.

RUSS 311.title: Russian Rural Culture in Immersion Setting
RUSS 311.description:
Introduction to contemporary rural Russian culture through research projects and life experience.

Corequisite(s): Russian 309 and 313.

Notes: This course is offered during a group study program in Russia. A supplementary fee will be assessed to cover additional costs associated with this course.

RUSS 313.title: Russian Language in Immersion Setting
RUSS 313.description:
Further development of oral skills and writing proficiency.

Corequisite(s): Russian 309 and 311.

Notes: This course is offered during a group study program in Russia. A supplementary fee will be assessed to cover additional costs associated with this course.

RUSS 317.title: Topics in Russian Civilization and Thought
RUSS 317.description:
Distinctive features in the development of Russian civilization and thought.

Notes: Taught in English. May be repeated for a maximum credit of 6 units (1.0 full-course equivalent).

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

RUSS 332.title: The Russian Verbal System
RUSS 332.description: A systematic survey of the Russian verbal system leading to the development of a structural understanding of the Russian language.

RUSS 334.title: The Russian Nominal System
RUSS 334.description: A systematic survey of the Russian nominal system leading to the development of a structural understanding of the Russian language.

RUSS 355.title: Topics in Russian Literature in Translation
RUSS 355.description:
Selected texts by author, genre or period designed to explore issues of significance in the context of Russian culture.

Notes: Taught in English. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units.

RUSS 397.title: Inter-Cultural Immersion Experience I
RUSS 397.description: Independent study course. Project with inter-cultural theme, derived from an immersion experience, most likely abroad.
RUSS 397.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

RUSS 400.title: Topics in Advanced Russian
RUSS 400.description: Provides diverse contexts and relies on various media and techniques to generate active and sophisticated usage of the language. Equips students with skills and strategies for independent language learning.
RUSS 400.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Russian 332 or 334.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

RUSS 461.title: Topics in Russian Literature
RUSS 461.description: Introduces and examines selected literary texts by author, genre, movement or period with attention to issues of particular significance in Russian literary culture. Exposure to various critical approaches and literary works.
RUSS 461.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Russian 303.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

RUSS 463.title: Topics in Russian Language and Culture
RUSS 463.description: In-depth study, from a historical or a contemporary perspective, of selected linguistic and cultural issues aiming to develop students' critical thinking and cultural understanding as well as their analytical and interpretive skills.
RUSS 463.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Russian 303.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

RUSS 497.title: Inter-Cultural Immersion Experience II
RUSS 497.description: Independent study course. Project with inter-cultural theme, derived from an immersion experience at an advanced level, most likely abroad.
RUSS 497.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Russian 397 and consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

RUSS 551.title: Independent Study
RUSS 551.description: An independent research project on a topic that is not normally a part of the program's course offerings.
RUSS 551.prerequisitesText:

RUSS 591.title: Honours Project
RUSS 591.description: A research paper or creative project for honours students in their final year on a topic chosen in consultation with their supervisor.
RUSS 591.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

SAST 203.title: Understanding South Asia
SAST 203.description:
The roots of ancient civilization; society, resources and environment; racial, ethnic and cultural diversities; philosophic and religious traditions; arts and aesthetics; historical bases of tradition and modernity; role of education in social development; ideological differences and economic development. Primary focus on India, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan and Nepal.

Also known as:  (formerly South Asian Studies 315)

SAST 303.title: Modern South Asia
SAST 303.description: Examines South Asia from the colonial era to the present. Topics may include colonialism, social issues such as gender and caste, or contemporary political movements.

SAST 531.title: Supervised Research in South Asian Studies
SAST 531.description: An interdisciplinary, inquiry-based course in which students pursue a supervised research project on a topic related to social, philosophical, economic, political and/or international issues within South Asia.
SAST 531.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from South Asian Studies 203, 303, 315 or 415 and consent of the Program Co-ordinator.

SAST 499.01.title: Methods in South Asian Studies
SAST 499.01.description: Investigation of themes and methodologies related to the study of South Asian civilizations. A single theme, multiple themes or the study and application of one or more methods employed in Asian Studies may be offered.
SAST 499.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from South Asian Studies 203, 303, 315 or 415.

SAST 499.02.title: Contemporary Issues in South Asia
SAST 499.02.description: Investigation of themes and methodologies related to the study of South Asian civilizations. A single theme, multiple themes or the study and application of one or more methods employed in Asian Studies may be offered.
SAST 499.02.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from South Asian Studies 203, 303, 315 or 415.

SAST 499.03.title: Topics in the History of South Asia
SAST 499.03.description: Investigation of themes and methodologies related to the study of South Asian civilizations. A single theme, multiple themes or the study and application of one or more methods employed in Asian Studies may be offered.
SAST 499.03.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from South Asian Studies 203, 303, 315 or 415.

SCIE 331.title: Scientific Explorations
SCIE 331.description: Students will develop a well-rounded perspective and appreciation of science by investigating the nature of scientific inquiry and critically assessing key historical and contemporary achievements in science.

Interdisciplinary projects may involve more than one Science discipline or a Science discipline combined with a non-Science discipline.

SCIE 507.title: Experiential Learning in Science - Topics
SCIE 507.description: Lectures, seminars, tutorials and/or research project leading to a focused examination of a topic from interdisciplinary perspective.

SCIE 511.title: Peer Mentoring and Collaborative Learning in Science
SCIE 511.description: Students (peer mentors) gain theoretical knowledge of peer mentoring, practical facilitation instruction and experience to support peers in their learning. Grounded knowledge of science-based learning theories, peer mentors will encourage and motivate learning, convey enthusiasm for course material, and provide support for active learning in and out of the classroom.

SCIE 529.title: Project Course in Sustainable Energy, Environment and Economy
SCIE 529.description: Intended to achieve integration across the interdisciplinary energy, environment and economy programs.
SCIE 529.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Energy and Environment, Engineering 355 and 75 units and admission to the Energy and the Environment Specialization, the Energy Management Concentration or the Energy Science Concentration.

SCIE 601.title: Theory and Practice of University Teaching and Learning in STEM
SCIE 601.description: Current educational theory and practice relating to university teaching and learning in STEM will be explored and critically evaluated. Students will critically evaluate their teaching beliefs and broaden their knowledge and skills through a combination of discussion, microteaching opportunities and a capstone project involving the design of a teaching unit.
SCIE 601.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to a MSc or PhD program in the Faculty of Science and consent of the instructor.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

SCIE 603.title: STEM Teaching Development
SCIE 603.description: Design and delivery of a unit of a course within the student's area of specialization and under the guidance of a faculty member. Course and curriculum design elements are emphasized through the production of a detailed lesson plan, strategy for assessment and evaluation of the success of the teaching unit. The importance of reflective practice and mentorship to the teaching function is stressed through reflective essays and group discussions. Experiences will be shared through a symposium poster presentation.
SCIE 603.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Science 601.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

SCIE 570.02.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 75 units, admission to a Science degree program, and consent of the Natural Sciences Program.

SCMA 451.title: Supply Chain Analytics
SCMA 451.description: Current issues confronting supply chain managers are examined. The role of supply chain management in the overall strategy and performance of companies is studied. Students analyze real-world cases and develop suitable solutions to improve supply chain operations. Topics include advanced inventory management, supply chain co-ordination, network design and risk management.
SCMA 451.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Operations Management 317 and Management Studies 391.

SCMA 453.title: Procurement Management
SCMA 453.description: An in-depth analysis of strategic procurement practices for competitive advantage, cost management, contractual negotiations and supplier management. Strategic implications of supply processes, outsourcing, and supplier relations are discussed.
SCMA 453.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Operations Management 317 and Management Studies 391.

Also known as: (formerly Operations Management 417)

SCMA 455.title: Logistics Management
SCMA 455.description: Logistics entails some of the major operations of supply chains. The objective of this course is to introduce the general concepts and analytical tools of logistics management from a supply chain perspective.
SCMA 455.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Operations Management 317 and Management Studies 391.

SCMA 461.title: Contract Negotiations in Supply Chains
SCMA 461.description: Business deal negotiation strategies, tactics, and common legal clauses for national and international supply chains. Contracting in supply chains. Establishing a short-term business relationship and a long-term partnership between companies.
SCMA 461.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Operations Management 317.

SCMA 559.title: Selected Topics in Supply Chain Management
SCMA 559.description: Investigation of selected topics in Supply Chain Management.
SCMA 559.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Operations Management 317 and Management Studies 391. For certain topics, consent of the Haskayne School of Business will also be required.

SCMA 631.title: Supply Chain Analytics
SCMA 631.description: Optimal design and management of supply chains with analytical tools. Topics include network design, inventory management, transportation, contracting, coordination and collaboration, capacity management, and customer-supplier relations.
SCMA 631.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Management Studies 613 and Operations Management 601.

SCMA 641.title: Sustainable Business Operations
SCMA 641.description: Sustainable operations and supply chain management focusing on the triple bottom line. Topics may include business models for sustainability, life-cycles of products and services, closed-loop supply chains, sustainability metrics.
SCMA 641.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Operations Management 601 and admission to an MBA program..

Also known as: (formerly Operations Management 668.01 (Sustainable Business Ops.))

SCMA 668.title: Selected Topics in Supply Chain Management
SCMA 668.description: Investigation of selected topics in Supply Chain Management
SCMA 668.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Operations Management 601 and admission to an MBA program.

SCPA 301.title: Performing Arts Management
SCPA 301.description: Introduction to politics, strategies, and practices of marketing and fundraising as they apply to non-profit performing arts companies.
SCPA 301.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 9 units in courses labelled Dance, Drama, Music, Music Performance or School of Creative and Performing Arts. 

Also Known As: (formerly School of Creative and Performing Arts 401).

SCPA 390.title: History and the Performing Arts
SCPA 390.description: The history of dance, drama and music through an inter-arts lens, focusing on works and ideas across time periods and art forms.
SCPA 390.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to BA Dance, BFA Dance, BFA Drama, BA Music, BA Honours Music, or BMus.

SCPA 499.title: Approaching Interdisciplinarity
SCPA 499.description: An exploration of the challenges and opportunities of interdisciplinary exchange and collaboration in the arts.
SCPA 499.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 48 units and admission to BA Dance, BFA Dance, BFA Drama, BA Music, BA Honours Music, or BMus.

SCPA 501.title: Topics in Inter-Arts Collaborations
SCPA 501.description: Experiential or lecture-based work that crosses the disciplinary boundaries of Dance, Drama and Music.
SCPA 501.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 6 units of courses labelled Dance, Drama or Music or consent of the School.

SCPA 505.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the School.

SCPA 599.title: Interdisciplinary Creation

SCPA 609.title: Interdisciplinary Processes
SCPA 609.description: Concepts and principles of interdisciplinarity are examined through examples of artistic practice and research with opportunities for practical application in preparation for thesis work.

SEDV 601.title: Energy Systems I
SEDV 601.description: Fundamentals of energy resources from production through consumption including technical, economic, social, and environmental, and policy aspects; fossil fuels, nuclear and renewables; electricity systems, the built environment, mobility, industries; energy transitions and sustainable and just energy strategies.
SEDV 601.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Sustainable Energy Development Program.

SEDV 603.title: Energy Systems II
SEDV 603.description: Analysis of energy systems, integration of renewable and non-renewable systems, energy storage, and energy system reliability; energy balances, basic thermodynamic calculations, and system efficiency; environmental impact analysis and economics of energy production and use. Students will work in teams on an analysis of a current or future energy project.
SEDV 603.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Sustainable Energy Development Program and Sustainable Energy Development 601.

SEDV 605.title: Indigenous Peoples and Sustainability in Energy Development
SEDV 605.description: In-depth analysis of Indigenous peoples and ecological sustainability in relation to energy development. Systems ecology, ecological economics, cultural anthropology, Indigenous rights and ethics provide theoretical foundations for sustainable development in global context of Indigenous peoples with primary focus on Canadian Indigenous peoples. Historical and legal-political context addresses treaties, policy and land-use including duty to consult and accommodate with emphasis on reconciliation.
SEDV 605.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Sustainable Energy Development Program.

SEDV 613.title: Energy Economics and Finance
SEDV 613.description: Financial principles and evaluation techniques and their application to energy investment planning; assessment methods applied to real-world examples; assessment of foundations in environmental energy economics and policies.
SEDV 613.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Sustainable Energy Development Program.

SEDV 615.title: Environmental Impact Assessment in the Energy Sector
SEDV 615.description: Principles and professional practice of environmental impact assessment, with application to energy development projects.
SEDV 615.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Sustainable Energy Development Program.

SEDV 619.title: Environmental Law in the Energy Sector
SEDV 619.description: General legal concepts, administrative law, aspects and sources of environmental law, environmental decision making, international agreements and treaties, and law reform.
SEDV 619.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Sustainable Energy Development Program.

SEDV 621.title: Environmental Management Tools in the Energy Sector
SEDV 621.description: Environmental management systems and issues are discussed as they relate to organizational and environmental impacts. Topics include: environmental management for both compliance and innovation; management processes including audits, development of indicators and reporting, green product development, risk management.
SEDV 621.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Sustainable Energy Development Program.

SEDV 623.title: Strategic Environmental Planning for Energy Organizations
SEDV 623.description: The strategy of sustainable development concepts and principles and their application to energy policies and development opportunities for businesses, including stakeholder engagement.
SEDV 623.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Sustainable Energy Development Program.

SEDV 631.title: Life Cycle Sustainability Assessment in the Energy Sector
SEDV 631.description: The concepts supporting life cycle sustainability assessment (LCSA) as they apply to energy production and consumption decision-making; life cycle thinking; goal and scope definition; mitigating problem shifting; inventory analysis; greenhouse gas emission quantification; environmental, cost, and social impact assessments; and multicriteria decision analysis.
SEDV 631.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Sustainable Energy Development Program.

Also known as: formerly Sustainable Energy Development 699.03 Lifecycle Assessment

SEDV 633.title: Energy and Climate Policy
SEDV 633.description: The role of energy policy in sustainable energy development including the rationale for policy, the policy making process, principles of policy analysis, and the impact of energy policy on energy systems. Theoretical overview of energy policy tools and examples of their use in practice. Review of current issues in energy policy domestically and internationally.
SEDV 633.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Sustainable Energy Development Program.

Also known as: formerly Sustainable Energy Development 699.01 Energy Policy

SEDV 635.title: Fundamentals of Water, Air, and Land Pollution
SEDV 635.description: Water and air quality, clean water and air acts, drinking water criteria, common water and air pollutants and their impacts on human and ecological health; water energy nexus - inter-relationships between the two; water and energy conservation; water use in energy and mining industries; options for water reclamation and reuse; fundamentals of water and wastewater treatment; acid rain, particulates, SOx, NOx, urban/photochemical smog, tropospheric ozone and its depletion, CFCs; greenhouse gases and global warming, greenhouse gas effects, climate change, GHGs trends, negative effects of GHGs; introduction to multi-media contaminant transport and contaminated sites; introduction to risk assessment.
SEDV 635.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):Admission to the Sustainable Energy Development Program.

SEDV 640.title: Capstone Project I: Research Design
SEDV 640.description: Identification of potential capstone project research questions that are anchored in energy, environment and one other aspect of the student's choice; development of research designs and skills to determine the feasibility of investigating potential research questions, narrowing options, and advancing the best option into a short proposal.
SEDV 640.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Sustainable Energy Development Program.

SEDV 641.title: Capstone Project II: Proposal Development
SEDV 641.description: Writing a comprehensive proposal designed to answer a research question. Seeking approval from a supervisor with expertise on the chosen topic, with guidance from the course instructor. Verbally presenting the research question and convincing the audience of its importance. Continuing investigation of the research question with progress reports submitted to both the supervisor and the course instructor.
SEDV 641.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Sustainable Energy Development Program and Sustainable Energy Development 640.

SEDV 642.title: Capstone Project III: Research Exploration and Examination
SEDV 642.description: Exploring the research question through an in-depth literature review, data collection, and analyses of the aspects of energy, environment, and one other aspect. Completion and submission of a professionally prepared final report that explains the investigation and findings. Presentation of findings.
SEDV 642.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Sustainable Energy Development Program and Sustainable Energy Development 641.

SEDV 698.title: Topics in Energy and the Environment I
SEDV 698.description: Study of selected topics related to energy and the environment and related subjects. Specific course(s) will reflect changing needs and faculty interests.
SEDV 698.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Sustainable Energy Development Program.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

SEDV 699.title: Topics in Energy and the Environment II
SEDV 699.description: Study of selected topics related to energy and the environment and related subjects. Specific course(s) will reflect changing needs and faculty interests.
SEDV 699.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Sustainable Energy Development Program.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SENG 300.title: Introduction to Software Engineering
SENG 300.description: Introduction to the development and evolution of software. Covers key conceptual foundations as well as key methods and techniques used in the different phases of the software lifecycle. Emphasis on both technical and soft skills needed for high quality software and software-based products developed in teams.
SENG 300.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Computer Science 219, 233 or 235; and 3 units from 319 or 331.

SENG 401.title: Software Architecture
SENG 401.description: Software architectures and design for non-functional software properties. Introduction to program comprehension skills including analysis of existing architectures.
SENG 401.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Computer Science 319, 331 or Software Engineering for Engineers 338; and 3 units from Software Engineering 300, 301 or Software Engineering for Engineers 480; and admission to the Schulich School of Engineering.

SENG 437.title: Software Testing
SENG 437.description: Concepts, methods, techniques, processes, and tools for software testing.

SENG 438.title: Software Testing, Reliability, and Quality
SENG 438.description: Concepts, methods, techniques, processes, and tools for software testing. The principles, processes, and applications of software reliability and software quality assurance.
SENG 438.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Computer Science 319, 331 or Software Engineering for Engineers 338; and 3 units from Software Engineering 300, 301 or Software Engineering for Engineers 480; and admission to the Schulich School of Engineering.

SENG 471.title: Software Requirements Engineering
SENG 471.description: Introduction to elicitation, modelling, expression and validation of the requirements. Techniques and methodologies for requirements engineering. Applications of requirements engineering to the management of the software development lifecycle.
SENG 471.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Computer Science 319, 331, Software Engineering for Engineers 338 or 409; and admission to the Schulich School of Engineering.

Also known as: (formerly Software Engineering for Engineers 471)

SENG 499.title: Introductory Topics in Software Engineering
SENG 499.description: Special topics at an introductory level on software development methods, technologies, or tools.
