SENG 499.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of either the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering or the Department of Computer Science.

SENG 501.title: Advanced Topics in Software Engineering
SENG 501.description: Special topics at an advanced level on software development methods, technologies, or tools.
SENG 501.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of either the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering or the Department of Computer Science.

SENG 511.title: Software Project Management
SENG 511.description: Analysis of methods, tools, and techniques for software project management as an effort to achieve quality software products.
SENG 511.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Software Engineering 300, 301, 403 or Software Engineering for Engineers 480.

SENG 513.title: Web-Based Systems
SENG 513.description: An overview of software engineering methods and technologies for developing web-based software systems.
SENG 513.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Software Engineering 300, 301 or Software Engineering for Engineers 480.

SENG 515.title: Agile Software Engineering
SENG 515.description: Investigation and application of agile software development practices.
SENG 515.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Software Engineering 401, 403, 411, or 443.

SENG 521.title: Software Reliability and Software Quality
SENG 521.description: The principles, processes, and applications of software reliability and software quality assurance.

SENG 523.title: Formal Methods
SENG 523.description: Software specification, verification, and validation using a mathematically rigorous technique.
SENG 523.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Software Engineering 300, 301 or Software Engineering for Engineers 480.

SENG 533.title: Software Performance Evaluation
SENG 533.description: Analyzing quality requirements of large-scale software. Performance analysis, testing, and tuning techniques. Evaluating software scalability. Capacity planning methodologies. Issues related to safety, security, and availability of software.
SENG 533.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Computer Science 457 or Software Engineering for Engineers 461; and 3 units from Software Engineering 300, 301 or Software Engineering for Engineers 480; and admission to the Schulich School of Engineering.

Also known as: (formerly Software Engineering for Engineers 533)

SENG 541.title: Fundamentals of Software Evolution and Reuse
SENG 541.description: Phenomena and approaches involved in the evolution and reuse of large-scale software, including design for modifiability and tool support. Strengths and weaknesses of industrially-current techniques as well as recent research results.
SENG 541.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Software Engineering 300, 301 or Software Engineering for Engineers 480.

SENG 550.title: Scalable Data Analytics
SENG 550.description: Sources and characteristics of large scale data, i.e., "big data", large scale data analysis, benefits of large-scale data analysis to various industry domains, programming paradigms and middleware technologies for scalable data analysis, algorithms that enable large-scale data processing, application of large scale data algorithms in selected application domains, e.g., Web user behaviour analysis and text processing, analytics frameworks.
SENG 550.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  3 units from Computer Science 319, 331 or Software Engineering for Engineers 338; and 3 units from Software Engineering 300, 301 or Software Engineering for Engineers 480.

SENG 605.title: Industrial Topics in SENG
SENG 605.description:
A study of practical approaches of industrial relevance to students specializing in Software Engineering.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SENG 607.title: Special Topics in Software Engineering
SENG 607.description:
A study of problems of particular interest to students specializing in Software Engineering.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SENG 608.title: Analytical Software Project Management
SENG 608.description:
Application of analytical methods such as clustering, classification, regression, machine learning, optimization, simulation on questions of managing artefacts and processes in consideration of the impact on time, cost, resource, and quality of software projects.

Also known as: (formerly Software Engineering 607.08)

SENG 609.title: Special Topics in Software Engineering
SENG 609.description:
A study of problems of particular interest to students specializing in Software Engineering.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SENG 611.title: Requirements Engineering I
SENG 611.description: The elicitation, modelling, expression, and validation of requirements.

SENG 615.title: Agile Software Engineering
SENG 615.description:
Investigation and application of agile software development practices.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Software Engineering 615 and Computer Science 601.93 will not be allowed.

SENG 622.title: Software Release Planning
SENG 622.description:
Product release planning covers systematic methods, tools and techniques for defining the functionality of a sequence of product releases in incremental development. The planning and re-planning is extablished as a systematic process tyring to optimize resources avaliable towards the functionality most requested by customers and stakeholders.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for both Software Engineering 622 and 607.25 will not be allowed.

SENG 627.title: Software Engineering Decision Support
SENG 627.description: Provides methodological foundations of software engineering decision-making and how to apply them to make better decisions about processes, products, and resources as well as for selection of tools and techniques.

SENG 629.title: Software Engineering Standards and Models
SENG 629.description:
Formal description of algorithms for current software engineering standards and models.  Trends and future development in software engineering standardization.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Software Engineering 629 and 609.17 will not be allowed.

SENG 637.title: Dependability and Reliability of Software Systems
SENG 637.description: Principles of software dependability techniques, and techniques to improve and predict software reliability.
SENG 637.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Electrical and Computer Engineering graduate program or Computer Science graduate program; or consent of Department.

SENG 639.title: Advanced Software Testing
SENG 639.description:
Advanced techniques, tools and concepts in software testing including: Agile testing, acceptance testing, GUI testing, test coverage analysis, automated testing, and new developments in testing research.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Software Engineering 639 and 607.22 will not be allowed.

SENG 641.title: Software Evolution and Reuse
SENG 641.description:
Phenomena and approaches involved in the evolution and reuse of large-scale software, including design for modifiability and tool support. Strengths and weaknesses of industrially-current techniques as well as recent research results.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Software Engineering 641 and 541 will not be allowed.

Also known as: (formerly Computer Science 601.33)

SENG 643.title: Automated Software Engineering
SENG 643.description:
Discusses the main techniques for automating software engineering tasks such as requirement analysis, design, development, and testing. The covered automation techniques are based on concepts from data science, search-based software engineering, and model-driven software engineering. Focuses on the fundamental techniques and algorithms in each category with examples.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Software Engineering 643 and 607.26 will not be allowed.

SENG 652.title: Software Engineering Project
SENG 652.description: A project in either software development or software best practice and experience.

SENG 696.title: Agent-Based Software Engineering
SENG 696.description: Principles and practices of engineering agent-based software systems.
SENG 696.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Electrical and Computer Engineering graduate program or Computer Science graduate program; or consent of Department.

SGMA 217.title: Introduction to Business Skills
SGMA 217.description: Introduction to the external business environment, human resource management, and marketing. Topics will include ethical decision-making, teamwork, secondary research, proper use of business communication tools and presentation skills. Pedagogical approaches may include case analysis, exercises, simulations, and class discussion.
SGMA 217.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business.

SGMA 371.title: International Business
SGMA 371.description: Covers the concepts and knowledge base required to understand how foreign cultural, economic and political developments affect the strategies of firms involved in international trade and investment, as well as of firms often seen as principally domestic in orientation.
SGMA 371.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 24 units.

Also known as: (formerly Strategy and Global Management 575)

SGMA 395.title: Business Law for Strategic Decision-Makers
SGMA 395.description: Business law topics may include: regulatory compliance and environment management, tort and contractual liability, legal issues affecting the strategic management of sole proprietorships, partnerships, corporations and joint ventures, personal liability of corporate directors and officers, intellectual property, advertising and promotion law, consumer protection legislation, legal issues affecting employees and independent contractors, the strategic management of international business, securities law and other current business law issues.
SGMA 395.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 24 units.

Also known as: (formerly Business and Environment 395)

SGMA 401.title: Business in Canada
SGMA 401.description: A comparative analysis of Canada's competitive position in the global economy utilizing case studies analyzing strategies employed by Canadian corporations to be successful in world markets.

SGMA 403.title: Strategy in Emerging Economies
SGMA 403.description: Examines key features of emerging economies. Students develop an understanding of key market segments, innovation, and competitive strategy for firms (both domestic and foreign) operating in an emerging economy.
SGMA 403.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 60 units.

SGMA 405.title: East Asia in the World Economy
SGMA 405.description: Investigation of how firms become international and achieve superior performance in the international business environment, with an emphasis on Asia. Exploration of opportunities and contemporary issues for doing business in the diverse countries of Asia. Similarities and differences in business practices among Asian countries are studied. International business concepts and strategies for doing business in Asia are considered.
SGMA 405.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 60 units.

SGMA 407.title: International Business Regulation
SGMA 407.description: International business regulations are examined, and their impact on a firm's international strategies is analyzed. Exploration of how multinational enterprises must simultaneously adapt to the external/regulatory environments of their home country and multiple host countries.
SGMA 407.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 60 units.

SGMA 409.title: Cross-Cultural Management
SGMA 409.description: Introduction to the challenges posed by managing in international environments and across cultural boundaries. Emphasis is placed on understanding the nature of cultural differences; the influence of these differences on organizational processes including leadership, teams, communication, ethics and conflict resolution; their impact on human resource practices including staffing and performance management; and implications for those holding international managerial roles.
SGMA 409.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 60 units.

SGMA 505.title: Consulting for Impact
SGMA 505.description: Introduces students to the skills and practices of consulting. Experiential learning comes through collaborating with consulting firms and providing consulting services to real clients.
SGMA 505.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, consent of the Haskayne School of Business, and 60 units.

SGMA 533.title: Dilemmas and Decisions in Business
SGMA 533.description: Managers must balance ethical, social, legal and economic issues while making complex decisions that affect both internal and external stakeholders. Using legal and business case methods as the primary teaching tools, students will, individually and in groups, gain an understanding of how to balance ethical, social and legal decision-making principles, process complex facts and obtain well-reasoned results in order to make decisions in turbulent times.
SGMA 533.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 60 units including Strategy and Global Management 395, and either admission to the Haskayne School of Business or enrolment in the Management and Society Minor.

SGMA 551.title: Social Issues, Strategies and Shareholders
SGMA 551.description: An examination of the management of social and environmental issues. A focus on the pressing global issue of climate change and the economic impacts, both threats and opportunities, of greenhouse gas emissions mitigation on energy production and consumption throughout the economy.
SGMA 551.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 60 units.

SGMA 555.title: Strategies for Sustainable Development
SGMA 555.description: Make better business decisions in light of our society, the environment and the economy. Solve social and environmental problems while generating a shareholder return. Practical frameworks for decision making.

SGMA 559.title: Selected Topics in Strategy and Global Management
SGMA 559.description: Examination of selected topics in Strategy and Global Management.
SGMA 559.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 60 units. For certain topics, consent of the Haskayne School of Business will also be required.

SGMA 561.title: Ethical Issues and the Professional Manager
SGMA 561.description: Major ethical principles are evaluated from different perspectives to provide tools for making sound ethical decisions in various business situations and in the face of moral dilemmas.
SGMA 561.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 30 units.

Also known as: (formerly Business and Environment 561)

SGMA 571.title: Business Under USMCA
SGMA 571.description: Legal, political, economic and social considerations important to Canadian firms pursuing the US and/or Mexican markets, including the implications of the United States - Mexico - Canada Agreement.
SGMA 571.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 60 units.

SGMA 573.title: Business With Japan
SGMA 573.description: An integrated approach to the cultural, governmental and structural factors influencing the conduct of business with Japan, whether as a supplier, customer, partner or investor.
SGMA 573.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 60 units.

SGMA 577.title: International Strategic Management
SGMA 577.description: A focus on why and how firms internationalize and the strategic challenges facing firms that operate within an international business environment.  The course covers key concepts, theories and perspectives in international management.  These are critiqued, contextualized and applied to particular firm level cases.
SGMA 577.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 60 units.

SGMA 579.title: Co-ordinating Global Business
SGMA 579.description: Applies international business theory to the practical operational challenges faced by international managers with a focus on functional implications throughout the entire value chain of the firm's cross-border activities.
SGMA 579.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 60 units.

SGMA 589.title: International Business Consulting
SGMA 589.description: Research project based on a live "case". Student groups are presented with a case of a real-world company facing an international strategy issue. Groups conduct primary and secondary research, analyze impediments, and apply knowledge and skills gained in the Bachelor of Commerce program to provide actionable recommendations for managers in charge of international strategy. Final projects may be submitted as IVEY teaching cases in cooperation with interested faculty.
SGMA 589.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, consent of the Haskayne School of Business, and 60 units including one of Finance 461, Marketing 467, Strategy and Global Management 371, 403, 405, 407, 409, or any 500-level Strategy and Global Management course.

SGMA 591.title: Strategic Management
SGMA 591.description: Analysis of competitive situations from the general management point of view, including fit between key environmental forces and the firm's resources, and changes in these over time. Formulating and implementing strategy based on that analysis. Developing and leveraging a firm's core competencies to gain long-term sustainable advantage.
SGMA 591.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 84 units including Accounting 217 or 317, Accounting 323, Entrepreneurship and Innovation 317, Management Studies 391, Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 317, Business Technology Management 317, Finance 317, Marketing 317, Operations Management 317, Strategy and Global Management 395.

SGMA 595.title: Advanced Business Law
SGMA 595.description: Various advanced topics that are of current interest in business law. These topics may probe deeper into several of the topics covered in the introductory business law course or may introduce new legal topics of current interest to business managers.
SGMA 595.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Strategy and Global Management 395.

Also known as: (formerly Business and Environment 595)

SGMA 601.title: Strategic Management I
SGMA 601.description:
The role of the CEO and other senior executives in formulating and implementing corporate strategies, and provides an overview of key strategic issues and topics. Covers such areas as industry analysis, executive leadership, corporate strategy, corporate diversification, strategic change, global strategy, mergers and acquisitions, and strategic implications of new technologies.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for both Strategy and Global Management 601 and 701 will not be allowed.

SGMA 602.title: Strategic Management II
SGMA 602.description: Application of strategic concepts and frameworks of analysis. Decisions and the processes to mobilize resources for the attainment of objectives. Measurement of performance through industry and competitive analysis.
SGMA 602.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Strategy and Global Management 601 or consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

Also known as: (formerly Strategy and Global Management 795)

SGMA 603.title: Global Environment of Business
SGMA 603.description:
Economic, political, social and legal factors affecting management decisions. Topics may include Canada in the world economy, business and government relations, business ethics and legal environment for business. Develops knowledge and ability to analyze and deal with complexities of the business environment. 

Also known as: (formerly Business and Environment 601)

SGMA 613.title: Legal Environment of Business
SGMA 613.description: The study of the various areas of business law. Topics may include: contracts, patents and copyrights, product liability, incorporation and other relevant legal issues.
SGMA 613.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources 601, Operations Management 601, Business Technology Management 601, and Accounting 601. 

Also known as: (formerly Business and Environment 613)

SGMA 631.title: Analytics of International Business Environment
SGMA 631.description: A data-driven approach to the analysis of international business environment. Use of data analytics to appraise emerging trends in a country/region/world business environment and derive strategic implications for business enterprises.

SGMA 651.title: Strategies for Sustainable Development
SGMA 651.description:
The strategic context for making business decisions with respect to sustainable development issues. The role of sustainability in economic development, international trade relations and emerging technologies. Stakeholder perspectives and the effect of environmental and social issues on industrial performance. 
 
Also known as: (formerly Business and Environment 651)

SGMA 653.title: Managing Social and Environmental Issues in the Global Market Place
SGMA 653.description:
Examines the new class of social and environmental corporate risks through a review of changes in international sustainable development policy initiatives, changes in communications, the emergence of an environmental and social activist sector, and the interaction of these factors resulting in new international business risk challenges. Uses lectures, cases, simulations and class discussion of theories and concepts. 

Also known as: (formerly Business and Environment 653)

SGMA 655.title: Strategic Management in the Global Energy Industry
SGMA 655.description: Characteristics of the energy industry. Major strategic issues facing top management teams in corporations involved in oil and gas and power businesses and relevant strategic tools for addressing them. Industry structure, energy value chain, key players and their strategies, industry dynamics and trends, supply and demand, expansion, M&As, roles of governments, OPEC and international politics, Kyoto Protocol, major technological drivers, organization and top management leadership.
SGMA 655.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Strategy and Global Management 601.

Also known as: (formerly Strategy and Global Management 751)

SGMA 659.title: International Business Environment
SGMA 659.description:
The environment which influences international business activities including economic, legal, political and socio-cultural factors. Foreign direct investment in Canada will also be considered.

Also known as: (formerly Strategy and Global Management 775)

SGMA 661.title: Ethics and the Professional Manager
SGMA 661.description:
The role of values in business decision making; alternative moral codes and their principles; moral principles as decision tools, and reasoning through moral dilemmas; role of business in society; specific issues in business ethics; application through cases and exercises. 

Also known as: (formerly Business and Environment 661)

SGMA 668.title: Seminar in Strategy and Global Management
SGMA 668.description: Study and discussion of current research literature and contemporary issues on topics related to Strategy and Global Management in the private and/or the public sectors.
SGMA 668.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Haskayne School of Business will be required for certain seminar topics.

SGMA 672.title: Strategic Analysis
SGMA 672.description: Introduction to the key concepts, tools, and principles of strategy formulation and competitive analysis.
SGMA 672.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Management program.

SGMA 674.title: International Business
SGMA 674.description: Strategic challenges of managing and operating within an international business environment, their potential implications at a firm level, strategies for firms competing in international markets, and operational tactics employed in functional areas.
SGMA 674.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Management program.

SGMA 676.title: Business Law
SGMA 676.description: Principal substantive subjects include: business and the Canadian legal system, constitutional rights, the administrative and regulatory process, contracts, employment, business organizations, property and negligence.
SGMA 676.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Management Program. 

Also known as: (formerly Business and Environment 674)

SGMA 678.title: Business Communications
SGMA 678.description: Creating clear and concise written and verbal communications, crafting persuasive presentations, understanding stakeholders and the value of personal branding.
SGMA 678.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Management Program. 

Also known as: (formerly Business and Environment 672) 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

SGMA 707.title: Advanced Strategic Management Tools
SGMA 707.description: Re-examination of the main tools used in strategy analysis with a unique triple focus on: 1) inclusion only of tools that are actionable and lead to outcomes with clear management implications; 2) critical assessment of the 'limits' associated with applying each tool (boundary conditions; weaknesses; danger of wrong interpretation of results; unexpected negative spill-over effects; etc.); and 3) discussion of the most recent insights from the scholarly and practitioner oriented literatures, emphasizing dynamics.
SGMA 707.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Business Administration program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

SGMA 796.title: Qualitative Research in Strategy and Organizations
SGMA 796.description: Processes of collecting, analyzing, and reporting qualitative data, as well as inducing theory from them. Application to the area of Strategy and Organizations is emphasized. Focus on various approaches to qualitative research and on developing competence in conducting it.
SGMA 796.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

SGMA 797.title: Advanced Seminar in Strategy and Global Management
SGMA 797.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SGMA 799.05.title: Interorganizational Relationships: Creating and Managing Strategic Alliances

SLAV 356.title: Topics in Perspectives on Eastern Europe
SLAV 356.description:
Selected significant current issues in East-European cultures through the lens of literature, visual arts, drama, music, and film.

Notes: Taught in English.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SOCI 201.title: Introduction To Sociology
SOCI 201.description: Sociology as a discipline examines how the society in which we live influences our thinking and behaviour. An introduction to sociology through the study of society, social institutions, group behaviour and social change.

SOCI 301.title: Topics in Sociology
SOCI 301.description: A variety of sociological topics are explored at an introductory level.
SOCI 301.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Sociology 201.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SOCI 303.title: Sociology Of Gender
SOCI 303.description: A sociological exploration of the way genders are constructed and how they play-out at the level of individuals and institutions, and in diverse social contexts.

SOCI 307.title: Sociology of Indigenous People in Canada
SOCI 307.description: The dynamics of Indigenous groups' relations with each other and the larger society. Topics include decolonization and relations with the state, demography, Indigenous organizations, Indigenous nationalism and nation-building, power, social class and public policy.

SOCI 309.title: Alberta Society
SOCI 309.description: Sociological introduction to the ideology, composition, dynamics, and institutions of Albertan society, using external comparisons where relevant.

SOCI 311.title: Introductory Social Statistics I
SOCI 311.description: Univariate and bivariate statistics for survey data. Topics include cross tabular analysis, the normal distribution, confidence intervals for means, hypothesis testing, Chi-squared and F distributions and bivariate linear regression analysis. In labs statistical software to analyze survey data will be used.

SOCI 313.title: Introductory Social Research Methods
SOCI 313.description: Research processes including problem definition, data collection and analyses; quantitative and qualitative strategies.

SOCI 315.title: Introductory Social Statistics II
SOCI 315.description: Multivariate statistics for survey data; and measurement issues in quantitative research. Topics include reliability, multivariate tabular analysis, multiple regression, dummy variable regression, statistical interaction and path analysis. In labs statistical software to test measurement and causal models will be used.

SOCI 321.title: Sociology Of Health & Illness
SOCI 321.description: Introduction to social factors influencing health, illness, and medicine. Topics covered may include the organization of medical institutions and occupations, the socialization of medical professionals, the social construction of illness, social determinants of health, and comparative health care systems and policy.
SOCI 321.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Sociology 201 or consent of the Department.

SOCI 325.title: Intro Deviance & Social Control
SOCI 325.description: The presentation and analysis of theories of criminality and of non-criminal deviance, methods to uncover the incidence of deviance and criminality, a survey of forms of deviant and criminal behaviours, and the social and institutional responses to them.
SOCI 325.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Sociology 201 or consent of the Department.

SOCI 327.title: Introduction to Criminal Justice
SOCI 327.description: Introduction to the field of criminal justice in Canada from a sociological perspective. May include: examination of the definitions of crime; crime measurement; institutional responses to crime by the police, the courts and correctional services; and alternatives to the justice model.

SOCI 329.title: The Sociology of Law
SOCI 329.description: An introduction to sociological problems regarding the origin, impact and definition of law, dispute resolution, and the relationship between law and social change.
SOCI 329.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Sociology 201.

Also known as: (formerly Sociology 429)

SOCI 331.title: Classical Sociological Theory
SOCI 331.description: The development of sociological theory from the nineteenth century to the Second World War.
SOCI 331.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Sociology 201 or consent of the Department.

SOCI 333.title: Contemporary Sociological Theory
SOCI 333.description: The development of sociological theory from the Second World War to the present.
SOCI 333.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Sociology 331 or consent of the Department.

SOCI 341.title: Social Psychology
SOCI 341.description: A wide range of interdependent individual and social topics that influence our thinking, feeling, and behavior. Topics may include social cognition, perception, social experience, group behavior, social interaction, and emotions.
SOCI 341.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Sociology 201 or consent of the Department.

SOCI 345.title: Media and Society
SOCI 345.description: Employing a critical sociological approach, explore the many forms in which our understandings of gender, ethnicity, and other social phenomena, are informed and in turn inform the many mediascapes that characterize the contemporary world. Uses analysis of media such as cinema, television, videogames, animation and the Internet, as well as their respective audiences, to delve into the interconnections between modern subjectivity and the imagined worlds of mass and new media.

SOCI 353.title: Urban Sociology
SOCI 353.description: Discusses the impact of urbanization on social relationships by analyzing city living in historical and global perspective but also through local issues such as density and neighbourhoods. Provides a sociological perspective on issues that cities are facing today.

SOCI 355.title: Population & Society
SOCI 355.description: Introduction to social demography -- the study of population structure (size, composition and distribution) and processes (fertility, mortality and migration). Focuses on both empirical and theoretical relationships between demography, social change and structured inequality.

SOCI 365.title: Social Stratification
SOCI 365.description: Introduction to the sociological study of social inequalities and stratification and the major theoretical explanations of social inequalities.
SOCI 365.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Sociology 201 or consent of the Department.

SOCI 371.title: Sociology Of Families
SOCI 371.description: A sociological examination of family life in all its multiple and changing forms. Topics may include key transitions and common practices in family life; gender, sexuality and family life, and family life in cross-cultural context.
SOCI 371.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Sociology 201 or consent of the Department.

SOCI 373.title: Sociology Of Aging
SOCI 373.description: Social and institutional factors associated with aging in modern society.
SOCI 373.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Sociology 201 or consent of the Department.

SOCI 375.title: Sociology of Ethnicity & Racialization
SOCI 375.description: Introduction to the forms of ethnic and racial dynamics in selected cases around the world. Such concepts as identity, ethnicity, race, racialization, racism, assimilation, integration, pluralism, colonialism, post-colonialism, transnationalism and diasporas are examined in theoretical and cross-national contexts.
SOCI 375.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Sociology 201 or consent of the Department.

SOCI 377.title: The Sociology Of Religion
SOCI 377.description: An introduction to the theories and concepts utilized by sociologists to interpret religious behaviour and the organization of religion.
SOCI 377.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Sociology 201 or consent of the Department.

SOCI 393.title: The Sociology Of Work
SOCI 393.description: A sociological perspective for gaining a better understanding of the meaning and nature of work. Provides an overview of core concepts and current topics fundamental to the sociology of work.
SOCI 393.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Sociology 201 or consent of the Department.

SOCI 399.title: Sociology of Sport
SOCI 399.description: Organized around the theme of social problems in sport, examines sports-related behaviour, consumption, and sponsorship. A variety of approaches shows how sport is socially constructed and embodies different meanings for different groups of people.

SOCI 401.title: Advanced Topics in Sociology
SOCI 401.description: A variety of specialized sociological topics are explored at an advanced level.
SOCI 401.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Sociology 313.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SOCI 403.title: Topics in Gender Relations
SOCI 403.description: Selected themes and issues in the sociology of gender relations. Topics such as illness, consumer society, environmental risk, compassion, homelessness, poverty and identity have recently been explored.
SOCI 403.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Sociology 303, 313, 331, 333.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SOCI 405.title: Topics in Canadian Social Structure
SOCI 405.description: A macro-level examination of Canadian social structure including a socio-developmental analysis of selected Canadian institutions such as bilingualism, regionalism, multiculturalism, multinational corporations, and ethnic stratification. Critical examination of sociological models for the study of Canadian society.
SOCI 405.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Sociology 313, 331, 333.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SOCI 407.title: Sociology Of The Body
SOCI 407.description:
(formerly Sociology 401.15)
Considers aspects of the lived body and the body as object of social construction, modification, and regulation.

SOCI 409.title: Social Determinants Of Health
SOCI 409.description: An advanced study of health in a social context.  Examines the social determinants of health and illness outcomes along with their implications for public policies conducive to better health.

SOCI 413.title: Qualitative Research Methods
SOCI 413.description: Research methods such as participant observation, naturalistic observation, interviewing, non-reactive techniques, and life histories, and methodological issues such as gaining access to subjects, and issues pertaining to the ethics of research.

SOCI 419.title: Topics in the Sociology of Health and Illness
SOCI 419.description: Advanced analysis of selected themes and issues in the sociology of health and illness.
SOCI 419.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Sociology 313, 321, 331, 333.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SOCI 421.title: Topics in Deviance and Criminology
SOCI 421.description: Advanced study of contemporary issues in the research in deviance and crime.
SOCI 421.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Sociology 313, 325, 331, 333. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SOCI 423.title: The Sociology of Youth Crime
SOCI 423.description: Explanations of the criminal activities of young people including an assessment of treatment strategies and legal regimes developed in response to this behaviour.

SOCI 425.title: The Sociology Of Violence
SOCI 425.description: An exploration of violence in a variety of situations and social institutions and more general patterns of victimization in contemporary society.

SOCI 427.title: The Social Organization of Criminal Justice
SOCI 427.description: Comparative social organization of the criminal justice system from a sociological perspective; special attention to and analysis of the structure of the Canadian criminal justice system.

SOCI 435.title: The Sociology of Knowledge
SOCI 435.description: The study of knowledge as a social practice; theories of knowledge, representation and interpretation; practical knowledge in everyday life; the role of organized knowledge in social domains such as science, biomedicine, bureaucracy, social service administration and professional occupations.

SOCI 443.title: Topics in Social Psychology
SOCI 443.description: An advanced study of social processes and interactions of persons in groups with some methodological considerations.
SOCI 443.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Sociology 313, 331, 333, 341. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SOCI 445.title: Visual Sociology
SOCI 445.description: Visual representation in contemporary society. Social Practices of making and using Visual images, such as photographs.The use of visual methods in sociological research.

SOCI 453.title: Topics in Urban Sociology
SOCI 453.description: Critical analysis of theories of urban institutional and ecological characteristics. Emphasis is on comparative data derived from a sample of world cities.
SOCI 453.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Sociology 313, 331, 333, 353. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SOCI 461.title: Worker Movements & Labour Unions
SOCI 461.description: A social movement perspective on working class struggle and accommodation in capitalist societies. Historical and contemporary movements will be considered, with an emphasis on Canada.

SOCI 467.title: Ethnic Relations in Canada
SOCI 467.description: An introduction to the structure and form of ethnic (racial) group relations in Canada. Contemporary relations will be analyzed from a historical perspective.

SOCI 471.title: Topics in the Sociology of Families
SOCI 471.description: Selected themes and issues in the sociology of families.
SOCI 471.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Sociology 313, 331, 333, 371.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SOCI 475.title: Topics in Race and Ethnic Relations
SOCI 475.description: Advanced analysis of selected themes and issues in race and ethnic relations within the framework of theory and research.
SOCI 475.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Sociology 313, 331, 333, 375. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SOCI 483.title: Topics in Social Inequalities and Social Justice
SOCI 483.description: Advanced, critical analysis of the causes and consequences of dimensions of social stratification and patterned inequalities. Teaching and learning practices are organized around social justice principles, i.e. ensuring the representation of diverse voices and perspectives.
SOCI 483.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Sociology 313, 331, 333, 365.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SOCI 485.title: Topics in Social Theory
SOCI 485.description: Exploration of selected themes in social theory to develop advanced knowledge of specific social theorists and schools of social theory.
SOCI 485.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Sociology 313, 331, 333. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SOCI 487.title: Sociology of Development
SOCI 487.description: A study of the process of change and modernization in the developing areas of the world.

SOCI 493.title: Topics in the Sociology of Work
SOCI 493.description: Selected themes and issues in the sociology of work. May include gender and work, families and work, and the sociology of organizations.
SOCI 493.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Sociology 313, 331, 333, 393. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SOCI 499.title: Field School/Seminar in Sociology
SOCI 499.description: A variety of specialized topics explored through concentrated learning opportunities. May include urban issues, the self in society, settlement and immigration, and disorder and crime.
SOCI 499.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SOCI 501.title: Directed Study
SOCI 501.description: Independent study of a variety of advanced topics under the supervision of a member of the department.
SOCI 501.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 6 units of courses labelled Sociology at the 400 level, and consent of the Department. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SOCI 504.title: Integrative Seminar
SOCI 504.description: Advanced topics in sociology to facilitate special research projects, especially community-engaged and/or group research.
SOCI 504.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 6 units of courses labelled Sociology at the 400 level, and consent of the Department. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SOCI 590.title: Sociology Honours Thesis and Seminar
SOCI 590.description: Students will conduct an independent research project under the direction of a supervisor. In the seminar, students will discuss and present their projects and other topics relevant to conducting research.
SOCI 590.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the Sociology Honours program and consent of the Department.

SOCI 601.title: Seminar in Special Topics in Sociology
SOCI 601.description:
Seminar on special topics. Consult Department for details.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SOCI 603.title: Seminar in Sociology of Health and Illness

SOCI 604.title: Directed Reading
SOCI 604.description:
Independent study at the MA level of a selected topic under the supervision of a member of the department. 

MAY NOT BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SOCI 606.title: Master's Seminar in Professional Sociology I
SOCI 606.description:
Students are introduced to, and develop skills in, aspects of professional practice as a sociologist, including applying for grants and scholarships; the ethical review process for research; writing research and thesis proposals; and presenting at conferences.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Sociology 606 and 602 will not be allowed.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

SOCI 607.title: Master's Seminar in Professional Sociology II
SOCI 607.description:
Students are introduced to, and develop skills in, aspects of professional practice as a sociologist, including applying for grants and scholarships; the ethical review process for research; writing research and thesis proposals; and presenting at conferences.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Sociology 607 and 602 will not be allowed.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

SOCI 611.title: Social Statistics: The General Linear Model
SOCI 611.description: Multiple regression with applications to sociological research, with topics such as regression diagnostics, categorical predictors, non-linear relationships, logistic regression, and testing of mediation and moderation.

SOCI 613.title: Seminar in Quantitative Research Methods
SOCI 613.description: Advanced study in the theory and practice of quantitative research methods. Topics may include the logic of causality, mixed methods designs, sampling, measurement, survey construction and implementation.

SOCI 615.title: Seminar In Qualitative Res Method
SOCI 615.description: Advanced study in the theory and practice of qualitative research methods.  Topics may include participant observation, in-depth interviews, narrative analysis, conversation and discourse analysis, autoethnography, archival research, and feminist research methods.

SOCI 617.title: Seminar in Applied Social Research Methods
SOCI 617.description: Focused on applied contexts in domains such as health care, criminal justice, education, and public administration, this course focusses on processes such as community engagement, needs assessment, program evaluation, policy analysis, and the communication of research results to diverse audiences.

SOCI 631.title: Seminar in Sociological Theory
SOCI 631.description: The history of Sociological theory from the beginnings to World War II, including readings from Marx, Weber, Durkheim, and the early Parsons.

SOCI 671.title: Seminar on Families, Relationships, and Personal Life

SOCI 677.title: Seminar In Sociology of Gender Relations

SOCI 680.title: Major Research Project
SOCI 680.description: Master's research project for course-based degree students.

SOCI 701.title: Doctoral Seminar in Sociology
SOCI 701.description:
No description available Seminar on selected topics. Consult Department for details.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SOCI 704.title: Directed Reading
SOCI 704.description:
Independent study at the doctoral level of a selected topic under the supervision of a member of the department. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SOCI 705.title: Selected Topics in Advanced Methodological Issues

SOCI 706.title: Doctoral Seminar in Professional Sociology I
SOCI 706.description:
Students are introduced to, and develop skills in, aspects of professional practice as a sociologist, including applying for grants and scholarships; the ethical review process for research; writing research and thesis proposals; and presenting at conferences.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Sociology 706 and 702 will not be allowed.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

SOCI 707.title: Doctoral Seminar in Professional Sociology II
SOCI 707.description:
Students are introduced to, and develop skills in, aspects of professional practice as a sociologist, including applying for grants and scholarships; the ethical review process for research; writing research and thesis proposals; and presenting at conferences.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Sociology 707 and 702 will not be allowed.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

SOCI 711.title: Selected Topics in Advanced Quantitative Methods

SOCI 715.title: Selected Topics in Advanced Qualitative Methods

SOIN 601.title: Fundamentals of Social Innovation, Research and Practice
SOIN 601.description: Exploration of key definitions and domains of social innovation.  Using community case studies students will gain an appreciation of the social innovation landscape, and this emerging field of knowledge, research, and practice.

SOIN 603.title: Leading for Social Innovation: Embracing and Adapting to Complex Change
SOIN 603.description: Focus on the individual as a change agent exploring: traits and mindsets for leading in uncertainty; embracing 'messy problems' and adapting to change in health and social care; understanding equity, diversity and inclusion, and Indigenous considerations in social innovation.

SOIN 605.title: Social Innovation Design: Teams, Networks, Coalitions and Partnerships
SOIN 605.description: Relational focus on developing social innovation initiatives, generating support and momentum, engaging stakeholders, and enabling collaboration for evaluation.

SOIN 607.title: Change That Sustains: Navigating Organizations, Systems and Institutions
SOIN 607.description: Institutional/system focus to enhance understanding and competence with navigating system, institutional, and organizational dynamics and structures for societal impact.

SOWK 201.title: Foundations of the Social Work Profession
SOWK 201.description:
Learners explore the history, philosophical foundation, codes of ethics, practice standards, theoretical perspectives, practice models, and diverse fields of practice related to Social Work.

Notes: Alberta Social Work Post-Diploma students cannot take this course as fulfillment of their non-Social Work course requirements.

SOWK 300.title: Generalist Practice in Context Theme Course
SOWK 300.description: Examination of the professional use of self in relation to the knowledge, values, and skills pertaining to the practice of generalist social work practice in rural, remote, and Aboriginal communities.

SOWK 301.title: Generalist Practice in Context Portfolio Project
SOWK 301.description:
Individual preparation of a self-directed portfolio as an expression of the student's own understanding of generalist social work practice in relation to the local context. The student's prior learning experiences will be incorporated in the development of the project.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Social Work 300.

SOWK 302.title: Research in Context Theme Course
SOWK 302.description: An introduction to knowledge generation relevant to generalist social work practice. Foundational concepts and approaches of various research methodologies will be introduced as ways of knowledge building to inform practice and influence policy, particularly within rural, remote and Indigenous contexts.

SOWK 303.title: Practice with Individuals in Context
SOWK 303.description: Focuses on interviewing and counseling skills from a generalist social work perspective. Emphasis will be given to skill development, critical reflection, practice evaluation, and practical application within rural, remote and Indigenous contexts.

SOWK 304.title: Diversity and Oppression Theme Course
SOWK 304.description: Examines diversity, colonization, oppression, and intergroup relations associated with the practice of social work in rural, remote, and Indigenous communities. Anti-oppressive frameworks will be introduced for understanding the processes associated with social justice.

SOWK 305.title: Diversity and Oppression Portfolio Project
SOWK 305.description:
Individual preparation of a self-directed portfolio as an expression of the student's own critical analysis of diversity, oppression, and social justice in relation to the local context. Honouring the student's prior learning experiences by acknowledging and incorporating aspects of that learning in the development of the project.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Social Work 304.

SOWK 306.title: Social Work Methods Course
SOWK 306.description: Examines various perspectives and theoretical approaches relating to the development, maintenance, and application of empowering relationships in generalist social work practice. Particular emphasis will be placed on local applications in rural, remote, and Indigenous organizations and communities.

SOWK 307.title: Practice Skills in Context
SOWK 307.description: Focuses on theory and practice relating to social work with individuals, families and groups in diverse communities. Particular emphasis will be paid to skill development, critical analysis and practical application within rural, remote and Indigenous contexts.

SOWK 310.title: Critical Analysis of Social Work Theories and Practice
SOWK 310.description:
Learners critically examine diverse theories and perspectives and integrate theory and practice.

Prerequisite: Admission to BSW Program.

Antirequisite: Credit for Social Work 310 and 365 will not be allowed.

SOWK 312.title: Social Work Practice Skills, Processes, and Strategies
SOWK 312.description:
Learners develop and practice skills and approaches in working with diverse individuals, families, groups, communities, and organizations. Learners critically evaluate and apply anti-racist, anti-oppressive, and anti-colonial models of practice.

Prerequisite: Admission to BSW program (University Transfer route, including After-Degree) and Social Work 201.

SOWK 314.title: Communication and Relationship Building Skills
SOWK 314.description:
Learners practice and apply foundational Social Work communication, engagement, and relational skills and processes to practice across contexts with diverse individuals, families, organizations, and communities.

Prerequisite: Admission to BSW program (University Transfer route, including After-Degree).

SOWK 318.title: Developing Identities in Social Work Practice
SOWK 318.description:
Learners examine social identities in Social Work practice, develop their Social Work practice framework, and apply professional ethics in working with diverse populations.

Prerequisite: Admission to BSW program (University Transfer route, including After-Degree) and Social Work 201

Antirequisite: Credit for Social Work 318 and 361 will not be allowed.

SOWK 322.title: Social Work Research
SOWK 322.description:
Learners develop foundational knowledge of research, research process and methodologies. Learners critically apply research skills in diverse contexts.

Prerequisite: Admission to BSW Program.

Antirequisite: Credit for Social Work 322 and 355 will not be allowed.

SOWK 355.title: Research in Context
SOWK 355.description:
An introduction to basic research methodology, data analysis and a critical appraisal and application of research findings within a reflective model of practice.

Antirequisite: Credit for Social Work 355 and 322 will not be allowed.

SOWK 361.title: Professional Use of Self
SOWK 361.description:
Focuses on the examination and integration of theoretical and practical understandings of professional social work practice. Topics covered include: critical thinking; ethical decision-making; knowledge of the associations to which social work professionals belong; professional writing; and self-care.

Antirequisite: Credit for Social Work 361 and 318 will not be allowed.

SOWK 363.title: Human Development and Environments
SOWK 363.description: Explores the nature of human behaviour and development in diverse environments and contexts (personal, community, social, and environmental) and explores the implications for social work practice and theory.

SOWK 365.title: Critical Approaches to Social Work Practice
SOWK 365.description:
Provides theoretical frameworks, including anti-oppressive social work concepts, as a foundation for reflective professional generalist social work.

Antirequisite: Credit for Social Work 365 and 310 will not be allowed.

SOWK 371.title: Social Work and Diversity
SOWK 371.description: Students will critically examine the issues of diversity and the power relations that form common links among the experiences of oppression and marginalization in Canadian society.

SOWK 383.title: Social Policy & Social Justice
SOWK 383.description:
Provides an understanding of Canadian social policy, its impact on social justice and how it influences social work practice.

Notes: University Transfer route only.

SOWK 390.title: Community-Engaged Practicum and Preparation
SOWK 390.description:
Learners prepare and participate in field experiences and integrative seminar. This is supported through social work supervision to develop their professional Social Work identity and engage in peer learning.

Prerequisite: Admission to BSW program (University Transfer route, including After-Degree).

Note: Students may be completing their practicum at locations that involve additional costs to meet requirements of specific organizations. Students are responsible for all costs associated with practicum activities. Some practicum activities may require variable hours during weekdays, evenings, or weekends.

SOWK 391.title: Practice & Evaluation with Indidviduals
SOWK 391.description:
An introduction to theories and skills for communicating with people in a professional social work context. Generic interviewing and basic counseling skills from a generalist perspective of social work practice will be developed.

Notes: University Transfer route only.

SOWK 392.title: Community-Engaged Practicum and Integration
SOWK 392.description: Learners engage in experiential, reflective, and curiosity-driven learning through community service and social justice initiatives. Social Work supervision and an integrative seminar scaffold, support, build Social Work competence, and engage in peer learning while developing their professional Social Work identity.
SOWK 392.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to BSW program (University Transfer route, including After-Degree), Social Work 201 and Social Work 390 with a grade of "C" or better.

Note: Students may be completing their practicum at locations that involve additional costs to meet requirements of specific organizations. Students are responsible for all costs associated with practicum activities. Some practicum activities may require variable hours during weekdays, evenings, or weekends. 

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

SOWK 393.title: Practice & Evaluation with Families
SOWK 393.description:
An introduction to theories and skills for family-centered social work practice with families. There will be an emphasis on diversity in relation to family development issues, the stresses families face, family assessment techniques, and theories and practices of family intervention.

Notes: University Transfer route only.

SOWK 395.title: Practice & Evaluation with Groups
SOWK 395.description:
An introduction to theories and skills for working with groups within a context of practice and assessment frameworks.

Notes: University Transfer route only.

SOWK 397.title: Practice and Evaluation with Communities
SOWK 397.description:
An introduction to theories and skills about community practice. The focus will be on understanding the basic values, and ethical, strategic, evaluative and political issues involved in working for community change.

Notes: University Transfer route only.

SOWK 399.title: Practice and Evaluation with Organizations
SOWK 399.description:
An introduction to theories and skills in the study of human service organizations. Examines organizational dynamics and how these impacts professional practice, relationships with clients, and the potential for organizational change.

Notes: University Transfer route only.

SOWK 410.title: Practicum I
SOWK 410.description: Application of conceptual framework, experience, knowledge and skills within a specific practice setting.
SOWK 410.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Completion of all required 300 level Social Work courses.

Corequisite: Social Work 411.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

SOWK 411.title: Integrative Seminar I
SOWK 411.description: Integration of theory and practice within the context of the field practicum.
SOWK 411.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Completion of all required 300 level Social Work coruses.

SOWK 412.title: Practicum II
SOWK 412.description: Application of professional theory and skills in supervised social work practice settings.
SOWK 412.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Completion of all required 300 level Social Work courses. University Transfer Route: Social Work 410 and 411.

Corequisite: Social Work 413. 

Antirequisite: Credit for Social Work 412 and 590 will not be allowed.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

SOWK 413.title: Integrative Seminar II
SOWK 413.description: Advanced integration of concepts, perspectives, theories and skills with practicum experiences, developing conceptual frameworks of practice.
SOWK 413.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): All required 300 level Social Work courses. University Transfer Route: Social Work 410 and 411.

SOWK 419.title: Leadership and Advocacy Skills for Social Justice
SOWK 419.description:
Learners apply leadership and advocacy models and skills in working with individuals, families, groups, communities, and organizations across diverse contexts. Learners critically reflect on their professional identities as leaders and change makers.

Prerequisite: Admission to BSW program (University Transfer route, including After-Degree).

SOWK 427.title: Multiple Dimensions of Mental Health
SOWK 427.description:
Learners develop theoretical knowledge and practical skills to address a continuum of mental well-being to mental illness, classification of mental disorders, and addictions within diverse local and international contexts. 

Prerequisite: Admission to BSW Program.

SOWK 428.title: Indigenous Peoples' Histories, Cultures, and Healing Practices
SOWK 428.description:
From an Indigenous worldview, learners gain an appreciation of the diverse Indigenous healing practices that are rooted in natural laws, languages, and spirit. Learners are invited to engage in learning that honours the resistance and resilience of Indigenous peoples in the face of colonial violence, genocide, and complex intergenerational traumas. 

Prerequisite: Admission to BSW Program.

Antirequisite: Credit for Social Work 428 and 553.37 (Creating Wellness Indg Trauma) will not be allowed.

SOWK 429.title: Africentric Social Work Practice
SOWK 429.description:
Learners critically examine African-centred worldviews, philosophies, values, and principles in historical and contemporary contexts, which inform the application and an exploration of the interconnections with anti-racist and anti-colonial Social Work. 

Prerequisite: Admission to BSW Program.

Antirequisite: Credit for Social Work 429 and 555.55 (AfricentricPerspectivesinSW) will not be allowed.

SOWK 436.title: Green Social Work and Sustainability
SOWK 436.description:
Learners examine the role of Social Work in addressing the environmental crisis across individual, community, organizational, and professional contexts. Learners critically assess and apply approaches and innovations to integrate environmental justice and sustainability in Social Work practice.

Prerequisite: Admission to BSW Program.

SOWK 437.title: Social Work Practice in an Interconnected World
SOWK 437.description:
Learners engage in critical examination of the interconnections among local, international, and global opportunities and challenges. Learners explore and apply Social Work skills to promote social action, social change, resilience, and wellness. 

Prerequisite: Admission to BSW Program.

Antirequisite: Credit for Social Work 437 and 557.01/557.16 (International Social Work) will not be allowed.

SOWK 502.title: Addiction and Recovery
SOWK 502.description: Critically examines the socio-historical context, theoretical and practice models, and debates surrounding addiction and recovery.
SOWK 502.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Social Work.

Also known as: (formerly Social Work 553.12 Addiction and Recovery)

SOWK 504.title: Anti-Colonial and Anti-Racist Praxis
SOWK 504.description: An experiential, relational and transformative learning encounter where students will apply the teachings of anti-colonial and anti-racist practice.
SOWK 504.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Social Work.

Also known as: (formerly Social Work 557.46 Anti Colonial and Anti Racist Praxis)

SOWK 506.title: Assessments in Social Work Practice
SOWK 506.description: Critical examination and application of approaches to assessment within different fields of social work practice.
SOWK 506.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Social Work.

SOWK 508.title: Child Welfare
SOWK 508.description: A critical examination of the socio-historical context, emerging theoretical and practice models, competing orientations and tensions, and evidence-based research related to child welfare in Canada.
SOWK 508.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Social Work.

Also known as: (formerly Social Work 551.05/551.13 Child Welfare)

SOWK 510.title: Children's Mental Health
SOWK 510.description: Focuses on the foundations of children's mental health, including assessment tools and intervention strategies.
SOWK 510.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Social Work.

Also known as: (formerly Social Work 555.03 Children's Mental Health)

SOWK 512.title: Critical Race Theory
SOWK 512.description: This course explores the foundations and central tenets of critical race theory and their relevance in local and global contexts.
SOWK 512.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Social Work.

Also known as: (formerly Social Work 557.47 Critical Race Theory)

SOWK 514.title: FASD and Child Welfare Practice
SOWK 514.description: Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorder is a leading cause of disability globally and this course focuses on social work interventions for families and individuals who often intersect with child welfare, justice and social service systems.
SOWK 514.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Social Work.

Also known as: (formerly Social Work 555.15 FASD and Child Welfare Practice)

SOWK 516.title: Forensic Social Work
SOWK 516.description: Focuses on how social work practice intersects with the criminal justice system, including restorative justice principles and approaches, the relationship between criminalization and victimization, integrating a trauma-informed lens to practice, and vulnerable populations.
SOWK 516.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Social Work.

Also known as: (formerly Social Work 557.36 Social Work and Criminal Justice System)

SOWK 518.title: Gerontological Social Work
SOWK 518.description: Examines contexts, theories, practice models and skill development in the field of gerontological social work.
SOWK 518.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Social Work.

Also known as: (formerly Social Work 553.03 Gerontology)

SOWK 520.title: Human Sexuality and Social Work
SOWK 520.description: Critically examines contemporary human sexuality topics in the context of social work theory, practice, and research. Topics may include reproductive justice, pleasure and the body, sex work, and sexual violence and consent.
SOWK 520.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Social Work.

Also known as: (formerly Social Work 553.07 Human Sexuality and Social Work)

SOWK 522.title: International Social Work and Social Development
SOWK 522.description: Critical examination of global social issues and challenges. Exploration and application of social work skills to practice, social action, ethics, global social policy, and global engagement.

SOWK 524.title: Intimate Partner Violence
SOWK 524.description: Critically explores how intimate partner violence occurs while considering intersecting oppressions on families, examining challenges for addressing safety and considers interventions within the diverse contexts of relationships.
SOWK 524.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Social Work.

Also known as: (formerly Social Work 551.19 Intimate Partner Violence)

SOWK 526.title: Loss and Grief
SOWK 526.description: Examines critical theories, responses and practice models and approaches to loss and grief from a social work perspective.
SOWK 526.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Social Work.

Also known as: (formerly Social Work 551.02 Loss and Grief)

SOWK 528.title: Practicing Self Care and Social Care
SOWK 528.description: Brings together theory, practice, and policy to contend with the history, philosophy and experiences of care, emphasizing experiential teaching and learning and the design of a personal framework for ethical care.
SOWK 528.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Social Work.

Also known as: (formerly Social Work 557.40 Practicing Self-Care and Social Care)

SOWK 530.title: Rural and Northern Social Work Practice
SOWK 530.description: Explores the unique culture of rural and northern communities and implications for social work practice.
SOWK 530.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Social Work.

SOWK 536.title: Slavery, Exploitation and Human Trafficking
SOWK 536.description: Introduces the link between slavery and human trafficking, critically examining different types of exploitation and promoting understanding of risk factors to better recognize, protect and assist trafficked persons and to help safeguard their rights.
SOWK 536.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Social Work.

SOWK 538.title: Social Work Practice and Disability Justice
SOWK 538.description: Critically examines social work theories and practice responses to disability justice within current socio-political and economic local and global contexts.
SOWK 538.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Social Work.

Also known as: (formerly Social Work 555.51 Social Work and Critical Disability)

SOWK 540.title: Social Work and Neurobiology
SOWK 540.description: Synthesizes foundational elements of neurological development within a social work frame that encompasses a bio-psycho-social perspective, and includes a focus on attachment, memory, and information processing impacted by trauma and substance abuse in the context of social work practice.
SOWK 540.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Social Work.

Also known as: (formerly Social Work 557.35 Social Work and Neurobiology)

SOWK 542.title: Social Work in Health Care
SOWK 542.description: Critically examines contexts, theories, evidence-based interventions, and skill development related to social work practice in the health care system.
SOWK 542.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Social Work.

Also known as: (formerly Social Work 553.08 Social Work in Health Care)

SOWK 544.title: Social Work in Urban Inner Cities
SOWK 544.description: Explores socio-historical contexts, critical theoretical and direct practice models for working with vulnerable community members in urban inner cities.
SOWK 544.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Social Work.

Also known as: (formerly Social Work 555.12/557.28 SOWK in the Inner City)

SOWK 546.title: Social Work Practice with Immigrants and Refugees
SOWK 546.description: Focuses on immigration and migration, including immigrant settlement and integration, irregular migration, global refugee crisis, forced migration, and working with newcomers in social work practice.
SOWK 546.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Social Work.

Also known as: (formerly Social Work 553.01 Social Work Practice with Immigrants and Refugees)

SOWK 548.title: Social Work Practice with Gender and Sexually Diverse People
SOWK 548.description: Critically examines the intersectionality of diverse gender and sexual identities and explores ethical and practice considerations for the social work profession.
SOWK 548.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Social Work.

Also known as: (formerly Social Work 555.54 Social Work and LGBTQ Communities)

SOWK 550.title: Spirituality and Social Work
SOWK 550.description: Critically examines the significance and diversity of spirituality and transpersonal theory; and the knowledge, skills and attitudes required for spiritually sensitive social work practice.
SOWK 550.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Social Work.

Also known as: (formerly Social Work 557.19 Spirituality and SOWK)

SOWK 551.title: Selected Topics: Social Work Interventions
SOWK 551.description:
Focuses on theory and practice related to social work interventions.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SOWK 552.title: Tools for Social Justice and Reconciliation
SOWK 552.description: Focuses on the utilization of multiple strategies to affect social change; and enhancing knowledge and comfort with community-based social justice practice through experience, theory, stories, and reflection.
SOWK 552.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Social Work.

Also known as: (formerly Social Work 551.06 Tools for Social Justice and Reconciliation)

SOWK 553.title: Selected Topics: Fields of Practice
SOWK 553.description:
Examines contexts, theories, practice models and skill development in specialized fields of practice.

Antirequisite: Credit for Social Work 553.37 and 428 will not be allowed.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SOWK 554.title: Trauma-Informed Practice in Mental Health
SOWK 554.description: Learners critically examine theoretical knowledge and develop practical skills to provide trauma-informed care, within an intersectional framework, in all stages of social work practice.
SOWK 554.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Social Work.

Also known as: (formerly Social Work 553.35 Mental Health and Trauma)

SOWK 555.title: Selected Topics: Practice with Selected Populations
SOWK 555.description:
Explores contexts, theories and practice models in working with specific populations.

Antirequisite: Credit for Social Work 555.55 and 429 will not be allowed.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SOWK 556.title: Animal Assisted Practice
SOWK 556.description: An introduction to the human-animal bond and the role of animal assisted activities and therapy across the lifespan and in a variety of social work and related practice contexts.
SOWK 556.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Bachelor of Social Work.

SOWK 557.title: Selected Topics: Contexts for Practice
SOWK 557.description:
Examines social work practice in specific contexts.

Antirequisite: Credit for Social Work 557.01 (International Social Work), 557.16 (International Social Work) and 437 will not be allowed.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SOWK 590.title: Final Practicum
SOWK 590.description: Learners engage in 400 hours of supervised Social Work practice building social work competence in various settings.
SOWK 590.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the BSW University Transfer route and a minimum of 81 units; or admission to the BSW Alberta Social Work Diploma route and a minimum of 81 units; or admission to the BSW After-Degree route and a minimum of 27 units.

Corequisite: Social Work 592

Antirequisite: Credit for Social Work 590 and Social Work 412 will not be allowed.

SOWK 592.title: Final Integrative Seminar
SOWK 592.description: Learners integrate academic knowledge with practice experience, engage in critically reflective practice, and demonstrate the values and ethics guiding Social Work practice. Learners evolve their personal practice frameworks in preparation for graduation as professional Social Workers.
SOWK 592.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BSW University Transfer route and a minimum of 81 units; or admission to the BSW Alberta Social Work Diploma route and a minimum of 81 units; or admission to the BSW After-Degree route and a minimum of 27 units.

Corequisite: Social Work 590.

Antirequisite: Credit for Social Work 592 and Social Work 413 will not be allowed.

SOWK 600.title: Social Justice & Theory in ASWP
SOWK 600.description: Examines concepts of culture, identities, oppression and social differentiation in relationship to theories of social justice, at all levels of professional practice.
SOWK 600.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MSW with a BSW; or the MSW with a non-BSW and completion of 27 units of foundation courses; or the Graduate Certificate in Advanced Social Work Practice.

SOWK 601.title: Clinical Work with Individuals
SOWK 601.description: Critical examination and application of evidence-based, anti-oppressive, anti-racist and decolonizing modalities and practices when working with diverse individuals.
SOWK 601.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MSW with a BSW and a specialization in Clinical Social Work Practice; or the MSW with a non-BSW and a specialization in Clinical Social Work Practice and completion of 27 units of foundation courses; or the Graduate Certificate in Clinical Social Work Practice with specialization in Individuals, Families and Groups. 

Also known as: (formerly Social Work 610.03 Clinical Work with Individuals)

SOWK 602.title: Research and Philosophy in Advanced Social Work Practice
SOWK 602.description: Explores social work research through examination of various paradigms, methods and approaches (eg., qualitative, quantitative, Indigenous methodologies, mixed methods, participatory action research, arts-based), and applies social work research to practice.
SOWK 602.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MSW with a BSW; or the MSW with a non-BSW and completion of 27 units of foundation courses; or the Graduate Certificate in Advanced Social Work Practice.

SOWK 603.title: Clinical Work with Families
SOWK 603.description: Critical examination and application of evidence-based, anti-oppressive, anti-racist and decolonizing modalities and practices when working with diverse families.
SOWK 603.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MSW with a BSW and a specialization in Clinical Social Work Practice; or the MSW with a non-BSW and a specialization in Clinical Social Work Practice and completion of 27 units of foundation courses; or the Graduate Certificate in Clinical Social Work Practice with specialization in Individuals, Families and Groups. 

Also known as: (formerly Social Work 612.03 Clinical Work with Families)

SOWK 604.title: Advanced Practice Theories in Context
SOWK 604.description: Examines theoretical models, philosophical frameworks and ethical foundations of social work practice as a means to facilitate change while locating social work's development and current practice in historical, economic, political, socio-cultural and environmental contexts.

SOWK 605.title: Clinical Work with Groups
SOWK 605.description: Critical examination and application of evidence-based, anti-oppressive, anti-racist and decolonizing modalities and practices in group work.
SOWK 605.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Social Work 601 and 603.

Also known as: (formerly Social Work 614.03 Clinical Work with Groups)

SOWK 606.title: Advanced Policy Practice in Context
SOWK 606.description: Explores the influences of public policy on the lives, relationships, and well-being of individuals, families, groups and communities, while examining the relationship between social justice in the policy-making process and the role of social workers in creating and shaping policy.

SOWK 607.title: Clinical Work with Other Professionals
SOWK 607.description: Professional social work practice within interdisciplinary organizations and agencies, including ethical decision making in interprofessional, interdisciplinary or transdisciplinary teams.
SOWK 607.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Social Work 601 and 603.

Also known as: (formerly Social Work 616.03 Clinical Work with Other Professionals)
