STAT 619.title: Bayesian Statistics
STAT 619.description: Fundamentals of Bayesian inference, single and multiparameter models, hierarchical models, regression models, generalized linear models, advanced computational methods, Markov chain Monte Carlo.
STAT 619.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

STAT 625.title: Multivariate Analysis
STAT 625.description: Normal distribution. Statistical inference: confidence regions, hypothesis tests, analysis of variance, simultaneous confidence intervals. Principal components. Factor Analysis. Discrimination and classification. Canonical correlation analysis.
STAT 625.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

STAT 631.title: Computational Statistics
STAT 631.description: Unconstrained optimization methods, simulation and random number generation, Bayesian inference and Monte Carlo methods, Markov chain Monte Carlo, non-parametric inference, classical inference and other topics. An emphasis will be placed on computational implementation of algorithms.
STAT 631.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

STAT 633.title: Survival Models
STAT 633.description: Advanced topics in survival models such as the product limit estimator, the cox proportional hazards model, time-dependent covariates, types of censorship.
STAT 633.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

STAT 635.title: Generalized Linear Models
STAT 635.description: Exponential family of distributions, binary data models, loglinear models, overdispersion, quasi-likelihood methods, generalized additive models, longitudinal data and generalized estimating equations, model adequacy checks.
STAT 635.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

STAT 637.title: Non-linear Regression
STAT 637.description: Topics include but are not restricted to selections from: linear approximations; model specification; various iterative techniques; assessing fit; multiresponse parameter estimation; models defined by systems of differential equations; graphical summaries of inference regions; curvature measures.
STAT 637.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

STAT 641.title: Statistical Learning
STAT 641.description: Introduction and Linear Regression; Classification; Regularization; Model Assessment and Selection; Support Vector Machines; Unsupervised Learning; Tree-Based Methods; Other Topics (e.g., Neural Networks, Graphical Models, High-Dimensional Data).
STAT 641.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

STAT 701.title: Theory of Probability I
STAT 701.description: Probability spaces, integration, expected value, laws of large numbers, weak convergence, characteristic functions, central limit theorems, limit theorems in Rd, conditional expectation, introduction to martingales.
STAT 701.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

STAT 703.title: Theory of Probability II
STAT 703.description: Stopping times, renewal theory, martingales, almost sure convergence, Radon-Nikodym derivatives, Doob's inequality, square integrable martingales, uniform integrability, Markov chains, stationary measure, Birkhoff's Ergodic Theorem, Brownian motion, stopping times, hitting times, Donsker's Theorem, Brownian bridge, laws of the iterated logarithm.
STAT 703.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Statistics 701 and admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

STAT 721.title: Statistical Inference
STAT 721.description: Statistical models, likelihoods, maximum likelihood estimators, likelihood ratio, Wald and score tests, confidence intervals, bounds and regions, Bayesian estimation and testing, basic large sample theory, estimating equations, jackknife, bootstrap and permutation.
STAT 721.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

STAT 723.title: Theory of Hypothesis Testing
STAT 723.description: Likelihood ratio (LR), union-intersection, most powerful, unbiased and invariant tests, Neyman-Pearson Lemma, Karlin-Rubin Theorem, confidence interval (CI), pivotal quantities, shortest length and shortest expected length CI, uniformly most accurate CI, confidence region, simultaneous CI, large-sample tests (Wald's, score, LR tests), Bayesian hypothesis testing, analysis of variance and linear models.
STAT 723.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Statistics 721 and admission to a graduate program in Mathematics and Statistics or consent of the Department.

STST 601.title: MSS 1st Term Co-operative Education
STST 601.description: Strategic Studies first term Co-operative Education work placement.
STST 601.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the co-operative education option of the MSS program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

STST 604.title: MSS First Term Internship
STST 604.description: Strategic Studies first term internship work placement.
STST 604.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Military and Strategic Studies program.

Also known as: (formerly Strategic Studies 601)

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

STST 605.title: MSS Second Term Internship
STST 605.description: Strategic Studies second term internship work placement.
STST 605.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Military and Strategic Studies program.

Also known as: (formerly Strategic Studies 602)

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

STST 609.title: The Canadian Military in the Second World War
STST 609.description: An examination of the political parameters imposed by the Canadian government, the quality of Canadian leadership, and the \"fit\" between British forms of military organization and the fighting quality of Canadian soldiers, sailors and airmen.

STST 610.title: Questions and Methods
STST 610.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to a Military, Security and Strategic Studies graduate program.

STST 611.title: Canadian Military Studies
STST 611.description: Canadian military studies, excepting the two world wars. Topics will include the evolution of Canadian defence policy, past or present, the development and evolution of the Canadian Forces or any of its main elements (army, navy or air force), Canadian military operability with the military forces of Allied nations, and the relationship between Canadian foreign policy and the use of the Canadian military.

STST 612.title: Questions and Methods II
STST 612.description: Methodological and professionalization questions and issues applicable to the practical and academic practice of military, security and strategic studies.
STST 612.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Strategic Studies 610 and admission to a Military, Security and Strategic Studies graduate program.

STST 613.title: The Canadian Military in the First World War
STST 613.description:
The development and operational achievements of the Canadian Expeditionary Force, wartime civil-military relations and conscription politics.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for both Strategic Studies 613 and History 520 will not be allowed.

STST 647.title: 21st Century Security Issues
STST 647.description: An introduction to a variety of 21st century security issues with an emphasis on the political, economic, historical, and social contexts in which security issues arise.
STST 647.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master of Strategic Studies graduate program and consent of the Graduate Program Director.

STST 649.title: Special Topics in Military, Security and Strategic Studies

STST 651.title: Reading Seminar
STST 651.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Graduate Program Director.

STST 653.title: Research Seminar
STST 653.description: A research paper will be written as part of this course.
STST 653.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Graduate Program Director.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

STST 662.title: Advanced Studies in Canadian Arctic Security
STST 662.description: The Canadian Arctic is an emerging area of concern due to changes scarcely imaginable even a few years ago. Examines the nature of some of these changes -- e.g. climate change and the northern seas' dramatically changing ice conditions, growing recognition of the region's resource wealth, and evolving international relations in the circumpolar region -- and what they mean for Canadian Arctic Security.

STST 663.title: Wars - Causes & Aftermaths
STST 663.description: An examination of the complexity and experience of conflict and war as well as the broader institutions that govern post-conflict recovery and transition in the 20th and 21st centuries. Special attention will be paid to the methodological complexities of studying violence

STST 751.title: Reading Seminar
STST 751.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Permission of the Graduate Coordinator.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

STST 753.title: Research Seminar
STST 753.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Graduate Co-ordinator.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SUSE 300.title: Introduction to Sustainable Systems Design
SUSE 300.description: Introduction to the fundamentals of sustainable systems engineering design. Projects focus on design for justice, centering on the voices and habitats of those who are directly impacted by the outcomes of the design process. Critical thinking and problem-solving skills development; systems thinking, sustainability metrics and assessment tools including introductions to material flow analysis and material budget, carbon footprint analysis, LCA, environmental health risk assessment, and product development for a circular economy.

SUSE 303.title: Signals, Instrumentation, and Data
SUSE 303.description: An introduction to essentials of instrumentation, measurement, and data analysis in sustainable systems. Continuous and discontinuous signals, analog and digital measurements, sampling, and analog to digital conversion. Introduction to data collection using embedded systems and data analysis techniques. Topics will be reinforced through weekly hands-on labs with examples in relevant areas of sustainable systems.

SUSE 307.title: Numerical Methods and Computing Tools for Sustainable Systems Engineering
SUSE 307.description: The theory and use of numerical computational procedures to develop sustainable engineering solutions. Introduction to computing tools in engineering. Methods for solving engineering problems using computing tools for the solution of multi-variable linear and non-linear equations; polynomial curve-fitting; single and multi-variable integration; function optimization; differential equations. Data representation and visualization.

SUSE 311.title: Engineering Thermodynamics and Fluid Mechanics
SUSE 311.description: The fundamentals of fluid mechanics, thermodynamics, and heat transfer required to analyze energy systems, including wind and hydro turbines, solar thermal processes, and power cycles. The first and second laws of thermodynamics with emphasis on efficiency measures along with the interaction between heat flow and second law efficiency are considered. Fluid mechanics topics include control volume analysis of typical fluid systems, the application of the conservation equations of axial and angular momentum and energy and application to wind and hydro turbines and pumping systems. Laminar and turbulent flow and their effects on fluid forces and important concepts like boundary layers are covered and a brief introduction to fluid measurements is given.
SUSE 311.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Engineering 201 or 212; and Mathematics 275 or Applied Mathematics 217.

SUSE 315.title: Engineering Economics and Decision Making for Sustainability
SUSE 315.description:
Knowledge and tools to assess broader performance of engineered systems; evaluation of trade-offs among economic, environmental, and social criteria; concept of cost benefit analysis beyond financial analysis; social discount rate; valuation of externalities; market failure; input-output analysis including material and environmental impact extensions; valuation of ecosystem services and natural capital; limits to growth; efficiency and equity.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Sustainable Systems Engineering 315 and any of Economics 201, Engineering 209 will not be allowed.

SUSE 400.title: Design of Sustainable Systems
SUSE 400.description: Team-based design applying conceptual and preliminary design principles to sustainable systems engineering projects. Use of quantitative tools to support the design. Application of the design process to open-ended projects that encompass the subdisciplines of sustainable systems engineering. Effective oral and written communication of the design proposal through engineering visualizations, technical reports and models.

SUSE 401.title: Remote Northern Sustainable Systems
SUSE 401.description:
Learn key ideas and strategies related to environmentally sustainable community development with a focus on food, water, and energy. Through pattern and data mapping, research and data analysis, and site visits, the course explores community needs and the challenges of environmentally conscious living. The renewable energy systems at the field station will be investigated along with energy usage. Learners delve into the common misconceptions that lead to unsustainable social practices and how to counteract these fallacies through community education and engagement. 

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Sustainable Systems Engineering 401 and 403 will not be allowed. 

Notes: This is a field camp held at the Arctic Institute of North America's Kluane Lake Research Station. Students will be assessed a supplementary fee to cover the costs of the field camp.

SUSE 403.title: Northern Sustainable Systems
SUSE 403.description:
Learn key ideas and strategies related to environmentally sustainable community development with a focus on net zero communities and geo-powered communities. Through pattern and data mapping, research and data analysis, and site visits, the course explores community needs and the challenges of environmentally conscious living. The renewable energy systems at various sites and integration into local and community energy networks will be explored. 

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Sustainable Systems Engineering 403 and 401 will not be allowed. 

Notes: This is a  field-based course. Students will be assessed a supplementary fee to cover the costs of various field excursions.

SUSE 405.title: Research Methods and Policy for Sustainability
SUSE 405.description: Conceptualizing human-environment-non-human realities and knowledge into research design, addressing qualitative and quantitative evaluation of effective outcomes in transdisciplinary models. Develop and apply knowledge and tools to support braiding multiple knowledge systems and examining the 'rules' of research, with the intent to challenge biases in scientific knowledge through the lens of real-world complexity (i.e., wicked problems). The course includes the application of a transdisciplinary design process to an open-ended 'wicked problem' in sustainability by applying a systems thinking methodology.
SUSE 405.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Sustainable Systems Engineering 401 or 403.

SUSE 409.title: Regenerative Design Principles and Indigenous Knowledge Systems
SUSE 409.description: Explores principles of regenerative design and systems thinking through an Indigenous Knowledge Systems lens, whole systems thinking to create resilient and equitable systems that integrate the needs of society with the integrity of nature. Topics explored are grounded in Indigenous methodologies and epistemologies and explore Indigenous Knowledge and the intersection of sustainability science.

SUSE 463.title: Systems Modelling, Simulation, and Analysis
SUSE 463.description: Introduces a systems thinking approach for modelling engineering and urban systems with an emphasis on sustainability. With the complex, interdependent, and non-linear nature of real-world problems, this course presents dynamics modelling techniques from societal, environmental, and economical perspectives. The course will also enable students to perform modelling and simulation of complex systems applied to climate change, energy and environment, transportation policy, infectious disease modelling, natural resource management, and urban dynamics. Complex systems characterized by feedback structure and accumulation effects, causal loop diagrams, stock and flows, delay loops, systems behaviour, instability and oscillation will be discussed. Students will learn to use simulation models on case studies to develop conceptual and modelling skills for the design and analysis of engineering and sustainability systems in a dynamic world.
SUSE 463.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Digital Engineering 319 and 3 units from Sustainable Systems Engineering 315, Engineering 209, Economics 201, or Economics 209.

SUSE 511.title: Food, Agriculture, and Biomass Systems
SUSE 511.description: Resource requirements, ecological impacts, and sustainability for food, agriculture, and biomass systems. Methods of modelling and analysis: food production capacity, foodshed analyses, life cycle assessment, and system dynamics and integrated modelling. Topics may also include policy-related modelling, renewable sources and thermodynamics of biomass, ecological, social, health, political, legal, and economic dimensions of food, agriculture, and biomass.

SUSE 519.title: Special Topics in Sustainable Systems Engineering
SUSE 519.description: Advanced topics in Sustainable Systems Engineering.
SUSE 519.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

SUSE 579.title: Distributed Energy Sources/Remote Systems
SUSE 579.description: An introduction to distributed small energy systems, such as hydropower, marine and wind turbines, and photovoltaics, as components of remote systems providing power for communities and other applications too far from the electricity grid to be easily connected. The design of these systems will be considered through the need for storage to ensure continuity of supply and will use specialized software developed for this purpose. System control will be investigated, along with modelling of the electrical and additional loads, such as greenhouses or containerized hydroponics systems, water, and wastewater treatment.

SUSE 581.title: Energy Systems Modelling
SUSE 581.description: The complexity of modern energy systems driven by rapid changes in the underlying cost of resources, advances in technology, and environmental pressures. Students will be introduced to practical tools to model and optimize energy systems from technical, social, and policy perspectives. Systems considered in the course will range in scale from regional to national and involve a range of energy vectors. We will examine couplings between different sectors of the energy system, including impacts of electrification of transportation and residential heating. The evolving interaction between electricity systems and more general energy use will be highlighted.
SUSE 581.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Sustainable Systems Engineering 463 and Electrical Engineering 487.

SUSE 589.title: Industrial Ecology
SUSE 589.description: The philosophy behind the concept of Industrial Ecology is the focus on the understanding of interactions between technical, economic, social, and ecological systems and processes. The course aims at presenting the developments in research and application in the field of Industrial Ecology and discussing its role in strategic sustainable development both at the local and global scale with a focus on urban and industrial systems. This course equips students with systems perspective of understanding the implications of the decisions they make at different levels in practicing their profession and acting as consumers. Emphasis is given to understanding how environmental assessment and improvements are carried out with support from systems analytical methods such as material flow analysis, risk analysis, life cycle analysis, energy analysis, cost benefit analysis, and eco-efficiency analysis.
SUSE 589.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Sustainable Systems Engineering 463 and Energy and Environment, Engineering 503.

SUSE 591.title: Advanced Renewable Energy Systems
SUSE 591.description: Non-carbon energy generation technologies: solar-thermal and concentrated solar power, geothermal, and biomass, and their integration with wind and solar-photovoltaics in electricity systems that may have significant storage. Technologies using a heated working fluid working in cycles whose optimum performance is studied. Consideration is given to the resources needed for these technologies, their planning, their technical status, and future development. The use of geothermal and other technologies for space heating will also be studied.

SUSE 595.title: Sustainable Materials
SUSE 595.description: Comprehensive, systems-focused basis for selecting materials in new uses or as more sustainable alternatives; more eco-efficient alternatives, including technologies to reduce material intensity, renewably sourced materials, CO2 absorbing materials, nanotechnology applications for sustainable materials, recyclable materials and material solutions inspired by nature (biomimetic).
SUSE 595.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Engineering 317, Mechanical Engineering 317 or Civil Engineering 317.

SUSE 601.title: Sustainability Principles in Engineering Practice
SUSE 601.description: Systems thinking and design for a circular economy; tools for sustainability and regenerative engineering; sustainability development goals and targets; principles of sustainability and systems thinking through an Indigenous knowledge systems lens; learning from natural systems; Indigenous knowledge and the intersection of sustainability science; and application of sustainability principles in engineering projects.

SUSE 603.title: Decision Making for Sustainability
SUSE 603.description: Theory and application of decision-making approaches and tools for engineering decisions with environmental, social, and economic dimensions. Treatment and effective communication of uncertainty, evaluation of trade-offs, and incorporation of stakeholder preferences are a focus. Evaluation of both public and private decisions are considered. Topics covered include problem formulation, time value of money, decision trees, value of information, utility functions, cost-benefit analysis, multi-criteria decision-making, game theory, stage-dependent strategies, and risk communication.

SUSE 663.title: Systems Modeling, Simulation, and Analysis
SUSE 663.description:
Systems-thinking approach for modelling engineering and urban systems with an emphasis on sustainability. Dynamics modelling techniques from societal, environmental, and economical perspectives with complex, interdependent, and non-linear nature of real-world problems. Modelling and simulation of complex systems applied to climate change, energy and environment, transportation policy, infectious diseases, natural resource management, and urban dynamics. Complex systems characterized by feedback structure and accumulation effects, causal loop diagrams, stock and flows, delay loops, systems behaviour, instability and oscillation. Use of simulation models on case studies to develop conceptual and modelling skills for the design and analysis of engineering and sustainability systems in a dynamic world.

Also known as: (Sustainable Systems Engineering 463)

SUSE 679.title: Distributed Energy Sources/Remote Systems
SUSE 679.description:
Distributed small energy systems, such as hydropower, marine and wind turbines, and photovoltaics, as components of remote systems providing power for communities and other applications too far from the electricity grid to be easily connected. The design of these systems will be considered through the need for storage to ensure continuity of supply and will use specialized software developed for this purpose. System control will be investigated, along with modelling of the electrical and additional loads, such as greenhouses or containerized hydroponics systems, water, and wastewater treatment.

Also known as: (Sustainable Systems Engineering 579)

SUSE 681.title: Energy Systems Modeling
SUSE 681.description:
Complexity of modern energy systems driven by rapid changes in underlying cost of resources, advances in technology, and environmental pressures. Practical tools to model and optimize energy systems from technical, social, and policy perspectives. Systems will range in scale from regional to national and involve a range of energy vectors. Couplings between different sectors of the energy system, including impacts of electrification of transportation and residential heating. Evolving interaction between electricity systems and more general energy.

Also known as: (Sustainable Systems Engineering 581)

SUST 201.title: Exploring Sustainability
SUST 201.description:
Sustainability, both in theory and practice is complex and challenging, and offers a lens for understanding the world and our place in it as global citizens.  This course will present a wide range of interdisciplinary perspectives from the local to the global scale on the critically important concepts that include food systems, global poverty, gender equity, water scarcity, land stewardship, and the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Sustainability Studies 201 and University 207 will not be allowed.

SUST 401.title: Global Sustainability
SUST 401.description: We rely daily on global resources and services, and the stresses and impacts of local consumptions are felt disproportionately around the world. This course gives a deeper understanding of global sustainability focusing on three main parts: understanding sustainability, measuring and researching sustainability, and doing sustainability.

SUST 403.title: Research Methods in Sustainability
SUST 403.description: In order to tackle real world sustainability challenges, we must engage in them directly. Students participate in applied research projects that link sustainability foundations and principles from Sustainable Studies 201 and 401 to work with stakeholders directly to address their needs on campus, in the community and beyond.

SUST 501.title: Seminar: The Theory and Practice of Sustainability
SUST 501.description: Emphasizes reflection and integration through experiential learning experiences from research projects and applied problem solving. Students will apply the lessons learned through reflective writing, presentations, case studies, and career goals development.
SUST 501.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Sustainability Studies 403 and enrolment in the embedded Certificate in Sustainability Studies.

SUST 503.title: Directed Studies
SUST 503.description: Supervised independent study of a specific topic.
SUST 503.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent from the Academic Co-ordinator of Sustainability Studies.

SUST 505.title: Special Topics in Sustainability Studies
SUST 505.description:
Thematic inquiry related to special topics in sustainability studies.

Also known as: (formerly University 511)

SUST 605.title: Special Topics in Sustainability Studies
SUST 605.description:
Thematic inquiry related to special topics in sustainability studies.

Also known as: (formerly University 611)

TAP 201.title: National Language I
TAP 201.description: Instruction in the Language (or one of the languages) of the country of residence as part of a Term Abroad Program.

TAP 203.title: National Language II
TAP 203.description: A continuation of Term Abroad Program 201.
TAP 203.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Term Abroad Program 201 or consent of the Faculty of Humanities.

TDST 600.title: Transdisciplinary Scholarship
TDST 600.description:
Exploration of transdisciplinary scholarship from a range of perspectives including science and engineering, social sciences and humanities, and healthcare. Emphasis will be placed on how applied transdisciplinary scholarship in the area differs from and complements inter- and multidisciplinary scholarship. 

Prerequisites: Admission to a program in Transdisciplinary Studies or Transdisciplinary Research.

TDST 601.title: Transdisciplinary Knowledge Engagement
TDST 601.description:
An introduction to integrative knowledge engagement with a focus on reciprocal partnerships with a range of community and industry stakeholders to close the gap between research and policy or practice. A focus on the tools and techniques required to ensure that research is collaborative and findings are effectively translated for the relevant stakeholders. 

Prerequisites: Consent of the Faculty of Graduate Studies.

TDST 606.title: Directed Studies in Transdisciplinary Research
TDST 606.description:
Independent study under the direction of a faculty member.

Prerequisites: Consent of the Transdisciplinary Research Program.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

TDST 607.title: Directed Studies in Transdisciplinary Research
TDST 607.description:
Independent study under the direction of a faculty member.

Prerequisites: Consent of the Transdisciplinary Research Program.

TDST 605.01.description:
Examination of work in a transdisciplinary research area.

Prerequisites: Consent of the Graduate Program Director.

TDST 605.02.title: Topics in Social Research Methods
TDST 605.02.description:
Examination of work in a transdisciplinary research area.

Prerequisites: Consent of the Graduate Program Director.

TDST 605.03.title: Topics in Ethics and Sustainability
TDST 605.03.description:
Examination of work in a transdisciplinary research area.

Prerequisites: Consent of the Graduate Program Director.

TDST 605.04.title: Topics in One Health
TDST 605.04.description:
Examination of work in a transdisciplinary research area.

Prerequisites: Consent of the Graduate Program Director.

TOUR 309.title: Introduction to Leisure, Tourism and Society
TOUR 309.description: An interdisciplinary introduction to the concepts, methods and practices of leisure, recreation and tourism studies.
TOUR 309.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 30 units.

TOUR 409.title: Travel and Tourism Management
TOUR 409.description: Economic, social, cultural, political, and technological dimensions of tourism, in particular changing travel markets, industry structure, evolving issues and problems.

UBST 253.title: Introduction to Cities
UBST 253.description:
A broad introductory survey, from diverse perspectives, of the processes that shape cities and urban life.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Urban Studies 253 and Geography 253 will not be allowed.

UBST 311.title: The Gendered City
UBST 311.description: Introduction to urban gender issues from historical and spatial perspectives. Issues such as the gendering of urban design and planning, daily urban activities, urban labour markets, urban politics, gentrification, suburbanization, and identity construction in urban places are addressed.
UBST 311.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Urban Studies 253 or Geography 253.

UBST 313.title: The City in Film
UBST 313.description: Introduction to the representation of cities in film. Theoretical understandings of urban processes are linked to urban experiences as portrayed in urban film. Topics may include changing urban form, suburbanization, economic restructuring, racial conflict, community formation, urban politics, and more. May focus on particular cities around the world.
UBST 313.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Urban Studies 253, Geography 253, Anthropology 379, Sociology 353.

UBST 451.title: Planning in the Canadian City
UBST 451.description: Introduction to Canadian urban planning theory and practice. Focuses on the history of planning, and aspects of practice such as neighbourhood planning, historic preservation, urban design and long-range planning.

UBST 461.title: The Transit City
UBST 461.description: An exploration of the relationships among public transit, urban form, and land use planning and policy in the context of challenges such as climate change, energy shortages, widespread urbanization and traffic congestion.

UBST 494.title: Sustainable Cities I
UBST 494.description: Field exploration of cities on the cutting edge of urban sustainability and smart innovation. Historical urban development and economic, cultural, political and regional processes are addressed, laying the groundwork for understanding how innovation in sustainability and smart planning are achieved. Resources, housing, food security, transportation, energy, and governance issues are considered.

UBST 495.title: Sustainable Cities II
UBST 495.description: Further field exploration of cities on the cutting edge of sustainability and smart innovation, building from Urban Studies 494. Economic, political, and cultural aspects of sustainability and smart innovation are considered, focusing on urban form, mobility systems, social geography, and political processes. Theoretical and practical links between urban, municipal, and national policies, and global sustainability discourses are made.

UBST 501.title: Research in Selected Topics
UBST 501.description: An examination of selected topics in Urban Studies in a lecture format.
UBST 501.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

UBST 505.title: Advanced Topics in Urban Studies
UBST 505.description: An examination of selected topics in Urban Studies in a seminar format.
UBST 505.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to Urban Studies major or minor and completion of 75 units (12.5 full-course equivalents).

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

UBST 553.title: Seminar in Urban Theory
UBST 553.description: Overview of contemporary themes in urban theory such as modernity and postmodernity, political economy, production of social difference, public and private space, globalization, inequality, and urban sustainability. Topics may vary depending on developments in the field and student interests.

UBST 591.title: Capstone in Urban Studies
UBST 591.description: Capstone course applying the broad interdisciplinary training of the Urban Studies Program to selected problems in urban studies. Collaborative research and analysis is stressed.
UBST 591.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 90 units and admission to the Urban Studies Major or Minor.

UBST 596.title: Directed Independent Study
UBST 596.description: Advanced study of a particular topic under the direct supervision of a faculty member.
UBST 596.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

UBST 598.title: Honours Thesis
UBST 598.description: Completion of supervised individual research and completion of an Honours thesis under the supervision of a faculty member. A presentation within the honours program is expected.
UBST 598.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Urban Studies Honours program.

UNEX 200.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Acceptance into an exchange program.
