UNIV 201.title: Global Challenges Inquiry I
UNIV 201.description: Students will engage in inquiry-based learning to explore solutions to a complex, socially relevant problem using knowledge, evidence, and methods from multiple disciplines, under the guidance of University of Calgary experts. Examples of problems include poverty, water and food security, child health, racial conflict, and gender discrimination.
UNIV 201.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Completed fewer than 18 units at the time of registration.

UNIV 203.title: Global Challenges Inquiry II
UNIV 203.description: Students will continue to engage in inquiry-based learning to explore solutions to a complex, socially relevant problem using knowledge, evidence, and methods from multiple disciplines, under the guidance of University of Calgary experts.
UNIV 203.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): University 201 and completed fewer than 18 units at the time of registration.

UNIV 205.title: Effective Learning Strategies
UNIV 205.description:
Theories, research and practice regarding learning and thinking in adult learners. The importance of metacognition, attention, memory, emotions, motivation and attitudes to learning will be discussed. Students will apply the theory and research to their own learning experiences.

Note: Sections may be restricted to specific student groups. Please check the class notes for details.

UNIV 302.title: Research on Global Challenges
UNIV 302.description: Explore responses and solutions to global challenges by conducting supervised research. Develop research skills with an interdisciplinary cohort of students, investigating topics such as poverty, hunger, health, education, gender, climate change, racialization, and economic growth.
UNIV 302.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Faculty of Arts and completion of 30 units.

UNIV 304.title: Experiential Learning in the Workplace
UNIV 304.description: Introduction to the foundational and transferable skills that support success in workplace, volunteer and professional settings. Through a current paid work, volunteer or career exploration experience, students will identify skills that support their success in the experience, reflect on strengths and areas for future growth, and learn how to articulate academic and foundational skills to employers. Foundational skills include; communication, creativity and innovation, problem solving, adaptability and collaboration.

UNIV 401.title: Topic in Interdisciplinary Studies
UNIV 401.description:
The focused examination of a topic from a variety of interdisciplinary perspectives.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

UNIV 501.title: Experiential Learning
UNIV 501.description: An application of theory in a community or workplace setting.
UNIV 501.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the student's faculty.

UNIV 601.title: Ethic Research With Human Subject
UNIV 601.description: A multidisciplinary course addressing issues in research with human subjects. Topics include theoretical approaches to understanding ethics, respect for persons, benefit and harm, confidentiality and publication, and selection of research subjects. Taught by a multidisciplinary team with very broad experience on research ethics boards.
UNIV 601.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Course Co-ordinator.

UNIV 511.02.title: Theoretical Basis for Interdisciplinary Intervention and Design

VETM 360.title: Introduction to Veterinary Medicine
VETM 360.description: Students explore how people associate with animals, the issues that arise from these associations and the roles that veterinarians play in these contexts. Students observe animals as companions, in sport, for food, and in research. The structure and function of the major livestock industries and the roles that veterinarians occupy within those industries are examined.
VETM 360.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

VETM 400.title: Clinical Presentations II
VETM 400.description: Building on Veterinary Medicine 300, students continue to develop analytic and non-analytic diagnostic reasoning skills. These skills include developing schemata and differential diagnoses lists, making decisions about using appropriate diagnostic tests, interpreting and integrating data from those tests, and using foundational knowledge to diagnose common clinical presentations.
VETM 400.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 405.title: Clinical Skills II
VETM 405.description: Building on Veterinary Medicine 305, students develop skills in basic surgical principles, clinical examination of relevant body systems, clinical and anatomic pathology, and parasitology. Students also gain hands-on experience in practical clinical intervention, case management, and disease prevention.
VETM 405.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 407.title: Professional Skills II
VETM 407.description: Building on Veterinary Medicine 307, professional skills competencies and knowledge are enhanced with additional focus on small business management skills, relationship-centered practice and self-care. Legal issues regarding veterinary practice are discussed. Research and informatics skills are used to identify knowledge gaps, generate testable hypotheses, and design experiments.
VETM 407.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 411.title: Basic Surgical Principles
VETM 411.description: A comprehensive introduction to general veterinary surgery principles across species. Provides students with a foundation in the basic principles of soft tissue and orthopedic surgery that can then be used to develop their hands-on surgical skills.
VETM 411.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 420.title: Health Management
VETM 420.description: Building on Veterinary Medicine 344, introduces additional epidemiological concepts used in veterinary medicine. These concepts include appropriate use and choice of diagnostic tests, developing a structured approach for investigating disease outbreaks, exploring strategies and effectiveness for treating and controlling disease, and developing evidence-based protocols.
VETM 420.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 422.title: Virology
VETM 422.description: Fundamental knowledge on the nature of viruses and prions are imparted through clinical, cellular and molecular analysis of important diseases of animals and, if inter-transmissible, humans. Students learn to develop diagnostic plans and understand principles of laboratory diagnostic testing. Implementation of intervention measures for viral and prion infections and diseases are discussed.
VETM 422.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 423.title: Bacteriology
VETM 423.description: Introduction to fundamental principles of bacteriology, and bacterial diseases of domestic animals. Provides an understanding of how bacteria interact with the environment and the animal host, and how bacterial virulence mechanisms lead to animal diseases. Diagnosis of bacterial infections, and matching of appropriate preventive and control measures with different pathogens are discussed.
VETM 423.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 424.title: Parasitology
VETM 424.description: Introduction to fundamental principles of parasitism in domestic and wild animals. Emphasis is placed on understanding the occurrence, transmission and impacts of parasites, and diagnosis of parasitic diseases of clinical, trade, and zoonotic importance in North America.
VETM 424.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 425.title: Systemic Pathology
VETM 425.description: Using a species-specific approach to review common disease conditions. Students identify and describe common gross and microscopic lesions and formulate a morphologic diagnosis. Disease pathogenesis, tissue sampling, sample submission, and the value of ancillary diagnostic testing, and communicating post-mortem findings are emphasized.
VETM 425.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 440.title: One Health and Veterinary Practice
VETM 440.description: Students will use a One Health approach to explore key issues at the interface of humans, animals and the environment. Students will integrate information, apply critical thinking skills to manage risks and develop prevention and control strategies for zoonoses and antimicrobial resistance; enhance food production, food safety and animal welfare; and protect the environment.
VETM 440.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

VETM 442.title: Clinical Pathology
VETM 442.description: Students develop a systematic approach to the use, evaluation and correct interpretation of routine clinical pathology tests. Integration of laboratory results with the patient's clinical presentation is emphasized. Correct interpretation of routine laboratory tests, communication of results, and appropriate integration of lab tests into decision-making in daily practice are covered.
VETM 442.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 443.title: Clinical Pharmacology and Toxicology
VETM 443.description: Effective and safe use of drugs in veterinary medicine. Basic principles of pharmacology, including mechanisms of action, for the major drug classes. Clinical toxicology principles that apply to common poisonings and adverse drug reactions.
VETM 443.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 445.title: Diagnostic Imaging
VETM 445.description: Introduction to principles and uses of common diagnostic imaging modalities. The theoretical basis behind each imaging technology, the acquisition of quality images, and the ability to interpret and describe normal and abnormal findings are emphasized. Control measures for working safely with diagnostic imaging equipment are examined.
VETM 445.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 461.title: Outbreak Investigation
VETM 461.description: Building on Veterinary Medicine 420, students further develop the framework for investigating outbreaks of disease. Students investigate a series of simulated outbreaks, applying steps to determine whether an outbreak exists, establishing a case definition, describing the epidemiology of the disease, generating and testing hypotheses, and communicating their findings.
VETM 461.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.    

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

VETM 462.title: Foreign Animal Disease
VETM 462.description: Students work through a simulation of an incursion of foreign animal disease into Canada. The simulation and background gives students experience working with disease surveillance, case identification, emergency preparedness, and the role of public practice veterinarians in maintaining the safety of Canadian livestock.
VETM 462.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 464.title: Career Options and Field Experiences in Veterinary Medicine
VETM 464.description: Students are exposed to career options in clinical and non-clinical veterinary medicine.
VETM 464.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

VETM 465.title: Applied Nutrition
VETM 465.description: Core concepts pertaining to nutritional requirements, feeding regimes, and nutritional disorders in production and companion animals are examined. Feeding management of exotic animals is also discussed. Emphasis is placed on practical application of nutritional concepts in production and companion animals.
VETM 465.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 501.title: Clinical Presentations III
VETM 501.description: Building on Veterinary Medicine 300 and 400, students continue their development of diagnostic reasoning skills and problem management in veterinary medicine. Students synthesize comprehensive treatment plans that take into account therapeutic approaches, outcomes, feasibility, economics, client expectations, compliance, public health, regulations, and the environment.
VETM 501.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 505.title: Clinical Skills III
VETM 505.description: Building on Veterinary Medicine 305 and 405, students gain experience in clinical evaluations, routine anaesthesia and surgery. Diagnostic and therapeutic skills, practical clinical intervention, case management, and disease prevention knowledge and skills are further developed.
VETM 505.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 506.title: Investigative Veterinary Medicine and Science Communication
VETM 506.description: Building on first and second year training in investigative medicine, students will have the opportunity to answer a real-world veterinary question while working under the guidance of faculty mentors. Based on their interests, students will choose from conducting a literature review on a controversial topic in veterinary medicine, analysis and preparation of existing data for publication, or preparation/planning for participation in a fourth year Investigative Medicine rotation. Principles and application of evidence-based medicine, critical thinking and effective communication of science to stakeholder groups will be emphasized.
VETM 506.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

VETM 508.title: Professional Skills III
VETM 508.description: Building on Veterinary Medicine 307 and 407, students will develop professional skills necessary for dealing with challenging issues in veterinary medicine. The concept of the healthy veterinarian and self-management will be expanded.
VETM 508.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 521.title: Equine Medicine and Surgery
VETM 521.description: Prepares students for general equine practice by providing the foundational knowledge needed for diagnosing and treating  common equine diseases using medical or surgical approaches. Emphasizes the importance of professional conduct in the context of equine practice and promotes life-long continuing education.
VETM 521.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 522.title: Small Animal Medicine and Surgery
VETM 522.description: Prepares students for small animal practice by providing the foundational knowledge needed for diagnosing and treating common diseases in cats and dogs using medical or surgical approaches. Promotes practices that comply with animal welfare professional conduct.
VETM 522.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 523.title: Anesthesiology and Therapeutics
VETM 523.description: Introduction to the principals and practice of veterinary anaesthesiology and therapeutics in production, companion and exotic animals, and the practical application of clinical pharmacology. Focus on local and general anaesthesia for low risk animals and on therapeutic decisions, drug selection, and drug delivery.
VETM 523.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 525.title: Advanced Health Management
VETM 525.description: Provides an overview of diagnosing, managing, and preventing common disorders that occur at a population level. Emphasis is placed upon application of evidence-based medicine to make a herd diagnosis and control, and prevent the problem. Health programs and animal welfare assessment for production and companion animals are explored.
VETM 525.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 530.title: Selected Topics in Clinical Medicine
VETM 530.description: Prepares students for clinical practice by providing the foundational knowledge needed for diagnosing and treating oncologic, ophthalmic and dermatological diseases in production and companion animals.
VETM 530.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 531.title: Sel Topics Small Ruminant, South American Camelid & Non-trad Livestock Prod
VETM 531.description: Selected medical, surgical and reproductive diseases of small ruminants, South American camelids and non-traditional livestock.
VETM 531.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 540.title: Food Animal Medicine and Surgery
VETM 540.description: Prepares students for general food animal practice by providing the foundational knowledge needed for diagnosing, treating and preventing common diseases using medical or surgical approaches. Promotes practices that comply with animal welfare and professional conduct.
VETM 540.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 541.title: Theriogenology
VETM 541.description: Provides knowledge and skills to develop clinical competence in managing the reproductive health of production and companion animals. Students integrate knowledge from various disciplines to diagnose and manage clinical issues pertaining to the reproductive health of animals on an individual animal or herd basis.
VETM 541.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 542.title: Emergency and Critical Care
VETM 542.description: Veterinary emergency and critical care, with emphasis on how to recognize and implement therapy in the unstable patient.
VETM 542.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s):  Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 550.title: Zoological Medicine
VETM 550.description: Provides the foundational knowledge needed for diagnosing, treating and preventing common diseases in non-traditional companion animal and wildlife species.
VETM 550.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 551.title: Laboratory Animal Medicine
VETM 551.description: Provides an introduction to laboratory animal medicine and disease, roles of the laboratory animal veterinarian and animal care committees, and the involvement of animals in research and teaching.
VETM 551.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 571.title: Veterinary Diagnostics and Therapeutics
VETM 571.description: Required for entering general veterinary practice. Students must successfully complete rotations in laboratory diagnostics, pathology, diagnostic imaging and other disciplines.
VETM 571.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 581.title: General Veterinary Practice
VETM 581.description: Required for entering general veterinary practice. Students must successfully complete clinical rotations in general veterinary practice at sites located within the Distributed Veterinary Teaching Hospital.
VETM 581.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine Program.

VETM 591.title: Clinical Enrichment
VETM 591.description: Students choose elective rotations from a range of practicum experiences in veterinary medicine in order to expand or deepen their knowledge and skills.
VETM 591.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VETM 601.title: Professional Skills in Health Science Research
VETM 601.description: Includes a series of workshops focusing on skills essential for success in health science research. Topics include: Research Integrity; Ethics; Grants and Grant Writing; Verbal and Written Communication of Research Findings; Career Development; and Career Options in the Health Sciences.
VETM 601.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Faculty.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

VETM 602.title: Wildlife Health and Disease Ecology
VETM 602.description:
Ecological, epidemiological, and evolutionary principles needed to understand the determinants of health and diseases on wildlife populations, and their link to global changes, agriculture, public health, and conservation. Fundamental concepts in epidemiology and disease ecology will be presented as well as contemporary emerging issues in disease ecology. Using `case studies', lectures, discussions, examples, and activities, material will cover the etiology, pathology, and impact of a wide variety of wildlife diseases. The course will also cover the principles underlying a shift from disease-centered to health-centered approaches, and concepts of wildlife health ecology and management will be explored.

Notes: This course is suitable for any graduate student with an undergraduate degree in biology or veterinary sciences.

Also known as: (formerly Veterinary Medicine 690.44 Wildlife Health and Disease Ecology)

VETM 604.title: Experiential Learning in Wildlife Health Ecology
VETM 604.description: Experiential learning or research experience tailored to the unique goals or career path of the student. Involvement with the Distributed Wildlife Learning Community (DWLC) to broaden, extend, and deepen learning by integrating wildlife health ecology theory with practical application of knowledge.
VETM 604.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master's program in Veterinary Medical Sciences with a Specialization in Wildlife Health and Ecology.

VETM 605.title: (MDCH605)Intro Biostat Methods
VETM 605.description: Analysis and design of research related to biological sciences. Emphasis is placed upon formulating good research questions, evaluating the appropriateness of different statistical methods for analyzing results, and performing and interpreting such statistical analyses. Statistical analyses will be carried out using modern statistical software.
VETM 605.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Cumming School of Medicine.

Also known as: (Veterinary Medicine 605)

VETM 606.title: Seminar in Wildlife Health and Ecology I
VETM 606.description: Exposure to a variety of Wildlife Health Ecology (WHE) research topics, projects, and activities. Students will develop their presentation skills by presenting on their research and expanding their critical thinking through discussions of WHE topics presented at seminars or research meetings.
VETM 606.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Master's program in Veterinary Medical Sciences with a Specialization in Wildlife Health and Ecology.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

VETM 607.title: Seminar in Wildlife Health and Ecology II
VETM 607.description: Exposure to a variety of Wildlife Health Ecology (WHE) research topics, projects, and activities. Students will develop their presentation skills by presenting on their research and expanding their critical thinking through discussions of WHE topics presented at seminars or research meetings.
VETM 607.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Veterinary Medicine 606 and admission to the Master's program in Veterinary Medical Sciences with a Specialization in Wildlife Health and Ecology.

VETM 610.title: (MDCH610)Biostatistics I: Essentials of Biostatistics
VETM 610.description: Introduces the fundamental concepts of summarizing data and statistical inference, including graphical displays, hypothesis testing, p-values, and confidence intervals. Specific topics include comparisons of means and proportions, non-parametric tests, correlation and regression, confounding, sample size determination, and power calculations. Additional topics include a brief introduction to analysis of variance and covariance, logistic regression, and analysis of time-to-event data. Students gain hands-on experience analysing data using STATA statistical software. Although this course uses STATA exclusively, much of the technical knowledge and some of the computing techniques are applicable to any statistical package.
VETM 610.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Veterinary Medical Sciences graduate program.

Also known as: (Community Health Sciences 610)

VETM 611.title: (MDCH611)Biostatistics II: Models for Health Outcomes
VETM 611.description: Extends the fundamental concepts to modelling health outcomes using modern regression analysis techniques. Logistic and linear regressions, and their extensions, are covered in detail. The rationale, formulation, and statistical assumptions underlying each regression technique are discussed. Methods for selecting and assessing models are included. Additional topics include a brief introduction to models used in the analysis of repeated measures, longitudinal studies, and time-to-event data.
VETM 611.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Veterinary Medical Sciences 610.

Also known as: (Community Health Sciences 611)

VETM 612.title: Animal Health Policy
VETM 612.description: Develop student's ability to apply principles of quantitative analysis and policy to guided analysis of production animal health policy as well as development of a research project proposal in animal health policy. The proposal will include: formulation of hypothesis and testable policy research questions; consideration of policy research methods; basic experimental design incorporating appropriate (e.g., epidemiology, economic) analysis; and outline for policy analysis of results.
VETM 612.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units in statistics, epidemiology, or related subject, and consent of the instructor.

Also known as: (formerly Veterinary Medicine 690.03 Animal Health Policy)

VETM 640.title: (MDCH640)Fundamentals of Epidemiology
VETM 640.description: Principles and methods of descriptive and analytic epidemiology. Emphasizes the underlying concepts and approaches of epidemiological research and critical appraisal of epidemiologic studies including: observational study designs and their vulnerabilities to bias, measures of frequency and association, basic methods for addressing sampling variability, confounding, and effect modification. Concepts related to causal judgment in epidemiology are also introduced.
VETM 640.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Veterinary Medical Sciences graduate program or consent of the Faculty.

VETM 650.title: Advanced Virology
VETM 650.description: A series of lectures and discussions about current topics in virology. The lectures will be delivered by researchers working on aspects of molecular virology, virus-host interactions, and clinical virology, both from the veterinary and human field. One theme will be discussed during each session and students are expected to prepare presentations about virological topics and participate in the critical evaluation of journal articles.

VETM 651.title: Molecular Epidemiology and Evolution
VETM 651.description: Introduction to the evaluation of sequence data of bacteria, parasites, and viruses. Students will obtain background knowledge on the evolution of pathogens, the generation of sequence data, the evaluation of this data and directions for further study in this field. The course is a combination of lectures/workshops, self-study exercises, computer practices, and critical evaluation of research papers.

VETM 690.title: Directed Study
VETM 690.description: Lectures, seminars, term papers and/or other training directed to one or only a few students in theoretical and/or laboratory methods at the advanced level in veterinary medical sciences. These courses are offered when no other suitable alternatives are available.

VETM 701.title: Advanced Topics in Reproductive Health
VETM 701.description: A series of topics, ranging from basic sciences to clinical topics (including ethical issues) to increase awareness and comprehension regarding current issues in reproductive health.
VETM 701.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Consent of course co-ordinator and student's supervisor, if applicable.

VETM 702.title: Advanced Topics in Stem Cell Biology and Regenerative Medicine
VETM 702.description: Provides a comprehensive overview of stem cell biology in the context of embryonic development and adult tissue maintenance. Students will gain an appreciation for embryonic versus adult stem cells and how these pluripotent or multipotent cells may be utilized in regenerative medicine (i.e. treatment of congenital defects, diseases or injury).
VETM 702.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the VMS graduate program or consent of the instructor.

VETM 704.title: Experiential Learning in Veterinary Medical Sciences
VETM 704.description: Experiential learning or research experience tailored to the unique goals or career path of the student. Involvement with the Distributed Wildlife Learning Community (DWLC) to broaden, extend, and deepen learning by integrating wildlife health ecology theory with practical application of knowledge.
VETM 704.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctoral program in Veterinary Medical Sciences with a Specialization in Wildlife Health and Ecology.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

VETM 706.title: Seminar in Wildlife Health and Ecology III
VETM 706.description: Exposure to a variety of Wildlife Health Ecology (WHE) research topics, projects, and activities. Students will develop their presentation skills by presenting on their research and expanding their critical thinking through discussions of WHE topics presented at seminars or research meetings.
VETM 706.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctoral program in Veterinary Medical Sciences with a Specialization in Wildlife Health and Ecology.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

VETM 707.title: Seminar in Wildlife Health and Ecology IV
VETM 707.description: Exposure to a variety of Wildlife Health Ecology (WHE) research topics, projects, and activities. Students will develop their presentation skills by presenting on their research and expanding their critical thinking through discussions of WHE topics presented at seminars or research meetings.
VETM 707.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Veterinary Medicine 706 and admission to the Doctoral program in Veterinary Medical Sciences with a Specialization in Wildlife Health and Ecology.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

VETM 721.title: Wildlife Parasitology: Principles and Techniques
VETM 721.description: Students will learn about the ecology of parasites in wildlife populations with emphasis on impacts of parasitism, invasive species, and conservation issues. This is taught through a series of seminars, critical evaluation and discussion of the literature, and independent and group projects. Laboratory sessions include on parasitology techniques for surveillance and research.

VETM 740.title: (MDCH740)Advanced Epidemiology
VETM 740.description: An expansion on the understanding of causality and threats to validity in epidemiologic research. The focus will be on the assessment and control of bias, including selection, information and confounding. The concept of effect modification (interaction) will be appraised. Stratified analysis will be considered as a tool for the assessment and control of confounding and effect modification and will be applied to a variety of study designs including case-control, and cohort studies.
VETM 740.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Veterinary Medical Sciences 640 or consent of the Faculty.

Also known as: (Community Health Sciences 740)

VTMD 200.title: Introduction to Veterinary Medicine
VTMD 200.description: An introduction to the veterinary medicine program. A primer for the safe handling of multispecies animals and a basic overview of the breadth of the veterinary profession.
VTMD 200.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program. 

Note: Offered during Block Week

VTMD 202.title: Professional Identity Formation I
VTMD 202.description: Explores the basic skills fundamental to a successful career in veterinary medicine. Topics will include leadership of self, working effectively in teams, ethics, role of research in veterinary medicine, veterinary informatics, new technology, introduction to financial concepts, and professional communication
VTMD 202.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VTMD 204.title: Exploring Veterinary Medicine I
VTMD 204.description: Introduces key skills and knowledge including basic surgical principles, biosecurity, husbandry, normal animal behaviour, and general animal handling and restraint.
VTMD 204.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program. 

Note: Portions may be taught off-site at Olds College in collaboration with the AHT program.   

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

VTMD 206.title: Healthy Animals I
VTMD 206.description: The basics of nomenclature, anatomy, physiology, clinical skills, clinical presentations, and diagnostic imaging for normal, healthy animals. Modules cover integument, musculoskeletal, neurology, respiratory, cardiovascular, and lymphatic systems.
VTMD 206.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VTMD 211.title: Practical Work Experience I
VTMD 211.description: Students spend a week in a veterinary work setting allowing students to dive deeper into regulatory and industry, research, clinical practice, or food production.
VTMD 211.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program. 

Note: Offered during Block Week

VTMD 213.title: Animals As Populations
VTMD 213.description: More basic universal skills that are fundamental to success as a veterinarian. Covers nutrition, foundations of population health, epidemiology, and the basics of health management.
VTMD 213.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VTMD 215.title: What Is A Veterinarian
VTMD 215.description: An exploration of what it means to be a veterinarian. The scope of practice, the value of the profession, and a veterinarian's role in contributing to the health and well-being of society, including One Health and animal welfare.
VTMD 215.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VTMD 217.title: Healthy Animals II
VTMD 217.description: The nomenclature, anatomy, physiology, clinical skills, clinical presentations, and diagnostic imaging for normal, healthy animals. Modules cover the head, oral cavity, gastrointestinal system, endocrine system, urinary system, reproductive system, fetal, special senses, and alternative species.
VTMD 217.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

VTMD 302.title: Professional Identity Formation II
VTMD 302.description: Expands on communication skills and explores wellness concepts, including conflict management, resolution, and leadership skills. It also integrates interprofessional learning, including the integration into a team of health professionals and collaborative problem-solving.
VTMD 302.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program and Veterinary Medicine 202. 

Note: May include off site learning.

VTMD 304.title: Science of What Goes Wrong I
VTMD 304.description: Pathologic basis of disease, pharmacology, toxicology, and oncology. An introduction to the basic disease mechanisms, basics of pharmaco/ toxico-kinetics, basic mechanisms of action of pharmaceuticals, and the derangement of homeostasis.
VTMD 304.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program and Veterinary Medicine 206 and 217.

VTMD 306.title: Science of What Goes Wrong II
VTMD 306.description: Basic systemic pathology, bacteriology, virology, parasitology, and mycology. Organ reactions to infection, basic organ dysfunction, basics of host-pathogen interactions, and mechanisms of disease spread.
VTMD 306.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program and Veterinary Medicine 206 and 217.

VTMD 308.title: Fundamentals of Diagnosis, Management and Treatment
VTMD 308.description: Integrates relevant physiology, anatomy, pharmacology, anesthesiology, clinical pathology, anatomic pathology, and analgesia to explore reasons and methods for collecting and recording diagnostic information. Basic tenets of population management and individual treatment plans.
VTMD 308.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program and Veterinary Medicine 206 and 217.

VTMD 311.title: Practical Work Experience II
VTMD 311.description: Students spend a week in a veterinary work setting allowing a deeper dive into regulatory and industry, research, clinical practice, or food production.
VTMD 311.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program and completion of 30 units of Veterinary Medicine at the 200 level.
 
Note: Offered during Block Week  may include off site locations.

VTMD 313.title: Veterinarians in Society
VTMD 313.description: An exploration of the veterinarian's role within the community and contribution to society. Includes the study of scientific communication, context-specific communication strategies, concepts of One Health, cultural humility, and Indigenous ways of knowing in the context of animal care and use.
VTMD 313.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program and Veterinary Medicine 302.

VTMD 315.title: Head, Oral, and Gastrointestinal
VTMD 315.description: Integrates anatomy, physiology, pharmacology, pathology of specific diseases, diagnostic imaging, surgery, medicine, immunology, analgesia, anesthesia, and epidemiology to explore pathologic alterations and the diagnosis and treatment of conditions related to the head, oral cavity, and gastrointestinal tract of sick animals.
VTMD 315.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program and Veterinary Medicine 304 and 306.

VTMD 317.title: Endocrine, Renal, and Reproduction
VTMD 317.description: Integrates anatomy, physiology, pharmacology, pathology of specific diseases (clinical and systemic), diagnostic imaging, surgery, medicine, immunology, analgesia, anesthesia, and epidemiology to explore pathologic alterations and the diagnosis and treatment of conditions related to the endocrine system, urinary system, reproductive system of sick animals..
VTMD 317.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program and Veterinary Medicine 304 and 306.

VTMD 319.title: Neonatal, Special Senses, Alternative Species
VTMD 319.description: Integrates anatomy, physiology, pharmacology, pathology of specific diseases (clinical and systemic), diagnostic imaging, surgery, medicine, immunology, analgesia, anesthesia, and epidemiology to explore pathologic alterations and the diagnosis and treatment of conditions related to neonatal concerns, special senses and concerns of alternative species.
VTMD 319.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program and Veterinary Medicine 304 and 306.

VTMD 401.title: Group Problem-Solving
VTMD 401.description: Students work in small groups to solve clinical cases based on a presenting complaint. In addition to honing their clinical reasoning skills, students will also participate in laboratories to improve communication skills. Student groups will also be responsible for presenting cases to Year 1 students.
VTMD 401.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program and Veterinary Medicine 420, 422, 424.

VTMD 403.title: Introduction to Clinical Rotations
VTMD 403.description: Bridges the school experience and the clinical experience. Students participate in faculty-led clinical rotations in diagnostic, small, and large animal facilities. Topics one week each: Fundamentals in medicine, Fundamentals in Surgery, Fundamentals in Anatomic Pathology, Fundamentals in Clinical Pathology, Fundamentals in diagnostic imaging, Fundamentals in anesthesia, Fundamentals in preventative and population medicine, Fundamentals in Diagnostic Imaging.
VTMD 403.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program and Veterinary Medicine 420, 422, 424.

VTMD 409.title: Topics in Veterinary Medicine
VTMD 409.description: An opportunity to explore veterinary medicine topics of interest in more detail. Topics available will vary from year-to-year.
VTMD 409.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program and Veterinary Medicine 420, 422, 424. 

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

VTMD 420.title: Integument and Musculoskeletal
VTMD 420.description: Integrates anatomy, physiology, pharmacology, pathology of specific diseases (clinical and systemic), diagnostic imaging, surgery, medicine, immunology, analgesia, anesthesia, and epidemiology to explore pathologic alterations and the diagnosis and treatment of conditions related to the integumentary and musculoskeletal systems of sick animals.
VTMD 420.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program and Veterinary Medicine 304 and 306.

VTMD 422.title: Neurology and Respiratory
VTMD 422.description: Integrates anatomy, physiology, pharmacology, pathology of specific diseases (clinical and systemic), diagnostic imaging, surgery, medicine, immunology, analgesia, anesthesia, and epidemiology to explore pathologic alterations and the diagnosis and treatment of conditions related to the neurology and respiratory systems of sick animals.
VTMD 422.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program and Veterinary Medicine 304 and 306.

VTMD 424.title: Cardiovascular and Lymphatic
VTMD 424.description: Integrates anatomy, physiology, pharmacology, pathology of specific diseases (clinical and systemic), diagnostic imaging, surgery, medicine, immunology, analgesia, anesthesia, and epidemiology to explore pathologic alterations and the diagnosis and treatment of conditions related to the cardiovascular and lymphatic systems of sick animals.
VTMD 424.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program and Veterinary Medicine 304 and 306.

VTMD 430.title: Introduction to Surgery, Anesthesia, and Hospitalized Case Management
VTMD 430.description: Begins with relevant anesthesia and surgery lectures and then allows students to take primary case responsibility for basic surgical sterilization procedures in healthy small animals. Covers admission of the patient through to assessment, surgical, anesthetic, analgesic, and post-operative care and discharge back to the guardian of the animal. Develop accurate and acceptable medical records and practice functioning as part of an integrated medical team.
VTMD 430.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program and Veterinary Medicine 304 and 306. 

Note: May occur in a laboratory setting or as a specific rotation at the UCVM Small Animal Clinic.

VTMD 500.title: Veterinary Practicum Rotations I
VTMD 500.description: Rotations are delivered on site at UCVM as well as at off-site locations. Rotations include General Veterinary Practice, Specialty Veterinary practice, and elective opportunities encompassing a range of practicum experiences in veterinary medicine in order to expand or deepen their knowledge and skills towards their chosen career path.
VTMD 500.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program and completion of 30 units of Veterinary Medicine at the 400 level.

VTMD 505.title: Veterinary Practicum Rotations
VTMD 505.description: Rotations are delivered on site at UCVM as well as at off-site locations. Rotations include General Veterinary Practice, Specialty Veterinary practice, and elective opportunities encompassing a range of practicum experiences in veterinary medicine in order to expand or deepen their knowledge and skills towards their chosen career path.
VTMD 505.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program and completion of 30 units of Veterinary Medicine at the 200 level.

VTMD 510.title: Fall Veterinary Practicum Rotations
VTMD 510.description: Rotations are delivered on site at UCVM as well as at off-site locations. Rotations include General Veterinary Practice, Specialty Veterinary practice, and elective opportunities encompassing a range of practicum experiences in veterinary medicine in order to expand or deepen their knowledge and skills towards their chosen career path.
VTMD 510.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program and completion of 30 units of Veterinary Medicine at the 200 level.

VTMD 515.title: Winter Veterinary Practicum Rotations
VTMD 515.description: Rotations are delivered on site at UCVM as well as at off-site locations. Rotations include General Veterinary Practice, Specialty Veterinary practice, and elective opportunities encompassing a range of practicum experiences in veterinary medicine in order to expand or deepen their knowledge and skills towards their chosen career path.
VTMD 515.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program and completion of 30 units of Veterinary Medicine at the 200 level.

WELL 300.title: Challenges of Intersectionality in Mental Wellbeing
WELL 300.description: Evaluation of cultural, structural, systemic, and/or socioeconomic issues related to positive mental health and wellbeing in today's society, through an intersectional lens that may include an analysis of ethnicity, culture, race, socioeconomic status, age, ability/disability, gender, sexuality, and other factors. Focus on developing students' abilities to foster mental wellbeing in others.
WELL 300.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Psychology 203 and admission to the Embedded Certificate in Mental Health and Wellbeing.

WELL 400.title: Capstone in Mental Wellbeing
WELL 400.description: Reflection and integration of experiential learning to engage in applied problem solving. Focus on helping students to become agents of change, fostering mental wellbeing in the community.
WELL 400.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Wellbeing 300 and completion of 45 units.

ZOOL 401.title: An Introduction to Invertebrate Zoology
ZOOL 401.description: Natural history and diversity of invertebrates, which include sponges, corals, jellyfish, snails, octopus, insects, crustaceans, sea stars, and various worms. Emphasis on how free-living and parasitic organisms feed, move, reproduce, and survive in marine, freshwater, and terrestrial habitats.
ZOOL 401.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Biology 371.

Also known as: (formerly Zoology 375)

ZOOL 403.title: An Introduction to Vertebrate Zoology
ZOOL 403.description: Systematics, natural history and biology of vertebrates, including fishes, amphibians, reptiles, birds and mammals. Laboratory work will emphasize the identification and morphology of native taxa as well as basic techniques of biological systematics.

ZOOL 461.title: Animal Physiology I
ZOOL 461.description: Study of control mechanisms in nerves, sensory organs, muscles and endocrine glands.

ZOOL 463.title: Animal Physiology II
ZOOL 463.description: Study of body fluids and hemostasis, body defence systems, reproductive physiology, respiration, circulation, excretion, gastrointestinal physiology and thermoregulation.

ZOOL 515.title: Comparative Vertebrate Anatomy
ZOOL 515.description: The structural, functional, developmental and evolutionary relationships of the organs and systems of the vertebrates. Laboratory work will emphasize the dissection, identification and homologies of structures in various vertebrates.

ZOOL 528.title: Research Project in Zoology
ZOOL 528.description: Research project under the co/supervision of faculty members in the Department of Biological Sciences. Original and independent thought, practical research, and written and oral reports presented on completion of this course.
ZOOL 528.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biology 315, 72 units and consent of the Department.

ZOOL 530.title: Honours Research Project in Zoology
ZOOL 530.description: Research project under the co/supervision of faculty members in the Department of Biological Sciences. Original and independent thought, practical research, and written and oral reports presented on completion of this course. Open only to Honours Zoology students or Honours Biological Sciences students.
ZOOL 530.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biology 315, 72 units and consent of the Department.

ZOOL 535.title: Entomology
ZOOL 535.description: Introduction to the insects, with emphasis on diversity, evolution, structure/function relationships, behaviour, and ecology.
ZOOL 535.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Zoology 401, 403, or 461.

(formerly Zoology 435)

ZOOL 567.title: Animal Behaviour
ZOOL 567.description: Offered from an evolutionary and ecological perspective. Development of ethological ideas; interaction of genotype and environment in ontogeny of behaviour; role of behaviour in dealing with environmental challenges.
ZOOL 567.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biology 311, 313 and 371; and one of Ecology 429, Cellular, Molecular and Microbial Biology 403, Zoology 401, 403, 435 or 461.

ZOOL 571.title: Palaeobiology of Vertebrates
ZOOL 571.description: Evolutionary trends in the major groups of vertebrates from both neontological and palaeontological viewpoints. The interpretation of palaeontological data and their applicability to our understanding of evolution, systematics and palaeoecology.

ZOOL 576.title: The Invertebrates
ZOOL 576.description: Collaborative research experience in invertebrate zoology, with emphasis on discovering, describing, and classifying diversity using zoological collections, systematic theory, and phylogenetic methods.
ZOOL 576.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Zoology 375, 401 or 435.

Also known as: (formerly Zoology 475)

ZOOL 577.title: Mammalogy
ZOOL 577.description: A detailed examination of the evolution, morphology, physiology, ecology and behaviour of mammals.
ZOOL 577.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): Biology 313 and 3 units from Zoology 379, 403 or 477.01 (Birds And Mammals).

ZOOL 581.title: Principles in Parasitism
ZOOL 581.description: How parasites have evolved, their diverse life strategies, their impact on the natural world, study of most parasitic groups (protozoan, helminth and arthropod parasites) and their characteristics, with a focus on the Canadian context.
ZOOL 581.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Cellular, Molecular and Microbial Biology 343, Zoology 375 or 401.

Also known as: (formerly Zoology 483)

ZOOL 595.title: Evolutionary Perspectives in Neurobiology
ZOOL 595.description: Explores form, functionandperformanceofinvertebrateand vertebrate neurons andnervoussystemsthrough examinationofphysical, biochemical, metabolic, (neuro)physiological and behavioral constraintsandtrade-offs.

ZOOL 597.title: Principles of Endocrinology
ZOOL 597.description: General and molecular aspects of endocrine physiology. Topics will include the mechanisms of hormone action (receptor occupancy and transduction of signal), current techniques in endocrinology, synthesis and release of hormones, and the functional role of different endocrine organs. Lectures will include examples from lower vertebrates and invertebrates to emphasize comparative aspects.

ZOOL 599.title: Topics in Zoology
ZOOL 599.description: Exploration of various areas in Zoology. Topics may vary from year-to-year. It will be offered as required to provide the opportunity for students to engage in additional areas in Zoology.
ZOOL 599.prerequisitesText:
Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Faculty.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

ZOOL 697.title: Advanced Topics in Comparative Endocrinology
ZOOL 697.description: The principles of endocrinology will be provided through the lecture component of Zoology 597, and this will be augmented with additional reading, term papers and seminars in comparative endocrinology.

ZOOL 507.01.title: Directed Research in Zoology I
ZOOL 507.01.description: Directed training in field/laboratory methods and research.
ZOOL 507.01.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 54 units and consent of the Department.

ZOOL 507.02.title: Directed Research in Zoology II
ZOOL 507.02.description: Directed training in field/laboratory methods and research.
ZOOL 507.02.prerequisitesText: Prerequisite(s): 54 units and consent of the Department.
